Zhou Ze walked to the morgue freezer, which consisted of layers of pull-out drawers.

The freezers containing bodies had labels on the outside, recording the deceased's name, gender, and other information.

Zhou Ze pulled open an empty freezer, reached inside, closed his eyes, and slowly felt, gradually entering a state of trance, as if only here could he find peace.

After a moment of hesitation, Zhou Ze lay down.

"Creak..."

The freezer slowly slid inward, until it finally closed.

Quiet,

Cold,

Silent,

Zhou Ze slowly closed his eyelids.

Sleepiness washed over him.

He finally found the feeling of sleep,

But he couldn't sleep just yet,

Because he didn't know,

Who had just stood outside and helped him push the freezer in...

---
* The original idiom "小姨子有半片那啥是姐夫的" literally translates to "a sister-in-law has half a 'that' for her brother-in-law." It's a vulgar folk saying implying an intimate or even sexual relationship between a brother-in-law and his sister-in-law, often hinting at impropriety or temptation. It's used here to convey the in-laws' immediate, crude assumption.

title: 第九章 你竟然是這樣子的徐樂！
content:
Zhou Ze began to kick outwards with both feet, trying to get out, but a "click-clack" sound came from outside, meaning the lock on the ice coffin had been fastened.

Locked in, unable to get out.

For a moment, Zhou Ze felt as if he was back in the narrow coffin he'd been placed in.

Only this time, Zhou Ze wasn't frantic or enraged. He just reached up and tapped the metal plate near his head:

"Something wrong?"

Zhou Ze didn't believe someone had come here to push his ice coffin in and then lock it, unless that person was a mentally deranged lunatic, and Zhou Ze didn't think his luck could be that bad.

Besides,

After entering the morgue, he had closed the door. A lunatic who knew the morgue door's password?

Do you believe it?

So, Zhou Ze could only assume that some "thing" had "helped" him, and helped very thoroughly.

However, after that query, the outside remained silent.

Zhou Ze simply gave up, closed his eyes again, and prepared to get some good sleep.

He fell asleep very quickly.

After all, he hadn't closed his eyes for two days, and a lot had happened in those two days, accumulating an incredibly frightening amount of fatigue.

Even if I die and the world floods,
No one can stop me from sleeping now.

…………

He didn't know how long he had slept, but when Zhou Ze opened his eyes, he felt refreshed and invigorated, a long-lost surge of energy, though his body was also frozen stiff.

The stiffness of his body was somewhat terrifying. Zhou Ze tried to wiggle his body a few times in the narrow space, and a series of "crisp sounds" came, so comfortable that he unconsciously made a noise.

At this moment, Zhou Ze's fingernails naturally grew long and black, shimmering with an unusual luster. The stiffness in his body and the cold that would be unbearable for an ordinary person were slowly gathering at his fingertips.

The entire process didn't last long, but it made Zhou Ze no longer feel cold or uncomfortable.

He instinctively kicked again, and the ice coffin slid out naturally.

The lock,
It was unlocked?

Zhou Ze was a bit surprised. He sat up from the steel plate, got out, and then pushed it back in.

His clothes were stiff, hanging on him like cardboard, giving him a very uncomfortable feeling, and Zhou Ze's gaze swept around.

The affiliated hospital's morgue wasn't very large; compared to those in big city hospitals, it even seemed a bit shy, but there were still quite a few bodies stored inside.

Zhou Ze didn't know who had helped him push it in earlier, and trying to find them now was indeed a bit difficult.

Fortunately, since the other party had unlocked the latch while he was asleep, Zhou Ze didn't plan to cause any more trouble here.

He walked towards the morgue door, intending to leave, but as he passed by the beds covered with white sheets, Zhou Ze stopped.

Those bodies covered with white sheets showed no abnormalities,
Including the old woman wrapped in her family's floral quilt, she also seemed unchanged.

But Zhou Ze still stopped,
Because he remembered that this old woman's head and feet were reversed from how they were when she lay down.

It was impossible that the morgue attendant came in while he was sleeping and did nothing else but flip the old woman around.

Zhou Ze stood beside the old woman and said:
"If it's you, and you don't come out now, I'm leaving."

The old woman pushing him in and then locking him up might have been malicious, but her silently unlocking the door for him again meant she wasn't trying to harm him.

Perhaps someone was about to come, and seeing an unlocked dark cabinet might have led to his discovery.

After all, it was very obvious from the outside whether these dark cabinets were locked or not.

He waited for half a minute, with no abnormalities, Zhou Ze decided not to wait anymore.

Just as he was about to turn and leave, a sigh came from behind him.

Zhou Ze found this feeling annoying.
Wavering,
Playing hard to get,
She was an old woman when she died, yet she insisted on acting like a young girl.

Alright, age discrimination is indeed wrong, but normal people's tolerance for beautiful female ghosts is always a bit higher, which is only human nature.

If Nie Xiaoqian had a face full of wrinkles and yellow teeth, do you think Ning Caichen would still have an interspecies romance with her?

Zhou Ze turned around and looked behind him.
An old woman with a head full of silver hair was crouching there, holding a faded handkerchief and wiping away tears.

But ghosts don't have tears, so from Zhou Ze's perspective, the old woman seemed to be wailing dryly.

"Keep crying, I won't disturb you."

Zhou Ze prepared to leave.
He realized he was ultimately a common man, even when looking at ghosts, he was a bit of an aesthetician.

"Help me, I have money," the old woman suddenly spoke.

"Mhm," Zhou Ze responded. He needed money.

That damn Xu Le had less than two hundred yuan combined in his Alipay and WeChat accounts, plus the eleven hundred returned by the "murderer," meaning Zhou Ze's total assets were currently less than thirteen hundred.

And Zhou Ze's previous life's house, savings, and assets should have all been donated to the orphanage, so he was essentially alone.

"My money is in the hidden compartment of my cabinet, an old yellow-lacquered wardrobe, there's thirty thousand yuan, and also my dowry from when I got married, jade hairpins, jade bracelets. I don't know how much they're worth.
I died suddenly, and I hadn't had time to tell my sons, I'm afraid they won't know."

Zhou Ze nodded, "I'll take a portion."

The old woman looked conflicted but still nodded, "That's fair."

The old woman knew that without Zhou Ze, this "anomaly," to relay the message, her sons might never find the wealth she left behind.

………………

After leaving the hospital, Zhou Ze took a taxi directly to a place called "Xingdong Town" in Tongzhou District. It wasn't very far, and Tongcheng's airport was in this town.

Earlier, at the hospital, Zhou Ze had inquired at the registration desk. The old woman had been sent to the hospital and died after resuscitation failed. Her family then simply left her body at the hospital and still owed a sum in medical expenses.

About half an hour later, Zhou Ze arrived in the town and, following the old woman's description, found the village.

It was a self-built two-story house, with a small brick outhouse similar to a rural privy attached to it.

When Zhou Ze arrived, he found several workers dismantling the house, specifically the brick outhouse.

Zhou Ze walked over, offered a worker a cigarette, and asked, "Still busy so close to New Year's?"

"Gotta make more money before New Year's, anyway, we're all from the same village," the bricklayer master said quite openly.

"What's going on with this house?" Zhou Ze asked while looking inside. Two workers were already lifting the roof, and the brick walls of the small house were being dismantled to be reused later. Inside, let alone the yellow-lacquered cabinet the old woman mentioned, there wasn't even a small stool to be seen; it was empty.

"Their old lady died. This house used to be where their old lady lived alone. Now they plan to knock it down and build a new kitchen," the master leaned his head in, let Zhou Ze light his cigarette, and smiled somewhat cautiously, saying, "See, that one who just walked past in front of the house is their eldest son."

Zhou Ze looked over and saw that the man, whose hair was also turning white, still had some bruises on his face.

"There are five brothers, and they got into a fight over the few coins their old lady left behind. When these bricks are taken down later, the other four will also come to divide them.

You say, times have changed, huh? Their old lady's body is still in the hospital and hasn't been claimed yet, and none of the brothers are willing to pay back the owed medical fees."

"What about the old woman's belongings in the house?" Zhou Ze was focused on this. From the old woman's description, the thirty thousand yuan in the cabinet was her life's savings, but those jade bracelets and jade hairpins were the truly valuable items; selling them would likely fetch a few hundred thousand yuan without much trouble.

"Sold to the scrap collector, cleared out long ago. It was sold when the old woman first got hospitalized," the master took another deep drag on his cigarette. "I'm going back to work."

Zhou Ze licked his lips with a wry smile. This trip of his was for nothing.

Not only did he not get a share of what the old woman left behind, but her sons also wouldn't benefit from it, only cheapening it for some old furniture dealer.

Zhou Ze was a bit vexed now. No money was indeed a big problem. He wasn't willing to use his abilities to swindle money, although it seemed easy and satisfying, but saving a girl last night almost killed him from pain. Heaven knows what problems would arise if he continued to mess around.

Whether there were gods three feet above his head, Zhou Ze didn't know.
But digging three feet down continuously, there certainly was hell, because he had been there.

He knew he wasn't human, and this was the human world. Moreover, he vividly remembered how the patient who died in front of him had screamed in terror, "I've been found," before his death.

However,
Money,
Zhou Ze wanted to grind the mill,
But who would give him money?

Zhou Ze needed money now, not to mention getting rid of his "live-in son-in-law" status.
He at least needed to buy himself a freezer or a large refrigerator, right?
Otherwise, he'd have to go to the hospital morgue every day to freeload on the cold air?

Feeling a bit depressed, he lit a cigarette and took a deep drag, feeling very vexed.

Just then, his phone rang in his pocket. Zhou Ze picked it up; it was an unknown number. He answered:

"Hello," Zhou Ze.

"Brother, the goods have been safely delivered. When are you coming to inspect them? The police have been checking very strictly lately. It wasn't easy to get this batch of goods in," the person on the other end of the line said in a low, cautious voice.

Zhou Ze slowly opened his mouth,
Making no sound,
At the same time,
Xu Le's image suddenly began to rise continuously in his mind.

title: 第十章 大佬！
content:
Anxiety, unease, and a touch of secret delight and bewilderment—these were perhaps Zhou Ze's feelings on his taxi ride to the outskirts of Tongcheng.

He was short on money, very short, but he didn't need a huge sum. A large amount wouldn't be very useful to him, at least not for the time being.

Because of his resurrection, the entanglements of his past life, and the troubles of his current one, he needed money to resolve things, and then, he would plan for the long term, not squander it or indulge in a life of excess.

For instance, leaving the Lin family. Although Lin Wanqiu was beautiful and elegant, he was simply too lazy to return to that house. They hadn't had any intimacy, and he hadn't truly enjoyed himself. It seemed Xu Le hadn't truly enjoyed himself either, so there was no sense of obligation.

Therefore, saying "goodbye" came with no psychological burden.

But leaving that house meant making some preparations. He needed a place to stay and a good quality freezer. Zhou Ze didn't dare to buy a used, discarded freezer from a second-hand market. What if something went wrong and he ended up dying while sleeping in it? Wouldn't that be a huge loss?

Money!

Even as a ghost, he needed money.

But listening to the person who called Xu Le just now made Zhou Ze feel somewhat uneasy. Xu Le, in his identity as a modern urban live-in son-in-law, so spineless at home, letting his in-laws walk all over him, and sleeping in a separate bed from his wife, turned out to be a hidden gang boss?

Well, this kind of conflicting image was really stimulating and quite fitting for an American drama: extraordinary characters always have very ordinary real-life identities.

Like Spider-Man being a middle school student, or Superman being a reporter for a newspaper.

So, how should he handle this situation?

How to deal with those people?

Zhou Ze didn't want his current identity to be "tainted," because that would mean endless trouble. In the real world, the police's investigation of him was already something Xu Le couldn't easily handle, not to mention the "they will find and catch you" mentioned by the old man and the faceless woman.

Feeling a bit of a headache and some discomfort, Zhou Ze still arrived at the abandoned small chemical fertilizer factory.

Two people were squatting at the entrance of the fertilizer factory: one wearing a somewhat worn military overcoat, the other a cheap, poor-quality suit.

Both of them were squatting there, a cigarette in their mouths, puffing away.

Zhou Ze paid the fare, got out of the car, and the two immediately stood up and walked towards him.

"Our boss is waiting for you," the man in the military overcoat said gravely.

Zhou Ze nodded and followed the military overcoat inside. The man in the suit continued to squat there, smoking, as if keeping watch.

Upon entering, Zhou Ze saw a bald, stout man wearing a gold chain, sitting on a plastic chair, pouring and drinking for himself. Seeing Zhou Ze approach, the stout man immediately stood up,

"Brother Xu, you've finally arrived."

The stout man was tall, about 1.85 meters. His gold chain was very thick, looking very flashy, and the gold powder rubbed off on his neck by the chain was even more ostentatious.

"Where's the goods?"

Zhou Ze clasped his hands behind his back, fingers slightly intertwined. There were only three people here. Taking them down wouldn't be a big problem, but what then? Handing them over to the police would surely expose him too, wouldn't it?

Should he deal with them himself, like a vigilante? "In the name of the Moon, I will punish you!"? That didn't seem right either. With his sensitive identity, if he casually killed people, it might have the same backlash as casually saving people. He was unwilling to try it lightly.

"Brother Xu is as straightforward as ever!"

The stout man wiped his mouth and then clapped Zhou Ze on the shoulder.

Zhou Ze's mouth twitched. He took a deep breath, forcing himself not to slap away the stout man's greasy, fat hand.

"Come, over here!"

The stout man made an inviting gesture, leading Zhou Ze to a small storage room in the back yard.

Upon entering,

Zhou Ze's pupils suddenly contracted,

A small mountain of goods, covered with black tarpaulins.

Zhou Ze had never done anything illegal before, but he knew that so much *goods*, if judged by law, would be enough for him to be shot hundreds of times over. He could eat so many peanuts* he'd get a stomachache.

"It's not just Tongcheng, is it?" Zhou Ze actually wanted to ask, 'Did you just rob a warlord from the Golden Triangle?'

"Brother Xu, of course. Tongcheng is too small. This batch of goods will eventually use Tongcheng as a springboard to flow into Shanghai." The stout man stretched lazily. "This time, let's hurry and get these goods moving. We can make a fortune."

Zhou Ze reached up and rubbed his forehead, saying with difficulty, "It'll be hard to get rid of them in a short time, won't it?"

After all, it wasn't like selling cabbage, where you ride a tricycle with a loudspeaker and shout.

"Don't worry, Brother Xu. We just need to distribute this batch of goods to the people below. While the profit isn't as high as selling them ourselves, it's fast and guaranteed to move. After this batch is done, we'll get another one," the stout man said dismissively.

Xu Le, oh Xu Le, you've even built a drug trafficking network. You're truly amazing...

Such a big boss, yet he was beaten to death by that idiot for three hundred yuan!

"Brother Xu, come take a look at the quality of this batch of goods."

The stout man said, lifting the tarpaulin,

And then Zhou Ze's face showed surprise,

Because what he saw wasn't a mountain of drugs, but stacks of books and CDs.

Could they be hidden in the books?

"Brother Xu, thanks to your classmate, getting this batch of goods was easy. These CDs are popular movies still showing in theaters. I even deliberately copied in some ************ for good measure. These pirated books and romance novels are also bestsellers on the market.

And Brother Xu, you specially wrote the extended twenty-part, two-million-word sequel to Bai Jie. Many of our sub-distributors pre-ordered this one, so there's no problem selling them."

"The 'goods' you're talking about are these?" Zhou Ze asked the stout man.

"Yeah?" The stout man paused. "Just these."

Disappointment,

Great disappointment,

Extreme disappointment,

And at the same time, a sense of shame,

Xu Le was still Xu Le after all. To boost the sales of these pirated items, he actually continued the story of Bai Jie himself.

And he wrote a two-million-word sequel.

How much free time did he have...?

"How much can I pull out?" Zhou Ze asked. "I'm thinking of quitting."

In a business partnership, there should be capital investment.

"What? Brother Xu, you're thinking of quitting?" The stout man seemed surprised. "We're just about to make money, and you want to quit now?"

"Yes, this matter doesn't align with my core values. I don't want to do it anymore."

Zhou Ze said very seriously. He didn't want to take any risks, especially before sorting out his current life. He didn't want to get involved in any potential vortex.

"..." the stout man.

"..." the military overcoat.

"Brother Xu, your awareness is high, I admire that. In the early stages, Brother Xu, you invested..."

The stout man held up four fingers, saying, "Twenty thousand yuan."

"Twenty thousand it is then. Give me the money, and the rest has nothing to do with me." Zhou Ze couldn't be bothered to quibble over it anymore. Twenty thousand yuan would solve his immediate urgent needs.

"Alright, I have twenty thousand yuan here." The stout man nodded and went to get the money.

About fifteen minutes later, Zhou Ze, with twenty thousand yuan in his pocket, hailed a ride-sharing car and started heading back to the city.

He didn't rush back to the bookstore first but went to an appliance market. He spent over ten thousand yuan on a freezer. This type of freezer was usually used by businesses to store food and meat products, and it was one of the higher-end models. Zhou Ze didn't hesitate to spend the money, after all, he would be relying on it to sleep in the future, and he was afraid of problems with cheaper ones.

The seller was very enthusiastic and sent a small truck to deliver the freezer directly to... the bookstore entrance.

The driver and Zhou Ze carried the freezer into the bookstore, and the driver looked a bit surprised.

"Boss, you run a bookstore, do you really need a freezer?" the driver asked.

Zhou Ze offered him a cigarette. "Business is tough, so I'm planning to sell some seafood on the side."

The driver took the cigarette and left. His job was done, and he didn't need to worry about anything else.

The bookstore had a small second floor, which Xu Le originally used to store books. After Zhou Ze cleared it out, he placed the freezer up there. Looking at his "new bed," Zhou Ze finally felt much more at ease.

Coming down from the second floor, Zhou Ze noticed someone in his bookstore. It wasn't a customer; it was his "wife."

Doctor Lin was flipping through a magazine. Seeing Zhou Ze come down, she asked, somewhat puzzled, "What were you busy with up there?"

"Organizing goods," Zhou Ze answered perfunctorily.

"I'm off work," Doctor Lin said.

"Hmm." *You're off work, but you're not sleeping with me...*

"That girl woke up." Doctor Lin looked pointedly at Zhou Ze. "Her father wants to treat our department to dinner at the Tongcheng Grand Hotel. You should come too."

"What would I do there?"

"The girl kept calling for 'Uncle' after she woke up." Doctor Lin asked Zhou Ze, a little curious, "Did you know her before?"

"Even when people are in a coma, they still have some perception, right?" Zhou Ze continued to make things up. "When I saved her, she might have actually been able to feel it."

"Are you coming?" Doctor Lin asked.

"No, I'm not going," Zhou Ze shook his head. "I'm not hungry, I have no appetite at all."

Doctor Lin nodded, not pressing the issue further. She seemed ready to leave, but at the bookstore entrance, she stopped again. "Are you coming home tonight?"

The familiar old question returned,

*If I come home, you still won't sleep with me...*

So, Zhou Ze answered very decisively:

"No, I won't be back. I'm a bit busy lately."

*Hmm, even though the store's business has already turned as cold as an iced latte.*

Doctor Lin hesitated for a moment, then didn't press, taking her car keys out of her pocket, ready to leave.

Just then,

With a "clatter,"

Doctor Lin turned around and saw her "husband" collapsed onto a bookshelf, with books scattered all over the floor.

"What's wrong with you?" Doctor Lin immediately rushed over to check on Zhou Ze.

Zhou Ze felt his vision blurring, his sight unable to focus. His chest heaved, and his legs suddenly felt weak, as if he had stepped on cotton, completely losing his balance:

"Fainted from hunger..."

Zhou Ze replied.

He,

Hadn't eaten for several days.

---

Five days after the book was released, it's ranked second on the overall new book list for the same period!

In the Supernatural category, excluding the monthly pass list (since we're not yet on the shelves for monthly passes), we're number one on all other lists!

Yesterday, we were #2 in daily sales on Qidian! Today, #11 in daily sales on Qidian!

As a new book with thirty thousand words not yet on shelves, Long just wants to say,

Brothers,

Awesome!

---
* *Peanuts*: In Chinese slang, "eating peanuts" (吃花生米) is a euphemism for being executed by firing squad, as the bullets are small like peanuts.

title: 第十一章 畫皮
content:
Next to the bookstore was a noodle shop. Its business was quite average, almost as deserted as Zhou Ze’s bookstore.

This pedestrian street was originally built around a plaza, but the plaza itself was now "abandoned." Besides a cinema, all other businesses inside had moved out or closed, making the entire plaza a "deserted" and "uninhabited" area.

At least in Tongcheng, the symptoms of urban overdevelopment were evident. In previous years, commercial centers were heavily planned and built, but Tongcheng was not Shanghai and couldn't attract such a large population.

Fortunately, the noodle shop could still do delivery business, and it seemed to be doing well. However, no one would suddenly feel "hungry" for knowledge and order books for delivery.

Zhou Ze leaned back in his chair, still feeling a bit dizzy. Doctor Lin sat opposite him, meticulously wiping his chopsticks with her own tissue before placing them in front of him.

She was very careful and considerate, just as she let Xu Le sleep on the bed while she slept on the floor. Yet, she was also very cold.

Zhou Ze didn't ask her if she genuinely opposed feudal arranged marriages or if she was a lesbian, because the question was pointless. Zhou Ze himself wasn't interested in the inexplicable social network Xu Le left behind, nor did he feel any attachment to it.

"Is your body really okay?" Doctor Lin asked again.

"Small problem, small problem." Zhou Ze was a doctor himself; he knew his eating and sleeping issues were difficult to explain with modern medical theories, let alone treat.

Fortunately, the sleeping problem was resolved, but this eating… it was a headache.

Not eating had caused him to faint earlier, but the thought of eating… made him nauseous.

"You don't have a good appetite. How about a bowl of sour plum juice first?" The noodle shop owner was around thirty, but his face already showed some wrinkles. The burdens of life seemed quite heavy.

"Sour plum juice, will it help?" Zhou Ze asked helplessly.

"It stimulates the appetite," the noodle shop owner smiled, then shouted towards the back room, "Wife, is the pickled vegetable noodle ready?"

The owner went into the back room, and the voices of the couple talking could be heard from there.

Zhou Ze looked at the sour plum juice in front of him, took a spoon, scooped a mouthful, and put it in his mouth. As soon as he swallowed, Zhou Ze's face changed.

"What's wrong?" Doctor Lin pulled out a tissue and held it near Zhou Ze's chin.

Zhou Ze, his face contorted, clutched his stomach, then took a deep breath and said:

"So sour."

Yes, so sour that his whole body felt like it was cramping, even overshadowing the nausea.

"Coming, the noodles are ready!" The proprietress brought the noodles over, placed them in front of Zhou Ze, and said, "You can't drink my family's sour plum juice so fast."

Doctor Lin looked at the noodles and frowned slightly, "These noodles are too overcooked."

She meant they were cooked for too long, losing their chewiness and greatly affecting the taste.

"This… our noodles are just like this," the proprietress said, looking a bit apologetic.

"It's fine, it's fine."

Zhou Ze waved his hand. Chewy or not, it didn't matter to him right now. As long as he could eat it, that was enough. He needed energy. If he couldn't eat anymore, Zhou Ze would have no choice but to go to the hospital for a glucose IV.

He solemnly raised his head, feeling as dignified and solemn as a sworn warrior, then abruptly lowered his head and poured the inconceivably sour plum juice into his mouth in one gulp.

Hiss…

That sour sensation,

was like pouring sulfuric acid into his stomach.

But then, Zhou Ze directly picked up his chopsticks, grabbed a mouthful of noodles, and shoved them into his mouth, devouring them as quickly as possible. In five or six bites, a bowl of noodles was gone. He then picked up the bowl and drank all the soup.

Phew…

"Clunk!"

Zhou Ze set down the empty noodle bowl,

let out a long breath. He ate it!

The next moment, Zhou Ze reached out and clutched his chest. The nausea, suppressed by the sour plum soup, surged back. But the food was already in his stomach. Zhou Ze almost choked himself with both hands to keep from throwing up again.

Not throwing up meant success.

The food,

was finally eaten.

Sweat beads had already soaked Zhou Ze's forehead. He picked up a tissue from the table and wiped himself directly.

At this moment,

Doctor Lin and the proprietress were both a bit stunned. Zhou Ze's eating manner just now was simply too terrifying.

"Heh heh, looks like you were really hungry. Want another bowl?" the proprietress asked.

"No, no need," Zhou Ze refused.

"Alrighty." The proprietress cleared the bowls and chopsticks in front of Zhou Ze, then shouted towards the back room, "His dad, knead the dough for the afternoon. Delivery orders should be coming soon."

The proprietress walked inside. Her figure wasn't graceful, just ordinary in appearance, but the ample chest and well-defined lower body added a special charm that was quite attractive.

"Do you like… this type?" Doctor Lin asked.

Because Zhou Ze had been watching the proprietress until she entered the back room.

"No." Zhou Ze shook his head. *I actually like your type, but you won't let me sleep with you.*

Zhou Ze's heart jolted slightly. The thought of "not letting me sleep with you" had been in his mind for a long time, almost becoming an obsession. He had to admit, Doctor Lin was indeed very beautiful and still young.

Even if she was Xu Le's wife,

even if Zhou Ze hadn't married in his previous life,

if he were to ask himself honestly,

he still wanted to sleep with her.

It was precisely because he couldn't that he felt conflicted, and it often stayed on his mind.

"Not going home?" Doctor Lin asked again.

"No," Zhou Ze confirmed.

"Then I'm leaving," Doctor Lin stood up. "Call me if anything happens."

After all, he was her nominal husband, even if there was no marital intimacy.

"Okay," Zhou Ze nodded. *If I had known you were so reasonable and considerate, I should have borrowed some money from you when I was broke.*

Doctor Lin left, driving away in her Porsche Cayenne.

Zhou Ze, however, remained sitting in the noodle shop. His bookstore was right next door. Even after finishing his meal, it was fine to sit and chat here, as they were neighbors.

The owner came out from the back room and offered Zhou Ze a cigarette.

"How much?" Zhou Ze asked.

"No need for politeness, brother, I can afford to treat you to a bowl of noodles." The owner waved his hand generously. They were neighbors; they'd see each other all the time. No need to be strangers over a bowl of noodles.

"Won't your wife scold you?" Zhou Ze asked.

"No, she won't. What does a woman know? She has no say in this," the noodle shop owner's chauvinistic aura was palpable.

A man, no matter his status at home, always had to put on a show outside. No one wanted to admit they were afraid of their wife in public, just as no one wanted to admit they were impotent.

"Heh heh, your wife is quite pretty," Zhou Ze said.

Teasing someone about their wife was a taboo. If two men were facing outwards, teasing a woman walking by on the street, that would be a playful topic between men.

The owner paused, said nothing, just smiled. The owner had a good temper; small business owners generally understood the principle of harmony bringing wealth.

"Her figure is very good," Zhou Ze continued. "Solid, flavorful, just like the noodles I just ate."

The owner took a deep drag from his cigarette.

"How is she in bed?" Zhou Ze asked again. This time, he was even more presumptuous.

The owner clenched his fists slightly, but then spoke casually, "Her legs, they can really clamp a man to death! Strong!"

Zhou Ze smiled,

the owner also smiled.

"Can you handle it?" Zhou Ze asked again. "She's at the age where she probably wants it most, right?"

The owner massaged his lower back, "Can't handle it anymore, not a young man anymore."

"Then, how about I give it a try?" Zhou Ze asked again.

The owner's face completely darkened.

His knuckles cracked audibly.

"If you can't, I can. I'm still young," Zhou Ze muttered to himself. Although, this was a bit disingenuous. Xu Le's physique, even if young, felt more like a "silver spear and wax head." It certainly wasn't as well-maintained as Zhou Ze's own body in his previous life.

"Isn't this joke going too far?" The owner was still trying to control his anger.

"What if your wife agrees?" Zhou Ze continued.

"Was that your wife just now?" The owner changed the subject.

"Mhm," Zhou Ze nodded.

"Would you be willing to let her go?" The owner asked again.

Zhou Ze hesitated, then shook his head. Although she was Xu Le's wife, she was nominally his now, and Zhou Ze was unwilling.

"Then why do you think I would be willing?" The owner retorted.

"Maybe you have some special preferences or unusual kinks? These things aren't rare now, are they?"

"Brother, I haven't laid hands on anyone in a long time," the owner stood up.

"Call your wife out. Ask her. I want to hear her say whether she's willing or not," Zhou Ze leaned back slightly, smiling.

"Heh heh." The owner took a few steps closer to Zhou Ze.

"You stand here and call her out," Zhou Ze insisted.

"You're looking for death!" The owner lunged forward.

"Can she come out?" Zhou Ze suddenly asked.

The owner froze,

then his face showed horror, and he staggered back several steps.

Zhou Ze stood up and walked into the back room, pulling back the curtain. The room was empty.

Only a woman's human skin,

hung on a hanger.

Because the curtain was pulled back and wind came in,

it swayed gently,

floating slowly.

"How… how did you see that?" The owner walked slowly towards him. From his voice, no emotion could be discerned.

"There's a saying… 'Are you trying to fool a ghost?'" Zhou Ze turned to face the owner. "This layer of skin on you should be torn off now.

I'm very curious,

how bored you must be,

to be here,

putting on this double act."

title: 第十二章 立意！
content:
老闆笑了笑，沒有絲毫被激怒的感覺，他只是覺得有些好玩。



  一個人的氣質以及一個的氣場，往往比他的話語更有可信度。



  「嘶啦…………」



  清脆的聲響，帶著些許的綿長，像是蛇蛻皮一樣，他開始撕去自己身上的皮。



  與此同時，老闆的身形骨架正在慢慢地縮減，體格也在緩緩地瘦削下來，像是一個氣球破了一個小洞，正在慢慢地放氣。



  周澤現在終於明白那碗面為什麼會煮得這麼爛了，



  對方這種「變身」，確實需要耗費一些時間。



  穿著還是老闆的衣服，繫著圍裙，但對方的那張臉，則變成了一個略顯青澀的青年。



  青年嘴角含笑，媚態天成，尤其是眼角延展出來的弧度，像是能夠撓到身邊男女心痒痒之處，恰如其分，恰到好處。



  一個男人，用「媚」來形容，是有些違和的，但有些男人，確實是媚骨天生，諸如古代帝王之流，喜好男風者不計其數，原因也的確是在於，有些男人，比女人更像是女人。



  「我好看麼？」



  青年問周澤。



  周澤感到自己剛剛吃麵後壓制下去的噁心感再度襲來，略有歉然地擺擺手，然後捂著自己胸口，做出一副我不能吐的姿態。 



  誰知盤中餐，粒粒皆辛苦！



  周澤很懂得珍惜糧食，尤其是被自己好不容易吞下去即將消化成自己體內能量的糧食。



  青年在旁邊一張椅子上坐了下來，他手裡拿著一隻打火機，隨意地打著轉兒。



  他在打量著周澤，因為周澤發現了他，他自認為自己的模仿渾然天成，又是在這小食飯館的場所，應該不會出什麼問題。



  最重要的是，



  他模仿的是他自己的爹媽。



  自自己年幼開始，他就在觀察自己的爹媽，爹媽的一舉一動，一縷縷神情，早就銘刻在心。



  「你是怎麼發現我的？」青年忍不住了。



  「你不是鬼？」



  周澤也是同時發問。



  青年微微皺眉，他以為周澤在諷刺他，說他裝神弄鬼。



  但實際上，周澤是從一開始就把他當成鬼的。



  周澤不想管閒事兒，一個前不久還在為一個冰櫃的錢範疇的人，周澤不認為自己有那個資格去管閒事兒。



  但這個閒事兒不管又不行，



  閒事兒就發生在自己的隔壁。



  所以周澤覺得，不管怎麼樣，還是先把事情戳破就好，好解決的，自己就解決了，不好解決的，大不了自己再搬家。 



  「你的指甲。」周澤說道，「我這個人，對指甲有些敏感。」



  老闆娘將麵條端送到自己面前，



  老闆親自給自己遞煙，



  指甲，都呈現在自己面前。



  雖然手指粗細白皙老繭程度各不相同，但指甲蓋上的紋路，是一樣的。



  而這陣子，周澤對指甲更加注意，不光是對自己的指甲，也包括別人的指甲。



  青年目光微微一眯，悵然若失，細節，做得不到位。



  雖然自己有著懈怠的意思，但只要被發現了，則確實是自己的紕漏。



  「你真的不是鬼？」周澤又問道。



  如果是人的話，那就真的有些誇張了。



  其實周澤見到的鬼並不多，撇開在地獄裡的那段旅程不算的話，在陽世間，他所見到的鬼真的是屈指可數。



  「畫皮，是我家祖傳的技藝。」青年站起身，伸手抓住了周澤的手，將其放在了自己胸口位置，「只不過，已經斷代了好多輩了，也就到我這一代時，才能重新撿起來。」



  這個動作有點曖昧，也有點破格，但周澤還是下意識地用手捏了捏。



  周澤絕不會認為是因為林醫生一直不讓自己睡導致自己現在對男人產生了興趣， 



  當然，眼前這個男人，的確比女人更媚，這的確是事實。



  「沒骨頭？」周澤臉上露出了意外之色，「不對，是軟骨病。」



  軟骨病又稱佝僂病，因鈣缺乏使骨骼鈣化發生障礙，骨質變軟而易變形，周澤以前是個醫生，自然知道一些，但正如哪怕一種感冒也分很多種情況很多不同的病理一樣，軟骨病也有著很多細分的類別，而眼前這位青年，他則應該是一種極端。



  相傳，春秋野史上有記載，魯國的一位王子就身患這種病，人若無骨，身體嬌柔，能夠像人一樣行走，也能夠類似蛇一樣爬行。



  「你可以理解成這是一種遺傳病，需要一定的概率才能表現出來，之前我家裡往上很多代都練不成畫皮，是因為他們沒得這種病，而我……」



  青年笑了笑，沒繼續說下去。



  「所以，你真的不是鬼？」周澤還是不死心。



  「我叫許清朗。」青年很嚴肅地回答。



  「你模仿的又是誰？」周澤問道。



  「爹，娘。」



  周澤愣了一下，面露苦笑。



  得嘞，



  這誤會大了。



  之前吃完面後，林姐姐離開，周澤想著捅破窗戶紙，故意拿話激他，結果沒成想，居然是人家沒事做在這裡玩角色扮演，追思自己的亡親。 



  但在周澤之前的視角，他只是想當然地認為，這是一隻鬼，類似「畫皮」故事裡的鬼，殺了人，扒了皮，還在「沐猴而冠」。



  「那……不好意思了。」



  拿你媽打趣，還真是有些不好意思。



  「我沒生氣。」許清朗說道，「但我很好奇，你一直把我當鬼，是個什麼意思？」



  「沒什麼意思。」



  「你見過鬼？」許清朗問道。



  「我就是一個鬼。」周澤看著許清朗，很認真地說道。



  表情嚴肅，神色莊嚴，



  掏心窩子啊。



  許清朗面色一滯，



  然後抑制不住地發出了「噗」的笑聲，



  看向周澤的目光，



  宛若看一個智障。



  周澤點點頭，有時候，就是這樣，你告訴他真相，你以為你在逗他，他反而不信。



  「不管怎麼樣，不好意思了，對了，我還想問，那人皮，是真的人皮？」周澤好奇道。



  「魚皮。」許清朗回答道，「加工，繪畫，製作而成。」



  「那你賣什麼面啊。」周澤有些不能理解，「我聽說赫哲族的蛇皮衣服一件能賣不少錢，當藝術品賣的，你這個，應該更值錢吧？」 



  「祖傳的東西，拿來牟利，我做不到。」



  「那你應該很有錢。」周澤說道。



  「家裡，剛拆遷。」許清朗沒直接回答，「分了二十幾套房。」



  「…………」周澤深吸一口氣。



  所以，世界就是這樣不公平，他上輩子在醫院工作，辛辛苦苦也沒掙幾個錢，而人家隨隨便便，就是二十幾套房。



  通城不比上海，但房價也接近萬多一平了。



  拆二代，羨慕啊。



  周澤搖搖頭，「你以後還要繼續下麵條？」



  「你以後還會繼續賣書？」



  二人又同時問了對方問題。



  「暫時看著吧。」周澤回答。



  「我也一樣。」



  「那，回見，對了，你家酸梅汁還有其他口味麼？」周澤對這一點很好奇，「比如苦瓜味的？葡萄味的？」



  「有秘方，可以做。」許清朗很實誠。



  「很好。」周澤伸手在許清朗肩膀上拍了拍，



  娘的，



  跟棉花一樣，



  軟綿綿的，是真的柔弱真沒骨啊，這要是抱在懷裡躺床上………… 



  周澤馬上在心底搬出林醫生剛洗完澡穿著睡衣出來的畫面，強行鎮壓自己那段不和諧的思想。



  周澤走出了麵館，



  許清朗走到了裡屋，掀開了帘子，對裡面掛著的那張女人人皮道：



  「媽，你說他真信了還是假信了？」



  女人皮輕輕搖曳，



  微微輕擺，



  像是在說，他沒信，



  也像是在說，她也不知道。



  ………………



  周澤回到自己店裡，冰櫃已經安頓好了，下面其實就得把徐樂留下來的破書店給整改整改了，一直讓它這麼虧下去，也不是辦法。



  書店門口的牌子上掛著「徐樂書屋」，要多土氣就有多土氣。



  總之，這家書店在那傢伙的手上，從上到下，由里到外，都流露出「鐵定虧本」的氣息。



  周澤坐到電腦前，嘗試了幾次登錄自己原本的QQ，結果都無法登錄，身份驗證根本過不了，申訴也基本沒辦法了。



  隨後，周澤只能出門打車出去，他打算換一個牌子，或者搞一副門牌對聯放這裡。



  他認識一個開牌匾店的，專門做木雕牌匾生意，店主是個老人，老人經常給那家孤兒院捐款，當年周澤自己也是孤兒院一員時，老人就在捐款了，等周澤工作之後，老人和周澤一起捐款。 



  那家牌匾店並不遠，就在狼山腳下，前後左右都是賣香燭的，就這家賣的是牌匾。



  只是，當周澤走進去時，卻發現店鋪里正在做大掃除，甚至連牌匾都被拆了下來。



  一個中年男子在那裡指揮著工人忙活。



  「你是？」對方看見走過來的周澤問道。



  「我找趙老先生。」周澤說道，他對那位老者，很是尊重。



  「不好意思，我爹上個月剛走。」中年人回答道。



  「走了？」周澤有些意外，也有些傷感，他和趙老其實不熟，只是彼此知道對方這麼一個人而已，也因此，人家葬禮沒通知到他也很正常。



  況且，可能對於趙老家裡人來說，趙老一直將打牌匾的收入捐出給孤兒院，他們自然對孤兒院沒什麼好感，甚至不會去通知孤兒院葬禮，生怕孤兒院再上來找他們要錢。



  「你是來訂做匾額的？」中年男子問道。



  「嗯。」周澤點點頭。



  「我們家，不做了。」中年男子歉然道：「以後，賣香燭了。」



  狼山是佛教十小山之一，哪怕吸引不到外來遊客，但本地人逢年過節地去燒香拜佛，也足夠讓坐落在山腳下的店鋪商家們大賺一筆了。



  這也是一種靠山吃山，靠水吃水。 



  「那可惜了。」周澤有些遺憾。



  他打算去老先生墓碑前看看。



  「不過家裡還有幾塊我爹以前打的匾額，賣不出去的，也不知道我爹刻那幾個匾額做什麼，也不是人訂做的，你要是喜歡，便宜點出給你。」中年男子本著賣廢品的心思打算處理掉了。



  「好，我看看。」周澤同意了。



  跟著中年男子走到了後面小院子裡，中年男子打開了一間庫房，開了燈。



  裡面放著一些雜物，包括趙老先生做工時的器具，雜亂無章地堆放，意味著子孫後代是不打算繼承這門手藝了。



  現在大家都做能發光的牌面，誰還願意用這個？辛辛苦苦的，還賺不來什麼錢。



  「呼…………」中年男子對著地上的幾塊牌匾吹了一口氣，道：「你看看吧，兩百塊一副，看上就可以拿走，沒看上就算了。」



  顯然，中年男子對能否把這幾塊牌匾給出掉，不抱什麼信心。



  周澤走過去看了看，



  第一副牌匾上寫著：



  「生死有命，富貴在天。」



  周澤搖搖頭，中年男子嘆了口氣，知道這塊匾額沒戲了。



  下一副寫著： 



  「人知鬼恐怖，鬼曉人心毒。」



  周澤微微一愣，他對這個，有點敏感。



  中年男子這次沒嘆氣，因為他知道直接沒戲，誰家開店吃飽了撐的在門口掛這個？



  第三副：



  「姑妄聽之，如是我聞。」



  周澤笑了，



  中年男子看著周澤笑了他也笑了，



  總歸有一個滿意了。

title: 第十三章 第一位顧客！
content:
The plaque was brought back, and Zhou Ze planned to nail it on both sides. Zhou Ze didn't care which one went on the left or the right.

Xu Qinglang, the kind elder brother next door, was very enthusiastic.

He was originally squatting at his doorway peeling garlic, but when he saw Zhou Ze about to hang the plaque, he directly went into his house and brought out a hammer and nails.

Zhou Ze said thank you and took his hammer. He felt a bit greasy and heavy in his hand. Enduring a slight discomfort, Zhou Ze still nailed both plaques up.

Then,

The two of them stepped back a few paces, looking at the plaques, at the door, and at the bookstore.

Zhou Ze offered Xu Qinglang a cigarette as thanks, and Xu Qinglang lit Zhou Ze's cigarette for him.

They both exhaled smoke rings,

In perfect synchronicity.

"It has 'artistic conception,' doesn't it?" Zhou Ze said, which was standard self-praise.

Xu Qinglang shook his head. "If I'm not mistaken, these two lines should be from the chapter titles of Ji Xiaolan's *Jottings of the Yuewei Hermitage*."

*Jottings of the Yuewei Hermitage* is a collection of stories by Ji Xiaolan, similar to *Strange Tales from a Chinese Studio*, using tales of fox spirits and ghosts to express the author's own thoughts.

In short, this couplet means: These are all stories I've heard; everyone present, just listen.

"Mm." Zhou Ze nodded.

"Still too literary. Your store will still lose money," Xu Qinglang's assessment was quite blunt.

"Why?"

"In this world, there are too many stories, all sorts of strange and bizarre things happen every day, but truly interesting things aren't that many.

Some things are pointless to say.

Some things are strictly forbidden to say.

Some things won't be heard unless they're changed.

Some things dare not be heard unless they're changed."

Zhou Ze looked at Xu Qinglang for a long time.

Xu Qinglang lowered his head slightly, his face flushing with embarrassment.

He was already naturally alluring in his masculine frame, and at this moment, he was even more dazzlingly beautiful beyond compare.

Seeing Zhou Ze remain silent, Xu Qinglang continued:

"For example, these stories of mountain spirits, fox immortals, and ghosts, do they really exist in the real world?" Xu Qinglang yawned. "How can the道理 (principles) conveyed through false stories ever be truly real?"

Zhou Ze continued to look at Xu Qinglang, not speaking.

Xu Qinglang felt a little prickle on his scalp from being stared at,

But Zhou Ze kept looking at him.

Finally, Xu Qinglang waved his hand, saying he needed to go back to make soup base. Walking back to his noodle shop, he felt as if he had "prickles on his back," because just now, he felt as though Zhou Ze wasn't looking at him,

But looking at a joke.

Zhou Ze paid no mind to Xu Qinglang. Since they were neighbors, they would just "keep to their own business." Anyway, they weren't in competition, and most importantly, Zhou Ze didn't have money to change shops.

In the afternoon, Zhou Ze organized most of the textbooks and study guides in the bookstore and had them taken away by a scrap collector at the price of waste paper.

He then went to the supermarket and bought ten small plastic chairs. The only two remaining bookshelves held books that Zhou Ze himself found interesting.

At present, rather than a bookstore, it was more like a senior citizens' entertainment center.

Zhou Ze stretched. He wasn't very good at business. For now, he was just messing around. Anyway, when Xu Le was around, he was constantly losing money, so Zhou Ze felt no pressure.

Coming up to the second floor, Zhou Ze turned on the freezer, set a temperature, smoked a cigarette outside while waiting, then reached in to feel the temperature in the freezer.

The temperature was about right. Zhou Ze lay inside.

The freezer, bought for over ten thousand yuan, certainly had many functions, such as a timer, which acted as an alarm for Zhou Ze.

Closing the freezer,

Zhou Ze placed his hands on his lower abdomen, lying perfectly straight,

Looking as if,

He had passed away peacefully.

…………

Late at night,

A red car parked on the road outside the bookstore. The entire street was somewhat deserted, with only the adjacent noodle shop and bookstore still lit up.

Inside the car sat a well-dressed girl in a black down jacket with shoulder-length hair, looking somewhat cute and delicate.

"Xiao Bai, you bastard! I prepared for three days, and today you tell me you've gone on a business trip! Go to hell, get lost!"

The girl hung up the phone, sulking in the driver's seat.

The Corgi in the passenger seat jumped onto the girl's lap. Its fur was flowing and shiny, clearly a good breed and well-cared for.

"Good boy, at least I still have you with me."

The girl lit a cigarette, extended her hand to flick the ash, and looked outside. She saw the bookstore. Crucially, through the glass window, she could see that the interior setup was unusual; there weren't many bookshelves, but rather rows of plastic stools.

She got out of the car, carrying the Corgi, and walked towards the bookstore. She didn't want to drive around aimlessly alone on this Valentine's night; she wanted to find a quiet place to sit.

The bookstore door was open, and upon entering, she could feel the warm air from the air conditioning.

The girl, leading her dog, first picked up a random magazine from a bookshelf, then sat down on a plastic chair.

The Corgi was unleashed and began its "exploration" of the store.

After finishing a magazine, the girl let out a small stretch and felt a bit thirsty. She called out:

"Boss, are you here? Do you have milk tea or coffee?"

The girl stood up, put the magazine she was holding back, and picked another illustrated version of *Dream of the Red Chamber*. When she sat down again, she couldn't help but call out once more:

"Boss, are you dead in the middle of the night? Is this how you run a shop?"

The bookstore's glass door had a small sign that read "Open, Welcome," the door was open, and the heating was on, so it was definitely still in business.

If the girl had been less polite or more curious at this point and had gone upstairs to take a look, she might have admired her own "self-fulfilling prophecy."

In the low-ceilinged space on the second floor, there was indeed an ice coffin,

And the boss was lying inside, truly looking like a dead person.

No,

The boss was already a dead person.

Of course, the girl might not have had time to admire herself before being scared out of her wits.

Isn't it terrifying for a normal person to enter a shop late at night and discover the owner lying in a frozen ice coffin?

The girl lit another cigarette, growing a little impatient, and pulled out her phone to play games.

Just then, footsteps came from the staircase. Zhou Ze didn't wake up because of the girl's shouts; he woke up naturally.

As soon as he came downstairs, Zhou Ze saw a small yellow figure darting to his leg, asking to be held.

Zhou Ze smiled and bent down, scooping the Corgi into his arms. The little fellow wasn't shy and seemed friendly with everyone.

Then, Zhou Ze noticed the woman sitting in the store.

Oh,

His first customer.

But he wasn't as excited as one might imagine, because today Zhou Ze had merely changed the bookstore's sign and tidied up the interior furnishings.

He hadn't yet figured out,

How to make money next.

"Do you have coffee here, boss?"

The girl asked.

Zhou Ze pointed to a water dispenser in the corner of the wall. There were disposable paper cups by the dispenser.

The girl was a little helpless, but still got up, poured herself a glass of water, and then sat back down on her plastic stool.

One host, one guest,

Silence between them.

After about half an hour of silence, the girl started browsing Weibo and watching videos. One video was very noisy and boisterous:

"Those passing by, don't miss out!

Under the old Taoist's blessing, hell money is in limited supply!

You can burn it and retrieve it for use when you go down there, and even earn some interest, higher than Yu'ebao's interest!

You can also burn it and send it to your deceased relatives below, quick and convenient, fair to all, no harassment from ghost officials, no layers of exploitation!"

The girl laughed when she saw the video. People usually like to share funny things. She looked up at the boss behind the counter and said:

"Boss, have you seen this video? This old Taoist's live stream is quite famous. He's almost a celebrity."

"Oh, live stream?" Zhou Ze was a bit puzzled. He took out his phone. Xu Le's phone indeed had many live streaming apps. It seemed this guy was truly bored in his daily life, either watching live streams or writing sequels to *Bai Jie*.

"Yes, search for his ID, it's hilarious. He supposedly opened a冥店 (underworld goods store) in Rongcheng, but he hasn't live streamed for a long time."

Zhou Ze opened the app and started searching for the old Taoist's ID as the girl suggested. He found a live streaming room – "Anchor Not Home."

Fortunately, he could watch past videos. Zhou Ze randomly clicked on a video from a month ago.

In the video, the old Taoist had his phone fixed in one spot and was practicing martial arts alone. His punches were good; he clearly was a trained practitioner. In the video frame, a young man sat there, a smile on his lips, eyes squinting, as if watching a monkey show.

Zhou Ze perfunctorily fast-forwarded the video. Another man appeared in the frame, sitting behind the counter, spoon in hand, seemingly drinking porridge.

The old Taoist was eloquently talking in the main video frame, continuously promoting himself and the hell money he sold on Taobao, but Zhou Ze's gaze instinctively focused on the man in the corner of the video.

He was frowning, he was struggling, he was in pain, he was resisting,

A mouthful of porridge,

He ate it with great difficulty,

Then continued with the second mouthful,

As if being tortured.

Zhou Ze watched, taking a deep breath, seemingly affected by the man in the corner of the video himself.

Eating,

It really isn't an easy thing.

He didn't know the identity of the man in the video, but he instinctively felt a slight interest. Was the other party an anorexia patient? Or did he have some stomach illness?

After the video ended, Zhou Ze opened the page, and on a whim, he directly used Xu Le's logged-in account to send the old Taoist a private message:

"Who is the man in the video sitting in the back drinking porridge?"

"Hey, I'm leaving. How much?" The girl stood up, stretched, "People will definitely think I'm crazy for saying this today, that I spent Valentine's night sitting in a bookstore reading *Dream of the Red Chamber* for so long."

"Just pay what you think is fair," Zhou Ze said.

The other person had only read for a while and poured herself a glass of pure water.

The girl glanced at Zhou Ze. "Boss, your method is really good, like those masters who interpret fortunes in temples.

There's a sign by the kneeling cushion that says 'Free Fortune Reading,' and after tourists draw a fortune and have him interpret it, he then pulls out a red donation book for you, with a long list of names and incense money, the lowest being a hundred."

Zhou Ze smiled, noncommittal.

The girl took out a hundred-yuan bill, placed it on the chair where she had been sitting, then carried her Corgi and pushed open the bookstore door, leaving.

Zhou Ze stood up, picked up the hundred-yuan bill, and flicked it in his hand,

A crisp sound,

This was one of the most wonderful sounds in the world.

When he walked back to the counter, Zhou Ze saw his phone screen light up. He opened the phone and found that there was indeed a reply, a private message from that old Taoist. The content of the reply was very simple:

"Gone!"

title: 第十四章 過年了！
content:
Tonight, this was the only customer, and all the income was one hundred yuan, but the cost was just a cup of water.

Of course, you could say there are other costs like electricity and rent...

But you can't calculate it that way. When Xu Le was here, these were also costs, but his income was almost negligible. One always needs to find suitable points of comparison to gain a sense of satisfaction and confidence in life.

Also, it was because of that girl with the Corgi that Zhou Ze realized it was Valentine's Day today.

Flipping through WeChat, he found Dr. Lin's WeChat ID. Clicking on it, Zhou Ze wanted to send a red packet. He tried to send 1314 but found he didn't have enough money. He had enough for 131.4, but sending that felt a bit stingy.

Anyway, she's not sleeping with me,

Forget it,

Not sending it.

Putting down his phone, Zhou Ze grabbed a random book and flipped through it, staying in that posture until morning.

He went next door for wontons. Whether the wrappers were thin or the filling was thick, Zhou Ze wasn't sure. He ate them the same way as before: a large bowl of plum juice went down first, then he devoured the wontons, followed by clutching his throat and taking deep breaths, suppressing the urge to vomit.

Thinking that every meal in the future would have to follow this routine, Zhou Ze felt like a shadow had been cast over his future days.

Zhou Ze also recalled the man in the video who similarly struggled to eat porridge, feeling a touch of sorrow. Eating was originally one of the greatest joys of being alive, but now, it was a stranger to them.

He wondered if there was an "Anorexics' Club" in the world, where everyone would gather around a table, and whoever could eat one bite of rice first would be given a thumbs-up by everyone:

"You're amazing!

My XXX is so impressive!"

Taking a deep breath, the image sent shivers down his spine.

Regardless, yesterday's video, including the old Daoist and the porridge-eating man in it, seemed too distant for Zhou Ze for now.

After Valentine's Day came Chinese New Year's Eve, or the thirtieth day of the twelfth lunar month. In normal times, this commercial center would be brightly lit with lanterns and decorations, very festive and "full of New Year's spirit." But in reality, it remained as it was, cold and desolate.

This is like life,

Since there has been glory, there will naturally be decline.

Zhou Ze remembered when this commercial center first opened, it was all the rage, but now, no one cares about it.

Xu Qinglang had good business today, probably because many other shops were closed. He, who insisted on doing takeout on Chinese New Year's Eve, naturally received more orders, as customers had fewer choices.

From time to time, takeout delivery riders in blue, yellow, or red uniforms went in and out of his noodle shop. Zhou Ze squatted at the entrance of his bookstore, smoking a cigarette and sighing with emotion.

Damn Xu Le, how great it would have been if he had opened a braised chicken shop back then.

Immortals in myths and legends are fond of saying: "One day in heaven equals one year on Earth."

In fact, Zhou Ze felt this should be true, and it also applied to Hell.

He remembered when he died in a car accident... no, he remembered when he was sent to the crematorium for incineration, it was just after Children's Day on June 1st, and now, in the blink of an eye, it was Chinese New Year's Eve.

More than half a year had passed so quickly. A fleeting dream, nothing more than wandering aimlessly for half a journey on the Yellow Springs road.

After smoking quite a few cigarettes and contemplating many thoughts, Zhou Ze felt a bit tired. He took out his phone, wanting to see if there were any movies playing recently. The cinema was right next door, so he could go there to pass the time.

"Hey, do you have any newspapers there?" Xu Qinglang, who had just finished sending off the last batch of delivery drivers, walked out.

"What for?"

"To paste on the wall," Xu Qinglang replied.

"So economical?"

"Newspapers on the wall create an atmosphere and a sense of history. You didn't sell them all yesterday, did you?"

"Still some left. Wait, I'll go find them for you."

Zhou Ze returned to the store and moved a stack of newspapers, about half a person tall, from a box near his freezer on the second floor. He brought them downstairs and handed them to Xu Qinglang, who was waiting.

"You're not going home for New Year's either?" Xu Qinglang asked.

"Spending New Year's with books."

Too bad Zhou Ze didn't have a goatee, nor wine in his hand,

Otherwise, he could have raised a cup to that boastful remark.

"Aren't you also not going home?" Zhou Ze asked after a moment of self-indulgence.

"With over twenty apartments, which home should I go back to?" Xu Qinglang sighed.

"..." Zhou Ze.

The two fell silent for a moment, then Zhou Ze spoke, "Let me tell you a story."

"Alright," Xu Qinglang nodded, a hint of shyness in his expression. His hair was a little long, with a few strands hanging down, nearly touching his lips. He reached up and gently brushed the strands away, his posture soft, truly charming and endearing.

Such charm was not for outsiders to know.

"Once, also on New Year's Day, late at night on the road, someone encountered the richest man in the area.

The rich man was dead drunk.

That person asked the rich man, why aren't you going home?

The rich man replied: Home, where is my home? My family and relatives are not with me. The home you speak of, is it my largest estate in the whole city?"

Xu Qinglang listened to the story and nodded slightly, seemingly deeply empathetic.

"Then that person pressed the rich man to the ground and beat him up, shouting:

"Who told you to come out here and show off on New Year's!"

Zhou Ze continued to finish the story.

"..." Xu Qinglang.

Their conversation ended.

Zhou Ze returned to his bookstore. The heating was on inside, making it warm and cozy. He turned his phone in his hand, with no one to contact.

He had thought about visiting the orphanage, but then decided against it, as he didn't have much money left.

But just then, a customer came in. It was a young man in a blue work uniform and a hard hat. He pushed open the bookstore door and walked in, asking somewhat shyly:

"Can I read books here? How much?" The man pursed his lips.

"Read whatever you like. Pay what you think it's worth," Zhou Ze waved his hand, indicating for him to make himself at home.

"That's great. Do you have any novels?" the young man said somewhat reservedly, "I like reading novels, like online novels."

Zhou Ze pointed to a box behind the bookshelf, "They're all in there."

The man walked over to the box and rummaged through it a few times, looking pleased. Some of the books still had their plastic wrappers on.

"Open them and read. No charge," Zhou Ze said generously.

"Alright."

The young man unwrapped an online novel and then sat down on a plastic stool, beginning to read.

Zhou Ze, as the owner, sat behind the counter trimming his nails, while the young man read. About half an hour later, the young man stood up from the chair, took out his cigarette, and offered one to Zhou Ze:

"It's not a good brand, don't mind it."

"Hey, cigarettes aren't good things to begin with, so what's the difference between good and bad?"

Zhou Ze took the cigarette, and the other person took one too, then actively walked outside the shop, lighting and smoking it while enduring the cold wind.

This surprised Zhou Ze, who had intended to smoke inside. He thought about it and decided against it, putting the cigarette aside and continuing to trim his nails.

After the young man finished his cigarette outside, he walked back in. This time he didn't sit on the plastic stool but leaned against the wall and sat on the floor.

Although the air conditioning was on inside, the floor tiles were still cold. The young man, however, didn't seem to mind, suggesting he was accustomed to it from his daily life.

About fifteen minutes later, four more men walked into the store from outside. They were dressed in neatly laundered blue work uniforms. The oldest was no more than thirty, and the youngest was probably around seventeen.

All four of them entered together. The young man leaning against the wall waved to them, apparently having called them over.

The newcomers greeted Zhou Ze, who responded perfunctorily and continued to trim his nails;

Zhou Ze decided to buy a professional nail care kit to do justice to his nails.

However, express delivery services were currently suspended, and most physical stores were closed, so he could only put it off for now.

When he looked up again, Zhou Ze found that all five workers were sitting on the floor, each holding a novel.

From the covers, it was clear they were all online novels, mostly fantasy. One held a horror novel, biting his nails as he read, clearly engrossed.

However, the other person's habit of biting his nails was something Zhou Ze couldn't agree with.

Only by cherishing one's nails can one truly cherish life.

From time to time, someone would laugh while reading a novel, a genuine laugh from deep within as they followed the story.

The bookstore had quite a few people, but it was very quiet. There were occasional small sounds, but nothing too disturbing.

Towards evening, Xu Qinglang walked in with a bowl of dumplings. As he entered, he immediately said:

"Well, well, the shop's quite lively."

Zhou Ze smiled and nodded.

"Hey, guys, want something to eat?" Xu Qinglang asked the workers sitting in the shop.

Everyone looked at each other,

Feeling a bit at a loss.

"Never mind, my treat," Xu Qinglang, after all, was a man with twenty-something properties. "It's New Year's, and it's not easy for you guys to not be home. We're all out here working hard for money, and brothers from all corners of the earth are brothers."

"Well, thank you, boss. May you get rich," the oldest worker stood up and thanked Xu Qinglang.

"You're welcome, you're welcome."

Xu Qinglang put down Zhou Ze's dumplings and went back to his own shop.

Zhou Ze drank a bit of the soup, then forced down two dumplings. That annoying Xu Qinglang forgot to bring him plum juice, and he couldn't eat them without it.

Taking out the cigarettes on the table, Zhou Ze walked out from behind the counter.

"If you finish one, change it yourself. I should have the complete set here anyway. This shop of mine is a losing business, so don't be polite with me, everyone."

Zhou Ze offered cigarettes one by one,

The workers were flattered as they took them.

Then, everyone stood up, walked out of the store, and squatted in a row to smoke.

They didn't want to dirty the shop's environment.

Zhou Ze thought about it, then also walked out of the shop. Outside, the wind was a bit cold. He squatted down beside them, smoking along.

The workers chatted,

Those who were married talked about their wives and children;

Those who weren't married talked about their sweethearts they knew in Tongcheng or their hometowns,

Teasing each other,

Joking with each other,

Even though they all knew each other well,

They still had things to talk about.

One could tell from their accents that this group of workers came from all over the country, not from the same village.

Tongcheng is close to Shanghai, part of the Yangtze River Delta region. Although it cannot compare to Shanghai in scale, the demand for labor here is very high every year. As long as one is willing to endure hardship, there is no worry about finding work or earning money.

After two more rounds of cigarette sharing,

Zhou Ze spoke, "Guys, are you really not going home for the New Year?"

"No, our families are all well."

"It's a hassle to go back and forth. There's still work in the first month of the New Year, and the boss will even give red envelopes! Might as well take them, and we can send more money back home."

"Haha, today's pretty good. We have novels to read, and cigarettes to smoke. This New Year, it's quite enjoyable."

"Boss, when are you closing?" one of the workers asked.

"Not closing," Zhou Ze replied.

"Boss not going home?"

"My old lady back home isn't listening, so I'm not going back."

Zhou Ze suddenly felt a surge of heroic pride!

All the workers gave Zhou Ze a thumbs-up, cheering for him.

Of course, no one chimed in too much. You could tell from his accent, and since Zhou Ze ran a bookstore, not a fruit stall, the workers guessed he was a local.

There were reasons for a local not going home to guard a shop during the New Year, so no one continued to tease or joke about it.

Moreover, they were all the pillars of their respective families, working away from home to earn money. Their elderly parents and children were cared for by their wives. They worked hard and were tired, but their wives were the same.

Life, it's just one generation after another enduring hardships and persevering. Whose life is truly easy?

Just as Zhou Ze was about to offer another round of cigarettes, a shout came from a distance:

"Xu Le!"

Zhou Ze looked up and stood up, only then noticing a Porsche Cayenne parked on the opposite side of the road, a familiar car,

Hmm, his wife's car.

The one shouting was his sister-in-law. She had indeed been frightened by Zhou Ze in the bathroom a while ago, but she had since recovered. She couldn't believe her brother-in-law was a ghost, so she simply attributed it to her own blurry vision from being scared at the time.

Of course, she couldn't have a good temper with Zhou Ze, after all, he actually made this young lady wet herself! How embarrassing!

"Xu Le, come home for dinner!"

His sister-in-law shouted.

"Not going back, the shop's busy and quite lively," Zhou Ze waved his hand.

Joke,

Go back and see those awful in-laws on New Year's?

Endure the temper of this immature sister-in-law?

Most importantly,

Go all the way home on New Year's just to sleep in separate beds?

Looking for a beating?

"Sis, is this guy crazy?! He's unreasonable, inexplicable, and a stubborn mule!"

The sister-in-law pouted in the back seat.

Dr. Lin smiled, "Let's go home and eat with Mom and Dad first."

"Oh, judging by that, sister, are you planning to come out tonight?"

"I am, after all, his lawful wife." Dr. Lin said no more, started the car, and drove away.

Watching the car drive off,

Zhou Ze turned to the workers beside him and asked, "Guys, is my wife pretty?"

"Beautiful!"

"Lucky man!"

"Absolutely gorgeous!"

"Hahahahaha."

Xu Qinglang walked out of his shop with a large tray,

"Here, braised pork over rice! Guys, dig in!"

The workers were a bit reserved, and some seemed awkward. The oldest worker said somewhat sheepishly, "We came out without..."

"I said before, I'm treating you guys to a meal! Bringing up money again means you don't see me as a brother. Who knows where we'll meet again, someday I might need your help."

"Okay!"

"You got it!"

"When you come to my hometown..."

"Deal!"

The workers all carried large bowls of rice into the bookstore. They squatted on the floor, placing their bowls on the plastic stools and eagerly began to eat.

One worker was eating and reading his novel at the same time, until another worker next to him tapped him on the head with his chopsticks.

"You're so greedy! If you accidentally stain the book, how will the boss sell it?"

"You're right, let's eat first."

The atmosphere was lively. Zhou Ze returned to his counter. He ate three more of the already somewhat cold dumplings. For some reason, perhaps because of the atmosphere, his nausea was much less than before.

After dinner,

Everyone continued reading.

Inside the room, with the heating on and novels to read, it was very harmonious.

Unknowingly, it was ten o'clock at night.

The oldest worker stood up, stretched, and said, "Guys, it's time. Let's head back, and we'll help him clean up the place."

"Alright!"

The five workers helped Zhou Ze clean the entire shop, top to bottom.

"Boss, we're leaving. Thank you for today."

"Don't mention it," Zhou Ze waved his hand.

They left,

Unlike the girl with the Corgi from last night, who left a hundred yuan after reading for a while, they read for a whole day and half a night, and didn't leave a single yuan.

But Zhou Ze didn't mind at all, nor was there the slightest hint of dissatisfaction.

Stretching, Zhou Ze intended to call Xu Qinglang to collect the bowls and chopsticks from the shop. When he reached the noodle shop, Zhou Ze saw Xu Qinglang sitting behind a table, reading a newspaper.

Hmm, the newspaper was the one Zhou Ze had given him earlier in the day.

Xu Qinglang wore a pair of gold-rimmed glasses, which indeed gave him a scholarly air. Truly worthy of a man with over twenty properties,

He looked refined no matter how you saw him!

"Those bowls and chopsticks, you clean them up," Zhou Ze said.

"Okay, I'll go now."

Xu Qinglang took off his glasses, rubbed his eyes, and got up to clean the bowls and chopsticks next door.

On top of the large stack of newspapers was a copy of the Yangtse Evening Post, dated seven days ago;

The front page headline in bold read:

"Residential Building Fire, Heroic Act Touches Hearts"

Last week, a densely populated residential community in Tongcheng suffered a sudden and severe fire.

Five young construction workers from a nearby construction site, disregarding danger, rushed in to rescue people. They saved more than twenty elderly people, women, and children in total, but after their final rush into the burning building to save others,

They never came out again.

The front page of the Yangtse Evening Post featured a large photo,

It was a group photo of these five men,

They stood shoulder to shoulder, making old-fashioned V-signs, seemingly taken when they first arrived at the construction site and lived in the same temporary shelter,

Faces that were both youthful and showed a hint of weathered wrinkles,

In the photo,

They smiled somewhat awkwardly, yet brightly.

Xu Qinglang walked into the bookstore,

Looking at the five bowls of braised pork over rice on the plastic stools in front of him,

Untouched, the food long since cold,

In each bowl, a pair of chopsticks stood upright, stuck straight into the rice.

"Brothers,

Eat well,

Drink well."

Xu Qinglang murmured.

Outside,

Firecrackers started to go off,

Tongcheng hadn't banned fireworks, and for a moment, the sky was filled with colorful displays, very lively and festive.

Zhou Ze looked up, gazing outside,

And softly said:

"It's New Year's."

title: 第十五章 生活要想過得去
content:
Firecrackers popped, bidding farewell to the old year. After midnight, fireworks and firecrackers erupted from all directions, creating a lively and dense symphony of sounds. What had been sporadic noises now became an overwhelming barrage.

Zhou Ze blew on his fingernails. The outdoor clamor had little to do with him. He had no home, and while he technically now had a "home," he didn't want to go back.

Many people, while alive, had the thought: *If I could be reborn, I would do this and that.*

To wield a pen with passion, to point fingers at the powerful, to scorn the feudal lords of old.*

But upon truly returning from Hell, you suddenly realize that your past pursuits, ideas, and aspirations are like when a kindergarten teacher asks, "Children, what do you want to be when you grow up?"

And the children all reply: "Scientists, doctors, astronauts, soldiers..."

Dreams are always plump.

Reality isn't exactly gaunt, but a person's enthusiasm is finite.

Sometimes, just being able to breathe, hear sounds, and sit here idly, wasting time—

Perhaps this is true peacefulness.

Xu Qinglang was still sleeping in the shop tonight. Zhou Ze heard him close the shop door.

He said he had over twenty apartments, but Zhou Ze knew his parents were still in the shop.

A family should always be together.

And this New Year, of course, was even more important.

Outside, it started to rain. A damp chill began to seep in, making one feel somewhat oppressed.

Zhou Ze's phone rang. It was his wife calling.

"Hello," Zhou Ze answered.

"Are you asleep?" Dr. Lin asked.

Zhou Ze thought the question was idiotic.

*If I were asleep, who would answer your call?*

*Could it be a dead person... oh no, a dead ghost?*

*No, something seems off.*

Zhou Ze leaned back slightly in his chair, a scene flashing in his mind: Dr. Lin lightly poking his chest with a finger, calling him: "You dead ghost..."

For the first time, he felt that speaking the truth could be so dazzling.

Perhaps he was too bored, or perhaps just idle,

Zhou Ze found his thoughts wandering,

Thinking a bit too much.

"Not yet," Zhou Ze replied.

"Creak..."

Dr. Lin pushed open the shop door and entered. She held a red umbrella, wearing leather pants and a white sweater, her hair falling over her shoulders.

Zhou Ze momentarily forgot to lower the phone.

This woman,

Was indeed very beautiful.

Especially her demeanor, which always gave you a feeling of "life is only like a first meeting," instantaneously piercing a man's heart.

"Afraid I'd be lonely?" Zhou Ze stood up and poured Dr. Lin a glass of water.

She was the mistress of this place.

Well,

To be precise, the money Xu Le used to open this bookstore came from her family.

Dr. Lin took the water, shook her head, and said nothing.

They were husband and wife, but in reality, they were like the most familiar strangers, in a more awkward position than that of platonic male and female friends.

To move forward, difficult;

To retreat, even harder.

"Let's go for a walk," Zhou Ze felt the room was a bit stuffy, and he couldn't invite Dr. Lin to sleep in his room upstairs.

Even if Dr. Lin had taken the wrong medicine today and intended to "feed herself to the tiger," seeing his freezer upstairs would probably make her immediately dial the number of a familiar psychiatric hospital to have him sent away for re-education.

"It's raining," Dr. Lin said.

"It's just a drizzle, it's fine." Zhou Ze waved his hand, feeling relaxed and at ease.

***

"Pouring, pouring, pouring..."

The rain grew heavy, very heavy.

Zhou Ze, who hadn't even brought an umbrella, intending to experience the preciousness of spring rain, was practically drenched to the bone. Dr. Lin still held her umbrella, standing beside him. Zhou Ze refused her suggestion to share the umbrella.

The pretense he made, he had to see through, even with tears in his eyes.

Patting his dripping hair, Zhou Ze shivered. He wasn't particularly afraid of the cold; he was quite resistant to it, but the woman beside him, though barely wet from the umbrella, was still trembling slightly.

The bus stop shelter could block most of the rain,

But the cold night wind could still run rampant.

Petty bourgeois sentiment,

A man and a woman together,

Soaked in the rainy night,

The beauty's pity,

This should have been a good opportunity, a good moment, for them to cultivate their relationship. Perhaps even a passionate encounter that resulted in an unexpected pregnancy was possible. But the two remained silent.

Zhou Ze lit a cigarette. Dr. Lin stood beside him.

One wanted to escape, the other was inherently resistant, so naturally, they wouldn't connect.

A forced melon, both the melon and the vine, would be twisted.

Zhou Ze secretly blamed Xu Le. If that timid fellow had just gone ahead and taken her by force after they got married, there wouldn't be this mess now. Even if Dr. Lin was a married woman or had children, she would probably still be breathtakingly beautiful, perhaps even more so.

And he could have just gone with the flow; he wouldn't be in this difficult position now.

Of course, this blame was unfair to Xu Le. If Zhou Ze himself had taken her by force that night, would Dr. Lin have resisted desperately, screaming "rape"? And then called the police to have Zhou Ze arrested? Accused him of sexual assault?

The rain was still falling.

Zhou Ze tossed the cigarette butt to the ground.

"Did you drive here?"

"Took a taxi," Dr. Lin replied.

"I'll take you back."

"Okay."

No need to dwell on how this seemingly foolish and naive New Year's Eve rainy night stroll began,

At least, the two of them felt that ending it now was most appropriate.

They hailed a ride-sharing car, and Zhou Ze and Dr. Lin got in together.

Fifteen minutes later, they arrived. Zhou Ze accompanied Dr. Lin out of the car. The driver completed the order and drove off.

Their home was just upstairs, but Zhou Ze and Dr. Lin didn't choose to go up immediately.

This scene was a bit like middle school sweethearts walking home together to the girl's apartment building, where they were about to part, lingering and affectionate.

But the atmosphere at this moment was not even as intense as that of shy middle schoolers, like meat broth without salt or MSG—tasteless but a shame to discard.

"Aren't you coming up?" Dr. Lin asked.

"Not going up. Let's talk about it in a while, and we'll handle our business then."

Dr. Lin understood the unspoken meaning in Zhou Ze's words and said, "I'm sorry."

Zhou Ze smiled, then reached out, intending to pat Dr. Lin's shoulder, but after his hand made contact, he suddenly felt an impulse and pulled her into a hug.

Dr. Lin's body stiffened for a moment but she didn't resist.

The two drew slightly closer, but it wasn't a particularly intimate gesture. Compared to their marital connection, it could already be said to be quite distant.

She smelled good; he didn't know what kind of shower gel she used, but it was very pleasant.

"I've always been curious about one thing: Do you have someone else in your heart?" Zhou Ze added, "That 'someone else' could be a man or a woman."

"Yes," Dr. Lin answered honestly, even without hesitation.

Before, her husband had always been timid, which made her feel sorry for him.

Now, her husband seemed like a different person, which also made her shed some burdens.

"Oh," Zhou Ze acknowledged, glancing slightly upwards, wondering if a certain protective color was appearing above his head.

He still felt a little disappointed.

It wasn't love.

It wasn't deep affection.

He barely even knew her,

But no matter what, she was nominally his wife, and yet he was still cuckolded.

Hmm, any man,

No,

Any male,

Would probably not be too happy about such a thing.

"I'm sorry." This was the second apology.

Zhou Ze released her hand, and they slowly separated.

"Saying sorry is too formal," Zhou Ze leaned against a nearby stone block and sat down. The rain had lessened, and there was a small eaves above him.

"I'll give you another sum of money. You can open another bookstore," Dr. Lin said, then added, "I'm sorry."

Zhou Ze originally wanted to wave his hand magnanimously and say, *I don't care about the money.*

But then he thought of his freezer, and his future life.

Zhou Ze suddenly found himself unable to say it.

*What if,*

*What if,*

*What if this woman took it seriously, thought giving money was insulting him, and really didn't offer any compensation?*

"Let's talk in a few days," Zhou Ze shrugged. "How's that guy?"

"He's very handsome, in my opinion," Dr. Lin replied.

It's a man.

Stab.

Another stab.

If it were a woman, it would be easier to accept...

Zhou Ze felt as if the photosynthesis above his head had intensified.

"No chance, right?" Zhou Ze asked a very silly question, and regretted it immediately, but still consoled himself, *I'm asking this for poor Xu Le.*

*You took over his body; now his wife cheated on him. You have to ask why, right?*

*Hmm, that's exactly it.*

"No chance," Dr. Lin replied just as quickly and definitively.

This woman was also a surgeon. Her way of speaking was truly decisive, like using a scalpel, cutting directly to the crucial points without any unnecessary fuss.

Otherwise, the patient would suffer more. In matters of the heart, it seemed the same principle applied.

"Alright, alright, can't compare, can't compare. Never mind, everyone lives their own lives. You go back and deal with your parents," Zhou Ze was a little annoyed.

Dr. Lin nodded, turned, and walked into the stairwell.

Zhou Ze stood up, ready to hail a taxi to leave, but at that moment, an unfamiliar number called him:

"Hello."

"Sir, I've brought my car back."

"That smart?" Zhou Ze was a little surprised. He recognized the voice as that of the previous driver.

"You left a bag in the back seat. I've brought it back for you."

"Oh, thank you."

The car pulled up again downstairs at the apartment complex. Through the car window, the driver handed out a woman's bag.

"Please check it."

"Okay."

Zhou Ze didn't hesitate. He opened Dr. Lin's bag. Inside were just a phone, a wallet, a charging cable, and a few packets of tissues.

He took out the wallet. As soon as Zhou Ze opened it, he froze.

His gaze fixed on the photo slot in the wallet.

There was a photo there.

The woman in the photo looked very young, even... naive, wearing an ill-fitting white coat.

And the man to the right of the girl, Zhou Ze felt a strangely familiar sensation.

He was stunned for a long while.

Only then did Zhou Ze recognize him.

*Isn't this me?*

This was a cropped photo, likely a group photo, but it had been specifically cut to feature only the two of them.

"Is anything missing?" the driver prompted.

"No, it's fine. Thank you, master. You can go."

The driver drove off.

Zhou Ze continued to hold the wallet and look at it. He didn't even think to call Dr. Lin at that moment and tell her to come down for her bag.

Some memories, not quite forgotten, but certainly not often thought of, began to surface.

He vaguely remembered,

Five or six years ago, he seemed to have supervised a group of students on internship, assigned directly from their school. There was a girl, surnamed Lin, and she looked like the girl in the photo.

Girls blossom when they grow up.

A smile appeared on Zhou Ze's lips.

Dr. Lin was once this cute and innocent. Who would have known that five or six years later, she would have grown into such a graceful beauty? He really hadn't noticed this girl's potential to develop.
