Moreover, at the time, he was very perfunctory about the hospital assigning him interns. These students were purely used as "medical dogs" under him.

Zhou Ze shook the wallet in his hand.

"Damn it, no wonder you were still single close to thirty."

This time, unexpectedly, he wasn't cursing Xu Le.

But cursing himself,

"My eyes,

Are truly blind..."

Zhou Ze stretched out his arms and yawned.

The one who cuckolded him,

Was actually himself.

Early morning after the rain, New Year's Day.

Heh heh,

He looked up at the sky.

He solemnly reached out and patted his chest.

Zhou Ze paused,

Then said very seriously:

"Xu Le, you truly are my good brother!

I shall raise your wife; you need not worry."

title: 第十六章 老司機帶帶我
content:
The lingering scent of firecrackers still hung in the air, a bit choking, but perhaps this was the smell of the New Year, commonly known as "nian wei'er."*

Especially for Zhou Ze at this moment, life seemed to have gained a touch of beauty.

It wasn't a romance of eternal vows, nor was it as exaggerated as "mountains crumble, heavens merge."*

It was simply like a child, who usually had no pocket money, finding a ten-yuan bill on the road with no police officers in sight and a small shop conveniently nearby.

After a journey through hell and a change of body, there were still many troubles, both discovered and undiscovered, that needed solving, and his own personality had subtly undergone significant changes.

Recalling his previous life, he emerged from the orphanage, his mind set on climbing step by step with his own hands and abilities. In hindsight, perhaps the reason he overlooked Doctor Lin back then wasn't because she was so dull or ugly five years ago. At that age, a girl should have been blooming, otherwise, she wouldn't have cropped that photo and kept it in her wallet.

Unfortunately, at that time, he had neither the energy nor the inclination to glance at the scenery along the way. His obsession was too strong, a look of bitter resentment, yet he pretended to be so cool, so aloof.

Unlike now, having died once and returned, he felt a sense of "freedom from official burdens,"* a mix of carefree liberation and melancholy.

But no matter what,

The feeling of being secretly loved, even of "loving until death,"

Was indeed wonderful.

He made a call, and Doctor Lin came down again. She descended somewhat hastily, took her women's bag from Zhou Ze's hand, smiled, and didn't say thank you. Given their current relationship, saying "thank you" was even more inappropriate than saying "I'm sorry."

Waving goodbye,

Zhou Ze left a receding figure,

To go back to sleep,

And await tomorrow, which would be even better.

Doctor Lin felt that her husband's mood seemed to have shifted slightly, like a sense of relief.

Perhaps, if both could see things clearly, it was indeed a good thing.

Rather than awkwardly continue to be entangled, it was better to part gracefully and each face life anew.

One could only call it the unpredictability of life. Doctor Lin could never have imagined that inside her husband's body currently resided another soul.

The man she, then an intern, had vaguely adored.

Zhou Ze hailed another car, then squatted by the residential complex gate, smoking. His phone screen kept showing ongoing searches, and Zhou Ze regretted letting the previous driver go. He should have asked him to wait so he could take his car back to the bookstore.

Now, it was quite difficult to hail a car on New Year's Eve.

After waiting for about ten minutes and smoking three cigarettes, Zhou Ze became agitated. He stood up straight and stretched.

Although he wasn't particularly afraid of the cold, walking back would be quite tiring.

Just then, a black sedan drove towards Zhou Ze from the road ahead. It slowed down as it passed him.

"Going somewhere?" The driver poked his head out the window. He had a round face, was middle-aged, stubbly, and wore a black cotton coat.

"Yes," Zhou Ze had no other choice.

"Get in, I won't charge you extra," the driver smiled.

Zhou Ze got in, told him the bookstore's location, and settled on a price. The driver started the car again.

The car seemed new; the seat covers still gave off a plastic and leather smell, and the interior was very clean.

Generally, few people were willing to use a new car for ride-sharing.

"That place is remote," the driver proactively offered Zhou Ze a cigarette, which Zhou Ze accepted.

"Mhm."

"Do you live there?"

"My shop is there."

"Oh, business must not be good, then?" Everyone knew that commercial center had long since died out and lacked any foot traffic.

"Are you not from around here?" Zhou Ze asked.

Tongcheng's local dialect was different from other regional dialects and almost a completely different language style from Mandarin, making it easy to distinguish.

"My family's from Rongcheng. I work here," the driver lit his cigarette. "Smoke, don't be shy."

Zhou Ze also lit a cigarette, took a puff, and frowned slightly. The smoke tasted unusually mild.

"Not going back for New Year's?"

"Wife and kids are home, no problem. I'm not going back; I'm hoping to earn a bit more money," the driver extended his hand out the window to flick ash. "I have four kids."

"Impressive," Zhou Ze praised.

"It's tough," the driver smacked his lips. "My wife's first born was a boy, and the second was also a boy. I wanted a daughter, and then the third was another boy. Thankfully, the fourth was finally a girl. I'm satisfied now."

"That's good," Zhou Ze echoed, took another drag from his cigarette, then tossed it out the window. The smoke was so mild, it was like smoking rolled paper.

"I don't have old-fashioned ideas, nor do I prefer boys over girls. I just like kids and wanted to have more, haha." The driver's words flowed more freely when talking about his children.

"The fine for the youngest hasn't been paid yet. When it's time for school, I'll go pay the money and get the household registration done. Oh, by the way, what kind of shop do you run?"

"A bookstore."

"How's business?" The driver touched a sore spot.

"Not great."

"Yeah, people can buy books online now, and there are coupons."

Ahead on the road, there was a car accident. Traffic police had set up roadblocks, reducing the four-lane road to a single lane. Thankfully, there weren't many cars on the road late on New Year's Eve, so it shouldn't cause too much delay.

"It's bad luck to get into a car accident on New Year's," the driver exhaled a smoke ring, his tone somewhat like a leader, tinged with criticism.

Zhou Ze leaned back in his seat, adopting a more comfortable posture, and asked:

"Is this car new?"

"Yeah, my son gave it to me."

Zhou Ze smiled. "How old are you? How old is your son?"

"Hehe," the driver narrowed his eyes. "My son is capable. These days, ambition isn't limited by age. If you have hands, feet, and a brain, and aren't constantly cursed by bad luck, how can you remain poor?"

"That's true," Zhou Ze agreed, nodding.

"Beep beep... Beep beep..."

A car behind them seemed to be in a hurry to get home, honking frequently, urging the cars ahead to move faster.

"Keep honking, you'll honk yourselves to hell."

The driver's temper flared a bit. He leaned out the window again and swore at the car behind him.

But the cars behind him honked even more frequently, as if deliberately demonstrating.

"Hey!"

The driver made to push open his door, ready to get out and have a proper discussion.

Just then, the traffic police directing traffic ahead gestured for the cars to pass quickly. The driver sheepishly sat back, started the car, and drove on.

"Business isn't good today, oh," the driver began to lament again. "I should have just gone home to see my wife and kids."

"It's not bad," Zhou Ze said noncommittally. He saw that the noodle shop next door was doing quite well. Most competitors were closed for the New Year, so even if demand was slightly lower during the holiday, business was still better than before.

Especially considering how long Zhou Ze had just waited for a ride without anyone accepting.

"Heh, it's not good, no." The driver still shook his head. "I don't dare rest. My kids' tuition, I have to send money home every month. I work during the day, and then drive for half the night. This life, it's pretty dull. Even this cigarette, I can't afford a better one."

This cigarette of yours... seems fake.

Zhou Ze took out his own cigarette, pulled one out, and fiddled with it in his hand.

"But it's good, too. The internet is convenient now. I video call my wife and kids before sleeping when I get home. It's really nice to see them." A relaxed expression appeared on the driver's face.

Zhou Ze closed his eyes slightly. He couldn't sleep, but at this moment, he didn't feel like talking or chatting.

But even without Zhou Ze's feedback or reaction, the driver continued to talk. It was New Year's, and he was alone in a foreign land, naturally lonely.

From naming his children, to their schools, to his parents, to the customs of his village, the driver rambled on.

Zhou Ze eventually just rested his forehead against the car window and urged, "Driver, please drive faster."

This driver was driving too slowly, perhaps only thirty miles per hour.

This was a highway, after all.

Zhou Ze even wondered if the other person was too lonely and intentionally driving slowly to find someone to chat with, but Zhou Ze had no interest in being a confidante.

"Hehe, it's a new car, and I'm not too familiar with it yet. I don't dare drive too fast, oh." The driver caressed the steering wheel dearly. "This car isn't worth much, it's even very cheap, but it's my eldest son's heartfelt gift. I have to cherish and treasure it.

I'll try to use this car to do business for a few years, and after my eldest son finds a partner, I'll get him a house. I'll take care of them one by one. I don't want the older ones to have to carry the younger ones; that's not fair to the older ones. After all, I'm the father who decided to have them. As long as I can still work and have a job, I have to grit my teeth and bear it. I'm not an irresponsible person, and I won't do something like just bringing them into the world and not raising them."

Zhou Ze frowned slightly,

He felt a bit annoyed,

Then he lit one of his own cigarettes and took a puff,

"Driver, seriously, please go faster." Zhou Ze was starting to miss his freezer, and he also regretted not asking Doctor Lin to drive him back.

"Don't rush, young man. It's New Year's, and we're fated to meet, aren't we? No need to rush. I understand, I understand. I'm an old driver..."

Zhou Ze flicked his cigarette ash,

Accidentally missing the window,

A clump of ash landed on the inside of the car door.

Immediately after,

The inside of the car door was burned by the ash, creating a hole,

A thumb-sized hole,

And the cold wind kept whistling in through the small hole.

---
* **年味兒 (nian wei'er):** The atmosphere or feeling of the New Year.
* **山無棱天地合 (shān wú léng tiān dì hé):** An idiom from an ancient Chinese folk song, meaning "mountains crumble, heavens merge." It is used to describe an eternal, unchanging love, usually implying an oath of undying love.
* **無官一身輕 (wú guān yī shēn qīng):** An idiom meaning "without official burdens, one feels light." It describes a feeling of relaxation and freedom after resigning from an official position or being freed from heavy responsibilities.

title: 第十七章 究竟，救了個什麼東西（修）
content:
For someone who doesn’t understand cars, buying one can be a real headache. You inevitably ask friends or relatives who are knowledgeable, as some cars do have their drawbacks and potential issues, such as quality or performance problems.

But ultimately,

A car door that can be directly poked through with a cigarette butt,

Can you still vaguely describe that as a car with quality issues?

All of this only indicates one thing:

This is a…

Paper car!

The driver was middle-aged, but his eldest son was probably only elementary school age. Because of this, the driver said the car was “sent” to him by his son.

Actually, the word “sent” (捎, shāo) here,

Could also be written as “burned” (燒, shāo).

His father died,

And his son burned him a paper car.

Zhou Ze shook his head. To be honest, he really hadn’t noticed it beforehand. It was only after he got into the car that he belatedly felt something was off, but he still wanted to pretend to be clueless.

He himself was a stowaway. He didn't harbor the lofty ambition of becoming a Celestial Master.

After all, he was also a ghost.

If he were to raise the banner of exorcising demons and defending the righteous path, it would truly be no different from a traitor, only a “ghost traitor.”

He placed his palm over the small hole, covering it, and Zhou Ze feigned drowsiness, half-closing his eyes, as if nothing had happened.

Zhou Ze remembered that when he was in the orphanage, there was a teacher who usually led physical education classes and also had a part-time job – gatekeeping.

And because his surname was Qin, the children at the time called him – Gatekeeper Old Man Qin.

Old Man Qin was very good at telling stories, often ghost stories. He seemed quite satisfied when the children looked frightened after hearing his stories. For this, the dean had spoken to him a few times, but he didn't curb his habit.

It was only before Zhou Ze left the orphanage to study outside that Old Man Qin passed away from a myocardial infarction.

Zhou Ze remembered a ghost story Old Man Qin told, called “Ghosts Carrying a Sedan Chair.”

Legend has it that in ancient times, there were many kinds of ghosts. Most people, after dying, went directly to the Underworld, entered the Yellow Springs, drank Meng Po Soup, and re-entered the cycle of reincarnation. Very few ghosts remained in the Human Realm.

But some ghosts did remain. They might have known they were dead, or they might not have, but regardless, they might still have been doing what they did in life.

For example, sedan chair bearers.

They would appear on roads in desolate areas or late at night, asking people if they wanted to ride in a sedan chair. The price was extremely cheap. After the person rode the sedan chair to their destination, money and goods were exchanged.

But for living people to do business with ghosts and enjoy services provided by ghosts, it would never be that simple and ordinary. What ghosts carrying a sedan chair wanted was not mere money, that filthy lucre, but your lifespan, or your vital energy.

Underground, ghosts carried sedan chairs for figures like Yama. What status did a living person have? Were they worthy?

It was like an eighty-year-old man kneeling before you; it would shorten your life.

Zhou Ze remembered this story, and very clearly. In fact, Zhou Ze still remembered many of the stories Old Man Qin told, even after he became an adult and started working.

Because Zhou Ze knew that the day before Old Man Qin suddenly fell ill and died, Old Man Qin, who usually only guarded the gate and never entered the back courtyard, exceptionally walked into the children’s dormitory, looking at room after room, child after child. Zhou Ze happened to be awake at the time and witnessed this scene.

It seemed as if Old Man Qin knew his end was near and came to say goodbye in advance.

Just as a fart from Warren Buffett can make people feel it contains profound financial secrets,

A person who knows they might kick the bucket tomorrow, his ghost stories can no longer be dismissed as mere absurd tales.

The driver was still rambling on, continuing to brag, and Zhou Ze remained calm in the back.

Shorten lifespan?

Lose vital energy?

Zhou Ze wasn't too afraid; he wasn't a living person, he was also a ghost.

To put it indelicately, although Zhou Ze didn't understand the stratification and hierarchy of ghosts, being able to walk in the sunlight, meet living people, and open a business, he must be far superior to the lonely wandering ghosts outside, right?

Moreover, even the faceless woman in the hellish pond could be injured by his fingernails. When facing other ghostly entities, Zhou Ze actually felt quite confident.

"These days, more people are buying cars and driving, and more people are breaking rules," the driver continued to chat. Even though Zhou Ze didn't respond or join in, he could still keep talking.

"When the forest gets big, all kinds of birds appear. In short, if you really get angry at every single one, you'll truly live many years less.

Although I know I shouldn't get angry, some people go out with a 'Hit me! You damned jerk, hit me!' sign taped to their foreheads. It's truly infuriating."

Zhou Ze narrowed his eyes. He felt a bit sleepy, even wanted to sleep.

But he knew he couldn't sleep. Therefore, this clear sensation he was feeling must be false.

Zhou Ze suddenly let out a silent chuckle.

He understood why this driver had been chattering endlessly the whole way. It wasn't that he didn't know his constant talking was annoying.

It was because Zhou Ze hadn't fallen asleep, so the driver had to keep talking to pretend everything was normal.

He wanted Zhou Ze to fall asleep,

And Zhou Ze’s reaction to sleep had always been quite slow.

Zhou Ze's lips curved into a smile. He rested his hand on the car seat and closed his eyes.

Sleep.

The car began to slow down.

The driver's voice also grew softer as Zhou Ze drifted off to sleep.

At the same time, the driver specifically turned to look behind him.

However, at that moment, a struggling expression suddenly appeared on the driver's face. Finally, he shook his head forcefully, sighed, and continued driving forward.

It seemed they were almost at the bookstore.

Zhou Ze wasn’t sure how a ghost driving a paper car could transport him, a person with a physical body.

This was hard to explain, as physics had no "ghost-mechanics" branch.

Furthermore, ancient Chinese legends mentioned "Yellow Turban warriors" and "Qimen Dunjia" (Mystical Doors and Hidden Jia). He guessed it was probably similar in principle to those.

Zhou Ze slowly awoke, because he sensed that the driver in front of him was gradually emanating light.

Interesting.

He seemed to have been encountering good ghosts lately.

This driver should have "collected his payment" from him, but he couldn't bring himself to do it. It was probably his first time doing something like this, and he couldn't go through with it. In this struggle, he achieved self-liberation and redemption.

He began to dissipate.

After dissipating, he would enter the Underworld and the cycle of reincarnation.

From this, it was evident that not all the "nonsense" the driver had spoken earlier was false. He had four children, he enjoyed being a father, and he worked hard to earn money to support his family and provide a good upbringing for his children.

He was a good father, and his character was quite decent. After becoming a ghost, when he tried the "ghost carrying a sedan chair" business, he ultimately couldn't bring himself to be ruthless.

Zhou Ze slowly raised his head and opened his eyes. The driver didn't notice, still driving along.

Gradually, Zhou Ze saw light shining in from outside. Through the window, he could see the bustling traffic on the road.

The driver was about to dissipate.

This must be a memory from the driver's life.

It's similar to the principle that lightning combined with a special environment can record a segment of an image.

Zhou Ze subconsciously lit another cigarette. Since the driver had already found self-liberation, it wouldn't matter even if he burned this car now.

Music was playing in the car, a currently popular song called “Coolness”;

The driver was humming along as he drove. He must have just finished a big fare and was in a good mood, planning to go back, buy some peanuts, and video chat with his children for a while. Though life was tough, it was quite pleasant.

Just then, Zhou Ze saw a minibus appear on the road in front of the car.

It must have been a school bus, with a school emblem and the words "XXX Elementary School" printed on it.

Zhou Ze didn't pay it much mind at first, but then a girl in the back seat of the car suddenly stood up. She was facing the back of the car, and even from inside the car behind, she could be clearly seen through the car window.

The girl was wearing a blue pleated skirt and was very cute.

Zhou Ze frowned slightly.

He knew this girl. He had saved her, and she was said to have woken up. Lin, the doctor, had recently told him that the girl’s father wanted to host a thank-you dinner and had planned to invite him.

Zhou Ze's gaze darkened. So, this driver was the culprit behind that car accident?

So many children injured,

And if he hadn't intervened, some children would have died.

"What a beautiful girl, just like my youngest."

The driver muttered to himself. This was the last memory from his life, so he didn't realize there was someone sitting in the back seat at that moment.

Zhou Ze looked around. He didn't think the driver was drunk, nor did he seem to have any other issues. So, what caused the driver to crash into the school bus? What led to that car accident?

Was it a chain collision caused by nearby vehicles?

Just then,

The girl, who had been standing at the very back of the school bus wearing a pleated skirt, suddenly opened her mouth. Her tongue shot out.

Yes,

It shot out,

Like a red carpet for a new bride, it directly extended, very long… very long… long enough to make one's scalp tingle.

At the same time,

The girl stared mockingly at the driver who was driving in front of her.

"Mommy, a ghost!!!!!!!!!!!!!!"

In a panic, the driver stomped on the accelerator, and the car slammed directly into the school bus in front.

"Boom!"

Sparks flew,

Zhou Ze stood at the entrance of the bookstore,

On the ground around him were the unburnt ashes of the paper car, drifting with the wind, swirling and falling, turning into the last scattering of specks.

Zhou Ze had no injuries, not a single one.

And the driver had kept his promise, delivering him to his destination.

But Zhou Ze wasn't in a hurry to go back into the bookstore.

He still held the cigarette between his fingers, slowly burning.

Taking a deep breath,

Zhou Ze licked his lips.

"Uncle, you can't smoke in the hospital," the girl's voice still echoed in his ears.

What,

Exactly,

Had he saved?

title: 第十八章 風波再起！
content:
The next morning, Zhou Ze, after his usual wash-up, went to the noodle shop next door. This had gradually become a habit for him. When eating was no longer an enjoyable process, it simply became a task. For tasks, simple and efficient was best, and nowhere was more convenient and quick than Xu Qinglang's place.

"Bitter gourd juice." Xu Qinglang placed a large glass cup in front of Zhou Ze, then served him a plate of egg fried rice.

Zhou Ze cautiously took a sip. The moment the liquid entered his throat, he felt an unbearable bitterness coating his lips and tongue. Immediately after swallowing, even his intestines and stomach began to knot up.

After about ten seconds, Zhou Ze recovered, letting out a long sigh.

It was truly bitter.

"Haha, powerful enough, right?" Xu Qinglang wore an expression that begged for praise, then sat down in front of Zhou Ze. "Speaking of which, you have quite the heavy taste. You can't eat without drinking this stuff?"

Zhou Ze composed himself, then picked up the full glass of bitter gourd juice and chugged it down. Immediately after, he quickly grabbed his chopsticks and began to wolf down the egg fried rice in front of him.

One minute later, Zhou Ze finished his meal, set down the plate, and closed his eyes.

"That eating style, it's exactly like a demon crawling out of hell," Xu Qinglang teased.

Whether it was just teasing or had another meaning was unknown.

Zhou Ze opened his eyes and glanced at the other man. On the seventh day when the five migrant worker brothers returned, it was normal for his sister-in-law and wife not to see them. However, this noodle shop owner could see them, otherwise he wouldn't have made those five portions of braised pork with rice.

But between the two of them, there was an unspoken understanding to acknowledge without explicitly stating it. Perhaps that was the way to get along.

"Why aren't you taking orders today?" Zhou Ze asked.

In the previous days, even on Lunar New Year's Eve, Xu Qinglang's phone was constantly receiving delivery orders. Today, however, seemed much quieter, with no delivery drivers coming to pick up food.

"Taking a break." Xu Qinglang took out a cigarette, put one in his mouth, and offered one to Zhou Ze.

Although it was strange to take a break after Lunar New Year's Eve when he didn't rest then,

As a man with over twenty apartments,

He certainly had the capital to be capricious.

"Do you know about 'ghost sedan'?" Zhou Ze asked. He remembered last night's events vividly, but he didn't rush to do anything; he simply went home and slept in his freezer.

Zhou Ze himself was the one who had saved the person. If there were any problems, Zhou Ze didn't want to get involved.

He was cautiously and lively living his own small life. If he encountered anything normally, he would help if it was convenient, but he wouldn't force anything.

Even if that little girl in the lily dress had some issues, it was no longer Zhou Ze's business to handle.

"Ghost sedan?" Xu Qinglang was startled for a moment, then chuckled, "Heh heh, there were many on Lunar New Year's Eve, right? They say that during the New Year, people burn scriptures and paper money, so ghosts also have spare cash and can afford to take a taxi."

Xu Qinglang continued to spout nonsense, then yawned. "By the way, why is your bookstore still not open?"

"I'll open it in the evening."

"Alright, being willful." Xu Qinglang took out his phone and glanced at it. "How about we go see a movie this afternoon?"

The scene,

Instantly fell into an awkward silence.

"No," Zhou Ze refused.

"See? You're not giving me face at all. After all my hard work concocting new juices for you, you're not even willing to go see a movie with me.

Men, they're all no good."

"............" Zhou Ze.

"My apologies, I forgot I was a man myself." Xu Qinglang shook his head with a touch of melancholy, looking as if he regretted not being born a woman.

"Did you experience some psychological trauma when you were little?" Zhou Ze asked. "I know some psychologists who might be able to help you."

Xu Qinglang scoffed,

"Heterosexuality is just a deviation created for reproduction; true love can only be between the same sex."

"I beg to differ."

"Those whose paths diverge cannot plan together."*

Their post-meal conversation ended on a sour note.

Zhou Ze returned to his bookstore, opened the door, thought for a moment, and decided not to lock it. He simply sat behind the counter, opened his computer, and sent a WeChat message to Dr. Lin:

"Go see a movie this afternoon?"

After about ten minutes, Dr. Lin replied:

"Working."

Just because it was New Year's didn't mean people wouldn't get sick or have accidents. Zhou Ze, who used to be a doctor himself, knew how much "flexibility" hospital holidays had.

He could understand it, but it was still somewhat unsatisfying.

Zhou Ze really wanted to tell her that he was Zhou Ze, not some random Xu Le.

But he was worried that the outcome would be Dr. Lin being scared out of her wits, even collapsing the vague, unrequited crush she might have had. Of course, most importantly, the fewer people who knew certain things, the better.

Someone would come to catch him,

Zhou Ze knew this very well,

He was waiting, and while waiting, he didn't choose to cower in a dark corner like a rat in a sewer. He still needed to live, and to live very normally. Otherwise, it would have been better not to have come out of hell, and just followed the main group down the Road to the Yellow Springs.

As for his neighbor next door, whether he had figured it out, Zhou Ze didn't know, and didn't care to know.

"In the evening, then."

Dr. Lin sent another message.

Zhou Ze smiled. He felt his smile was idiotic, exactly like going back to middle school when he saw the class study monitor glance at him shyly.

In the past, he had lived too laboriously.

This lifetime, he had to live a bit more freely and loosely.

Many truths in life can only truly be understood and seen clearly just before death or when old, but by the time you understand them, you've already lost the chance to start over.

Zhou Ze cherished his current life and opportunities very much.

A red sedan stopped on the road in front of the bookstore, and two women got out.

One was under thirty, the other looked to be only five or six.

The woman wore a red dress, her hair flowing. Though a mother, she still exuded a captivating allure, able to stir one's heart even more.

The girl wore overalls, and was likely bundled in several layers of warm clothing, like a small zongzi, adorably naive.

But upon seeing the girl, Zhou Ze's eyes instinctively narrowed.

Those who come are not good,

Those who are good do not come.

He hadn't gone looking for her,

Yet she had come to him.

He had heard Dr. Lin say that at the appreciation dinner, the girl had called him "uncle," and Zhou Ze had been secretly pleased. Now, upon reflection, she had never intended to let him go.

Ultimately,

The father of four children, his death, was because of this girl.

The bookstore door was pushed open. The woman curiously surveyed her surroundings, while the girl timidly walked up to Zhou Ze's counter, looked at him, and in a soft, sweet voice, said:

"Hello, Uncle."

Zhou Ze nodded, somewhat reservedly,

While actually wondering if he should just use his fingernails to strangle the girl to death.

"Hello, I'm Rui Rui's mother."

The woman walked up to Zhou Ze and placed a gift box on the counter.

"Thank you."

The woman bowed to Zhou Ze,

With deep sincerity.

"You're welcome," Zhou Ze remained seated.

He really wanted to pretend everything was normal, so that the girl wouldn't notice anything.

But it was too difficult,

Even an Oscar-winning actor,

After seeing the driver's memories from last night,

Would probably find it hard to remain normal in front of this girl, right?

Since he couldn't pretend convincingly, he simply wouldn't pretend.

"Mommy, I want to read a book here," Rui Rui said to the woman.

"Alright, Mommy is going to get her hair done first. You stay here with Uncle and read." The woman smiled at Zhou Ze. "Thank you for your trouble."

"It's no trouble."

"Only through Dr. Lin did I know you run a shop here."

Busybody.

"You and Dr. Lin are truly a perfect match."

That was a disingenuous compliment. Xu Le himself wouldn't believe it.

The woman drove off, leaving her daughter behind. This was a bookstore, and Zhou Ze was half her daughter's savior, and Dr. Lin's husband, so she felt completely at ease leaving her daughter there, with no worries about anything happening.

Next, Rui Rui picked out a picture book herself and sat on a plastic stool, reading.

She wasn't noisy, nor did she fuss.

She didn't ask for a drink, nor did she clamor for snacks.

Zhou Ze sat behind the counter, watching her.

Just then, Xu Qinglang walked in, saw the little girl who looked like a porcelain doll, and immediately went over and picked her up.

"Oh, what a cute little girl!"

"Thank you, big sister," Rui Rui replied.

Xu Qinglang's smile bloomed like a chrysanthemum, becoming even brighter.

The little girl's flattery had hit Xu Qinglang's soft spot.

Zhou Ze, however, remained poker-faced, still sitting there.

"Come out, I have something to tell you," Xu Qinglang put the child down and pointed at Zhou Ze.

Zhou Ze and Xu Qinglang walked outside.

"People from the plaza came and asked if we wanted to terminate the contract. They can refund our prepaid rent."

"No refund for now," Zhou Ze didn't want to make more trouble for the time being. Besides, he didn't have enough capital; even with the prepaid rent, it wouldn't be enough to open another shop.

"I thought so too." Xu Qinglang nodded, indicating he understood. "So, I'll represent you in the negotiations?"

"Alright."

"Good, it's settled then."

The two stood outside the door and smoked a cigarette before parting ways.

When Zhou Ze turned around and pushed open the bookstore door to go inside,

He found that the little girl was no longer on the row of plastic stools. The picture book was placed on one of them.

Zhou Ze frowned,

Looked up,

At the staircase, he heard the sound of small leather boots,

The little girl emerged from there, half her body visible, half hidden by the wall.

She had just,

Been on his second floor.

---
* An idiom meaning "people with different principles cannot work together or share a common goal."

title: 第十九章 不公平！
content:
"Did you go up to look?" Zhou Ze asked.

The little loli shook her head, "It's dark up there, I can't see anything clearly."

No sooner had she spoken than the little loli slowly walked down, then stood in front of Zhou Ze.

She was very short, dressed in many layers, and her delicate face was like a masterpiece of art.

But Zhou Ze knew that her tongue could be very, very long, so long it made one's scalp tingle.

"Uncle, I'm going back to reading."

The little loli smiled innocently, sat back down on the small plastic stool, picked up the illustrated children's book, and continued to read it with relish.

Zhou Ze stood behind her, his hands clasped behind his back.

Choke her to death,
Choke her to death,
No matter what her intentions are,
There's no need to keep up this charade!

This voice echoed in Zhou Ze's mind; it wasn't anyone else's voice, but Zhou Ze's own thoughts.

Compared to Xu Qinglang, the owner of the noodle shop next door, this little loli in front of him stirred up a great deal of irritation and dislike in Zhou Ze.

He was the one who saved her,
She was very cute,
Very sensible,
Very well-behaved,
Very refined and polite,
Possessing a rare sense of propriety and decorum for a child her age.

Perhaps,
Precisely because her initial impression on him was so, so good, when Zhou Ze witnessed her true nature, the twisted human relationship and the shocking contrast made Zhou Ze's dislike and repulsion even stronger.

The little loli continued reading her book, seemingly oblivious and unconcerned with Zhou Ze behind her.

Zhou Ze stared at her, seeing even the fine downy hairs on the back of her neck clearly.

To choke,
Or not to choke,
Ultimately,
To choke or not to choke?

…………

"Mom and Dad, your son is resting today."

Inside the back room, Xu Qinglang arranged several cold dishes and hot dishes on a small table, along with two cups of wine.

One cup was Maotai, his late father's favorite kind.
The other cup was homemade rice wine; his late mother didn't drink alcohol and strongly disliked her father drinking, but occasionally at banquets, if the host was too enthusiastic, his mother would only drink a little rice wine.
His mother often said that rice wine was nourishing.

At the east and west corners of the small table, there were also two candlesticks, their flames flickering.

Two human skins hung behind the chairs, swaying without a breeze.

Xu Qinglang first toasted his father, then had a small sip with his mother.

Picking up his chopsticks, he said to his parents:
"Eat, eat, Dad, you're trying to snatch my meat again!"

He picked up several pieces of meat for himself and devoured them.

He remembered from his childhood that his father always pretended to snatch meat from him, but each time he would urge him to gobble it down, leaving his mouth full and unable to swallow.
And his mother would then scold his father while gently patting his back.

Today was the first day of the Chinese New Year.
Most people would offer sacrifices to their ancestors before the New Year,
But Xu Qinglang was different; he did it on this day because his parents had died together on this day in an accident.

New Year,
While in the eyes of ordinary people, it might have lost some of its "flavor of the year" compared to the past, for Xu Qinglang, it meant the return of a heartbreaking moment.

Taking a deep breath,
Xu Qinglang smiled,
And said:
"Dad, Mom."

He pursed his lips,
Xu Qinglang poured himself another glass of baijiu, then drank it all in one gulp.
The spicy alcohol made his already delicate and charming face even redder and more tender.

He was a man,
Yet he possessed a beauty that could ruin men.
If he had lived in ancient times, he would surely have been a plaything for emperors and nobles. Of course, even in modern times, if he wished, he could still thrive effortlessly.
How terrifying a man who could turn straight men gay was, went without saying.

After much hesitation,
And much contemplation,
Xu Qinglang finally couldn't hold back,
And said:
"The person next door... the person next door, I'll find a chance to ask him, ask him... ask him how exactly he came back!"

Xu Qinglang wasn't drunk, but his speech was a bit slurred.
Clearly,
He knew in his heart that the person next door wouldn't simply sit down and tell him the answer as if they were just chatting.
This process,
Would ultimately be somewhat unpleasant, and would require him to use some methods.

The two human skins stopped swaying,
As if displeased.

"Dad, Mom, it's okay, your son will definitely bring you back to life!"

"Clatter!"
"Clatter!"

Two pairs of chopsticks fell to the ground.
Xu Qinglang, holding his own chopsticks, was stunned for a moment,
But still shook his head,
"No, I can't listen to you this time. Even if you disagree, I'll still pry it out of him!"

…………

Choke,
Or not to choke?

Zhou Ze was still pondering this question.
He didn't know why he was so hesitant, nor did he understand what exactly he was struggling with.

He was a ghost,
No longer the doctor from his previous life.
He was dangerous, and his situation was very precarious. Therefore, he knew he should nip all dangers in the bud.

This little loli was a threat to him.
She had come to find him,
She had come on her own accord,
Just like her soul spoke to him that day,
She,
Must have been eyeing him for a long time.

Even children understood the story of the farmer and the snake. Zhou Ze didn't believe that everything would be fine just because he had saved her once.
In fact, most animosity in this world evolves from kindness.

Zhou Ze's fingernails had slowly grown long, and at the same time, wisps of black mist were swirling around his fingertips.
At the same time,
A black glow was also swirling in the depths of Zhou Ze's eyes.

Must choke her to death,
Choke her to death!

Zhou Ze repeated to himself in his heart. He had managed to be reborn with great difficulty; he still had a life, and things he wanted to do.

He still wanted to be lazy, still wanted to reminisce, still wanted to think,
He didn't want to be like the old and young on the Road to the Underworld, numb and hollow, knowing only to walk forward step by step.

Zhou Ze raised his hands,
Slowly moving them towards the little loli.

The little loli was reading, very earnestly, with a smile on her lips, very cute and endearing.

Suddenly, she felt two fingers placed on her temples.

She asked somewhat puzzled, "Uncle?"

"Let me massage you, it protects your eyes."

"Mm." The little loli responded, continuing to read her book.

A well-applied pressure came from her temples, and the little loli felt very comfortable.

Afterward,
The little loli watched her uncle quietly walk to the chair behind the counter and sit down.

"Uncle, what's wrong?"

"Nothing." Zhou Ze waved his hand.

The little loli continued to lower her head and read.
Then,
"Smack!" a crisp sound.
The little loli looked up, again towards the counter, and saw that one side of Zhou Ze's face was red.

"Uncle?"

"Swatting a mosquito." Zhou Ze let out a complete sigh of relief, then leaned back in the chair, a sigh escaping his heart: Damn it, I still couldn't do it, why am I so useless?

The little loli apparently didn't realize there would be mosquitoes in the middle of winter, but she still stood up and looked around, as if helping Zhou Ze look for the mosquito.

Damn it,
Keep faking it,
You're a drama queen!
Still acting!
And so convincingly!
Hurry up and stick out your tongue,
Let's have a fight!
It'd be great if you killed me or I killed you,
Still hiding behind a loli face, banking on me being unable to strike?
I... really can't.
Shit!

Zhou Ze felt a bit helpless. He turned and went to the restroom, turned on the faucet, and splashed cold water hard on his face.

"I used to be a doctor, healing people was instinct, it was my profession.
You're already a ghost,
How can you still be such a goodie-two-shoes!
Useless thing!"

Zhou Ze started cursing himself in the mirror.

Then, Zhou Ze also noticed that the frequency of him cursing himself seemed to have surpassed the frequency of him cursing Xu Le lately.

Meanwhile, the little loli, who was originally sitting and reading in the bookstore, put down her book at this moment.
She looked meaningfully at the direction of the restroom door, but didn't walk towards it. Instead, she walked out of the bookstore,
And went next door.

…………

"Dad, Mom, no matter how much you try to dissuade me, it's no use. I want you to sit down and eat with me properly. He can do it, and I can turn you into this too!
Our family can continue to live together, just like before."

Xu Qinglang was still rambling.

Suddenly,
The two human skins that were originally hanging by the small table began to sway wildly as if possessed.
Xu Qinglang's face showed a look of shock. He looked up at the yellow talismans pasted above his inner room, only to find that those talismans had somehow turned gray.

He violently lifted the curtain and rushed out,
He saw a little girl standing in his noodle shop.

The girl opened her mouth,
A long tongue stretched out,
Very long,
Very long,
Terrifyingly long!

"The Underworld has order, the deceased shall pass."

A somber child's voice came from the girl's mouth.

The next moment, the two human skins in the back room began to wilt and decay, losing their luster and flexibility. Two white streams of air dripped out, landing beside the little girl, transforming into the images of a man and a woman in their middle age.

They swayed unsteadily,
Seemingly having forgotten everything,
Knowing only to walk aimlessly, step by step, along the long tongue the girl had extended from her mouth, as if the girl's tongue was their destination, leading to some unknown place.

Gradually, their figures became fainter and blurrier.

"You... you actually... you actually are..."

Xu Qinglang pointed at the sweet-talking little loli he had recently held, his face filled with shock. But when he saw his parents slowly disappearing,
He immediately tried to rush over hysterically. However, his feet seemed to be shackled, unable to run, and he fell heavily to the ground instead.

He stretched out his hand, pointing at his parents, and began to plead:
"Don't take them away, don't take them away,
I haven't harmed anyone,
I have never harmed anyone,
I just want our family to be together,
They haven't harmed anyone either!
No, no, please, I beg you, I beg you…………"

However, faced with Xu Qinglang's tearful pleas,
The little loli remained unmoved. Only after the two souls had completely vanished did she retract her long tongue, and then, she reverted back to her adorable loli image.

Xu Qinglang felt as if two pieces had been forcibly gouged out of his chest.
His parents,
Had completely left him.

Xu Qinglang's eyes were bloodshot. He pounded the tiled floor with all his might, hitting it hard.
Suddenly,
He seemed to remember something,
And immediately pointed at the next door, shouting:
"He's not human either, he's not human either,
Why don't you take him, why don't you take him!
This isn't fair, what you're doing isn't fair!
He's not human either,
Why do you only take my parents,
He's not human either,
It's not fair,
It's not fair!!!!!"

title: 第二十章 不患寡而患不均
content:
The bathroom wasn't really well-renovated by Xu Le; it only had a simple washbasin and a squat toilet, not even a showerhead. As for the second floor, never mind a bed, there wasn't even a straw mat; it was purely used as a small storage room because Xu Le used to go home every day.

Even with a pair of in-laws who looked down on him,

Even with a bossy sister-in-law,

Even with a wife who didn't sleep with him,

Xu Le would still leisurely go home every evening after finishing the few tasks at the bookstore and locking up.

This was life.

It wasn't about dignity,

Nor was it about freedom,

But he found it sweet.

He was a wimp, he was a coward, he lacked ambition.

Because he was Xu Le, not some historical figure who left a name behind, so everyone thought he didn't matter.

If he were overlaid with the identity of an ancient person, then Xu Le's life would be seen as great wisdom veiled by foolishness, adding far too much flavor for no reason.

Zhou Ze couldn't appreciate Xu Le's flavor. He grew up in an orphanage, and though his feelings of inferiority didn't show, they were indeed always present. Thus, he was sensitive and he worked hard, whether in his studies, his work, or his own life; it was always like this, always striving to be the best and most outstanding.

However, at this moment, looking at his wet face in the mirror, a hint of pity emerged in Zhou Ze's heart.

Pity for Xu Le, and also pity for himself.

Everyone has their own cage; it's just that the style and size of the cage differ, but there's always a cage.

Zhou Ze didn't want to be some Ghost King, nor did he hope to wield power in the human world by relying on his special abilities. On one hand, he knew that if he were too high-profile, something bad would probably happen immediately. On the other hand, his previous life was already very tiring, and this life he wanted to live differently.

No matter what, he wanted to survive, to continue living in this physical body.

He spread his palms before him; his nails had long receded, showing no abnormality.

Zhou Ze smiled.

Forget it.

Perhaps it was just what he deserved.

Wiping his face with a towel, then his hands, Zhou Ze exited the bathroom. But when he re-emerged, the struggle that had been on his face was gone, replaced by a certain nonchalance.

The little loli was still sitting on the plastic stool, intently reading her illustrated book.

"Uncle, Rui Rui's thirsty."

The little loli called out to Zhou Ze.

Like a pet charming its owner.

Zhou Ze nodded, poured a cup of water into a paper cup, lukewarm, and brought it to the little loli.

The little loli took the cup, took a sip, and her lips curved into a crescent moon smile.

Zhou Ze simply sat down on the tiled floor, reached out and ruffled the little loli's head, openly, without any pretense of caution.

Time slowly passed.

The little loli continued to read,

Zhou Ze continued to lie beside her.

One big, one small,

Coexisting peacefully.

The little loli would bring the interesting stories she read to Zhou Ze and share them with him, and Zhou Ze would respond, telling her some profound fables or other small stories.

He didn't know how much time had passed when the red car drove by again.

The girl's mother pushed open the door and thanked Zhou Ze. Her hair looked the same as when she arrived. Zhou Ze curved his lips; he really wanted to suggest that the woman go talk to that hair salon and demand an explanation, saying they shouldn't fool people like that.

Of course, if he really said that, the woman might blame him for being nosy.

The little loli bowed to Zhou Ze and said thank you, then left with her mother.

From beginning to end, the little loli didn't look back at him.

Gone was gone.

Zhou Ze walked to the counter and picked up the gift box the woman had given him earlier. Only then did he discover there was a stack of cash inside, three thousand yuan.

Not bad.

Zhou Ze didn't think of returning it.

He was short on money; he'd take it for now.

Zhou Ze felt that he had come to terms with things, like an immortal cultivator suddenly achieving clarity of thought.

But he also felt like he was just letting things go to hell, come what may, he'd be carefree.

However, at least he felt much more relaxed now.

Zhou Ze casually picked up a book with a very large cover from the bookshelf. It was "Master Calligraphy Appreciation," a completely unsellable item. He wondered if Xu Le's head had been repeatedly crushed by a large iron gate back then to even stock such a book.

He flipped it open at random.

The page happened to have the four characters "Rare is it to be confused."*

"Tsk, tsk."

Zhou Ze clicked his tongue.

Interesting.

He checked the time and found it was almost evening. Remembering he had an appointment with Dr. Lin to see a movie tonight, Zhou Ze decided to go grab some food first.

Walking next door, Zhou Ze paused, seeing Xu Qinglang kneeling on the ground.

Xu Qinglang's eyes were bloodshot, surrounded by many empty bottles. At this moment, he held a bottle and continued to drink.

"Unfair... so unfair..."

Xu Qinglang mumbled, as if he hadn't noticed Zhou Ze entering the shop at all.

"Hey?" Zhou Ze reached out and patted Xu Qinglang's shoulder, "Are you alright?"

He really wanted to remind Xu Qinglang that for other men, getting drunk might just mean having their money stolen, but if Xu Qinglang got drunk and went out, it wouldn't be as simple as just losing money.

In fact, if he were to lie on a late-night street with a woman, Xu Qinglang might be violated more times than the woman.

Xu Qinglang's body trembled, and he slowly raised his head, looking pitiable with tears streaming down his face. He formed an orchid gesture with his hand, pointed at Zhou Ze, and said mournfully:

"Today is my parents' death anniversary."

Zhou Ze was silent for a moment, then said, "My condolences."

He waited for a moment.

Xu Qinglang continued to drink.

Zhou Ze could only remind him, "Not cooking tonight?"

"Cook! Cook!"

Xu Qinglang staggered to his feet, his slender waist swaying gracefully and provocatively. That teetering posture made one want to go and support him directly, to inhale his fragrance.

"You don't have to force yourself, you know?"

Zhou Ze said this, but still sat down in a chair, ready to eat.

It wasn't easy for him to get a meal, so he didn't want to look for another place.

Xu Qinglang waved his hand and walked into the inner room.

Soon,

The sound of the stove lighting up came from inside; Xu Qinglang was stir-frying.

Zhou Ze took out his phone and saw that Dr. Lin had just sent him a message, saying she would pick him up soon.

Zhou Ze replied with an "Okay."

Then he thought it wasn't formal enough.

He replied with a "hahaha paopaobing emoji."*

Immediately, he felt it was too frivolous.

He recalled the emoji.

Then he thought recalling it was too obvious.

So he replied with "Hehe."

Immediately after, he felt "Hehe" wasn't friendly enough.

But then he thought recalling it a second time would seem too pretentious.

Such a struggle...

Zhou Ze was struggling by the dining table.

The other chef, who was stir-frying, was also struggling.

In the wok was twice-cooked pork, which, once stir-fried and served over rice, would be a simple yet appetizing bowl of twice-cooked pork over rice.

"Why didn't she arrest you, but she arrested my parents?"

Xu Qinglang muttered to himself while stir-frying.

An ancient saying goes, "Worry not about scarcity, but about uneven distribution." This sentence encapsulates too many truths and reveals the darkest side of human nature.

"This isn't fair, it's really not fair," Xu Qinglang continued to murmur.

"How can you play favorites? How can you play favorites?"

Xu Qinglang's eyes were vacant, but his stir-frying rhythm remained unchanged. He was a good chef; cooking was almost an instinct for him.

Silently, Xu Qinglang took out a yellow jar from the cabinet under the stove and poured some powder into the twice-cooked pork.

"My parents were taken away, why weren't you? Did you save her life?"

"Heh, what a joke."

"You want to eat?"

"Alright, I'll give you food."

Xu Qinglang kept taking deep breaths.

"Is it ready?" Zhou Ze urged from outside.

"Almost."

Xu Qinglang paused, a hint of panic and hesitation flashing in his eyes, but he still put the lid on the wok. He realized he hadn't microwaved his own rice yet, so he had to re-heat it.

After the rice was done, Xu Qinglang placed the twice-cooked pork on top and then carried the plate out.

Zhou Ze was still struggling with his phone screen. Seeing Xu Qinglang walk out somewhat disoriented and dejected, putting down the food, he asked with some concern:

"Looking like that, you didn't forget to put salt in, did you?"

Xu Qinglang shook his head.

Zhou Ze picked up his chopsticks, ready to eat.

Xu Qinglang's hand trembled, his lips slightly parted, just about to speak when Zhou Ze put down his chopsticks.

"Where's the plum juice or bitter gourd juice?" Zhou Ze asked.

"Oh, right."

Xu Qinglang went back, got a cup of plum juice, and returned.

Zhou Ze first picked up the plum juice, sniffed it, then took a deep breath, preparing to drink it when his phone vibrated.

"I'm here, come out."

Zhou Ze hesitated, then put the plum juice down.

He knew that after drinking this with his meal, his whole face would probably be sour for a long time, as if everyone around him owed him a huge sum of money.

Thinking about it, forget it.

Counting both his past and present lives, this was his first time asking a girl out to see a movie, so he'd better be a bit more serious.

No choice. Originally, the difficulty of Dr. Lin's 'dungeon' was an 'entry-level novice quest'.

Now that he was in Xu Le's skin, the novice quest instantly became a 'Great Boss-level quest'.

He didn't know whether to be secretly pleased or miserable.

What he needed to strive for now was,

To defeat himself? Only then could he win the beauty.

"The money, put it on account. We'll settle it at the end of the month. I'm leaving now."

Zhou Ze got up, pushed the door open and went out.

Dr. Lin's car was parked by the road, the window down, waiting for him.

And in the noodle shop, Xu Qinglang's expression alternated between cloudy and clear, then he suddenly spilled the entire plate of twice-cooked pork rice on the floor.

Clutching his head, he began to cry on the ground.

He cried louder and louder,

Until, finally,

It turned into dry wailing...

---
**Footnotes:**
* "Rare is it to be confused" (難得糊塗 - nándé hútú): A famous Chinese idiom by Zheng Banqiao, meaning it's sometimes wise to feign ignorance or to be less discerning in certain situations, for the sake of peace or practicality. It implies a philosophical acceptance of ambiguity or a deliberate choice not to be too clear-headed in complex matters.
* "paopaobing emoji" (炮炮兵表情): Refers to an emoji of the cartoon character "Paopaobing," a popular soldier-like character in Chinese internet culture, often used for humorous or silly expressions.

title: 第二十一章 狗說
content:
Doctor Lin got out of the car, and just then, Zhou Ze walked over. The two were quite in sync; neither spoke, silently heading towards another entrance of the shopping mall.

This mall was "dead." Aside from Zhou Ze and Xu Qinglang's small shop, only a cinema and a buffet restaurant remained.

Of course, due to the overall situation, the cinema was probably operating at a loss. Few people went there to watch movies on weekdays; buying a ticket would easily get you a private screening.

However, during the New Year period, most people were on holiday, and families going to the cinema together became common, adding a rare touch of life to this already ice-cold cinema.

But to Zhou Ze, this lively atmosphere felt more like a last gasp.

A collapsing building; this was a case of no egg being left unbroken when the nest overturned.

Zhou Ze bought tickets and a couple's meal, checked the time, and then walked into the cinema with Doctor Lin.

Because they arrived a bit late, and Zhou Ze bought tickets for the nearest showing, all the good seats were gone. Zhou Ze and Doctor Lin could only sit in the first row.

They could have waited, but there was nothing else to do in this mall, and *Detective Chinatown 2* was a 2D movie, so sitting in the first row wouldn't affect the viewing experience much.

Doctor Lin hadn't said much on the way there, and now she sat quietly beside Zhou Ze, gracefully crossing her long legs and looking up at the screen.

Zhou Ze offered her popcorn, but Doctor Lin waved her hand, indicating she didn't want any.

Zhou Ze sighed. For someone who was a confirmed bachelor in his previous life, how to pursue a girl was truly an unfamiliar subject.

The movie had good humor, and Zhou Ze occasionally chuckled. Doctor Lin also often smiled, but her laughter was usually soundless, very subtle, and very beautiful.

However, for Zhou Ze, the atmosphere of this movie outing was somewhat different from what he had expected.

A bit bland, like food without salt.

The movie ended, and Zhou Ze and Doctor Lin walked out side by side. It was only seven in the evening, not late, but once they left the cinema area, other parts of the mall were already pitch black.

Doctor Lin remained silent, simply following along.

Zhou Ze wanted to say something, but he didn't know what.

It was he who said he wanted to end things and say goodbye yesterday. If he acted too enthusiastically today, would she think he was crazy?

"To my bookstore..."

"Go to your bookstore to sit for a bit..."

Both seemed to be trying to break the awkward silence and had the same idea.

Back at the bookstore, Zhou Ze found that the noodle shop was closed, and the rolling shutter was uncharacteristically pulled down. He didn't know if Xu Qinglang was still inside.

Doctor Lin picked out a magazine and sat on a chair behind the counter. Zhou Ze also took a book and sat beside her, casually flipping through it.

Two cups of hot tea sat on the counter, steam rising gently.

Zhou Ze suddenly felt he had no right to mock Xu Le anymore, because he realized he had made his first date so artistic and so respectfully distant—it was incredibly rare!

So rare he wanted to slap himself as a reward!

"Now, you're not closing?" Doctor Lin asked. In fact, her unspoken meaning was that she wanted to leave; after all, it was evening, and if Zhou Ze closed, she could conveniently say goodbye.

"Oh, I usually open for business at night," Zhou Ze replied, not catching the hidden meaning. He was stating a fact.

Doctor Lin was momentarily speechless, only able to smile and gently smooth a strand of hair behind her ear, then continued reading her book.

"Creak..."

The bookstore door opened, and two men and a woman walked in.

None of the three were very old, only in their early twenties. The two men had clearly been drinking, and one of them was quite tipsy, his entire face flushed.

"Boss, do you have water?" the woman asked.

Zhou Ze pointed to the water dispenser on the wall.

The woman poured a few cups of hot water for her friends, then walked to the counter and asked:

"How much?"

As she spoke, the woman took out her phone, apparently ready to pay by scanning a QR code.

"Thirty," Zhou Ze replied.

"Boss, you can't fleece customers like this even during the New Year. Thirty for three cups of purified water," the woman playfully scolded, but still scanned and paid. Then she turned to her two male companions and said, "Let's rest here and read some books."

They were treating the bookstore as a temporary resting place. Zhou Ze charging 30 yuan felt to them like a minimum charge for entering a teahouse, which they could understand.

"Read books? What kind of books?"

The somewhat drunk man shouted loudly,

"I want to read ghost stories, horror novels, does this shop have any?"

The man laughed to himself as he spoke.

Zhou Ze sighed, took two horror novel collections from under the counter, walked to the man, handed them to him, and inadvertently touched him with his finger.

Hmm, he was a human, not a ghost.

Tonight's date was already a failure.

If Doctor Lin had to experience another "Night of a Hundred Ghosts" like the five migrant workers last time, that would be the absolute worst. Zhou Ze didn't want that.

If he was human, that was good. He looked cute, even if he was drunk.

Zhou Ze didn't touch the other two; it wasn't convenient.

The drunk man sat down, and his two friends, one man and one woman, also sat on plastic stools. The three of them played on their phones and casually flipped through books.

They probably felt that the 30 yuan minimum charge should at least seem worth it.

"What kind of garbage is this ghost story?"

The man threw the book, and it landed right next to the water dispenser.

The woman went to pick up the book and found that some water had spilled out because she had just poured water, and the book's cover and inside pages were wet.

"Boss, how much?"

"Eight percent off the marked price." Zhou Ze was amused; these three young people were quite polite.

Of course, Zhou Ze hoped the drunk man would quickly throw all the books on his shelf, and get them all dirty, which would help him clear his inventory.

The woman reluctantly scanned and paid, then walked over to the drunk man.

"Let's go, stop acting crazy."

"This isn't a ghost story at all. The person who wrote it must have never seen a ghost," the drunk man insisted.

Zhou Ze softly "hmm"-ed, thinking, *Yes, you probably have seen a ghost, right in front of you.*

Doctor Lin also put down her book at this point and looked at the drunk man. Clearly, she found this matter quite interesting.

"Oh, Brother Liu, you have ghosts at home?" the man who came in with the drunk man joked.

The woman glanced at him, signaling him not to talk nonsense.

"Get lost! You have ghosts at home!"

The drunk man stood up,

"Damn it, that ghost only picks on me every New Year to torment me. It leaves everyone else alone! My three brothers, plus my sister, plus my parents and my grandparents, none of them are touched, only me!"

"A female ghost?" his companion asked again.

"If only it were a female ghost! It's a female...dog!"

"Pfft!"

The drunk man's two companions instinctively burst out laughing.

Even Zhou Ze and Doctor Lin lowered their heads and coughed a few times, but it was truly funny.

Especially the drunk man's look of complete grievance when he said it wasn't a female ghost but a female...dog.

*My heart aches,*

*I'm drunk and I want to confide!*

"Every New Year, those few days before and after, it comes for me! As soon as I fall asleep, it comes! Damn it!"

Although the drunk man was acting crazy, he was still in control, not appearing frightening, but rather amusing.

"It started seven years ago, and every New Year since, it comes on time, more punctually than my parents give me New Year's money!" The man hugged his head, squatted directly on the ground, and started crying. "Damn it, I can't live like this anymore!"

"What exactly happened? That dog, did you know it?" his companion asked.

"It was a dog my family used to keep. It tore up the money my dad kept under the bed, so my brothers and I killed it and ate its meat."

"It must be that dog holding a grudge, coming back for revenge," the companion analyzed.

"I just don't understand why it only comes after me! When we killed the dog, it was me, my brothers, my dad, and my grandpa!

When we ate the dog meat, it was the whole family, just an extra dish for New Year!

That dog ruined five thousand yuan, it deserved to be eaten!

But why does it only hate me?"

The drunk man almost cried, "I asked, my brothers, including my dad and grandpa, they're all fine! Why does it only target me?"

"You're drunk, let's go. I'll take you home." The woman helped the man up, motioning for the other companion to help.

The group walked out of the bookstore,

The earlier liveliness suddenly became quiet.

"Tell me, why?" Doctor Lin looked at Zhou Ze, not caring about truth or falsehood, purely chatting after hearing a story. "Why did that dog only torment him? Is there something special about him?"

"You're very interested in this?" Zhou Ze asked, somewhat surprised.

"Hmm," Doctor Lin nodded.

Zhou Ze smiled. "Actually, it's very simple. To understand a dog's mind, you first have to put yourself in the dog's shoes."

"How so?" Doctor Lin pursed her lips in a smile. "It's hard to put yourself in a dog's shoes."

Indeed, how can a human put themselves in a dog's mind?

"The dog's ghost came back for revenge, to torment him, because it held a grudge," Zhou Ze explained. "This should be the same as with humans."

"Then why didn't it get revenge on the other family members?"

"Perhaps it's because of that money. The dog was mischievous and tore up part of it, but another part might have been secretly taken by this guy when he was young.

So the dog felt it was unfair. It tore up the money, was punished, killed, and eaten—it felt that was fair and deserved.

But why was it that,

that person also stole money and made some of it disappear, but nothing happened to him?

So it was unconvinced; it didn't seek revenge on the other family members, only on him."

Doctor Lin shook her head and said somewhat unexpectedly, "It was just a drunk story told by a drunk man, but after your analysis, it feels like a real event."

Zhou Ze walked to where the group had been sitting and found a wallet on the floor. He picked it up and walked to the shop entrance.

Just then, the female companion came running back.

"Excuse me, there's a..."

Zhou Ze handed her the wallet.

"Thank you!" The woman bowed to Zhou Ze to express her gratitude. "If this guy had lost his wallet and ID tonight, his family would have scolded him again."

"No problem," Zhou Ze waved his hand.

The other person also waved back at Zhou Ze, then turned and ran to catch up with her companions.

Under the moonlight,

As the woman ran,

beneath her coat,

there seemed to be a fluffy yellow tail gently wagging...

title: 第二十二章 天雷，勾動地火！
content:
Zhou Ze felt he must have been seeing things. Having just heard a drunkard’s ghost story about a dog, coupled with the dim streetlights, it was perfectly normal to have an optical illusion.

Yes, that must be it.

Zhou Ze wasn’t Zhang Tianshi of Longhu Mountain; he knew he was still a bit of a “goody-two-shoes.” He couldn’t change himself, otherwise, he would have already extended his fingernails to pinch that little loli during the day.

As for whether he would end up being pinched to death by the little loli or still be pinched to death by the little loli,

That remained to be seen.

Since he couldn’t change himself, he might as well try to let fewer annoying things affect him. If he saw something, he would avoid it if he could, or cover his eyes if he could.

Anyway, that dog had been tormenting that man for seven years. Counting the years,

It was time for the seven-year itch;

If that dog really wanted to harm someone, it would have done so long ago. Zhou Ze didn’t care what it would do next.

The woman came to his shop, bought water, and paid for the book. She paid very straightforwardly, which was a good karmic connection. That was enough.

However, Zhou Ze realized for the first time that there were indeed many incredible things in this world. Perhaps it was because he used to be human and was now a ghost; different circles naturally led to different perspectives on the world.

“What’s wrong?” Doctor Lin also walked to the shop entrance at this moment.

Zhou Ze smiled. “I’m very lucky that I’m not like Spider-Man, without some inexplicable elder or relative suddenly popping out to tell me:

With great power comes great responsibility.”

Doctor Lin didn’t understand what this meant, but she still said, “I should go back.”

It was late, and she really should go back.

“Won’t you stay a little longer?”

“I might have to be on duty tomorrow,” Doctor Lin said, tying her scarf.

“You can adjust it,” Zhou Ze said.

“It’s not convenient.”

“You don’t want to?”

Doctor Lin frowned slightly. This was the first time she felt an aggressive aura from Zhou Ze, and she was a little flustered.

“You are my wife,” Zhou Ze said, looking into Doctor Lin’s eyes, very seriously.

Doctor Lin subtly retreated half a step. “Yesterday, you said…”

Just yesterday, Zhou Ze had said they should end it, and both would be free.

“Yesterday was yesterday.” Zhou Ze took half a step forward. “Before I sign the divorce agreement, I am your husband, and you are my wife. So, I want you to stay and accompany me now!”

Zhou Ze’s voice grew louder and louder.

Doctor Lin didn’t speak, standing still.

A sudden surge of inexplicable anger rose in Zhou Ze’s heart.

He extended a finger, pinching Doctor Lin’s chin and making a very flippant gesture to lift her head.

Doctor Lin looked at him, her gaze clear and calm, especially her vivid red lips, which were dazzling. She was very beautiful, truly beautiful. It was that kind of exquisite face combined with a highly harmonious temperament, giving a very comfortable feeling.

Zhou Ze directly lowered his head and kissed her lips.

He kissed fiercely and roughly, like a wild beast, fully unleashing its ferocity from within himself! And the woman before him was the object of his desire.

Doctor Lin raised her hand, seemingly preparing to slap the man in front of her, but her hand stopped midway and slowly lowered again.

From the corner of her eye, glistening tears flowed.

“Why are you crying?”

Lips parted,

Zhou Ze looked up at Lin Wanqiu.

“Do you think your tears can make me feel guilty? Do you think your tears can make me stop?

I’m telling you,

Your crying won’t help today. You are my wife, I am your husband!

Look at your parents, what kind of people are they? Look at your sister, how does she usually look at me!

And look at you,

You are noble,

You are cold and elegant,

You are a goddess,

You are ethereal!

In the bedroom, you even sleep in a separate bed from me!

You’re married, you’re already a married woman, yet you’re still hypocritically concerned about your chastity. Don’t you even see if you’re worthy anymore!

I know, I’m just a moron. In your whole family’s eyes, I’m a good-for-nothing moron!”

Zhou Ze grabbed Doctor Lin by the neck with one hand, pushed her against the counter, and then directly stripped off Doctor Lin’s coat.

“Today I’m going to teach you, to tell you how a wife should act!”

“Xu Le…” Doctor Lin didn’t resist. She just looked at Zhou Ze coldly. “You… scoundrel…”

“Heh heh.” Zhou Ze smiled, unconcerned, then took off his own coat and directly pressed Doctor Lin onto the counter.

He was rough, he was brutal,

At this moment,

The tinder was already laid, needing only a tiny spark to ignite into a raging blaze!

Zhou Ze was that kindling!

She smelled so good, her skin was so tender, her body so voluptuous. Everything, absolutely everything, was so beautiful, so captivating.

But at this moment, Zhou Ze suddenly stopped, staggering back a few steps.

In front of him, Doctor Lin lay on the counter, her top disheveled, while Zhou Ze himself was panting heavily.

No,

How did it turn out like this?

Doctor Lin was still lying on the counter, still with her eyes open, still not resisting.

She felt guilty towards Xu Le. She was a very independent and strong woman, but her social environment and the family education she received since childhood always left her conflicted.

Her parents coerced her with threats of death, hoping for grandchildren soon, which forced her to agree to marry Xu Le. Yet, she held onto her own bottom line, harboring feelings for another man, even if that man had died in a car accident half a year ago, even if that man might have long forgotten her, or even never knew that such a woman had been secretly following him for several years after her internship ended.

To describe it using the critical style common in middle school textbooks: Doctor Lin succumbed to feudal etiquette in life, yet was unwilling to continue living this way, still holding onto her own perseverance and resistance in her heart.

This was also why, despite being a million times unwilling, Lin Wanqiu still didn’t resist, allowing Zhou Ze to do as he pleased just now;

She felt she had no reason to resist. Zhou Ze was her husband, and she knew that her actions since marriage had been unfair to her husband and to this marriage.

She didn’t accept it, didn’t agree to it,

But she wouldn’t resist.

“Put on your clothes! Put your clothes on properly!”

Zhou Ze roared at Lin Wanqiu, who was still lying on the counter.

Lin Wanqiu froze for a moment, then stood upright, looking at Zhou Ze in disbelief. Just moments ago, she had already resigned herself.

“I haven’t even gotten to do anything to you yet, don’t look like you’ve just been r-a-p-e-d. Put your clothes on,

Now,

Immediately,

Right away,

Then get out!”

Doctor Lin silently put on her clothes, then adjusted her collar in the mirror. She was expressionless. Once everything was tidied, she poured Zhou Ze a fresh cup of hot water and placed it on the counter, then walked out of the bookstore without even looking at Zhou Ze.

Zhou Ze slumped to the ground, feeling somewhat lost and confused.

On his lips and in his palms, her lingering warmth seemed to remain. He didn’t know why he had stopped, nor why he hadn’t continued.

It was clearly very comfortable,

Clearly very desirable,

Clearly very intoxicating,

But for some reason, he felt something was off. It seemed this wasn’t the feeling he wanted.

He had just been about to sleep with her,

She had agreed,

But that moment just now was completely different from what he had wanted.

Zhou Ze stumbled to his feet. He picked up the teacup, took a sip, then spat out the hot water. The water was scalding, with not a drop of cold water added to neutralize it.

He dropped the cup, letting the water wet the floor, and Zhou Ze looked around, recalling his recent actions, remembering the words he had just spoken.

His fist clenched then loosened, only to clench again quickly.

He went to the bathroom, turned on the faucet in the sink, and directly put his head under the running water, splashing himself.

He needed to calm down, to become peaceful,

Not just to quench the fire in his body, but also the one in his heart.

The cold water in winter was not something an ordinary person could endure. Zhou Ze lifted his head, feeling a dizzy spell in his mind.

He looked at the mirror in front of him,

The mirror reflected his own image.

Zhou Ze gripped the edge of the sink tiles tightly, panting continuously. Then, he slowly raised his head, as if talking to himself, and said,

“It’s you!

“It’s you, you damn bastard, you good-for-nothing!

You’re influencing me, you’re trying to control me,

You trash, you scum, you bastard!”

Zhou Ze cursed at his reflection in the mirror,

Yes,

This wasn’t him. His behavior just now was too abnormal. That sudden, inexplicable rage, that baseless confusion, that inexplicable impulse,

It was definitely more than just youthful vigor.

Just now, at that moment,

Someone he thought had long gone to hell, long ceased to exist in this world,

He had influenced him.

He hadn’t left,

He was still hiding by his side,

Perhaps,

He was hiding inside his own body!

He was spineless, he was weak. He had endured all contempt in life, dared not resist, and lacked the courage to hold his head high. But after death, he was curled up in a corner, yet thinking of using someone else’s hand to retaliate against his wife in the simplest, most brutal way!

Using another person’s strength to retaliate against his wife.

“I used to pity you, and felt a little bit sorry for you,” Zhou Ze muttered. “Now I understand, pitiful people must have hateful aspects. That you lived your life the way you did, can only mean you deserved it!”

“*Slap!*”

Zhou Ze raised his fist and directly punched the mirror.

The mirror shattered,

Zhou Ze’s hand was also gushing blood, which began to drip into the sink.

On the fragmented pieces of the mirror,

Zhou Ze’s face was still reflected,

No,

It was Xu Le’s face.

Zhou Ze stood there without moving,

The person in the mirror also didn’t move,

But in the next moment,

A sinister glint appeared in the eyes of the person in the mirror, who then opened his mouth and said,

“Oh, you found me.”

title: 第二十三章 嗨！
content:
"You... are courting death."

Black light emerged from the depths of Zhou Ze's eyes; at this moment, he was enraged.

Yes, he was usurping the nest,

But,

So what?

I'm going to continue living in your body; can you stop me?

Your revenge,

Is it just suddenly provoking me to force myself upon your wife?

Is that all you've got?

Zhou Ze spread his right hand, black fingernails slowly growing, wreathed in tendrils of black mist.

Many times, the true solution to a problem depends on your position, your standpoint.

From Zhou Ze's perspective, there's no right or wrong to distinguish. He wants to live; everything done under this premise is correct. Otherwise, everything loses meaning.

If it loses meaning, is there any need for right or wrong to exist?

"No matter where you hide, I will drag you out, even if... you're hidden within this body!"

Zhou Ze's face began to contort. His fingernails started digging into his chest.

"Hiss..."

Intense pain, accompanied by an uncontrollable tremor, made Zhou Ze shiver and directly fall to his knees.

He opened his mouth,

Looking somewhat dazed,

Not there,

He's not there at all!

Why?

He had just verified it at the risk of his soul nearly being torn apart: within this body, there was only his, Zhou Ze's, sole soul. Xu Le was simply not there!

Zhou Ze crawled back to his feet, looking at his own face in the broken mirror. This time, he waited a long time, but the person in the mirror showed no change.

Xu Le had ceased to exist a long time ago,

So, everything I did to Doctor Lin earlier was driven by my own nature?

No,

That's impossible,

Impossible!

It can't be like this.

For the first time, Zhou Ze felt that the person in the mirror was so unfamiliar. It wasn't because he had changed bodies and appearances, but because his own inner self, his soul, seemed to be entirely different from his original self-perception.

Body and soul, which is the real self?

From ancient times to the present, many great poets and philosophers, both Chinese and foreign, have offered a similar answer: the physical body changes and decays, but the soul can be eternal.

It can be noble, it can be remembered, it can shine brilliantly throughout the river of history.

Zhou Ze also believed that he was still Zhou Ze, still his original self. Now, it was merely his body that had changed, but he still considered himself Zhou Ze.

Now,

He began to fear,

Because if Xu Le's soul no longer existed,

That meant,

The one who changed... was himself?

………………

"Go to sleep, dear."

"Okay, I'll take our daughter to rest first. You should also finish up and rest early."

"Alright, once I've revised this treatment plan."

Wang Ke gently massaged his neck and yawned. He was indeed very sleepy, but the work at hand had to be finished. At just over thirty, he already had many gray hairs.

Men at this age are most awkward. If they don't strive, it's too early to retire. If they do strive, their bodies are already starting to decline.

"Ding ding ding... Ding ding ding..."

Wang Ke frowned slightly. So late, and someone is still visiting?
