He walked to the entrance and looked at the black-jacketed man standing outside on the video screen. He asked, "Excuse me, who are you?"

"I'm looking for Wang Ke. A friend introduced me."

"I'm sorry, if you have business, you can make an appointment with my assistant. I generally..."

"Zhou Ze introduced me," the man outside said.

Hearing that name, Wang Ke paused, then opened the door.

The person looked rather young, perhaps only twenty-five.

"Come in," Wang Ke gestured for him to enter and personally poured him a cup of tea, placing it on the coffee table.

Zhou Ze sat on the sofa, looking at his former friend.

He hadn't changed; he was still striving in his field. As children who grew up together in the orphanage, they had been close since childhood, and in the old dean's eyes, these two were among the most successful children to emerge from the orphanage in recent years.

Zhou Ze was a hospital deputy director at a young age, and Wang Ke already had his own psychological clinic, not a small, cramped storefront, but one located beside South Main Street, in the heart of Tongcheng.

This villa, too, was definitely not something an ordinary person could afford.

"You know Zhou Ze?" Wang Ke asked first.

"Yes, he died half a year ago," Zhou Ze replied, then picked up the teacup and took a sip. He still liked Maofeng tea; his taste hadn't changed.

"What can I do for you?"

"To see a doctor."

"See a doctor?" Wang Ke coughed. "You can make an appointment."

"It's urgent," Zhou Ze looked into Wang Ke's eyes, "Very urgent."

Wang Ke fell silent, then smiled and nodded, standing up and saying, "Please come to my study with me."

Regardless of the sudden and impolite visit, and the abrupt request, since the other party said he was Zhou Ze's friend, Wang Ke had no reason or way to refuse.

Zhou Ze sat properly in Wang Ke's study for a while. Wang Ke entered wearing white clothes, indicating his seriousness.

"Tell me about your situation," Wang Ke twirled the golden-dark fountain pen in his hand, which was quite striking under the study lamp.

Zhou Ze slowly shook his head, "Don't hypnotize me, not even shallow hypnosis."

Wang Ke nodded and put down the pen.

"I might have some... multiple personality disorder," Zhou Ze carefully chose his words.

"More specifically," Wang Ke asked.

"I feel that within my body, there exists another person's personality. Specifically, at certain moments, that person's disposition will suddenly influence my actions, and I can clearly perceive that those are definitely not things I would do.

I have always been... a very disciplined person."

"Symptoms of multiple personality disorder?" Wang Ke narrowed his eyes. "How long has this been happening?"

"Recently, I suppose."

"Alright, on this paper, draw your second personality. Just based on your feelings, draw what he looks like, even if you've never seen his true appearance."

Wang Ke handed a blank sheet of paper and the fountain pen to Zhou Ze.

"Second personality?" Zhou Ze asked.

"Yes," Wang Ke nodded.

"But... strictly speaking, I am the second personality," Zhou Ze pointed to himself. "The one causing trouble now should be the original personality of this body."

Wang Ke's gaze sharpened, and he began to re-examine Zhou Ze.

"Are you saying your current state is the second personality?"

"According to your theory, yes, it should be," Zhou Ze replied.

The original owner of this body was Xu Le, and Zhou Ze was the outsider, so Zhou Ze was the second personality.

"You've already killed him?" Wang Ke asked with interest. He seemed... somewhat excited.

"More or less, and I'm sure he's gone," Zhou Ze replied.

"Then this is essentially an act of murder," Wang Ke reminded him. "Although legally, your action cannot be judged or classified, I must sit here and condemn you for it."

"After the condemnation?"

"You came to me because you want to find a way to completely get rid of the first personality's influence on you?"

"Yes."

Wang Ke started twirling his pen again, not for hypnosis this time, but because he was thinking.

"I don't know if I should help you, because from my perspective, you killed a 'person' who originally existed, and if I help you, I would be helping you destroy evidence, making me an accomplice."

"Help me," Zhou Ze said.

"I need to consider it," Wang Ke pondered.

"No need to consider, help me," Zhou Ze urged, then added, "Er Dan Ge."*

When that "Er Dan Ge" was uttered, Wang Ke's expression suddenly changed. He said somewhat surprised, "Zhou Ze even told you that?"

Zhou Ze nodded.

Wang Ke looked up, somewhat conflicted, but then gritted his teeth and picked up his pen to write a prescription:

"I'll prescribe some medicine for you. These drugs are actually just auxiliary; they can help stabilize your emotions and aid your sleep."

"Then there's no need for them," Zhou Ze said.

"The most important step is that you need to change your environment," Wang Ke ignored Zhou Ze's previous words, finished writing the prescription, and continued, "Sever ties with the social connections of your first personality's original life and reconstruct your own social connections.

Many people believe that human thought is solely anchored in the soul, although whether souls, or ghosts, truly exist in this world is still unknown.

But this statement itself is inaccurate. In fact, our bodies, our muscles, our eyes, and many, many other organs can actually store a person's 'soul'. This 'soul' is different from the soul in the broad sense.

It refers to something akin to 'muscle memory' created by athletes through countless repetitions of training, as well as 'psychological suggestion', and so on. You can understand it as a kind of inertia.

You are the second personality, having killed the first personality,

But this body has, after all, been operating under the first personality for too long. It has its own inertia, its own memories. Sometimes, the reason you suddenly make inexplicable choices, leaving yourself shocked and surprised afterward, giving you the illusion that the first personality still exists and is causing trouble,

Is due to this reason.

First, sever all your current interpersonal relationships and build your own social circle. Let this body begin to re-adapt to you, cancel out the previous inertia, and the problem will be solved.

Actually, your current situation isn't serious. Your logical thinking is very clear. Overcoming it is just a matter of time." Wang Ke smiled.

At this moment, someone knocked on the study door,

"Dear, do we have guests?"

"Yes, please bring two more cups of coffee."

"Okay."

Zhou Ze thought of Doctor Lin, of his in-laws, and of his sister-in-law,

Indeed,

Initially, he had rejected that person's social connections and even wanted to break them off long ago.

But he didn't know when,

*She doesn't sleep with me anyway,*

It had instead become his obsession?

"How long will it take to sever ties?" Zhou Ze asked.

"Not long at all," Wang Ke shrugged, looking very relaxed. "I've been observing you since you walked in. The feeling you give me, how should I put it...

You are the second personality, but I think you're the most thorough case I've ever seen of a second personality completely eliminating the first.

It's like... borrowing a corpse to revive a soul in ancient ghost stories; very clean, very swift, even 'perfect' could describe it.

Right now, you can think of it as a slight side effect from a medicine you took. Your own immune system can completely overcome it, maybe just two or three months.

After that, you can pick up your old social connections again, and there won't be any problems."

Zhou Ze nodded, "Thanks."

"You're welcome."

"Coffee's here."

The study door was pushed open, and a woman entered with two cups of coffee, placing them on the desk.

Zhou Ze looked at the woman, and the woman also looked at Zhou Ze.

The next moment,

Zhou Ze's mind suddenly stirred, and the woman's face also abruptly changed.

"What, you two know each other?" Wang Ke asked.

"Yes, he's Doctor Lin's husband, Xu Le," the woman replied.

"Ah?" Wang Ke stood up in surprise,

He took the initiative to shake Zhou Ze's hand and express his gratitude.

Before, the man in front of him was a patient introduced by his deceased childhood friend. Now, he was also his daughter's savior, naturally making their relationship even closer.

Zhou Ze perfunctorily responded, his mind actually wondering whether he should remind his childhood friend, who was entirely devoted to his career, that his wife had recently become very engrossed in the indescribable activity of "getting her hair permed."

After thinking about it, he decided to remind him anonymously after leaving. Although the two of them, having known each other's personalities since they started working, had both focused entirely on their careers and thus didn't disturb each other,

Their friendship and childhood memories hadn't changed, but they never had the habit of casually meeting for drinks or tea. In fact, if not for this tricky problem, Zhou Ze wouldn't have sought out Wang Ke.

Wang Ke was married, Zhou Ze didn't know that. He had a child, Zhou Ze also didn't know that. But if he needed help and mentioned his name, Wang Ke would certainly agree.

Wang Ke and his wife saw Zhou Ze out of the house. Zhou Ze refused Wang Ke's kind offer to drive him back.

"Dear, what did he come to see you about?"

"A consultation," Wang Ke replied. "You said he runs a bookstore?"

"Yes, a bookstore like a tea party."

"Alright, I'll go check it out sometime."

…………

Zhou Ze had just walked out of the villa's perimeter,

When he suddenly felt something, stopped, turned around, and looked back at the villa.

On the villa's balcony,

Stood a small loli,

She was holding her white teddy bear, wearing red pajamas, standing outside in the breeze.

Her hair fluttered, her skirt billowed, yet she remained perfectly still, seemingly oblivious,

Only her eyes,

Were fixed on him.

Zhou Ze's expression was initially solemn, and his body was somewhat tense,

But slowly, the tension began to fade. The pressure of Xu Le's matter on his mind was relieved by the recent conversation, and Zhou Ze felt very relaxed.

However, what made Zhou Ze a bit troubled was,

It seemed he not only had to warn his old friend about his wife's issue,

His daughter,

Also seemed to have a problem.

Silently, Zhou Ze felt a pang of sympathy for his old friend in his heart.

What sin did he commit in his past life to have such a "happy and harmonious" family?

At this thought, Zhou Ze's mouth curved into a bitter smile.

The next moment, facing the gaze of the small loli on the distant balcony,

Zhou Ze raised his hand,

And waved in that direction:

Saying:

"Hi."

Translator's Note:
* "Er Dan Ge" (二蛋哥): A casual, affectionate, and somewhat playful way of addressing an older male friend, often used among childhood friends. "Er Dan" (二蛋) is a common, slightly rustic nickname, implying a close, unpretentious relationship. "Ge" (哥) means older brother.

title: 第二十四章 老道
content:
After leaving the villa district, Zhou Ze wasn't in a hurry to hail a taxi; he decided to walk alone on the night streets.

Wang Ke said that his situation wasn't too bad and he only needed to sever Xu Le's old social connections, which, in fact, had already been done.

Given how he treated Doctor Lin, he figured she wouldn't bother with him for a while. As for his in-laws' home, he hadn't been back in days.

The only real difficulty might be his bookstore, as the money to open it came from his in-laws.

He'd just leave things as they were for now; he needed to calm down during this period.

Ahead, there was a pedestrian overpass. Zhou Ze walked onto it, sat down on a step, took out his phone, and idly scrolled through it.

Coincidentally, Zhou Ze clicked on that live streaming app. Xu Le had followed many gaming and beauty streamers, but Zhou Ze wasn't particularly interested in those. Scrolling down, Zhou Ze saw that the old Taoist priest streamer he watched last time still hadn't started a broadcast.

He hadn't broadcast in so long, he probably really stopped.

The streaming industry might seem easy, making money from home, but the pressure is also immense. Not to mention not broadcasting for a month or two, even a few days could make you a fleeting sensation.

However, just then, Zhou Ze discovered an unread message in his account. Opening it, he found it was a private message from the old Taoist priest, sent two days ago.

"The humble Taoist has arrived in Tongcheng, dear, want to meet up?"

Below it was the old Taoist priest's phone number.

Zhou Ze frowned slightly. The old Taoist priest's message included many heart emojis. Zhou Ze then checked the information on Xu Le's account.

It was a female account,
and the address was indeed Tongcheng.

Xu Le must have tried streaming before, as she had her own live streaming room, but the viewership was dismal.

Zhou Ze finally understood where this strange feeling came from. The old Taoist priest's message clearly hinted at trying to hook up with fans. He came to Tongcheng for some business, then searched for his fans in Tongcheng, casting a wide net to reel some in.

Zhou Ze wasn't interested in the old Taoist priest. He was interested in the young man who appeared in the old Taoist priest's videos, the one who had difficulty eating porridge.

Still, Zhou Ze replied with a message: his own number.

Standing up, he stretched, Zhou Ze was ready to leave. He missed his freezer a bit.

However, his phone rang at that moment.

Picking up the phone, the caller ID showed a Rongcheng number.

Zhou Ze answered.

"Hello, benefactor, where are you?!"

The old Taoist priest's voice was loud, as if he was shouting into the phone's speaker, and there seemed to be the sound of a train nearby.

"Where are you?" Zhou Ze asked.

Was that old Taoist priest so idle? Didn't he have many fans? Why did he always reply to his messages so quickly?

Could it be that female fans' names were indeed very appealing?

"Huh..." The old Taoist priest was startled and silent for a moment. He hadn't expected the fan he planned to meet to be a man!

A "big-dick cute girl"!

Sadness,
disappointment,
gloom!

But the old Taoist priest immediately changed his tone, crying out hoarsely:

"Big brother, I'm hungry! Please, three to five bottles, give me some food!"

...

Taking a taxi, Zhou Ze found the old Taoist priest in a nooks and crannies under a railway bridge. The old Taoist priest was wearing a dirty Taoist robe, with disheveled hair and some bruises on his face, looking like a true refugee. He had been lying on a plastic sheet below.

Nearby on the street, there was a restaurant called "Longtan Home Cooking." Zhou Ze ordered him two bowls of noodles, a plate of Kung Pao Chicken, and a plate of small mixed fish. The old Taoist priest ate with gusto.

"Brother, you're really something!" The old Taoist priest finished one bowl of noodles and finally started to slow down. Then he told the owner to warm a pot of yellow wine, and immediately gave Zhou Ze an apologetic smile. He didn't have much money left in his pocket, so Zhou Ze would definitely be paying for this meal.

"How did you end up like this, old man?" Zhou Ze had a glass of water in front of him; he hadn't touched any of the dishes on the table.

"Sigh, don't mention it." The old Taoist priest took a sip of noodle soup, smacking his lips. "I've been out of luck lately. I originally came to Tongcheng with a film crew for location scouting."

"Changed professions?"

"Something like that, I don't feel like streaming these days." The old Taoist priest sighed, "People always need to have some dreams, don't they?"

"Indeed." Zhou Ze nodded.

"The humble Taoist's dream for the future is to star in a 'Mr. Vampire' movie, whether it's part three, four, five, or six, seven, eight." When talking about his dream, the old Taoist priest's whole demeanor seemed to change slightly.

"How did you end up like this in a film crew?" Zhou Ze asked, curious.

"Hehe, I was originally a minor supporting role in the crew, but who knew fate would play such a trick."

The wine arrived.

The old Taoist priest first poured a glass for Zhou Ze, then filled his own. He took a small sip, squinting his eyes:

"Tsk tsk tsk, beautiful, beautiful."

Zhou Ze picked up his plain water and took another sip.

"The assistant director was a scoundrel, trying to take advantage of a young actress. That girl probably wasn't even eighteen yet. Sigh, the girl cried and refused.

I happened to stumble upon it and went up and beat that assistant director."

The old Taoist priest reached out and patted his chest, saying:

"Making money is making money, getting famous is getting famous, but no matter what we do, we can't go against our conscience, right?

Brother, don't you agree?"

"Mm." Zhou Ze responded, "So you got fired?"

"Not yet, he didn't dare bring that up." The old Taoist priest grinned, "Many people knew that I beat him up, so he wouldn't dare deal with me that way, otherwise his own reputation would be completely ruined."

"And then?"

"And then, that little actress I rescued that night voluntarily walked into the assistant director's room the next night and didn't come out all night."

The old Taoist priest sighed as he said this, "They're all pitiable people, all struggling people."

"And then after that?"

"And then that little actress accused me of groping her, sexually harassing her. The assistant director didn't show up, and the main director fired me from the crew." The old Taoist priest continued to smile, but his smile held some bitterness.

"Drink," Zhou Ze said.

"Come on, let's have a drink!" The old Taoist priest raised his glass. Seeing that Zhou Ze was holding plain water, he immediately said, "Are you looking down on me, brother? Let's have a drink. Today, brother is in trouble, and I'm grateful for your care. We'll meet again someday, and when I have money, I'll return the favor."

Zhou Ze shook his head, "I'm allergic to alcohol."

"Alright then, tea instead of wine!"

The two clinked glasses, and the old Taoist priest drained his.

The grievances, the struggles, the indignation, the inequalities of life,
all contained within a single cup of wine.

"You're out of money?" Zhou Ze asked. This question didn't really need to be asked.

"Mm." The old Taoist priest finished speaking, then looked expectant, hoping Zhou Ze would lend him some money. He had some money left before, but he had given it all away as donations at the beginning of the month, and now he was fired from his job, which suddenly left him strapped for cash.

"Oh." Zhou Ze nodded.

"..." The old Taoist priest suddenly felt a sense of familiarity with this person's way of talking.

"Holy cow,"
you just say "oh,"
and why did you even ask if I had money?

Zhou Ze stood up, paid the bill, and prepared to leave. Treating the old Taoist priest to a meal was purely because Zhou Ze was also a bit bored tonight and wanted to talk to someone.

He could have gone back to Xu Qinglang's, but Xu Qinglang had closed early tonight, and the roller shutter was down, so he couldn't find him.

Now, he was tired and wanted to go back to rest.

"Brother, you run a bookstore?" the old Taoist priest asked.

"Mm."

"Running a bookstore doesn't make much money, does it?" The old Taoist priest spread his palm, his fingertips pinching back and forth as if calculating.

"Mm."

"The humble Taoist believes that running a冥店 (mingdian)* is actually more profitable." The old Taoist priest saw that Zhou Ze seemed uninterested in his "calculations." Fine, this person in front of him was someone who grew up under the red flag and didn't care for feudal superstitions, so the old Taoist priest put away his thoughts.

"A mingdian?" Zhou Ze shook his head. "Don't want to open one."

He himself was a ghost, why would he open a mingdian?

"To be honest, I used to run a mingdian in Rongcheng." The old Taoist priest pulled out a stack of money from his pocket—it was spirit money. "Brother, thank you for this meal today. I don't have much to give you, but take this stack of spirit money. Don't be quick to scold me; this money certainly can't be spent, but it carries yin virtue. Just keep it on you. Don't be afraid of bad luck; it can bring you some good fortune."

Zhou Ze didn't reach for the money.
Who in their right mind would take a stack of spirit money and keep it on them?

"Brother, don't disbelieve." The old Taoist priest, seeing Zhou Ze's refusal, grew anxious. He immediately pulled open his Taoist robe and pointed to a wound on his right chest, saying, "It was a stack of spirit money that saved my life back then."

"Alright, alright, I'll take it."

Zhou Ze didn't want to see a grown man baring his chest in front of him, so he had no choice but to take the spirit money.

"I remember watching your video, there was another person in your mingdian, that person had difficulty eating porridge," Zhou Ze asked.

"Oh, him? He's an employee I hired. So lazy, all he does is sunbathe all day, doesn't do anything. I constantly scold him, saying you can't be so lazy, being so young."

"Oh, does he have anorexia?" Zhou Ze asked.

"Something like that." When talking about that person, the old Taoist priest seemed a bit downcast. "Why, is he very handsome?"

"No, I just felt a bit of kinship."

"Kinship my foot." The old Taoist priest laughed as if he'd heard a funny joke.

You feel kinship with a ghost, are you also a ghost?

Hahahahahahaha,
you're killing me!

The two walked out of the restaurant together. Zhou Ze offered the old Taoist priest a cigarette. There was a supermarket still open next door, with a small fruit stall outside its entrance.

"You stand here and don't move, I'll go buy you some tangerines," the old Taoist priest said playfully.

"I'll only eat two, you can have the rest," Zhou Ze replied.

"What?" The old Taoist priest thought Zhou Ze was a bit out of touch and didn't understand his reference. Feeling a bit bored, he thought this bookstore owner must be a bookworm.

Zhou Ze didn't bother to explain.

Actually, "You stand here and don't move, I'll go buy you some tangerines" is from Zhu Ziqing's "The Retrospect," spoken by a father to his son.
And what Zhou Ze said was from "Rickshaw Boy," spoken by a grandfather to his grandson.

Finally, Zhou Ze reached out and patted the old Taoist priest's shoulder. "I'm leaving. Take care."

Just as the old Taoist priest was about to say something,
he suddenly clutched his crotch.

Then, a smell of burnt hair wafted out.

"Oh my god, it's burning me!"

---
*冥店 (míngdiàn): A shop that sells items for the deceased to use in the afterlife, usually paper effigies of money, cars, houses, etc., that are burned as offerings during funerals or ancestral worship. Often translated as "hell bank" or "spirit money shop." Here, "mingdian" is retained for clarity and cultural context.

title: 第二十五章 大火
content:
"What's wrong with you?" Zhou Ze frowned; clearly, he, too, had smelled it.

"Nothing, just gotta pee, you go ahead!"

The old Taoist said, then immediately turned and ran outside.

Zhou Ze looked at his hand, didn't follow up to ask anything, but simply took a taxi back to the bookstore.

The old Taoist came to the roadside, reached into his pants, and pulled out a talisman. The talisman had already turned red and disintegrated into ash in the wind, scattering away.

This was the old Taoist's ancestral talisman. As for why it was hidden in that particular spot, it's best left unsaid to outsiders.

But the scene from moments ago was seared into the old Taoist's memory.

Of course, looking down at his "walnuts"* tightly clenched from the burn,

they were also seared into his flesh.

"Damn it, Boss, I never expected to meet someone from your hometown more than two thousand kilometers away in Tongcheng."

In the unseen world,

perhaps there's a kind of connection.

For example, when Zhou Ze watched the old Taoist's live stream video and saw the young man sitting behind the counter of a冥店** struggling to drink porridge, he felt an inexplicable empathy.

It wasn't just anorexia;

in fact,

they were of the same kind.

In this world, he wasn't absolutely unique or singularly abnormal.

Just as the Faceless Woman roared in Hell, unwilling to accept it:

"How can you also leave?"

This implied that

not only Zhou Ze, but others had also left in front of the Faceless Woman before.

Adding in the old man with black fingernails whom Zhou Ze rescued after the car accident,

this world,

was truly not as peaceful as imagined.

..................

It was already one in the morning when he took a taxi back to the bookstore. Zhou Ze cleaned up the glass shards on the bathroom floor, then boiled several kettles of water to wipe himself down with a towel.

He decided to have someone install a shower tomorrow, as for someone with a slight潔癖***, not being able to bathe was absolute torture.

Back on the second floor, he adjusted the temperature and lay down, closing his eyes, ready to bid farewell to the day's fatigue and all its troubles.

He slept soundly and peacefully.

The night passed without incident.

When Zhou Ze woke up the next morning, he emerged from the freezer, first went to wash up, then opened the store door and glanced next door.

Next door was closed again today.

Doctor Lin couldn't be contacted for now.

His "wife" was gone,

and now even he was gone.

Zhou Ze shook his head sharply. Damn it, why would he have such a thought?

Xu Le's "lingering poison" was harming him,

yes,

it must be so.

Having not eaten since last night, Zhou Ze had no choice but to order takeout on his phone, adding a note to the vendor to send extra vinegar.

After about twenty minutes, a delivery rider in a yellow uniform arrived on an electric scooter. He pushed open the door and walked in, handing the takeout to Zhou Ze, who was sitting behind the counter reading a book.

"Thank you, it's not easy, delivering food during the New Year," Zhou Ze said politely.

"It's not easy for you either, eating takeout during the New Year," the delivery rider retorted directly.

".................." Zhou Ze.

Zhou Ze felt like he'd been shot in the knee. He looked up specifically at the delivery rider in front of him. The guy was young, probably just twenty-something.

"Is this a bookstore?" The delivery rider looked around the shop. "The kind where you can sit and read? How much?"

"Pay what you think it's worth," Zhou Ze opened the takeout bag.

"Alright then."

The delivery rider sat down on a plastic stool, picked up a copy of "Battle Through the Heavens," and started reading, thoroughly engrossed.

Zhou Ze, meanwhile, chugged down the vinegar provided by the vendor. Perhaps because he had been "trained" by Xu Qinglang's abnormally sour plum juice recently, Zhou Ze felt nothing from the ordinary vinegar.

Immediately after, he devoured his meal in a frenzy. Halfway through, nausea and a feeling of sickness began to creep in.

Zhou Ze clutched his neck, forcing himself not to throw up. Finally, after a terrible struggle, the nausea slowly receded, and Zhou Ze wiped his mouth, then began to cough heavily.

"Brother, eat slower. My grandma would say you're eating like a hungry ghost reincarnated."

The delivery rider said, still reading his book.

Zhou Ze glared at him, then simply sat in his chair, gasping for breath. He needed to recover.

Damn Xu Qinglang,

why isn't he open yet!

Zhou Ze decided that if the other shop wasn't open by the afternoon, he would have no choice but to break in and look for any leftover plum or bitter gourd juice. Otherwise, he really couldn't eat.

The delivery rider seemed to have stopped taking orders and sat there reading his novel for an hour.

"Huh, why do I smell burnt coal?" The delivery rider suddenly sniffed, then walked out of the bookstore.

Zhou Ze didn't pay it any mind. The guy probably just wanted to read a bit and didn't want to pay; it didn't matter.

This bookstore truly earned money "as fate would have it."

But then, the delivery rider, who had just stepped outside, immediately opened his mouth and shouted:

"Wow, it's on fire!"

Zhou Ze was jolted awake and quickly walked out of the shop. He looked up, and his gaze instantly narrowed: on the fourth floor of the building above, thick smoke was billowing out.

This was...

the location of the movie theater!

The former commercial center, which still had some human traffic, was that movie theater. And recently, because it was the New Year's holiday season, many people came here to watch movies.

"Let's go, save people." The delivery rider immediately ran towards it.

Zhou Ze stood there for ten seconds, hesitating. The fire was definitely big, but it would absolutely not reach his bookstore. He was trying to suppress his deep-seated instinct to save people.

In the past, he couldn't remember how many times he had rushed to the front lines of disaster sites to participate in rescues, but recently, he decided to break this bad habit.

However, after intense internal struggle, Zhou Ze still ran along.

He was,

still a masochist!

On the stairs from the first to the third floor, many people were running down, while Zhou Ze was running up.

Although this commercial center was "abandoned," it was located in the city, so fire trucks should arrive quickly.

Fewer people watched movies in the morning than in the afternoon, but the number was still considerable. When Zhou Ze ran up the stairs to the fourth floor, he saw even more dense smoke inside, and the flames were burning eerily. Even if it was an accidental fire, it couldn't burn this exaggeratedly!

But this was not the time to analyze the cause. Through the thick smoke, Zhou Ze saw the delivery rider, whose face was blackened with soot, carrying an old woman out on his back.

The rider looked at Zhou Ze, smiled, revealing a mouthful of white teeth, then turned his head and ran back into the viewing area to continue rescuing people.

The fire hadn't spread completely, but in the viewing area, the flames were extremely intense.

Zhou Ze no longer hesitated. Since he had already come, he had to do something. He immediately ran into the thick smoke.

"Cough, cough... cough, cough..."

Going in hastily without any protective measures was a very foolish act. It was easy to fail to save anyone and end up dying inside oneself.

So Zhou Ze knew his time was limited. If he saw anyone who needed help, he would just get them out. He couldn't do much else; he could only wait for professional firefighters to handle it.

"Phew..."

Zhou Ze had just opened the door to Cinema 2 when flames suddenly shot out. Zhou Ze could only retreat to avoid the brunt of it.

And inside, there were still cries.

Zhou Ze gritted his teeth and rushed in. Inside the cinema, flames were everywhere—on the floor, the ceiling, the walls—all on fire. And because of the confined space, the smoke generated from the burning was trapped inside.

In general, in fire accidents, more people die from smoke inhalation than from being burned.

It was only at times like this that everyone realized how important those annoying fire safety announcement videos before every movie were.

As soon as Zhou Ze rushed in, he saw two people lying in the narrow aisle.

One was an adult man in a black suit, lying on the floor, coughing, clearly unable to get up.

The other was a boy, about ten years old, collapsed on the ground unconscious, either passed out or already dead from suffocation.

"Save me... save me... sa..." The man in the suit barely managed to lift his head, looking at Zhou Ze standing in front of him.

Zhou Ze jumped over him, picked up the little boy on his back, and prepared to rush out first.

He was already feeling dizzy. Clearly, without a gas mask or other professional equipment, he couldn't last much longer either.

However, just as he was carrying the boy and about to run out, Zhou Ze felt someone grab his foot, and he fell to the ground, the boy on his back also tumbling off.

"Save... save... first... save me... I'll... give you... money... first... save me..."

The man in the suit used his last bit of strength to tightly grasp Zhou Ze's ankle. He knew he couldn't last much longer. He couldn't breathe at all; his lungs felt like they were on fire.

Zhou Ze, who had fallen, felt his head spin, almost blacking out. Instantly, he bit his tongue, forcing himself to stay conscious.

"Bang!"

"Bang!"

Zhou Ze used his other foot to kick the hand and head of the man who was grabbing him.

After several kicks, the man finally let go.

Zhou Ze shakily got back on his feet, hoisted the boy onto his back, and rushed out of Cinema 2.

After rushing out of the thick smoke and into a safe area, Zhou Ze's knees buckled, and he collapsed to the ground. The boy on his back also fell, but because of Zhou Ze's subconscious cushioning, he didn't fall badly.

Firefighters had already arrived and were busy extinguishing the fire, and some firefighters, wearing equipment, were rushing into the blaze.

"There are still people in Cinema 2."

Zhou Ze grabbed the uniform of a firefighter running past him and said.

"Okay, I understand," the firefighter nodded and rushed into the fire.

"Hoo hoo... hoo hoo..."

Zhou Ze lay sprawled on the tiled floor, panting heavily. Opposite him, the delivery rider, whose yellow uniform was now blackened with soot, was also leaning against the wall, gasping for breath. The two exchanged glances and smiled weakly at each other.

Paramedics had also arrived, a group of "white angels" and doctors. Zhou Ze was too exhausted to check if Doctor Lin was also part of this rescue operation.

Gritting his teeth, he got back up. Zhou Ze looked at the boy being given emergency treatment by the doctors; the boy's chest was still rising and falling, so he should be fine.

At the same time, Zhou Ze saw several other people later carried out by firefighters: some couldn't be saved, while others were. The man in the black suit lay motionless on a stretcher; he must have been dead.

Zhou Ze felt no guilt. There was no reason for him to feel guilty.

He was doing good, saving people, but who to save first was up to him. No one had the right to morally bind him.

Moreover, at that moment, he simply couldn't carry a child and an adult man out simultaneously. If he had tried, the end result would have been his own death inside.

He was a "scholar" who had been reincarnated into Xu Le's body, a man without the power to truss a chicken, not Arnold Schwarzenegger.

Besides, that guy almost caused him to die in the cinema too.

Struggling to get up, he refused the nurse's offer to check his condition. Zhou Ze walked towards the bathroom at the other end of the building, turned on the tap, and vigorously splashed cold water on his face.

Finally,

he caught his breath.

He looked up,

Zhou Ze stared at himself in the mirror,

and suddenly noticed,

in the mirror, behind him, a faint figure slowly appeared.

This person,

wearing a black suit,

was staring at him with a look of intense resentment.

His mouth was open, yelling incessantly, as if questioning him about something, hysterical, frantically agitated.

After death, if one encounters a specific catalyst, there's a certain probability of turning into a vengeful ghost.

And right now, this man had just died, his soul still in the process of becoming a ghost; it would likely fully form around the "first seven" days.

He wasn't a ghost yet, just a nascent form.

But because of Zhou Ze's unique nature, he could perceive the other's presence in advance.

He hated Zhou Ze,

for not saving him,

and this hatred,

was strong enough to make him become a vengeful ghost!

"Heh, interesting."

Zhou Ze smiled,

and put his head back into the sink, continuing to rinse himself with water.

At the same time, he sighed inwardly:

"Heh, humans, huh..."

---
* 尿急 (niào jí) "Urinary urgency" - In this context, the old Taoist claims to have "pee urgency," but later it's revealed he was checking a talisman. The "walnuts" (核桃 - hétáo) are a euphemism for testicles, which were scalded by the "hot" talisman.
** 冥店 (míng diàn) - Literally "underworld store," a shop that sells funerary items, paper offerings for the dead, etc.
*** 潔癖 (jiépǐ) - Obsessive cleanliness, mild germophobia.

title: 第二十六章 頭七
content:
According to *Jianghai Evening News* (Tongcheng’s local newspaper), seven people died and over thirty were injured to varying degrees in the recent movie theater fire.

A week has passed, and the movie theater has been shut down. Reopening it anytime soon is impossible, and it's even likely the theater will be abandoned altogether. It was already operating at a loss, so there's no reason to invest heavily in reopening it.

This effectively spells the complete demise of the commercial center.

Zhou Ze hasn't contacted Dr. Lin lately; both have maintained an unspoken understanding of non-interference, living their own lives. However, his in-laws called a few times, demanding to know why he wasn’t home and accusing him of being too bold.

Zhou Ze eventually blocked their numbers.

The current headache is that the money for this bookstore came from his in-laws. He’s beholden to them, and he still hasn’t figured out how to earn some money to open his own store and achieve true independence.

One could only say that Xu Le left him with a very poor foundation.

Several media outlets had contacted him, hoping to interview Zhou Ze about his act of heroism and promote positive energy in the new era, but Zhou Ze refused them all.

He wasn't interested in fame. As the saying goes, "a tall tree catches the wind," and with his identity and role, truly becoming a celebrity would bring more uncontrollable dangers.

Business has been mediocre this week, with daily sales under a hundred, not even covering rent and utilities. Zhou Ze didn't pay much attention to these figures.

What he did care about was that Xu Qinglang next door hadn't opened his shop for a week.

Zhou Ze hired an unscrupulous locksmith to pick the lock and went inside. He didn't find any sour plum juice or similar items. The kitchen in the back room was meticulously clean and tidy.

It was quite helpless,
A man with over twenty apartments who is also very handsome,
If he suddenly one day decides to renounce the world and chase after the winds,
You'd truly have a hard time finding him.

And so, Zhou Ze had a rather miserable week.

Chili oil,
Aged vinegar,
Dark soy sauce,
High-concentration orange juice, etc., he tried them all. While they allowed him to eat some food, they left him utterly miserable, far less effective than Xu Qinglang's family's ancestral sour plum juice.

As night fell, Zhou Ze squatted alone outside the bookstore, a cigarette in his mouth, occasionally glancing next door, feeling a sense of desolation about life.

By the roadside in front of the shop, four or five pagoda incense sticks were burning. They were lit by people from the mall. According to custom, today was the day to welcome the God of Wealth. Even though they knew the God of Wealth could hardly save the mall, they still had to go through the motions.

What if a miracle happened?

Occasionally, Zhou Ze would also look behind him or at the glass in front of him.

The black-suited man's malevolent ghost was continuously perfecting itself. Tonight was his *touqi* (first seven days after death), so he should be almost complete.

A malevolent ghost taking physical form is an exceedingly rare probability. Furthermore, ordinary malevolent ghosts at most make you trip and fall or bite your tongue while eating. A malevolent ghost that can make you mildly ill and need an IV for two days is already considered formidable.

Things like malevolent ghosts running rampant and killing people everywhere, as seen in movies, are impossible in reality; otherwise, the Yang Realm would have descended into chaos long ago.

Even Zhou Ze, who had already undergone *jieshi huanhun* (borrowing a corpse to return a soul), was so low-key.
How dare those mere scraps without physical bodies come out to show off?

This week, when he had nothing to do, Zhou Ze would read books, daydream, trim his nails, and incidentally check if the malevolent ghost behind him had become clearer.

It was quite like... a nurturing experience, feeling the weight of paternal love.
Daddy loves you,
Daddy waits for you to grow up.

Zhou Ze could clearly perceive the emotions of the one behind him. His greatest hatred wasn't directed at the cause of the fire, but at Zhou Ze himself. He was resentful, angry, anticipating, waiting.

Perhaps,
In his view, tonight, his *touqi*, was the time for his revenge.

Interesting.
Zhou Ze flicked his cigarette ash. Once he fully formed, Zhou Ze would show him how red the flowers were.

Zhou Ze didn't feel he did anything wrong by saving people, nor did he feel the man in the suit was wrong to hate him.

Previously, Zhou Ze had encountered a similar situation: someone was drowning, and another person went down to rescue them. The drowning person clung tightly to the rescuer, and they both drowned.

Generally, when rescuing someone in water, you should approach them from behind and embrace them for the rescue. If you approach from the front, the drowning person can easily grab you tightly as their last straw.

Of course, understanding is one thing,
But understanding will not be Zhou Ze's reason for allowing the man in the suit to run wild in his bookstore tonight at midnight.

During the day, Zhou Ze ordered takeout and chatted with the new delivery driver, learning that the previous driver who saved people had recently become famous. Not only did he attend various award ceremonies, but he was also praised and rewarded internally by his company, now nicknamed "the most handsome delivery guy." He's still delivering food, but he does it while live-streaming, and his popularity is incredibly high.

While drinking aged vinegar and eating his meal, Zhou Ze casually scrolled through Weibo and found the delivery driver on the hot search list.

A week has passed since the incident. From the initial handling and summing up to the current development and promotion of positive energy, it's currently at its peak in terms of topic popularity and buzz. The incident's influence has spread not only in Tongcheng but across the entire country.

At 11 PM, Zhou Ze watched the man in the suit slowly solidify further while watching a movie. The movie was called *Cop Toxin*, a few years old work by the recently famous director Dante Lam, starring Daniel Wu and Nick Cheung.

The bookstore door was pushed open, and a delivery driver in a uniform walked in, holding a selfie stick.

"This is a bookstore I frequent. After I finish my busy delivery shifts every day, I come here to read. It's not for any scholarly pursuits, but simply because I enjoy reading."

With that, the delivery driver took down a copy of Wen Tiejun's *Eight Crises* from the bookshelf.

This book discusses China's economic crises throughout its modern history. The delivery driver opened the book, sat on a plastic stool, and read with great relish.

Zhou Ze remembered that last time he came, he read two volumes of *Battle Through the Heavens*.

"Alright, that's it for the live stream today. I want to quietly read for a bit. Everyone, please get some rest too. Thank you all for your company today." The delivery driver bowed to his phone screen.

The phone screen was flooded with card purchases, planes, and rockets, indicating truly terrifying popularity.

Turning off his phone, the delivery driver closed *Eight Crises*, stretched, looked at Zhou Ze, and said:

"Boss, let's go get some late-night supper. My treat."

Zhou Ze shook his head, pointing to the computer screen in front of him.

"What are you watching?" The delivery driver came closer, looked at the screen, and smiled, "I've seen this movie, *Cop Toxin*, right?"

"Mhm." Zhou Ze nodded, simultaneously checking the time in the bottom right corner of the screen. It was almost midnight.

The "baby" behind him was already quite impatient.

"No reporters interviewed you?" the delivery driver asked.

Zhou Ze shook his head.

"You really should have accepted interviews. It would have been much better for your bookstore's business."

"I like quiet," Zhou Ze said, feigning a cool demeanor, though not entirely truthfully.

Money is important, but life is more important.

"We can watch this movie later," the delivery driver seemed to feel a kinship with Zhou Ze, being a companion who had rushed into the fire to save people.

There was a certain...
Mutual appreciation.

"Do you know?" Zhou Ze began, "Cop Toxin is based on a real case. The real-life protagonist's name was apparently Tsui Po-ko."

"Hey, I really didn't know that." The delivery driver smiled somewhat shyly, "It's just watching a movie, who pays attention to that?"

"Mhm, you're right." Zhou Ze closed the computer, stretched, "It's so late, what do you want to eat?"

"Whatever."

"Then I'll order takeout."

"No, let's go out to eat. My treat. What good stuff is there in takeout? Let me tell you, some restaurant kitchens are simply unwatchable, and some businesses don't even have a physical store, they just rent a dilapidated house and do it themselves. Tsk tsk, anyway, I wouldn't dare eat it."

"I see." Zhou Ze nodded, "By the way, do you know what happened with Tsui Po-ko?"

"You tell me, then I'll know, won't I?"

"He killed his colleagues, took the money, and then went about his life freely, even appearing on TV shows. He liked to show off, to be famous." Zhou Ze rubbed the tip of his nose, "A very complex person, he really enjoyed being on camera."

The delivery driver was silent for a moment, not continuing the topic. Instead, he said, "Boss, are you going to get late-night supper or not?"

"I don't really want to. Look at how many pagoda incense sticks are in front of my shop. They've been smoking me out all day; I've lost all appetite."

Pagoda incense sticks are large incense candles, taller than an average person, stacked in layers like a pagoda, very thick, and they burn for a long time.

"Heh heh, there's absolutely no smell in your shop at all," the delivery driver said, pointing to the central air conditioning above Zhou Ze's bookstore. "This here, that must be an air purifier, right?"

"Mhm, installed with the air conditioning. And I always spray some air freshener in the bookstore; after all, you need to create a reading atmosphere, right? We don't offer coffee or pastries, so we can only offer a pleasant scent."

"So, Boss, you're still not giving me face," the delivery driver said, feigning anger, "We did go through life and death together, you know."

Zhou Ze raised his hand and asked curiously, "So, I've always been curious about something."

"What is it?"

"That day, I didn't smell anything at all. In my shop, it's very difficult, almost impossible, to smell other scents from outside. That day, how did you smell the fire?"

The delivery driver paused, his expression a bit unnatural, but he didn't make a big deal of it. He said, "My nose has been good since I was little. My grandma used to say I had a dog's nose. When I was a kid, I was great at finding hidden snacks at home."

"Do you know what day today is?" Zhou Ze asked again.

"What day?"

"*Touqi*."

"*Touqi*?"

"Yes, the *touqi* of those seven people who died in the fire!"

title: 第二十七章 深夜派對
content:
The delivery driver stood still, looking at Zhou Ze who was seated behind the counter.

"Don't be afraid, there are no cameras in the shop, and I don't have a voice recorder either," Zhou Ze stretched, "Of course, you won't believe me when I say that. Tsk, whatever."

"I don't know what you mean by that," the delivery driver was calm.

Anyone who could do such a thing must be very calm.

The police haven't precisely identified the arsonist yet, which speaks to his skill—though here, it's a derogatory term.

"I am absolutely certain that you set that fire," Zhou Ze spread his hands. He was merely stating a fact, a fact that needed no rebuttal.

"You're drunk," the delivery driver said.

"Not drunk."

Zhou Ze smiled.

"Based on that, you're saying I set the fire? You're better than the police?" The delivery driver's composure was beginning to fray, but he still restrained himself.

"Hiss... Of course I'm not better than the police, but I'm not blind. As for me saying I determined you were the arsonist based on that, I'm sorry, it wasn't.

I just confirmed you were the arsonist first, then reverse-engineered a piece of evidence, just to get a taste of being Conan."

Zhou Ze pointed behind the delivery driver.

The delivery driver immediately turned his head, thinking there were police standing there, but there was no one, nor any siren sounds.

In this mall, which was practically deserted, and late at night, there wasn't even a single passerby.

"They all came in with you," Zhou Ze said.

"Who?" The delivery driver frowned.

"The six people who died in the cinema. They followed you in, and then I just went 'oh,' you're the killer. It's obvious.

Unless that idiotic clown standing behind me is singularly focused on hating me,

You can't possibly say the other six victims all mistook their killer, can you?"

Zhou Ze slowly stood up, looking at the delivery driver in front of him.

"Playing tricks!" The delivery driver almost roared. For some reason, he felt the pressure increasing, and cold sweat began to bead on his face.

"Don't be nervous, they can't harm you."

Zhou Ze walked out from behind the counter, holding a plastic bag.

Inside the plastic bag were small boxes of rice and some pickles.

In Zhou Ze's vision, six people, both men and women, including two elderly individuals, were sitting on plastic stools.

They were all quietly reading, very still, not making any noise.

In front of each person, Zhou Ze placed a bowl of rice, topped with pickles, with disposable chopsticks standing upright in the rice.

Then, Zhou Ze took out a bottle of baijiu costing less than 10 yuan, poured it into plastic cups from the water dispenser, and placed a cup in front of each person.

"Brothers, it's not easy for me either. This bookstore has been losing money, so I can only treat you with these. Don't mind me being cheap, alright? You guys are dead, but I still have to live.

Anyway, your families will also make offerings to you, so it's not like you're missing out on a little from me, right?"

Zhou Ze bent down, speaking as if he were greeting regular customers.

He wasn't so kind as to leave a portion for the brain-damaged idiot behind him.

"You're out of your damn mind!" The delivery driver couldn't hold back. "Ha, I should really record this and upload it online, let the netizens see what you're like!"

"Do you dare?" Zhou Ze turned sideways. "You talk as if you really dare. How many days have you been livestreaming? Even 55 has fallen."

Indeed, there were many reasons why the police hadn't found the arsonist yet, but if the police had a key suspect to investigate, the arsonist would find it very difficult to remain hidden.

"I'm leaving, you're crazy."

The delivery driver's earlier amiable demeanor vanished. He managed to successfully convert his popularity into livestreaming income, also earning a huge revenue, not just because he was a "hero," but also due to his marketing strategy.

He was down-to-earth, and his original persona was well-established. On this foundation, livestreaming food delivery, which could have been boring, became captivating to watch.

He knew he was panicked, he was flustered, so he wanted to leave, to escape this bookstore.

He regretted coming here today, deeply regretted it.

Zhou Ze didn't stop him. However, as the delivery driver reached out to push open the bookstore door,

Zhou Ze took out his phone and checked the time, saying,

"It's midnight."

"Dong!"

There was no clock in the bookstore, but at that moment, the delivery driver seemed to hear a bell tolling.

He pushed the door hard, but it didn't budge. He became angry, looked at the lock, it wasn't locked, and there was nothing blocking it, but the door just wouldn't open.

The delivery driver began to frantically kick the door, but it still didn't move an inch.

What he couldn't see was,

The six people who were sitting there reading,

All slowly stood up.

On the seventh day after death, the soul returns home.

Every injustice has its perpetrator, every debt its master.

They came here, following their enemy.

And now,

They all stared fixedly at their enemy,

A person who had set fire and killed them, yet became a hero.

"I told you not to save me!"

A low growl came from behind Zhou Ze.

Zhou Ze happened to blow on his fingernails at this moment, then sharply turned around. The nails on his right hand instantly lengthened, their translucent black radiating an unusual glow, wisps of black aura swirling around his fingertips, bringing an unnerving presence.

At the same time, black mist churned in Zhou Ze's eyes.

"Hsssss... AHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHH!!!!!!!!!!!!"

The black-suited man, who had just managed to transform into a malevolent spirit, was directly grabbed by the shoulder by Zhou Ze's hand. He then began to tremble. The black aura from Zhou Ze's fingertips was like sharp little knives constantly piercing his body, and wisps of green smoke rose upwards from the top of the black-suited man's head.

"I understand you, but you disgust me."

Zhou Ze said in a deep voice,

"So, goodbye."

Zhou Ze applied more force with his fingers.

The black-suited man wailed and showed a pleading expression. He hoped Zhou Ze would spare him. He had already become a vengeful spirit; once he "died" again, his soul would be scattered, with no chance of even entering hell.

But Zhou Ze didn't let go,

His gaze remained icy.

Only when the black-suited man's body had completely melted and evaporated did he retract his hand, subtly seeing some ashes in his palm.

"Whew..."

Zhou Ze blew on his palm, then clapped his hands.

Turning around, Zhou Ze sighed.

He wondered if it was because of his presence that the bookstore's layout had changed,

Or,

Perhaps it was just a coincidence.

The six customers who had entered earlier and quietly read books were now emanating black mist, showing signs of transforming into malevolent spirits seeking revenge.

Meanwhile, the delivery driver continued to frantically punch and kick the wall.

Looking up, "Heaven spares no one" might just describe the scene before him.

These six victims, too, were once panicked and disoriented amidst thick smoke and raging fire, unable to escape, tragically dying within.

"Everyone, please give me some face. Don't be in such a hurry to become malevolent spirits."

Zhou Ze walked into the group, raising his hand in a gesture towards the six people.

"Come on, relax, give big brother a smile?"

Zhou Ze wanted to lighten the mood. Once they became malevolent spirits, they wouldn't enter reincarnation. After seeking revenge and completely losing their obsession, they could only dissipate into the wind.

This was the most tragic outcome.

Zhou Ze felt that it wasn't worth it, truly not worth it.

The arsonist had already caused their deaths, separating them from their loved ones. Their children lost a father or mother, their parents lost a child.

There was no need to push themselves into an even more terrifying abyss because of this killer.

However, Zhou Ze's words had no effect.

The six people's faces remained icy, and the black mist around them grew thicker. Black patterns began to appear around their eyes and lips.

They were quickly starting to resemble the idiotic black-suited man just before he charged at him.

"Since you won't smile for big brother, how about big brother smiles for you?"

Zhou Ze forced a very ugly smile.

It was over,

What a mess,

Beyond saving.

Zhou Ze knew it would be easy for him to disperse these malevolent spirits, just like the idiot who had been following him for a week, who, just when his cooldown was over and he was about to unleash a big move, was slapped to death by him.

But making himself exorcise these ghosts, he truly didn't know how to do it. Moreover, Zhou Ze himself was a ghost, so it wasn't convenient for him to do this, like asking Zhang Fei to embroider.

"There is a path in the netherworld, and the Underworld River can be crossed!"

A sharp cry came from outside, followed by the bookstore door being pushed open. Xu Qinglang entered, holding a small porcelain bowl with rice grains and three lit incense sticks.

"Rise!"

The three incense sticks burned rapidly.

At the same time, the rice grains in the bowl turned from crystal white to black, and the black mist on the six people began to thin. Finally, their expressions shifted from cold and stern to peaceful and serene.

The six people slowly sat down, each in front of their bowl and chopsticks.

"Xu Qinglang!" Zhou Ze shouted, pointing at Xu Qinglang.

So excited,

Truly excited,

More excited than seeing Dr. Lin stepping out of a bath.

Just thinking about how difficult it had been for him to eat this past week,

How could he not be excited!

As for Xu Qinglang's recent display, Zhou Ze wasn't surprised. In fact, everyone had simply seen through it but chosen not to say anything before.

Xu Qinglang gave Zhou Ze a sidelong glance, an instant transformation of charm, like azaleas blooming on the mountain.

But at the same time, he said exasperatedly,

"Are you having a New Year's Eve midnight party in here?"

"I didn't want to," Zhou Ze briefly explained the situation to Xu Qinglang.

Xu Qinglang nodded, indicating he understood, and bowed to the six people, saying,

"Everyone, on the seventh day after death, it's best to return and see your loved ones. They should be waiting for you at home. I will give you an explanation for what happened here."

Upon hearing this, the six people silently passed through the glass and left.

Zhou Ze's gaze then fell upon the bowl containing the "black rice."

"Why doesn't this stuff affect me?"

Xu Qinglang's mouth twitched. He forcefully suppressed the urge to flare up and fight Zhou Ze for three hundred rounds,

And snorted,

"You're different."

He was still angry, still held a grudge against Zhou Ze, and was still unbalanced, but because of his appearance, demeanor, and voice, that phrase "You're different" carried a strong sense of a maiden's resentment.

Next,

Xu Qinglang looked at the delivery driver, who was curled up in a corner, having fainted from fear. "How should we deal with him?"

Saying this, Xu Qinglang made a gesture of cutting something in half.

Zhou Ze shook his head,

And said,

"Let's hand him over to the state."

title: 第二十八章 你想……接替我麼？
content:
周澤最後報了警，警察很快來了，按照周澤的說法，是說這位外賣小哥來到自己店裡後忽然發了瘋，說有很多被他燒死的人亡魂來找他復仇，然後不停地對著牆壁狂踹狂砸最後暈厥了過去。



  從警局做完筆錄出來時，天都已經亮了，影院縱火案，一波三折，但現在至少打開了局面，之前警方很可能只是因為燈下黑的緣故，沒有懷疑到見義勇為的外賣小哥身上，現在哪怕還沒有確切的證據，但只要真的將目光落在對方身上進行查找，應該很快就能發現真相。



  至於之後輿論的轉向，網上吃瓜群眾的顛覆以及那些曾給這位外賣小哥刷禮物的目瞪口呆，就不是周澤需要擔心和思考的問題了，他能做的，也就只有這麼多，願意做的，也就只有這麼多。



  鬼的事兒，還是交給鬼來解決，人的事兒，還是交給警察來解決為好。



  站在警局門口，呼吸著清晨新鮮的空氣，頭腦頓覺清醒。



  打車回到店裡時，周澤看見隔壁許清朗的店已經重新開門營業了，許清朗本人換了一身平常點的衣服坐在店鋪門口一邊擇菜一邊曬著太陽，嘴裡還哼著「童子戲」（地方曲種）小調，悠哉悠哉，自有一股子風流韻味流淌出來。



  一切，



  仿佛依舊。



  周澤走到店裡，許清朗拍了拍手，問道：「吃啥？」 



  「隨便吧，我要酸梅汁。」



  許清朗點點頭。



  周澤在店裡坐了下來，手指輕輕地敲擊著桌面。



  不一會兒，許清朗端上來一碗雞蛋面，麵湯清澈，麵條筋道，當然，這些都不重要，最重要的是，熟悉的酸梅汁，又出現在了周澤面前。



  「給我做一桶吧，多少錢？」周澤指了指店裡的飲水機水桶，「先做一桶。」



  「等過陣子吧。」許清朗在周澤面前坐下來，嘴裡叼著一根煙，他似乎很想做出一副小痞子抽菸吊啊吊的姿態，但偏偏給人一種「女人抽菸也能這般美麗」的違和感。



  他不娘，也不gay，只能怪老天給錯了皮囊。



  就著酸梅汁吃完了面，破天荒地，這次吃碗麵後周澤的噁心感不再那麼強烈了，但依舊多喝了好幾杯水緩了緩。



  「記得林黛玉初進賈府吃飯後遇到什麼事兒麼？」許清朗吐出一口煙圈問道。



  周澤想了想，明白了過來。



  林黛玉初入賈府，第一頓家宴，飯畢後，下人送上茶湯，林黛玉在家裡被父親教導過飯後不宜飲茶容易消化不良，但見賈母和諸多姐妹都喝了，她也只能跟著一起喝。



  「我能吃飽了就行。」周澤搖搖頭，以他現在這個情況，很可能這輩子是做不成一個老饕或者美食家了，至於消化問題，再說吧。 



  「我心裡有些不平衡。」許清朗開門見山地說道，「我父母，走了。」



  許清朗父母早就走了，但周澤清楚許清朗這次說「走了」是什麼意思，應該是下去了。



  「怎麼忽然就走了？」周澤問道，本想回應一個「節哀」，想想，不合適。



  「被發現了。」



  周澤拿煙的手微微一抖，



  被發現了？



  周澤記得那個老者在臨死前，也曾喊過「他們發現我了！」



  許清朗看著周澤，「我很不甘心，也很不平衡，為什麼她帶走了我父母，卻不帶走你。」



  「他？她？」周澤腦海中浮現出了那個小蘿莉的形象，再結合許清朗那日的狀態和晚上的離開，就猜出了七七八八。



  「她，不可能吧。」



  「陰司有序，亡者上路！」許清朗壓低了聲音，盯著周澤的眼睛，「長舌化路引，深喉許幽冥，熟悉麼？」



  「黑白無常？」



  「那只是一個統稱。」許清朗嘆了口氣，「但他們確實是執法者，遊歷陽間，肅清秩序，將人和鬼，區分開來。人有人間道，鬼有奈何橋。」



  「哦。」



  周澤還是有些不太相信，如果小蘿莉真的是白無常那種的身份，那她之前在校車上顯露出真身吐出長舌頭導致車禍和那位司機的死亡該怎麼算？ 



  「她沒帶走我，反而帶走你父母，所以，你恨我？」周澤伸手指了指自己。



  「對。」許清朗點頭道。



  「那這面里沒下毒吧？」



  「…………」許清朗。



  「沒下毒吧？」周澤又問道。



  「沒。」許清朗回答。



  「那就好。」周澤並不知道，在那天的回鍋肉蓋澆飯里，飯菜里是下了毒的，若不是那天林醫生來得早了一些，可能自己真得吃下那頓飯。



  「你是真傻還是假傻？」許清朗有些沒好氣地看著周澤，「她為什麼不抓你？」



  「對啊，她為什麼不抓我？」周澤也問道。



  「我問你呢！」許清朗提高了聲音。



  「我也不知道。」周澤攤攤手，「可能，是因為我救了她一次吧。」



  「…………」許清朗。



  兩個人的談話，最後以菸頭燒滅了作為終止符。



  雙方這次算是開門見山了，打破了原本的那種默不作聲地默契。



  周澤走回自己的店裡，收拾地上的塑料板凳時，卻發現有六張塑料板凳下面都貼著厚度不均的冥鈔。



  這是看書錢還是吃飯錢？ 



  周澤記得前陣子那個開直播的老道也曾給自己一沓冥鈔，說是能積攢陰德，那麼，他的那些冥鈔就是以這種方式弄來的麼？



  他是怎麼弄過來的？



  周澤將冥鈔都收集起來，整整一沓，手感不錯，沒有平日裡見到的那些冥鈔的粗糙，摸在手裡，有絲綢的觸感。



  這讓周澤想到了老道所說的冥店，和鬼做生意，最好的店鋪當然是冥店，因為那裡賣的東西，也都是給死人的。



  也因此，如果自己手中現在拿的冥鈔是死人的「鈔票」，那麼開冥店，肯定能比自己賺得更多。



  腦海中，再次浮現出視頻畫面里坐在櫃檯後面艱難喝粥的男子，



  周澤忽然覺得，



  自己好像發現了一件可能會很有趣的事情。



  當然，再有趣的事兒，現在也沒精力去管了，昨晚一宿沒睡，現在既然回來了，就得好好地補一個覺。



  周澤將書店捲簾門給拉了下來，上了鎖，不知道為什麼，他的書店正在變得晚上開門的時間比白天多，或許，自己以後有機會可以再訂做一個牌子，



  叫



  「深夜書屋。」



  反正白天也沒什麼生意，書店也一直在虧損著，自己可以隨意地玩一些噱頭，搞一些事情，最爛最壞的結果也不就是現在這個樣子唄。 



  外賣小哥的事兒是罪大惡極的錯誤，但也給周澤一些啟發。



  衛生間的洗澡設備已經被裝了起來，周澤買的是電熱水器，脫去衣服，周澤洗了一個澡，換上了一套干整的衣服上了樓。



  當周澤彎下腰準備調置冰櫃溫度時，整個人卻愣在了那裡，



  因為在他面前的冰櫃裡，



  躺著一個人。



  對方閉著眼，像是陷入了沉睡，呼吸平穩，雙手交叉放在胸前，有著一種小大人似地安逸。



  很平靜，也很可愛，



  前提是，



  她的舌頭如果不會變得那麼長的話。



  小蘿莉，



  把自己的巢穴給鵲巢鳩占了。



  周澤很想大喊一聲，讓隔壁的許清朗同學過來復仇。



  但想想還是算了，不是他覺得把許清朗喊來復仇是害了他，而是他認為許清朗也沒那個膽子過來復仇，說不定人家來了他還會親切地問候一聲：



  「您醒了啊？



  您想吃點什麼？



  我給您去做。」



  小蘿莉睜開了眼，她的眸子很深邃，不再是以往見面的清澈和單純。 



  對方伸出手，周澤幫忙把冰櫃蓋子打開。



  小蘿莉從裡面坐起來，周澤注意到了，她其實沒有設置溫度，只是選擇了一個通風換氣。



  「你躺在這裡，不冷麼？」坐在冰櫃裡的小蘿莉開口問道，沒等周澤回答，小蘿莉又開口道：「哦，我忘了，你不一樣。」



  說完，坐在冰櫃裡的小蘿莉伸手輕輕拍了拍自己身邊的空位置，一臉天真無邪地看向周澤：



  「一起睡不？」



  周澤伸手想要揉一揉這個女孩兒的頭，但手在旁邊，卻停了下來。



  她是黑白無常一類的存在，是陰司在人間的執法者。



  小蘿莉伸手，她的小手抓住了周澤的大手，把周澤的手按在她的頭上，然後按著周澤的手在自己頭上來回揉了揉。



  「…………」周澤。



  「你，很好。」小蘿莉終於從冰櫃裡站起來，但似乎因為腿短的原因，爬出來有些困難。



  周澤將她從冰櫃裡抱出來，



  也不知道她之前是怎麼躺進去的。



  「你，很好。」小蘿莉伸手指著周澤，「重複道。」



  「額……謝謝。」周澤不知道該如何回復了。 



  「我要走了。」小蘿莉轉過身，背對著周澤，雙手交叉負於身後，周澤知道她是想表現出一種高山仰止的氣質。



  但她的問題和許清朗一樣，



  老天給錯了皮囊。



  她這個樣子，怎麼都覺得好可愛。



  憋住，



  不准笑。



  周澤在不停地提醒自己，



  這是黑白無常老爺，



  不准笑！



  哈哈哈哈哈！



  但還是忍不住啊！



  作死了哈哈哈！



  完蛋了哈哈哈！



  憋得越狠笑起來就越誇張，連眼淚都滴出來了。



  小蘿莉沒理會周澤的笑聲，也沒治周澤一個大不敬之罪，



  只是問道：



  「你想，接替我麼？」

title: 第二十九章 過分麼？
content:
"Do you want to take my place?"

This question caught Zhou Ze off guard.

What did that mean?

Was he going from an unregistered resident, hiding from city to city, to a local civil servant all of a sudden?

The surprise came too suddenly.

Zhou Ze was hesitant to accept.

Pies might fall from the sky, but most people who encountered such things ended up being killed by the pie itself.

Most importantly, Zhou Ze didn't believe that saving her life was worth her treating him like this.

One should know that the matter with the driver still hadn't been cleared up. This little loli was very cute, but that was just her skin.

Xu Qinglang had said that she once appeared in his shop, expressionlessly stuck out her tongue, and took away the souls of his parents.

No matter how Xu Qinglang cried and pleaded, she remained unmoved.

One couldn't expect such a person to repay kindness. It would be a blessing if she didn't bite you back.

As a ghost messenger from the Underworld,

How many joys and sorrows had she witnessed?

How much human evil had she seen?

How much ghost malevolence had she encountered?

She wasn't a simple little girl, nor could she be.

"What's wrong, speechless?" The little loli asked again.

"I don't know what to say. Are you just asking casually?" Zhou Ze asked cautiously.

"You can answer that you don't want to," the little loli said.

Then, silence.

The little loli continued, "And then, I'll drag you down."

"............" Zhou Ze.

Alright.

Wouldn't that be more comfortable?

Why bother with multiple-choice questions?

Just fill in the blank.

The question was: if you don't write "Y," you'll be shot.

"I agree," Zhou Ze replied. This time, he didn't hesitate or struggle.

The little loli turned around, smiled, somewhat innocently, and then slowly walked to Zhou Ze. She pretended to be a grown-up and tried to straighten Zhou Ze's collar.

This seemed to be a way for a superior to show regard for a subordinate, much like ancient emperors granting their officials the opportunity to dine with them.

However, the little loli was too short. When she stood in front of Zhou Ze, she couldn't reach his collar, so she could only help him adjust his belt.

"Pick me up," the little loli pouted and commanded.

Zhou Ze bent down and picked up the little loli.

The little loli reached out to help Zhou Ze straighten his collar, then frowned, seemingly feeling that being held by Zhou Ze like a daughter was somewhat inappropriate.

"Do I look silly like this?"

"Very cute."

The little loli extended her small hand, intending to slap Zhou Ze's cheek directly.

At that instant, Zhou Ze's nails, as he held the little loli, rapidly lengthened and darkened, and a black vortex swirled in the depths of his eyes.

The little loli stopped, a meaningful smile appearing at the corner of her mouth.

Zhou Ze didn't make any further moves either.

"Do you know that showing anger and resistance in front of me is a very silly act?" the little loli asked.

"Doesn't matter, I'm already someone who's died once anyway."

"That's because you were lucky. You only walked a short distance on the Yellow Springs Road before leaving. You never experienced the pain and torment of a trip to hell!" The little loli said loudly. "That kind of torment makes all who commit suicide and go to hell regret it immensely! It's better to live a bad life than to die a good one—that's no empty comfort."

"Is that so?"

"Put me down."

Zhou Ze put the little loli down.

The little loli leaned back slightly, looking at Zhou Ze. "Do you know why I chose you?"

Zhou Ze shook his head.

"Because you're very smart, or rather, you're very calm and know your limits," the little loli said, counting on her fingers. "The Underworld has order, and the mortal world has laws. Many people sneak out for various reasons, but you're the calmest one I've ever seen."

"I don't believe that's the real reason," Zhou Ze said.

"I don't want to tell you the real reason," the little loli stretched. "I'm tired and want to go down, so I happened to meet you, and you won't cause too much trouble, so I chose you.

Heh heh, a while ago in Rongcheng, there was a guy who made a lot of noise. He was clearly a pathetic stowaway, yet he styled himself a judge. As a ghost, he dared to exercise his judgment in the mortal world. Don't you think he was stupid?"

"Stupid," Zhou Ze replied. Then, Zhou Ze suddenly remembered that the old Daoist seemed to be from Rongcheng. "What happened to him afterward?"

"He was banned."

The little loli tilted her head, a look of innocent playfulness on her face. "Rules are flexible, but those who cross the line too much have no hope at all."

"He died?" Zhou Ze asked. "I mean, was he dragged back to hell or his soul scattered?"

Upon hearing this, a hint of anger appeared on the little loli's face, as if her sensitive spot had been touched.

"That, you don't need to know."

The little loli grasped Zhou Ze's palm, her small hand meeting his.

Immediately afterward, Zhou Ze felt a burning sensation in his palm. When the little loli removed her hand, Zhou Ze saw a black rune appear in the center of his palm.

The rune wasn't complex; it looked like an eye.

"The Underworld has order, and the Yellow Springs can be crossed," the little loli said very seriously. "Those who should go down, you send them down. Those who should be scattered, you can scatter directly.

Of course, if you want to shout when you see injustice on the road,
That's fine,
But you bear the cost of that yourself.
If you mess up, you bear the consequences."

The little loli yawned, as if she were tired.

"You said you're tired, so how long will you rest? Am I, like, a substitute?" Zhou Ze asked.

"We'll talk when I get back," the little loli prepared to go downstairs.

Zhou Ze continued to ask, "So what do I do? Patrol every night,
Look for ghosts,
And then,
Mess with ghosts?"

"The door is in your hands, you decide. You can continue running your bookstore. You're a ghost, a ghost possessing a corpse. Those dirty things and miscellaneous creatures will naturally gather around you.

To them, you're a candle in the dark, and they are moths.

Moreover, after I left that mark on you, it's like upgrading you from a candle to an incandescent lightbulb, enough to blind their dog eyes."

"............" Zhou Ze.

The little loli went downstairs, and Zhou Ze followed.

"I'll read a bit, then I'll leave. This body's mother will come to pick her up soon."

The little loli sat down on a plastic chair and casually picked up an illustrated book to read.

Zhou Ze stood beside her, not serving her, but needing to ask some questions.

"Speak," the little loli said.

"Is there... a salary?" Zhou Ze asked. "You know, what I do here is a losing business."

"The economy is sluggish; living people's money is getting harder and harder to earn now," the little loli sighed.

"Yeah," Zhou Ze echoed.

"Then earn money from the dead."

"Money from the dead can't be spent," Zhou Ze shrugged.

"That's because you're doing it wrong," the little loli spread her hands. "Get some ghost money, the kind that dead people give."

Zhou Ze took out a stack of ghost money and split half of it into the little loli's hand.

"You've earned quite a bit, haven't you?" The little loli glanced at him and smiled.

Zhou Ze didn't mention that half of it was given to him by the old Daoist from Rongcheng last time. In a mystical way, Zhou Ze felt that if this little loli knew about it, it would bring him trouble.

The little loli, holding the money, pushed open the bookstore door and squatted on the roadside.

"Lighter."

Zhou Ze handed her the lighter.

The little loli burned the ghost money, and the ashes were quickly blown away.

Then, the little loli stood up and clapped her hands. "Done."

Zhou Ze stood in the wind, feeling a bit disheveled.

"Is this money prepaid into my underground bank account?"

"Let's wait and see. This place of yours still doesn't have enough popularity." The little loli and Zhou Ze, one big and one small, stood at the storefront waiting, for about half an hour.

The little loli's delicate face was somewhat red from the wind, while Zhou Ze wasn't afraid of the cold, but standing there like a simpleton, looking around, felt very strange.

Finally,

A pot-bellied man walked past them, and then, a wallet dropped from the man. The man didn't even notice and continued walking forward.

Zhou Ze went up to pick up the wallet and found that it actually contained several thousand yuan, along with an ID card, bank cards, and other items.

"Should I return it to him?" Zhou Ze asked tentatively.

The little loli burst out laughing,

"This person did something bad, so this time it's a financial loss to avoid disaster. This money is what you deserve."

The little loli pushed open the door and entered the bookstore, then rubbed her hands. Clearly, the past half hour had been quite cold, and the bookstore was warm.

Zhou Ze walked in with the wallet, somewhat disbelieving. "He won't call the police?"

"Take this money; it's not hot at all," the little loli said, a bit impatient.

"Alright, so from now on, if I'm short on money, I'll just stand at the door burning ghost money, and someone will just deliver money to me, right?"

Zhou Ze was a bit exasperated but also found it amusing.

Xu Qinglang came over at that moment, carrying a large bottle of plum juice.

"Hey, we only had this much material in the shop, so I could only make this much. The rest, wait..."

As soon as Xu Qinglang pushed open the door and entered, he saw the little loli sitting there, stumbled, and the bottle in his hand fell to the ground, shattering into pieces.

Plum juice splashed all over the bookstore floor.

Zhou Ze looked at Xu Qinglang, signaling him to control himself.

The little loli seemed to completely disregard Xu Qinglang,

Indeed, a person with good luck and a bit of occult knowledge wasn't worth her second glance.

"Whose daughter is this? So cute, hahahaha, come on, little friend, Uncle has a tank of little goldfish at home, do you want to come with Uncle to see them?"

Xu Qinglang's smile was very awkward, forced out.

The little loli simply spat out one word: "Scram."

Xu Qinglang smiled again, turned around, and returned to his own shop.

"Do you think I'm too much?" The little loli looked up at Zhou Ze.

"A little," Zhou Ze said honestly.

"Then let me tell you again, the driver's death was just because I was bored while sitting on the school bus and revealed my true form to play a prank.

Would you think,
Even more excessive?"

The little loli tilted her head, looking at Zhou Ze, with a blank, innocent expression.

title: 第三十章 biu！
content:
"Is that excessive?"

Zhou Ze had no way to answer that question. Whether what the little loli said was true or false, he had no right to question it deeply.

It was helpless, but it was the truth.

Although he heard the little loli from Rongcheng say that her "kind" from Rongcheng had tried to be the judge of this mortal world in the guise of a ghost,

Zhou Ze admired and respected him greatly, but his end was also lamentable.

When you don't have the capital and the strength to stand on the same line as the other party, you don't even have the right to an equal conversation, so where does the right to question come from?

"Boring." The little loli shook her head, but then smiled, "But that's precisely what I admire about you."

The little loli continued to hold her book in both hands, as if she were about to fall asleep, and murmured:

"You are the most self-aware person I've ever met."

"..." Zhou Ze.

Was that a compliment or an insult?

"I'm leaving." The little loli was getting more and more sleepy, exhausted.

"I have one more question. Is there no other way to solve or improve the eating and sleeping problems?" This was the question Zhou Ze most wanted to ask and most urgently wanted to resolve.

Since his return through 'borrowed corpse, returned soul', apart from these two issues, he could perfectly integrate into social life at all other times.

"Assembled computers are not as stable as original ones." The little loli shook her head weakly. "As for sleeping, unless you have a Yin creature that crawled out of Hell beside you to provide you with a Hell-like environmental magnetic field, you simply can't rest.

You are originally a person from Hell, staying in the human world means you're unacclimated, and it's the most severe kind of unacclimation. Because you have some special qualities, you can still solve it with special methods. Others simply can't sleep; after half a year of no sleep, they are almost driven mad, driven to death!

So, you are already considered lucky."

The little loli gave two more weak "hehe" sounds. "If I don't go back, you could actually hug me to sleep."

"..." Zhou Ze.

"As for eating, I still can't get used to human food."

After saying all this,

The little loli's head tilted to the side, and she directly fell into a deep sleep. Zhou Ze reached out to support her. Seeing that the little loli was still breathing and her body was normal, he immediately breathed a sigh of relief.

Zhou Ze used to be a doctor, so he could naturally tell that the girl was fine.

This little one was Wang Ke's daughter, so he couldn't just watch her have an accident.

However, what disappointed Zhou Ze a little was that the little loli's departure was a bit too ordinary.

"Shouldn't it be a 'biu' sound as she disappears into the ground? Just falling asleep means she's gone back?" Zhou Ze muttered to himself.

It wasn't grand, and there was nothing to see, like drawing a talisman on his palm;

There was no sense of ceremony, no flair.

The little loli in his arms suddenly opened her eyes and said, "Alright."

Zhou Ze was stunned. She was faking sleep!

The next moment,

A mass of dense Yin energy, so thick it seemed to condense into droplets, surged from the little loli. Even with the central air conditioning on in Zhou Ze's bookstore, the temperature instantly dropped;

The door was closed, but gusts of cold wind swept through inside, along with the rustling sound of turning pages.

A vast shadow covered the area, like the awakening of a ferocious beast, bringing a pressure that only ghosts could perceive.

Zhou Ze's fingernails grew back under this stimulation, and a feeling of surging blood rushed through his body, as if his own power was responding to the other party.

Then,

It really was,

A "biu" sound,

All the Yin energy instantly surged into a point underground,

In an instant,

The clouds dispersed, the fog vanished,

The temperature rose,

The sun shone,

In a daze, it truly seemed to echo the line:

It's as if all the birds have flown back to the forest after eating their fill, leaving only a vast, clean expanse!

...

In the evening, Xu Qinglang brought dinner. The sour plum juice was gone, replaced by bitter gourd juice.

"The sour plum juice is gone,

let's just make do with bitter gourd juice for now."

Xu Qinglang said with a bit of embarrassment. During the day, he had been scared out of his wits when he saw the little loli.

Actually, he knew himself that he was quite cowardly and useless.

When his parents were taken away by the little loli, he didn't dare to seek revenge on her, nor did he dare to resist. He could only kneel there and beg like a weakling.

Moreover, he had even taken his anger out on Zhou Ze for this, attempting to poison Zhou Ze's food.

Now, Xu Qinglang had come to terms with it. Cowardly is cowardly, he was just a minor Xuan master with Yin-Yang eyes due to his physical constitution. To make him face the Hell Reapers, he truly didn't have the courage.

In fact, the little loli could have punished him for privately keeping his parents' souls, by deducting his lifespan or even directly taking his soul back to Hell.

She had treated him like a fart and let him go,

So there was no need for him to jump around anymore.

The dead cannot be brought back to life, and his previous actions had indeed violated the laws of heaven.

Zhou Ze finished his meal and placed a thousand yuan in front of Xu Qinglang.

"Money for previous meals, plus future ones. Let me know when it runs out."

"Oh, got money now?" Xu Qinglang finally showed a hint of a smile, then pushed the money back to Zhou Ze, saying softly, "Life is tough, don't be extravagant. You need to be mindful of your family."

"..." Zhou Ze.

"I'm a man with over twenty apartments; I don't care about your small change."

"..." Zhou Ze.

Zhou Ze really wanted to say that he would soon have money too, as long as he earned more 'dead people's money,' then burned paper money at the entrance, some idiot would come to his shop and throw their wallet, like a scattering money child.

But Zhou Ze thought about it again,

Even if he burned a carload of ghost money, he wouldn't be able to burn enough for twenty-something apartments, would he?

Unless an armored truck had an accident in front of his shop...

"I'm thinking of changing storefronts, what about you?" Xu Qinglang suddenly asked.

"Change to where?"
