People often say that those who live to be seventy or eighty are almost like foxes, but this female corpse had lived for two hundred years, enduring the vicissitudes of life.

Zhou Ze ignored the female corpse’s “lament” and turned his head to Xu Qinglang.

“Can she be killed?” Zhou Ze asked.

“…………” The female corpse.

Xu Qinglang shook his head, then nodded.

“What does that mean?” Zhou Ze asked.

“The malevolent energy within her is an issue. If she were to self-detonate that energy in her last moments and it leaked out, it would certainly affect innocent people nearby,” Xu Qinglang explained. “That would be very troublesome.”

“Indeed.”

The female corpse echoed, having given up on trying to play on Zhou Ze’s emotions. The most heartless are the ungrateful, and clearly, Zhou Ze had now been blacklisted in her mind.

“But she wouldn’t dare to pull that stunt. Otherwise, her soul would already be in Hell. If she causes any heinous trouble in the mortal realm, she would also be punished in Hell.

So, she can still be killed.”

Xu Qinglang held a cigarette in his mouth. Before, he had been flustered like a quail about to be forced, but now, with the ‘Cosmic Burst’ Zhou Ze beside him, he could enjoy the show and make sarcastic remarks.

“Don’t kill me, don’t kill me! She is her, I am me. We are two different people!”

The female corpse hastily cried out. She could see that these two men genuinely intended to use a permanent solution on her.

All intelligent beings possess a survival instinct, and the female corpse was no exception.

A thousand sails pass by a sunken boat, and countless trees sprout before a decaying one;

The female corpse was not, in fact, Madam Bai. To a certain extent, she was an independent life, a “spiritual intelligence” born from Madam Bai’s physical body after two hundred years. However, the female corpse and Madam Bai still had countless intricate connections.

Xu Qinglang was right. The female corpse dared not do anything excessive in the mortal realm. Even if she died, she would not choose to act recklessly and cause Madam Bai to suffer punishment in Hell.

Zhou Ze squatted down in front of the female corpse. “Then what did you mean earlier? Was it just for fun?”

The female corpse nodded.

“Heh heh.” Zhou Ze chuckled twice. Thinking about it now, he had been a bit too “young” and inexperienced as a ghost messenger, which was why he had agreed to Madam Bai’s request.

“Is there no way to subdue her?” Zhou Ze asked.

“Extracting a wisp of her zombie soul blood would allow you to control her, but she has to willingly give it to you,” Xu Qinglang suggested from the side.

The female corpse suddenly lifted her head, her eyes flashing with intense hatred as she stared fixedly at Xu Qinglang, as if at this moment, Xu Qinglang was her greatest enemy.

“Either die, or hand over your soul blood. You choose,” Xu Qinglang said with a smile.

“You… choose for yourself,” Zhou Ze also looked at the female corpse. Clearly, he agreed with Xu Qinglang’s suggestion.

Zhou Ze had a clean freak, and he didn’t want the female corpse to inexplicably come down and clean his cup with her tongue again.

“Alright, I’ll give it to you.” The female corpse took a deep breath, as if to bury her current reluctance and anger. Then, she closed her eyes. Immediately, a red, worm-like strand emerged from the center of her forehead.

Zhou Ze reached out and pinched the strand with his fingernails, then pulled it out and placed it in his palm. It was somewhat warm, a little damp, and slippery.

After handing over her soul blood, the female corpse’s spirit suddenly became extremely listless. She almost fainted, barely managing to stay upright.

“Go clean yourself up in the bathroom and then lie down upstairs. From today onwards, you are not allowed to step out of the bookstore without my permission,” Zhou Ze warned.

“Yes, Officer.” The female corpse lowered her head, her posture very submissive. With her soul blood in his grasp, she had no choice but to bow.

…………

*Slap.*

Zhou Ze tossed the medicinal wine bottle onto the table. He was clearly applying medicinal wine to Xu Qinglang, but it sounded as if he were doing something quite disgusting.

“You apply it yourself.”

“Don’t be like that! You weren’t injured, but I was thrown against a wall. I have so many bruises, don’t you have any sympathy?” Xu Qinglang grew more agitated as he spoke. He continued, “Zhou Ze, ever since you came here, haven’t you noticed that I’ve been having bad luck?”

“That’s fate,” Zhou Ze said, refusing to take the blame. “By the way, that incantation you chanted earlier, I found it very familiar.”

*Heaven and Earth without limits, Profound Heart Orthodox Law.*

“It’s from a TV show. I thought it sounded good, so I used it. It doesn’t actually help with casting spells at all,” Xu Qinglang admitted honestly.

“Like adding a BGM for yourself?”

“Heh…………” Xu Qinglang rolled his eyes, picking up the medicinal wine and applying it himself. “There’s some plum juice in the kitchen. Take it with you. I won’t open tomorrow morning; I need more rest.”

“I’m going back to rest.” Zhou Ze stood up, took the plum juice, and bid farewell. After returning to the bookstore, he went straight up to the second floor.

The female corpse, obediently, had washed herself clean and was lying in the freezer, wearing Zhou Ze’s clothes.

The white shirt was a bit too big for her, hanging down and covering the curve of her backside. She wasn’t wearing trousers, and her legs were crossed as she lay there, her eyes alluring.

Zhou Ze tapped the side of the freezer. “I remember Madam Bai saying she died before she was married.”

Because of this, Madam Bai should, in theory, have been a virgin. However, the female corpse before him seemed a bit flirtatious.

“That’s because she didn’t tell you she had an affair with a poor scholar before her marriage, and her father found out, feeling it disgraced the family, and forcibly drowned her.”

“Oh, so, she’s an experienced old hand?”

“Indeed. Do you know how much effort and care she put into making sure I didn’t look as terrifying as a drowned person?”

“Women, after all, love beauty.” Zhou Ze shook his head. “Go to sleep.”

With that, Zhou Ze placed a pillow by the freezer and lay down.

With the female corpse beside him, the chill emanating from her made him feel very comfortable, even more so than lying inside the freezer.

He slept soundly that night. When he woke up the next morning, Zhou Ze opened his eyes and saw a pair of long legs slowly swaying in front of him, even the curve of her instep was just right.

If she were wearing stockings or high heels…

And facing the female corpse, Zhou Ze could be more at ease.

Neither of them was human, so there was no need for the hypocrisy of pretense. It was simpler this way.

“If you can’t hold back, I can lie down. I know you actually want to do that kind of thing.

Holding it in for too long isn’t good, especially since your body isn’t original. Otherwise, there really could be problems, you know.”

The female corpse spoke very openly, and then she smiled, saying, “Don’t worry, I won’t get pregnant.”

Zhou Ze went downstairs to wash up, then started cooking instant noodles. With everything ready, Zhou Ze took out the plum juice and, with great difficulty, finished his morning meal with the instant noodles.

“It must be painful, eating human food,” the female corpse said, sitting on the stair step, turning her face to look at Zhou Ze.

“None of your business.”

“You’re already dead, yet you insist on living like a human. Don’t you get tired?”

“You’re talking a bit too much,” Zhou Ze frowned slightly.

“You said yesterday I’m not allowed to leave the bookstore. So what else can I do besides talk to you?”

Zhou Ze picked up the mop and broom from behind the counter and tossed them all to the female corpse.

“Clean up.”

……………………

The sun was beautiful today. The female corpse knelt on the bookstore’s tiled floor, wiping it with a rag. Zhou Ze, meanwhile, had moved a plastic stool outside the shop and was basking in the sun.

It wasn’t until noon that Xu Qinglang opened his shop door and came out. He took a cigarette from Zhou Ze, glanced at the scene inside the shop, and smiled:

“You’ve trained her well.”

Zhou Ze continued to squint, enjoying the sunlight.

Xu Qinglang exhaled a smoke ring, then, as if he remembered something, said:

“Your signboard is well-made, it has a good vibe. It makes my place next door look inadequate. I’m also planning to get a custom signboard.”

“Pretentious?” Zhou Ze chuckled.

“Is that a problem?” Xu Qinglang raised an eyebrow. “If I display my twenty-something property deeds, who can say I’m not refined?”

Zhou Ze shook his head helplessly.

“Come on, help me brainstorm. I think your ‘*Gū wàng tīng zhī, rú shì wén*’¹ is pretty good. I plan for the horizontal scroll of my couplet to be ‘*Rén shēng rú mèng*’². How’s that? It sounds stylish.

But for the couplet, I’d like something related to ‘eating,’ to fit my restaurant, right?

I haven’t thought of anything good. Do you have any suggestions?”

Zhou Ze pondered for a moment. “Do you really want to hear it?”

“Just say it,” Xu Qinglang urged.

Zhou Ze looked at the female corpse inside the shop and said:

“Humans eat dirt all their lives,
Dirt eats humans once.
Horizontal scroll:
Life is but a dream.”

---
¹ *Gū wàng tīng zhī, rú shì wén*: An idiom that can be translated as “Hear it as you wish; thus I have heard.” It implies that the speaker is relaying information as they heard it, without necessarily endorsing its truth, or that the listener can take it with a grain of salt. In this context, it likely adds an air of detached wisdom or philosophical depth to the bookstore.
² *Rén shēng rú mèng*: “Life is but a dream.”

title: 第三十八章 嬰說
content:
"Here, have a taste, the new version of Sour Plum Juice."

Xu Qinglang placed a cup on Zhou Ze's counter. This sour plum juice looked richer in color than before. He shook it in his hand, as if holding a glass of wine.

"What's different?" Zhou Ze asked before drinking.

"The flavor is richer, a bit like old Huangjiu, with a kick that comes later. It'll keep you from wolfing down your food like before, improving your quality of life."

"Heh, how *sweet*."¹

The female corpse, who was organizing the bookshelf nearby, let out a sour remark.

Zhou Ze took a sip. Unlike the sour plum juice he'd had before, this one was somewhat sweet and refreshing, with a pleasant aftertaste. The flavor was excellent.

However, it didn't seem to be the feeling he was looking for.

But just after he had tasted it for a short while, Zhou Ze felt a sharp pang in his stomach.

"Hiss..."

His body also began to tremble uncontrollably.

That lingering sourness...

So potent.

His fingers curled slightly, then slowly unfurled. Zhou Ze nodded, very satisfied.

"You've thought this through," Zhou Ze said.

"Don't mention it." Xu Qinglang smiled slightly. "I plan to make this one of my signature side dishes. It's a shame that people who like this flavor are probably quite few."

"Mm." Zhou Ze agreed with that.

"Creak."

The bookstore door opened, and a group of students walked in. There were quite a few of them, seven or eight, all looking like "good kids."

"Boss, what's the WiFi password?" a girl asked.

Zhou Ze pointed to the wall, where it was written.

"Phew..."

The students each found plastic stools and sat down. Then the girl took some homework out of her backpack and distributed it for the others to copy.

With the winter break about to end, this was a pretty normal sight.

Zhou Ze naturally wouldn't be so bored as to go educate these kids about the meaning of learning or the drawbacks of copying others' homework. He tapped his finger on the counter, and the female corpse, understanding, came over to pour Zhou Ze a cup of warm water.

The leading girl walked over to the bookshelf, casually flipping through books. After choosing a few, she walked up to Zhou Ze. "How much?"

"Ninety-five," Zhou Ze replied.

"Here, keep the change."

The girl was generous, throwing down a hundred-yuan note.

Zhou Ze took the money and said nothing more.

By about five in the afternoon, this batch of students had finished copying their homework and left. The bookstore returned to its usual quietness.

Xu Qinglang wasn't in the shop; he had gone to custom-order a plaque. Of course, he wouldn't order one like Zhou Ze had suggested:

"Man eats earth a lifetime, earth eats man once."

Because anyone with a normal brain could tell that such a plaque was not suitable for a dining place; it was more fitting for the sides of a grave.

The female corpse worked quite efficiently. Today, she cleaned both the first and second floors. Apart from occasionally posing suggestively to show off her charm, she basically showed no other flaws.

She didn't say where she was going, and Zhou Ze didn't ask.

Of course, Zhou Ze remembered Madam Bai's reminder: "Next Cold Clothes Festival, cremate the corpse with bamboo and wood."

Zhou Ze wasn't sure if Madam Bai knew that her corpse had already developed sentience.

If she knew, yet still entrusted it to him, and at the same time, told him the method and time to cremate her, what did that mean?

Last night, the female corpse also admitted that even if Zhou Ze were to kill her, she would not *bingjie*² on her own, letting the malevolent energy escape and harm innocents, thereby implicating Madam Bai in Hell.

However,

Madam Bai seemed to simply want to cleanly resolve this problem.

From this perspective,

This female corpse, whom he treated as a maid,

was actually a pitiful person.

"What's your name?" Zhou Ze asked.

"My surname is Bai," the female corpse replied.

"Bai what?"

"Bai Yingying."

"Bai Yingying?"³

Zhou Ze nodded. That name was a bit strange.

"Actually, you don't have to struggle so much with eating." The female corpse stretched, her ample figure accentuated. "It's like how you can sleep peacefully when you sleep with me.

Your soul is tainted with the aura of Hell, but your body is still that of a living person.

You need to sleep and eat to replenish your physical body, but your soul doesn't need these things, so it instinctively resists and rejects them."

"Keep going."

"I can feed you from now on." The female corpse smiled shyly. "Food, after passing through my mouth and carrying my juices,

will be imbued with the aura of a ghost. Then, when you eat it, you won't feel so uncomfortable."

Zhou Ze suddenly understood why that glass of water had tasted sweet to him last time. It wasn't that the female corpse's mouth was sweet, but because of this reason.

"Thank you."

"Don't mention it."

A man in a leather jacket walked out from the shop door. His clothes were a bit unfashionable, his hair was messy, and his face was red; he must have been drinking recently.

He walked around outside twice, then finally pushed open the door and entered the bookstore.

At first, Zhou Ze didn't pay much attention, but soon, Zhou Ze's gaze slightly narrowed.

He knew this man.

Sun Tao, his former assistant, a... very promising young doctor.

The female corpse's gaze also sharpened slightly. She lightly poked Zhou Ze's waist and said softly,

"Officer, that, can I eat him?"

Eat a person?

Zhou Ze frowned slightly.

"Officer, didn't you notice, on that person's back?"

Upon this reminder, Zhou Ze stood up and looked at the man's back, which surprisingly had a dark, blob-like object hanging on it.

An ordinary person might not know what it was, because it was indeed quite abstract, somewhat similar to a black worm, but it also had some special human-like features.

But Zhou Ze, due to his former profession, recognized it at a glance—a premature infant.

"Woo woo woo... woo woo woo..."

Perhaps because Zhou Ze had noticed him, the infant let out a faint cry.

This sound was somewhat familiar. Zhou Ze began to search his memories for related incidents. Finally, he found the source of the familiarity.

Nurse Chen.

To be precise, it was the sound that had once come from Nurse Chen's belly, though only Zhou Ze could hear it at the time.

Zhou Ze felt no glee at being able to perform "paternity tests";

only sorrow welled up inside him.

That child, was it still not saved?

The female corpse had said she wanted to eat him, not referring to the person, but the soul of that male infant.

Zhou Ze glared at her. The female corpse pouted, not daring to say anything more, only swallowing her saliva unwillingly, while also pitifully adjusting her heavy chest:

"I don't eat living people's food, and every night I'm like a furnace top, having my malevolent energy harvested by you.

If I don't replenish myself, these will shrivel up, and then you won't be able to peek at me while I work."

Zhou Ze was momentarily stunned. She had been aware of his gaze all along?

"You lecherous ghost," the female corpse cooed.

"Boss, do you have any alcohol?" Sun Tao called out.

"Go next door," Zhou Ze replied, but still stood up and poured him a glass of water.

After all, he was a junior whom Zhou Ze had once mentored. Zhou Ze had grown up in an orphanage, and Sun Tao in a single-parent family. Back then, Zhou Ze had ignored even fangirls like Dr. Lin, yet he had taken great care of this junior named Sun Tao.

For no other reason than their similar personalities; their childhood experiences had taught them the meaning of striving and hard work, both wanting to live and fight to become someone to prove themselves.

"Pfft... hahahaha..." Sun Tao took the water, drank a large gulp, then burst out laughing. "Boss, why are you looking at me like that? I'm not interested in men."

"Oh," Zhou Ze replied.

There's such a beautiful man living next door, I'm not interested in you yet.

Sun Tao sat on the plastic stool, bit his lip, then shook his head.

"Boss, do you have any children?"

"We haven't planned on it yet. He thinks I'm too young," the female corpse interjected from the side, desperately trying to get attention.

Sun Tao looked up at the female corpse. Although she had a full figure and was tall, she looked to be only a high school student. He immediately laughed,

"You really are still young."

The female corpse indignantly turned her face away, then swallowed another mouthful of saliva.

"I actually had a child," Sun Tao said with some emotion.

Zhou Ze wanted to say, you do have a child, and that child is hanging on your back.

With the development of modern medicine and the "modernization" of people's thinking, abortion and induced miscarriage are no longer such harsh words. However, few people realize that the resentment of unborn infants is actually the greatest.

These kinds of untimely deaths make infants most likely to turn into ghosts. Of course, their ability to seek revenge is actually very weak.

At most, due to their resentment, they will bind themselves to their so-called parents for a period, and then they will dissipate on their own.

The female corpse said she wanted to eat him because these kinds of infants, not having been fully born, are like unsprouted seeds. For entities like the female corpse, they have extremely high "nutritional value."

"What happened?" Zhou Ze asked. "Did your girlfriend disagree?"

Zhou Ze remembered that although Nurse Chen had been very uneasy and shocked at the time, she had said she would keep the child.

"No, she was willing, but I wasn't. I chickened out. I told her to abort the child."

For some reason, Sun Tao really wanted to talk to this bookstore owner. In this bookstore owner, he found a familiar big-brother feeling.

And that big brother had passed away more than half a year ago.

"Chickened out?" Zhou Ze asked.

"Her parents originally looked down on me, hehe, their family has very good circumstances," Sun Tao looked up, seemingly trying to hold back his tears.

"But the deed is done," Zhou Ze said.

"But I wasn't willing to use something like that to blackmail their family. I didn't want my colleagues, my friends, to think I used such means to get into their family;

I didn't want others to think I was a *phoenix man*⁴.

I don't covet their family's money, nor anything else.

I didn't want to get married and have my head still be beneath in-laws who looked down on me, or even their whole circle of relatives.

I grew up in a single-parent family, so I understand even more that dignity is earned through one's own efforts."

"Even if she was willing?"

"Her willingness is her willingness, but I wasn't willing. I wanted to live with dignity.

Hehe, when I first started in this profession, an old big brother told me that dignity and how others treat you are earned with your own hands. I haven't achieved anything yet, so I didn't want to..."

Zhou Ze took a deep breath, then asked, "Then did that big brother of yours tell you one more thing?"

"What?" Sun Tao asked in surprise.

"That is, when you're having fun, don't forget to wear a ***condom***."

With that, Zhou Ze directly swung his fist and smashed it into Sun Tao's face.

"Bang!"

Sun Tao was inexplicably hit hard by a punch, falling to the ground, utterly bewildered.

"Don't make excuses, don't talk about dignity, don't say anything else,

You are just selfish, completely and utterly selfish."

With that,

Zhou Ze kicked Sun Tao, who was still on the ground.

"Bang!"

Sun Tao curled up, in great pain and still drunk, but he still shouted angrily:

"Are you sick? Hitting people!"

"Yes, I'm sick. I was blind as a bat back then, thinking about cultivating you and giving you a hand!"

At this moment,

The curled-up mass that had been hanging on Sun Tao's shoulder crawled towards Zhou Ze,

Making "squeaking" sounds in its mouth.

The female corpse heard it,

Zhou Ze heard it too,

But Sun Tao couldn't hear it.

His unborn child, who had never truly seen the world,

At this moment, was baring its teeth,

Towards the person who hit its father,

Letting out an angry cry...

***
¹ "奸、、、情" (jiān... qíng) literally means "illicit... affair" or "adultery," but here, it's a play on words, a homophone for "甘情" (gān qíng) meaning "sweet feeling" or "sweet affection." The original text includes ellipses, hinting at the speaker's hesitation or playful suggestion of a hidden meaning. The closest English equivalent to capture the humorous, slightly suggestive, and sarcastic tone is "how *sweet*."

² *Bingjie*: A Taoist concept where a cultivator intentionally disperses their physical form to release their soul, often to achieve immortality or avoid earthly entanglements.

³ "白莺莺" (Bái Yīngyīng) and "白嘤嘤" (Bái Yīngyīng) are pronounced the same. "莺莺" typically refers to a warbler (a type of bird), often implying something delicate or beautiful. "嘤嘤" is an onomatopoeia, like a faint crying or whimpering sound, often used to describe someone acting childishly or cutely (in a slightly annoying way). Zhou Ze's repetition with the second character implies he's thinking of the onomatopoeia, highlighting the strangeness of the name when heard.

⁴ *Phoenix Man*: A derogatory term in Chinese culture referring to a man from a poor rural family who, through personal effort and education, achieves success in the city. However, he is often perceived as still adhering to traditional, conservative, and sometimes patriarchal rural values, leading to conflicts with his more urbanized wife and her family.

title: 第三十九章 地獄之門
content:
Zhou Ze sat down, not continuing to hit the man. Indeed, he had no reason to hit him. Whether or not to have children was the man's own freedom and power.

Moreover,

now even the only victim,

was unwilling to hit the man himself.

"Heh..."

Zhou Ze lit a cigarette.

Sun Tao got up from the ground, pointed at Zhou Ze, and shouted, "Are you crazy? I'm calling the police. I'm going for an injury report."

"You deserved it," Zhou Ze exhaled a smoke ring without lifting his head.

"You... you... you..." Sun Tao pointed at Zhou Ze, then pushed open the bookstore door and walked out. He secretly cursed his luck, wondering why he had inexplicably come to this bookstore today.

The infant tried to follow him out but was grabbed by Zhou Ze.

The infant struggled, very displeased, but Zhou Ze ignored its reaction and still pressed it to the ground.

"What are you still following for? If you keep following, you won't even have a chance in your next life," Zhou Ze said.

"Squeak, squeak, squeak..."

The infant was still struggling, completely ignoring Zhou Ze's words.

"My Lord," the female corpse approached Zhou Ze, her eyes full of appeal and flattery. Evidently, she thought Zhou Ze kept the infant to nourish her.

Right?

Most men have a nurturing dream.

The female corpse felt she was perfect for it,

both in terms of age and figure.

"My Lord... *ma... hmm... ma...* Boss... *hmm... ma... ma...*"

The female corpse swayed her figure, shaking just right.

Then the person wished for stillness, but the flesh did not cease;

it was spectacular.

"They can still grow, you know, as long as they get enough nutrition."

"Get out."

"............" the female corpse.

"Help me keep an eye on him. Don't let him run. If you try to eat him, you'll die with him," Zhou Ze stood up expressionlessly.

"Yes, Boss."

The female corpse had no choice but to squat down and grab the infant with both hands.

"Boss, he won't call the police, will he?" The female corpse was afraid of trouble.

"No, a person like him wouldn't make a fuss and let the whole world know he got drunk and was beaten."

"Heh, such a prideful fellow," the female corpse sneered.

Actually, Zhou Ze didn't say one thing: that guy's personality was quite similar to his own in the past.

Zhou Ze looked at his right palm, slowly closed his eyes, silently recited something in his mind, then opened his eyes.

Hmm,

nothing happened.

Immediately after, Zhou Ze squatted down and extended his palm towards the infant.

Hmm,

still nothing happened.

The female corpse holding the infant at first looked confused, but quickly realized what Zhou Ze was trying to do, and then her body trembled slightly, struggling to hold back laughter.

Zhou Ze glanced at the female corpse. "If you can't hold it in, then don't."

Yes, Zhou Ze himself had to smile bitterly.

The little loli said she put the key to the Gate of Hell in his hand, but when he first tried to open the door to send a ghost in, he didn't know how to open it.

In short, it was unlikely that the little loli was simply playing a joke on him by putting something like a tattoo on his hand.

"Hahahahahaha... How could this concubine possibly laugh at you, Boss...

Hahahahaha... This concubine dares not be disrespectful to Boss...

Hahahaha."

"Alright, do you know how to open it?" Zhou Ze asked.

The female corpse shook her head. "Boss, I really don't know. Or, is there a chant?"

Zhou Ze heard this and silently recalled the scene Xu Qinglang described when the little loli took back his parents' souls.

Immediately, he spread his hand and said in a deep voice:

"The Underworld has order, the Yellow Springs can be crossed."

"Whoosh..."

Outside the glass door, withered yellow leaves blew past.

It seemed a crow also flew away, cawing "caw... caw... caw";

Inside the bookstore, it was still quiet.

In short, there was still no reaction.

"Or, a different chant?" the female corpse suggested. "Everyone must have one that suits them, right?"

"Are you telling me to shout 'Open Sesame'?" Zhou Ze retorted.

"Well, that depends on what position you prefer, Boss."

The female corpse looked innocently childish.

Zhou Ze recalled that during the fight that night, Xu Qinglang also shouted the incantations "Heaven and Earth, boundless; Mystical Heart, righteous Dharma," and then produced talismans and a bronze mirror;

But afterward, as Xu Qinglang said, those were just lines he thought sounded cool from TV shows, like background music for a protagonist's entrance in a movie.

Actually, they were useless.

Thinking about it now, perhaps the phrase "The Underworld has order, the Yellow Springs can be crossed" that the little loli said with her mouth open and tongue sticking out was also something similar to add "coolness."

It seemed that the little loli was no different from Xu Qinglang in terms of humor, even though she was a seasoned Ghost Catcher.

Zhou Ze's thoughts stirred, and the fingernail on his left index finger began to grow long.

The female corpse showed a look of fear. She was afraid of Zhou Ze, and most afraid of his fingernails, which carried an aura that terrified her.

This made Zhou Ze himself somewhat suspicious that the old man who died in front of him back then might not have been so simple.

Smugglers also fell into two categories: one like his former self, who had to behave cautiously, and another like the one in Rongcheng the little loli mentioned, who caused a lot of trouble, even making it difficult and thorny for the Ghost Catchers.

In short, the old man who infected him with gray nail fungus shouldn't have been so simple.

The black nail pierced the mark on Zhou Ze's right palm. Immediately, when Zhou Ze pulled out the nail, a black thread was pulled out.

It was like hot caramel, very sticky but unbroken.

The pulled-out thread was used by Zhou Ze to draw a square frame,

and then,

the frame floated up,

the inside also turned black and empty, and gusts of阴风 (yin wind) began to blow.

The infant in the female corpse's hands began to struggle. Evidently, it did not want to return to Hell.

When a person dies, it's like a lamp goes out,

but not many people can truly accept it.

How many seventy or eighty-year-olds, or even people who have been evil and done bad things their whole lives, try to cling to life, let alone this little infant.

But Zhou Ze knew that sending it to Hell, to anticipate a new beginning and reincarnation, was the most correct choice.

Without asking for its opinion, Zhou Ze became quite overbearing at this moment. He directly took the infant from the female corpse and threw it into the dark square frame.

Then, the frame slowly dissipated, and a faint burnt smell permeated the air.

The female corpse stuck out her tongue and said nothing.

Zhou Ze was a bit lost in thought. After all, this was his first time sending a ghost back to Hell; he hadn't done so with the woman who wanted to accompany her son for the college entrance exam last time.

"Have you ever been to Hell?" Zhou Ze asked.

"No," the female corpse answered honestly. "And I can't go down there."

The female corpse had no soul of her own,

a zombie does not enter the Five Elements, nor does it reincarnate as a human.

This sounded quite impressive,

but a line needed to be added afterwards:

Hated by humans and ghosts, abandoned by heaven!

Meaning, if the female corpse went for a stroll without anything to do, there was a certain probability that a sudden dry thunderbolt in broad daylight would strike her and turn her to ashes.

This world was just that unfriendly to her.

Humans have the mortal realm,

ghosts have Hell,

beings that belong to neither are anomalies.

Zhou Ze sat back behind the counter. He didn't feel happy, only somewhat dry and bored.

If the mortal world was compared to a production line, then what he did was merely toss defective products into the incinerator for remanufacturing.

"Boss, here's a stack of these."

The female corpse picked up a few sheets of joss paper from the tile floor and handed them to Zhou Ze.

Zhou Ze was a bit surprised; he hadn't expected any payment this time.

"It's easier to meet the King of Hell than the petty demons," the female corpse said, then regretted it slightly but still toughened her resolve: "It is only right for a Ghost Catcher to 'flay' those they escort on their way.

Perhaps his mother had burned joss paper for him before."

Zhou Ze nodded, took the joss paper. There was some leftover joss paper in the drawer behind his counter from last time; even with these few sheets, it was still a bit scarce.

"Do you know any other friends? Refer some business our way. To be human... oh no, to be a ghost, one must study more to progress better."

"Boss, this concubine only knows some lonely spirits who have long since lost their incense offerings and have no money at all. And they wouldn't dare come before you. If you were to take them, wouldn't that just be giving you free performance credit?"

"Performance credit?" Zhou Ze heard this for the first time. "Ghost Catchers have performance credit?"

"Don't they?" the female corpse asked, somewhat confused.

"I don't know," Zhou Ze shrugged. He genuinely didn't know, because the little loli had only left him with a line: "You're the most *bishi*<sup>1</sup> person I've ever seen," and then:

*Biu*

She disappeared.

She didn't leave him a copy of "Ghost Catcher's Code of Conduct" or "How to Be an Ideal, Aspiring, and Driven Ghost Catcher."

"I suppose there should be," the female corpse said with some difficulty. "Just like my Madame, who lingered in the mortal realm for two hundred years, protecting the local area, diligent and conscientious, all she wanted was to atone for her past lingering sin and also seek an official position when she returned to Hell.

If her temple hadn't been destroyed back then and the incense offerings were still there, it wouldn't have taken her this long."

"Do you know any other Ghost Catchers?" Zhou Ze asked.

"How could this concubine know so many Lords?"

"Oh," Zhou Ze nodded. It seemed he would have to ask someone knowledgeable in the future.

Just then, the sound of an electric scooter came from outside. Xu Qinglang was back.

"Oh my god, I'm exhausted."

Xu Qinglang walked into the bookstore and threw a cigarette to Zhou Ze.

"Didn't you go to order the signboard?" Zhou Ze asked.

"That's ordered, and then I picked up a batch of goods along the way. Wanchai Ferry is on special discount recently, so I stocked up a lot. It really tired me out."

"Aren't your dumplings freshly made?"

"Hehe, the cola in fast-food restaurants is bought from the supermarket next door and then resold. How could I have the free time to make dumplings at home every day?"

"Wanchai Ferry, quite fitting for you."

"Right, I like that flavor too... Hey, gotta go, I'm going back to put them in the fridge first." Xu Qinglang waved to Zhou Ze and went back to his own shop.

After Xu Qinglang left, the female corpse suddenly giggled.

Zhou Ze was a bit surprised. "Did you understand?"

The female corpse laughed:

"He really is good-looking. Most men would turn gay with him around.

So,

Wanchai (彎仔, literally "bent boy") Ferry."

——————

PS: Given that since the book was published, readers in the comment section often leave messages saying "the author plagiarized 'He Comes From Hell'" or "the author's beginning is very similar to 'He Comes From Hell'," I, Long, will give a unified response:

"He Comes From Hell" was written by Long.

<sup>1</sup> *Bishi* (逼数): A slang term, often used to describe someone who is "in the know" or "has a clue," but can also imply arrogance or overconfidence, depending on context. Here, it likely means "knows what's what" or "has a good grasp of the situation."

title: 第四十章 百鬼夜行
content:
In recent years, Tongcheng has become famous not for its economy or its snacks, but for its Gaokao.

For most high school seniors across the country, the Tongcheng practice exams are on par with the Huanggang secret exams.

Of course, these matters usually had no impact on Zhou Ze. His bookstore had long since shed its reliance on "living business" and had completed its industrial restructuring and transformation, earning money from the dead.

However, the胖子 who had come to him last time sought him out again.

His purpose was simple: the next semester was the Gaokao semester, and 胖子 planned to make another big splash by pirating the secret exams.

There were likely many twists and turns, and even an extremely intricate chain of interests involved. Zhou Ze wasn't very clear on it, and in fact, Zhou Ze believed Xu Le wouldn't be either.

The reason 胖子 wanted to bring Xu Le in, both last time and this time, was purely to leverage some of Xu Le's student connections.

Xu Le, in this whole arrangement, was actually an intermediary satisfactory to both sides.

Blitheringly idiotic,

Yet the most trustworthy.

Piracy is an unavoidable hurdle in contemporary Chinese society, and the so-called "shanzhai" culture it spawned, seemingly grand and flourishing, has even begun to gradually move out of the realm of derogatory terms and into neutral ones.

But when all is said and done, it is still illegal. While the prevailing atmosphere makes this phenomenon almost universally widespread, if you're unlucky enough to be targeted, it's always a lot of trouble.

Zhou Ze refused 胖子, who left somewhat dejectedly. As he stood by the door, 胖子 lit a cigarette, touched his gold-dusted gold chain,

And cursed:

"Sabi."

Zhou Ze, meanwhile, continued to sit behind the counter, reading. 胖子's visit was just a minor interlude in his life recently.

The female corpse, as usual, sat in her chair with her eyes closed after cleaning the bookstore, leaning against the wall, as if spacing out or feigning sleep.

Their lives had taken on the aroma of an old woman's bound feet.

Zhou Ze was content, recalling that what he had most looked forward to in his previous life was living exactly like this: whiling away the hours, wasting time, reading, and spacing out.

No need to be ready to face emergency patients at any moment, nor to constantly push himself to climb higher and higher.

As for the female corpse, she had been lying in a coffin for two hundred years and was long accustomed to monotony and silence. Now, it was just a drizzle.

Compared to the bookstore's "calm as water," Xu Qinglang was far more ambitious and progressive. He was wealthy and didn't have much pursuit in the occult; instead, he thought about how to make money and develop through his own abilities.

Therefore, Xu Qinglang was very displeased with the decadent style of the master and servant next door!

"Look at you, lazy as a dead man every day." Xu Qinglang, as usual, came over after a day of work to smoke a cigarette and shower Zhou Ze with some mockery.

"I am a dead man already," Zhou Ze waved his hand, exhaling a smoke ring.

"Look at you, a man who's lived two lives, and you barely have any money. I'm a man with over twenty apartments, and I'm still working hard."

As usual, after belittling Zhou Ze, he had to praise himself.

Zhou Ze glanced at Xu Qinglang and chuckled, "Are you preparing your dowry?"

"Nothing good ever comes out of a dog's mouth." Xu Qinglang looked up at the night sky (the ceiling). "I want to live more comfortably when I retire later."

"Twenty-some residences are enough to attract a ghost madam to carry you back in an eight-person sedan for marriage. If you work harder, earn more money, buy more houses, maybe next time a female ghost king or something will consider you a suitable match, and I, a Ghost Messenger, can also bask in your reflected glory.

When you become rich, don't forget me."

"Hehe." The female corpse, feigning sleep nearby, cooperated well with her boss.

"It's almost eight, I need to get ready," Xu Qinglang said, checking the time.

"For what?" Zhou Ze was a bit surprised.

Usually, Xu Qinglang retired quite early in the evening.

"Today is the opening day of the Confucius Temple. Isn't Gaokao just a few months away? I have a relative's child back home who's taking Gaokao this year, and they asked me to burn incense for them at the Confucius Temple."

"You'd go for that?" Zhou Ze knew Xu Qinglang's temperament. To say he was indifferent and selfish would be an overstatement, but he was generally too lazy to bother with anything other than making money.

"I ate at their house when I was a kid and received aid from them. Otherwise, I don't know if I would have lived to see the demolition, so I owe them this favor," Xu Qinglang said earnestly.

"Hmm," Zhou Ze nodded.

"How about we go together?" Xu Qinglang suddenly invited, "Help me grab the first incense?"

"Does the Confucius Temple also value the first incense?"

"Heh, it's always a good omen, isn't it?"

"I don't have much strength." Zhou Ze had seen how crazy people were when vying for the first incense. With his physique, he really couldn't take it, unless he used his fingernails to clear a path, but he couldn't just knock everyone around him down, could he?

"Ask her," Xu Qinglang pointed at the female corpse. "She's strong as an ox, she can take the brunt of it for me."

The female corpse frowned, preparing to retort.

"Do you want to go out for a stroll?" Xu Qinglang raised an eyebrow.

The words on the female corpse's lips immediately vanished, replaced by a radiant smile.

She hadn't stepped out of the bookstore these past days.

Helpless, Zhou Ze could only nod in agreement. He didn't trust the female corpse to go out alone. Though she was currently as attentive and compliant as a maidservant, one's heart is hidden, let alone a zombie without a "heart"?

Zhou Ze even believed that if his powers ever vanished, the first one to devour his flesh and blood would likely be this very female corpse who was now so subservient to him.

The three took a taxi to the Confucius Temple. To say the area outside the temple was a sea of people would be an exaggeration, but it was certainly packed three layers deep.

Oh, the pity of parents' hearts!

Xu Qinglang met his relatives, a couple who looked very honest and reliable middle-aged people, outside the Confucius Temple.

Their son, of course, hadn't come. Everyone was there to seek good fortune; no one was foolish enough to truly believe this would guarantee high scores. There were almost no students present, likely all at home studying or something.

Tongcheng's Confucius Temple "opened its doors" after the New Year. As for why not before, perhaps the esteemed scholars in the temple felt it would be beneath their dignity to compete for incense with those demons and monsters during the festive season.

Better to do it after the New Year,

To see your gates desolate, while their gates are crowded with believers, thereby showing their class.

As for the specific reasons and how it was done in other parts of the country, Zhou Ze wasn't clear. Customs were simply inexplicable rules; who could explain them?

Just like the recent viral news about a father-in-law kissing his daughter-in-law at a wedding in a city adjacent to Tongcheng, claiming it was a custom. There was even less logic to that.

"Creak!"

The red wooden gate opened,

And suddenly, the waiting parents outside transformed into "fierce beasts," charging into the Confucius Temple.

The female corpse took the lead, with Xu Qinglang and his relatives following closely behind, like Zhao Zilong at Changbanpo.

Zhou Ze didn't join the commotion. He just squatted on the curb outside, smoking.

As he smoked, Zhou Ze was surprised to find the cigarette in his hand suddenly went out.

Zhou Ze lit it again, but the subsequent puffs were suddenly tasteless.

"Heh." Zhou Ze flicked the cigarette butt away and looked around. He knew his cigarette had been offered up as incense.

Not partaking of pure incense, not accepting offerings,

Just to smoke this one puff of a mortal's cigarette,

He wondered which demon or god it was.

Zhou Ze naturally wasn't angry, thinking, "Damn, someone dared to steal my cigarette." A month ago, he was still an illegal immigrant; half a month later, he was only promoted to a temporary worker.

He had no "sudden rise to power" or "this road is mine" arrogance.

"Clang!"

A gong sounded,

In the night, it was so abrupt, and so jarring.

Zhou Ze followed the sound,

From the flower garden behind the Confucius Temple walked out a short, dwarfish old man. The old man held a copper gong, a cigarette in his mouth, and was hopping and skipping outwards.

The old man even specifically glanced at Zhou Ze, opening his mouth and exhaling a smoke ring, seemingly indicating his thanks for Zhou Ze's cigarette.

Zhou Ze also smiled,

He lit all the remaining cigarettes in his hand with a lighter and arranged them on the ground, keeping only one for himself.

Soon, the cigarettes on the ground went out. The dwarfish old man hopped even more excitedly, seemingly growing fonder of this sensible junior. His small pockets were bulging, likely filled with cigarettes.

The dwarfish old man led the way with his gong,

Behind him, a group of people slowly followed.

They weren't the parents who had just crammed into the Confucius Temple,

But a group of strangely dressed people.

The first few, with feathered fans and scholar's caps, staggered in their steps, their faces ashen, slowly following the old man forward.

Then came two with greasy pigtails, their gazes dull, also following the old man forward.

After them, the attire became increasingly modern. The last few were even dressed in modern clothes, indistinguishable from ordinary high school students.

However, some of them had greenish faces, others had shattered skulls.

Out of professional habit, Zhou Ze quickly deduced that the latter students had either died from poisoning or had jumped from a building.

One of them looked somewhat familiar to Zhou Ze; he seemed to have seen his photo when browsing the news a few years ago. He had committed suicide by jumping from a building due to the pressure of a poor performance on a mock exam.

The dwarfish old man walked forward, beating his gong, while the group of "scholarly students" behind him followed like puppets on strings.

They were like a parade,

Circling the Confucius Temple.

And the nearby pedestrians,

Except for Zhou Ze, no one could see them.

"Bang!"

A gong sounded,

"To live in peace, no need for high buildings; in books, there is gold!" the dwarfish old man shouted in a hoarse voice.

"Bang!"

Another gong sounded,

"To marry, do not despair of a good match; in books, there is beauty!"

The dwarfish old man continued to shout.

After circling the Confucius Temple three times,

This bizarre procession slowly vanished.

A moment later,

The parents who had finished burning incense began to emerge from the Confucius Temple,

Their faces filled with satisfaction,

With hope,

With the eager desire for their children to succeed.

title: 第四十一章 最尷尬
content:
Xu Qinglang, the female corpse, and the middle-aged couple all emerged. The couple's faces were beaming, clearly having secured the "first incense" with the female corpse's help.

Whether useful or not, it was a good omen.

Even non-superstitious parents, before a child's big exam, would give them a _zongzi_ (rice dumpling) and a _niangao_ (rice cake), symbolizing "high-grade sticky rice cake" (meaning "high school graduation").

The female corpse's expression was not very good. As everyone walked back, she lagged behind.

"Let's get some late-night supper, how about barbecue?" Xu Qinglang suggested.

He owned a restaurant himself, but he wouldn't let himself prepare barbecue late at night;

Empress Xu's skin was precious, how could she endure such smoke and fire?

However, Xu Qinglang regretted his suggestion as soon as he made it.

Among this group,

There was a zombie, and a living dead person who didn't partake in human food.

Just imagining the scene at dinner, these two would sit there motionless, like clay statues in a temple enjoying incense offerings.

The thought alone was enough to kill one's appetite.

"You go, we'll head back first," Zhou Ze said.

"Oh, we couldn't possibly," the middle-aged man said.

"It's fine, uncle, we'll go eat. Let the young couple enjoy their walk."

Xu Qinglang pulled the middle-aged couple away.

Zhou Ze didn't rush to hail a taxi, walking along the sparsely populated side street with the female corpse.

The weather was starting to warm up; the evenings weren't as cool as before.

"What's wrong?" Zhou Ze asked the female corpse.

The female corpse had been sulking ever since leaving the Confucius Temple.

"Uncomfortable," the female corpse replied.

"Still haven't stopped menstruating?"

It had been two hundred years.

"............" the female corpse.

After a moment of silence, the female corpse finally spoke, "The statues in the Confucius Temple were staring at me; it felt strange."

"You think they were looking at you?" Zhou Ze asked.

"Yes," the female corpse nodded.

"You think they disapproved of you?"

"Yes," the female corpse continued to nod.

"You think that because you're a zombie, you shouldn't have been in that place?"

"Yes," the female corpse still nodded.

"The sage advocated 'teaching without discrimination'." Zhou Ze smiled, reaching out to pat the female corpse's head, saying, "You are a zombie, a type of existence that both humans and ghosts dislike, but you went to the Confucius Temple to help someone offer incense, and you contributed incense and popularity to them.

You feel they were looking at you,

It might be because of your uniqueness, so they were noticing you.

It's like a husky suddenly joining a pack of prairie wolves; anyone would take an extra look, right?

Of course, it's also possible they're just a bunch of clay figures, and their eyes are reportedly made from donkey dung balls, because it makes them look more lively and lustrous.

Everything is just you putting psychological pressure on yourself."

"But what if they really were looking at me, what if they really had an issue with me..." The female corpse still hesitated.

"Then they don't deserve to be enshrined in a temple as those so-called sages!"

Zhou Ze's words were forceful,

"Sages enjoy offerings for thousands of generations; if they don't even have that much magnanimity, then what face do they have to sit on the temple altar?

A false sage, what is there to be afraid of?"

The female corpse looked at Zhou Ze, a smile playing on her lips, and said, "Boss, what you just said was really domineering."

"Of course," Zhou Ze savored the flattery from his servant.

"But Boss, you are a ghost messenger; there is a certain destiny in the unseen. For ordinary people, the implication might not be great, but for you, it's different.

Furthermore, you run a bookstore, which falls under the good fortune of the sages. For you to malign a sage like that, it's really not good for you."

The female corpse rarely spoke so candidly to Zhou Ze; in the past, she would have wished for Zhou Ze to court death;

Jump, jump, jump yourself to death, and I'll collect your body, then peel off your nails and grind them into powder to brew as pearl powder tea,

Oh no, feed them to pigs!

"Still the same words: 'If you have a clear conscience, you won't fear ghosts'… or sages knocking on your door."

Zhou Ze looked up at the streetlights and continued:

"In my previous life, I treated the sick and saved lives, never taking red envelopes, never crossing ethical lines. I always upheld medical ethics.

In this life, even after becoming a ghost and possessing a new body, I haven't done anything with a guilty conscience.

What is there to be afraid of?"

Zhou Ze took a deep breath and repeated, "There's nothing to be afraid of."

Upon hearing this, the female corpse fell into contemplation.

Zhou Ze's words weren't a declaration of a rebellious teenager, but rather a warning to himself.

The two continued to walk aimlessly forward, the evening breeze cool but pleasant.

Finally, the female corpse stopped and asked, "Boss, where are you going?"

Zhou Ze stopped, subconsciously looking around, and was surprised to find that he had walked into the entrance of a small residential complex.

Familiar surroundings,

Familiar guardhouse,

Familiar guard in the guardhouse secretly sleeping on duty,

Familiar express delivery lockers.

He had simply walked,

Naturally, back to the complex where he used to live.

Although he had been at the bookstore for a month, subconsciously, this was still his home.

Having grown up in an orphanage, he understood the meaning of "home" even more deeply, and he was also more attached to housing.

Fortunately, when he bought his house, Tongcheng's housing prices hadn't soared to such ridiculous levels. It was also because he couldn't wait to become a "mortgage slave" after starting work, which turned out to be a stroke of luck, much to the envy of his colleagues who bought homes later.

However, Zhou Ze couldn't even retrieve his old WeChat and QQ accounts now; mobile verification was impossible, and asking friends in his contact list to help verify would either make them think he was crazy or scare them to death.

Even his own house was sold by the hospital after his death, and the money was donated to the orphanage in his name.

Zhou Ze didn't object to this, as he had no other relatives in the world.

"This is where I used to live," Zhou Ze told the female corpse.

"So, shall we go up and take a look?" the female corpse suggested.

"It's already been sold," Zhou Ze sighed.

"Just consider it a visit to an old haunt."

Zhou Ze nodded and walked over.

He entered Building 8, Unit 2, took the elevator up to the fifth floor.

Zhou Ze walked to a door. It was still the same door; the buyer probably hadn't had time to redecorate.

Even the mat at the entrance hadn't changed.

And the cactus placed at the door was still there.

Zhou Ze reached out and felt under the pot, pulling out a key.

Back then, he was often called to the hospital for emergency shifts at night, and many times he forgot his phone or keys. So, his spare key was kept here, to prevent him from being locked out of his home.

With a hopeful try, he inserted the key and turned it.

"Click..."

The lock opened.

The door hadn't been changed,

And the lock hadn't been changed either?

Zhou Ze was a bit surprised. He pushed open the door and casually turned on the light.

The furnishings in the living room were all as they were.

Zhou Ze even saw his own slippers, changed into them, and walked in. The female corpse followed him in.

"Boss, is it still the same as before?" the female corpse asked.

"Yes, that's what puzzles me the most."

It was indeed still the same as before,

But this didn't make sense.

Wouldn't an ordinary person who bought a house throw away everything that belonged to a deceased person?

How could they keep everything, preserving it all, without feeling it was bad luck?

Perhaps, the person who took over his house just bought it for investment? Not actually to live in?

Zhou Ze sat down on the sofa, as if at this moment, he had become himself again.

Each time he returned home exhausted, he would watch TV, cook a late-night snack. Life was busy, yet fulfilling.

The female corpse went to make tea, poured a cup for Zhou Ze, and then said:

"Boss, you've been dead for more than half a year, haven't you?"

"Seven months."

Zhou Ze replied, but why did the conversation feel a bit strange?

"But it's so clean here, it doesn't look like no one has lived in it for seven months," the female corpse reminded him.

Zhou Ze nodded; indeed, it was true. The place was very clean, someone must be cleaning it regularly.

But Zhou Ze found it hard to imagine that the person who bought his house would be so lazy as to throw nothing away, change nothing, and even keep the original door lock.

Zhou Ze pushed open the bedroom door and found that even his bedding and sheets were the ones he used to use.

"Boss, I'm going to take a shower. I was stared at by those old things in the Confucius Temple for so long, I've got goosebumps all over."

"Go ahead, turn on the water heater first," Zhou Ze reminded her, "The bath towel is in the cabinet by the bathroom door."

If,

All the furnishings were truly the same.

The female corpse went to take a shower. She was very clean; women naturally were. In her previous life, she was a young lady from a good family, and lying in a coffin for two hundred years without being able to bathe must have been difficult.

So she basically showered once in the morning and once at night, wasting a lot of Zhou Ze's water bill.

But thinking about how she worked as a server in his shop without asking for wages, Zhou Ze just put up with it.

Pulling back the curtains, Zhou Ze stood on the balcony, looking at the shimmering night lights ahead.

This place,

It was his home.

It hadn't changed,

But it no longer belonged to him.

Things remained, but people had changed;

It was truly a case of things remaining while people changed.

He took out a cigarette, lit it, and exhaled a smoke ring.

He felt a little lost inside; he thought he should have been able to let go, but in reality, he couldn't.

Just as he had personally cast that infant into hell to await reincarnation,

He now deeply realized,

As a living person, his attachment to the human world was truly hard to describe in words.

Even he, at this moment, had an urge to buy his house back.

As for money,

With his abilities, if he really wanted to illegally get some money,

Would it be difficult?

This impulse was finally suppressed. Zhou Ze knew that this was a path of no return, a Pandora's Box; once opened, he definitely wouldn't be able to stop himself.

Zhou Ze considered himself a disciplined person, but no matter what, when it could be avoided, one should not test one's "human integrity."

"Click..."

Unexpectedly,

The sound of a key in the lock came from the door.

Had the owner returned?

Zhou Ze turned around and walked from the balcony back into the living room. He was thinking about how to explain his presence in the house to the owner, but he wasn't overly nervous.

All things considered, he was a ghost messenger. If he ended up being caught by the police for trespassing,

Wouldn't that be too much of a loss for him?

Discipline was discipline, but there was no need for self-torture.

This, after all, was his former home.

However, when the door was pushed open,

The one who walked in,

Was a familiar figure.

Doctor Lin stood at the door, looking at Zhou Ze standing in the living room, her face showing shock and panic, and she said,

"You... how are you here?"

Zhou Ze was momentarily speechless,

The one who bought his house,

It was Doctor Lin?

"Listen to my explanation." Lin Wanqiu.

"Listen to my explanation." Zhou Ze.

They both said the same thing at the same time,

For Lin Wanqiu, she was panicking because she thought Zhou Ze had discovered evidence of her "emotional infidelity,"

That he had found this place; she was his wife, yet she had bought another man's former house and had been cleaning and tidying it, and because of that man, she had refused to share conjugal life with him.

Doctor Lin felt very much in the wrong.

Fortunately, this awkward atmosphere didn't last long,

Because something even more awkward appeared,

"Boss, I accidentally got my clothes wet."

The female corpse said as she walked out, wrapped in a bath towel,

She walked into,

The living room,

And stood between Zhou Ze and Lin Wanqiu.

title: 第四十二章 車禍現場
content:
The air was suddenly quiet, which was the most terrifying thing…

Zhou Ze pursed his lips. Doctor Lin lowered her head, also somewhat relieved.

One had an emotional affair,

The other had a “physical affair.”

One person’s mistake was guilt;

Two people making a mistake together was gender equality.

Zhou Ze laughed at this moment, a somewhat uninhibited laugh.

That’s right,

After his death, the person who bought his house was his current “wife.”

Indeed, Doctor Lin had money. It was easy for her to buy a second-hand house with a deceased owner in Tongcheng. Moreover, it seemed only she would clean it and keep its original layout.

Moved?

Of course, he was moved.

Zhou Ze was Zhou Ze. Even though he was currently in Xu Le’s body, he still viewed things from his own perspective.

Xu Le was a thing of the past. No matter how rough or undignified that kid’s emotional life was, Zhou Ze wouldn't pay much attention to it.

It was like during Chinese New Year, when everyone was having a reunion dinner, and a fool at the table suddenly pulled out his phone and asked everyone, "Look at how some refugees in Africa are starving and skinny. Can you still eat your food?"

To have such a woman, as if possessed, constantly remembering him, missing him,

As a man,

How could he not be proud, not moved?

"Find my clothes for me to change into," Zhou Ze pointed to Bai Yingying.

The female corpse nodded and said, "Oh." This time was different from last time; she didn’t dare to act on her impulses and intentionally add fuel to the fire out of fun. She dutifully went to Zhou Ze's bedroom, found his clean clothes, changed, and came out.

Doctor Lin still stood in place, saying nothing.

She seemed to feel a sense of relief and release. However, Zhou Ze didn't let her continue with that emotion. Instead, he walked forward, took Doctor Lin's hand, and said very earnestly:

"There's something I need to tell you. Come with me."

Holding Doctor Lin's hand, Zhou Ze, with a hint of forcefulness, led her out the door and into the elevator. Bai Yingying followed behind, silent. She knew that anything she said now would be wrong.

One could only say that everything was too coincidental.

After getting downstairs, Zhou Ze walked to Doctor Lin’s Cayenne and extended his hand, signaling Doctor Lin to give him the car key.

Zhou Ze had decided he would tell her his identity, regardless of whether she could accept it, or if she was like the "Lord Ye's love of dragons"* in ancient stories.

In short, Zhou Ze wanted to tell her the truth. He didn’t want to be hesitant or hide anymore. After all, circumstances were different now. He used to be an unregistered person, but now he had been cleared.

There was no reason to make himself suffer.

"You don't have a driver's license," Doctor Lin reminded him.

"Give me the key," Zhou Ze said forcefully, with no room for doubt.

He wanted to take her to the hospital, to that familiar operating room, to show her his true identity with practical actions;

Otherwise, he worried that if he merely described it, she might think he was having an "imaginary husband syndrome" episode.

Doctor Lin handed the car key to Zhou Ze, and then all three got into the car.

Zhou Ze sat in the driver's seat, Doctor Lin in the passenger seat, and Bai Yingying obediently in the back.

The car started, backing out.

Zhou Ze looked skillful and at ease.

Xu Le, that dimwit, didn't even have a driver's license.

He, however, was an experienced driver.

Then,

Only the ear-piercing sound of "screech, screech, screech…" was heard, and the car body shook.

Zhou Ze fell silent.

The other two women in the car also fell silent.

The Cayenne's body had scraped against the utility pole, grinding hard for a full rotation.

In the dark night, it was as if another very diligent crow,

By extreme coincidence, flew across the sky again,

Occasionally letting out "caw... caw... caw" sounds.

The air became awkwardly silent again.

Zhou Ze unbuckled his seatbelt and said, "You drive."

"To People's Hospital?"

Doctor Lin asked after switching seats.

"Yes, People's Hospital." Zhou Ze, sitting in the passenger seat, covered his forehead with his hand, then gently tapped the car window.

It had been too long since he drove, and he had changed bodies, so his driving skills were much rustier.

But no matter how many reasons there were,

It was truly embarrassing just now.

The car got on the road and soon ascended the East Expressway Viaduct.

The car was quiet. Doctor Lin didn't speak. Even if she didn't know why Zhou Ze wanted to go to the hospital, she didn't ask.

Their current marital relationship,

It was truly riddled with holes.

Bai Yingying sat in the back seat, looking at the scenery outside the window. She hadn't been out for a long time. Although Madam Bai used to talk to her almost every day, she rarely had the chance to personally go out and see the world outside.

Moreover, she knew it wasn't appropriate for her to speak now.

Zhou Ze suddenly sat up straight and said, "Is that car driving against traffic?"

On the other side of the low concrete wall was the opposing lane of the viaduct. A white car was there, but its front was facing the same direction as Zhou Ze's car.

This meant the other car was driving against traffic.

And at this moment,

A bus drove past in the adjacent lane, its high beams blinding.

Immediately after, there was the ear-piercing screech of sudden braking.

Zhou Ze instinctively closed his eyes and covered his head with both hands. The bus was in the adjacent lane and couldn't hit them, but this scene was almost the most terrifying image in his memory.

He himself was hit by a large truck in this manner on his way home from work back then.

Everything at this moment triggered the most terrifying and unwilling-to-recall scene in his heart.

"Bang!"

A dull impact sound came, and Doctor Lin immediately stopped the car.

In the adjacent lane, the bus and the white car driving against traffic collided. The car was pushed out, then heavily slammed into the concrete barrier by the front of the bus. Its body was completely deformed.

Turning on the hazard lights, Doctor Lin quickly got out of the car. Looking at her husband, who was curled up and trembling in the passenger seat, a hint of disappointment flashed in her eyes. But she immediately opened the trunk, took out the warning triangle, placed it behind the car, and then quickly climbed over the barrier to the other side.

She was a doctor; she needed to fulfill her responsibilities. When an accident occurred, if there were professional rescue personnel nearby, the victims' lives had a high probability of being saved.

"Boss?" Bai Yingying called from the back.

Zhou Ze released his hands and looked around blankly. He saw the accident scene in the adjacent lane, and Doctor Lin had already rushed over.

"Come with me, let's save them."

Zhou Ze got out of the car, his legs feeling somewhat weak.

This was a kind of self-preservation instinct in humans. When mental trauma was triggered, it often led to the body producing a weak protective response.

Taking a deep breath, Zhou Ze didn't hesitate at all. He also climbed over the barrier to the other side, ready to save people.

Bai Yingying followed him.

The bus driver also had blood on his face, probably from hitting his head on the steering wheel or something during the crash. Three other people got off the bus, presumably passengers. In short, the bus was quite empty.

"This motherfucker must be sick. Driving against traffic on the viaduct, seeking death but harming others!" the bus driver cursed, covering his forehead wound with one hand.

Anyone would be furious to encounter such bad luck.

"Stop shouting, save people!" Doctor Lin snapped at the bus driver.

The accident responsibility could be discussed later; for now, they needed to get the people out of the car.

"Hey, are you still conscious? Can you answer me?" Doctor Lin shouted at the person in the deformed car.

But there was no response.

The bus driver grumbled but still participated in the rescue. This road was already a bit remote, a section of the viaduct where few cars traveled. Occasionally, a car would pass by, but it didn't stop to watch curiously; it just drove off.

"Pry open the car door!" Zhou Ze suggested.

"No equipment, how do we pry it?" Doctor Lin's emotions were a bit agitated, especially when her husband, who didn't understand, was giving misguided instructions, making her even more annoyed.

There were two people in the car, a woman and a child. Their condition was very bad, both covered in blood, and there was no response to their shouts.

The car door was dented inwards and almost jammed. This required the fire department to come with specialized equipment to cut it open.

Zhou Ze stepped forward and grabbed the car door. Bai Yingying also came over at this moment. As a zombie, she was, of course, strong. She exerted force with Zhou Ze.

Only a "crack" was heard,

The car door was directly detached, and Bai Yingying also pressed down the back of the car seat.

Doctor Lin looked on, stunned.

The bus driver and the few passengers on the bus also looked on, stunned.

This must be good luck, it was only lightly jammed.

Zhou Ze bent down, one hand supporting the person's neck and the other holding their leg, carefully dragging the woman out first. Then, he went to pull out the boy's body.

Doctor Lin first examined the woman's body, her expression solemn. When the boy was pulled out, she examined his body as well, and her expression immediately turned somber.

Dead,

Both were dead.

"Dead?" the bus driver asked in disbelief, his face very grim. He was having terrible luck! "These bastards, coming out late at night to harm people, they've ruined me!"

"Call the police and 120," Doctor Lin, whose phone was left in the car, shouted to the bus driver.

Though furious, the bus driver still took out his phone to make the call.

Zhou Ze, however, turned over both the woman's and the boy's bodies. Doctor Lin looked at Zhou Ze's action, a little puzzled.

"I just quickly checked them when I pulled them out. They have many external injuries, all caused by the car accident.

However, they have one thing in common: there are concave skull injuries at the back of their heads. If I'm not mistaken, these should be fatal injuries.

I think they might have been hit with a hammer wrapped in cotton cloth."

"What does this mean?" Doctor Lin immediately followed up to examine the wounds at that location, then quickly understood, saying, "They were already dead before the car accident!"

Yes, otherwise, it would be difficult to explain why two people suffered the same fatal injury in the same spot. It was too coincidental, almost impossible.

"Dead people were placed in the car, and then it drove against traffic." Zhou Ze looked at Doctor Lin, a smile on his face, and said, "Then it was disguised as a car accident. Quite a good accidental event."

Immediately after, Zhou Ze turned his face to look at the bus driver behind him, who was calling the police. The few passengers who had originally been standing around the bus also slowly started to surround them.

The bus driver also looked at Zhou Ze, a meaningful smile appearing on his face, and said to the person on the other end of the phone:

"Boss, I'm a bit unlucky. I ran into a few busybodies."

---
* Lord Ye's love of dragons: An idiom that describes someone who pretends to love something but is actually afraid of it.

title: 第四十三章 不行，不可以！
content:
As a surgeon, Zhou Ze could easily detect abnormalities in the cause of death of a corpse, so forensic pathologists, whose profession aligns with this, could obviously also discover them.

Therefore, in Zhou Ze's view, the staging of this car accident was actually quite a failure; it was merely "superficial" and couldn't withstand scrutiny.

He wondered if these people had other contingencies or methods to perfectly complete this case as an accident, or if they were truly just "rookies."

Of course, now was not the time to ponder this question, because these people seemed disinclined to prolong the discussion.

"Grab them, then drive their car away."

The bus driver checked the time; time was precious now.

Several of his subordinates lunged forward. To them, a thin man and two young women wouldn't cause any trouble.

Bai Yingying tilted her head, glancing at Zhou Ze. She was waiting for his command.

Dr. Lin stood still. It was clear she was nervous, but she didn't scream or shout, which was already quite remarkable.

Most people facing this situation, even those who usually boasted of having guts as big as the sky, would find it normal to be scared to their knees, begging for mercy and claiming, "I didn't see anything."

"Don't kill anyone," Zhou Ze reminded.

"Haha," the bus owner laughed upon hearing this.

Unfortunately, Zhou Ze wasn't speaking to him.

Bai Yingying responded with a cheerful "Got it!" and charged forward.

Zhou Ze took a step back, grasping Dr. Lin's hand, and said, "It's alright, I'm here."

Bai Yingying, charging at the front, almost stumbled.

*I'm out here fighting for my life,* she thought.

*And you're over there being lovey-dovey?*

*Mistress,*

*Oh no, even a maid has dignity, alright!*

Dr. Lin pursed her lips and blamed herself, "I'm sorry."

It was her stopping to help the injured that led them into this crisis, so she apologized.

"It's just occupational hazard," Zhou Ze said with a wry smile. Last time in the cinema, he also rushed in like that. It just goes to show that some professional habits are truly impossible to change.

The female corpse, having just been fed a mouthful of dog food, instinctively struck a bit harder.

"Little girl, come here, big brother will show you some love."

A man opened his arms, ready to embrace this high school girl.

The boss wouldn't let them kill here; he intended to take them away. After all, they couldn't linger here for too long.

However, his arms embraced empty air.

Immediately after, his left arm was seized by the female corpse.

"Crack..."

"Crack..."

"Crack..."

Dr. Lin's body trembled as she listened, and Zhou Ze also found it grating.

He even felt that if the sound of "Crispy Corner" (a type of snack) breaking were used here, it would be more effective than the current "GG" sound.

Crispy and crunchy.

The man's mouth hung open; he couldn't even cry out in pain. The female corpse took another step forward and kicked the man's lower leg.

"Creak... Creak... Creak..."

Three more crisp sounds.

Pringles could also be used for the "GG" sound, Zhou Ze thought.

"What... the..."

The man crumpled to the ground. One arm was completely crippled, and one leg was also completely broken. He lay on the ground like a toad, only able to wail and squirm.

Zhou Ze felt no compassion. He forbade the female corpse from killing because matters of the living realm should be handled by the police. He believed that the judicial organs of this country would ensure that all evil would be exposed.

But these people before him were, after all, cold-blooded murderers who had intended to attack him. Zhou Ze wasn't so overflowing with saintly compassion that he felt sorry for treating them this way.

Who knew what they had intended to do to the three of them just now?

If he were still the doctor from his past life, and the female corpse were merely a high school girl, then who would pity them?

"Bang!"

"Clang!"

"Slap!"

The other two men were directly knocked down, also with broken bones. Though not fatal, they were incapacitated.

From Zhou Ze's professional perspective, even if these three men on the ground received hospital treatment, they would likely be unable to live independently for the rest of their lives.

The bus owner's phone dropped and hit the ground.

He instinctively swallowed,

feeling that everything before him was so unreal.

He hadn't brought a shotgun because, according to the plan, he would be facing questioning and investigations from traffic police and the regular police, so he naturally couldn't carry any prohibited items.

He had originally thought that even with the addition of Zhou Ze and these "kind-hearted" people, this matter wouldn't lead to too many variables.

Even if variables appeared, he would still be able to control them.

However, the problem was now quite severe, because the girl had walked up to him.

"I..." The bus owner, who had just been so brilliant in his acting, couldn't even speak now.

"Bang!"

The female corpse reached out and flipped the bus owner directly onto the ground, placing a foot on his neck.

"Stop for a moment."

Zhou Ze called out.

The female corpse stopped without asking why.

Zhou Ze walked forward, crouched down, and patted the bus owner's bearded face.

Then he felt he was being redundant and wiped his hand on the female corpse's trouser leg.

This guy's face was so greasy.

"..." The female corpse.

"Do you have anyone else?"

What Zhou Ze had to consider now was how to eliminate all future troubles. He wasn't afraid himself, but this matter couldn't be kept under wraps. What if they dealt with the small fish, and the big fish escaped, retaliating against Dr. Lin?

There's no such thing as being able to guard against a thief for a thousand days.

Earlier, the little loli had mentioned that there was someone like her in Rong City, overstepping bounds and acting as a judge. Zhou Ze naturally couldn't follow in their footsteps.

Although emotionally, Zhou Ze truly admired him and found him impressive and ambitious.

But this matter had already affected his daily life, so he had to personally take action and bring it to a close.

The female corpse directly smashed down on the bus owner's left arm.

"Creak..."

"Ahhh!!! No more, no more... It's just us few. We all met while working... Just us few. We were hired by an employer."

Zhou Ze nodded, then looked at the female corpse and said, "Is there any way to make them forget this incident?"

Zhou Ze didn't want to cause trouble, nor did he want to make the news.

The female corpse made a throat-slitting gesture.

Zhou Ze shook his head. He couldn't kill them, at least not by himself.

"Or, boss, you can prick them with your fingernail a little. It can make them disoriented for a while, like they're drunk, and then they'll black out."

"How much to prick?" Zhou Ze asked.

"Just a little, otherwise they might actually die. Also, I know you don't want to cause trouble, boss. After you go back, burn all the remaining joss paper you have, and trouble won't come knocking.

But then, probably no one will throw money in front of the shop either."

Zhou Ze looked up at Dr. Lin in the distance, then silently walked to each of the thugs lying on the ground, subtly pricking them one by one with the black nail that had grown on his little finger. All these individuals trembled, foamed at the mouth, and then quickly lost consciousness.

But, none were in life-threatening danger.

Scanning the surroundings, there didn't seem to be any cameras here, otherwise they wouldn't have chosen this spot for staging an accident. Zhou Ze picked up one of their phones, dialed the emergency number, and then threw the phone away.

After all that was done, Zhou Ze waved to Dr. Lin, then got back into her car.

Dr. Lin also got into the driver's seat.

"Drive away first, don't stop here," Zhou Ze reminded her.

"Okay." Dr. Lin took a deep breath and started the car.

"Don't tell anyone about this."

Zhou Ze reminded her while the car was moving.

"Why?" Dr. Lin clearly couldn't quite understand.

Zhou Ze pointed behind them,

"She's a practitioner of Tai Chi Bagua Palm. She accidentally crippled someone during a sparring match, so she fled to me. She just saved me, so our identities can't be exposed, otherwise she'd be arrested by the police."

The female corpse in the back rolled her eyes.

*He's telling lies that wouldn't even fool a ghost.*

Dr. Lin remained silent, unsure if she truly believed him, and simply continued driving without a word.

The car was still heading towards People's Hospital. For Dr. Lin, even if Zhou Ze hadn't said where to go initially, she would have instinctively driven there. After all, it was her workplace, and she could feel safe there.

The car drove into the People's Hospital parking lot, and all three got out.

Dr. Lin didn't ask Zhou Ze where he was going. She couldn't have guessed that the place Zhou Ze wanted to go was actually the emergency room. She simply walked forward in silence.

The female corpse leaned close to Zhou Ze's ear and whispered, "Are you still confessing tonight?"
