"Oh, that should be my family's residential compound."

"Your family lives there too?" Xu Qinglang smiled even more brightly, "Next time, maybe we can get coffee together?"

"My family doesn't live there."

"Then what do you mean?"

"I mean, the company that demolished your homes and compensated you with resettlement apartments should be my family's company."

"............" Xu Qinglang.

***
¹ "The water is too cold" (水太凉, *shuǐ tài liáng*) is a historical anecdote and idiom related to the late Ming dynasty. When Emperor Chongzhen committed suicide, many Ming officials chose to surrender to the incoming Qing dynasty instead of dying for their emperor. The phrase reportedly comes from one official who, when pressured to drown himself in a lake to show loyalty, claimed "the water is too cold" as an excuse, implying he valued his life over imperial loyalty. It's used to mock those who make excuses for not sacrificing themselves or not upholding their principles.

title: 第五十八章 撕啦！
content:
This was perhaps Xu Qinglang's deepest wound;

Men like to show off in front of the opposite sex, boast, and strut around, just like a gorilla beating its chest and constantly grunting, "Ooh-ooh-ooh-ooh!" when seeking a mate.

In Zhou Ze's opinion, this was the first time the fawning Xu Qinglang seemed to be releasing that kind of mating signal.

Unfortunately, the girl's words: "Your house is a resettlement property provided by my family's company."

"Crack!"

It was as if something shattered.

Xu Qinglang wanted to clutch his chest and kneel down.

Pain,

So much pain,

Heart-wrenching pain.

The girl slowly stood up and said to Zhou Ze, "Boss, let's add each other on WeChat. If we plan to cooperate in the future, you can contact me."

"Okay." Zhou Ze naturally wouldn't refuse.

After adding each other on WeChat, the girl led her Corgi dog away.

Xu Qinglang let out a long breath, waved his hand, slowly turned, and left the bookstore.

He needed some time to recover from his injuries.

Zhou Ze's lips curved into a smile. It seemed that for at least the next while, the phrase "dozens of houses" wouldn't be leaving Xu Qinglang's mouth.

Turning around, Zhou Ze saw Bai Yingying sitting on a plastic stool, lost in thought. No, not lost in thought; more precisely, she was reading a copy of *Those Matters of the Ming Dynasty*.

"Boss, what did you mean by 'the water is too cold' when you were talking to that ghost?"

A large part of the female corpse's memories were inherited from Madame Bai. In that era, the types of books women read were few, and they naturally couldn't be as "learned" as men who studied for official examinations.

As for the collection of talented women in *Dream of the Red Chamber*, that could probably only appear in books.

"He was a literary leader in the late Ming Dynasty and seemed to have served as the Minister of Rites. When the Qing army entered the passes and the Ming Dynasty was about to fall, he prepared to die for his country. His beloved concubine, Liu Rushi, was ready to accompany him, but when his concubine jumped, he never dared to jump, saying, 'The water is too cold.' He eventually surrendered to the Manchus."

"Then that person truly isn't a good person, is he, Boss? Were you using that to mock that ghost?" Bai Yingying asked.

"In fact, although Qian Qianyi eventually surrendered to the Qing, he secretly funded anti-Qing forces and even provided information to the anti-Qing army, for which he was once prosecuted by the Qing court."

"This..." Bai Yingying didn't know how to evaluate this person.

She was very simple, just like old people and children watching TV who like to ask directly: "Is this person good, or is this person bad?"

For many people, the world is either black or white. As for the gray area, it's too complicated, too difficult to understand, so they simply pretend not to see it.

"The one I just threw into hell is essentially similar to Qian Qianyi." Zhou Ze smiled, picked up his teacup, and sat down on the chair behind the counter.

"Then why did you send him to hell?" Bai Yingying asked, somewhat confused. "At least, you could have turned a blind eye and let him stay in the human world for a bit longer, right?"

Zhou Ze shook his head. "Are you starting to pity him?"

"The water is too cold, it's human nature." Bai Yingying pouted. "I'm dead now, a zombie, but if I were still alive, I think it should be my own choice not to be buried with the emperor and the court.

Dying, of course, can be praised, but not dying can also be understood."

"The Ghost Judge said he should have died on that day, which is actually correct." Zhou Ze put his water cup down. "I originally died and then came back to life through a corpse. I myself am trying my best to cling to life. I shouldn't have the right to ask others if they should die.

Don't you think so too?"

Bai Yingying nodded.

"Everything needs to be considered within a specific context. To understand ancient people and their ways of behaving, one must immerse oneself in that era, in the culture, customs, and other backgrounds of that time.

From a modern perspective, of course, ethnic harmony means all Chinese people are one family.

But in the late Ming Dynasty, everyone should have had their own stance.

Your thoughts are like an old farmer in ancient times thinking the emperor ate ten fried dough sticks and ten large meat buns for breakfast every day. It's wrong and inappropriate for us, with our commoner's mindset, to project onto those great figures in history.

Yes, Qian Qianyi did many things to help the anti-Qing army after surrendering to the Qing, and even mocked the Qing Dynasty in the documents he compiled, but that was not enough for him."

"Not enough? Does he really have to die?" Bai Yingying asked, puzzled.

"He must die." Zhou Ze answered very seriously. "Including the ghost I just threw down, he must also die!"

After speaking, Zhou Ze took a deep breath,

"He doesn't have to die. He could leave freely, become a wealthy old man, completely disappear from the world, abandon wealth and glory, and remain utterly unknown. That's also an option."

"Why?" Bai Yingying clearly disagreed. "Everyone's life should be in their own hands."

"When Dodo's army entered Nanjing, Qian Qianyi was the highest-ranking official in Nanjing. He led everyone to kneel and welcome the Qing army into the city, surrendering to the Manchus.

He could not surrender, nor was he qualified to surrender.

His prestige, his identity, his power, his status, his enjoyment, his preferential treatment, all were given to him by the imperial court, which can also be understood as given by the country.

The more benefits you receive, the more responsibility you are naturally obligated to bear.

You received so much from the country, rising to the highest ranks of officialdom. Even when your waist was almost too weak to move, you still pursued Liu Rushi, living a carefree life like 'a pear blossom pressing down on a crabapple tree'.

Then, when the country needed him, he naturally had the duty to fulfill his responsibilities.

This is a kind of contractual spirit.

When the nation is in trouble, every commoner has a responsibility. In fact, if ordinary people just looked up,

At the sky,

No one would criticize them.

But those ancient officials who received salaries and enjoyed the people's hard-earned money, they themselves had a duty, when the nation's ship was about to sink, to do everything possible to prop it up, or even, to be buried with the ship.

It's hard to be a hero, but easy to be a villain. We should applaud heroes even more, not seek excuses by identifying with villains.

It's not that 'since I can't be a hero, it's understandable to be a villain.' That's never the case."

Bai Yingying listened, nodding in a half-understanding way.

"Take the one at the Confucius Temple, for example. In the Ming Dynasty, he was an Censor, similar to a prosecutor today, but not yet a chief prosecutor. But later, he became one of the Nine Ministers, similar to a minister today.

After surrendering, he still did so well, rising steadily. You tell me, should he have died?

There was a high official in the Ming Dynasty who once declared, 'The nation has nourished scholars for a hundred and fifty years; to die for righteousness is today.' He was speaking of this very principle."

"My head is spinning." Bai Yingying shook her head.

"This is a bookstore. Although there are more novels, you can also read other books." Zhou Ze stretched his neck. "Anyway, you don't have anything else to do."

Bai Yingying glanced at Zhou Ze, implying that he didn't seem to have anything to do either.

Zhou Ze stood up, went to the restroom to wash his face, and when he came out, he saw Bai Yingying refilling his teacup. Bai Yingying then asked:

"Oh, by the way, Boss, what happened to that high official who declared, 'The nation has nourished scholars for a hundred and fifty years'?"

"Oh, the emperor sent the Brocade-Clad Guard to beat him severely with sticks in front of the Left Shun Gate."

Zhou Ze sniffed,

"And then there was no 'then'."

"..." Bai Yingying.

The master and servant, for once, were in a literary mood, discussing history and worldviews;

Of course, this good atmosphere didn't last long, because the female corpse immediately put down her book and picked up her phone to play *King of Glory*.

However, a new customer arrived at the shop. He was a middle-aged man, about forty years old, wearing a black down jacket. His face was a bit rough, and his clothes were somewhat worn, making him appear a bit simple and honest.

"Boss, can I put up a notice here?" the man humbly asked Zhou Ze.

"What notice?" Zhou Ze asked.

"A missing person notice," the man honestly replied.

"Go ahead and post it." Zhou Ze stood up and walked to the entrance of the shop, watching the man post the notice on the wall.

"No photo?" Zhou Ze noticed that the notice only had text and no photo.

"She was still small when she was taken, only a few months old, so there's no photo." The man rubbed his hands and offered Zhou Ze a cigarette. "Don't mind it."

Zhou Ze took the cigarette and asked, "Was she abducted?"

"No, she was given up for adoption. She already had an older sister back then, and at that time, there was no second-child policy. I couldn't afford the fine and was afraid of losing my job, so I had to give her up for adoption.

These years, we've thought about her day and night, hoping to see her again. But we haven't had much contact over the years. After all, she was adopted by another family. As long as they treated her well, we didn't want to bother her; it wouldn't be good for her."

"Oh," Zhou Ze nodded.

"This time, her younger brother is unlucky. He got leukemia. I only know that the family who adopted her a dozen years ago lived somewhere near here, so I can only look for her here.

Her eldest sister wasn't a match, so now her brother's life depends on her to save him. And it would be a chance for our family to reunite."

"Brother?" Zhou Ze frowned and asked, "How old is she this year?"

"Seventeen."

"How old is her brother?"

"Sixteen."

"Pitiable," Zhou Ze sighed.

"Yes, how could such a young child get this disease? Boss, please keep an eye out for me. I'm going to continue posting further down. I've already contacted the media, and there might be an interview tomorrow.

I estimate we'll find her soon, and then our family can be reunited, and her brother can be saved."

The middle-aged man smiled very simply and honestly,

Then walked towards the front.

After he had walked far away and his figure disappeared into the night,

Zhou Ze looked at the missing person notice on the wall by the shop entrance and said softly,

"Pitiable."

Then,

Zhou Ze reached out,

And tore down the notice that had just been put up.

title: 第五十九章 第二根半價
content:
The second daughter is seventeen this year, and the youngest son is sixteen.

In other words, after that simple and honest middle-aged man sent his second daughter away, he immediately, with feelings of intense guilt, longing, and grief, had another child with his wife.

So, all that talk about violating the one-child policy, fines, and so on, was fake.

He just wanted a son. The first child was a daughter, and the second was also a daughter, so he simply gave her away, then immediately rushed to conceive new life.

Even when she was given away, he didn't even know her address or have any contact information, clearly indicating he wouldn't bother with her later.

Luckily, the next child was a son, otherwise he would have given away a third daughter, a fourth daughter...

Now, because his son has leukemia and needs a match, and their eldest daughter failed to match, they finally thought:

Oh, we seem to have a girl we gave away.

Then, to save their son, they started looking.

They mobilized the media and posted missing person flyers.

To move others, you must first move yourself; humans are such emotional and complex beings.

In the more than ten years since their daughter was given away, they might have felt some guilt, but they didn't regret it. If they regretted it, they would have started searching long ago, and it would have been easier to find her in the first few years after she was given away than after more than a decade has passed.

If you make a mistake that causes you pain, you will constantly self-hypnotize in the following days to alleviate or even erase that pain.

That middle-aged man was very successful. He fabricated many reasons, and after telling the lie a hundred times, he even believed it himself.

He thought he still loved and missed his second daughter. He thought he had given her away out of helplessness, out of necessity, a heaven-moving, unavoidable act, much like the story of "Orphan of Zhao".

They wouldn't consider that the daughter they gave away is now seventeen;

She should be in high school, have her own social circle, and live a life no different from her peers;

Perhaps her adoptive parents never even told her she was adopted, and she believes her adoptive parents are her biological parents.

Her life should be very peaceful,

But soon, a bolt from the blue will strike her!

My child, let me tell you some happy news: your biological parents have been found!

My child, let me tell you some exciting news: your previous parents were not your biological mom and dad!

My child, let me tell you some joyful news: you have an older sister and a younger brother!

My child, let me tell you something great: you can save your sick younger brother!

Isn't it unexpected?

Isn't it a surprise?

Isn't it touching?

"Boss, what's wrong with you?" Bai Yingying asked, seeing Zhou Ze standing at the door in a daze.

"There's one thing that always makes my hair stand on end whenever I think about it," Zhou Ze said.

"Is it that exaggerated, Boss? You've even been to hell. What could scare you like this?" Bai Yingying looked at Zhou Ze curiously.

"It's that to do many jobs, to work in many industries, to apply for many positions, you need to be certified, you need to pass tests, just like getting a driver's license. You have to be confirmed that your skills are up to par, that you're familiar with traffic laws, and they even make you drive on the road to see if you can withstand the test.

Otherwise, allowing someone with unqualified driving skills and mindset to get a driver's license is actually irresponsible to other pedestrians and car owners on the road."

"And then?" Bai Yingying pressed.

"But to be a parent, you don't need a license."

...

The night passed without a word. When Zhou Ze woke up the next morning, he habitually went to the shop next door for breakfast, but its door was closed.

This made Zhou Ze a little worried that Xu Qinglang might have been too devastated last night and just given up entirely.

Zhou Ze didn't care if he gave up, but he couldn't do without his juices.

He called, and Xu Qinglang answered quickly. It turned out he had gone to claim his lottery winnings and said he'd buy everyone a gift as a token of appreciation later.

There was nothing Zhou Ze could do but order takeout. He wolfed it down with the plum juice he still had at home and finished.

The shop door was still closed. Although not locked, it clearly showed an attitude of not bothering to do business, something Zhou Ze had long since come to terms with.

However, when he sat back down at the counter and opened the drawer, Zhou Ze unexpectedly found a thick stack of冥钞 in it.

At first, Zhou Ze thought Bai Yingying had purposely bought some冥钞 to surprise him, but then he thought Bai Yingying wouldn't be that childish.

He flicked the冥钞 in his hand; it was real.

Isn't it ridiculous...

Now, with the convenience of mobile payments, the situation where people in shops or wet markets would hold large banknotes up to the sun to check for authenticity has become increasingly rare.

But these were real bills.

Zhou Ze thought for a while. It must be the commission he received yesterday for escorting that Imperial Censor. That official would later reach the rank of one of the Nine Ministers in the Qing Dynasty, with a vast family fortune. Naturally, the offerings from his descendants and filial piety would be considerable.

Zhou Ze estimated that if these冥钞 were burned, someone would probably drop several wallets at his door, at least five thousand yuan's worth.

This wave seemed profitable. He earned over five thousand in the middle of the night, and the only cost was less than a hundred yuan in taxi fares for the round trip.

Zhou Ze wasn't in a hurry to burn the paper money now. These冥钞 would be useful at critical moments, able to ward off minor misfortunes and avoid trouble or interference in certain matters. Sometimes, they were more effective than several thousand Renminbi.

"Xu Le!"

The voice called out before the person even entered the shop.

Zhou Ze looked up and saw his sister-in-law walk in.

"Here, for you."

His sister-in-law was carrying a shoulder bag today. She took out a wad of money and placed it on Zhou Ze's counter.

"Your money back."

Zhou Ze smiled, "You could have just transferred it by phone."

"Nah, it feels better to hand over a stack of cash directly," his sister-in-law pouted.

After the last incident, his sister-in-law's opinion of Zhou Ze had improved a little. Of course, it was also because the old Xu Le was too cowardly to even control his own wife, so his sister-in-law naturally looked down on him even more.

But now, Zhou Ze was somewhat unyielding with her, adopting the air of an elder, and she, in turn, began to take him seriously.

"Xu Le, your business is really bad," his sister-in-law said, hands in her pockets.

"No classes today?"

"It's the weekend," his sister-in-law pouted discontentedly. "But I'm going to a bar later. I told my sister I was coming here to read and do homework, so don't you dare spill the beans."

Your sister hasn't contacted me in half a month.

Zhou Ze felt a little melancholic. He had originally thought that Dr. Lin actively embracing him after that confession was a good start, but perhaps that was just Dr. Lin's courage at the moment.

Once a person calms down, their thoughts slowly become more complicated. Dr. Lin might not have found her way out of that strange dilemma and knot.

Her legal husband, whom she didn't like, died.

Then the person she liked reincarnated into her legal husband's body.

It seemed like a happy ending,

But there was an insurmountable moral chasm.

Fortunately, after the incident with the faceless woman, Zhou Ze was no longer in a hurry regarding this matter.

At least the thought "she's not sleeping with me" hadn't crossed his mind for a long time.

Perhaps it was also because Bai Yingying had been accompanying him to sleep every night recently.

Even though Bai Yingying could only be looked at and not used,

Just being able to look was good.

"Those places like bars, go less," Zhou Ze reminded. "It's not too late to relax and do what you like after you get into college."

"Alright, you're just like my parents and my sister. You say you're a college student, how did you end up like this?"

His sister-in-law's way of speaking,

To describe it positively, was straightforward;

To describe it negatively, was thoughtless.

Zhou Ze believed that this cowardly Xu Le's decision to hire someone to buy his own life was definitely assisted by his sister-in-law constantly "filling up his rage bar" on the side.

It seemed his sister-in-law didn't know about the female classmate's incident, possibly due to considerations for protecting minors.

"I'm back!"

Xu Qinglang returned, carrying a pile of things.

"I'm exhausted. It's really weird today, couldn't get a taxi. I don't know if I'm just unlucky today or if all the taxi drivers went to a conference."

Xu Qinglang put the things down, then wiped his sweat.

Bai Yingying walked over at this moment, her eyes lighting up when she saw the things on the ground.

These were computer parts.

"Install it in my shop. You can play whenever you want," Xu Qinglang said to Bai Yingying.

"Okay."

Then, Xu Qinglang handed Bai Yingying a bag and tossed Zhou Ze an exquisite lighter.

"Here, fair share!"

"What's this?"

His sister-in-law wasn't interested in these gifts. What interested her was the plastic fan still tucked behind Xu Qinglang's neck.

Winter wasn't over yet, carrying a fan was interesting.

"A group of people were doing an event at the mall and forced it on me," Xu Qinglang replied.

His sister-in-law took the fan. It was a very ordinary plastic fan with "GG" printed on it. After seeing it, his sister-in-law couldn't help but let out a "Pfft" of laughter.

"What's so funny?" Zhou Ze asked.

"It says 'Where Are We Going, Dad?' on it," his sister-in-law replied.

"What's so funny about that? Is your funny bone that ticklish?" Xu Qinglang reached for the fan, then his eyes widened.

"Perfect, you go with my brother-in-law," his sister-in-law cast a mischievous glance at Xu Qinglang and Zhou Ze.

"'Where Are We Going, Dad?' GG?" Zhou Ze asked.

Xu Qinglang's expression was a bit volatile, but he still tossed the fan to Zhou Ze, "See for yourself."

Zhou Ze took the fan and glanced at it,

Only to see a hospital building in the background,

At the very top was a large line of text: "Where Are We Going, Dad?"

Then below it were two lines of cartoon text:

"Take your son for a circum...cision!

Second one half price!"

title: 第六十章 十里長車（上）
content:
"Seriously, today is really weird. Taxis are genuinely invisible."

Dropping the fan, Xu Qinglang restacked his things, preparing to assemble a computer at home.

"Just bad luck, I guess." Zhou Ze didn't take it seriously and walked out of the shop to light a cigarette.

The morning sun was still very pleasant.

Bai Yingying didn't like being in the sun, which might be related to her identity and nature. However, she wasn't like the zombies in old Hong Kong films that would turn to ash upon contact with sunlight.

According to Xu Qinglang, Bai Yingying, having been nourished by Madam Bai's soul for two hundred years, was no longer an ordinary being. While not as terrifying as a drought demon, she was definitely no low-level zombie.

And indeed, if Bai Yingying wished, she could completely change her appearance and blend into urban life with a different identity.

But her soul-blood was in his hand, so she couldn't leave. Besides, she didn't seem to want to leave. Maybe one day a bolt of lightning would strike her dead, as she wasn't favored by Heaven.

"Smoke less. You're smoking too much lately."

His sister-in-law also walked out of the shop, seemingly planning to go out and have fun.

Zhou Ze ignored her.

Actually, Zhou Ze envied her. She had grown up in a pampered environment, a sweet innocent, but that was also a kind of happiness. Unlike himself, a child raised in an orphanage, always with an inherent sense of insecurity. Anyone who wanted to succeed would strive relentlessly.

Like his childhood friend Wang Ke, who worked tirelessly day and night, not even knowing when his wife went out to get her hair done.

People,

It seemed, were just that coincidental, because a red car quickly pulled up on the road in front of Zhou Ze's shop.

Out stepped familiar faces: Wang Ke's wife and the little loli.

"Hello, Sister. Hello, Uncle."

The little loli greeted them very politely.

His sister-in-law couldn't help but crouch down and pinch the little loli's cheek, saying, "This little doll is so cute."

The woman smiled at Zhou Ze and said, "I'm going to get my hair done. She'll read a book here for a while."

"Alright," Zhou Ze replied.

The woman thanked him, then turned and got back into her car and drove off, her movements wide, showing an eagerness.

His sister-in-law also hailed a taxi and left, reminding Zhou Ze again to cover for her before she went.

At the shop entrance, the little loli stood beside Zhou Ze, who was squatting and smoking.

"You didn't come back, did you?" Zhou Ze suddenly asked.

"Uncle, what are you saying?" The little loli looked a bit confused, adorable in her blankness.

"Hehe."

Zhou Ze reached out and patted the little loli's head.

"Come on, let's read."

Zhou Ze picked out a copy of *Gǔwén Guānzhǐ* for the little loli and handed it to her, then asked, "How are your grades at school?"

"My grades are very good," the little loli said proudly.

"Do you have any hobbies?" Zhou Ze asked again.

"I can dance ballet and I'm learning to play the piano," the little loli replied.

"What would you like to drink?"

"I want to drink Coca-Cola." After saying that, the little loli stuck out her tongue. "Mom usually doesn't let me drink it."

Zhou Ze nodded, went to Xu Qinglang's place next door, and brought back a can of Coca-Cola.

"Here."

The little loli took the Coca-Cola and said sweetly:

"Thank you, Uncle."

After taking a sip of Coca-Cola, the little loli turned another page of the book and read with relish.

"You're back."

Zhou Ze, holding a glass of water, suddenly spoke.

The playful cuteness on the little loli's face gradually faded, replaced by a deep solemnity akin to an adult's.

She held up the book in her hand,

"When I realized I shouldn't be reading this book, it was already too late."

The book the little loli was holding was the *Gǔwén Guānzhǐ* that Zhou Ze had initially handed her, and it wasn't a modern or youth edition.

"Why did you come looking for me?" Zhou Ze asked.

Had the one in Rongcheng been dealt with?

So, she was back?

"I just came back from Hell. I missed you, so I came to see you." The little loli stood up, tilted her head slightly, looked at Zhou Ze, and smiled, "I've noticed you're quite lazy, and very unmotivated."

"I don't understand what you mean," Zhou Ze asked.

"The attendance record shows that my performance in this large region lately is at the bottom," the little loli licked her lips. "I told you to handle things before, but I didn't tell you to be this lazy."

"Attendance record?" Zhou Ze's heart stirred when he heard that.

"What, is there a problem? Do you think ghost officers don't have performance reviews?" The little loli retorted.

"Can you... let me see it?"

"Why don't you ask why I can't just give it to you directly?"

The little loli leaned close to Zhou Ze. She wanted to look him in the eye, but she was too short. When she got close, it turned into Zhou Ze looking down at her.

This made her very uncomfortable.

Immediately, she waved her hand,

And said, very annoyed:

"Pick me up."

Zhou Ze bent down and picked up the little loli, allowing her eyes to meet his.

"Don't think I don't know what's on your mind." The little loli's cool fingers stroked Zhou Ze's chin for a moment. "Do you really want to become a full-time employee?"

Zhou Ze nodded.

There was nothing to be ashamed of admitting.

"I can give you something to look forward to. I'll be going to Rongcheng in a while. Once I've dealt with that troublemaker, I might get a chance for a promotion.

At that time, my original position can be transferred to you, as long as you raise my performance again next month."

The little loli gave Zhou Ze a big promise.

Zhou Ze understood a bit. The little loli's behavior was somewhat like a person working at a company who hands over their tasks to someone else to help them, while they go off to do freelance work.

"Perhaps, I can anticipate another possibility," Zhou Ze said.

"What possibility?"

"You die in Rongcheng, and then the position naturally becomes mine."

Deep down, Zhou Ze didn't wish for that person to get into trouble. After all, the other party had helped him out in his dream last time.

As for why he spoke so directly, it was simple: there was no need for too many twists and turns between them.

"Hehe..."

The little loli didn't get angry or upset. Instead, she jumped down from Zhou Ze's arms, clasped her hands behind her back, and said:

"Do you think he still has a chance? You don't know how many ghost officers have come this time."

"You shouldn't explain it to me," Zhou Ze lit another cigarette, exhaling a puff of smoke. "Explaining means you're also afraid."

"Don't flatter him, or yourself." The little loli turned around, her deep eyes fixed on Zhou Ze. "Aren't you a doctor? Why would you wish for my death?

Isn't she cute?"

"Oh, what a cute child! Where did you come from?"

Bai Yingying just came down from the second floor at this moment. Upon seeing the little loli, she happily walked over, ready to hug the child.

"Madam Bai?"

The little loli frowned slightly.

"Uh..."

Even a fool like Bai Yingying knew that the person in front of her wasn't just some neighborhood kid.

"Oh, my old neighbor has cultivated enough merit and gone down. You are the shell she left behind." The little loli glared at Zhou Ze, "You kept her by your side, no wonder fewer ghosts actively came to you!"

"Who are you?" Bai Yingying asked timidly.

"My time is limited. This is just a reminder to you. I'm not afraid of you having other intentions. Who wouldn't have other intentions?"

The little loli walked confidently to the bookshelf,

"I'll be back in a month. I'm not sure if you can take over my position, and I'm not sure if I'll be promoted.

But if you can't raise my performance next month,

Then there's no need for you to stay in the human world. Go back to your Hell and wait to drink Meng Po's soup."

After saying these words, the little loli tilted her head and fainted. Immediately, a black light suddenly rose up,

*Biu!*

It shot directly into the ground!

"Boss, who is she? Is she a Judge?" Bai Yingying asked Zhou Ze.

"She's a ghost officer. I'm a temporary worker; she's a permanent employee." Zhou Ze picked up the sleeping little loli and placed her on the boss's chair behind his counter, covering her with a blanket.

"She's just a ghost officer, but it feels like even a Judge wouldn't put on airs as much as she does."

"Have you seen a Judge?"

"No."

"What identity will your madam have after she goes down?"

"I'm not sure, but she should get an official title in Hell."

Just then, a middle-aged man in a police uniform pushed open the bookstore door and walked in.

As soon as he entered,

He felt the temperature in the bookstore seemed to rise, and Zhou Ze and Bai Yingying both sensed a discomfort.

As if thorns were in their backs.

Zhou Ze turned around and looked at him. The man wore a police cap, with the national emblem on it shining brightly under the reflection of the sunlight outside.

He had a square face, thick lips, and a large build, exuding a sense of authority.

"Boss, recommend some good books for me to read. I'm going on a business trip later and need something to pass the time on the road," the police uncle said, taking off his hat and scratching his scalp.

"Oh, alright."

Zhou Ze smiled slightly, observing the other person carefully for a moment to confirm he wasn't a ghost.

Only then did he turn to the bookshelf, find a few books, and hand them to him.

The police uncle took the stack of books. He paused when he saw the first one, which was *Basic Knowledge of Public Security*.

When he flipped to the second book,

The police uncle paused again; it was *The People's Police Law of the People's Republic of China*.

Below those were two more books: *Theory and Practice of Dispute Resolution* and *Explanation of Grappling Techniques*.

The police uncle took a deep breath, seemingly deliberating how to phrase his words, then put the books down,

"I misspoke. I'm taking my son on a trip, and I'm worried he'll get bored on the way, so I'm buying him some books to pass the time. He prefers horror."

"Oh, got it."

Zhou Ze took two books from a box below and handed them to the other person again.

They were *Horror Web Novels* and *Horror Broadcasts*.

The police uncle finally nodded with satisfaction:

"These are good."

title: 第六十一章 十里長車（下）
content:
The police officer sat there, flipping through a book, occasionally taking out his phone to check the time.

Honestly,

His presence in the shop was a huge source of pressure for Zhou Ze and Bai Yingying.

It was like having thorns in their backs.

He was a good police officer, full of righteousness, and with his uniform on, he could practically make all evil spirits retreat.

But Zhou Ze couldn't retreat; after all, this was his own shop.

Fortunately, Zhou Ze and Bai Yingying weren't low-level lone spirits or mountain sprites and monsters. Although it was uncomfortable, there was no actual harm.

On the contrary, Zhou Ze felt a genuine respect for this person from the bottom of his heart.

"People's hearts are hidden behind their bellies," is true,

But as ghosts, they were more sensitive to this feeling.

So, the batch of books Zhou Ze initially gave him wasn't meant to trick him. Zhou Ze had preconceived notion that a police officer who could cultivate such a righteous aura would likely enjoy serious and valuable books.

However, Zhou Ze later realized that police officers are also human;

And as humans, they have their own interests and hobbies. For example, the police officer sitting there now was deeply engrossed in a novel.

"Uncle, have some tea."

Bai Yingying timidly brought over a teacup.

"Oh, thank you." The police officer took the teacup, looked at Bai Yingying, and asked, "Aren't you in school?"

"Today's a holiday."

Bai Yingying didn't dare to say she wasn't in school and was just messing around, to avoid further trouble.

Bai Yingying was a little afraid of the man in front of her, even more so than Zhou Ze.

Zhou Ze was a modern person and could understand this mindset. While the man in front of him instinctively made him feel scared, from another perspective, it also meant that this person was more worthy of respect.

But Bai Yingying just felt her heart beating a little fast. After handing over the tea, she immediately ran upstairs and didn't want to come down again.

"Boss, how much?" The police officer looked at Zhou Ze.

"Just pay what you think is right," Zhou Ze said.

"That won't do. Never mind, I'll settle up when I leave. They'll probably be here to pick me up in about half an hour." The police officer sat back down, patted his pocket, and paused.

As an old smoker, Zhou Ze understood and offered him a cigarette.

"Thanks."

The police officer thanked Zhou Ze for lighting his cigarette, and then they both smoked.

Cigarettes are indeed a bridge for male social interaction, turning strangers into smoking buddies, and making it easier to boast a little.

"Your business here isn't very easy, is it?" the police officer asked.

"Just getting by," Zhou Ze replied.

"Oh, I remember who you are now." The police officer patted his head and said, "During the last fire, you bravely rushed into the flames to save people, didn't you?"

Zhou Ze nodded.

"Look at my memory. Oh, right, the bureau wanted to give you a commendation banner last time, why didn't you go receive it?"

"It was just my duty; I didn't want to show off," Zhou Ze replied.

The police officer nodded, somewhat helplessly saying, "Indeed, in the end, no one expected that the arsonist would be one of the heroes who rushed into the fire to save people."

"Damn it, taxis really have disappeared, and ride-hailing cars are hard to get at this time. I can't even get a taxi. Old Zhou, it seems we really have to move. You can't even get a cab in this godforsaken place.

I'm missing a cable here; I have to go back and buy one, otherwise, the host won't be able to be assembled."

Xu Qinglang complained as he walked in, then saw the police officer sitting in the bookstore.

"Oh, Bureau Chief Zhao!"

Xu Qinglang clearly knew the police officer. He immediately smiled and said warmly:

"Bureau Chief Zhao, you look as robust as ever. *Hiss*, I remember seeing news about you a while ago. What was it about? I forgot, but it seemed like you earned another merit and received a medal. Yes, that must be it. Congratulations!"

"You little rascal, you've grown more handsome." Bureau Chief Zhao stood up with a laugh, patted Xu Qinglang's shoulder, looking quite affectionate, "Are you still stealing chickens and snatching dogs?"

"How could I dare? My family's house was demolished, and we got over twenty apartments. Now I'm a law-abiding taxpayer," Xu Qinglang replied.

"You..." Bureau Chief Zhao pointed at Xu Qinglang, "You've really turned your fortunes around."

"Bureau Chief Zhao, your son is getting married soon, isn't he? How about I give you an apartment as a wedding gift for your son?"

"You brat, if you dare to say such nonsense in front of me again, believe it or not, I'll arrest you and throw you back in the bureau?" Bureau Chief Zhao sternly scolded.

"Hey, I'm just a noodle shop owner, I'm not bribing you. If it weren't for you back then, I probably wouldn't have made it until my family's old house and land were demolished. It's only right to honor you with an apartment."

"You just live your life well."

"You two know each other?" Zhou Ze asked.

Bureau Chief Zhao nodded and said, "Know each other? More than just know each other. This kid has been running around stealing things and picking pockets since before he was ten. I've caught him so many times.

The first time I caught him, I even told my subordinate police officers that I caught a little girl thief, who knew he was a boy!"

"I didn't know better back then, so let's not bring it up," Xu Qinglang didn't want Zhou Ze to hear about his past embarrassing incidents.

"Bring it up, we must bring it up. You little rascal did a lot of foolish things back then. Those mistakes cannot be forgotten; they must be kept in mind to warn yourself not to commit them again. Good times are hard to come by."

"Bureau Chief Zhao, I understand." Xu Qinglang nodded.

"By the way, I sent you to be an apprentice to Master Sun. How is Master Sun doing these days?" Bureau Chief Zhao asked.

"He's alright, but his shop has been passed on to his son, and I've also branched out on my own."

It turns out that this was also the reason Xu Qinglang opened a noodle shop. Back then, his family experienced changes, and he was almost becoming a hoodlum on the streets. Bureau Chief Zhao, who was then the director of the police station, caught and educated him several times. Finally, Bureau Chief Zhao even arranged for him to be an apprentice at a noodle shop, which put him on the right path.

Otherwise, Xu Qinglang might have needed an additional "apartment" now – a prison cell.

"Bureau Chief Zhao, why are you here?" After saying that, Xu Qinglang quietly reminded him, "Let me tell you, you should rarely come to this place; the *feng shui* isn't good."

The implication was that Zhou Ze's bookstore had far more dead people looking at books than living ones.

Zhou Ze raised an eyebrow at the side.

What did he mean?

"You brat, you still haven't changed your habit of playing ghostly tricks. I was born under the red flag, grew up under the red flag; I don't believe in these crooked, evil teachings.

Besides, if you walk upright and sit straight, and haven't done anything guilty, you won't be afraid of a ghost knocking on your door.

Even if there really are ghosts in this world, the ghosts will be afraid of me, not the other way around!"

Zhou Ze rubbed the tip of his nose beside them. You really hit the nail on the head.

"Bureau Chief Zhao, I'll personally cook up a few dishes. We haven't seen each other for many years. How about we have a couple of drinks tonight?"

"Can't do it, someone will pick me up soon. I'm going on a business trip to another province. I just bought two novels to read on the way, in case I get bored."

"You're already a bureau chief, and you're still so busy," Xu Qinglang said, a little regretfully.

"It's good to be busy. I'm a police officer. If police officers become lax, the common people won't be able to rest easy."

Bureau Chief Zhao scratched his head, put his police cap back on, then took out his phone to check the time again and said:

"It's about time. They should be here to pick me up. I'm leaving now."

"Have a safe trip."

Zhou Ze thought to himself that he finally sent this magnificent great god away.

Bureau Chief Zhao walked to the door, then seemed to remember something, reaching into his pocket as if to get his wallet:

"Look at my memory, I took books and drank tea, almost forgot to pay."

"Look at you being a stranger, I paid for it," Xu Qinglang immediately stepped forward and said, "This boss grew up eating my food; he's family."

"............" Zhou Ze.

"No, that won't do. Why should you pay for the books I bought?" Bureau Chief Zhao disagreed.

"Alright, in a few days, I'll visit you personally and let you repay me for the books, and I'll also grab a meal. How about it?" Xu Qinglang pleaded, "You have to give me a reason to visit, don't you?"

"Alright then, your aunt's cooking is still pretty good. I might not be home then, but I'll have your aunt cook you a meal, and you learn a thing or two. Just tell her I said so. Strive to turn this noodle shop into a hotel in the future.

People always need some pursuits; don't just lie around on those apartments, living off them and waiting to die. That's no fun either."

"Heh, what would I go there for if you're not home?" Xu Qinglang laughed.

"Alright, I'm leaving now, goodbye!" Bureau Chief Zhao waved to Zhou Ze and Xu Qinglang, pushed open the bookstore door, and left.

"Boss, there are so many cars outside!" Bai Yingying, who had been upstairs, came down the stairs and called out to the people in the bookstore.

"What cars?" Xu Qinglang asked, "Is it a wedding procession?"

"Wedding cars don't have the same prestige as an eight-bearer sedan chair," Zhou Ze teased Xu Qinglang.

"Not wedding cars, they're taxis, so many taxis, the whole road is full of taxis," Bai Yingying said, she could see clearly from the upstairs window.

"Taxis?" Xu Qinglang paused, then said, "Damn, no wonder it was so hard to get a taxi today, I couldn't even see any. Are they organizing a strike and protest?"

Suddenly, Xu Qinglang froze.

He seemed to have remembered something and immediately took out his phone to search. Finally, he found it.

It was a news report from half a month ago.

The headline featured a large photo of Bureau Chief Zhao, and the content below described how a car theft ring that had been active across multiple provinces was apprehended in Tongcheng. They were discovered by an off-duty deputy police bureau chief returning home. During the struggle, the deputy bureau chief unfortunately died in the line of duty.

Three days later, the police apprehended the entire criminal gang, not missing a single member. This car theft ring mainly stole taxis and was also responsible for the deaths of two taxi drivers.

Bureau Chief Zhao had died a long time ago.

"He's already dead... I remember reading that news and being sad for a long time, but just now, as soon as I saw him in front of me, I instinctively felt that he was still alive and completely forgot about that news."

After saying that, Xu Qinglang angrily looked at Zhou Ze:

"He's a ghost; he's not a living person! Why didn't you tell me just now? I had so many things I didn't get to say to him!"

Zhou Ze was also astonished and said, "He's a ghost?"

"You didn't realize? You're a ghost messenger; you didn't realize?"

"When he came in, I observed him carefully. He was human."

"How could he be human!" Xu Qinglang almost roared.

He could have said goodbye to him earlier, but he was just chatting!

"Why would I lie to you? I observed him carefully and truly didn't realize he was a ghost."

"I didn't notice either," Bai Yingying said as she came over.

At that moment, on the road outside the shop,

A line of taxis, arranged in two parallel rows, moved slowly forward. The line was very long, almost endless.

Xu Qinglang pushed open the bookstore door and walked out. Zhou Ze and Bai Yingying followed him out.

Nearly a thousand taxis spontaneously organized themselves into a procession, moving forward. The taxi drivers, both men and women, changed their usual habit of driving fast and constantly overtaking.

This time,

They drove very, very slowly.

At the end of the procession,

There was a hearse playing a funeral dirge.

At the same time, a large black-and-white photo, Bureau Chief Zhao's portrait, hung above the hearse.

"Is it a funeral today?" Xu Qinglang said despondently, "So when he said he was going on a business trip and someone would pick him up, it was this funeral procession?

But how could I not tell he was a ghost, and you couldn't either."

"Some people are alive but already dead;

Some people are dead but still alive.

Perhaps, that's why," Zhou Ze said.

"Sigh." Xu Qinglang nodded upon hearing this, then waved his hand at the long procession, bidding farewell.

At the same time, he felt a sense of relief, no wonder it was so difficult to get a taxi in Tongcheng today.

Zhou Ze watched as the car carrying the portrait slowly drove past,

And silently said in his heart:

"Rest in peace."

——————

This story is based on a true event.

title: 第六十二章 人格分裂
content:
Xu Qinglang had originally planned to perform a ritual for Bureau Chief Zhao, hoping he would pass peacefully, and to do his part.

But then he reconsidered: Bureau Chief Zhao had passed quite peacefully already, even bringing two books along for the journey, lest the path to the Yellow Springs be too dull.

Furthermore, the spontaneous farewell convoy of thousands of taxis and numerous citizens was surely enough to ensure Bureau Chief Zhao's smooth journey; there was no need for him to gild the lily.

"Old Zhou, he was a really good person."

Xu Qinglang puffed on his cigarette, eyes reddening slightly, a truly pitiable sight.

"He also left with dignity."

Even though he was a doctor in his previous life, and had saved and helped many people, Zhou Ze didn't consider himself particularly great. His profession was doctor; saving the dying and helping the injured was simply his duty.

In truth, those ordinary yet great people merely do their jobs in society, but the brilliance they exude isn't confined to their work.

There are always some things that can move you, and move many others.

People often ponder whether the eyes of the masses are truly discerning.

But the nearly one thousand taxi drivers, male and female, who formed the farewell escort, their hearts were crystal clear.

"I'm going to rest."

Xu Qinglang pulled out a tissue, wiped away the tears from the corners of his eyes, and turned to go back to his noodle shop. He wanted to drink some alcohol, then get a good night's sleep. Strong people never like to show their vulnerable side to others.

After finishing his cigarette, Zhou Ze also walked back to the bookstore. The little loli told him to boost his performance, but Zhou Ze remained as lazy as ever.

This was largely due to a lack of initiative, and also, Zhou Ze was waiting for a result: what would be the fate of that person in Rongcheng?

Although Zhou Ze himself felt that the other party's chances of turning things around were slim—the little loli had personally gone back to Hell and even released the Faceless Woman to help, also uniting with many other ghost messengers.

But,

What if?

What if?

Yes, what if!

Zhou Ze even genuinely considered and hoped that if the person in Rongcheng managed to kill the little loli, wouldn't the little loli's position naturally fall to him?

One must always have dreams.

Taking out his phone, Zhou Ze dialed a number—Old Daoist's phone.

After treating Old Daoist to dinner last time, they hadn't contacted each other again.

No one answered on the other end. Zhou Ze put down his phone, but soon, the call was returned:

"Hello, big brother, I'm not in Tongcheng right now, I'm in Xucheng. What's up, do you need something?"

"Oh."

Zhou Ze had originally wanted to tell Old Daoist to warn that person to be careful, but on second thought, he didn't bother with extra words, nor did he chat much, simply hanging up.

Old Daoist on the other end of the line probably felt bewildered.

In that dream, the young man clearly knew he was being targeted, so his current reminder was redundant.

That person already knew.

Stretching, the little loli woke up, returning to her cute and blank expression, and then her mother, having finished her hair, came back to pick her up.

It was evident that her mother's hair treatment was very successful; while seemingly unchanged, she looked much more radiant and healthy, like dewdrops on a summer morning's flower bud, appearing more mature and tender.

When she walked out of the car, her legs were spread wider.

Today's matters should have ended here. Zhou Ze had planned to take a shower and then prepare for the evening's business.

The little loli said that keeping Bai Yingying, this zombie, by his side was like putting a lampshade over himself, a white-hot bulb, which would affect the probability of encountering ghosts. But Zhou Ze currently had no intention of sending Bai Yingying away.

Sleeping with a freezer was, of course, not as comfortable as sleeping with Bai Yingying.

Moreover, ghosts kept coming to the bookstore, and Zhou Ze was getting a bit annoyed. This was with Bai Yingying present; if she weren't, he'd probably have to deal with a large number of lingering spirits every night.

Zhou Ze felt he had degenerated. In his previous life, he was so ambitious, so motivated.

In this life, he only wanted to muddle through, but this lazy and aimless feeling, a life of just reading books and slouching in a chair every day,

It was truly comfortable.

As Zhou Ze asked Bai Yingying to get his clean clothes for a shower,

Someone pushed open the shop door. Zhou Ze turned around, slightly surprised by this person's arrival, as his daughter and wife had just left the shop.

"I'm here for a follow-up, to see how you're doing lately."

Wang Ke naturally pulled out a plastic stool and sat on it, motioning for Zhou Ze to sit opposite him.

He owned his own psychiatric hospital, and his fees were quite high, so actively following up and offering free consultations to Zhou Ze was, in his and others' eyes, a great honor for Zhou Ze.

Of course, half of this honor was attributed to the real Zhou Ze, and the other half was because Zhou Ze had saved his daughter earlier.

Zhou Ze sat opposite Wang Ke,

Trying to keep his gaze low, not looking at Wang Ke's head.

Because Wang Ke's head was radiating a dense green light, as if ten thousand horses were galloping.

The bookstore's computer was connected to a small Bluetooth speaker, randomly playing some pop music. At this moment, it happened to switch to Stefanie Sun's "Green Light."

Even random playback was so mischievous these days.

"Tell me, how have you been feeling lately?" Wang Ke asked.

"I think I'm very well, the problems are mostly gone now," Zhou Ze replied.

"I can see that. You're very calm, and you're handling things with ease now," Wang Ke nodded.

However, a silence fell between them.

Zhou Ze found it a bit strange; it seemed that the other party wasn't specifically here for a follow-up on his condition, that was just a pretense.

"There's something I'd like your help with," Wang Ke said again.

"Tell me."

Regardless of their relationship in the previous life, simply based on the advice and analysis he provided for Zhou Ze's condition recently, Zhou Ze owed him a favor.

"I have a client who has dissociative identity disorder. Her case is quite complex and a bit difficult to handle, so I need you to go and observe and analyze her."

"That shouldn't be difficult for you, should it?" Zhou Ze asked.

"It is," Wang Ke gave a wry smile. "Her father is an important business partner of mine; my psychiatric hospital was established with his investment.

If it were simply a matter of helping the first personality eliminate the second, or vice versa, I have ways and the ability to try.

But the complexity lies in this:

To my partner, his daughter's first personality is, of course, his daughter herself, but the second personality is very similar to his wife."

"So... mother and daughter are living in one body?"

"Yes, his wife passed away from illness last year, and he was very sad. His daughter is only sixteen this year. I analyze that it might be because the girl subconsciously couldn't accept the fact that her mother had passed away.

So, in her own consciousness, she gradually 'recreated' an image of her mother to accompany her.

If this problem had been discovered earlier, it would have been fine, but by the time it was truly noticed and taken seriously, it was too late. The second personality had already formed and was very mature.

During the day, she's the daughter; at night, she's the mother.

During the day, she goes to school, plays computer games, and watches TV series in her room.

At night, she wants to rest in her father's bedroom. If my friend doesn't open the door, she cries outside, saying he has another woman and doesn't want to touch her anymore."

"Quite interesting," Zhou Ze chuckled.

Wang Ke's expression was a bit awkward. Zhou Ze's comment made him uncomfortable; joking about a patient was very disrespectful.

"My apologies." Zhou Ze raised a hand, indicating he had spoken out of turn, but still said, "So, how does your business partner want to resolve this issue?"

Have his "wife" die again,

Or, have his daughter become his wife?

Happiness, choose one of two.

Zhou Ze was also a doctor in his previous life; logically, he shouldn't be thinking about this matter with such a jocular attitude. But in reality, Zhou Ze couldn't maintain a perfectly serious demeanor, especially as he had already discerned the father's thoughts from Wang Ke's narration.

There were nothing but three ways to solve the problem: keep the daughter, keep the "wife," or keep both.

Of course, there was another extreme way, keeping neither, but that amounted to murder and was immediately excluded.

As a doctor, you should only be responsible for your patient.

In his previous life, when Zhou Ze saved people in the hospital, he often encountered external interference. For example, a pregnant woman had acute inflammation, and her family members actually stopped the doctors from performing an X-ray, saying they were afraid it would affect the baby's health, but the situation at the time was that both the pregnant woman and the baby could die directly from the inflammation.

In this case, the so-called "wife" was merely a virtual personality, a symptom of the daughter's illness caused by missing her deceased mother.

Therefore, helping the daughter recover and shake off the influence of the so-called second personality was the correct direction for treatment.

But Wang Ke was conflicted, which meant the father chose the third option: he loved his wife, he missed his wife, so he hoped to see his daughter in his daughter's body while also feeling that his wife was still alive.

"He loves his wife very much," Wang Ke said.

"But often, love is actually a disguise for selfishness."

"So, you're unwilling to help?"

"I don't know how I can help you."

"You are the most perfect case of a successful second personality integration I've ever seen. I believe you might be able to communicate with the mother's personality. To ensure they coexist harmoniously in one body; the problem now is that the two personalities are showing unstable tendencies.

They will gradually cross over and become chaotic.

Then, they will become another stranger."

"I'm sorry, I can't do that." Zhou Ze looked at Wang Ke, "Mr. Wang, I remember my good friend Zhou Ze told me about you, saying you were a very upright and principled person."

Wang Ke frowned slightly, but quickly relaxed, saying:

"People change. Without that investor's help, I wouldn't be where I am today."

Wang Ke stood up, appearing ready to leave. Since he couldn't persuade Zhou Ze, he had no reason to stay.

"I think I bought a lottery ticket, and I forgot to check the winning numbers. Maybe I won five million, I should check now," Zhou Ze suddenly said.

"That probability is too low," Wang Ke smiled.

"Scratching a lottery ticket is like looking at a paternity test. Everyone knows it's pointless, but you can't help but take a look."

After saying that, Zhou Ze smiled at Wang Ke and continued:

"Right?"

title: 第六十三章 鬼啊！
content:
Three days had passed since Zhou Ze had refused Wang Ke. Zhou Ze had practically forgotten about it. These past few days, Bai Yingying, having nothing to do, would go to Xu Qinglang’s shop to play computer games, while Xu Qinglang would come to the bookstore to chat with Zhou Ze and read newspapers.

Although Bureau Chief Zhao had told Xu Qinglang before he left that it was best not to waste life lying on a house, Xu Qinglang had agreed.

Yes,

Laziness certainly doesn't lead to success,

But,

Laziness can make one comfortable.

Xu Qinglang had still fallen into decay. For these three days, his shop hadn't lit a fire except when Zhou Ze ate and when he himself ate. He hadn't even opened his food delivery app; it had remained in "Shop Closed" status.

At noon, Zhou Ze had just finished lunch with strawberry juice. As he strolled at the bookstore entrance, he saw that familiar red car driving over.

This left Zhou Ze a bit speechless. Just three days, and this woman was going to get her hair done again?

Too much hair styling could damage one's hair.

Soon, the woman stopped the car, and then Wang Ke also got out.

Wang Ke jogged over to Zhou Ze, looked at him, and said,

"Help me."

Very simple,

And very direct,

Just those two words.

Without any preamble, it meant these two words directly extended from the previous topic: the patient with the mother-daughter fusion.

"Things have gotten worse. Her personality is starting to become chaotic," Wang Ke said, very urgently. "You have to help me."

Zhou Ze shrugged,

Meaning was simple,

Sorry,

He still wasn't willing to get involved in this matter.

A simple one-plus-one-equals-two problem had been delayed into a more serious issue. This was a man-made disaster, not a natural one.

In this, Wang Ke, who considered the investors' position, had lost his professional ethics and duty as a doctor.

"I don't have time." Zhou Ze pointed to his bookstore. "I need to mind the shop."

He intended to refuse. He just needed an excuse or a reason, even if it was a lousy one. It didn't matter.

"Whatever your daily turnover is, I'll pay you ten times that."

Wang Ke said directly,

"Come with me. I think you can help. She almost succeeded in committing suicide last night. If she hadn't been discovered early, she would be a corpse now!"

Zhou Ze was in agony.

His neighbor was richer than him,

His wife was richer than him,

His maid was also richer than him,

And his childhood friend said, "Whatever your daily turnover is, I'll pay you ten times that."

So disheartening,

So disheartening that Zhou Ze even thought of asking "Little Loli" to help him check next time he saw her, to see if he was born with a fate of poverty. How could he be so poor in two lifetimes?

"This is about sentiment; money can't measure it." Zhou Ze genuinely didn't want to go. He was a surgeon. To be honest, he only knew a little about psychology.

"Come with me, give me a hand!"

Wang Ke grabbed Zhou Ze's hand.

This made Zhou Ze uncomfortable.

Even Xu Qinglang, that man more beautiful than a woman, had never made such a gesture towards him. He immediately took a step back, trying to pull his hand away, but Wang Ke held onto his hand tightly.

Zhou Ze's brows furrowed slightly.

Was he going to be so pushy?

Just as Zhou Ze was about to get angry,

Wang Ke suddenly lowered his voice and said,

"A Ze, help me!"

Zhou Ze's eyes suddenly widened, staring intently at Wang Ke.

What did he just call him?

Wang Ke kept taking deep breaths and said, "If this matter isn't resolved, my career is over. I won't lie to you, it was my suggestion to my investor to choose the dual personality preservation. I told him I had the ability to handle the treatment and arrangements.

Now, I'm panicking. I'm helpless. I can only rely on you."

"What did you just call me?" Zhou Ze also lowered his voice.

Xu Qinglang happened to walk out of his shop to smoke, watching the two men outside holding hands and "whispering sweet nothings" and "huddling together" in hushed tones;

He immediately took a sharp breath, feeling a severe toothache, and sighed,

"What an outrage, what an outrage."

Wang Ke's wife and Bai Yingying stood nearby, somewhat bewildered to see their respective men behaving so intimately and exchanging secrets.

"A Ze, help me."

Wang Ke repeated.

He had seen it,

He had seen it for a long time,

But he had been pretending to be foolish,

Or rather, he wasn't sure, and this discovery and deduction were too shocking. But at this moment, he could only hope for Zhou Ze's help.

Zhou Ze bit his lip, looked up, and then nodded.

He agreed.

He had no choice but to agree.

Just as when he had gone to Wang Ke's house to find him, and directly stated the name Zhou Ze, Wang Ke had immediately put down his most important work to treat him,

Now,

Wang Ke had said his name. In front of him, he was no longer Xu Le, but Zhou Ze, and there was no longer any room for refusal.

As childhood friends who had grown up together in the orphanage, although they had largely lost contact after finishing their studies and starting work, each striving in their own fields, the memories of growing up together and encouraging each other were still very real.

"Come on, get in the car."

Wang Ke impatiently opened the car door for Zhou Ze, and Zhou Ze got in.

Wang Ke and Zhou Ze sat together in the back seat, with the woman driving.

Inside the car, for a long time, no one spoke.

This made the driving woman feel a bit stifled, but she didn't ask anything further.

Zhou Ze opened the car window, letting some outside wind in, then said,

"How did you find out?"

"We grew up together, daily habits, detailed actions." As he spoke, Wang Ke tapped his own head with a finger. "Besides, this is my profession."

Zhou Ze smiled faintly and said nothing more.

Wang Ke continued, "If you help me resolve this, I won't reminisce with you, nor will I contact you again, nor will I bother you again, and I have no other curiosity.

You can trust me on this, brother."

"Are you still... the old you?" Zhou Ze retorted.

"Last time, a man named Xu Le knocked on my door in the middle of the night, saying Zhou Ze introduced him. What did I do?"

Zhou Ze nodded.

After a while, Zhou Ze added, "I'm a surgeon."

Meaning, there's no use in you calling me here; I'm not a psychologist.

Unless the girl attempted suicide again, he'd have no problem participating in the rescue, but for other matters, he was truly powerless.

"I've suspected for a long time that it's more than just a multiple personality," Wang Ke said, glancing at his wife who was driving, and lowering his voice.

"Oh?" Zhou Ze was taken aback,

Then he understood the implication,

What's very similar to "multiple personality disorder"?

Demonic possession!

No wonder Wang Ke came to see him last time, saying his second personality could connect with the other party's second personality,

Damn it,

The implication was:

You ghosts can communicate with each other!

Damn it!

………………

This was Tongcheng's most exclusive residential area, nestled at the foot of Lang Mountain. High-end villas dotted the landscape. As the car drove in, the security guards at the gate saluted the people in the car.

This reminded Zhou Ze of the small community he lived in during his previous life, where the old gatekeeper in the guardhouse would usually skip work and sleep at night.

Wang Ke, of course, didn't realize that Zhou Ze was currently suffering from the torment of wealth disparity, and thought Zhou Ze was depressed because he had seen through his identity.

The car drove up to the villa entrance. A young man, the butler, walked over.

"Doctor Wang, Mr. Zheng is already angry," the butler reminded.

"Something happened to Miss Zheng again?" Wang Ke's expression became solemn.

"Not... that kind of thing..." The young butler seemed unable to articulate it, finally only saying, "No life-threatening danger, not suicide this time."

Wang Ke and Zhou Ze got out of the car and went directly upstairs to the second floor. Wang Ke's wife did not follow.

There were many rooms on the second floor, all covered with red carpets. The villa was large, but the decoration style didn't appear vulgar or ostentatious, suggesting that the owner was not a parvenu; on the contrary, he should be a person of great taste.

After turning a corner, Zhou Ze saw a middle-aged man with half-white hair standing at the door of a bedroom. The man was holding a cigar and looked worried.

When he saw Wang Ke and Zhou Ze approaching, a flicker of anger appeared in his eyes, but it vanished quickly, replaced by a genial and helpless smile, and he said,

"Doctor Wang, Pingping is again..."

"What's wrong, Mr. Zheng?" Wang Ke was also somewhat anxious.

He was the doctor responsible for Zheng Pingping's treatment. Now that things had turned out this way, he couldn't shirk responsibility, and he clearly knew that the wealthy businessman in front of him must be very dissatisfied with him, but the other party understood that getting angry at this moment was meaningless, so he had been restraining himself.

"See for yourself."

Mr. Zheng motioned for the two young men at the door to open the bedroom door. Wang Ke and Zhou Ze walked in.

Inside, two nannies were attending to a young girl in a dress with a cloth strip wrapped around her arm, dancing gracefully and singing a "Child's Play" opera in a stylized voice.

Wang Ke looked bewildered,

"How could this happen?"

Zhou Ze noticed the girl's wrist was bandaged with gauze, indicating she had recently attempted suicide by slitting her wrists but hadn't succeeded.

As the girl danced, she seemed to notice the two people who had entered. She immediately raised her voice, flicked the cloth strip, and pointed at Wang Ke, singing:

"A life of solitude, cursed your parents;
A lifetime of toil, only to serve others,
Ultimately, destined for separation from wife and children, abandoned by all, in bitter sorrow!"

The girl sang, flicking her sleeve and feigning tears, seemingly grieving over it.

Wang Ke was a bit lost, not knowing what opera this was.

But Zhou Ze understood.

The girl again waved her sleeve at Zhou Ze, singing simultaneously:

"From a young age, orphaned and destitute, wandering alone;
Seeking to climb the ladder to the clouds, yet falling to an early death and ruin in the underworld, truly sighing and lamenting..."

Singing and singing,

As she "sighed and lamented,"

The girl suddenly stopped short,

Like an old record player that had suddenly jammed,

Then the girl's face showed confusion. She waved her long sleeves again and sang:

"Born with a good appearance, but with a barbarian mind!
A man's knees are worth gold, yet you have no part in it!
Ultimately, you'll achieve nothing, having lived on earth in vain..."

Now,

The girl jammed again.

Then the girl let out a shriek,

And collapsed directly onto the floor, a large wet patch on her pants,

Pointing at Zhou Ze, her face filled with fear as she cried out,

"Ghost... ghost...

A ghost!"

title: 第六十四章 領證！
content:
The girl pointed at Zhou Ze and screamed, but thankfully, she was already deranged and had a split personality, so her so-called "accusation" had no effect on Zhou Ze.

No one would believe what a mentally disturbed person said.

And even if a normal person said such things, they would be considered mentally disturbed.

But the words the girl had sung earlier, in the tune of "Child's Play," might have seemed nonsensical and gossip to others, yet in Zhou Ze's ears, they held an unusual meaning.

She was singing…

...a judgment!

A "judgment" is a poem or verse that summarizes a person's entire life, determining their past and their future.

For example, in "Dream of the Red Chamber," the line "Once from two commands, then three persons wood; weeping to Jinling, sorrows more acute" is the judgment for Wang Xifeng.

"A solitary fate, cursed her parents;
A lifetime of toil, just to make wedding clothes;
Finally ends in spousal separation, children scattered, abandoned by all, in bitter sorrow!"

This referred to Wang Ke. Wang Ke, like himself, grew up in an orphanage, implying that Wang Ke had cursed his parents to death. After becoming an adult, he focused on his career and neglected everything else. The last line is easy to understand: spousal separation and children scattered.

Zhou Ze felt that Wang Ke might have sensed his wife was having an affair, but he hadn't exposed it. Also, his daughter was chosen by a ghost messenger to become a flesh vessel.

And then, the judgment the girl sang about him:

"Orphaned and helpless from youth, wandering aimlessly;
About to ascend the ladder of success, but cut short and fell into the netherworld, truly lamentable..."

This referred to himself: an orphan who, by his own abilities, became a department head before thirty. Just as he was rising rapidly, he suddenly died in a car accident.

As for "though born with a good face, inside was but a ruffian," this referred to Xu Le being outwardly splendid but inwardly rotten. He looked decent, otherwise, he wouldn't have been chosen by the Lin family parents to be a live-in son-in-law.

Here, "ruffian" (草莽) doesn't mean a robber or bandit, but rather that Xu Le, apart from his good looks, was essentially an empty-headed idiot.

The original line, "Though born with a good face, inside was but a ruffian," is a comment on Jia Baoyu in "Dream of the Red Chamber."

Zhou Ze actually thought the judgment's description of Xu Le was very apt. The Lin family was genuinely wealthy. As a live-in son-in-law, it shouldn't have been difficult for Xu Le to start a business or venture, but this fellow, like a dead literati, opened a bookstore that only lost money.

Of course, the girl's final "skip" and terror were because she had seen two lives within him.

One was the physical body,

One was the soul.

In an instant,

She understood that she had seen a ghost.

This made Zhou Ze smile. In that case, this girl in front of him shouldn't be possessed by a ghost.

He wouldn't have scared a ghost so badly that it peed itself like his sister-in-law did.

The two nannies immediately came over, held the girl down, and continuously comforted her.

Wang Ke also went over, trying to persuade her verbally.

Zhou Ze, meanwhile, surveyed the surroundings. This should be the girl's original boudoir, with a pink theme and a princess bed, very warm and lovely. It was just a pity that its owner was now in a state of madness.

What puzzled Zhou Ze was, if this girl wasn't a ghost, then where did her "Child's Play" song and such accurate judgments come from?

"Child's Play" is a local Tongcheng曲目 (qumu). Nowadays, only some elderly people listen to it; young people might not even have heard of it. Yet, this girl had just sung it very professionally.

Could it be that the fusion of two disordered personalities created a new personality, and this personality possessed such a special ability?

Don't people often say that there's only a fine line between genius and madness?

But then he thought it seemed wrong again, yet he couldn't pinpoint exactly what was wrong.

"Where is the master?"

At this moment, the girl suddenly spoke calmly. She pushed away the nannies beside her and stood up.

"Has my master come home?"

Wang Ke froze in place.

Zhou Ze also slightly opened his mouth.

Did the role just switch?

Had she turned into the madam personality?

"A-Qiu, I'm here." Mr. Zheng walked over at this moment and then motioned for everyone else to leave. He wanted to comfort his "wife."

Walking onto the balcony, Zhou Ze lit a cigarette.

"What's going on?" Wang Ke asked, standing beside Zhou Ze. His hope rested on Zhou Ze.

Zhou Ze shook his head. "She's not possessed by a ghost."

"Is it really a mental problem?" Wang Ke pursed his dry lips. He was in a difficult situation now, somewhat caught between a rock and a hard place.

In fact, if he had initially adhered to his medical principles and provided psychological treatment to the girl, things might not have escalated to this point.

But it was too late to say anything now.

However, this wasn't entirely Wang Ke's fault. To gain the investor's support, he would naturally try to please his investor.

Furthermore, from the way Mr. Zheng immediately entered when he heard his daughter's personality switch to his wife, and from the tone he used when calling "A-Qiu," it was evident that more than half of the problem lay with him.

"What's this room for?" Zhou Ze asked, pointing to the room next to the bedroom. It was draped in white gauze, and the French windows were completely covered.

For some reason, Zhou Ze always felt there was something inside that made him uncomfortable.

"It's Miss's art studio," the young butler at the side said.

"Oh, can I go in and take a look?" Zhou Ze asked.

"This..." The butler seemed hesitant, then looked at Wang Ke.

"Let him take a look," Wang Ke nodded. "Learning more about Miss's situation will also help with the treatment's progress."

"Alright."

The butler immediately got the key, opened the door, and then stood outside. Zhou Ze and Wang Ke walked in together.

"You liked to draw when you were little. I remember you once told me you wanted to be a painter," Wang Ke said, somewhat nostalgically.

"The orphanage didn't have the conditions for that back then," Zhou Ze said.

For Zhou Ze's situation at the time, learning to paint and pursue art was quite unrealistic. So, after the college entrance examination, he ultimately chose medical university to find a job and support himself.

"Don't worry, no matter how this turns out, I won't bother you again," Wang Ke gave a wry smile. "Actually, I'm also scared. The last time I came to find you, I was on edge the whole time."

Your daughter is a ghost messenger; if you knew that, wouldn't you just faint?

At this moment, the butler called from the doorway, "Doctor Wang, Mr. Zheng is looking for you."

"I'll go check, and I'll give you a ride when I leave." Wang Ke left the art studio, leaving Zhou Ze alone there.

Zhou Ze walked around the art studio by himself, looking at some of the paintings on the floor and walls. He was a bit lost in thought. To be honest, while these paintings clearly showed they were by a young artist, each one seemed to possess a unique spiritual quality, reflecting the artist's inherent talent.

Finally, Zhou Ze stopped in front of an easel covered with a black cloth. Without the slightest mental burden, he directly reached out and lifted the cloth. Immediately, Zhou Ze's pupils contracted sharply.

The painting on the easel was a skull.

It didn't look particularly special; after all, such skull paintings could easily be found online.

But this skull gave Zhou Ze a feeling of his heart skipping a beat, and even his breathing seemed to slow down because of it.

This was a special feeling, an unusual resonance.

After several deep breaths to calm his mind, Zhou Ze was able to examine the painting more closely. He then noticed that the skull in the painting had a three-dimensional quality, especially on the far left, where there was a spatial fold.

This was like the difference between a flat drawing of a book cover and a three-dimensional drawing of a book cover.

This was a copied work, because the girl's previous paintings were all in the style of "petite and charming, flowing household life," but this one was completely different from her previous style!

From the painting,

She must have been copying a book, or a small booklet?

And the cover of that book or booklet was this skull.

Zhou Ze began to search around. The girl must have placed that object in front of her when she painted it, so it was highly likely that the object was in this art studio.

Soon, Zhou Ze discovered a small cabinet in the corner of the art studio. It wasn't locked. Zhou Ze opened the cabinet, which contained some illustration booklets and art books. After flipping through them continuously, Zhou Ze finally found what he was looking for: a booklet no bigger than the palm of his hand, looking somewhat like a driver's license.

He took it out and placed it in front of him. The front cover was that skull, identical to the one in the painting.

That's right, what the girl copied was this thing.

Zhou Ze instinctively opened the booklet, but the moment it was opened,

The girl, who had just fallen asleep in the adjacent bedroom, suddenly opened her eyes, a crimson gleam appearing within them. Then she jumped directly off the bed. If not for the quick reflexes of the nannies who held her, she might have rushed out of the bedroom.

"Wuwuwu... Wuwuwu..."

The girl struggled desperately, her nails carving many bloody lines across the nannies' faces.

"What now!"

Mr. Zheng rushed back into the bedroom again, looking at his daughter in such a state, feeling immense pain.

Meanwhile, on the other side of the wall, Zhou Ze remained motionless, still holding the booklet open.

However, in Zhou Ze's mind, countless men, women, old and young, appeared in an instant. They appeared very quickly and disappeared just as quickly, but each time one appeared, a few lines of black brushstrokes would simultaneously appear beside them, bearing their judgment.

For a moment, the terrifying amount of information made Zhou Ze's head spin.

"Hiss..."

Suddenly, Zhou Ze tilted his head back, drew a sharp breath, and closed the booklet.

This wasn't an ordinary skull-themed booklet.

It contained records of countless departed souls and the annotations of their lives.

This was also something Zhou Ze had never seen before.

At this moment, Zhou Ze noticed a burnt mark in the center of the skull on the booklet's cover.

Zhou Ze instinctively touched the mark with his fingernail.

And at that very moment, Zhou Ze's black fingernail seemed to grow uncontrollably. The black aura on his nail swirled into the booklet, and the entire booklet began to feel incredibly hot, yet he couldn't drop it. It felt as if it were branded into Zhou Ze's flesh.

Meanwhile, the girl in the next room, who had been struggling wildly, suddenly quieted down, as if she had finally found release, and fell directly into a deep sleep.

The painful sensation didn't last long, but it was enough to make Zhou Ze sweat profusely, as if he had just endured the punishment of branding!
