"Thud..."

The booklet dropped from Zhou Ze's hand.

Zhou Ze hung his head, sweat dripping continuously.

But he saw that on the back of the booklet, which had only been a black cover, two clear lines of blood characters had appeared:

"The Underworld has order,
The Yellow Springs can be crossed."

title: 第六十五章 持證上崗！
content:
Pick up this booklet. This time, Zhou Ze didn't feel it hot to the touch; instead, he felt a warm, cool sensation, as if he were holding a piece of ancient jade.

A very strange connection seemed to have formed between himself and the booklet.

Zhou Ze had read some wuxia novels before, but the feeling at this moment wasn't like a magical artifact recognizing its owner in those stories.

The booklet was still a booklet,

He was still him,

But inexplicably, Zhou Ze felt a sense of intimacy with this item from the bottom of his heart, like a thirty-year-old man holding a photo of himself taken when he was three or five.

Strange, yet incredibly familiar.

Opening the first page of the booklet, that vast imagery swept over him again. Zhou Ze closed his eyes, and then all those chaotic things disappeared.

Last time, he had been passively infused.

This time, he seemed able to control the intake.

Finally, the first page was opened. On it was a handprint. Zhou Ze wasn't sure if it was his or someone else's. There was no way to do a detailed fingerprint comparison now, but in fact, this handprint was very strange. Zhou Ze even felt that no one in the world should have such a handprint.

The lines of the handprint were very harmonious, so harmonious that you couldn't find the slightest flaw, and incredibly neat, every detail achieving a very comfortable feeling.

Below it were two columns.

First column: Name: Zhou Ze.

Second column: Position: Temporary Ghost Catcher.

Actually, Zhou Ze had already had a thought before, that this should be the so-called ghost catcher's ID, or more precisely, the Underworld's ID. After all, the Underworld was also a small society, small but complete, and ghost catchers were just one of its positions.

Zhou Ze and Xu Qinglang had discussed his current situation before, and one clear point was that his temporary worker status was very delicate, liable to be made a scapegoat at any time, and without any security or status guarantees.

When the little loli returned last time, she directly admitted this when he questioned her.

At the same time, she casually drew him a big pie, not caring at all whether he wanted to eat it or not.

The reason for all this was that he lacked this ID!

With this ID in hand, he wouldn't be an unregistered person.

Most importantly, this ID meant he had gained access to a "performance review" system, much like the establishment and development of the imperial examination system in ancient times, which opened up channels for the lower class to move upward.

In the past few months of running the bookstore, Zhou Ze had been very lax. It wasn't that Zhou Ze was naturally like that, but his previous awkward status meant that doing more was prone to more mistakes, and not doing anything wasn't a big deal.

It was similar to the mentality of those money-losing state-owned enterprises a decade or two ago.

Now, he could at least set a small goal for himself.

One hundred million was out of the question,

But there was hope that he could raise his rank through his own efforts.

Similar to Madam Bai, a female ghost who protected her hometown folks for two hundred years in the human world and managed to cultivate merit to seek a position in Hell, Zhou Ze's starting point was actually much better than Madam Bai's.

However, what made Zhou Ze uncomfortable was why his current position was still only "Temporary Ghost Catcher"?

Zhou Ze knew that this absolutely wasn't something granted by Heaven out of appreciation for his "diligence," "devotion to duty," "exhaustion of efforts," or "until death"

*Biu*

—a certificate suddenly delivered.

Zhou Ze also knew that with his previous work attitude of "three days fishing, two days sunbathing," drinking tea and reading novels in the bookstore every day, and sleeping with Bai Yingying at night,

It was already incredibly merciful of Heaven not to strike him down with a bolt of lightning and turn him, a malevolent spirit, into dust. How could it reward him at this time?

This was someone else's Underworld ID,

But he happened to pick it up.

No, to be precise, Zheng Pingping picked it up, but Zheng Pingping was a living person, an ordinary person. She couldn't control this item at all, and instead suffered its influence, having her mind confused by it.

Coupled with the stimulus of her mother's recent death, this led to Zheng Pingping's behavior becoming abnormal.

She blurred who she was, because this booklet recorded the verdicts of countless past lives, which was like instantly reading the lives of thousands of people.

"Zhuang Zhou dreams of being a butterfly," or "returning to the village only to find the axe handle rotted," basically described this situation.

Lost in oneself, oblivious to all changes around, you were originally a grain of sand, but then a great river washed over you. Forget about others, could you even find yourself?

However, since he had "stolen" this item now, it should also mean that Zheng Pingping's connection with this ID had been severed, and her psychological illness should recover quickly.

However, the key problem was that Zhou Ze didn't think the previous owner of this item was also a "Temporary Ghost Catcher."

Could a temporary ghost catcher's performance record be so exaggerated?

Then were all the people in Hell model workers and pioneers of the era?

Were they all workaholics?

Looking at the little loli's lazy demeanor, she was actually quite similar to him. Otherwise, she wouldn't have left the performance for him to do while she went out to earn extra money.

Upon closer inspection, Zhou Ze found a faint white smudge over his name and the original position of "Temporary Ghost Catcher," somewhat like correction fluid.

Zhou Ze reached out and rubbed it, even scraping it with his fingernail, but nothing came off. The white smudge remained.

This gave Zhou Ze a bit of OCD. The truth was beneath the white smudge.

Originally, this should have been where the original owner's information was written. It was just that the original owner had likely kicked the bucket, and he had inherited this ID, with the official rank and other information on the ID consequently being "refreshed."

Zhou Ze even thought about asking Bai Yingying to try Tide laundry detergent back at the bookstore to see if it could rub off.

The booklet had several pages. When Zhou Ze turned to the second page, he saw a very simple line of text:

"Eight percent"

"Is this an experience bar?" Zhou Ze instinctively rubbed his nose.

Actually, ancient China already had a way of expressing "fractions." Of course, it wasn't with the Arabic numerals, numerator, denominator, and a horizontal line that people use today, but directly with this method of description.

The "Records of the Grand Historian: Book of Celestial Officials" has writings like "...two thirds..." and "...eight ninths..." "Two thirds" meant "two out of three," and "eight ninths" meant "eight out of nine."

Here, "eight percent" meant eight out of one hundred.

Zhou Ze shook his head, feeling a little ashamed. He had previously felt that the little loli's anger at his laziness and passive work was trivial, that she was making a fuss.

But now, it seemed that in the past two months, he had only completed eight percent of the temporary ghost catcher's tasks.

He was indeed quite lazy.

At the same time, Zhou Ze wondered if this meant that if he completed the remaining ninety-two percent, making it a hundred percent, his "Temporary Ghost Catcher" status could become permanent?

From a contract worker to someone with a permanent position?

Zhou Ze hadn't paid much attention to this before. He even looked down on those who wholeheartedly sought to enter the system in his previous life. Some of his classmates spent hundreds of thousands to get in, and then earned two to three thousand a month, yet still felt superior and complacent, believing that other classmates who were still striving for careers outside or working hard in Beijing, Shanghai, and Guangzhou were just laborers.

But now, Zhou Ze had a profound and urgent desire to remove the word "temporary" and enter the Underworld system!

This meant a sense of security, meaning he could sleep soundly tonight without worrying about not seeing tomorrow's sun.

Perhaps, his former classmates who were like that were also seeking this sense of security. After all, among all professions, nothing was more stable than an iron rice bowl.

Zhou Ze wanted to turn to the next page, but found that the following pages were stuck together, no matter how he tried to separate them.

Perhaps,

Because of his current rank, he was simply not qualified to view the information on the later pages?

Putting away the ID, Zhou Ze stretched.

Wang Ke was still in the adjacent bedroom. Zheng Pingping had already woken up and was slowly regaining consciousness. Wang Ke was very excited and thrilled. As a seasoned psychologist, he could keenly detect that Zheng Pingping's condition was rapidly improving!

He didn't know what caused it, but he instinctively made "diligent efforts."

Zhou Ze walked out of the studio, lit another cigarette, and thought about how he would strive harder after returning to the bookstore. In the future, when he had nothing to do, he would set up a stall with incense and candles and some cold food outside the bookstore to attract ghosts.

Then, regardless of anything, he would send them all to Hell for reincarnation.

For example, the mother who wanted to stay with her son until he finished his college entrance exams before going to Hell last time—Zhou Ze wouldn't just wave her away next time he encountered her.

You could say this might be a bit heartless, but the primitive accumulation of capital was inherently bloody.

To become a permanent employee as soon as possible,

Zhou Ze would truly do whatever he wanted.

Just then, Zhou Ze saw Wang Ke's wife and the young butler standing at the staircase entrance, seemingly talking about something. Zhou Ze didn't get too close, but he caught words like "when to get her hair done again."

And frankly, looking at Wang Ke's wife's slightly shy, yet feigned calm expression, everything was self-evident.

Modern butlers were different from before. This was a new profession, and the income was quite high. Generally, only high-end residential areas like this would have modern butler service, considered high-level service personnel, whose prestige was no less than that of "flight attendants" in people's eyes a decade ago.

Of course, Zhou Ze wouldn't run over and shout, condemning "adulterers." Wang Ke probably guessed something, but since he, the party involved, deliberately didn't expose it, Zhou Ze, an outsider, had no reason to help.

However, as a childhood friend, Zhou Ze would naturally feel uncomfortable if Wang Ke was cheated on.

Mr. Zheng was standing on the balcony, smoking a cigar. His expression was slightly relaxed because Wang Ke had just told him that his daughter's condition had greatly improved.

"Mr. Xu, where do you work?" Mr. Zheng finally had the mind to chat with Zhou Ze.

"I run a bookshop."

Zhou Ze replied.

There was no other way. Faced with such a wealthy businessman, he could only pretend to be refined.

"Oh, very good, very good. I'll visit if I get the chance," Mr. Zheng said politely.

Zhou Ze then took the opportunity to ask, "Did Miss Zheng just lose control of her bladder and bowels? I'm not very talented, but I'm skilled in some formulas for regulating mind and body and strengthening foundations."

Mr. Zheng's face suddenly darkened upon hearing this. As a wealthy businessman, he certainly wouldn't lack good traditional Chinese doctors. He was angry that Zhou Ze dared to say his daughter had lost control of her bladder and bowels right in front of him!

She had clearly only wet herself once,

And there was no poop!

"Thank you for your kindness, sir. My daughter is just a bit mentally fatigued; there's nothing wrong with her body."

One doesn't hit a smiling person. Since Zhou Ze offered to help with a formula, Mr. Zheng naturally couldn't get angry at Zhou Ze.

Zhou Ze's face showed a very obvious look of surprise, saying:

"She didn't? But the butler was just talking to someone about it, saying Miss's crotch was full of..."

At this point,

Zhou Ze realized that saying this seemed impolite and inappropriate, so he immediately chuckled, saying:

"It's good that Miss is fine, it's good that she's fine."

title: 第六十六章 愛上一匹野馬
content:
Mr. Zheng kept the two for dinner, but Zhou Ze refused, and Wang Ke also refused, both acting as if they were deep in功与名 [1] . Zhou Ze didn’t expose him; he knew his childhood friend needed this favor from the investor, so he let it be.

On the way back, Zhou Ze didn't see the young butler. However, Zhou Ze knew that after he "accidentally" let something slip, Mr. Zheng had given a few words to his two followers, and then the butler disappeared.

It was still Wang Ke’s wife driving, looking a bit distracted, checking her phone occasionally.

Wang Ke himself was immersed in the emotional aftershocks of "surviving a disaster." With Miss Zheng’s condition rapidly improving, his pressure had eased.

Zhou Ze didn’t tell Wang Ke about the butler or how he had deliberately badmouthed him in front of Mr. Zheng. It was just a casual act of boredom, and he wouldn’t seek any credit for it.

The crucial issue was that Zhou Ze didn't know which way Wang Ke's emotional inclinations leaned. Although they were childhood friends, many years had passed, and everyone had their own experiences and, naturally, their own changes.

What if he told him, and Wang Ke thought:

"I treat you like a brother, but you want to take off the green hat [2] from my head!"

Damn it,

Presumptuous,

Unbearable!

What then?

Looking at Wang Ke's wife, who was driving, also his sister-in-law, Zhou Ze slightly pursed his lips.

Indeed,

A wife's heart is like a knife.

His phone rang, and Zhou Ze answered. It was his sister-in-law.

"Hello."

"Hello, Xu Le, my sister has started work," his sister-in-law said.

"Oh," Zhou Ze responded unhurriedly.

"She hasn't been feeling well recently. Go see her and make sure she doesn't overwork herself," his sister-in-law added.

"Oh."

"I say, what's wrong with you? I, the esteemed miss, am giving you a heads-up, and you don't even thank me, let alone show any excitement.

Oh, oh, oh, 'oh' your head!

I'm telling you, you still haven't explained that Maserati thing!"

Zhou Ze shook his head. His sister-in-law was truly trying to help him. The reason was simple: recently, when she went out to have fun, her excuses and reasons were always that she was studying at his bookstore.

Her elder sister was busy with work and had no time, and her brother-in-law, though a good-for-nothing, was at least a university student and could still help with her studies.

A very good reason, and a very good excuse.

Even the Lin family parents, who usually couldn't stand Xu Le, tacitly approved of their youngest daughter going to the bookstore for tutoring.

Sometimes Zhou Ze couldn't help but want to go back to the Lin family and point at the Lin family parents' noses, telling them that not to mention a university graduate,

Even if you ask second or third-year university students to tutor high school students, how many do you think can actually do it?

But his sister-in-law still had some conscience. This silly girl, judging from recent events, was not bad, aside from being a bit foolish.

See, she even specifically gave him a heads-up.

"Alright, thank you," Zhou Ze said perfunctorily.

"Hmph, oh, I'm coming to your place to read tonight too," his sister-in-law added.

After hanging up the phone, Zhou Ze stretched, only to unexpectedly find that the car was just passing the West Gate of People's Hospital.

What a coincidence,

He hadn't planned on going.

Of course, Zhou Ze didn't ask Wang Ke's wife to stop the car. He just pretended he hadn't seen it and wouldn't go out of his way to make it a coincidence.

Dr. Lin had started work, which meant she had gotten through some of it. But Zhou Ze had just received his certificate and was preparing to make a big push to get promoted quickly, so he didn't have the energy to think about anything else for the time being.

However, Wang Ke's wife voluntarily turned the car into the hospital.

"My father-in-law was recently hospitalized. I'm just stopping by to see him. We'll be quick," Wang Ke said apologetically to Zhou Ze.

"Never mind, I'll go first."

Zhou Ze pushed open the car door and got out.

Wang Ke also got out, and Wang Ke's wife drove the car into the hospital's underground parking lot.

"Are you taking a taxi back yourself?" Wang Ke asked.

Zhou Ze nodded.

"Alright, brother, take care." Wang Ke reached out and patted Zhou Ze on the shoulder. "I won't actively seek you out again, but if you need anything, you can come to me."

"You're too kind," Zhou Ze said.

After Wang Ke finished speaking, he looked at Zhou Ze earnestly twice more, then turned and walked towards the inpatient building.

Zhou Ze silently lit a cigarette. People do change, indeed.

Wang Ke was a few years older than him and had graduated and entered society earlier. His former "Brother Wang," "Brother Erdan," now seemed a bit unfamiliar to Zhou Ze.

At wit's end, not hesitating to consult ghosts and gods,

Sigh.

Zhou Ze exhaled a smoke ring, thought for a moment, and then still walked into the emergency building ahead.

He could have chosen not to come if he hadn't received his sister-in-law's heads-up.

He could have pretended not to see the hospital when the car passed by.

But now that he was already at the hospital, it would be a bit unreasonable not to go see his wife.

Before, he had an obsession: she wouldn't sleep with him.

Didn't that obsession disappear now?

No, it seemed that after that obsession was gone, some strange new problem appeared.

"You can't get it up again, what's the point of thinking so much, get lost!"

A woman's icy voice came from behind Zhou Ze.

Zhou Ze took a deep breath, turned around, his fingernails feeling an urge to grow out.

"Hey, wife, didn't the doctor say I'm fine? Maybe it's because you're not sexy enough, and not active enough in bed, you're not getting my G-spot."

"Get lost, I'm not willing to serve you. You can't handle things in bed yourself and you want my help? Are you even a man?"

The woman and man had probably just come out of the urology department and were arguing.

Zhou Ze's expression was a bit bitter.

At this moment,

It was as if that diligent crow had reappeared, flying overhead,

Emitting "caw... caw... caw..." sounds.

On the ground, a fallen leaf also appeared, blown by the wind, flipping over Zhou Ze's feet.

Zhou Ze didn't want to go to the emergency building anymore.

He felt that he should give Dr. Lin more time to think, accept, and adapt, and shouldn't stimulate her at this moment.

Yes,

He should think more for her, give her some time and space; he shouldn't pressure her.

Zhou Ze nodded, feeling he had convinced himself, and prepared to leave.

But just then, an ambulance drove into the hospital, and Zhou Ze saw several doctors and nurses running out of the emergency building, among them a familiar figure.

Dr. Lin also saw Zhou Ze and froze for a moment. Zhou Ze gave her a slight smile, walked over, and said gently:

"I was just about to come up and see you."

Dr. Lin suddenly clutched her lower abdomen and sat down on the steps.

"What's wrong? Are you uncomfortable?" Zhou Ze asked.

Dr. Lin shook her head and said, "It's nothing."

"What exactly is wrong with your body?" Zhou Ze asked carefully. He remembered his sister-in-law telling him that Dr. Lin hadn't been feeling well these past few days.

"Woman's stuff," Dr. Lin said, lowering her head.

The ice queen, at this moment, also showed a hint of shyness.

Her period?

Zhou Ze felt a surge of speechlessness. Perhaps, for a silly girl like his sister-in-law, menstruation was the most painful thing.

"Dr. Lin, the patient's condition is a bit serious. She's a pregnant woman."

A young male doctor hurried over, pushing a stretcher. He seemed a bit nervous, and then when he looked at Zhou Ze, his expression changed, and he immediately said:

"You're here too?"

The last time Zhou Ze entered the hospital for a rescue operation and confessed to Dr. Lin, this was the intern who had been at a loss that day.

"Go in first, I'll take a look."

Dr. Lin forced herself to stand up, preparing to check the patient's condition.

Zhou Ze could only follow her inside.

Once inside the emergency building, the young girl accompanying the pregnant woman kept asking the male intern questions. The intern seemed overwhelmed and very flustered.

"Can you even treat people? Hurry up! Don't you see how much my sister is hurting? What about the baby? My brother is thirty, and it's so hard for him to finally have this child, do you know how hard it is?!"

"I... you wait... let me check again..." The male intern started to get nervous, even dropping his notepad.

"What 'you this,' 'you that'? Hey, don't you have any other doctors here? You can't just disregard human life like this!" the young woman continued to shout.

"I'll go take a look." Dr. Lin, who was behind, quickened her steps to check the situation, but after a few steps, she winced in pain again.

"Your problem is a bit serious," Zhou Ze said. "Irregular diet recently has made your body worse."

Dr. Lin said nothing but still walked towards the patient.

"Never mind, I'll take a look." Zhou Ze reached out and patted Dr. Lin on the waist.

"You..." Dr. Lin felt this was a bit inappropriate.

"You don't trust my medical skills?" Zhou Ze smiled. "You were trained by me."

It's just that back then, I didn't realize you could become so beautiful. My blindness was my fault.

Zhou Ze actively walked to the patient, preparing to examine her.

The young woman immediately shouted, "Who are you?! Hey, what are you doing?!"

Zhou Ze was not wearing a white coat.

"Doctor, please take a look." The intern seemed to have found a savior.

Zhou Ze glanced at the young woman and said, "I'm off duty. If you don't want me to check, I'll go home."

The young woman immediately smiled apologetically and said, "I'm sorry, I was wrong. Please, quickly check my sister. She's not due yet."

Zhou Ze took a pair of gloves from the intern, then examined the patient and asked:

"How far along are you?"

"28 weeks," the young girl answered for her sister.

The intern looked at Zhou Ze, assisting him.

"Premature rupture of membranes, fully dilated cervix, severe amniotic fluid pollution," Zhou Ze said as he took off his gloves.

"This... this is going to... going to..." The young girl was immediately frightened.

"Premature birth," Zhou Ze uttered these two words, then told the intern, "Notify obstetrics and gynecology to prepare for surgery."

"Okay." The intern immediately pulled out his phone and made a call.

Zhou Ze shook his head somewhat helplessly. This guy was lucky he wasn't assigned to him for his internship, otherwise, given his old temper with Dr. Lin, he might have verbally abused this guy into changing professions. He was really too stupid.

"Premature birth?" The young girl was immediately stunned upon hearing this, then grabbed Zhou Ze's arm and said, "Doctor, please save my sister, save the baby in her belly. It's not easy for my brother to have this child, it's really not easy."

Zhou Ze was unmoved. As a doctor, he had seen too many such cases. If he cried every time, doctors would probably become dried husks of people.

"Then go ask your brother what happened. It's hard enough to have a child, how did it get to this point?"

"Doctor, what exactly happened?" The young woman was a bit confused.

"This is caused by unhygienic and overly vigorous sexual activity during pregnancy, with a large amount of internal ejaculation."

Zhou Ze looked at the woman on the bed and asked:

"When a man gets carried away, he's like an animal, but couldn't you have persuaded him for the sake of the child in your belly?"

She was almost 30 weeks pregnant, and they couldn't endure even this much?

The pregnant woman on the bed didn't speak, seeming very nervous and scared.

But the young girl who accompanied her immediately exploded, shouting:

"That's impossible! My brother went to Beijing to work for the baby's milk money before the New Year. He hasn't been back for half a year!"

"I fell in love with a wild horse, but my home has no grassland..."

The male intern's phone rang. He immediately answered and then told Zhou Ze:

"Obstetrics and gynecology said the operating room is ready."

***
[1] 功与名 (gōng yǔ míng): "功" (gōng) refers to merit or achievement, while "名" (míng) refers to fame or reputation. The phrase "深藏功与名" (shēn cáng gōng yǔ míng) means to "deeply hide one's achievements and fame," indicating that someone does good deeds without seeking recognition or praise.
[2] 绿帽子 (lǜ màozi): A "green hat" is a Chinese idiom meaning a cuckold. Wearing a green hat implies that one's spouse has been unfaithful.

title: 第六十七章 府君饒命！
content:
"Sent to Obstetrics and Gynecology."

Zhou Ze sat down beside Doctor Lin, looking at her still somewhat distressed face, and said, "You should rest more, otherwise you're being irresponsible."

"I can manage," Doctor Lin shook her head, still a bit stubborn.

"What I mean is, with your current physical condition, you're being irresponsible to your patients."

"............" Doctor Lin.

"Hehe," Zhou Ze licked his lips and apologized, "Sorry, I unconsciously reverted to my old self."

"It's fine," Doctor Lin said softly.

"Go back and rest. Come back to work when your body is well. A doctor's job is indeed important, but it's not like society will stop functioning if one doctor is temporarily absent."

Doctor Lin nodded.

Just then, Zhou Ze's phone rang. He checked the caller ID; it was Xu Qinglang.

He stood up and went to the hallway outside to answer the call. "Hello, what's up?"

"Your shop's doing good business today, come back and take a look," Xu Qinglang said with a yawn.

"Good business?" Zhou Ze was quite happy. He had just gotten his license, and business was already coming to him?

"Okay, I'll be right back."

Zhou Ze decided that this time, no matter how many stories of "Dou E's injustice" the departed souls in the bookstore told, he would ruthlessly send them to hell.

They were departed souls;
sending them to hell was the proper course, and being iron-fisted about it, he felt no psychological burden.

"You can go back if you have something to do," Doctor Lin pointed to her office. "I'll go back by myself later."

Zhou Ze nodded and said no more. Nothing was more important now than him getting officially employed as soon as possible. As for his relationship with Doctor Lin, they could take it slow.

The elevator in the emergency building was still packed, even at night. Zhou Ze simply chose to take the stairs down. When he reached the third floor, Zhou Ze suddenly stopped.

For some reason, he felt as if someone was following him.

Could it be that Doctor Lin wanted to look at him a few more times but was too embarrassed, so she was secretly following him?

Alright, while there was such a possibility, Zhou Ze wasn't so narcissistic as to immediately believe it. He quickly walked down another floor, then abruptly turned back at the corner.

"Whoosh............"

A gust of wind swept down from above.

Zhou Ze suddenly looked up and started running upstairs, but still found nothing.

Finding nothing meant there was definitely something strange.

Zhou Ze bent down, his black fingernail extending, and lightly tapped the tile floor.

The next moment, a black footprint appeared on the tile floor. Zhou Ze silently clenched his index finger into a fist and hid it, then slowly stood up and followed the direction of the constantly appearing black footprints below.

From his fingernail, an invisible mist continuously emanated, tracking the imprints below.

Because of its unique nature, hospitals are rarely absolutely clean, but it wasn't late at night yet, and for something unclean to be walking around so openly was very abnormal.

Following the imprints, Zhou Ze arrived at the fourth floor. The footprints led out and then turned into a patient room.

There were patients in the room. Given the current extreme shortage of medical resources, an empty patient room was a rare sight. For instance, right now, some patients could only temporarily rest or receive IV drips on makeshift beds in the hallway.

Zhou Ze pushed open the patient room door.

Inside, there were three beds.

Two elderly women lay on the beds on either side, and a young woman lay in the middle. Next to each bed was a caregiver.

When Zhou Ze walked in, everyone in the room except one sleeping old woman looked at him.

"Hello, excuse me, did anyone come in just now?"

Zhou Ze asked directly.

"No," a caregiver auntie replied.

The others all shook their heads.

Zhou Ze nodded, indicating he understood, then turned and left the room.

At this point, Zhou Ze intended to leave.

You couldn't blame Zhou Ze for being insensitive and not catching a ghost when he encountered one. Xu Qinglang had just called and said his shop was "doing good business," and Zhou Ze worried that if he returned late, all the customers would be gone, resulting in a big loss.

As for the unclean thing running outside, if he encountered it and could deal with it, he would. But if it was troublesome or wanted to play hide-and-seek, Zhou Ze really wasn't willing to spend too much energy on it.

He was a ghost messenger, with the prefix "temporary" before it, not a Taoist master.

However, as Zhou Ze grabbed the doorknob to close the door, his fingernail accidentally brushed against it.

In an instant, Zhou Ze felt a sensation like static electricity. Immediately after, the lights in the room went out, then came back on.

The three beds in the room instantly emptied, and the patients along with their caregivers disappeared.

Zhou Ze abruptly took two steps back. Only then did he see that the sign on the door of the room he was facing said "Storage Room." This wasn't a patient room!

"Whoosh............"

Another gust of wind blew, very fast, as if realizing its illusion had failed and intending to flee in a panic.

Zhou Ze reached out and grabbed something cold and fleshy, but then there was a crisp snap, and the thing slipped from his grasp.

The wind dispersed.

Zhou Ze looked at his palm. There was a clump of black hair, very long and curly, like the hair from another dense area he saw every day when he showered, besides the hair on his head.

Seemingly out of professional habit, Zhou Ze brought his hand to his nose and sniffed.

A strong, fishy, oceanic smell came over,
absolutely nauseating,
like a salted fish left in a stuffy warehouse for a month.

"Hiss..."

Zhou Ze suppressed the urge to gag, then squatted down again, tapping the tile with his fingernail. Another clear string of black footprints appeared.

He clapped his hands, twisted his neck, and then followed the footprints again.

The nature of the situation had changed again. If the other party was merely like the old woman lingering in the morgue of the affiliated hospital due to inheritance issues, Zhou Ze wouldn't have pursued relentlessly. After all, there were too many such spirits clinging to the human world due to past attachments, and they generally didn't have the intention to do evil or the ability to cause destruction.

But the one he had just encountered actively followed him, was able to create an extremely realistic illusion that almost fooled him, and judging by the body hair he pulled from it, the thing had a physical form.

This meant that the other party already possessed the ability to cause trouble, and it was in the hospital where his wife worked. Zhou Ze now found it difficult to convince himself to stand by idly.

Ultimately,
he was just being nosy!
Zhou Ze had read many novels in the bookstore in recent months, and he most disliked protagonists who were "holy mothers," feeling no connection to them at all. But when it came to himself, he found he still couldn't completely let go.

Of course, there was another extremely important reason: he had just become a ghost messenger. According to the information he gathered from his conversations with the little loli, if something unclean caused trouble in a ghost messenger's territory, that ghost messenger would also suffer repercussions.

The footprints went upstairs. Zhou Ze followed them all the way to the eighth floor, which was the operating room floor. After going up the stairs, Zhou Ze found his target without much effort.

A figure in a white lab coat was leaning against the wall of the operating room, pressing its ear to the wall while moving one hand below, doing something many otaku do at home.

When Zhou Ze approached, the figure didn't turn around, but Zhou Ze saw its body tremble slightly, speeding up the friction in its hand. It seemed Zhou Ze's arrival increased some kind of pleasure for it.

"You are a ghost messenger. I don't wish to offend you, but why do you pursue me relentlessly? We can perfectly well mind our own business."

The other party's voice was hoarse, like an old man speaking, but the tone was strange, often pronouncing several syllables very quickly.

"What are you doing?" Zhou Ze pointed at it.

"I'm waiting for my woman to come out," the other party replied. "My lord, please go back. It's not good for either of us to fall out. I can assure you, I will not do anything heinous, nor will I make things difficult for you."

"Heaven is above, and I dare not act recklessly."

"Your woman? Who are you waiting for?" Zhou Ze asked.

Could it be another tale of human-ghost love?

But just then, across the corridor from the operating room, the young girl who had accompanied his sister-in-law earlier ran out with various tickets and receipts. She was probably going to pay the fees.

Inside,
lay the pregnant woman who was about to miscarry!

"You're not her husband," Zhou Ze rebuked.

"A woman I fancy is my woman. Moreover, she and I have a fateful connection to continue. Even Heaven has silently approved this," the other party's tone was very impatient.

Zhou Ze was the one who first examined the pregnant woman. He had initially thought he had stumbled upon another cheating incident. He had even lamented that he himself had encountered similar problems,
his best friend was already experiencing such a problem,
and now even when he entered a hospital to see a patient, he encountered such a problem.
He seemed to encounter such "green-colored" situations wherever he went lately,
he even had the urge to rename his bookstore "Green Bookstore,"
to echo the nation's call for environmental protection.

However, fortunately, this time it was no longer just a simple dramatic "green-colored" situation, but it seemed more troublesome than just that.

"One corpse, two lives," Zhou Ze reminded, taking two steps forward at the same time. "If her surgery isn't successful now, it'll be one corpse, two lives. And you still say you're not doing anything heinous."

"You, a mere ghost messenger, have you grown brazen!"

The other party seemed unable to contain its anger.

It suddenly turned around.

It was wearing a doctor's white coat. Its back previously revealed nothing, but when it turned to face him, its terrifying and ferocious image immediately became clear.

This was a monkey,
a monkey capable of standing in human form.
Most of its body was incredibly rotten, and even its skull was missing, empty inside. But its lower part, like a bullwhip, swung back and forth, appearing quite disgusting.

"You are nothing but a petty ghost messenger at the lowest level of the underworld, do not push your luck!"

"And what are you, exactly?" Zhou Ze retorted, then took a few more steps forward.

"Squeak, squeak, squeak!"

The monkey bared its teeth and growled. Then, its black tail behind it suddenly stood erect and plunged violently into the tiles.

The next moment,
around where Zhou Ze stood, on the ceiling, tiles, and walls, black holes appeared,
and from these small holes, long tails emerged, swarming towards Zhou Ze.

These tails carried an extremely foul, fishy smell, and sticky liquid dripped from them. For Zhou Ze, who always had a cleanliness fetish, he now felt as if he were standing in the most pungent area of a seafood market.

Most importantly,
this scene,
he had seen it many times in movies before.

Immediately,
Zhou Ze spread his hands, his black fingernails fully grown. In the depths of his eyes, a black halo also circulated.

To be honest, besides the time he hit Bai Yingying, he had never truly been in a proper fight.

To Zhou Ze's surprise,
the booklet in his pocket began to feel slightly warm at this moment, as if it, too, was somewhat eager.

A little excited,
and a little expectant,
he had just gotten his license, like someone who had just obtained a driver's license always wanted to try driving.
Zhou Ze really wanted to fight.

However, a somewhat unexpected scene unfolded before Zhou Ze. As his certificate began to feel slightly warm,
the monkey, which had just been so arrogant and disdainful of him as merely a petty ghost messenger of the underworld, suddenly knelt down, continuously kowtowing to him, slamming its head against the ground, and shouting,
"Mercy, Lord! Mercy, Lord! This beast knows its wrongdoings, this beast knows its wrongdoings!"

For a moment,
Zhou Ze, who had been full of enthusiasm, was left hanging in the air, neither up nor down.
It was like a man who had done all the foreplay, sprayed on the delay spray,
taken Viagra, put on a chocolate-flavored "blue elf" condom, started a porno, mixed the red wine,
only to pull back the covers and discover the beauty in bed was actually Xu Qinglang!

title: 第六十八章 猴言亂語
content:
"Lord Prefect?"

This was certainly not a title for him. Zhou Ze's identification clearly showed his name in the first field and "Temporary Ghost Messenger" in the second.

Moreover, it couldn't be a respectful alternative, like how common folk in the Republican era called soldiers "Lao Zong." If a temporary Ghost Messenger could be called "Lord Prefect," wouldn't such a high honor be too common and worthless in hell?

So,

the problem must lie with the small booklet he had just acquired.

This identification once had an owner. Even though it had been "refreshed" because Zhou Ze now had it, there must still be remnants of the previous owner's information on it.

All in all,

he had found the relic of a very remarkable individual, and he had done so with effortless ease.

Of course, at this moment, Zhou Ze had no time to gloat or indulge in a glass of red wine to celebrate. Instead, he felt a slight pang of disappointment, as he hadn't gotten to fight this uglified Monkey King.

But since his opponent had conceded, Zhou Ze wasn't so perverse as to squat down and encourage his opponent to quickly regain confidence in life and stand up and hit him, hit him,

hit him!

Since this was a beautiful misunderstanding, then let the misunderstanding continue.

Zhou Ze silently walked towards the monkey, one hand clasped behind his back, subconsciously imitating the little loli's cool pose, to prolong the opponent's misunderstanding.

He reached the monkey, which was still kowtowing repeatedly. Its skull must have been opened, and it was hollow inside. In fact, besides that "ox whip" which was in perfect condition, the rest of its body was decayed and damaged.

Zhou Ze extended one hand, pressing his fingernail onto the monkey's brow.

"Give me your soul blood."

Zhou Ze said blandly.

"As Lord Prefect commands."

The monkey looked terrified and was utterly convinced. At its brow, a black earthworm emerged.

Zhou Ze used his fingernail to pinch the earthworm and began pulling it out. The earthworm grew longer and thicker.

Xu Qinglang had once suggested that Zhou Ze take Bai Yingying's soul blood, which would mean controlling Bai Yingying's life. Zhou Ze now intended to use the same method to completely control this monkey while it was disoriented.

However, this monkey's soul blood was really thick, which indirectly showed how formidable this monkey was.

Why had this monkey suddenly appeared in the city?

Just then, the soul blood suddenly got stuck. Zhou Ze pulled hard, but it wouldn't budge.

And the monkey, which had been respectful, suddenly froze, its eyes becoming incredibly clear!

The high and mighty Lord Prefect wanted to extract its soul blood—this was its honor, an unresisted decree. But why was the high and mighty Lord Prefect having such difficulty extracting its soul blood?

Suddenly, the monkey's mouth split open, emitting a piercing shriek, and its claw directly struck Zhou Ze.

Zhou Ze felt as if he had been hit by a large truck, but as he was flung backward, his fingernail instantly exerted force, directly snapping the monkey's soul blood.

"Crash..."

Zhou Ze shattered the glass behind him, landing amidst the shards. He looked up, his chest heaving, blood spilling from the corner of his mouth, and his entire body was in excruciating pain.

"Damn it, you're not the Lord Prefect!

You scoundrel, how dare you impersonate the Lord Prefect!"

The monkey went berserk. Although its soul blood hadn't been fully extracted by Zhou Ze, because it had been snapped by him, even if it didn't immediately cause death, it was enough to destroy its foundation for cultivation.

Zhou Ze struggled to his feet, his body covered in cuts from the glass shards, looking very disheveled.

However, the monkey at this moment was like a mad beast, directly pouncing on Zhou Ze.

"Thud!"

The man and monkey collided, though this time the monkey's force was much weaker than before. They tangled together, rolling several times on the ground.

"This is my destiny, and my karma. The Heavenly Dao allows it; debts must be paid, it's only right!

You, a mere Ghost Messenger, why do you interfere? Do you truly believe yourself to be one of the Ten Kings of Hell?"

Zhou Ze didn't reply. Instead, he plunged his fingernail deep into the monkey's body. The pus within the monkey's body continuously evaporated, emitting an odor that even a gas mask would likely be useless against.

Finally, after a round of grappling, the monkey's body slumped, losing all strength, and fell to one side. Zhou Ze staggered to his feet, his fingernails largely corroded away.

He was a person who took great care of his fingernails. Even in his previous life, besides operating surgical tools, he often trimmed his nails. Not to mention in this life, his fingernails were even more important to him, so he naturally cherished them more.

But at the moment, this was not the time to dwell on such things. Zhou Ze felt a hint of lingering fear. If his identification hadn't deceived the opponent, allowing him to gain the upper hand and snap the opponent's soul blood, he might have been the one lying on the ground after this confrontation.

This wasn't a ghost,

this was a demon.

Zhou Ze cursed himself many times in his mind,

why had he followed it, almost getting himself killed?

Humans are such complex creatures; they can be driven by a momentary sense of justice and what they perceive as conscience to do things without considering the consequences, but then they often regret it,

feeling like an idiot.

Zhou Ze felt that next time he encountered such a situation, he should call the police, let them handle it, and then he could leave with a clear conscience.

Madam White had stayed in Tongcheng for two hundred years, and the little loli had just turned a blind eye, hadn't she?

Shaking his head, he cast away the jumbled thoughts in his mind. Zhou Ze looked at the monkey beside him.

The monkey's mouth was open, its eyes began to cloud over, and its body started to shrivel, like a leaking balloon. But it wasn't dead yet, because it could still speak.

"I cultivated for three Jiazi cycles, obtained a fortuitous encounter, performed good deeds, became a spirit, and glimpsed the Great Dao... As a different kind of being, achieving enlightenment in the human world was truly difficult."

It seemed everyone liked to recount their past before dying, making their life sound incredibly impressive and tough. The monkey's mindset was actually not much different from a human's.

"You've cultivated for so many years, yet you couldn't control that thing between your legs." Zhou Ze spat out a mouthful of blood, his teeth filled with bloodstains.

"One Jiazi cycle, one physical body; one Jiazi cycle, one reincarnation." The monkey's voice began to weaken, but it still carried immense resonance.

"Every Jiazi cycle, I reformed my physical body and started cultivating anew, from scratch. In the wilderness, I rescued lost travelers, gathered and delivered medicinal herbs to the villagers at the foot of the mountain, and drove away nearby mountain monsters and ghosts.

Though I had no temple, I performed the duties of a mountain god, protecting the people of that mountain region generation after generation. Even now, in that small town, there is still a stone statue of me, and stories of the divine monkey helping people are still passed down."

Zhou Ze wiped his fingernails on his clothes, looking at his damaged nails with great regret. Of course, he only showed a cold smile at the monkey's words.

A divine monkey?

A mountain god protecting the villagers?

Helping others?

You helped others a bit too much, didn't you? When the husband went out to work, you even went to comfort his lonely wife?

Moreover, recalling how this guy was pleasuring himself against the wall when he went upstairs, it was really hard to associate it with a divine monkey.

"Don't put on a show for yourself, just picking the good parts to say." Zhou Ze raised his hand again, preparing to put an end to this monkey.

"It was them, during my fourth cycle of cultivation and reincarnation, who caught my newly reincarnated body. At that time, I was just a small monkey. Her husband was a logger in the forest, he fell and injured himself in a canyon. It was I who brought him fruits and dew, it was I who led his fellow workers to rescue him.

But when he was rescued, he bound me with the logging rope and said to his fellow workers:

'Great calamities survived surely bring great blessings. I heard monkey brains are very good; take them and give them to his wife to taste, it has miraculous effects on infertility!'"

The last part, the monkey spoke in classical Chinese, which showed its fury and also that it was at its last gasp, its consciousness gradually becoming hazy, instinctively speaking in its most accustomed way.

"They opened my head, took my marrow, cut my flesh, and shared it among themselves to eat, saying it was a great tonic!"

As the monkey spoke, its body, which had shrunk to the size of an ordinary monkey, began to tremble. This was a biting, deep-seated anger, resentment that went to the bone!

Cultivating for three Jiazi cycles, accumulating good deeds, protecting a region, yet on the eve of its great achievement, it was utterly destroyed, not by its own enemies, but by the very people it saved.

For anyone, this would be an overwhelming hatred.

"My physical body is destroyed, my Great Dao has collapsed, yet the resentment in my heart is unquelled!

The cause of that day, the fruit of today!

I am already dead and gone, willing to enter reincarnation and be reborn in the animal realm, but my resentment is unresolved, my soul cannot enter hell. I must descend the mountain to seek revenge, settle the karma, and only then can I be completely liberated."

"Is that why you assaulted his wife?" Zhou Ze asked.

"You are human, I am beast. For humans to consume beasts is only right!

But for beasts to repay humans with resentment is intolerable by the Heavenly Dao, is it not?"

Zhou Ze hesitated for a moment, then nodded, "It is."

He was unwilling to deny it, and didn't want to deny it.

Of course, eating monkey brains was illegal and wrong, but from Zhou Ze's personal emotional perspective, he still couldn't accept this monkey coming down the mountain for revenge, almost causing a double death.

For example, when you see people eating braised pork in a restaurant, you might think it tastes delicious.

But if you saw a group of pigs gnawing on human flesh in a restaurant, as a human, what would you think?

It's a very selfish stance, a very distorted perspective, but the principle is the same: different positions lead to different viewpoints.

Moreover, Zhou Ze felt that no matter what, the child in the pregnant woman's womb was innocent.

"You must be in great pain. I'll help you find release, then we'll see if I can send your soul to hell."

"Thank..." The monkey spoke its last word.

Zhou Ze's fingernail pierced the monkey's body again,

the monkey's body trembled,

its body completely lost all life.

But Zhou Ze searched and waited for a long time, yet found no trace of the monkey's departed soul.

This likely meant that the monkey's soul had been scattered, because its revenge was incomplete, and so its soul could not enter hell.

Standing up, Zhou Ze noticed a faint layer of black mist dissipating around him, like a barrier that had prevented the events here from being perceived by the outside world. Otherwise, the commotion of his fight with the monkey would have attracted many people by now.

Zhou Ze hoisted the monkey's corpse onto his shoulder, supported himself on the stairwell, and slowly walked down.

At the same time, he reminded himself in his mind to remember today's lesson: he was just a Ghost Messenger, managing ghosts. Mountain spirits and monsters were outside his scope of work.

Under the cover of night, Zhou Ze used a shovel left in the gardener's shed at a park outside the hospital to dig a pit for the monkey and buried its body.

Then, after simply tending to his own wounds, Zhou Ze, feeling exhausted, leaned against a large tree and sat down.

He took out his phone, whose screen was shattered but still functional, and sent a message to Doctor Lin:

"Were the pregnant woman and her child saved?"

After five minutes, Doctor Lin replied:

"They were saved, mother and child are safe."

Zhou Ze lit a cigarette, took a deep drag, and then felt a sharp pain in his lungs, coughing violently.

But soon, Doctor Lin sent another photo and a line of text:

"However, the child is deformed, with three legs."

Zhou Ze looked at the photo on his phone,

the small, premature infant lay quietly, breathing evenly,

but its lower body had three legs,

that extra leg,

looked like a monkey's... tail.

title: 第六十九章 莫欺少年窮！
content:
His body was somewhat weary, his heart a little lost. Zhou Ze tossed away his cigarette butt, slung his jacket over his shoulder, and followed the streetlights down a dimly lit path.

His silhouette stretched long behind him.

At the park exit stood an old man with white hair, impeccably dressed in a sharp suit, standing stiffly and meticulously, like an old white poplar steadfast in the desert.

Just one glance was enough to tell that the old man was someone who demanded extreme, even abnormal, perfection in his attire and posture.

Zhou Ze didn't look at him and continued on his way.

The air was filled with the sweet, cloying smell of watermelon slush. This scent made Zhou Ze uncomfortable, as the red flesh of watermelon reminded him of many unpleasant scenes.

"Sir, are you feeling very down?"

The old man deliberately matched Zhou Ze's pace, staying a respectful half-step behind.

"A little," Zhou Ze replied.

The two continued forward, keeping perfect step, creating a peculiar synchronicity.

"Sir, is it because of that monkey?

Or for that corrupted infant?" the old man asked.

Zhou Ze didn't answer, continuing to walk slowly forward.

He stopped at a traffic light intersection, waiting for the green light.

The old man also stopped.

"There's no right or wrong in this matter," Zhou Ze replied.

"No right or wrong?" the old man repeated, then asked, "But everything has two sides, so right and wrong can naturally be distinguished.

The monkey was a good monkey; it even did more good deeds than many so-called kind people.

You admit this, do you not, sir?"

"So, your point is?" Zhou Ze pulled out another cigarette, cupped his hand against the wind, and lit it. "I was wrong?"

"After several transformations and arduous cultivations, to have it all come to naught because of the very person you saved—if it were you, sir, how would you feel?" the old man asked.

"I'd be furious," Zhou Ze answered directly, without needing to think.

"And after the fury?"

"If given the chance, I'd kill their entire family," Zhou Ze exhaled a smoke ring.

"Sir, your logic is very sound," the old man remarked. "But you prevented it from seeking revenge, even after you learned the whole story and truth from its mouth, you still personally ended it."

"Yes."

"Do you think what you did was right?" the old man asked again.

"I said, there's no right or wrong in this matter," Zhou Ze flicked his ash. "Stepping back, even by ten thousand steps, the child is innocent."

"According to you, if the monkey had only chosen to take revenge on the husband, you would have understood;

You likely wouldn't have stopped it, would you, sir?"

Zhou Ze remained silent.

"But the husband killed the monkey and took its brain because he wanted his wife to eat it to cure her infertility," the old man reminded. "So, cause and effect, seemingly attributed to the monkey and the husband, actually originate from the monkey and that infant."

"Can cause and effect be calculated that way?" Zhou Ze asked.

"Is my calculation unreasonable?" the old man countered.

"According to your calculation, you could say that because a meteorite struck Earth, dinosaurs went extinct, which led to new species, then hominids, then humans and monkeys, and then this tragedy.

So, the cause and effect should be attributed to the meteorite."

"That's sophistry, sir," the old man's tone seemed to remain unchanged, very calm, as if he were purely discussing a problem with you.

"I am human," Zhou Ze pointed to his head. "From a human perspective, I don't think I can allow an anomaly to harm humans in a hospital."

"You are not human, you are a ghost," the old man reminded him again.

"This time, it's your turn to play sophist."

"Heh heh," the old man chuckled.

The light turned green.

Zhou Ze stepped forward, and the old man continued to follow.

A young man in tattered clothes,

An old man in precise attire,

The two cast only a single shadow on the ground.

"Ultimately, the child still had problems," the old man continued, speaking in a calm tone that made one want to stab him. "It seems at this moment, one could lament: The ways of Heaven are a cycle, and who can escape them?"

"I never believe that children in swaddling clothes should bear collateral responsibility for the wrongs committed by adults."

"Ancient laws included collective punishment, which means it had its reasons for existing," the old man said.

"It has been abolished now, which means its non-existence is better than its existence."

"Sir, you pity that child, but who pities that monkey?"

"You can go ask its ancestors on Mount Huaguo."

"So, ultimately, it's still a theory of species-ism above all else, merely a protective color over regional or racial discrimination."

"I have a piece of bread; this is my dinner for today," Zhou Ze spread out one hand, indicating he was holding a piece of bread.

"And then?"

"And then, as I was about to eat this bread, I suddenly remembered that in some impoverished regions of the Earth, people are still starving, emaciated from hunger.

So, I can't bear to eat this bread, content to starve with them, or even die of hunger with them."

"Sir, I think your sarcasm is not very appropriate," the old man shook his head. "Can you consider the monkey an animal? Its actions over three jiazi* have made it more human than most so-called people."

"Alright, then another example.

I have a luxury car, fine red wine, and caviar in front of me, and I remember that people on Earth are still starving. I can't bear to enjoy them, so I decide to starve with them, and die of hunger with them.

If you eat such good food, if you drive such a good car, people will point fingers and curse you, telling you that you should donate your money for enjoyment to the impoverished regions."

The old man stopped, as if deep in thought.

Zhou Ze didn't stop, continuing to walk forward.

Finally, the old man caught up.

"I'm still very curious why you stopped it."

"What do you think I should have done?"

"Pretend you didn't see it," the old man replied. "You are a ghost messenger, a guardian of the rules of the Underworld in the Human Realm. A referee is respected because of his neutrality; if he acts as both referee and player, the game collapses."

"I don't understand what you mean," Zhou Ze stopped and looked at the old man, this meticulously dressed old fellow he wished he could crumple his suit.

"The meaning is simple: the two examples you gave earlier simply meant you made the choice you wanted at that moment, and my questions just now were merely the chattering of an outsider."

"I thought you didn't understand."

"I understood. You are a good person," the old man repeated. "A good 'person'."

From a 'human' perspective, indeed.

"So, you deliberately came up to me just to define me?" Zhou Ze looked at the old man. His fingers were still burning with pain. "I didn't know trouble would come so quickly after picking up that thing."

Earlier, the little loli said he was a incandescent light in the night; now Zhou Ze felt he was an incendiary bomb in the night.

The old man shook his head and said, "I am not your trouble. In fact, I am a servant left by the Master, and you have just inherited the Master's identity token.

Because of this, my seal was lifted, I awoke, and then I found you. And, incidentally, observed you for a while."

"Picked up a good thing, and got an old man as a bonus?"

A smile appeared at the corner of Zhou Ze's mouth.

"Should I say:

'Thirty years east of the river, thirty years west of the river, don't bully a young man in poverty'?

And then exclaim 'How terrifying' for good measure?

That seems more fitting."

"I don't understand, sir," the old man said directly.

"You should read more," Zhou Ze reminded him.

"Alright," the old man nodded solemnly. "I've learned something."

Ahead, they encountered another red light, and the two stopped again.

"Sir, since you have inherited the Master's identity token, you have naturally become my new Master," the old man said, simultaneously bending at the waist and bowing to Zhou Ze.

Zhou Ze stood still, looking at the old man.

Today had been truly eventful.

He picked up a document, killed a monkey, and now an old man appeared, claiming him as his master.

Zhou Ze wasn't overjoyed; he just felt a bit troubled. He couldn't discern the intentions of this suddenly appearing old man.

"The Master once gave an instruction, for me to tell his successor," the old man spoke again. "Of course, this message is for you, and also for me, his servant.

"Speak."

"If his successor is a good person, then..."

"Pfft!"

The sound of a sharp object piercing flesh rang out.

Zhou Ze looked down in stunned surprise.

He saw the old man's hand directly pierce his chest.

So swift,

So sudden,

He didn't even have the slightest psychological preparation.

Slowly, Zhou Ze's feet left the ground. The old man raised his arm, and Zhou Ze was lifted with him.

Under the dim streetlights, Zhou Ze could clearly see his blood flowing down the old man's arm, staining half of his suit.

"The Master said, if his successor is a good person, then kill him and wait for the next one."

The old man continued to speak these words calmly.

He wasn't killing someone;

He was simply discarding trash,

Like a fastidious chef selecting his ingredients, if something wasn't quite right, he'd toss it and get a new one.

And Zhou Ze was this inexplicably discarded trash.

Blood flowed ceaselessly. Zhou Ze's broken fingernails elongated, but before Zhou Ze could make another move, the old man's hand, which had pierced through Zhou Ze's palm, suddenly exerted force.

Instantly,

Zhou Ze felt immense pain throughout his limbs and bones. Zhou Ze's body convulsed, completely unable to retaliate.

"I'm very sorry, sir. A minute ago, you might have thought today was your lucky day, because you acquired something you really wanted.

I wonder if you noticed the blurry white smudges under the 'Name' and 'Position' fields on the document.

You might have thought that hidden beneath the white smudges were the Master's name and position;

And indeed, that is true.

But not just those,

Also the names and positions of the eight successors before you."

The old man continued to speak calmly.

"Were they... they... all... good people?"

Zhou Ze opened his mouth, blood constantly spilling from the corners. He felt like a salted fish, hung on a branch,

Slowly, waiting to be air-dried.

"No, sir, you are the only good person among these nine," the old man replied.

"Then why... why... did they... also... die..."

"Because when I asked them if they were a good person, they all thought answering 'yes' seemed more advantageous."

The old man tilted his head slightly, showing a hint of helplessness.

"And then,

They all died."

---
* Jiazi (甲子): A traditional Chinese sixty-year cycle, used for reckoning years and days. Three jiazi would be 180 years.

title: 第七十章 我的心呢！
content:
Zhou Ze remembered clearly what death felt like; he had once been pushed into a crematorium’s incinerator and enjoyed the treatment of being burned to ash.

And beforehand, the crematorium staff had even used a steel hook to pierce his stomach to prevent it from bulging and exploding during cremation.

That feeling was very similar to his chest being pierced through now.

Pain?

Of course, it hurt.

But when the pain became too intense, you became numb instead, like undergoing surgery in a hospital after receiving a spinal anesthetic. Separated by the curtain blocking your view, you could probably only feel something rummaging around inside your belly.

Zhou Ze still wanted to resist, but his body was at this moment seized by a deathly spasm. Even his eyelids felt unusually heavy.

No matter how unwilling, no matter how much he resisted,

his eyelids,

still closed.

…

Slowly opening his eyes, Zhou Ze saw dim lights all around. In front of him was a long marble table, its chaotic patterns nonetheless exuding a sense of exquisite artistry.

Looking down, Zhou Ze found himself seated in an armchair, a Grand Tutor’s Chair, leaning back. Below his neck, he wore a white neck wrap, but it looked more like a bib, tied there to prevent food stains from dirtying his clothes.

In his two hands, he held a silver knife and fork,

and in front of him, on a pristine white plate, lay a piece of roasted meat, emitting faint wisps of steam, garnished with lemon and cauliflower.

"Sir, I’ve seared the cauliflower with a blowtorch; it will give it a grilled flavor. I hope you enjoy it."

The old man’s voice came from across the table. He was dressed similarly, cutting a steak and putting it into his mouth, chewing.

"What does this mean?"

Zhou Ze didn't rush to eat; he asked directly.

Didn’t they say they were going to kill him?

"There was a slight accident." The old man picked up the wine beside him and took a small sip.

"Whoosh!"

The old man placed one hand on the table and pushed a credential towards Zhou Ze.

"I didn’t expect the identity plate to be so damaged." The old man finished, then continued to cut a piece of meat and savor it.

"So?"

"So, I apologize, you can’t die now." The old man smiled slightly and said, "Sir, you truly are very lucky."

"You’re not killing me?"

"Yes, sir. Because the identity plate left by my master can no longer withstand another process of recognition and refresh; otherwise, it would directly shatter and become useless."

The old man shook his head, raised his wine glass, and toasted Zhou Ze,

"So, congratulations, sir. It seems my previous words were mistaken. Today is indeed your lucky day."

Zhou Ze picked up the wine glass, looking at the clear red wine inside. He didn’t rush to drink but asked:

"Is there any strange poison in this wine?"

"You jest, sir."

Jest?

Just now you said I was your new master,

and then what?

You directly pierced through my chest with one hand!

Who exactly is jesting?

"Sir, please taste my cooking. When the old master was alive, I was responsible for his daily meals. Though many years have passed, I don't think my culinary skills have deteriorated too much."

"Is there no poison in the meat?" Zhou Ze asked with a smile.

"Sir, you are overthinking. For me, to kill you or torture you, it wouldn't require such trouble."

You make a very good point; I really can't argue with that.

Zhou Ze cut a piece of meat with the knife, used the fork to put the meat into his mouth and chew. He instinctively wanted to vomit, but unexpectedly found the meat melted in his mouth and had an excellent texture.

Most importantly, he didn't feel the slightest bit of nausea.

"Is it delicious?" the old man asked.

"It's acceptable," Zhou Ze replied.

"If it's delicious, eat more. As a chef, it’s a very happy thing when your dishes are liked and eaten a lot."

The old man ate half a plate of meat, then put down his knife and fork, took out a hot towel, and wiped his hands.

Zhou Ze ate a few more pieces of meat, then asked:

"What happens next?"

"Sir, you are jesting again." The old man’s face showed a benevolent smile. "After your meal, sir, you are free to leave. I will not restrict your freedom."

"It just ends like this?" Zhou Ze found it somewhat absurd.

"Yes, it's over," the old man affirmed.

"But I remember you said that the Prefect wanted a bad person, right?"

"Yes, that is indeed true."

"Just because the identity plate is damaged, I get an exception?"

Is it really just because of good luck?

"No, the Prefect’s will does not tolerate the slightest discount."

"I don't understand."

"The answer is in your heart," the old man reminded him.

"I really dislike that cryptic way monks talk," Zhou Ze said.

The old man reached out and patted his own chest. "Sir, in that regard, I feel the same way."

Zhou Ze’s expression suddenly darkened, as if he had thought of something. He immediately lowered his head, pulled aside the neck wrap, and exposed the left side of his chest.

It was empty there.

"I’ve applied the best ointment to your wound; it will heal within days, leaving no scar. I even took the liberty of treating other wounds on your body.

You don’t need to thank me, nor do you need to be polite."

Thank you for your motherf**king *!

"My heart? Where's my heart?!" Zhou Ze demanded.

The old man pointed to the dining plate in front of Zhou Ze and said amiably:

"You said it tasted good."

"Clang!"

Zhou Ze slapped the knife and fork onto the table.

The old man picked up a cup of tea, rinsed his mouth, spat it out, then slowly stood up.

"Without a heart, there are fewer worries, and you can live more comfortably.

A good person, without a conscience, can't be good anymore, don't you agree?"

Zhou Ze gripped the tablecloth tightly with both hands, looking up at the old man,

"You'd better kill me now."

The old man smiled faintly, "So, sir, are you going to say 'Don't bully a young man for being poor' again?"

Then, the old man lightly patted his chest, took a sharp intake of breath, and feigned,

"Truly terrifying indeed."

"..." Zhou Ze.

"Sir, you won't have a chance to take revenge on me. My lifespan has long since reached its end. When you leave this room, I will also dissipate."

"Will you go to hell?"

"Hell has no place for me," the old man replied. "It is the final end."

Then, the old man pointed to the plate in front of Zhou Ze again,

"Sir, would you like me to pack it for you?"

Zhou Ze stood up, feeling an emptiness in his chest. The large hole in his wound was shocking, but he wasn't dead. More precisely, Xu Le's body wasn't dead, and he didn't even feel the slightest bit of pain.

Would the wound heal within days?

Picking up the credential on the table, Zhou Ze walked towards the door, but stopped midway and asked:

"I'm curious, who exactly is that Prefect?"

"Ever since the Prefect was deceived by that Bodhisattva who went to Hell back then, he no longer wishes for his name to be mentioned."

Without an answer, but unwilling to linger, Zhou Ze pushed open the door and stepped out. When he looked back, the door he had just exited was gone.

Behind him was a field of desolate graves.

…

Inside the room, the old man quietly cleared the dishes and swept the room clean again.

Then, he spread his hand and clapped the table.

"Come out."

A small golden snub-nosed monkey, appearing from who-knows-where, leaped onto the table, scratching its ears and cheeks at the old man, looking very endearing.

However, the monkey's body was somewhat ethereal, clearly not a real entity.

"Though injustice has its source and debt its owner, what you did this time went too far. Even if the final consequence fell upon that infant, it should not have been the object of your revenge.

If all were to pursue and comply with karma, why would you, this little beast, strive for the Great Dao?

Eating, drinking, birth, aging, sickness, and death—isn’t that the most compliant with karma?"

The golden snub-nosed monkey shook its head, then nodded.

"Don't blame me for seizing the soul attached to that infant. Your 360 years of merit will be compensation for that child. Even if he is disabled, he will have smooth sailing in the future and even become a normal person after surgery.

You should not feel at a disadvantage. Let this matter end here. Soon, I will give you a new body. You may leave and either resume your cultivation or simply play in the mountains and forests. Just do not repeat what you did today.

Even humans cultivating the Dao face five ailments and three deficiencies, let alone you, a mere beast. Consider this a tribulation on your path to cultivation."

With that,

the old man pushed open the door to the inner room.

This small room contained no other furnishings, only a traditional Chinese ink painting hanging on the wall.

In the painting,

there was a majestic mountain,

Nature’s masterpiece, where yin and yang divide day from night!

A man, wearing a purple crown and a yellow robe, stood atop the mountain.

The painting had yellowed,

the person in the painting had long since passed,

only that majestic mountain in the painting still stood there, towering over all others.

"Prefect, your humble servant has completed your command."

The old man knelt before the painting.

The scene of their farewell reappeared in his mind:

…

"You old rascal, die later, hold on a bit longer. Help me watch who this identity plate falls into. If it's a good person, kill him for me and find someone else!

I was misled by those monks, believed their nonsense about 'Hell shall not be empty before I become a Buddha,' and ruined my reputation!

The one holding my identity plate absolutely cannot be a good person, or I won't rest in peace!"

"Master, what is a good person, and what is a bad person?

A good person might do bad things, and a bad person might do good things.

As for the distinction between good and bad, this old servant is foolish and fears spoiling the Prefect’s instructions."

"Damn it, there aren’t so many convoluted arguments. If you think he’s not a bad person, just kill him."

"Yes, your humble servant will obey your decree."

…

"Is he a good person?"

Inside the room, the old man, who had been kneeling, slowly raised his head and murmured to the painting:

"He is indeed a 'good' person,

but in my eyes,

he is a 'bad' person."

As the old man spoke, his face began to darken. Yellow hair started to grow on his face and hands.

His features began to distort, transforming into a hairy face with a pointed mouth like a thunder god!

This was an old ape!

Born in the wilderness of Mount Tai, its lifelong ambition was to carry that Mount Tai.

Ancient words called it: Mountain-Moving Ape!

"My disciples and grand-disciples, cultivated for three hundred and sixty years, benevolent and diligent in practice, suffered such a great calamity, encountered such hardship!

He, relying on his human standing, disregarded everything and directly went and killed it!

Why!

Why!

Just because he is human, because he was human in life?!

So, any non-human, if it threatens humans, regardless of right or wrong, regardless of what is true or false,

should be killed? Should die?"

The old man sat down cross-legged,

and finally murmured:

"From a human perspective, he is a good person.

From the perspective of the ape clan, your humble servant sees him as a bad person.

Heh,

in the end,

it was precisely because of this that I couldn't make him die.

Prefect,

Is this your intention?

Prefect,

Your humble servant is coming to follow you. For all these years, without your humble servant by your side to serve you meals, you must have been unaccustomed, right?"

The old man lost his life.

The ape's body sat there.

The soul-state golden snub-nosed monkey then ran out, first kneeling and kowtowing to the old man's remains, then burrowed into the old man's skin.

A short while later,

from beneath the old man's clothes,

a small monkey, no bigger than a palm, emerged,

"Squeak, squeak, squeak…"

The little monkey chirped a few times, then ran off.

title: 第七十一章 恐怖的求婚
content:
It was past midnight when Zhou Ze took a taxi back to the bookstore. The bookstore door was still open, and there were quite a few people inside.

Zhou Ze remembered Xu Qinglang calling him earlier to say that business was good tonight. It seemed he was right; even at this hour, there were still customers.

Pushing open the glass door, Zhou Ze was a little disappointed to find that all ten-odd people sitting in the shop were alive.

The last incident with Bureau Chief Zhao was an exception. This time, there's no way ten-odd people could all be exceptions, could there?

Even during the time of the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors, the public's customs—no, the ghost-world's customs—weren't this simple.

They sat in a circle, with one person standing in the middle, telling a story. Everyone else listened intently. It seemed to be a suspenseful horror story, and the narrator spoke with inflections and used some body language, trying to create an atmosphere.

Bai Yingying sat behind the counter, playing on her phone.

When Zhou Ze returned, Bai Yingying actively stood up and poured him a glass of water.

Zhou Ze sat down and instinctively reached a hand to cover his chest. Although it was covered by clothes, it seemed that, for now, that area was empty.

"Boss, what's wrong?" Bai Yingying asked, a little strangely.

"Hm?" Zhou Ze looked at Bai Yingying.

"I just feel like something's different about you. You weren't like this when you left this afternoon."

Undoubtedly, the female corpse was very sensitive.

"It's nothing," Zhou Ze didn't want to talk right now.

"You're back, so can I go play games next door?" Bai Yingying pleaded.

Zhou Ze nodded.

"Boss is the best."

Bai Yingying went to the noodle shop next door. Soon, Xu Qinglang walked from the noodle shop into the bookstore, came to the counter, handed Zhou Ze a cigarette, and asked:

"Is this a tea party?"

Zhou Ze shook his head, indicating he didn't know.

"Heh, sounds like they're telling ghost stories." Xu Qinglang became interested and even pulled up a plastic stool to sit with them.

The person in the middle of the circle was telling a story about a ghost baby seeking revenge. It was full of climaxes, and the storytelling was indeed good; the people around were very engrossed.

Slowly, Zhou Ze understood. This must be a "club," similar to a book club or cycling club, an organization gathered because of a shared hobby.

After the last story ended, the leading man took out a large white paper with some drawings on it, then pulled out several pens.

Zhou Ze was a bit far and couldn't see clearly. Xu Qinglang turned his head and mouthed to Zhou Ze:

"Pen spirit."

The pen spirit game is a type of ghost-summoning game, imbued with a mysterious aura. It is said that playing such games easily leads to misfortune and possession by a deceased spirit.

These people were all very excited. Everyone reached out and jointly held a long pen. A man in a yellow woolen overcoat, wearing black-rimmed glasses, seemed to be the leader. After everyone was ready, he spoke piously:

"Pen spirit, pen spirit, where are you? Pen spirit, pen spirit, where are you?"

The pen still didn't move, but the bookstore suddenly fell silent.

The man with black-rimmed glasses continued:

"Pen spirit, pen spirit, will we encounter ghosts tonight?"

Ten seconds after he finished speaking,

The long pen held by everyone slowly began to move.

Everyone held their breath.

Actually, when many people hold one pen, as long as the tip is smooth enough, it's very easy for it to slide. If someone among them subtly misbehaves, it becomes even simpler.

"Swish!"

The pen tip suddenly twitched,

And pointed directly towards where Zhou Ze was sitting.

Xu Qinglang's mouth slightly opened. Beginner's luck?

Zhou Ze remained steadily seated behind the counter, half-closed eyes watching the situation.

Due to the pen's movement, most people's gazes were directed towards Zhou Ze's squatting position.

"Yes!"

The man with black-rimmed glasses pointed to the area where the pen tip was, saying.

There were "yes" and "no" areas, and at this moment, the pen tip was precisely in the "yes" area.

"Alright, put your things away. We'll set off together later. Remember, we'll be active for half an hour. Everyone's phones are charged, right? Everyone must record video later, for at least twenty minutes."

"Okay."

"Understood."

"Mm."

The rest of them packed their things and left the bookstore. The black-rimmed man walked up to Zhou Ze's counter and said apologetically:

"Sorry, Boss, we're from the Horror Story Enthusiasts Association. We explore supernatural events when we have nothing to do. We didn't scare you, did we?"

Zhou Ze shook his head.

"Then you're really brave, Boss. When that young lady was here, I asked her if we could play the pen spirit game, and she agreed. But now that you're back, I was actually worried you'd blame us. This is for the tea and water, Boss, please take it."

The man handed over six hundred yuan.

Zhou Ze took the money and asked, "Where are you going later?"

"Just the building above your shop. There haven't been any businesses here for a long time, right? There was also an arson case recently, where several people died. We plan to try our luck there tonight."

"You want to see ghosts that much?"

"I don't know, but people are always curious about the unknown, right? Actually, everyone gathers here with a desire for thrills.
