Saying this, the priest looked towards the construction site in the distance again,

“But it’ll be soon anyway. Dying there versus dying at the hands of the person in front of me, the outcome is essentially the same, isn’t it?”

However,

Just as he finished gloating,

The priest’s eyes suddenly became cloudy.

**Madam Qingyi**, pressed beneath Zhou Ze, suddenly flipped her left hand towards the priest.

“I made a mistake. I could have watched from a distance with binoculars, enjoying the show,

Why did I get so close?

Now, I’m going to be controlled and used as a henchman.

How unlucky…”

The priest lowered his head, then suddenly raised it, his eyes glowing green. After that, he quickly picked up the scalpels he had just dropped and charged directly at Zhou Ze.

“*Swish!*

*Swish!*”

Two scalpels,

Directly pierced Zhou Ze’s back.

“Ah!”

Zhou Ze raised his head, letting out a silent roar.

Immediately after, the priest, holding the scalpels, tried to pull them down along the insertion wounds, but the blades seemed to be stuck in Zhou Ze’s bones, unable to move.

“*Crunch!*”

Zhou Ze suddenly turned around, his arm sweeping horizontally.

Yes,

Zhou Ze couldn’t fight, had never learned martial arts, nor had he practiced anything like Sanda or Muay Thai. Therefore, when he was in a frenzy, he could only react according to instinct.

If a mosquito bites me,

I’ll swat the mosquito dead.

Zhou Ze’s arm struck the priest’s face directly.

The priest’s entire face was almost contorted, and he was struck flying backward, landing just at the edge of the rooftop. If he had been even a little further back, he would have fallen off.

The left side of his face was badly swollen. He opened his mouth and spat out several broken teeth.

The gaps between his teeth were stained with blood.

“**Baka** [5]!”

The priest flipped his hands again, and two talismans appeared. These were **Onmyoji** [6] ghost-taming talismans.

When he charged at Zhou Ze again, he dodged Zhou Ze’s punches, then directly slapped the two talismans onto Zhou Ze’s chest.

Immediately, the talismans seemed to burn, leaving two scorched marks on Zhou Ze’s chest, and the scent of cooked meat even began to spread.

However, Zhou Ze directly wrapped his arms around the priest, hugging him tightly, then violently slammed him against the rooftop parapet.

“*Bang!*”

The concrete parapet cracked significantly, and the priest spat out a large mouthful of blood.

Two grown men,

On the rooftop,

Fighting to the death,

Over a woman.

…………

“Hey, attention over there! Push it down quickly, before those old fogeys get here, hurry up!”

A construction foreman directed a bulldozer forward.

Ahead was a dilapidated old temple. The temple enshrined no **Bodhisattvas** [7] nor any Taoist figures. In fact, this temple didn’t even have a plaque.

“*Boom!*”

The temple wall was pushed down, along with the damaged statue inside, whose head had fallen off who knows how many years ago.

Excavators and bulldozers worked together, finally leveling the temple completely.

“Hey, what kind of temple was this?”

The excavator operator got down from his machine. Honestly, when demolishing, he was most afraid of encountering such situations. Demolishing someone else’s temple might harm one’s own **yin virtue** [8] and easily invite misfortune.

In every industry, more or less, there are similar superstitions.

“A small temple. When I was a kid, people still went to worship there. Not anymore. My grandpa even took me to worship it once. It was called **Madam Qingyi**, similar to **Goddess of Child-Giving** [9]. People prayed to her for children.”

“Then why did you make us push it down?”

“If we don’t push it down, how can the project proceed? You don’t know how long those old people who used to live here argued with us over this broken temple. Who still worships this damn **Madam Qingyi** now? There are infertility clinics everywhere; if you can’t have kids, just go to a doctor.

Besides, when I was little, I thought this **Madam Qingyi** was some important figure, but later I grew up and found out there’s no such person in history. It’s just old superstition and feudal traditions. We’re basically breaking down superstitions here.”

The foreman spat a mouthful of thick phlegm onto the ground and shouted:

“Tell those guys to hurry up! Before sunset, demolish this entire area for me!”

…………

On the rooftop,

**Madam Qingyi**, who had been tackled by Zhou Ze, slowly began to shatter.

The priest was right,

She was not a ghost.

As **Madam Qingyi** collapsed,

The priest’s eyes cleared. He stood up, clutching his chest, God knows how many ribs were broken. When he saw Zhou Ze charging at him again, he was so scared that he opened the rooftop door and fled down the stairs, not daring to look back.

Mid-charge, Zhou Ze’s body suddenly slowed, swaying unsteadily. The greenish glow in his eyes gradually faded,

And the bronze luster on his body also receded,

Leaving only a multitude of horrifying wounds, from top to bottom.

Zhou Ze’s body swayed, and he finally stumbled to the edge of the rooftop, unable to control his balance.

He lost his footing,

And fell straight down.

The back of the building was a garbage disposal area,

Bags of household waste were piled up like mountains there. Many stray cats and dogs were scavenging for food.

“*Thud!*”

“*Meow meow meow!!!*”

“*Woof woof woof!!!*”

When Zhou Ze crashed into the area,

He startled the cats and dogs, sending them scattering.

Zhou Ze had almost lost most of his consciousness; only his fingers were still instinctively curling.

Two brave stray dogs came closer, sniffing Zhou Ze’s body with their noses.

“*Squeak squeak squeak!!!*”

At this moment, a golden snub-nosed monkey with a plastic toy hammer in its hand leaped up in three swift bounds, swinging the plastic toy hammer to chase away the two dogs.

Then it looked at the man, who was covered in wounds and barely breathing.

When it saw the man’s face,

The monkey scratched its head,

For some reason,

It felt very uncomfortable seeing this face,

It couldn’t remember things from before and had been living here lately. These stray dogs and cats had also been tamed by it, and being a lord in a garbage heap was not bad.

But this face,

It really made the monkey unhappy! Even though it didn’t know where this feeling of unhappiness came from, it was just unhappy!

“*Pop pop pop!*”

The monkey used the plastic toy hammer to hit Zhou Ze’s head several times,

“That’s for making this monkey unhappy,

That’s for looking so unhappy to this monkey!”

After hitting him a few times,

Zhou Ze’s head slumped to the side,

Completely unconscious.

“*Whoa!*”

The monkey was so scared that it immediately dropped the plastic toy hammer,

And covered its mouth with both hands,

It was really worried it had just hammered this guy to death.

***
[1] **Ghost Messenger (鬼差, Guǐchā)**: A term used in Chinese mythology for an emissary or officer from the underworld responsible for guiding souls to the afterlife or apprehending spirits.
[2] **So desu ne (所嘚寺內)**: A Japanese phrase meaning “That’s right,” “I see,” or “Indeed.” Used here phonetically in Chinese.
[3] **Madam Qingyi (青衣娘娘, Qīngyī Niángniáng)**: The name of the headless woman. "Qingyi" literally means "green/blue clothes," and "Niángniáng" is a respectful title for a goddess or empress.
[4] **Back-killer (背影杀手, Bèiyǐng Shāshǒu)**: A slang term referring to someone who looks attractive from behind but is disappointing when seen from the front.
[5] **Baka (八嘎)**: A Japanese word meaning "idiot" or "fool," often used as an insult. Here, it’s a phonetic transcription in Chinese characters.
[6] **Onmyoji (阴阳师, Yīnyáng Shī)**: Practitioners of Onmyōdō, a traditional Japanese esoteric cosmology, often associated with divination, exorcism, and spiritual rituals.
[7] **Bodhisattva (菩萨, Púsà)**: An enlightened being in Buddhism who postpones their own nirvana to help others achieve enlightenment.
[8] **Yin virtue (阴德, Yīndé)**: In Chinese folk belief, accumulated good deeds performed secretly, which bring blessings to oneself or one's descendants in the future.
[9] **Goddess of Child-Giving (送子观音, Sòngzǐ Guānyīn)**: A popular Buddhist deity in Chinese folk religion, specifically associated with granting children to infertile couples. She is a manifestation of Guanyin (Avalokiteshvara).

title: 第八十六章 與猴子同居的日子
content:
The small, abandoned shed barely offered shelter from the sun and rain. The surrounding environment was a mess, yet there was no obvious trash; instead, some children's toys were neatly arranged.

Oh, and there was a person lying there.

It was a pity no reporter passed by at that moment, otherwise, if they could have captured dozens of stray dogs and cats dragging a person along, the image would surely have moved many to tears.

The little monkey was holding a lump of something dark and shapeless, like a ball of mud, but this mud looked very clean.

Then, it took a bit and slowly smeared it on the man's wounds.

The man had so many wounds: two burns on his chest, a penetrating wound on his back, and countless lacerations all over his body, resulting in more than half of his body being covered in the mud after the application.

He looked like a "beggar's chicken"* about to be unearthed.

The monkey was sometimes quite frustrated because it truly couldn't stand the man and often felt the urge to strangle him. But after struggling with its frustration, it instinctively found ways to keep him alive, preventing him from dying in front of it in such a muddled way.

He really should have died. Such severe injuries, even if his fall from the rooftop ended by hitting a dumpster that absorbed most of the force, his original injuries alone were enough to kill an ordinary person several times over.

But he didn't die. The monkey sometimes pressed its ear to his chest and could hear a strong heartbeat.

From the heartbeat, the man seemed very healthy, not weak at all, but overall, it was a miracle that he still had a heartbeat.

It was as if his heart was a separate part, detached from the rest of him.

Even if his other organs were decaying, his heart continued to bound around boisterously, doing as it pleased.

Seven days passed like this. During these seven days, the man remained unconscious. The monkey tried to feed him some mashed food.

The food was brought by the stray dogs and cats as offerings to it. It mashed the food and fed it to the man, but each time, the unconscious man quickly spat it out.

This greatly angered the monkey. It had given him its cleanest and most delicious food, its own rations, and he dared to spit it out!

The monkey felt its life was lacking. Look, the food it usually thought was great, this guy instinctively refused to eat it even when unconscious.

This was looking down on this lord!

With its pride wounded, the monkey found a jar with half a bottle of Lao Gan Ma chili crisp in the shack and directly fed it to him. The monkey had eaten it before and it had made it jump around.

To the monkey's surprise, the guy actually ate it. The monkey then brought some more food, mashed it, and continued to feed him, and he ate that too.

The monkey was shocked.

How strong were this guy's tastes?!

Finally, on the eighth day, Zhou Ze's eyelids fluttered slightly. He slowly opened his eyes, feeling somewhat bewildered about where he was. It wasn't a hospital, nor a bookstore.

It looked more like a homeless person's makeshift dwelling.

At the same time, a furry tail swung back and forth in front of him.

A little girl's face was staring at him.

Oh, no,

It was a bright red apple staring at him.

Not quite.

Finally,

Zhou Ze saw it clearly.

It was a monkey's ass facing him.

The monkey was still smearing mud on his wounds. Zhou Ze could even smell the earthy odor of the mud. He felt a bit anxious, wanting to open his mouth to warn the monkey that this might cause his wounds to become inflamed and fester, but when he opened his mouth, Zhou Ze could only produce "err err..." sounds.

His lips were dry, and his throat was painful; he couldn't make any proper sounds.

The monkey was startled and finally turned its face, that of a little girl, towards Zhou Ze.

Man and monkey began to stare at each other.

The monkey suddenly scratched its head and ears. This guy was awake, but the way he opened his eyes seemed even more infuriating!

Zhou Ze, meanwhile, found it a bit absurd. He had mostly forgotten his memories of that day on the rooftop, only remembering that he had had a satisfying fight.

It seemed he had fought a woman, and then a Japanese person. In any case, it was a muddled fight, and the ending was equally muddled.

It felt like someone who had too much to drink waking up the next day with gaps in their memories of being drunk.

If he couldn't speak, he wouldn't speak. If he couldn't move, he wouldn't move. If there was a monkey beside him, then there was a monkey.

His life as a bookstore owner since his "borrowed corpse resurrection" had successfully transformed Dr. Zhou, who in his previous life had been diligent and eager to climb the ranks, into a handsome man who knew how to adapt to circumstances.

Like an eighty or ninety-year-old, he had seen through what needed to be seen through. And Zhou Ze, in fact, had already died once.

The monkey routinely smeared mud on his wounds every day, and fed him Lao Gan Ma, then spicy strips, Wangzai Little Steamed Buns, half a chicken leg, and other such foods.

And after taking good care of him each day, it would stand in front of him, holding a plastic toy hammer, repeatedly hitting its own head, looking very displeased.

Zhou Ze thought this monkey seemed a bit mentally unstable.

However, this monkey was genuinely intelligent, unlike ordinary monkeys. It could even understand the meaning in your eyes. But most of the time, apart from attending to Zhou Ze, it didn't stay by his side for long.

It would often turn its back, presenting its little girl's face to Zhou Ze, then stare at the sun or moon, lost in thought.

This was a monkey with a story, one that even knew how to ponder life.

For the first few days after waking up, Zhou Ze didn't feel anything unusual. But after four or five days, Zhou Ze suddenly thought of something.

The Great Sage Equal to Heaven was born from a stone, which was extraordinary enough.

For such "human-like" monkeys to appear one after another in the small city of Tongcheng seemed unlikely.

And just a few days ago, he seemed to have just met a monkey.

And then,

That monkey had been killed by him.

That incident ultimately led to a rather messed-up situation: an old man, claiming to be his servant, invited him to a meal, and made his conscience into a dish.

But that monkey had indeed been killed by him. Even if he couldn't find its soul later, it should have lost its physical body.

One evening, the monkey returned from outside, holding a rolled-up newspaper. When it unrolled it, there was a fried dough stick inside.

Zhou Ze could now barely swallow on his own. The monkey tore off a piece of the dough stick, fed him a bite, then dipped it in Lao Gan Ma and fed him another bite.

The man and monkey had developed a certain unspoken understanding during this time.

Halfway through the dough stick, the monkey suddenly froze. It was looking at the newspaper.

Zhou Ze was a bit surprised. He thought the monkey was intelligent, but he hadn't expected it to be intelligent enough to read a newspaper.

It was like a pet dog at home; you'd think it was very smart if it could relieve itself in designated spots and sit or lie down on command. But if one day you saw your dog sitting on the toilet and flushing it after using it,

You wouldn't think it was smart; you'd be horrified.

Fortunately,

The monkey wasn't actually reading the words,

But looking at the cover image of the newspaper.

"Three-Legged Boy's Surgery a Success."

The monkey looked at the picture,

And froze for a long time.

Like a person, it sighed, then the monkey reached up and wiped its eyes.

Zhou Ze watched the monkey. At this moment, he felt no fear. Yes, this monkey was the one he had killed. He was now certain.

And yet, this monkey was now returning good for evil.

It had saved him. Although he didn't know what those mud plasters were, they had at least controlled his injuries.

The monkey had originally had its cultivation destroyed because it was caught by the lumberjack Zhou Ze had saved, and its brain was taken and its flesh eaten. But it seemed that even if this monkey had lost some of its previous memories, its true nature remained the same.

The monkey looked a bit melancholic, then continued to share the rest of the dough stick with Zhou Ze. The monkey found a rope and tied one end around Zhou Ze's neck.

Zhou Ze didn't react, letting the monkey do as it pleased, until the rope formed a loop around Zhou Ze's neck. The monkey then sat down by Zhou Ze's bedside.

It looked at Zhou Ze, and Zhou Ze looked at it.

There were tears in the monkey's eyes, anger, hatred, and unwillingness.

Just as Zhou Ze recognized it, the monkey seemed to have recognized Zhou Ze too.

The grievances between the two of them were unclear as to who was right or wrong, but if either party said an end was needed, it seemed perfectly reasonable.

The monkey slowly tightened the rope. It could completely strangle Zhou Ze now, just as Zhou Ze had stabbed himself with his fingernails and killed himself in the hospital.

Zhou Ze lay there, appearing utterly defenseless.

At this moment, several stray dogs appeared outside the shack. Their animal instincts told them that a big meal might be coming soon.

At their level of intelligence, they naturally didn't understand why their monkey brother would save this person only to kill him later. Perhaps they thought the meat would taste better if the person was well-fed?

But the monkey suddenly turned around and bared its teeth at the stray dogs outside.

The stray dogs scurried away in fright.

The monkey then slumped and looked at Zhou Ze, then reached out and untied the rope from Zhou Ze's neck.

"Slap!"

The monkey slapped itself, a very loud slap.

Then it jumped off the bed, rummaged through a pile of trash, and found a phone with a broken screen. Then it jumped back in front of Zhou Ze.

The phone was turned on. This was something the monkey had brought back yesterday, and Zhou Ze saw that the broken screen had a signal display, which meant there was a working SIM card inside.

The monkey knew what a phone was. It extended its paw and pointed at the buttons on the phone, signaling Zhou Ze to tell it what to press.

Zhou Ze reached out and took the phone from the monkey's hand.

The monkey was startled by Zhou Ze's movement. It hadn't expected that he could already move.

If his hand could move, then his fingernails could move too.

A moment later,

Zhou Ze smiled.

Then the monkey picked up its plastic toy hammer again,

This time aiming for Zhou Ze's head:

"Pop! Pop! Pop!!!"

Serves you right for faking it!

Serves you right for faking it!

Serves you right for faking it!

After hammering for a while,

The monkey dropped the plastic toy hammer,

And sat there,

And smiled too.

---
*Beggar's chicken: A traditional Chinese dish involving a chicken wrapped in clay and lotus leaves and slow-cooked.

title: 第八十七章 老闆，你居然……
content:
Holding the phone, Zhou Ze struggled to sit up against the wallboard. In fact, he could move a little now; he might not be able to get out of bed and walk around, but in other aspects, he really wasn't as weak as he had previously appeared.

He stretched out a hand and pointed to a spot under the bed.

The little monkey turned its head and saw half a pack of opened Xiaosuyan cigarettes.

It jumped down, picked up the cigarettes, and brought them to Zhou Ze's hand.

Zhou Ze then mimed lighting a cigarette.

The little monkey was startled and felt indignant, wishing it could pull out its big stick and hit Zhou Ze!

"Haven't smoked in a long time, want one."

The little monkey jumped off the bed again, rummaged through the pile of miscellaneous items, and indeed found a lighter, which it threw over.

He lit a cigarette, took a puff, and exhaled a smoke ring. Although his body was still weak, like a canvas patched countless times and ready to fall apart at any moment, this first cigarette in over ten days allowed Zhou Ze to experience a sense of comfort.

He had deliberately pretended to be immobile. As for his purpose, Zhou Ze couldn't quite explain it.

Guilt?

Debt?

Perhaps there was, perhaps there wasn't. Even now, Zhou Ze didn't feel that he had made the wrong choice back then.

But at least for now, this monkey had indeed saved his life, and he owed it a lot.

Holding his phone, Zhou Ze thought for a moment and realized he couldn't remember Bai Yingying or Xu Qinglang's phone numbers. This era wasn't like the past when you'd go to a small shop to use a public phone; few people bothered to memorize numbers anymore; they were all stored directly in contacts.

Helpless, Zhou Ze could only dial "110".

Xu Qinglang and the others had indeed reported his disappearance. Zhou Ze told the operator on the phone that he was fine and asked them to help contact the reporting party to pick him up, so as not to trouble the police uncles with a deployment.

About half an hour later, Xu Qinglang arrived in a Nissan, with Bai Yingying also in the car.

Xu Qinglang walked into the shack, pinching his nose. Upon seeing Zhou Ze lying on the bed, his eyes immediately welled up, but he quickly controlled himself.

Perhaps,

The cruelest thing in this world,

Is saying you'll come home to cook,

But you never make it back to eat.

Bai Yingying lifted Zhou Ze off the bed. Her strength was immense; carrying Zhou Ze was like child's play for her.

Zhou Ze said to Xu Qinglang, who was to one side, "Bring that monkey along too."

The little monkey squatted by the bed, watching Zhou Ze being carried away, holding its plastic toy hammer.

It waved it,

As if saying goodbye.

However, when Xu Qinglang walked towards it, the little monkey immediately jumped onto the wallboard. It clearly didn't want to leave.

Being a local king here, with a host of cat soldiers and dog generals as subordinates, and so many subordinates bringing offerings every day, how comfortable it was! It simply didn't want to leave.

Moreover, it found this guy it had saved a bit of an eyesore.

Xu Qinglang looked at Zhou Ze.

Zhou Ze repeated, "Take it away."

No room for negotiation,

The pet I've taken a fancy to,

Must be taken.

Xu Qinglang tried to grab the monkey, but the monkey was very agile, and Xu Qinglang couldn't catch it at all.

Bai Yingying settled Zhou Ze in the car, then dashed forward. The monkey hadn't expected this woman to be so fast; it was a step too slow in jumping and was caught by the tail.

"Squeak squeak squeak!!!"

The monkey bared its teeth at Bai Yingying, its face fierce!

You stinking hag,

How dare you grab me!

"Roar!"

Bai Yingying also opened her mouth at the monkey, revealing her zombie fangs.

The sight of her green face and fangs,

Completely stunned the monkey.

Dare to be naughty again,

Believe it or not, I'll eat you!

"Good boy, come with Grandma."

Bai Yingying held the monkey by its rear with one hand and its tail with the other, putting it into the car, then closed the car doors and windows.

Zhou Ze sat in the back seat, half-reclining.

The monkey sat next to Zhou Ze,

Arms crossed, clearly sulking.

It felt that it had saved Zhou Ze, but Zhou Ze was now trying to deprive it of its freedom. This was very bad!

I treated you as a patient, but you want to torture me in a secret room!

"I'm taking you because I'm afraid you'll save someone again and be harmed by them instead," Zhou Ze explained weakly. "Let's consider the grievances of the previous life settled. This life, I owe you first. Stay with me for a while, and if you still want to leave later, then go."

The monkey didn't know if it understood or not, but it did become a bit more obedient than before.

Xu Qinglang tossed over a pack of biscuits. The monkey caught them, tore open the bag itself, and ate with its hands, not forgetting to put one in Zhou Ze's mouth.

The man and the monkey had developed this kind of daily tacit understanding during this period.

"Oh, it seems I worried for nothing. You two have been living quite comfortably lately."

Xu Qinglang teased, driving the car.

"Are you jealous of a monkey?"

Bai Yingying suddenly interjected.

Xu Qinglang was choked up and said nothing more.

The bookstore hadn't moved yet. Zhou Ze, the boss, had suddenly disappeared for half a month, so no one was in the mood to relocate. Thus, Xu Qinglang drove back to the old place.

Getting out of the car,

It was still Bai Yingying who carried Zhou Ze into the bookstore. Zhou Ze, too, accepted his situation; if he had a choice between Xu Qinglang and Bai Yingying,

Zhou Ze still felt more comfortable with Bai Yingying carrying him.

The monkey didn't run away but followed closely into the bookstore.

"You're back?"

The old Taoist was cleaning the bookstore. Seeing Zhou Ze return, he immediately came over to flatter him, then said,

"A good man is always blessed."

Then, the old Taoist saw the monkey behind him and immediately brightened, "Did you bring a pet back with you?"

Saying that,

The old Taoist struck a pose like the Monkey King, shouting,

"What use is this iron rod to me!"<sup>1</sup>

Unexpectedly, the little monkey actually cooperated, also striking a pose of scratching its ears and cheeks, pointing a finger at the old Taoist with one hand and scratching itself with the other.

"Hey, this monkey is smart, like me."

After saying that, the old Taoist felt as if something he said wasn't quite right.

Just as they entered the shop, a woman came down the stairs.

First to appear were a pair of flesh-colored stockings, long legs, an exquisite high school girl's uniform, and long flowing hair.

Tang Shi had mostly recovered and was able to walk.

Women are all about beauty, and the first thing she did after regaining mobility was to doll herself up.

On this point, Zhou Ze felt Bai Yingying was much more simple. This big simpleton, besides loving video games, didn't pay much attention to dressing up.

"If you didn't come back, we'd all have to leave," Tang Shi said with a smile. "The dog's gone, so the doghouse smell has faded, and we can't hide anymore."

"I just got back, can't you say something nice?" Zhou Ze was truly speechless about this woman.

"Alright, I'll say something nice. The noodle shop owner next door told me about what happened that day. Do you know what kind of thing you provoked?"

"Something called Empress Qingyi, I think," Zhou Ze replied.

"A temple deity, a temple deity that was about to be completely overthrown. You actually took the initiative to provoke her. Do you know that her time was almost up, and she herself knew it was almost up?"

"She was killing people."

"Do you know what kind of people she was killing?"

Zhou Ze glanced at the monkey, who was still roughhousing with the old Taoist, and shook his head, saying,

"I'm not interested in knowing."

Tang Shi walked to Zhou Ze's side, then covered her nose, disdainfully saying,

"You stink."

"That's why they call me a stinking man."

"Were you always so flirty?" Tang Shi didn't get angry.

"Before, you were lying there like a mummy, who would be interested in flirting with you?" Zhou Ze pointed to the bathroom and said to Bai Yingying, "Help me take a bath."

Bai Yingying was startled,

But the simpleton girl immediately said, "Oh, okay."

In Zhou Ze's current condition, bathing himself was impossible, but he was covered in layers of mud, and it would be uncomfortable not to bathe.

Let Xu Qinglang help him bathe?

Just thinking about it was unbearable.

Let the old Taoist help him bathe?

The thought of the old Taoist scrubbing his back while singing "Xintianyou,"<sup>2</sup> and seeing the old Taoist's bony body, it just wasn't appealing.

As for Tang Shi, forget it. If he asked her to help him bathe, she'd probably "whoosh" control a pen to give him a quick, clean end.

Only the simple and kind Bai Yingying remained.

Entering the bathroom, Zhou Ze sat on a stool. Bai Yingying helped him take off his clothes. She herself didn't take off her clothes, so the bathing scene wasn't as sensual as one might imagine.

Holding the showerhead, she slowly rinsed off the mud from Zhou Ze's body. Seeing the scars covering Zhou Ze's entire body, Bai Yingying gasped in surprise, asking,

"Boss, your injuries are too terrifying. That Empress Qingyi is truly a scoundrel. I heard her temple has been demolished, serves her right."

"She didn't do it," Zhou Ze said. "Actually, most of the injuries on my body I inflicted myself."

Zhou Ze found it difficult to understand that state, and he wasn't even sure if he could voluntarily enter that state again. But one thing was certain: if he were to repeat the incident on the rooftop, he would still end up with a body full of injuries.

His body, to be honest, was a bit too weak.

Bai Yingying began to apply shower gel to Zhou Ze, her hands gliding over his body.

Unconsciously, a look of intoxication appeared on her face, and she said,

"Boss, I don't know why, but when I touch your body, I really like this feeling. It's a very intimate feeling."

As a zombie, Bai Yingying sensed a kinship with Zhou Ze's current body. And although this kinsman appeared very weak, the suppression and disparity in their ranks instinctively gave her an urge to submit.

Bai Yingying had felt this way when she first hugged Zhou Ze.

"Just focus on washing, don't mess around."

Zhou Ze reminded her.

Just then, Xu Qinglang coughed outside the bathroom.

Bai Yingying's body stiffened, and her fingertips began to rub rapidly back and forth on two raised nubs on Zhou Ze's chest.

"What are you doing?"

"I made a bet with Miss Xu, I want to see if Boss can get hard."

Saying that,

Bai Yingying also lowered her head,

Deliberately looking down,

Then she suddenly opened her mouth wide and let out an exclamation:

"Boss, you actually..."

---
<sup>1</sup> This is a famous line from the Chinese classic novel Journey to the West, spoken by the Monkey King. It implies a sense of feeling powerless or without purpose, ironically given that he possesses immense power.
<sup>2</sup> "Xintianyou" is a style of folk song from Northwest China, characterized by its high-pitched, robust, and sometimes melancholic or expressive melodies, often associated with the hardships and simple joys of rural life.

title: 第八十八章 厭食者聯盟
content:
After bathing, Zhou Ze, dressed in a white shirt and casual trousers, was carried out by Bai Yingying and placed on a bamboo mat on the second floor. When Bai Yingying came down, Xu Qinglang immediately approached and asked:

"What's the situation?"

Sneaky,
Cautious,
This feeling was very much like the trepidation of operating an underground casino, as if the police would burst in at any moment to bust the gambling.

Bai Yingying hesitated, her face flushed.

Xu Qinglang frowned.
You're a zombie, what are you blushing about?

"So, what happened?" Xu Qinglang pressed, eager for an answer.

"Uh..." Bai Yingying.

"Spit it out, did it get hard?" Xu Qinglang asked impatiently.

"This..." Bai Yingying.

"Could it be that he has a slit down there?"

"Uh..." Bai Yingying.

"Or is his smaller than yours when he takes it out?"

"What..." Bai Yingying.

"Hey, don't keep me in suspense. Do you still want the latest graphics card or not?"

"The boss said he'd get me a brand new, top-spec host after the shop moves," Bai Yingying said shyly.

"You've been bought off?" Xu Qinglang's face darkened.

"Yeah." Bai Yingying was very honest.

"No, he only has just over ten thousand *yuan* at most. He still needs to move and renovate, and I'm covering the rent for now. He doesn't have that much money."

"The boss asked me for two jade hairpins and pawned them for five hundred thousand *yuan*. He said he'd return seven hundred and fifty thousand in half a year."

"He tricked you into pawning funerary objects?" Xu Qinglang looked at her as if she were an idiot. "Are you stupid?! Those are your burial items."

"The boss said he'd give them back," Bai Yingying mumbled.

"You believe everything he says. If he said he was your zombie ancestor, would you believe that too?"

"I do," Bai Yingying whispered.
Because she really felt the aura of a zombie from the boss.

"You're hopeless, you silly girl," Xu Qinglang said, looking disappointed. "Oh right, let me ask you something. Do you have any other sisters?"

"What?"

"I also want to find a female zombie to be a maid. It's a profitable business."

"Oh."

Bai Yingying straightened up.
A chilling aura suddenly emanated from her.
The silly girl instantly transformed into an ice-cold goddess.
Xu Qinglang, who was still wallowing in self-pity, suddenly trembled.
That familiar thrill from their first meeting returned, and almost instinctively, Xu Qinglang became a little quail again.

"Who did you say you wanted to take as a maid?" the female corpse asked.

"Nothing, I said I'd go buy a new graphics card this afternoon and install it for you, so you can play *PUBG* with max settings."

...

"Here, this is the information on Lady Qingyi."
Tang Shi handed a tablet to Zhou Ze.

Zhou Ze's hair was still damp. He leaned against the wall, sitting on the bamboo mat, looking like a disheveled but handsome guy who had just finished playing basketball and showering in college.

Xu Le had all sorts of flaws and was a useless person in many ways,
But you couldn't deny that Xu Le was indeed very good-looking.
Otherwise, he wouldn't have been chosen as a live-in son-in-law by the Lin family parents.

"For having children?" Zhou Ze glanced at Lady Qingyi's information and said.

Lady Qingyi was a small temple in Tongcheng. She didn't exist in historical records, nor did she have a place in the mainstream mythological system. Even in Tongcheng, she wasn't a household name.
Her popularity wasn't widespread, and stories about her were mostly fabricated by later generations.
Just as many scenic spots in Yangzhou's Slender West Lake are related to Emperor Qianlong's travels to the south, it's as if Emperor Qianlong did nothing else but constantly create various stories in the Slender West Lake to name these attractions during his southern tours.

The story of Lady Qingyi was also a bit far-fetched. There's a town in Tongcheng called Lüsi, rumored to be named after Lü Dongbin's four visits there. This Lady Qingyi was a widow whom Lü Dongbin met during his visit to Tongcheng.
The widow had no children, did not remarry, remained chaste for her deceased husband, and, being fond of children and kind-hearted, took in many orphans, essentially serving as an ancient orphanage or daycare. After Lü Dongbin discovered her, he gave her a blue robe as encouragement.
After she died, the local people erected a temple to commemorate her merits, calling it Lady Qingyi.

Most people who came to this temple to offer incense were seeking children or continuity for their family line, similar to the effect of the "Child-Giving Guanyin."

However, it was mentioned at the bottom that due to urban renewal, the Lady Qingyi Temple had been demolished.
As for rebuilding, it would be difficult. Firstly, she wasn't as famous as Mazu, and secondly, the difficulty of building new temples was genuinely high. Developers wouldn't add extra work for themselves. Although some local elders objected, the temple was eventually torn down.

The information included a photo from a few years ago. In the photo, the Lady Qingyi Temple was already dilapidated, and the head of the deity statue had fallen off years ago, leaving only a headless sculpture standing there.
This matched the image of the headless woman.

"So-called temple gods are soul forms created by faith and incense, just like the Faceless Woman who came to test you; she was formed from the grievances of the deceased on the Yellow Springs Road," Tang Shi explained.

"Is she killing people out of anger because she knew her temple was about to be torn down and she was about to disappear?" Zhou Ze asked.

"Temple gods have their own code of conduct; even in their final frenzy, they would never act without purpose."

"I know this, I've checked." Xu Qinglang came up the stairs at this moment. "The girl whose head was cut off by the ceiling fan had three abortions at the hospital. Lady Qingyi was deliberately imposing her final punishment according to her own code of conduct."

"Punishment?" Zhou Ze asked back. "Who gave her the authority to do that?"

Xu Qinglang shrugged. "Everyone has a different perspective, so their stance naturally differs. In her eyes, a child is a life. Carelessly or irresponsibly getting an abortion is, in itself, a blasphemy against life."

"So, if I hadn't happened to run into her, she would have continued to find such people and cause their accidental deaths?" Zhou Ze asked.

"That should be it," Tang Shi nodded. "She was already mad and obsessed. Anyone, when pushed to a dead end, will go crazy, even if she is a temple god."

"I've always wondered about one thing: why did she only let the women die? Old Zhou, do you remember the boyfriend of that girl in the noodle shop? Why was he fine?
Did Lady Qingyi also favor boys over girls?"

"So the most pitiful one was still the student boyfriend."
Zhou Ze gave the answer.

Xu Qinglang was startled by the answer,
Then a look of sudden understanding appeared on his face, and he said:
"When will my thinking be as excellent as yours?"

"Anyway, next time you do something, you can slow down a bit," Tang Shi reminded him. "A desperate person, especially a temple god like that, don't touch them next time. Whatever she does, her past merits will offset it; it's not your fault."

"It's not about whether I want to get involved, it's that I happened to run into it, so..."
He thought for a moment,
Zhou Ze then thought of the monkey from back then,
And suddenly lost the desire to explain, just waved his hand and said: "Forget it, let's not talk about it."

Tang Shi, however, smiled sweetly at this moment and said, "I originally thought you were different from him. Now I suddenly realize that, in essence, you are still the same."

"I don't want to follow his path. By the way, are your injuries healed?"

"Almost healed."

"Then what are you still doing here? Aren't you going to help your friend? I can book your flight to Rongcheng."

"Whether I go or not, it doesn't make much difference. The outcome won't change just because I go. Besides, I believe he can come back."

Xu Qinglang was about to leave when he suddenly remembered something and said, "Oh, by the way, the matters with the new shop are all handled. We can move anytime."

"Let me recover a bit more," Zhou Ze said.
He didn't want to manage the shop from a wheelchair.

"Alright, take good care of yourself and be careful not to get wet."
Xu Qinglang went downstairs.

Tang Shi still stood there, flicking a finger, and a White Rabbit candy unwrapped itself and flew into her mouth.
Then, chewing, she asked Zhou Ze:
"Something seems to have changed about you."

"Perhaps."

"But I still need to remind you to take good care of this body, because for us, returning from hell and choosing a body is a one-time opportunity. Once this body is ruined, you'll become a wandering ghost."

"No exceptions?" Zhou Ze frowned. He wasn't very fond of this body; although he had gotten used to it, there were always some unspeakable difficulties.
Especially when facing Dr. Lin.

Tang Shi thought for a moment and said, "That person seems to have the ability to change bodies, but he is a special case. For us, it's a unique and singular opportunity."

"You seem to be in a good mood today." Zhou Ze noticed Tang Shi was talking a bit more today.
Zhou Ze wasn't so narcissistic as to think this woman was overjoyed because he came back safely, which made her talk more.

"He sent a message. There will be a result by the end of the month."

"Oh, the 'Husband-Watching Stone' received news, so she's so happy she can't contain herself."

Zhou Ze stretched, "I hope he has a burst of power over there, kills all those ghost messengers and faceless women, and even if he self-destructs, he drags them down with him, so I can continue to live my peaceful little life."
The little loli and the Faceless Woman were like the Sword of Damocles hanging over his head.

"Once things over there are handled, he might come here too. Then, perhaps you two can even become neighbors."

*Heh*, women.
To be honest, Zhou Ze didn't have much confidence that he could return safely from Rongcheng, but he also knew that for Tang Shi, she wouldn't listen to any rational words now.
Zhou Ze could only follow her lead and continue:
"Alright then, we can even form a group. Marvel has something called the *Avengers*, right? We can have one too,
*League of Hell-Comers*?
*Hell-Bound League*?"

"Too obvious a rip-off, and tacky," Tang Shi was clearly dissatisfied with the name.

"Heh, then you suggest one."

"*Anorexic League*, how about that?"

title: 第八十九章 無題
content:
A week later, Xu Qinglang’s noodle shop and Zhou Ze’s bookstore were both set to move tomorrow. However, Xu Qinglang still opened his noodle shop tonight, saying he planned to do business there for the last day.

It's hard to leave one's homeland; this noodle shop also carried a long period of Xu Qinglang's life, and even his last moments with his parents.

If it weren't for the little loli's intervention, perhaps Xu Qinglang could still "dine" with his parents every night, enjoying the warmth of a family together.

Zhou Ze's bookstore, on the other hand, was already closed. All the books inside were packed into boxes, just waiting for the truck to come and transport them tomorrow.

With Bai Yingying, a strong laborer, and Tang Shi, a "controller of objects," the packing efficiency was indeed very fast. Boss Zhou, whose injuries were mostly healed but not completely, only needed to sit in the adjacent noodle shop, sipping tea, looking much like an old landlord from the old society.

The old Daoist and the monkey were playing in the deserted shopping mall behind. The monkey and the old Daoist were very close; one person and one monkey could certainly play together.

There was no forest here, but the empty commercial center behind was enough for the monkey to run wild and have fun.

Sipping tea, watching the sun gradually set outside, Xu Qinglang sat there looking at his phone, showing little sadness, and certainly not much joy.

Fortunately, at this moment, a customer finally arrived.

This was today's first customer.

And, as expected,

This would also be today's last customer.

After the last time Zhou Ze took a taxi and asked the driver to find him an 'unclean' place, and the driver ended up driving here, whatever little popularity this place originally had dried up completely.

People who used to pass by here on their way to or from work also chose to take a detour.

This was also Zhou Ze's reason for deciding to move.

The newcomer was dressed in a suit, but his hair was disheveled, and the suit was a bit dirty. He didn't look like an office worker, more like an unemployed wanderer, but the suit itself was quite expensive.

"What would you like to eat?" Xu Qinglang asked, standing up.

"Stir-fry a few of your best dishes, and a bottle of Snow beer, chilled."

"Okay."

Xu Qinglang first got him the beer and then went to the kitchen to stir-fry dishes.

The man sat opposite Zhou Ze, across an aisle.

He glanced at the noodle shop and said,

"Moving, are we?"

"You can tell?" Zhou Ze was a little surprised.

"I can tell. It's just been cleaned. Who would bother cleaning so meticulously in this godforsaken place? This clearly means you're preparing to move."

The man took out a cigarette, lit it, and then directly flicked the ash onto the dining table.

A moment later, Xu Qinglang brought out the first dish. The man looked at the dish and shook his head, saying:

"Boss, your cooking really isn't as good-looking as you are."

"Eat your food," Xu Qinglang replied indifferently.

A man with over twenty apartments doing business usually had this kind of temper.

The man picked up his chopsticks, took a bite, and then spit it out, "This dish is made without care, it's not authentic."

Xu Qinglang had already gone back to the kitchen to stir-fry the next dish, so he didn't hear the man's soliloquy.

"I think his cooking is pretty good," Zhou Ze said.

"Pretty good?" The man reached out and gently tapped the table, "Cooking and making meals as a hobby, can that be called 'pretty good'?"

He then bit open the beer cap with his teeth, gulped down a large mouthful, and said, "I can taste it. It's clear he's not short on money, just doing it to experience life. This cooking has no sincerity at all."

"It's hard to find a sincere restaurant nowadays."

"Oh, what's your relationship? I said his food wasn't good, why are you suddenly targeting me?"

The man pointed at Zhou Ze, then at the kitchen, and smiled silently,

"Oh, something fishy, something fishy here."

Zhou Ze couldn't be bothered to deal with this guy. The reason he struck up a conversation earlier was that this guy looked a bit familiar, as if he had seen him somewhere before.

Of course, it must have been in his previous life.

"Disgusted? Do you feel I'm disgusting? Disgusting people live more comfortably. I just feel your life must not be that comfortable. You sit there sipping tea, looking very cultivated, but you're also someone who likes to meddle.

People, as long as they like to meddle, their lives won't be comfortable."

The man took another drink of beer and looked at Zhou Ze with a smile.

"By the way, the bookstore next door, that should be yours, right? Is it closing too?" The man pointed to the next door, "When I just came over, I saw that everything inside the glass door was packed."

"Yes, we're moving."

"Did you sue?" the man asked, narrowing his eyes.

"Sue for what?"

"Sue the developer here, sue the management here. I heard that things have been happening one after another here, clearly it's the management's negligence.

First a cinema fire,

Then someone jumping to their death,

This led to your business failing. Sue them, make them compensate your losses."

"Sue for what? Business was already bad before." Xu Qinglang brought out the last dish, then placed the rice on the table and said to the man, "Eighty yuan."

"Tsk, you're asking me for eighty yuan, and I'm telling you about a big deal. That cinema fire, you can sue the cinema, make them compensate your losses."

"Someone committed arson, and the arsonist is a pauper, can't pay for anything," Xu Qinglang retorted.

"Nonsense, did the cinema have no responsibility for the fire?

Did the management here have no responsibility?

Sue, sue them to compensate your losses. Also, those two who jumped, I heard their families are quite rich. Sue them! Them jumping here affected your normal business operations, make them compensate for the losses!"

"Your theory is quite novel," Zhou Ze said, somewhat amused.

Not to mention that he and Xu Qinglang, due to their special identities, had no intention of claiming any losses from here. Even if they were normal people, it would probably be difficult for them to think of demanding compensation from this.

"What's novel about it? If there's a law to follow, follow it! Chinese people just don't like to file lawsuits, but I'm telling you, this lawsuit can be fought, and you can get compensation.

Even if we pull out a single hair from that cinema company, it's thicker than our waists.

I can help you fight this lawsuit. I happen to be short on money, so I won't charge you a lawyer's fee. We'll split the compensation fifty-fifty. Don't worry, it won't be a small amount; if it were small, I wouldn't take this case."

"Go away, who has time to fight this lawsuit with you? Besides, someone's family died, and we go demanding compensation from them? Is that appropriate?"

Xu Qinglang was getting annoyed with this guy.

"Is 'appropriate' useful? Can 'appropriate' get you money? You were 'appropriate' and your business still couldn't continue and you're preparing to move, weren't you?"

The man took another drink. The bottle of beer was almost empty.

"Why not take the money? Are you two idiots?!"

"Are you surnamed Du?" Zhou Ze suddenly asked.

The man was startled, then looked at Zhou Ze, "Oh, you actually recognize me."

"Old Zhou, do you know him?" Xu Qinglang asked Zhou Ze.

Zhou Ze nodded, "A great lawyer."

"Him? A great lawyer?" Xu Qinglang laughed so hard tears almost came out. "This is clearly a shyster."

"He really is a great lawyer," Zhou Ze repeated.

Zhou Ze remembered that his hospital had two medical accidents caused by new drugs in the past. Patients sued the hospital, and the hospital then hired this Great Lawyer Du, who perfectly won the lawsuits.

He was from Tongcheng, but he used to have his own law firm in Shanghai, considered a very famous professional lawyer in the industry, with a very high winning rate.

However, back then, his fees were also very expensive; only wealthy tycoons and large corporations could afford his legal fees, not ordinary people.

"Since you recognize me, you should know how good I am at lawsuits. Come on, hire me for this case. You'll have money to open a new store, and I'm short on cash."

Great Lawyer Du looked at Zhou Ze, with a look that seemed to say, "Hurry up and beg me."

"Sorry, we're not interested," Zhou Ze still refused.

"Not interested in RMB? Are you perhaps interested in冥币?"<sup>1</sup>

Great Lawyer Du clutched his stomach and laughed,

Then stood up,

Pointed at Zhou Ze and Xu Qinglang,

"Don't want money, two big idiots."

With that, he felt in his pocket, took out a hundred-yuan note, and placed it on the table,

"The food was really bad, keep the change."

Then, holding the remaining half bottle of beer, he staggered out of the shop.

"This guy's crazy, isn't he?" Xu Qinglang said while clearing the table. "Never mind, we're closing. From now on, it's just coffee and pastries."

"He's quite formidable, he used to be," Zhou Ze said.

"You speak so highly of him?"

"Not highly. In any industry, to reach the top in a region, especially in a place like Shanghai, one must truly be capable.

Do you know what his most famous case was?"

"Tell me about it."

"A juvenile home invasion murder case. Despite the prosecution having a lot of evidence, because the suspect's family spent a large sum of money to hire him as a defense lawyer,

He actually managed to win the case, and the suspect was acquitted."

"So, did that child actually commit murder?" Xu Qinglang asked.

Zhou Ze hesitated, then nodded, "He probably did."

"Someone so money-grubbing, could he still get by in the industry?"

"He'd only do better, because what tycoons and big corporations need are lawyers who can help them win lawsuits and protect their interests, not just lawyers who talk about conscience."

"I understand that principle." Xu Qinglang stretched, then pointed with some curiosity at the figure staggering away outside, drinking and acting drunk:

"So why did this guy end up in such a sorry state, even bothering to come here and incite us to let him fight a lawsuit?"

Zhou Ze took a sip of tea,

And slowly said:

"Later, the juvenile who was acquitted committed another home invasion murder.

By a twist of fate,

He broke into

Great Lawyer Du's house.

His wife and daughter, on that day,

Were killed."

***
<sup>1</sup>冥币 (míngbì): spirit money or joss paper, burnt as offerings to the deceased in Chinese traditional religion. Here it means "money for the dead".

title: 第九十章 死不瞑目！
content:
The new store opened, filled with a festive atmosphere.

For Zhou Ze, the store's renovation, rent, and all other imaginable expenses weren't actually paid by him.

Xu Qinglang covered half, and the remaining half came from Bai Yingying's funeral dowry.

Of course, Xu Qinglang was preparing for "semi-retirement" now, intending to just sell coffee and make small desserts at the bookstore, living a healthy life.

Earning money would be up to Zhou Ze.

Fortunately, everyone wasn't too doubtful of Zhou Ze's money-making ability. The new store's location on South Street had heavy foot traffic, and likely quite a bit of ghost traffic too.

As long as Boss Zhou upheld the professional spirit of not fearing hardship or staying up late, continuously sending the incoming ghosts to Hell for re-education and a chance at being human again, earning piles of Hell Bank Notes shouldn't be a problem.

Then everyone could just squat at the bookstore entrance burning paper money and waiting for people to drop their wallets, even skipping bank transaction fees.

The bookstore's overall color scheme was soft and dark. The bookshelves weren't densely packed. Fast-changing newspapers and magazines had their own row, novels had another, and more serious books were in a separate area.

As for teaching aids and similar items, Zhou Ze didn't bother stocking them.

The bookstore had a second floor, which was divided into three rooms and a bathroom, serving as everyone's living quarters.

On the first day of business, there were no firecrackers, no flower baskets or salute cannons. Everything was simple and peaceful.

The old Taoist priest was tactful, cleaning with Bai Yingying, while Zhou Ze sat behind the bar, savoring the cocktail Xu Qinglang had just prepared.

After taking a sip, he set the glass down. The little monkey picked it up, secretly took a sip, and then found it extremely unpalatable, sticking out its tongue repeatedly.

Tang Shi was alone in her upstairs bedroom. She was a homebody; if she had nothing to do, she could stay in her room all day without feeling bored.

Once everything was tidied up and ready for customers, it was already after dusk, and the sky had grown dark.

Bai Yingying held the signboard with one hand, hanging up the "Midnight Bookstore" sign. She then jumped down, clapped her hands, and after confirming it was perfectly straight, smiled contentedly.

Afterward, she followed her boss's instructions and hung up and secured the two couplet signboards, "Listen with a Grain of Salt" and "Thus I Have Heard," on the left and right sides respectively.

These were the signs brought from the old store.

Bai Yingying had asked Zhou Ze about the meaning of "Listen with a Grain of Salt" and "Thus I Have Heard." Zhou Ze explained that they simply meant stories he had heard and was telling everyone.

They didn't represent his personal views, and people should just listen for entertainment, not taking them seriously.

The bookstore still primarily dealt with the business of the dead; the living's business was merely a bonus. After all, not far from South Street was "Tongcheng Bookstore," a large bookstore specializing in physical books. Competing with it would be incredibly difficult and utterly unnecessary.

Zhou Ze remembered that when he was a child, "Tongcheng Bookstore" was considered the most influential bookstore in the hearts of Tongcheng people. However, in recent years, with the continuous compression and downturn of the physical book market, Tongcheng Bookstore had already reduced its operating area, appearing much shabbier than in its heyday.

One could only say that the widespread adoption of smartphones and screen reading had gradually made most people forget the habit of reading the scent of ink on paper.

With everything complete and in order, it was time to wait for business.

In fact, business came quickly. From its official opening at 7 PM until now, several groups of customers had already arrived, but they had all just ordered coffee or other drinks, resting and chatting. They were all living people.

When living people came, Zhou Ze didn't move at all. Instead, Xu Qinglang was constantly busy greeting them and preparing drinks, swamped with work.

After sending off these groups of customers, it was already 9:30 PM. Xu Qinglang took a sip of water, looked at Zhou Ze swaying in the rocking chair, and felt an immediate imbalance in his heart!

"Old Zhou, I think we should hang a sign that says, 'No Living People Allowed.' What do you think?"

"Then the Industrial and Commercial Bureau will be knocking on our door the next day," Zhou Ze unhesitatingly rejected Xu Qinglang's suggestion.

"But I feel like this is more tiring than running my noodle shop," Xu Qinglang complained with a mournful expression.

When he ran his noodle shop before, not many people actually ate in the store; most orders were for takeout. If he wanted to rest, he could simply turn off the takeout app. But now that customers had come in, he couldn't exactly kick them out, could he?

"Look, here they come."

Zhou Ze looked outside the door.

It seemed that due to the location, the real business for today was also arriving quickly.

Entering was an old woman, leaning on a cane, her figure thin and somewhat shriveled. Her eyes were wide open, as if she had died with her eyes still open.

The old woman had a faint trace of resentment, which meant she still had some lingering obsessions, so she hadn't gone to Hell or entered reincarnation.

But her slight resentment was still far from turning into a malevolent ghost, remaining a "harmless" type of ghost.

"Prepare the dishes," Zhou Ze told Xu Qinglang.

This time, Xu Qinglang didn't complain or whine. In fact, preparing food for those about to be sent to Hell was his own suggestion.

He felt that Zhou Ze's previous method of directly sending ghosts to Hell was too simple and crude, without any foreplay, too dry and lacking in service quality.

Therefore, he suggested preparing some food before sending people to Hell, giving them a send-off. That way, they would leave more Hell Bank Notes.

It was the same principle as how movie theaters had significant income from selling cola and popcorn, besides the main income from movie tickets.

The dishes were simple: a plate of dried radishes, a plate of peanuts, a bowl of rice with chopsticks stuck upright in it, and a cup of aged yellow wine.

These were all pre-prepared items, just needed to be plated, so it wasn't troublesome.

The old Taoist priest set up the small table and stools, and pulled the curtain to block the view from outside. Otherwise, if other customers came in and saw this, they would probably be startled.

This was a small private room, specifically for ghosts.

Zhou Ze walked over, holding his teacup, and said to the old woman, "Please."

The old woman hesitated. It was clear she was afraid, but she feared Zhou Ze even more. At once, she could only sit down tremblingly.

Xu Qinglang handed the old Taoist priest a bottle of cow's tears mixed with talisman water. The old Taoist priest rubbed it on his eyes and also saw the old woman.

Honestly, the old Taoist priest hadn't encountered such an open-door ghost business since leaving the netherworld store. For a moment, he felt a bit nostalgic and couldn't help but think of his boss, who was still in Rongcheng.

However, it would be soon.

The old Taoist priest had already sent a notification to his followers in his live-streaming room, which had been dormant for several months. He would restart his live stream on April 1st, at midnight, roughly after 00:20 on March 31st.

That day was when his boss said he would return.

Bai Yingying also brought a small stool and sat down. The old woman seemed a bit shy. A zombie, a ghost messenger, a Xuanxiu, plus an old Taoist priest whose crotch seemed to be steaming with heat…

The old woman felt immense pressure.

Her slight resentment felt truly insignificant surrounded by this pack of wolves.

"Eat up. After you eat, you can be on your way."

Zhou Ze urged.

The old woman smiled, lowered her head, and began to eat.

Just as a tiger, though formidable, behaves like a little kitten when facing its zookeeper in the zoo, the old woman, who could have scared people sick or unconscious with a fleeting glimpse outside, now obediently ate her meal.

"Ma'am, how did you die?" the old Taoist priest began to ask at this point.

The old Taoist priest was an active person. Even at his age, the older he got, the more he talked.

He often chatted with the little monkey, telling stories of how he subdued demons five hundred years ago and suppressed a great mischievous monkey under Five Finger Mountain, and so on.

The monkey was also supportive. As long as the old Taoist priest bought some snacks, the monkey would sit there listening to the old Taoist priest brag for an entire afternoon, occasionally waving its hand in approval:

"That's a great story!"

"Sānpengsī lǐ." (Meaning: "Died of illness.")

The old Taoist priest was confused. He knew the old woman was speaking in dialect, so he looked at Zhou Ze.

"Died of illness," Zhou Ze translated.

The Tongcheng dialect was very different from Mandarin.

"Ma'am, this won't do. Even if you're a ghost, you can't forget to learn. You have to learn Mandarin well, otherwise, when you get to Hell...

Think about it, there are so many people on the Yellow Springs Road. It'll be hard to find someone who speaks Tongcheng dialect. You won't even have anyone to chat with on the road, how boring would that be?"

The old Taoist priest kindly reminded her.

The old woman was a bit embarrassed and could only lower her head to eat.

"Do you have children?" the old Taoist priest asked again.

"Yú guǒ ó tēi." (Meaning: "I have a daughter.")

The old Taoist priest looked at Zhou Ze again, meaning, "Translate quickly."

"She has a daughter," Xu Qinglang translated.

"Then your daughter must have burned a lot of paper money for you, right?" The old Taoist priest rubbed his hands.

The old woman was startled at his words, then smiled bitterly, "Our family's financial situation isn't good." (Translated by Xu Qinglang)

"Family's financial situation isn't good?" The old Taoist priest didn't get discouraged and continued, "It's alright, paper money isn't expensive anyway. As long as your child cares about you, there can be more paper money."

"Lying in bed, no money to treat the illness," (Translated by Xu Qinglang) the old woman said, putting down her chopsticks and wiping her tears.

"How pitiful," the old Taoist priest wiped his own tears along with her.

Bai Yingying also pouted, feeling a bit upset herself.

"My daughter in the hospital bed asked me if I wanted to continue spending money on treatment. I was lying in bed, unable to speak or move. She cried and told me that if I didn't want to continue treatment, I should blink. If I didn't blink, she would even sell everything we owned to pay for my treatment."

"That's a good daughter," the old Taoist priest said. "What did you do?"

"I blinked, and then I went home from the hospital, and then I died," the old woman continued to wipe her tears.

"It's not easy, you're also thinking of your children. Truly great, it's not easy for anyone, children need to live too," the old Taoist priest lamented along with her.

In reality, such things are common, especially when facing terminal illnesses, which means continuously pouring money into treatment. Many families simply cannot afford such an expensive way of treating illnesses.

"Ma'am, you are very great," Bai Yingying said.

"Let me pour you another drink," Xu Qinglang offered.

Meanwhile, watching everyone around him with tear-filled eyes, Zhou Ze couldn't help but feel a little amused.

He pointed to the old woman's eyes, which had been wide open since she entered, and asked:

"How did you blink?"

At his words, the old woman…

stopped crying.

She immediately said fiercely:

"She asked me,

'Mom, I'm asking you, if you don't want to continue treatment, just blink. If you don't blink, I'll even sell everything we own to pay for your treatment.'

And then,

after waiting for five minutes,

I couldn't stand it anymore,

so I blinked.

She immediately started wiping her tears and said:

'Okay,

Mom,

I understand what you mean.

We won't treat it anymore.'"

title: 第九十一章 雨夜追捕
content:
After Xu Qinglang translated the old woman’s last words, the previously deeply moved crowd looked bewildered.

What the hell,

Where’s the heartwarming story of "I for my children, my children for me," and filial piety?

Why this twist?

Zhou Ze clapped his hands and asked, "Are you done eating?"

The implication was,

If you’re done eating, it’s time to go.

The old woman shyly put down her chopsticks and said,

"I don't know how I ended up here. I didn't want to go down. I still wanted to..."

Zhou Ze silently watched her,

A smile appeared at the corner of his mouth,

Customer first,

Customer requests must be listened to with a smile.

The old woman’s body stiffened, startled into a shiver,

And immediately said,

"I think it's better for me to go down early."

Zhou Ze thought he should put up some slogans in this small private room:

Confess and be lenient, resist and be strict.

That seemed a bit too serious, or perhaps:

Reform diligently, become a new person.

These thoughts in his mind only amused him. Zhou Ze stood up, opened the Gate of Hell, and the old woman was still hesitating, but Zhou Ze directly grabbed her shoulder with one hand and tossed her in.

And just like that,

The new store's first order was complete.

Next, Zhou Ze bent down and looked under the small table, seeing a small stack of Hell Bank Notes.

"Count them, are there more than before?" Xu Qinglang urged.

"It seems there are more," Zhou Ze confirmed.

"That means this method works! I told you, the profit margin for extra services is the largest. Should we offer other services?"

Despite owning more than twenty apartments, Xu Qinglang’s desire to make money remained as strong as ever.

No one would complain about having too much money.

"How about a massage? Or a spa?" Zhou Ze chuckled.

"That's a bit too much," Xu Qinglang frowned.

"Some funeral homes now offer such services, like hydrotherapy massages for the deceased. I saw it once, in a glass cubicle, where family members stood outside watching while the technician showered and massaged the corpse, and even did nail trimming, a whole package."

"You're disgusting." Xu Qinglang, looking as if he couldn't stand it, turned to start clearing the dishes from the table.

Actually, the dishes hadn't been touched at all, at least they looked untouched, but they still had to be thrown away.

If it were offerings for one's own ancestors at home, after the ceremony, people could still eat the dishes or fruits. After all, it was food that their own ancestors had eaten, so there was no big deal in everyone sharing a meal.

But Xu Qinglang and the old woman were not related, so he certainly wouldn't eat her leftovers.

Putting the Hell Bank Notes into the cabinet, Zhou Ze settled back into his armchair,

Rocking forward,

Rocking backward,

He liked this ease and enjoyed this leisure.

Bai Yingying went upstairs to play on the computer, the old Taoist priest took the monkey upstairs to watch TV, and Xu Qinglang also went up to rest.

Thus, only Zhou Ze, the boss, was left on the first floor of the bookstore.

Holding his phone, he casually browsed, checking the news and such. Outside, it began to rain without him noticing, and the rain was quite heavy, changing from a sparse drizzle to a downpour.

This season, it really could rain at any moment.

He picked up his water glass, took a sip, and when Zhou Ze stretched and looked up again, he found a dense line of people standing at his bookstore's entrance.

Oh,

Business is this good today?

This was only the first night the new store opened. If it continued like this, Zhou Ze felt he could not only quickly repay the money he owed his maid but also immediately buy a good car.

Hmm, it's just that Xu Le, that useless fellow, doesn't even have a driver's license, so he'd have to get one himself.

Walking to the storefront, Zhou Ze paused, realizing that those standing outside were not people, but rows of clothes.

It was just that the people who usually sold clothes on stalls outside had moved their stalls to his shop entrance to take shelter from the rain because of some preconceived notions, which made Zhou Ze mistakenly think there were ghostly figures outside.

He opened the shop door.

Outside stood two young women, around twenty years old, with wallets clipped to their waists and ponytails, looking fresh and capable.

"Boss, sorry, we're blocking your business. We'll leave as soon as the rain lessens. So sorry, so sorry." One girl bowed and apologized to Zhou Ze.

"Boss, do you have coffee? We'll buy two cups of coffee." The other girl was more resourceful. If they bought coffee, the owner might not be so quick to shoo them away.

"It's fine, wait until the rain stops before you go."

Zhou Ze wasn't that heartless, plus his business could still get customers even with an iron plate blocking the entrance.

"Thank you, boss."

"Thank you, boss."

The two girls thanked Zhou Ze again.

Zhou Ze returned to his spot behind the bar. The upgraded bar area was indeed much more sophisticated and comfortable than the previous counter, with surround sound playing soft music.

About fifteen minutes passed, and the rain showed no signs of letting up. One of the girls from the clothes stall pushed open the bookstore door and walked in.

She went to the bookshelf, picked out a few fashion magazines, and then came over to Zhou Ze, ready to pay.

"Forty-eight." Zhou Ze glanced at the price and casually said, "Make it fifty, keep the change."

"Okay."

The girl responded and handed Zhou Ze a fifty-yuan bill.

Zhou Ze accepted the money.

A moment later,

The girl paused,

It seemed,

Something wasn't quite right.

Zhou Ze continued to lean back in his chair, and the girl, no longer fussing about the two yuan, took her books and sat down on the small sofa in the shop.

Her companion was outside watching the stall, while she held a blank notebook and began sketching designs from the magazines.

Zhou Ze got up, poured a glass of orange juice, and brought it over to her.

"It's free," Zhou Ze said.

"Oh, thank you, boss."

"Studying design?" Zhou Ze asked.

"Yes, we're students from Tongcheng University."

"University students coming out to set up a stall, that's really good."

Zhou Ze praised them a couple of times. He wasn't a perverted uncle with ulterior motives, so he didn't prolong the conversation. However, just as he reached the shop entrance, Zhou Ze suddenly saw the girl who was outside watching the clothes talking to a man dressed in black.

Several other people stood behind the man in black. They seemed a bit cold, shivering in the rain, but even so, they didn't move closer to take shelter under the eaves.

Zhou Ze pushed open the shop door and walked over.

The man in black looked up, saw Zhou Ze, and then immediately looked down again.

The few scantily clad people behind him suddenly became timid, not daring to make eye contact with Zhou Ze.

Zhou Ze walked up to the man in black, who was wearing a hat that obscured half his face. Then, Zhou Ze turned his head and saw that the girl who was handing out clothes had a blank, hazy look in her eyes, and the money she had just collected was a stack of old Hell Bank Notes.

"Isn't that going too far?" Zhou Ze said.

"We are all lonely souls, on our way back to our hometowns, but it's raining, and my brothers have no clothes, so we are really cold. We beg for your mercy, Lord Envoy."

"Lonely souls, then hurry up and go to hell."

Zhou Ze's attitude was very stiff; clearly, he had no intention of negotiating.

What a joke,

Lonely souls are also performance!

Boss Zhou was currently aiming for performance, and even a mosquito's leg is meat; he wouldn't let it go.

It seemed that changing shops was the right choice. Look how lively it was tonight.

The man in black slowly raised his head, revealing his scarred face, and said in a deep voice:

"Is Lord Envoy not planning to discuss this properly?"

"What is there to discuss between you and me?"

Zhou Ze reached out, first grabbing the girl's shoulder and pulling her back slightly, then he took a step forward, standing in front of the man in black,

He extended his hand,

And gently poked the man in black's chest,

"You can try to fabricate a pitiful story to make me soft-hearted,

Oh no,

My apologies, I forgot,

My conscience was temporarily eaten by myself and hasn't been found yet."

"After I take them back to our homeland, I will bring them back to hell. You can rest assured about that, Lord Envoy!"

Although the man in black had a face full of scars, he spoke with conviction, clearly in command of this group of minor ghosts.

"Do I have to buy a plane ticket and go to your hometown for a visit? Sorry, brother, I don't have time."

Zhou Ze's fingernails grew long,

Black smoke slowly began to swirl out,

At this moment, the girl sitting inside the shop looked outside and only saw her companion and the boss seemingly chatting, completely unaware of anything else she shouldn't see.

"I can't hand them over to you now. I must take them back first!"

The man in black charged at Zhou Ze, full of aggression!

But the next second,

Zhou Ze merely flicked his arm,

The man in black was sent flying directly, the sharpness of the fingernails making his soul unstable.

"Heh heh."

Zhou Ze chuckled twice.

An ordinary ghost,

Dared to attack him, a Ghost Messenger.

The man in black charged again, but without exception, he was sent flying by Zhou Ze once more.

At this, the few ghosts who had been standing there timidly immediately showed signs of instability.

Zhou Ze had initially thought they would all rush forward to help their boss fight, which would be a show of loyalty.

Or,

These few ghosts would quickly kneel down and beg him for mercy,

Though begging wouldn't have much effect.

But instead, they directly turned around and pounced on the black figure, whose soul was starting to blur after being repeatedly sent flying by Zhou Ze.

They were furious, beginning to gnaw and tear at the black figure.

Zhou Ze stood aside, watching the spectacle with a smile, and said,

"It seems your subordinates have been squeezed pretty hard by you."

Even though the man in black was being torn at, he still didn't utter any screams, and at the same time, he sternly retorted:

"They are the criminals I was pursuing. My car and their car collided in an accident during the pursuit, and we all died.

But even in death,

I will drag them to the public security bureau at the scene of the crime to be turned in!"

title: 第九十二章 漩渦
content:
Zhou Ze reached out, his fingertips continuously swirling out black mist to disperse the gang of guys gnawing around the man in black, but the wisps of black mist still enveloped the little ghosts, preventing them from escaping.

Since the battle on the rooftop, Zhou Ze found that his mastery of this power seemed to have reached a new level.

"Are you a police officer?"

Zhou Ze lowered his head, looking at the man in black lying on the ground, his soul nearly shattered.

"What do you think?"

The man in black stood up, his soul fragmented, looking quite miserable.

But his gaze was firm, bright and piercing.

"Just didn't expect it."

Zhou Ze remembered the last time he saw Bureau Chief Zhao, who, on the day of his funeral, entered his bookstore, and neither he nor Xu Qinglang could tell if he was alive or dead.

Thinking about it, he was relieved.

Bureau Chief Zhao was nearing retirement age, having diligently worked his entire life, much like Madam Bai, who had gone to hell earlier; her merits were fulfilled.

Such a person was an anomaly among anomalies.

It was like learning from Lei Feng and doing good deeds; it's precisely because Lei Feng is an anomaly in this society that we need to learn from him. If everyone were a living Lei Feng, what would be the point of learning?

"Come inside with me."

…………

It was still raining outside. The girl who had been sitting in the bookstore sketching from a magazine went out to check on her companion and found her asleep leaning against a clothes rack. She draped a coat over her and stayed outside with her instead of going back in.

Two university students out selling wares to earn money, like delicate wildflowers in this city, stubborn and strong.

For them, it was an ordinary day: setting up their stall, encountering rain, seeking shelter.

They couldn't possibly know what kind of business the bookstore they were sheltering in conducted, nor did they remember that one of them had just nearly made a deal with a ghost.

Inside the bookstore, Zhou Ze set out some peanuts and orchid beans. The man in black sat opposite him, while the little ghosts stood shivering at the side.

"Thank you for the hospitality."

The man in black said in a deep voice.

"Once you're done eating, it's time to go." Zhou Ze said.

The man looked up at Zhou Ze; clearly, he was unwilling.

"They are already dead, and you have sacrificed yourself. Your responsibilities have been fulfilled. There's no need to stubbornly cling to your obsession, dragging them along with you.

If something goes wrong along the way and their souls escape your control, this world will gain several more wandering ghosts, and perhaps cause other troubles."

Zhou Ze patiently explained.

In fact, the central idea was just one.

I respect you, but respect is respect, and work is work.

You have your obsession, but I also have my responsibility.

Living people are your concern.

Dead people are my concern.

"Then can I ask you a favor?"

"You first."

"Help me investigate the cause of my death." The man in black lifted his scarred face, which now looked especially fierce. "I was an undercover agent, and someone betrayed me. Otherwise, I could have arrested them and brought them to justice alive."

The man in black recalled that in the car, one of the individuals suddenly answered a phone call, and the atmosphere immediately shifted. He realized that his identity had been exposed, and a struggle ensued in the car, ultimately leading to the vehicle plunging into a ravine, resulting in the tragic accident that destroyed the car and killed everyone inside.

"This sounds like a plot from a crime drama."

Zhou Ze sighed after hearing the man's narration.

Being an undercover agent is truly not easy.

"Come, a toast to you."

Zhou Ze raised his wine glass, clinking it virtually with him.

Then, he put down his glass.

"You agreed?" the other party asked.

"No, just stalling for time to formulate a polite refusal, so we don't feel awkward."

"…………" the man in black.

"I'm sorry, I can't do that. This is just a bookstore, actually a waystation, for sending souls that shouldn't linger in the human world to be reincarnated in hell.

Matters concerning living people in the human world are not my business, nor can I interfere. The only thing I can do is write an anonymous letter for you and send it up. Anything more, I cannot and will not do."

The man in black was somewhat disappointed. He wanted to say something more, but it turned into a sigh, and then he drank the wine.

Ghosts drinking only absorb the essence of the wine; the liquid in the glass doesn't seem to change at all. Zhou Ze poured out the wine from his original glass and refilled it.

"Drink two more, then I'll send you on your way. Wish you a safe journey."

When a man is about to die, his words are kind.
