But now, the old woman could return to hell by herself. Even if Zhou Ze risked his wound rupturing or fainting to open a Hell Gate for her, it would be a thankless effort, like giving her an express ride, and he wouldn't gain any benefit himself.

The old woman's soul was slowly dissipating, gradually sinking into the ground.

"Boss, why is your hand trembling?"

Bai Yingying, who had been supporting Zhou Ze, sensed his abnormality.

"It pains me."

Zhou Ze uttered these two words.

He finally understood the little loli's warning about the potential consequences of keeping Bai Yingying by his side. Some ghosts attracted to him would get scared by the zombie and immediately enlighten themselves, meekly heading to hell without a fuss.

What would be left for him to do then?

Of course, this was something that couldn't be forcibly reversed, and today's surprises had already come: the key to the Hell Gate and the news that the little loli might have had a major accident, which was far more significant than the achievement of one wandering soul.

This sleep was quite peaceful.

When Zhou Ze woke up the next day, he found that some of his strength had returned, and he wasn't as weak as yesterday. Without waiting for Bai Yingying to help him, Zhou Ze propped himself up with his hands and stood.

Though a bit shaky, he was standing nonetheless.

"Boss, are you alright?"

Bai Yingying was quite worried, fearing Zhou Ze might suddenly fall, especially when he gestured for her not to help him down the stairs.

With Zhou Ze's current physical condition, he was much like an elderly person with unsteady legs.

Bai Yingying was genuinely concerned that if Zhou Ze fell, he might break an arm or a leg, or even more exaggeratedly, become paralyzed. The old Taoist's intellectually-challenged electric "woo-woo-woo" wheelchair might actually come in handy then.

Early in the morning, the female corpse's thoughts were a bit scattered.

She began to automatically imagine her boss sitting in an electric wheelchair, "woo-woo-woo-woo-woo-ing" along,

and even sucking on a pacifier.

It was truly...

"Hahahahaha..."

Laughing,

Bai Yingying stopped. She saw Zhou Ze turn his head to look at her.

"Zombie transformation?" Zhou Ze asked.

Bai Yingying shook her head.

"Corpse dementia?" Zhou Ze asked again.

Bai Yingying immediately shook her head again.

She also didn't dare to voice the scene she had just secretly imagined, otherwise, once the boss recovered, he would surely stab her to death.

Mm,

Stab with his fingernails.

Zhou Ze felt that his maid seemed to have a screw loose this early morning, and said again,

"Give me two barks."

"Yingyingying."

Oh, normal again.

Slowly holding onto the stairs to go down, Zhou Ze had a sense of accomplishment akin to learning to walk as a child. To be honest, he never wanted to experience that drunken blackout feeling again.

The pleasure was temporary, instantaneous, followed by an extremely long period of weakness and lethargy.

It was like overindulging in "that stuff" where you're full of vigor in bed all night, seven times,

Only to wake up the next day with a weak back and knees, and possibly even a sudden stroke.

The old Taoist was already up. No matter how late he went to bed, he always rose early. He had a fixed schedule and would even practice a set of martial arts in the morning.

As a kind-hearted old Taoist dedicated to activities concerning fallen women,

He understood the importance of maintaining his physical health.

When Zhou Ze came down, the old Taoist had already finished his exercises and was chatting with the little monkey.

The old Taoist held some black mud in his hand, and there was a large bag of it on the ground.

Zhou Ze frowned slightly.

That was the stuff the little monkey had smeared on his wounds when he was injured. It was remarkably effective, no less than the "Black Jade Ointment" from martial arts novels.

It just smelled a bit foul, and for a clean freak like Zhou Ze, having several layers of mud smeared on him was nothing short of torture.

But then,

An even more shocking and torturous scene appeared.

The old Taoist brought the plastic bag filled with mud close to the little monkey.

More precisely, he brought it close to the little monkey's crotch,

While making "shoo shoo shoo shoo..." sounds with his mouth.

"Little ancestor,

Quick, pee,

Now we're counting on this stuff to get rich,

Good boy,

Quick, pee, good boy, shoo shoo shoo shoo..."

Zhou Ze's face turned black.

The mud smeared on his body,

Actually,

Actually,

Actually came from this!

"Ouch!"

Bai Yingying was quick, catching Zhou Ze just as he was about to fall.

The old Taoist heard the commotion and turned his head,

He flashed Zhou Ze a smile as bright as the big sun outside, waving the black mud in one hand as he greeted,

"Boss, good morning!"

Heaven help him,

If Zhou Ze hadn't been injured coincidentally recently,

The old Taoist really didn't know how many times he would have already died.

…………

From noon to afternoon, the bookstore usually didn't open for business. This bookstore, located in the prime real estate of the South Street city center, was just that whimsical, that high-class!

However, if a customer came in, wanting to buy books, read, or have drinks, they wouldn't be turned away.

But Xu Qinglang had previously hung a sign to reduce his workload:

"Minimum consumption 100 RMB."

This was enough to deter eighty or ninety percent of potential customers.

Zhou Ze let it be; with fewer casual people, everyone's workload would be lighter.

Of course, there were also wealthy patrons who didn't care about money. Just as Zhou Ze finished his meal and was struggling with the nausea in his body, a middle-aged man with a slicked-back hairstyle and a yellow jacket walked in.

He seemed quite pleased with the store's quietness. After ordering a glass of ice water, he took out his laptop and sat on the sofa to work.

Soon after,

His laptop seemed to be on public playback,

And a voice rang out:

"Macau's first online casino is now live! Beautiful dealers dealing cards online..."

The old Taoist understood the implied meaning of the music,

His ears twitched, and he immediately moved closer,

As if he had found a kindred spirit.

But when he saw the screen, the old Taoist was dumbfounded. Where were the promised Japanese educational action films? What the hell were all these chips on the screen?

"Do you also play online gambling?"

The man asked, looking at the old Taoist who had approached with interest.

What kind of person was the old Taoist? He could become sworn brothers with a monkey.

He could trick adorable viewers in the live stream into buying冥币 (hell money) from him,

And he could trick coal bosses from Liaoning into transporting coal to Shanxi to sell.

He immediately said:

"Yeah, I play occasionally, but not for big stakes. It's not really that interesting, not exciting.

I usually like to go to Macau to relax."

As the old Taoist spoke, he even picked his ear with his pinky finger,

Looking utterly unconcerned!

At the same time, the old Taoist also signaled the little monkey to lean forward, and he reached out to stroke it.

This pretense,

See that?

A golden snub-nosed monkey, a protected national animal, is my pet.

Isn't that just as good as those Arab tycoons keeping leopards?

The man was initially taken aback. There was no way to know if what the old Taoist had bragged about was true, but this golden snub-nosed monkey was certainly real.

And running a bookstore like this in the city center of South Street meant either being insane or having so much money that one was simply playing a life simulation game.

Suddenly, the man became enthusiastic towards the old Taoist, warmly inviting him to sit next to him and giving him a detailed introduction to how his website worked.

Zhou Ze listened from the side, then took out his phone, wondering whether to call the police.

Most online gambling in China were scams, tricking people into depositing money, letting them win some first, then fattening them up like pigs to be slaughtered. It was essentially the same old tricks from ancient gambling houses, but countless people still fell for it.

Because no matter how the tricks changed, it didn't really matter,

The key was the human heart's greed; it was passed down through generations and couldn't be changed.

But the conversation that followed made Zhou Ze temporarily put away his phone and not call the police.

Because the old Taoist maintained his high-class demeanor,

He showed disdain for common gambling methods like "Shi Shi Cai" (a type of lottery) and others, which made the man, in an effort to hook this eccentric wealthy client, go all out.

Finally, he said:

"There's a truly exciting project, but I don't know if you, boss, dare to play it?"

"Hmph, I even dare to bathe ghosts, so I'm not afraid of your 'exciting project'!"

This, someone could attest to,

The old Taoist wasn't bragging.

"Tell me, what do you gamble on?" the old Taoist urged.

The man hesitated for a moment but then spoke:

"Lives!"

Suddenly,

Zhou Ze, who was sipping coffee and listening to the conversation, felt his spoon tremble slightly.

In his mind, he saw the old woman from last night, standing in the shop, staring intently at the clock, unaware she was already dead,

And that sacrificing police officer he had personally sent down,

Who, before leaving, told him that the gambling syndicate he was investigating,

Didn't gamble on anything else,

Nor played anything else,

But,

Gambled with lives!

title: 第一百零八章 死亡遊戲！（第六更，求訂閱！）
content:
"Gambling with your life?

Like underground boxing, where you sign a waiver of life and death?"

"No, not that kind, boss. I can guarantee you've never seen anything like it."

The old Daoist priest grew interested. He had wandered half his life, a seasoned traveler of the Jianghu. Though clad in Daoist robes and hailing from a family of Daoist priests, in his generation, what kind of low-class or unorthodox things hadn't he seen?

Even if he hadn't eaten pork, surely he had seen a pig run?

"Heh heh, tell me then. I truly don't believe there's anything I haven't seen."

The old Daoist priest, with an air of ethereal grace, hitched up his robes.

"Just so you know, our minimum investment here is 50,000 yuan." The man looked at the old Daoist. "You don't have to worry about me swindling your money. Our industry is very, very big now, and we only take a commission. So whether you win or lose, our platform is always profitable."

The old Daoist grunted, clearly unwilling to part with that money.

He had engaged in his fair share of trickery and deceit, so he naturally didn't want to be swindled in his old age. Moreover, he was very fond of his money pouch.

"I'm interested," Zhou Ze suddenly spoke.

Yes,

He was interested.

Whether it was the old woman from last night,

Or the good police officer he had sent to Hell,

Both had, either indirectly or directly, used the phrase "gambling with your life."

Zhou Ze genuinely wanted to see what kind of game this "gambling with your life" truly was.

In his domain, five or six souls had already entered Hell because of this "life-gambling" matter.

What,

Exactly, was this game?

The man glanced at Zhou Ze, who sat there looking somewhat sickly.

His disdain was palpable.

He looked good, quite handsome,

But clearly, he was just a bookstore clerk.

You're interested,

Heh heh,

Do you have money?

He didn't say it outright,

But his expression and gaze made it abundantly clear.

You, fellow, are obviously broke.

I've seen countless people; could I be wrong?

Zhou Ze licked his lips,

Wanting to smile to ease the awkwardness,

Then suddenly felt that smiling at this moment, with Bai Yingying and the old Daoist present, might be even more awkward;

But this feeling of not knowing whether to smile or not,

Was actually even more awkward...

Then,

So annoying,

I really want to send you to Hell,

How dare you make me awkward!

The old Daoist saw that his boss's expression was starting to change, and his heart immediately skipped a beat.

As a seasoned Daoist who had served two "ghost bosses," he had ample experience in flattering ghosts!

Immediately,

He slammed the table,

And said directly:

"Dammit, it's just 50,000 yuan, just pocket change, no problem at all;

Don't you dare look down on people with your dog's eyes. I'll transfer the money to you, and I'm not afraid of you trying to fool me.

Anyone who dares to fool me,

I have ways to send them to Hell!"

The old Daoist smiled, revealing his white teeth.

"Alright, to Hell it is." The man took out his phone. "I'll open an account for you first. Just deposit the money."

The man didn't find the threat of Hell unusual; he thought the old Daoist was using underworld slang, meaning "if you fool me, I'll have you killed."

The man probably never dreamed that,

In this bookstore,

Helping people go to Hell,

Was actually a genuine revenue-generating service.

"Open two accounts. I'll transfer 100,000 to you."

The old Daoist transferred the money without hesitation, then leaned over to Zhou Ze, grinning obsequiously, inviting his boss to see what this life-gambling game was all about.

He really wasn't afraid of this guy reneging on the deal.

As the saying goes,

It's easy to meet the King of Hell, but hard to deal with the little devils.

Of course, these words couldn't be spoken in front of the boss, otherwise, he probably wouldn't even know how he died.

Unfortunately, the old Daoist didn't know that over the past two days, by eagerly volunteering to scrub Zhou Ze's back, then offering an electric wheelchair, and then playing with mud, he had already walked on the edge of death several times.

"Where did you get so much money?"

Zhou Ze asked.

"I started streaming again. I got a lot of tips yesterday," the old Daoist explained.

This world is problematic,

Truly very problematic!

Even as calm and steady as Doctor Zhou, he couldn't help but fall into deep thought.

His neighbor Xu Qinglang was very rich,

His maid was very rich,

His wife was very rich,

And now,

The old Daoist he took in could easily produce 100,000 yuan!

Then he looked at himself, still in debt.

The man was happy to have attracted two more customers. He immediately turned his laptop towards them and began a detailed explanation of the rules and specific gameplay, while saying:

"Don't worry, this game is absolutely thrilling. This is a high-end game truly for the rich, because in this game, you can gamble with human lives, deciding life and death.

How about that,

Doesn't it feel like being a Ghost Messenger?"

The man made a joke, thinking himself witty and humorous.

The old Daoist's mouth twitched upon hearing that.

"Heh." Zhou Ze.

..................

"Boss, we really should have brought Bai Yingying. It would be more convenient for her to serve you."

The old Daoist was very sensible this time. He let Zhou Ze walk with his cane and didn't foolishly volunteer to carry Zhou Ze on his back again.

"If she came, there'd be no one to watch the bookstore," Zhou Ze replied.

"Ah, isn't there Miss Tang?"

"Her watching the store?"

Zhou Ze looked at the old Daoist,

The old Daoist looked at Zhou Ze,

Both shook their heads in silence,

Alright,

No need to say more,

Everything was understood without words.

Imagine Miss Tang Shi alone watching the store,

It's likely that if an irritable customer came in demanding coffee or hurrying to buy a book,

A pen might immediately fly over and pierce them into a honeycomb.

"Boss, be careful ahead, it's a bit bumpy."

Zhou Ze leaned on his cane, looking around.

This was a spot in Tongcheng's urban area, not very remote, but a bit far from the city center, and it was in the old district. Here, several small clinics and hospitals operated, along with many inns.

Of course, these small hospitals didn't look very legitimate.

There weren't many people coming and going on the street. If one had a sensitive nose, they could even smell disinfectant. All in all, the place gave off an uncomfortable feeling.

"The address is this way, right?" Zhou Ze asked.

"Yes, it should be here."

The two walked into the alley. Inside, the alley was a world of its own, with many doors. Zhou Ze and the old Daoist knocked on a door with a "203" sign.

Soon, a middle-aged man opened the door. He had a cigarette in his mouth and eyed Zhou Ze and the old Daoist with scrutiny.

"Let me see the account," the middle-aged man said.

"Here." The old Daoist handed him his phone.

The man verified it, nodded, and smiled, "You've already placed your bets, haven't even seen it yet?"

"That's why we came to see it," the old Daoist explained.

"Alright, come in."

The middle-aged man stepped aside, coughed, spat a thick gob of phlegm onto the ground, then wiped his snot with the back of his hand.

Zhou Ze and the old Daoist entered. It was a cramped space, with a spring bed, and many instruments placed beside it, somewhat resembling a hospital's intensive care unit, though far more rudimentary.

At the corner of the wall, two cameras were installed, monitoring every corner of the room in all directions.

An old man lay there, extremely emaciated, like a mummy in a pyramid. Even his skin had turned dark brown.

A bed,

An old man,

Profoundly exemplified an idiom— "oil runs out, lamp goes out" (meaning on the verge of death).

On the bedside table sat half a bowl of thin gruel.

The old man squinted, opening his eyes occasionally, but paid no attention to Zhou Ze and the old Daoist who had entered. He seemed used to it; people probably came in to see him often.

To see him,

When he would finally die.

He was the subject of many people's bets.

Many had already bet online on how much longer this old man would live.

A month? Two months? Three months?

The odds changed periodically, just like betting on football matches.

During this period, the old man was not allowed to receive any treatment. The instruments here were only for monitoring his physical condition, generating data reports that were uploaded daily to the platform for those who had bet and those who were about to bet to review and analyze.

At the same time, those who had placed bets had the right to come and see the old man's condition in person,

After all, what is learned from books is superficial; one must practice to truly know.

Is it absurd?

No,

It's not absurd.

The old man was looking at the clock.

On the wall, where he could see it as soon as he opened his eyes, there was a digital clock displaying the date and time.

On him,

Zhou Ze saw a trace of the old woman's expression from last night.

"Boss, what disease does he have?" The old Daoist knew Zhou Ze used to be a doctor and should be able to tell accurately.

"Cancer, late stage," Zhou Ze replied.

"Oh, an incurable disease."

"It's incurable, but with proper treatment, his life could be prolonged, and at the very least, his suffering could be reduced."

Clearly, this old man would not receive any treatment, because the platform's detailed rules stated that any treatment would constitute a breach of contract.

"Have you seen enough, gentlemen?"

The man approached, holding a bowl of instant noodles.

"Let's go," Zhou Ze said.

"Go?" The old Daoist was somewhat confused.

How could they just leave?

Damn it,

Help him!

This was real life-gambling.

Just letting people watch someone die in plain sight!

"Why not leave? He knows what we're here for," Zhou Ze pointed to the old man.

Clearly,

The old man knew he had been abandoned for treatment,

And,

He understood why he and the old Daoist, and others, came to see him every day.

Just like that old woman,

They all understood.

In fact,

They were even cooperating,

Like the old woman, who kept holding on to die on that specific day. This was her obsession, which caused her to become a wandering soul and enter the bookstore after she died, without realizing she was already dead.

"This..."

The old Daoist still felt uneasy in his conscience, but he followed his boss out anyway.

As they reached the doorway,

The middle-aged man leaned against the wall, slurping his instant noodles, and called out, "Hey, want to know some inside info?"

"What inside info?" the old Daoist turned his head to ask.

The middle-aged man rubbed his fingers together,

His meaning was clear: to get inside info, you had to spend more money.

"You can increase your bets, it's actually not a loss."

The man reminded them kindly.

"Hey, who are you to him? Why should we believe you?" the old Daoist countered.

In his eyes, the man was just a doorkeeper, a caregiver.

"I've also placed a bet."

The man took a sip of noodle soup, then gestured with his chin towards the room,

And said:

"He's my father."

title: 首訂兩萬！
content:
First subscription of twenty thousand<sup>1</sup>,

It's the best result Long has had since he started writing.

Thank you all for your support!

For a niche supernatural novel to achieve this result, Long is already proud enough.

Our first subscription has already broken the original highest first subscription record for supernatural novels by five times.

Five times!

Here, I want to thank the senior authors who encouraged me back then, thank Brother Bu Zheng, Brother Zhou Zi, Brother Xiao Qi, Brother Nai Qi, Sister Xuan Shui, and other brothers. When Long was most lost, they either comforted him or actively promoted his chapters.

Actually, many of the elder brothers and seniors who specifically came to encourage Long were people Long didn't know or were unfamiliar with before, and had never interacted with.

Therefore, it's easy to add to a splendor<sup>2</sup>, but Long will never forget the kindness of sending charcoal in the snow<sup>3</sup>.

I also want to thank Brother Yi Suo, the editor of the supernatural genre, Sister Zhu Sha, the responsible editor, and Brother Zi Liang.

I still remember when I stumbled last time, it was before the Chinese New Year.

Originally, it was agreed with the supernatural editors to release the new book after the New Year, but Long unilaterally changed his decision.

Without a book in hand, my heart felt panicked, as if life had lost its purpose. I couldn't just browse the comment sections or read the chapter discussions. I felt very lost and uneasy.

Then Long called the editor and said, "I want to publish my book."

At that time, the esteemed editors were already at the airport, preparing to go home for the New Year holiday. They called to help Long make new arrangements, which almost delayed their trip. Ultimately, Long was able to publish the book before the New Year.

At that time, Long made a promise: "Let me publish the book. I can't guarantee anything else, but the only thing I can guarantee is that no matter how unpopular the supernatural category was before, my new book will have a first subscription of ten thousand!"

As a dead otaku, referred to by readers as "Fat Long,"

Honestly,

This fat slob, besides writing books and stories, really has no other special skills.

Thank you to my old readers for your continuous companionship, and thank you to the new readers for joining and supporting me.

I stumbled once two months ago, but this time, Long got back up, and he stands twice as high as last time.

This is all due to everyone's great affection for Long.

Long can only repay everyone with better stories.

Many people ask Long if he's competing for the monthly ticket rankings.

To be honest, Long can't compete anymore. Since the later stages of "Horror Broadcast," Long's spirit has been very fatigued, and his body has subtly started to show some problems. Then, in the past few months, there have been many things and many twists and turns. Two new book periods are no less than two Gaokao exams.

After dealing with the matters of these few days since going on shelves, Long still needs to go to the hospital.

I'm tired, truly a bit tired. During the new book period of "Late Night Book House," Long more than once experienced back pain while sitting in a chair and sudden nosebleeds.

This body, after all, isn't made of iron.

However, at the time, I thought, even if I died and lay in a coffin, I'd still vigorously knock on the coffin lid a few times and shout:

"Tell me the first subscription results after it's on shelves, otherwise I won't rest in peace."

For the first two chapters on shelves, some readers might feel the style is a bit different from before. Actually, that was Long's own catharsis.

A breath held for two months, at that moment, Long released and vented it.

If I didn't vent it, it would be unbearable!

Long also knows that many old readers, like him, also need to vent.

Saying this isn't to evoke pity in order to better compete for the monthly ticket rankings.

What Long wants to say is that he doesn't plan to compete for the monthly ticket rankings anymore.

Long's biggest period of growth was during the writing of "Horror Broadcast." Every day, he focused on writing good chapters and publishing them. For an entire year, he didn't compete on any rankings or publish single chapters; he just concentrated on how to write stories and how to improve his writing skills, and then he wrote Uncle Fugui,

He wrote "Life and death are determined by fate, wealth and honor by heaven."<sup>4</sup>

In fact, sometimes Long even hesitates to post the concluding remarks at the end of a chapter, fearing it might affect everyone's reading experience.

"Late Night Book House,"

The title has already set the tone of the book.

This is a book house that opens in the dead of night,

It's a story that happens in the quiet of the night.

"Listen to it as a rumor, as I have heard"<sup>5</sup>,

The stories told in the book are also things Long has heard secondhand. I'll just retell them to everyone in a different way. Don't take them too seriously; just listen casually, treat them as a diversion, a way to pass the time.

So, let's try our best not to disrupt this atmosphere.

Long also doesn't want to lose his balance for the sake of competing for rankings, or write poorly paced or bad stories just to push for more updates.

Monthly tickets, I will still ask for them. If you have monthly tickets, just cast them for Long. For example, for this month's "New Book" monthly ticket ranking, we are determined to secure the first place.

As for other things, like competing for the overall ranking, that's up to everyone spontaneously. If you have a vote, just cast it for Long. If you enjoy it, feel free to give a reward.

A cent or a yuan is also love,

A helmsman<sup>6</sup> or an alliance leader<sup>7</sup> is also affection,

Of course, the more the merrier.

After this,

Long plans to seclude himself, ignore everything, and just focus on writing stories, and everyone can just focus on reading them.

May the years be peaceful,

May the book house's performance get better and better,

Finally,

I wish everyone good health.

<sup>1</sup> Refers to the number of initial subscribers to a serialized web novel. A high number indicates popularity and financial success.
<sup>2</sup> "锦上添花" (jǐn shàng tiān huā): Literally "add flowers to brocade," meaning to make something already good even better; to gild the lily.
<sup>3</sup> "雪中送炭" (xuě zhōng sòng tàn): Literally "send charcoal in the snow," meaning to provide timely help to someone in need; to offer help in dire circumstances.
<sup>4</sup> "生死由命富贵在天" (shēng sǐ yóu mìng fù guì zài tiān): A common Chinese saying meaning "Life and death are determined by fate, wealth and honor by Heaven."
<sup>5</sup> "姑妄听之，如是我闻" (gū wàng tīng zhī, rú shì wǒ wén): "Listen to it as a rumor, as I have heard." This phrase suggests the stories are not necessarily factual but are presented as heard, with an element of folklore or hearsay. "如是我闻" is also a common opening phrase in Buddhist sutras, meaning "Thus have I heard."
<sup>6</sup> "舵主" (duò zhǔ): In web novel communities, a "helmsman" is a specific tier of paid supporter, usually involving a significant donation.
<sup>7</sup> "盟主" (méng zhǔ): In web novel communities, an "alliance leader" is an even higher tier of paid supporter than a "helmsman," usually involving a very substantial donation.

title: 第一百零九章 我該死了沒有？
content:
“He’s my old man.”

A light, airy sentence,
but it seemed to have a deafening effect.

The middle-aged man took out a cigarette from his pocket, lit one for himself, and offered one each to Zhou Ze and the old Taoist.

The old Taoist remained blankly still.

Zhou Ze, however, calmly took the cigarette and lit it.

“So, have you thought about it?” the middle-aged man continued to persuade. “Don’t worry, I won’t scam you. I can show you the orders I’ve placed. Then you can just place your orders at the same time as me.”

“You’re a good son,” Zhou Ze said, exhaling a smoke ring.

The middle-aged man frowned slightly and sneered, “Are you in on this deal or not? Speak.”

He wasn't stupid; he could obviously hear the sarcasm in Zhou Ze's words.

“Why not?” Zhou Ze said.

“Good, five thousand, not expensive, right? You’ve already bet a hundred thousand. Two orders, a hundred thousand. Another five thousand will guarantee your profit.”

When money was mentioned, the middle-aged man began to get excited, completely disregarding Zhou Ze’s previous mockery.

“What if your old man doesn’t make it?” Zhou Ze asked.

“How could that happen? He’s my old man, and he knows I’ve bet on him too. Don’t worry, I’ll cheer him on, make him hold on. Even if he dies, he’ll have gotten something first.”

The middle-aged man had a look of everything-under-control,
as if at this moment,
father and son were truly connected,
and a thick father-son bond permeated the air, moving and astonishing those who witnessed it.

“When a person dies is unpredictable,” Zhou Ze reminded him. “Even a *gui chai* cannot pinpoint it.”

*Gui chai* cannot casually take a living person’s life. Of course, it’s not impossible, but the cost is too great. A slight misstep could lead to eternal damnation.

“Heh heh, if you have the guts, tell the *gui chai* to come take my old man now.”

The middle-aged man spat out another wad of phlegm, then took out his phone.
“You can just transfer the money to me directly. Once the money’s transferred, I’ll show you my orders right away.”

“This humble Taoist will transfer your mother’s *cao hai*!”

The old Taoist directly clenched his fist and slammed it toward the man’s forehead.

*Bang!*

The middle-aged man was stunned by the punch and fell to the ground. He tried to get up and resist, but the old Taoist stared at him with eyes like a glaring ox.

He cowered.
You really can’t expect a man who relies on his father’s life to get rich to have much backbone or spirit.

“You wait, you hit me, didn’t you? I’m calling the police!”

The man immediately reached for his phone that had fallen to the ground.

“Call them. We’ll wait,” Zhou Ze said.

The man’s eyelids twitched. He didn’t dare to call the police, truly didn’t. At the moment, he picked up his phone, glared fiercely at the old Taoist, then walked into the house, shut the door, and locked it from the inside.

The old Taoist let out a long breath, turned around somewhat dejectedly, looked at Zhou Ze, and said,
“Boss, I’m sorry, this humble Taoist got carried away.”

“It’s fine,” Zhou Ze said indifferently, asking, “Why did you suddenly get so agitated?”

“The biggest regret of this humble Taoist’s life is that when my father died, I was away in another city and didn’t make it back in time to see him one last time.

That brat’s words really disgusted this humble Taoist. He’s a complete beast; his conscience must have been eaten by dogs, earning money off his own father’s life.”

Zhou Ze flicked the ash off his cigarette and said nothing.

“Boss, don’t you feel anything else?” the old Taoist asked, pressing his lips together. “Anyone would be annoyed by such a beast, right?”

“I’m an orphan.”

“…………” the old Taoist.

Zhou Ze smiled, exhaling a smoke ring, and said, “Actually, I’ve seen many similar things in hospitals. At first, I couldn’t understand it either,

and I was even very angry.

A long illness makes a child unfilial—of course, there are many unfilial children, but the vast majority of people actually want to cure their family members.

Although national medical insurance and rural social security are becoming widespread, and medical conditions are improving year by year, if someone truly suffers from a terminal or serious illness, it’s like pouring money into a bottomless pit.”

Zhou Ze flicked the cigarette butt from his hand, making a “throwing” motion.

“Human lives are more important than money,” the old Taoist still insisted on his view.

“Human lives are indeed more important than money. ‘Life is priceless’ is indeed a well-known slogan, but the value of anything can actually be measured; it simply depends on the perspective.

For example, to treat a seriously ill elder, a family might borrow heavily, turning an ordinary family into paupers, and then the elder’s illness might still not be cured, and they pass away anyway.

Then how should that family’s life, the children’s education, and their future be managed?

I once encountered a case where an elderly man secretly ran out of the hospital. We found him. His son was very filial and was willing to sell everything to treat him, begging him on his knees to return to the hospital for treatment.

But he didn’t want to burden his son. He said he either wanted to go home and wait to die, or he would rush onto the road and get hit by a car. In short, he didn’t want to stay in the hospital spending money and implicating his son.”

The old Taoist pressed his lips together upon hearing this.

“This is the helplessness of life. This helplessness runs through history, regardless of East or West. People always have to face choices, and sometimes these choices are truly cruel.”

The old Taoist smiled bitterly, “So, are we still calling the police?”

“Yes, why not?” Zhou Ze looked at the old Taoist, “Life can sometimes be helpless, but life should not be desecrated.

It can wither in helplessness, but it should not be churned in a septic tank.

Gambling with human lives, treating the lives of their own kind like fighting cocks, crickets, or dogs, for fun, for thrills—these people deserve to go to hell.

When we get back, I’ll give you some ghost money; you can burn it.”

Upon hearing this, the old Taoist instinctively rubbed his hands, saying awkwardly,
“How could I accept that, Boss? It’s only right for me to work for you. It’s just a hundred thousand yuan, right? What’s the big deal? Am I such a petty person?”

Immediately after, as if afraid Zhou Ze would go back on his word, the old Taoist quickly continued,
“If you insist on giving it, Boss, I wouldn’t want to refuse your kindness.”

“You’re overthinking it. Burning ghost money is for you to gain some *yin de* (yin virtue), and then to turn yourself in as a material witness when you report the case. You were also involved in the gambling, but it’s estimated that your merits and demerits will cancel out, plus the effect of the ghost money, nothing will happen.”

“…………” the old Taoist.

Zhou Ze walked forward, leaning on his cane, while the old Taoist followed dejectedly behind, probably drawing circles in his mind.

Just then, Zhou Ze suddenly stopped.

“Boss, tired?” the old Taoist asked.

*My boss abuses me a thousand times, but I treat him like my first love.*

This was a fundamental rule for serving a ghost that the old Taoist knew well, otherwise, the ghost might turn him into one too.

“Something’s wrong. What time is it now?” Zhou Ze asked.

“It’s four-thirty in the afternoon,” the old Taoist said, glancing at his phone.

“Why is the sky so overcast?” Zhou Ze pointed up.

“It’s going to rain, probably,” the old Taoist guessed.

“But the weather forecast said no rain today,” Zhou Ze said.

“The weather forecast predicts an 80% chance of rain tomorrow. There are probably only ten people on their team, and then they vote by a show of hands. If eight people think it will rain, then it’s an 80% chance.”

“Then, what about over there?” Zhou Ze pointed to the distant sky.

The old Taoist looked and was immediately stunned. Over there, the sky was clear and sunny.

This eerie contrast was truly alarming. This wasn't Yunnan or a plateau; it was the Yangtze River Delta plain region, where such a scene of sun in the east and rain in the west was very rare.

“Something’s wrong,” Zhou Ze said, then he looked at a large gate to the right, with a sign that read “Xinrui Hospital.” Inside the gate was a large clock.

It was a decorative clock, very large.

Zhou Ze pushed the gate open and walked inside, with the old Taoist following him.

“Hey, what are you doing?”

Just then, a hospital security guard approached.

This hospital was actually very small, probably without much accreditation. All the departments, including the inpatient ward, were in a three-story building. There was only one security guard, not an old man, but a burly man with a tough face wearing a security uniform.

“Just looking around,” Zhou Ze replied.

“What’s there to see?” the security guard barked.

“Hey, are you out of your mind? The hospital’s open, and you won’t let us in?” the old Taoist retorted immediately.

Ever heard of a fox borrowing a tiger’s prestige?

This humble Taoist is a dog relying on a ghost’s power,
I’ll scare you to death!

Wait, did something sound wrong?

“This isn’t a place for seeing patients. If you need to see a doctor, go somewhere else. Also, this is private property, no tours. Go, go, go…”

The security guard completely ignored the old Taoist and came up, ready to shoo them away.

Zhou Ze looked at the large clock placed at the entrance of the hospital hall, lost in thought.

The old Taoist stepped forward and collided directly with the security guard.

*My boss is doing something very important… err, daydreaming, but you can’t disturb him!*

“You want to fight, don’t you?” the security guard pointed at the old Taoist.

“Come on, try it!” the old Taoist retorted.

In terms of combat, the old Taoist truly wasn’t afraid!

“Do you know what this hospital does?” Zhou Ze asked, looking at the clock.

“None of your damn business. This is just a crematorium, and it has nothing to do with you. If you know what’s good for you, hurry up and get out. If you lost money gambling, don’t come here looking for trouble, go find the bookmaker!”

The security guard shouted directly.

Zhou Ze nodded.
It seemed he knew.

Then Zhou Ze reached out and patted the old Taoist’s shoulder.
“Let’s go.”

“Boss, why are you so cowardly today… *sigh of relief*, haha, no fighting, good, no fighting, everyone makes money peacefully, makes money peacefully.”

The old Taoist chuckled, then followed Zhou Ze out.

The security guard glanced at the two people walking out, and “hmph” a sound from his nose.

Walking out onto the street, Zhou Ze lit another cigarette.

The old Taoist was a bit dejected.
He felt that this boss wasn’t as inspiring as the previous one. If it were the previous boss, when that guy said, “He’s my old man,” the former boss would probably have made the father see his child buried.

This current boss was too disciplined, too self-restrained.

“He’s a living person, he’s not under my jurisdiction,” Zhou Ze explained.

“Mm,” the old Taoist responded weakly.

“Old Taoist, I really don’t like this place,” Zhou Ze said.

“This humble Taoist doesn’t like it either,” the old Taoist echoed.

“What time is it?” Zhou Ze asked again.

“Four forty-three.”

Zhou Ze, with the cigarette between his fingers, nodded and said,
“It’s coming out.”

…

The security guard picked up his walkie-talkie and said, “Hey, surveillance room? Those two guys who just came in, I chased them away. They don’t look like they lost money and came to cause trouble.”

As he finished speaking, the walkie-talkie suddenly emitted a dense static.

“Hello? Hello?” The security guard patted the walkie-talkie, “What a crappy machine.”

*Dong… dong…*

The large clock beside him chimed.
The security guard subconsciously turned his head, then frowned, and then scratched his head, leaning closer. *Damn it, it’s not on the hour, why are you chiming?*

Four forty-three… four minutes.

Just then, the security guard suddenly saw the sound of gears grinding from inside the large clock. The sound was loud, very terrifying,
and carried a sense of juice being crushed and splashed, like a large piece of pork being churned in a blender.

The security guard was confused and instinctively took a step back.

Immediately after,
he saw a hand slowly reaching out from the large clock.
This hand looked as if it had just been crushed by gears, completely mangled and bloody. It also had a dense layer of tiny holes,
and maggots were peeking out of each hole.

This image,
was definitely a nightmare for anyone with trypophobia.

The surrounding temperature,
suddenly dropped,
giving one the illusion of falling into an ice cellar.

The security guard was so scared his body started trembling. He wanted to run, he wanted to scream, but his legs felt like they were filled with lead and couldn’t move at all.

This hand slowly grasped the security guard’s neck.
A terrifying force came from the arm, pulling the security guard closer to the large clock.

The security guard’s face was pressed against the outer wall of the clock, his face almost distorted.

An eerie, trembling voice came from the walkie-talkie:
“What… time… is… it…? Am… Am… I… supposed to… die… yet?”

title: 第一百一十章 人知鬼恐怖
content:
Tick... tock... tick... tock...

The hands of the clock were moving.

Few people paid attention to these subtle changes. People always said to cherish time, shouting "an inch of time is an inch of gold," but those who truly lived by it were few and far between.

Yet, many had experienced this feeling: suddenly, you quieted down and heard the "tick-tock" of the hands. You could clearly perceive time quietly slipping away, and with it, your life.

This was a chilling silence, a goosebump-inducing quiet. In the ethereal realm, it was as if a Ledger of Life and Death truly existed, on which everyone's fate had already been written.

People lived only to complete this process.

According to the Ledger of Life and Death, they were born.

Then, according to the Ledger of Life and Death, they died.

This was the great terror hidden within time.

In the basement of the Unlicensed Hospital, the space wasn't large, but it was divided into small rooms, each containing a bed.

Some beds had people lying on them.

Some beds previously had people lying on them.

Some beds were waiting for the next person to lie on them.

This wasn't hell, yet it carried the very breath of death.

Around them, some doctors and nurses moved constantly, but here, in this hospital, they were not the white-clad angels of healing and compassion that people commonly knew.

They simply observed and recorded, noting down each target's data and then uploading it online.

It was like playing football lottery; the odds would constantly change. A star player on a team suddenly getting injured, a head coach suddenly being replaced—all sorts of on-field and off-field factors would cause the odds to shift.

Here, it was the same. The vital signs data of each person would excite gamblers sitting in front of computer screens, making them read meticulously.

They probably wouldn't even read their own parents' medical records as diligently as this.

From the real-time surveillance videos and the details within various data, they sought their judgments and threw out their chips.

This was a game of life-and-death gambling. What the gamblers gained here was not just the return on their odds but also the thrill of controlling life.

And these thrills were built upon the trampling of their fellow humans' lives.

A woman who had been lying in bed suddenly struggled to sit up for some reason. At this moment, it was exactly the shift change for the nearby doctors and nurses, and the staff in the monitoring room might have been slacking off, failing to notify of the woman's abnormal movement.

The woman pulled out the tubes attached to her body. She struggled to get out of bed, but she rolled directly onto the floor.

She was much younger than the others on the beds, appearing to be in her thirties or forties, but her body was clearly severely swollen. Her calves were unimaginably thick, almost swollen into a single mass.

She couldn't stand up. Every day, even her food intake was strictly rationed by quantity and type, with no excess, all for the sake of fairness.

The fairness people pursued was most thoroughly implemented and carried out in this aspect.

She was crawling.

She was trying hard to crawl.

She crawled to the door. The door was ajar. She pushed it open with effort and continued crawling out. She was like Sadako crawling out of a television, dressed in white, with disheveled hair, but she was still alive.

Of course, she wouldn't live much longer. The candle of life on her was already flickering, on the verge of extinguishing.

She was lucky. She crawled out of the narrow ward, into the corridor, and to the office door. Along the way, no one passed by, and no one discovered her.

Her hand rested on the office door. She wanted to ask the doctor inside to let her make a phone call.

There was an electronic clock in her ward, displaying the date and time.

Today was her son's fifth birthday.

She wanted to remind her husband to celebrate their son's birthday.

Thinking of her son, a smile appeared on her lips. Her son was her deepest bond. After ten months of pregnancy, what normal mother wouldn't love her child?

She had this illness, and it was incurable. Their family's financial situation was already poor, and her husband was addicted to gambling and unemployed. Previously, the family had relied on her working outside to support them. Now, she had this illness that modern medicine was powerless against.

She couldn't bear to throw their already meager family savings into treating herself. Her son was about to start kindergarten, then school. Now, and in the future, they would all need money.

Her husband knelt before her, asking her to come here.

She knew what kind of place this was. She knew what those two cameras in the ward were for.

She agreed. She consented.

Dying at home was death, and dying here was also death. She knew she had become a chip, but at least by being this chip, the platform would give her family a large sum of money.

Her family needed money, and her child, growing up, also needed money.

Her husband knelt before her and promised that he would turn over a new leaf, become a good person, a good father, and raise their son well.

She knew she was dying soon.

She had been staring at the timetable.

She wanted to hold on.

To hold on and remind her husband to celebrate their son's birthday. She wanted to last until this day.

This was why she, lying in her sickbed, unable to receive any treatment, not even pain medication, enduring the torment of her illness every day, had held onto a breath of life and hadn't died yet.

She pushed the door.

It wouldn't move.

She was already very tired.

She had little strength left in her body.

Inside the office, sounds of arguing could be heard.

The voices of the arguing parties were very familiar: one was the main doctor who examined her three times a day—morning, noon, and night—and the other was her husband.

She smiled.

Her husband was actually here.

Then she could tell him about their son's birthday in person.

She could also ask her husband to relay a few words to her son. As a mother, she would be in heaven, always accompanying her child's growth.

"Why isn't she dead yet, why isn't she dead yet!" her husband roared.

"How should I know? Your own wife isn't dying, and you blame us?" This was the doctor's voice.

"But I bet 200,000 that she would die last week. I thought she wouldn't live past last week."

"Your wife has astonishing vitality. She's practically a medical miracle. She's been off medication for so long; any ordinary person would have collapsed by now."

"It was you, you told me, you told me she would die last week! That's why I dared to bet 200,000, 200,000!"

"Let go, let go of me! Are you crazy? I'm not the King of Hell; I can't control who lives or dies."

"You can't control it, yet you leaked this information to me and took a kickback from me? You deliberately harmed me! Do you know, this 200,000 is money my wife traded her life for!"

"If you keep this up, I'll call security."

"Please help, I'll bet another 100,000. Can you make her die this week? Give her an injection secretly, make her die this week, that way I can break even and even make a profit!"

"Another 100,000? Where did you get another 100,000?"

"I sold my son, 100,000 yuan!

Once I turn my fortunes around and break even with this bet, I'll buy my son back.

Doctor, please help, secretly kill her. Otherwise, I'll have no wife and no son!"

"Heh, you're something else. I'm sorry, there are rules here, and cameras are monitoring. I won't do such a thing."

"Then what do I do, what do I do?

Oh, doctor, let me see her, let me see her once. Which ward is she in? I'll go see her, I'll make her die, this week. She'll understand!

If she doesn't die, our son won't be redeemed, and all the family's money will be gone. She loves me very much, and she loves her son. If you just let me see her once, she'll definitely be willing to die for our son.

Doctor, I beg you,

Doctor, I beg you, doctor."

"This doesn't meet the requirements. We're not some wild, unregulated place. We are very legitimate, and it's because we're legitimate that we have the most clients betting with us."

"Here, take this, take it. When you do your check-up, please pass on a message for me. And you can also place a bet; trust me, she will die, she's willing."

The voices of the two men continued,

And the woman outside the door,

Had stopped breathing.

But her eyes,

Were wide open.

On the closed door,

There were still scratches, marks made by fingernails.

………………

Outside the hospital, Zhou Ze and the Old Daoist stood there.

"Old Daoist, do you have any more of those talismans?"

"None left, inherited ones, long gone.

The last two were used up when I was taking pictures of hair at the bookstore last time."

The Old Daoist said sincerely, "If this poor Daoist still had them, I would definitely give them to you, Boss."

"Oh," Zhou Ze responded.

The Old Daoist sighed in relief, then unconsciously reached into his crotch.

The next moment,

His crotch suddenly felt hot,

So hot that the Old Daoist immediately jumped up, quickly reaching in to pull out a scorching red talisman.

"Whoa, whoa... hiss, hiss... So hot, so hot."

While patting his crotch, the Old Daoist saw Zhou Ze looking at him, and immediately said:

"Hahahaha, Boss, isn't this amazing? I actually forgot I had one more in my crotch. It's the very last one, truly the last one."

"I wasn't going to ask you for it," Zhou Ze said.

"What?"

"I was originally going to remind you that later, there will be a very powerful vengeful ghost returning on its seventh day, and its resentment might be quite strong. If your talisman is still hidden in your crotch, it might hurt a lot."

The Old Daoist's face immediately contorted into an old, tender chrysanthemum:

"Boss, why didn't you say so sooner?"

"You said you didn't have any, so I believed you."

"…………" Old Daoist.

Continuously rubbing his crotch, dispelling the burning sensation, the Old Daoist looked at the hospital ahead. The light inside seemed much dimmer. Even though the Old Daoist had little Taoist magic, he could sense that something had happened inside the hospital.

"Old Daoist, what's your take?" Zhou Ze asked.

The Old Daoist was stunned.

What did he mean, "what's my take"?

Are you a ghost or am I a ghost?

Are you a ghost messenger or am I a ghost messenger?

It's haunted in there, and you're asking me for my take.

What kind of nonsense question is that!

But the Old Daoist immediately replied with seriousness:

"Boss, there must be something fishy going on here!"

"Heh."

The Old Daoist felt a bit inexplicable.

After a while, seeing that Zhou Ze had no intention of going in, he said, "Boss, these scum, they're definitely scum, not worth helping."

The Old Daoist was worried that Zhou Ze would just walk in and catch ghosts.

He knew Zhou Ze's character; he was very adherence to rules, completely different from his previous boss.

"We went in, but the security guards inside chased us out," Zhou Ze said.

"Hmm?"

"This vengeful ghost's seventh day return has immense resentment, so it's very unusual. Furthermore, in this place, every so often, someone dies staring at the clock, layer after layer of resentment accumulating, all finally falling upon this ghost. That's why her return on the seventh day has such a great impact.

She even has the ability to harm ordinary people."

"That fierce?" The Old Daoist smacked his lips. Why did he feel a little excited?

It would be best if these scumbags died, served them right!

"Actually, she wouldn't have become so exaggerated all at once," Zhou Ze added.

"Then what happened?" The Old Daoist looked around. "Is there some mysterious person nearby instigating this?"

Zhou Ze nodded.

The Old Daoist immediately widened his eyes and said in a deep voice, "Can we find them, Boss?"

Zhou Ze shook his head.

"Then what do we do? What if that guy has ulterior motives?" The Old Daoist was a bit anxious.

"That person probably severed the connection between the great clock and that female ghost, which is equivalent to opening the cage that held the female ghost. This is a demon unleashed.

If that security guard hadn't stopped me, I could have prevented this. Sigh."

"No, don't..." The Old Daoist spoke halfway, then chuckled awkwardly, "Boss, how about I go in with you right now?"

The Boss needed to catch ghosts for performance, so the Old Daoist could only choose to follow.

"Not going. The security guard is too fierce and too strong. Both of us, an old man and a cripple, can't beat him."

"I can..." The Old Daoist had intended to volunteer. That security guard looked like a brute, but the Old Daoist was confident he could handle him, and besides, he didn't know what the ghost inside had done to that guy.

But a scene suddenly came to the Old Daoist's mind.

The Boss just said that someone severed the connection between the female ghost and the great clock, unleashing the evil spirit.

The Old Daoist remembered that when he and that security guard were bickering and arguing,

The Boss, standing behind the great clock, seemed to have used his fingernails to fiddle with the clock.

Yes,

He remembered correctly!

"Boss, I can't beat him. I'm old, useless."

The Old Daoist pretended to be very dejected, and even winked at Zhou Ze.

Zhou Ze was noncommittal,

Placing his hand to his mouth,

He gently,

Blew on his fingernails...

title: 第一百一十一章 鬼曉人心毒
content:
"Ahhhhhh!!!!"

"Ahhhhhhh!!!!!"

"Ahhhhhhh!!!!!"

Screams continuously echoed from the small hospital. The old Daoist stood at the entrance, watching many people in white coats run out as if something was chasing them.

But they just kept running in circles in the small courtyard, falling and getting back up, seemingly unable to see the door, and no one ran out of it.

"Is this... a ghost's wall?" The old Daoist asked Zhou Ze, looking at him.

Zhou Ze ignored him and continued to watch.

He saw a woman relentlessly chasing people, asking:

"Am I supposed to die yet?"

"What time is it?"

"Am I supposed to die?"

She was anxious,
She was desperate,
She was bewildered,
As if, if she didn't die at the fixed time, her son couldn't be redeemed.
If she didn't die at the regulated time, her family would be shattered.
If she didn't die at the regulated time, she would have made a huge mistake!

Zhou Ze's brows furrowed deeper the more he watched.

The old Daoist couldn't see what was happening inside, so he was completely confused, but watching a group of living people screaming and running around, constantly falling, was quite amusing, like watching monkeys in a circus. And some of the female nurses, wearing skirts, tore their clothes as they ran and fell, revealing large expanses of their bodies:

Lacy,
Hollowed-out,
And even Peppa Pig!

The old Daoist, with the thought of getting some interest back for those victims, almost had his eyeballs pop out. Anyway, he kept looking at all the places he shouldn't.

Finally, Zhou Ze couldn't watch anymore; he genuinely couldn't.

"Truly... an idiotic teammate."

The old Daoist heard this and froze for a moment, instantly feeling very wronged, his old face wrinkled into a tender chrysanthemum.

Boss, don't be so discouraging, right?

I was just looking...

You don't look, you're not interested, you're hard... erm... but I'm still normal!

Zhou Ze reached out to the old Daoist for a lighter, just then seeing the old Daoist looking at him with a wronged expression. He then seemed to understand something and smiled:

"I wasn't talking about you."

"Then who were you talking about?" The old Daoist truly didn't understand.

"Her."

With that, Zhou Ze pushed the door open and walked in, leaning on his cane.

The old Daoist followed him in. Anyway, wherever the boss went, he went, because no matter how amazing the boss was, he still needed a sidekick to butter him up and shout "6666."

The old Daoist had always been precise about his self-positioning.

However, the moment he followed the boss inside, the old Daoist felt a chill run through him, as if someone with cold hands had gently slid them across his back while he slept, giving him a finger-tip tour.

That thrill,
Directly made the old Daoist's flaccid sack shrink into a large walnut.

Then, a female nurse suddenly ran in front of the old Daoist and fell right before him. The old Daoist quickly bent down to help her up.

"Are you okay? Are you okay?"

While helping her, his hand instinctively took advantage.

Hmm, this is also acting on behalf of Heaven!

However, what surprised the old Daoist was that the anticipated soft sensation didn't appear. Instead, his hand, with the force he used, directly pierced into the female nurse's chest.

"Hiss..."

The old Daoist gasped in fear and began to retreat, but the female nurse was like a maggot in the bone, clinging to him.

"Oh my god, Boss, help me, help me!"

The female nurse in his arms suddenly lifted her head.

Her face began to become rough and swollen, pitted with holes, and maggots and crawling insects wriggled and moved about inside, going back and forth.

She bared her teeth,
Her mouth full of yellow teeth, a large fleshy tumor protruded from her mouth. The tumor was yellowish-green, looking like it could burst at any moment.

"What time is it, am I supposed to die yet?"

The female nurse asked the old Daoist.

The old Daoist was so scared he fumbled with his crotch, only then realizing he had thrown away the talisman earlier because his crotch was burning.

This action successfully caught the female nurse's attention, and her hand also reached for the old Daoist's crotch.

"Oh oh oh oh oh oh!!!!!"

The old Daoist felt as if his "thing," which had shrunk from a gluten stick to a caterpillar, instantly shrank even further.

That walnut was almost frozen into a marble.

So cold,
The female nurse's hand was so cold,
So cold the old Daoist couldn't bear it,
This feeling was like stripping naked on a Himalayan peak and pole dancing towards the sunrise,
Thrilling and deadly!

The old Daoist quickly raised both hands. No one was holding a gun to him, but someone was holding his gun,
So, surrendering was an instinctive action.

Boss,
Where did you go?
Your loyal Daoist is about to be cut off from his lineage!

"Enough!"

Zhou Ze's voice came.

The old Daoist felt that Zhou Ze's voice at this moment was even more pleasant than those beautiful female celebrities on TV. It was a pity he couldn't see where the boss was standing, otherwise, he really wanted to rush over and kiss him hard!

"Dong... dong..."

The bell rang, signaling the time to go home.
All the surrounding scenes disappeared, and the terrifying coldness in the old Daoist's crotch also began to fade, leaving only a lingering numbness. He was almost scared to the point of collapse, directly dropping to his knees.

He looked up and saw Zhou Ze standing by the large clock.

In Zhou Ze's hand, there was a minute hand that had just been broken off.

"Zzzzzzzzz... zzzzzzzzzzz..."

A faint, scratching sound came from the cement floor, like a broken electrical wire, but it was very grating, making one's scalp tingle.

The old Daoist looked around. Several doctors and nurses, including the burly security guard, lay motionless around him. They weren't dead; they were scared unconscious.

"Tell me... what time is it... am I supposed to die yet?"

From behind the large clock, a woman in white climbed out. Her face was blank as she first stared at the old Daoist, making him shiver again. Then, inadvertently, she extended her finger and pointed at Zhou Ze on the other side.

There,
Big sister,
The big boss is over there. You should fight the big boss first. I'm just a small fry.

The female ghost was indeed cooperative and turned to look at Zhou Ze on the other side.

Then, she began to crawl towards Zhou Ze.

Zhou Ze looked at her, very disappointed.

This was genuine disappointment.

In his previous life, Zhou Ze was a doctor. He always upheld his professional ethics. Although he didn't have the grand dream of "saving all beings" or the selfless dedication, in his work, he always adhered to "people-oriented" principles.

This small hospital was a microcosm of this street, a microcosm of this black gambling industry chain. It made Zhou Ze feel oppressed and very uncomfortable.

It was the kind of discomfort where,
If you don't do something, you feel like you won't sleep well tonight.
And these doctors and nurses lying unconscious on the ground, if there were no surprises, should also have come from proper medical schools or nursing schools, with their own professional skills, definitely not just filling positions.

Yet, this group of people violated their ethics, violated the fundamental duties of a doctor. They learned the skills to heal and save lives, but they stood by dying patients, merely recording a series of cold data.

Then,
They watched the patient die with cold eyes, absolutely refusing to offer aid, because aid and medication would affect the fairness of the gambling.

There's a saying popular among doctors: "Encouraging someone to study medicine is like inviting a lightning strike from Heaven."

Most doctors' work is far from as leisurely and comfortable as commonly perceived in society. The vast majority of medical personnel face great dangers every day, from exposure to infection in the operating room, heavy workloads, and even... medical disputes.

But since they put on that pure white uniform, they must live up to their identity.

That's right,
Zhou Ze wanted them to die.
Whether it was out of impulse or pique, at that moment, Zhou Ze truly wished for all the dregs of this industry to go to hell!

To toy with human lives, to find pleasure in human lives, this was a blasphemy against life. And as someone who had died once, Zhou Ze understood the preciousness of life even more.

Since you treat human lives as tools for cockfighting or dogfighting, then I can also choose not to treat you as humans.

The old Daoist could beat the burly security guard, and even though Zhou Ze leaned on a cane, with one fingernail, he could bring down an ox.

But Zhou Ze naturally backed away, exclaiming, "Can't mess with that, can't mess with that."

Some things, it wasn't convenient for him to act, so he wanted to watch the fire from across the river, to observe from a safe distance.

He was indulging, he was passively dealing with it,
The purpose,
Was to kill with a borrowed knife.

Anyway, it was inevitable that you would become a malevolent ghost. You could no longer enter the cycle of reincarnation. Even if you went to hell, you could only endure endless karmic fires until your soul was scattered.

So,
Why not give you a chance,
To clean up this garbage dump,
You'll be satisfied,
I'll be satisfied,
And the smog in this sky can dissipate a bit.

But this woman in front of him,
She was like an idiot!

Zhou Ze gave her a chance, even secretly pushing her. She was much stronger than ordinary malevolent ghosts and had the ability to seek revenge.

But her so-called revenge was just scaring people unconscious?

When they woke up, they would be fine again?

"Zzzzzzzzz... zzzzzzzzz... zzzzzzzzz..."

The female ghost continued to crawl towards Zhou Ze, then looked at him pitifully, asking:

"What time is it, am I supposed to die yet?
Please,
Tell me, tell me..."

Zhou Ze slowly bent down, looking at the female ghost's pockmarked face, and asked:

"Don't you hate them?"

Yes, don't you hate them?

"What time is it?" The female ghost continued to ask.

Zhou Ze then pointed at the unconscious nurses and doctors below and asked, "Don't you want revenge?"

They placed you on a cold bed, watching you die. Don't you want revenge on them? Don't you want revenge on those gamblers, on those behind-the-scenes bookmakers who count their money happily, on the husband who personally pushed you into the abyss of despair—revenge?

"Please tell me what time it is, I'm calculating if I should die. If I die, I'll get money, my husband will get money, our family will have money, and our son can be redeemed.
Please tell me, tell me, what time is it, what time is it!
I must die at the appointed time. My family needs money, my son needs money when he grows up, he needs money for school, and he'll need money for marriage later.
What time is it,
Please tell me, tell me!!!!!!!!!"

The female ghost seemed very angry at Zhou Ze's repeated disregard of her question. She began to become incredibly furious, so furious she wanted to strangle Zhou Ze!

Zhou Ze paused,
This female ghost,
She didn't have murderous intent towards those doctors and nurses,
But she had murderous intent towards him?

For a moment, Zhou Ze wanted to laugh, and then he did laugh.

"Hehehe..."

Laughing, Zhou Ze slowly stood up.

The female ghost instinctively lunged at Zhou Ze,

"What are you laughing at? Answer me the time, what time is it!"

Zhou Ze stretched out his hand, his fingernail directly piercing the female ghost's glabella. The female ghost let out a bloodcurdling scream. Zhou Ze's fingernail was like a soldering iron, causing her terrifying pain.

"Boss?" The old Daoist walked over at this moment.

Zhou Ze closed his eyes. He thought of the old woman who came to the bookstore that night, crying heartbrokenly because she had died prematurely and was unwilling. He thought of the old man he saw earlier, being watched by his son, lying in bed, waiting for the time to die.

Human life is precious, but the premise is that one knows how to cherish it and how to respect it;
Life is your own. If you don't cherish it yourself, don't blame others for looking down on your life!

Zhou Ze shook his head,
And said:
"Old Daoist, I think I made a mistake. I seem to have meddled too much."

"Hmm?" The old Daoist still didn't understand.

Zhou Ze opened his eyes, glanced at the several doctors and nurses lying unconscious on the ground, and said:

"I found that I don't hate these guys as much as before."

"Uh, why? They're just a bunch of beasts," the old Daoist said.

Zhou Ze looked at the female ghost twisting and struggling under his palm,
And said:
"Yes,
They are indeed beasts,
But those who are pitiful must also have something hateful about them."

title: 第一百一十二章 瞞天過海！
content:
The female ghost, under Zhou Ze's fingernails, was beaten until her soul body was damaged, even becoming transparent and unreal.

She was in great pain, she was suffering greatly, she was pitiful, but for Zhou Ze, while he could try to use her to kill others, he could never allow her to leave the hospital, nor could he allow her to leave his sight and control.

Now, she couldn’t serve as a blade, so she could only be sent to where she belonged.

The Gate of Hell opened,

Zhou Ze grabbed the female ghost by the shoulder with one hand and threw her directly inside. After being severely wounded by his fingernails, the female ghost had no power or strength left to resist.

Clapping his hands, Zhou Ze took out his certificate book, which had increased to twenty-five percent.

The收益 from this female ghost was quite high, not because Zhou Ze had simply gone with the flow, but because this female ghost was originally a grotesque being, born from the accumulated resentments of many people who had died on this street.

Unfortunately, she lacked the brutality of a powerful ghost as imagined; a typical mismatch between her appearance and identity.

Zhou Ze leaned on his cane and began to walk out. He didn't want to stay there any longer, unwilling to linger in a place that made him, a ghost messenger, feel uncomfortable and depressed.

The old Daoist followed along. After they reached the street corner, the old Daoist subconsciously looked back. Inside, there were several similar small hospitals and clinics, and of course, many illicit operations hidden in the corners.

This was the human world,

Yet it was more like an incinerator of hell.

In the invisible sky, it was as if chimneys rose from the ground, with smoke billowing. And those people lying on beds, painfully waiting to die, were like cartloads of coal slag being sent into the incinerator.

“Boss, back to the bookstore?” the old Daoist asked.

Zhou Ze nodded.

“Boss, it’s not worth getting angry over that. Just look at it with an open mind. That female ghost was actually quite pitiful. At least, she was a good mother.”

“That’s precisely what makes me feel sad.”

“Boss, you say that pitiful people must have something detestable about them, but I disagree. I think she did nothing wrong. Anyway, since death was inevitable, why not sell herself before dying to leave some income for her family? It’s human nature, even though human life shouldn't be bought and sold. But when it really comes to that point, using one's last remaining value is actually understandable.

Moreover, her actions didn't harm anyone. It was a matter of mutual consent.”

“Old Daoist, have you ever been arrested by the police?” Zhou Ze suddenly asked.

“Uh, a few times, that was because…”

“Have you ever been caught in a prostitution raid?”

“Uh, no, not that. Lucky me. Sometimes I was on edge though, being this old. Even though I was trying to care for those fallen women, my intentions were good, but I was afraid of being misunderstood by outsiders.

You know, in this world, if you want to do something, especially something good, it's always easy to be criticized.”

“Then do you think prostitution raids are right or wrong?”

“Well…” The old Daoist didn't know how to answer.

“According to your logic, the 'ladies' are willing, they need money, and you have needs, and you give money. Both parties get what they want. Why should the police meddle?”

The old Daoist didn’t know how to refute.

“Even in the self-proclaimed free and open America, prostitution is illegal in all states except Nevada, which borders Los Angeles.

Law, in fact, is the last moral benchmark of a society. And what you call protecting the 'fallen',

Seems like mutual consent, willing engagement, but if it were legalized or brought into the light, do you know how many prostitution rings it would spawn? Many women would even be forced into prostitution. In an illegal environment, there are already many cases of forced prostitution.

India is a country that advocates legal individual prostitution, and you understand India's rape rate.”

“Those are two different things…” the old Daoist explained.

“Two different things?”

Zhou Ze smiled,

He pointed to the street behind them and continued:

“This is just the tip of the iceberg of what we see. Do you know that the flame of evil might start as just a flicker? Some moths are willing to fly into it, the fire wants to burn them, and the moths make their own choice.

But when this fire grows bigger and bigger, it will no longer be satisfied with only burning the moths that actively fly into it. It will burn nearby houses, nearby forests, and then it will cause a great disaster.

In the end, aren't those moths that fed the initial flicker and made it grow also among the culprits?

When this industry begins to mature and expand, who can guarantee that even more bloody and exciting gambling methods won't emerge? Moreover, when willing moths are not enough, won't those who are addicted to this game, those platforms accustomed to earning huge profits from this game, forcefully or semi-forcefully seek new chips to continue the game?

Six months later,

A year later,

Three years later,

This growing and maturing dark industry brings in an innocent person, creating conditions for similar death gambling.

Does that person have the right to curse those idiots who, for money, initially volunteered as chips and joined this game?”

The old Daoist smacked his lips. He felt what the boss said seemed very reasonable, but he still felt something was off. He stubbornly retorted:

“Boss, I think the real culprits are those organizers, the bookmakers.”

“When an avalanche occurs, no snowflake is innocent.”

...

When they returned to the bookstore, it was already dark. Because he wasn't in a good mood, Zhou Ze had walked back, which took quite some time.

The bookstore door was open. Tang Shi was sitting behind the counter. A man and a woman were sitting there reading.

“Where’s Bai Yingying?” Zhou Ze asked.

“She went upstairs to play games. I’m helping her watch for a while. She’s been playing all day.” Tang Shi said indifferently.

Zhou Ze was speechless. It seemed he needed to limit the game time of that internet-addicted girl. She actually dared to leave the store for Tang Shi to manage; wasn't she afraid of a bloodbath in the bookstore if something really happened?

“You two were out for quite a while. Oh, where’s the old Daoist?” Tang Shi asked, surprised that the old Daoist hadn’t returned to the bookstore with Zhou Ze.

“Went to the police station to report a crime,” Zhou Ze replied.

“Want something to drink? A cocktail?”

“You know how to mix them?”

Tang Shi didn't speak but began to mix a drink on her own. Her mixing movements were quick and skilled. Soon, a cocktail was placed in front of Zhou Ze.

“Try it.”

Zhou Ze picked up the glass, took a sip, then nodded,

“Very good.”

“Thanks.” Tang Shi sat back in her chair, holding a book called “The Origin of Hell.”

“Is this book from the bookstore?” Zhou Ze didn’t recognize the book, and there was no publisher listed on it.

“His book, a fantasy book from his middle school years. You can read it for fun to pass the time.”

Zhou Ze carried his drink upstairs. As soon as he pushed open the bedroom door, he saw Bai Yingying sitting at the computer desk, wearing headphones, talking excitedly, as if arguing with her teammates.

It seemed they initially didn't know she was a girl, and only realized it when she spoke during the argument, saying something else.

“Heh heh, you want me to play with you?”

Bai Yingying didn’t know Zhou Ze was already standing behind her. She lowered her voice and said coquettishly:

“Do you want to sleep with a corpse, big brother? The kind that goes ‘_ying ying ying_’*.

Go sleep with your moms, you jerks! I'm old enough to be your great-great-grandmother!”

Then, Bai Yingying took off her headphones, disdainfully tossed them on the desk, leaned slightly back, and propped one long leg up. With one hand, she casually pulled a pack of women's cigarettes from her pocket, expertly tapped the filter end down on the desk, then put it in her mouth. Her fingertips rubbed, a spark appeared, and she lit the cigarette.

“That’s a good way to light a cigarette,” Zhou Ze said. “Can you teach me?”

“Go ask your mom to teach you. I’m busy…”

As Bai Yingying was speaking, she suddenly took a deep breath, quickly extinguished the cigarette in her hand, then stood up and bowed her head towards Zhou Ze, greeting him in a soft, gentle voice:

“Boss, you’re back.”

Zhou Ze sat in the chair Bai Yingying had just been in; the chair still retained some warmth. He took a cigarette from the pack and lit it. It was a woman's cigarette. He took a puff and frowned slightly; this type of cigarette was too light for Zhou Ze's taste.

“Was it hard to hold it in?”

Zhou Ze turned sideways to look at the female corpse.

He wasn't sure when he had grown accustomed to Bai Yingying obediently staying by his side, making “_ying ying ying_” sounds.

He seemed to have forgotten the intimidation and horror Bai Yingying brought to him and Xu Qinglang when she first woke up in the bookstore. Zhou Ze was also a bit confused, wondering which version was her true self.

“No, boss, don’t misunderstand. In front of you, Yingying is truly just a shy little bird. Boss, you should actually know yourself,

You are also a zombie, and your bloodline is much higher than mine.”

Zhou Ze narrowed his eyes and said:

“But in my previous life, I was just a doctor, just an ordinary person. I’ve always wondered something: I’ve already died once and changed bodies. If it were merely a matter of bloodline, that should be ruled out. Otherwise, there’s only one explanation, and that is that Xu Le himself was a zombie, but that doesn’t make sense either.”

“Boss, my Madam once told me that some zombies, they…”

At this moment, Zhou Ze’s phone rang. Zhou Ze picked up his phone and motioned for Bai Yingying to pause and talk later.

It was the old Daoist’s call. The two had walked back together, but Zhou Ze had given the old Daoist some冥钞 (冥钞) to burn somewhere before going to the police station to report.

“Hello, did you report it?” Zhou Ze asked.

“Boss, no… didn’t dare to report…” the old Daoist stammered over the phone.

“Didn't burn the冥钞 (冥钞)? It's just participating in gambling, plus the act of self-reporting, and burning some冥钞 (冥钞), you won't even be detained, at most you'll just make a statement.”

“No… no, boss… I’m at the police station, and there are many reporters here now. Apparently, half an hour ago, someone reported that all the nurses, doctors, and patients in a hospital were killed. It seems… it seems it’s the same hospital we were at earlier.

Boss, I can’t turn myself in now. Burning more冥钞 (冥钞) won’t help. If I turn myself in, the police will definitely detain me as the prime suspect.”

“Everyone’s dead?”

Zhou Ze frowned slightly. That shouldn’t be right. When he left, those doctors and nurses were just lying there unconscious, not in any serious danger; they should have woken up shortly.

“Absolutely, it’s that hospital,” the old Daoist said in a lowered voice. “I just asked a reporter, and he told me.”

“How is that possible? We haven’t been gone that long.”

“Boss…” the old Daoist asked nervously, “Weren’t you also wondering earlier why that female ghost didn’t kill anyone or take revenge?”

“What are you trying to say?”

“This humble Daoist is thinking, at that time, perhaps there were two ghosts, but one of them was hiding.”

---
*Translator's note: “_ying ying ying_” is an onomatopoeia, usually describing a soft, delicate, or somewhat affected sound, often used in a cutesy or coy manner. It can imply a desire for pity or attention.

title: 第一百一十三章 真兇浮現！
content:
