The incident happened suddenly, and many deceased were brought in, a total of over ten bodies. To expedite the autopsy and examination process, several bodies were transferred to Tongcheng Affiliated Hospital to assist with the investigation.

Tongcheng is a peaceful city, and precisely because of this, the sudden occurrence of such a severe murder case immediately garnered attention from all sides. News about the incident had already spread on WeChat Moments and Weibo, causing many citizens to feel fear and unease.

To some extent, this put pressure on the police handling the case.

The police force was fully deployed in hopes of uncovering the truth of the incident soon, and a special task force was immediately established. Of course, none of this concerned Zhou Ze.

For now, he only needed to ascertain one thing: were the deceased doctors and nurses killed by humans, or by… ghosts?

In reality, Zhou Ze felt no unease about the deaths of those people, nor did he feel any responsibility or guilt. If that female ghost had been a bit more capable, she would have long ago become Zhou Ze's weapon for killing with a borrowed knife. Those scoundrels who treated human lives as gambling tools, their deaths would only make the world cleaner.

But what Zhou Ze couldn't tolerate was if there was another ghost, constantly hidden in the shadows, and he hadn't discovered it, only for it to start killing as soon as he left. That would be his dereliction of duty.

Like a hunter who catches birds all day, only to have a bird peck out his eye—that feeling was far from pleasant.

He casually stole a white coat, put it on, and entered the morgue. Two bodies were currently undergoing autopsies, while three remained here. Zhou Ze used to be a doctor here, working for ten years, so he was naturally very familiar with the affiliated hospital.

Moreover, Zhou Ze had actually been to this morgue once since his reincarnation. Last time, he encountered the case of several children fighting over an inheritance, with their deceased mother’s body left unclaimed.

The old Daoist also rushed over from the police station and met Zhou Ze at the affiliated hospital. He had cultivated relationships with some reporters and obtained some superficial information, which he quickly came to report to Zhou Ze.

However, to the old man’s disappointment, Zhou Ze was not interested in this news. Unlike his previous boss, he had little interest in solving cases.

The temperature in the morgue was naturally not high, and a chilling aura permeated both inside and out.

"Boss, why are the bodies being transported to the hospital for autopsy?" The old Daoist couldn't understand this.

"Forensic pathologists, even in developed countries, are in short supply, and it's the same domestically. If it were a case with only one or two lives, it wouldn't be necessary, but this time there are over ten deceased. The forensic resources allocated to the Tongcheng police bureau would certainly not be enough, so they had to seek assistance from private institutions."

Zhou Ze checked the numbers, then scanned the table behind the door a few times before pulling out a freezer drawer. Inside lay the body of an old woman with gray hair.

The old Daoist's eyes widened immediately upon seeing the body. "This must be a ghost's doing. The nurse小姐姐 was sucked dry like a husk."

Zhou Ze tapped the metal plate. "This is the body of a patient from the hospital's basement."

"Oh, I see."

The old Daoist rubbed his head, somewhat embarrassed.

"Then how did she die?" the old Daoist asked again.

"The body was already suffering from cancer before death. Those patients lying in the basement, used as gambling tools, had already had all medical assistance terminated. They could die at any moment.

"Roughly speaking, this body has no obvious external injuries, and I didn't detect any residual malevolent energy on her."

"Is her cause of death very strange and difficult to find?" the old Daoist said, stroking his chin in a feigned thoughtful manner, as if he too were deeply contemplating the matter. "That's interesting. A mysterious cause of death, there must be something strange about this."

"Died of illness."

"Huh?"

"I said, she probably died of illness."

"This..."

If it weren't Zhou Ze in front of him, but someone else, the old Daoist would probably have exploded in anger.

Died of illness, and you spent so long analyzing it, making me act so engrossed.

Am I not supposed to feel awkward?!

Zhou Ze ignored the old Daoist's thoughts and pulled out the second body, a young male corpse.

"This body looks a bit familiar. Oh, holy crap, it's that security guard's body." The old Daoist recognized the body, as he had had physical contact with this security guard.

Zhou Ze reached out and lifted the corpse's chin; there was a dark red wound there.

The wound was deep, and the incision was very smooth.

"Was this a slit throat?"

The old Daoist guessed.

Zhou Ze nodded. The cause of death was excessive blood loss from a sharp object severing the throat.

Zhou Ze then pushed open the freezer containing the third body, which was a female corpse.

"I know this one too. She was a nurse at the hospital. She was wearing Peppa Pig on the bottom, so I took a few extra glances."

Zhou Ze examined the female corpse's chin area and found no wound there. However, moving down her neck, Zhou Ze saw a very deep cut below her left breast. The wound mark wasn't as long as the male corpse's neck wound, but its depth was probably more terrifying.

Excluding other possible accidental factors, purely based on Zhou Ze's experience in his previous life, the fatal injuries of these two individuals should be the two wounds he found.

"This must have been a stab with a dagger."

The old Daoist was also someone who had wandered the *jianghu*, and for a while, he had even served as a barefoot doctor in the countryside. Although his skills were mostly for bluffing, he had seen a lot.

"It should be a sharp object similar to a dagger," Zhou Ze nodded.

Ghosts don't use knives to kill, so for now, it seemed to be a human act.

Since it was human-caused, it had nothing to do with Zhou Ze. Earthly matters were for the police to handle; he was only responsible for containing ghosts.

But this matter still made Zhou Ze very uncomfortable. He had indeed wanted to kill these doctors and nurses before, but in the end, he didn't. However, a scene could be inferred in his mind:

After he and the old Daoist left,

Someone, holding a dagger or a small knife-like object, came to this hospital, and these nurses and doctors were likely still unconscious.

He approached them one by one, slitting their throats with the dagger or stabbing their abdomens, letting them slowly and painfully die of blood loss while unconscious.

People killed those whom ghosts didn't.

Whether I kill or not is my business. You taking advantage of my absence and their unconsciousness to finish them off—Zhou Ze felt like he had been exploited and outmaneuvered.

"Let's go, it's fine," Zhou Ze said.

Since it wasn't a ghost's doing, Zhou Ze intended to withdraw.

"Then... do I still need to turn myself in?"

"With such a big incident, some things cannot be kept hidden. Even if you don't turn yourself in, this dark industry chain will be uncovered in this incident."

"That's good."

The old Daoist was really worried that Zhou Ze would continue to make him surrender and be a star witness.

Leaving the hospital, it was already late at night. There were many late-night food stalls outside. The old Daoist suggested eating something, as he hadn't eaten since noon.

Zhou Ze nodded in agreement. He also felt a bit light-headed; Xu Qinglang had returned to his hometown, and his appetite had been noticeably poor these past few days.

However, because he didn't bring sour plum juice, the old Daoist ate heartily beside him, but Zhou Ze found it very difficult to eat. Each bite of food had to be swallowed with great difficulty, suppressing the urge to vomit.

And the food at the late-night stalls was quite oily, which made it even harder for Zhou Ze to eat.

While eating, the old Daoist wiped his mouth, got up, and went to the front. When he returned, he held two warm steamed buns.

"Boss, you should eat something lighter. There's a 24-hour pastry shop right ahead. I bought you two steamed buns."

Zhou Ze also put down his chopsticks and took the steamed buns. He had to eat something, at least to maintain the energy needed for his body's activities, so he wouldn't deplete his body and collapse.

Holding the steamed buns in his hand, Zhou Ze shook his head helplessly. "The steamed buns aren't fresh."

"Uh..." The old Daoist said, somewhat helplessly, "It's already night, after all. To get fresh ones, you'd have to wait until they just open in the morning."

Zhou Ze poked the steamed bun with his fingernail. It was soft on the outside and a bit hard on the inside.

Just as he was about to tear off a piece and put it in his mouth, Zhou Ze suddenly froze.

He abruptly turned the steamed bun around, looking at the spot where his fingernail had just pierced.

Dropping the steamed bun, Zhou Ze immediately stood up and rushed across the road towards the hospital.

"Boss!"

The old Daoist called out, and seeing that Zhou Ze didn't respond, he threw two hundred yuan onto the table, shouted "Check please" to the food stall owner, and then ran after his boss.

The two returned to the hospital. Zhou Ze still headed straight for the morgue. Coincidentally, a doctor in a white coat came out of the morgue door. Fortunately, he had his back to Zhou Ze and walked in the other direction, going upstairs from there.

After that doctor left, Zhou Ze and the old Daoist opened the morgue door and entered again.

Zhou Ze personally pulled open a freezer drawer; the female corpse lay inside.

"Boss, what exactly happened?" the old Daoist asked breathlessly.

"It wasn't a dagger that killed her," Zhou Ze said in a deep voice.

"Not a dagger, then a small knife, right? You ran all the way back just for that?" The old Daoist sighed.

Zhou Ze didn't speak.

Instead, he silently let his index fingernail grow out.

Then,

Zhou Ze gently placed the dark fingernail on the female corpse's left chest area,

Following the existing wound,

He inserted it,

A perfect fit!

It wasn't killed by a dagger,

Nor by a small knife,

In fact, it wasn't killed by any sharp tool,

It was a fingernail,

A fingernail!

The old Daoist's mouth immediately gaped open, so astonished he didn't know what to say, only stammering:

"Zom... zom..."

"I knew when I first saw this wound, I had a familiar feeling," Zhou Ze turned his head and looked at the old Daoist. "Pull out the male corpse's freezer too, and verify it again."

The old Daoist immediately nodded and pulled open the freezer where the male corpse was.

Then the old Daoist froze completely.

He said,

"Boss, this isn't good, something's wrong!"

"What's wrong?" Zhou Ze pulled out his fingernail and turned to look at the old Daoist.

"The body... the body is gone!"

The old Daoist turned sideways to Zhou Ze, indicating that the freezer he had pulled out was empty.

Immediately after,

A more terrifying scene unfolded. The old Daoist reached out, trembling, and pointed at Zhou Ze,

Because he saw,

Behind Zhou Ze,

The female corpse, which had been lying on the morgue rack,

Was slowly sitting up.

The female corpse turned her face,

Smiling,

And looked at him...

title: 第一百一十四章 醫院驚魂！
content:
The female corpse suddenly sat up. All was silent.

This was very much like a classic scene and plot device from a horror movie: the protagonist and some minor character are investigating something when a terrifying scene suddenly appears, and the whole affair begins to spiral into an unknowable abyss of mystery.

"Boss..."

Old Daoist priest had seen much in his time, but he had never witnessed anything this strange. After all, many past incidents ultimately had a greater "human" factor, while ghosts often seemed somewhat constrained.

But now,
This was true corpse reanimation, dammit!

"What is it?" Zhou Ze asked, not turning around, but looking at the Old Daoist.

"You... you..."

The female corpse looked at Zhou Ze in front of her. She wasn't actually smiling, but in this atmosphere and under the current lighting, from the Old Daoist's perspective, the female corpse was like a venomous snake, preparing to devour someone.

Because of this, it gave the Old Daoist the illusion that the female corpse was smiling, as if everything was under her control.

"Speak, hey," Zhou Ze said, a bit impatient as the Old Daoist continued to stammer.

And at this moment, the female corpse opened her mouth and bit down towards Zhou Ze's neck.

"Boss, behind you..."

"Smack!"

Zhou Ze suddenly extended a hand, like a snake catcher grasping a snake by its vital spot, and clamped onto the female corpse's neck, his nails instantly piercing into it.

The female corpse began to twist, to struggle, she seemed to be in great pain.

"What is it, speak," Zhou Ze urged.

Seeing this, the heart that had been in the Old Daoist's throat immediately plummeted back down.

"Nothing," the Old Daoist replied weakly, feeling he had wasted his expressions and emotions.

"Oh."

Zhou Ze responded, then threw the female corpse to the ground.

"Thud!"

With a crisp sound, the female corpse's skin began to crack, and black pus slowly seeped out from inside, like a water balloon played with by a child with malicious intent, bursting upon hitting the ground.

When the water inside seeped out, only the tattered balloon skin remained.

The female corpse was the same; when the black pus splattered out, her bones and insides seemed to have completely vanished, leaving only the outermost layer of skin, floating and sinking in the pus.

That face, immersed in the liquid, constantly wrinkled and changed, like a person continuously altering their expression.

Zhou Ze looked at his nails. There were several nicks on them. When he had pierced into the female corpse earlier, he distinctly felt a strong corrosive property, which had caused some damage to his nails.

The terrifying and strange scene was so casually resolved by Zhou Ze that the Old Daoist had a ridiculous feeling that they had the wrong script. He even felt that such a good atmosphere and buildup had been wasted.

He immediately rubbed his face hard, forcing himself to sober up, then said:

"Boss, I just thought of something. When we came in, wasn't there a doctor in a white coat walking out?

Was he a real doctor?"

"Ah! Ah! Ah! Ah! Ah! Ah!"

From upstairs, a piercing scream echoed.

………………

In the hospital room, a girl sat on a nearby bed, unable to help but doze off. Her mother, who had just undergone surgery, lay on the bed with an IV drip, still under anesthesia.

The girl slept fitfully for a while, her body swaying, then she woke up. She was exhausted, but her sleep was restless. She needed to care for her mother, at least to check if the IV drip was finished so she could call a nurse to help replace it.

She looked up and saw that this bottle was almost empty. Standing up, the girl gently yawned, then reached out and pressed the call button by the bed, notifying the nurse to help change the IV bag.

The button was pressed, but after a while, no nurse came. The girl grew a little anxious, walked to the hospital room door, and pushed it open. She planned to go to the nurse's station at the other end to check; perhaps the nurse on duty had also fallen asleep.

Pushing the door open, just as she stepped out, the girl saw a male doctor in a white coat standing on the opposite side of the corridor, his face obscured by a white mask, turned sideways to her.

"Doctor, excuse me, I need a bottle change here."

The girl called out to the doctor.

The doctor ignored her, remaining motionless where he stood.

"Doctor? Doctor? We need a bottle change here."

The girl called again.

The doctor's body trembled slightly, as if he had been startled awake from a daze. Then he half-turned and walked towards the girl.

The girl let out a sigh of relief. Her mother only had one last bottle of IV fluid, and then she could finally get some proper sleep.

However, gradually, the girl noticed something was wrong, as if there was something amiss somewhere.

At first, the girl thought she was too tired, leading to neurasthenia, making everything seem off. But slowly, the girl realized this wasn't the reason; rather, the doctor walking towards her was indeed problematic.

He... was barefoot!

Yes, a doctor, walking barefoot in a hospital?

Working barefoot?

Was it possible?

The girl immediately took two steps back, closed the hospital room door, and then quickly locked it from the inside. This was her subconscious reaction.

In fact, everyone possesses a sixth sense. When human ancestors lived a primitive life, they were constantly on guard against attacks from wild beasts, naturally possessing an instinct for self-preservation.

Of course, with the development of human society, humanity has been at the top of the food chain for a very long time, and this instinct is slowly degenerating. But some people are inherently more sensitive, with a more acute perception of danger than ordinary people.

Through the transparent glass on the hospital room door, the girl saw the male doctor still walking towards her, and his way of walking was also somewhat peculiar.

After taking a step, his foot immediately twisted, causing his body to twist along with it, like the exaggeratedly comical walking style in a Charlie Chaplin silent comedy.

But in the dead of night, in a hospital, in a deserted ward corridor, this way of walking brought not comedy, but a horrifying terror that made one's hair stand on end!

The doctor continued to walk towards her, his swaying motion growing wider and wider. The girl even heard "creaking" sounds.

The girl wondered if she was having a nightmare.

Why would something like this happen in a hospital?

She lowered her head, closed her eyes, and forced herself to calm down. If this was a dream, please wake up.

Then, she opened her eyes and found herself still standing behind the door. This, it seemed, was not a dream.

Summoning courage, the girl once again looked out through the glass window on the hospital room door, only to find that the doctor was gone, completely out of sight.

The girl was a little confused. What was going on?

Had she seen things?

Or was she already having illusions?

She didn't dare to open the door. Even if she had seen things, she wasn't prepared to open the door and confirm it at this moment. After all, she was a girl, and after her mother fell ill, she became even more cautious.

Outside, it seemed there was really no one left.

The girl pressed her face against the door to get a wider view through the glass.

Suddenly,

The girl felt the light in front of her was blocked.

A male doctor's face, wearing a mask,

Appeared silently from the glass window,

The distance between his face and the girl's face,

Was less than a centimeter, just the thickness of the glass!

The girl was completely scared stiff.

She forgot to scream, forgot everything, just stood there dumbfounded, looking at the person outside the glass window, that face!

The mask was squirming, as if the mouth covered by it was speaking, but what came out was not human language, but the "creaking" sound she had heard before,

Like walking through a muddy puddle in rain boots on a rainy day.

And the male doctor's eyes were exaggeratedly huge, five or six times larger than normal human eyes. His eyeballs were swollen like eggs, almost the size of a chicken egg, practically bursting out of their sockets.

At the same time, these eyeballs were constantly shaking, wobbling, like the eyes of a puppet, able to flip up and down, as if they could fall out at any moment.

The girl covered her mouth, her body trembling with immense fear.

"Click-creak..."

It was the sound of the doorknob turning.

The doctor was opening the door!

The girl immediately pushed forward with her body, bracing against the hospital room door.

She had just locked the door, so it couldn't be opened from the outside, but because it couldn't be opened, the doctor outside started pounding on the door.

"Bang! Bang! Bang!..."

The girl bit her lip, pressing against the door. Her eyes were full of tears. She was terrified, frantic. She didn't know why this was happening in a hospital.

"Creak-creak-creak..."

Along with the sounds of the door being hit, the "creaking" sound grew more intense and clear.

"Boom!"

A sound came from outside the door.

The girl didn't know what had happened, but she suddenly realized that the person outside was no longer hitting the door. Leaning against the door, she heavily gasped for breath.

It was too terrifying.

Truly too terrifying.

If this was a nightmare, please let her wake up quickly.

But soon, the girl suddenly found her feet wet, as if a puddle of water had flowed in from under the door.

The girl lowered her head and looked at the ground.

Something white seemed to be seeping through the bottom door crack along with the pus on the floor.

It was a human skin!

On top was a face twisted into a grotesque knot.

Those two huge eyeballs flowed like two freshly cracked egg yolks covered in egg white.

With a "squelch,"

One of the eyeballs burst, and yellowish, foul-smelling liquid splattered onto the girl's face.

The other eyeball continued to roll around,

As if the doctor was lying on the ground, with one eye squinted and the other open, looking at her with a mocking expression.

"Ah! Ah! Ah! Ah! Ah! Ah! Ah! Ah!"

The girl collapsed.

Her scream,

Echoed throughout the entire inpatient building.

title: 第一百一十五章 清明時節雨紛紛
content:
Zhou Ze and the old Daoist priest followed the screams and found the floor. Because Zhou Ze's legs were inconvenient, by the time they arrived, many people had already gathered there. Many family members of inpatients were out to watch the commotion, forming three layers of crowds.

There were even some patients in hospital gowns, holding their IV drips in one hand and leaning against the wall with the other, coming over to gawk, perfectly embodying the spirit of "life never ends, neither does watching a good show."

Several nurses nearby were comforting a girl, and someone was calling the hospital security. Security should arrive soon.

Because Zhou Ze was also wearing a white lab coat, he and the old Daoist priest easily squeezed through the crowd and got inside.

On the ground was a puddle of yellowish-brown pus, and something like an egg yolk was constantly floating in it. An uninformed person might think someone had peeled an egg and thrown it there, but Zhou Ze knew that it was actually a human eyeball.

"Boss, this fellow's amniotic fluid also broke."

The old Daoist priest whispered in Zhou Ze's ear.

Zhou Ze frowned slightly. The old Daoist priest always got mischievous at critical moments; this might be a self-preservation mechanism for him under stress, involuntarily trying to relax himself during tense times.

Then, Zhou Ze extended his index finger and stirred it in the pus.

Seeing this, the old Daoist priest also squatted down and put his finger in to stir. Honestly, this stuff was too disgusting, but since the boss did it, he could only follow suit.

It must be said that the old Daoist priest was a very dedicated person. Whether following his previous boss or his current one, he had a strong desire to learn and imitate.

Immediately, the old Daoist priest saw a scene that made him want to throw up his supper. Zhou Ze actually put his middle finger in his mouth and sucked it, then bowed his head in thought, as if discerning the ingredients within.

At the same time,

He even smacked his lips.

So dedicated?

What did it taste like?

The old Daoist priest hesitated.

A fierce struggle occurred in his mind in a short time, but in the end,

He also put the finger that had just stirred the pus into his mouth and tasted it. The taste was overwhelmingly pungent, with a stinging, spicy sensation erupting immediately upon entry, more burning to the throat than drinking high-proof baijiu.

There was even a taste of aged seafood, a taste that most boys and some girls knew.

The old Daoist priest's face turned green, but seeing his boss still deep in thought with a normal expression, at that moment, a feeling of awe for Zhou Ze inexplicably rose in the old Daoist priest's heart.

He could endure this taste; he was truly not human!

Zhou Ze turned his head and saw the old Daoist priest's miserable face, like he had just been inseminated, then looked at the liquid still clinging to the old Daoist priest's fingertips. He asked, somewhat surprised:

"What are you doing?"

The old Daoist priest gently patted his chest and said tragically, "Shennong tasted a hundred herbs. What the boss can do, this humble Daoist naturally can too."

Zhou Ze nodded and smiled.

The old Daoist priest felt flattered, as if he had finally been recognized by his boss at that moment, just like when Patriarch Bodhi tapped Sun Wukong's head three times.

"I used my index finger to stir, and put my middle finger in my mouth."

Zhou Ze showed his fingers to the old Daoist priest and continued:

"I just had leeks stuck in my teeth after supper, so I was just picking them out. Who would be crazy enough to taste this stuff? Are they masochists?"

"..." The old Daoist priest.

The old Daoist priest wanted to say more, but then his stomach began to cramp. He pushed through the surrounding crowd and rushed straight to the restroom to vomit.

Zhou Ze silently stroked his chin. The startled girl was still sitting in the hospital room, with several nurses comforting her. Zhou Ze didn't go to inquire about the girl's condition, as he had experienced a similar scene himself in the morgue before.

It's just that some things were merely a drizzle and small-scale for him, but for ordinary people, they were already shocking enough to shake the world.

A dead body suddenly sat up.

The fatal wound came from extremely sharp nails that could be used as weapons.

The pus that the corpse eventually turned into.

Everything indicated that the murderer was not an ordinary person, but a devil hidden in the darkness. In fact, since Zhou Ze became an underworld official, he had never encountered an opponent with such mysterious and varied methods.

That thing clearly couldn't be treated as an ordinary fierce ghost.

Standing up, Zhou Ze walked to the other end of the corridor, took out his phone, and dialed Tang Shi's number.

"Hello." Tang Shi's voice was as cold as ever.

"Do me a favor. It seems a... a wild zombie has appeared here."

"You can go find plants."¹

The implication was that she was busy and couldn't be bothered.

"Then help me call Bai Yingying and ask her to come to the hospital."

"That's no problem."

After hanging up the phone, Zhou Ze once again wondered if keeping Tang Shi by his side was a mistake. This woman was even more useless than a vase.

His own Yingying was much better.

Both were women, both were not living people, yet the difference could be so great.

The old Daoist priest had vomited all the stomach acid out and walked out of the restroom, coming over to Zhou Ze. He asked, somewhat complainingly:

"Why did that thing have to do this when killing someone?"

"He did it on purpose," Zhou Ze said.

"Will everyone he kills turn into zombies? Hey, this is just like the old Hong Kong zombie movies from the eighties and nineties. People bitten by zombies turn into zombies too."

Saying that, the old Daoist priest looked into Zhou Ze's eyes, somewhat eager to try.

"What are you looking at?"

"Uh, Boss, a small request, can all zombies become like Bai Yingying?"

"Get straight to the point, don't beat around the bush."

"Uh, ahem... what this humble Daoist means is, look, Boss, I'm getting on in years. Who knows, one day I might kick the bucket and go to the Western Paradise."

"You're a Daoist priest, not a monk."

"Uh, that is to say, kick the bucket and ascend to immortality. But this old Daoist worries, if I leave, who will take care of you?"

"..." Zhou Ze.

"So, Boss, if that day comes, could you bite me?"

"I find it disgusting."

"..." The old Daoist priest.

Can we still be friends!

"It's not as exaggerated as you think. Being bitten by a zombie won't turn you into one. If you don't believe me, you can go back and let Bai Yingying bite your neck. Besides getting a zombie poison that will speed up your demise, I guarantee there won't be any other effects.

As for turning into a zombie, you might as well choose a very inauspicious tomb and bury yourself. Perhaps in a hundred years or so, you might pop out, but that 'you' after that has nothing to do with the 'you' now; it's a new life."

"Movies are all lies?"

"What do you think?"

The old Daoist priest was a bit dejected. He had thought he had found a way to extend his life, but it turned out to be this result. Still, the old Daoist priest was a bit unwilling to give up and said:

"Then what about these two people?"

"What was the outcome?" Zhou Ze asked. "They just split open, and all their bones and organs turned into pus."

"Why is that?"

"Because they were used as nutrients and absorbed by someone. They didn't turn into zombies. To take a step back, would you want to become that kind of zombie?"

"Will he continue to kill?" The old Daoist priest asked, a bit worried.

"If he hasn't eaten his fill," Zhou Ze pursed his lips. "Of course, even if he's full, it doesn't mean he won't get hungry again."

Zhou Ze suddenly seemed to remember something else and said to the old Daoist priest, "Try to find out what happened to those other bodies, if similar situations occurred..."

His phone rang at that moment. Zhou Ze picked it up and saw "Wang Ke" on the caller ID.

Since the "eating meat" incident last time, Zhou Ze hadn't contacted Wang Ke again, and Wang Ke had also promised not to contact him actively.

"Hello." Zhou Ze still answered the call.

"I'm sorry I have to go back on my word, but I think you'll be interested in this," Wang Ke's voice came from the other end of the line.

"Speak."

"Have you heard about the mass deaths at that small hospital?"

Zhou Ze turned around, looked at the puddle of pus behind him, and said:

"Just heard."

"I'm a part-time consultant for the police station, usually helping with psychological profiling and such. This incident is very serious, and I've been invited to help. Based on the existing known conditions, I need to delineate some psychological and physical characteristics of the culprit. Haha, for this, I drew a sketch. Would you like to see it?"

"Okay."

"Ding dong..."

A WeChat message notification sound.

Zhou Ze minimized the call and opened WeChat.

It was a very rough sketch, but the person in the sketch made Zhou Ze's pupils contract.

"What kind of joke are you playing?" Zhou Ze asked.

"Haha, I don't believe it's you, but the person I drew based on the known conditions and clues really looks a lot like you. How about it, this time I'm not asking you for a favor; I'm just asking if you're interested?"

"Interested in what?"

"I can get all the police investigation materials here." Wang Ke rubbed his brow on the other end of the phone, sounding a bit tired. "Although I don't want to admit it and feel a bit helpless, I increasingly feel that the culprit in this case might not be human."

"Are you at the police station?"

"No, I'm at home. You can come to my place. The case files and latest information will all be compiled here for me." Wang Ke paused, then added, "Also, I'm making meat soup for supper. You can come have some."

Zhou Ze directly ignored the last part and said, "I'll be over."

After saying that, Zhou Ze was about to hang up, but Wang Ke's voice came again: "Don't hang up yet."

"Something else?"

"Yes, I've never had a chance to say this to others before, and it's not good to say it to others, it sounds like scolding them.

But this time, it's a rare opportunity. This is the first time I've said this to someone else:

Happy Qingming Festival."²

---
¹ "You can go find plants" (你可以去找植物) is a literal translation. It's an implied dismissal, as if to say, "that's not my area of expertise, go find someone who deals with plants (like a botanist or someone who can help with natural remedies for a wild zombie)." Given Tang Shi's personality, it's a sarcastic way of saying she won't help.
² "Happy Qingming Festival" (清明節，快樂) is a literal translation. Qingming Festival is a traditional Chinese holiday where people visit ancestors' graves. It's a day associated with the dead, so saying "Happy Qingming Festival" is ironic, dark humor given the context of dead bodies and zombies.

title: 第一百一十六章 路上行人慾斷魂
content:
When Zhou Ze and the old Taoist priest walked out of the hospital, Bai Yingying happened to arrive in a taxi. She was wearing blue jeans and a white hoodie, looking youthful and beautiful.

Although she had been asleep for two hundred years, her age remained frozen at a youthful sixteen.

"Boss." Bai Yingying greeted Zhou Ze from across the street.

"So, the wild ones are prone to causing trouble," the old Taoist priest sniffed, watching Bai Yingying cross the road. He sighed, "The domesticated ones are more sensible."

It was clear now: the mastermind was very likely a zombie. And conveniently, there was a domesticated zombie at the bookstore—Bai Yingying.

The old Taoist priest had personally witnessed Bai Yingying cleaning, greeting customers, and even sleeping with the boss after work. Truly the most dedicated employee of the new era.

"Boss, is the situation very serious?" Bai Yingying asked as she approached. She understood that her boss wouldn't specifically call her unless things were extremely tricky.

Zhou Ze looked at the old Taoist priest. "You tell her the situation." Then, Zhou Ze flagged down a taxi, and they all got in.

The car drove to the villa district. After getting out, the three walked directly to Wang Ke's villa.

They rang the doorbell, and soon, Wang Ke opened the door, gesturing for Zhou Ze and the others to come in.

"The soup will be ready soon. Let's all have some. We can't neglect our health while working."

"This gentleman's words resonate deeply with this humble Taoist priest."

The old Taoist priest was overjoyed. He had to pay and leave his supper halfway through to follow Zhou Ze back to the hospital, and his stomach wasn't entirely full yet.

Everyone sat down in the living room. Wang Ke brought over a tray with four bowls of meat soup. He placed a bowl in front of Zhou Ze, the old Taoist priest, and Bai Yingying, and held one for himself.

The meat soup was pure, sprinkled with green onions and a drop or two of sesame oil. Each bowl also had two or three chunks of meat. The old Taoist priest didn't hesitate, picking up his bowl and starting to eat with great relish.

Watching the old Taoist priest heartily slurping the soup, Zhou Ze sat beside him, shaking his head slightly. For some reason, he felt a wave of nausea, even though the soup in front of him hadn't been touched. That feeling of revulsion was incredibly strong.

Bai Yingying also didn't eat; her soup remained untouched.

"Ha, satisfying!"

The old Taoist priest wiped his mouth with the back of his hand. Seeing that Zhou Ze hadn't touched his chopsticks, he asked in surprise,

"Boss, have some. It'll warm you up."

"I'm not hungry. You eat," Zhou Ze said.

"Oh, I couldn't possibly," the old Taoist priest demurred.

"Eat it, don't waste it."

Saying this, Zhou Ze even moved the bowl of meat soup that was in front of Bai Yingying to the old Taoist priest.

"Haha, then I accept with pleasure. Mr. Wang's cooking is truly unparalleled."

The old Taoist priest resumed eating heartily.

Zhou Ze felt he couldn't watch any longer. He stood up and looked at Wang Ke. "Let's talk about the case."

Wang Ke nodded, put down his bowl and chopsticks, and stood up, gesturing for Zhou Ze to follow him into the study.

On the desk in the study, there were many documents.

"Here, these are the photos that just arrived. The dissected bodies are fine, nothing happened to them, but several bodies that hadn't been dissected yet showed abnormal changes. The bodies turned into pus, and there were also some emergency responses that dead people shouldn't have.

For example, suddenly sitting up on the stretcher, and some people heard walking sounds coming from inside. When I received these messages, I immediately thought of you."

Wang Ke placed a stack of photos in front of Zhou Ze.

Zhou Ze flipped through the photos while asking,

"Any other clues?"

Zhou Ze was already aware of what was in the photos; he had personally experienced it just now.

"The police investigated the identities of all the deceased. There were no major surprises; the victims were basically all people related to that hospital. Therefore, the police's theory is that this was a revenge killing, and the perpetrator committed these heinous acts with the aim of retaliation.

The police are now focusing on suspects who had medical disputes with this hospital. However, this matter is truly surprising. This hospital, upon investigation, especially with such a serious violent incident, some things simply couldn't be hidden.

Gambling, using human lives as a gambling game—that's truly shocking."

Wang Ke reached out to adjust his glasses while twirling the pen in his hand.

"And what else?" Zhou Ze continued to ask.

So far, all the information Wang Ke had obtained was already known to him.

"That's it. To identify the killer, we first need to completely dismantle this entire underground black industry chain. Then, from those who lost money gambling, we'll start by investigating gamblers from this city or province. Additionally, the families of those who were used as gambling tools are also key suspects.

This means there are currently a great many suspects, and the investigation will be difficult and time-consuming. I'm still waiting for more specific information."

Zhou Ze was getting impatient. He stood up, ready to leave. The information Wang Ke provided was of no value to him.

"Don't go, stay a bit longer."

Wang Ke tried to keep him.

"Have some more soup."

"Then there's really nothing more to talk about," Zhou Ze said.

If you bring up soup again, I’ll have to leave even if I don’t want to.

"Actually, there's one more thing, something the police haven't discovered, but I have."

Wang Ke leaned back, looking at Zhou Ze, his gaze deep behind his glasses. "But I'm afraid you'll misunderstand me."

"You don't have to say it."

Zhou Ze didn't press him. Honestly, he could get involved in this matter or not. He was just a ghost messenger, not a Heavenly Master from Longhu Mountain, and he didn't have much of a passion for saving all living beings.

Wild zombies, by rights, were not under Zhou Ze's jurisdiction, unless that zombie was so full it decided to attack the Midnight Bookstore.

Otherwise, he could perfectly well eat and sleep as he pleased in the bookstore.

And even if that zombie truly lost its mind and came to the bookstore, with himself, Bai Yingying, and Miss Tang, it would likely be the zombie that ended up suffering.

"I'll tell you anyway."

Wang Ke took out another photo from the drawer, turned it around, and placed it in front of Zhou Ze.

The background of the photo was the signboard of a hospital, the one where the incident occurred. Zhou Ze also saw the familiar large clock behind the photo.

"There are a total of seventeen people in the photo: four security guards, four nurses, three doctors, and two administrative staff. Standing at the very front are four people.

The two in the middle are the hospital's investor and a manager from the gambling platform, respectively. The leftmost one is a renowned old doctor from Tongcheng who has already retired.

In the hospital death incident, the four security guards, four nurses, three doctors, and two administrators died on that very day.

However, among the four people in the front row, two of them died one after another a week ago.

For example, the hospital's investor died in a car accident a week ago, and this old doctor was found dead at home three days ago.

Just got the news, the owner of this gambling platform died tonight while trying to escape..."

Wang Ke sighed as he spoke.

Zhou Ze reached out, placed his hand on the photo, and gently pushed away Wang Ke's index finger that was pressing on it.

"I'm curious, is this fourth person still alive?"

Wang Ke slowly moved his finger away. The face of the fourth person, previously covered by his finger, was revealed.

A very familiar face.

It was Wang Ke's face!

Zhou Ze looked up at Wang Ke.

Wang Ke spread his hands. "Calm down, let me explain."

"Very surprising," Zhou Ze lit a cigarette.

"Don't jump to conclusions. This really has nothing to do with me. This boss was my roommate in college. He said he opened a clinic and invited me to attend the ribbon-cutting. I couldn't refuse to give him face. In fact, my role, like that old doctor's, was just to fill out the crowd that day.

I truly had no idea about their shady dealings, such as using human lives for gambling. After the opening, I never went to that hospital again, nor did I gain any benefits from it, and I have absolutely no connection to this matter."

Wang Ke looked at Zhou Ze,

"In fact, it's hard for you to imagine how profitable this black industrial chain is. Even a thin layer of skimmed profits from it would be a huge sum.

If I were truly involved, would I still be worried about money for the development of my psychological research firm?

You saw how anxious I was during Mr. Zheng's daughter's incident, like a cat on a hot tin roof. I'm short on money, and if I were involved in this, would I still need to run around doing odd jobs for Mr. Zheng like a servant?"

Wang Ke's explanation made a lot of sense.

Because he couldn't have predicted what was happening now and started acting for Zhou Ze in the past.

"So, you called me here, to consult on this case and show me evidence, and that was just a pretense?" Zhou Ze exhaled a smoke ring, then flicked the ash, watching it fall onto the study carpet, and slowly said,

"Your real purpose is that you're afraid of dying and you want me to protect you?"

"Don't make me out to be so pathetic," Wang Ke took off his wire-rimmed glasses and rubbed his temples. "The psychological profile I created, the final portrait I drew, it really looks like you.

I called you here to confess to you, because I think those people might have been killed by you. Your identity... well, I know about it.

If it was you, wouldn't it be simpler for me to call you over?"

Zhou Ze shook his head. "I'm not that free."

"If it's not you, then I might die tonight or tomorrow," Wang Ke shook his head, somewhat helplessly.

"I'll stay until tomorrow, you'd better pray the killer comes for you tonight."

The implication was,

No later than that.

Zhou Ze couldn't be Wang Ke's personal bodyguard.

"What about your wife and daughter?" Zhou Ze asked.

"I told them to get some rest upstairs early. I don't want to disturb her. Fortunately, the killer is only targeting people in the photo right now, and hasn't shown any intention of wiping out entire families."

Zhou Ze nodded upon hearing this.

Walking out of the study, Zhou Ze saw the old Taoist priest had eaten all three bowls of meat soup from the coffee table and was now leaning back on the sofa, rubbing his belly contentedly.

"Was it good?" Wang Ke asked the old Taoist priest.

"It was delicious, the craftsmanship is incredible, and the meat was very fragrant," the old Taoist priest praised.

"Heh heh, this is fresh pork my wife specially bought from a farmer today."

"Thoughtful," the old Taoist priest licked his lips.

"There's more in the pot; I'll heat it up later."

"That would be great," the old Taoist priest clearly hadn't had enough. After he digested a bit, he could eat more.

Just then, a woman's voice came from upstairs:

"Darling, do we have guests?"

"Yes, you go back to rest."

"Okay, darling, you finish up and rest early too. I'll clean the kitchen tomorrow."

The woman, having spoken from the stair landing, turned and walked back into the bedroom.

She lay down on the bed, a large red bed that looked festive, though also a bit rustic.

Even in rural areas, very few homes used such bright red bedspreads anymore.

And,

At the edge of the bedsheet,

Drops of crimson,

Were dripping down,

Pooling beneath the bed,

Drip,

Drip,

Drip...

title: 第一百一十七章 借問酒家，何處有牧童
content:
Wang Ke’s life was very boring and monotonous. He was a workaholic, constantly striving for his future, climbing relentlessly.

Those who grew up in poverty often have a greater obsession with money when they become adults, yearning for the sense of security that financial accumulation brings.

Moreover, it’s difficult for people from normal families to understand the psychology of children who grew up in orphanages. What they lack is more than just the simple “financial security.”

Zhou Ze, in the past, was the same. However, after living a second life, Zhou Ze had become much lazier and more open-minded.

There’s no obsession that “dying once” can’t solve.

If not,

Then die a few more times,

And you’ll see things more clearly.

Wang Ke suggested playing poker. Zhou Ze was noncommittal, Bai Yingying disdained the idea, and the old道ist wanted to participate but playing poker with just two people was impossible, so they had to give up.

In the end, Wang Ke directly pulled out his patients’ medical records for study, immediately starting work. It was clear how terrified he truly was.

Zhou Ze looked at this “elder brother” he grew up with in the orphanage, as if seeing his former self.

Even before dying, they wanted to possess more, pursue more. Everyone enjoyed the pleasure that work brought, that accumulation and the satisfaction similar to a squirrel hiding nuts in its tree hollow.

Regardless of whether there was a tomorrow, they had to work.

Outside the window, light began to appear. A night had passed, somewhat slowly, yet also somewhat quickly. The zombie didn’t come. No one knocked on the door, and no one broke through the window. Tonight was very peaceful.

Zhou Ze deliberately waited a while longer, until morning, before intending to get up.

“That’s enough for today. I’m going back.”

Wang Ke didn’t shamelessly beg Zhou Ze not to leave and to continue protecting him. He kept his head down, still looking at his medical records. When Zhou Ze bid farewell, he finally looked up, stretched tiredly, and smiled at Zhou Ze:

“Have breakfast before you go.”

The old道ist really wanted to nod, but he had to look at Zhou Ze’s expression. For the old道ist, he was extremely satisfied with the Wang family’s food: delicate, exquisite, focused on taste enjoyment rather than simply filling the stomach.

“No, no need to trouble yourselves.”

Zhou Ze maintained a respectful distance from anything related to “eating” in the Wang family.

Upon hearing this, the old道ist was a bit disappointed. Actually, he had quite a good meal yesterday, eating so many odd things without getting a stomach ache.

“Are the guests leaving?”

At this moment, Wang Ke’s wife came down the stairs.

She was wearing a black nightgown, and because guests were present, she had put on an extra white jacket, but her graceful figure was still evident.

A charming young woman, full of allure.

Bai Yingying stood behind Zhou Ze, gently tugging his arm. Zhou Ze followed her gaze and saw a string of red marks on Wang Ke’s wife’s left calf.

It looked like blood, winding its way down from the depths of a dense forest along a stream’s path, leaving traces of the years’ tribulations.

“Darling, last night, I accidentally knocked over my bottle of red nail polish without even noticing. When I woke up this morning and saw that red puddle on the floor, it scared me half to death.

I watched a horror movie recently, you know, and I thought you were like the male lead in the movie, eating me while I slept.”

Wang Ke’s wife walked up to Wang Ke, reaching out to caress his chin. Her husband hadn’t slept all night, and she felt a pang of sympathy.

“You’re too thin, I wouldn’t be full,” Wang Ke chuckled in reply. “Go make breakfast.”

“No, thank you, sister-in-law.”

Zhou Ze refused again.

“We’ll be going now. If anything happens, you can come find me at my bookstore. Oh, by the way, my bookstore has moved to South Street now, it’s not far from here.”

Zhou Ze meant that if they truly sensed something was wrong, they could come to his bookstore for refuge.

This was the most Zhou Ze could do. He couldn’t stay by Wang Ke’s side 24 hours a day, protecting him without fail. Besides, today was Qingming Festival, precisely when his bookstore’s “business was good.”

Many new customers would flock to the bookstore due to the Qingming Festival. This was big business, like a peak season, and Zhou Ze didn’t want to miss it.

Declining Wang Ke and his wife’s attempts to keep them, Zhou Ze and the two others walked out of the Wang family villa.

Just outside, Zhou Ze stopped, turning to look at the balcony.

Wang Ke’s daughter should still be sleeping. It was the Qingming Festival holiday, so she didn’t have to go to school.

The little loli likely hadn’t returned, or perhaps, she couldn’t return at all. In fact, if the little loli had returned, Wang Ke’s worries would probably have been unnecessary. If that zombie truly intended to seek revenge on the Wang family, it might very well have gone there only to never return.

“Boss, was that… really red nail polish?” Bai Yingying asked from behind Zhou Ze.

“It could also be menstruation, and she found an excuse to avoid embarrassment.”

“…………” Bai Yingying.

Zhou Ze suddenly thought of a question, looking at Bai Yingying, and said, “You should have stopped, right?”

“…………” Bai Yingying.

How could she possibly answer that? And besides, how would a zombie have such a thing!

The three walked to the community entrance. Since it was morning, it was quite lively, with many street stalls already open.

No matter what malicious events had recently occurred, people’s lives always had to continue.

A middle-aged man with all his limbs intact knelt on the ground, holding a bowl, begging. He looked somewhat pitiful, dirty, and kept muttering “ah ah ah,” like a mute.

When the old道ist passed by, the beggar reached out and grabbed the old道ist’s pant leg, signaling for him to give him something. The old道ist, after all, was dressed as a monk, seemingly easier to scam money from.

Begging was also a profession that required rich experience, and it also involved distinguishing and focusing on one’s clientele.

Who knew the old道ist would just wave his sleeve, pushing away the hand that was grabbing him, and at the same time spit at the beggar, scolding:

“With hands and feet, and younger than this poor道ist, what good thing can’t you do, yet you choose to beg here? You’ve completely disgraced your ancestors!”

Given the old道ist’s age and status, saying these words was perfectly justified.

He was old, yet he still live-streamed, and served ghosts. He was usually quite frugal, but Zhou Ze had heard from Bai Yingying that the old道ist apparently sponsored several poor students in the mountains.

Upon hearing this, the beggar seemed to become infuriated, immediately standing up. All they heard was a scream, and then he fell to the ground, flailing his arms and legs, crying “Ah ah ah ah!”

His direct meaning was that the old道ist had hit him; his implied meaning was that he was going to extort money.

The old道ist saw this scene and was so angry he almost laughed, wishing he could truly go up and punch this scoundrel a few times.

Of course, onlookers also began to appear around them. Everyone came with the mentality of watching a show, and no one spoke up for the beggar or stood up for him.

In this day and age, people’s compassion had long been exhausted by countless beggar-scammers. Sympathy for the weak is human nature, but in this era, sometimes those who appear to be “weak” often have reversals, and their lives might be better than those who sympathize with them.

Zhou Ze, however, frowned slightly. He didn’t want to waste any time on such matters, so he gave Bai Yingying a meaningful look.

Bai Yingying understood and moved closer to the crowd.

The beggar felt a chilling coldness spread through his body, and he immediately jumped up, shouting:

“I’m freezing to death! I’m freezing to death!”

He could speak now, and laughter immediately erupted from the crowd. Although they didn’t understand why, everyone found it amusing.

The beggar scurried away in embarrassment.

The old道ist sniffed and sighed, “Some people deserve to be poor.”

Zhou Ze smiled, not mentioning that he had seen an iPhone X in the beggar’s pocket earlier.

The three had breakfast together at the community entrance. Bai Yingying thoughtfully brought plum juice, and this time Zhou Ze ate more. He hadn’t touched his supper last night and indeed needed to eat to replenish his energy.

After eating, Bai Yingying prepared to hail a taxi back to the bookstore.

Just then, an elderly man with white hair and a hunched back walked past them. The old man carried a bag in his left hand and a plastic bag in his right, as if he had just returned from buying groceries.

What drew attention was that the old man’s left hand, holding the bag, only had two fingers. This was a genuine amputee.

The old道ist saw this and proactively stepped forward, asking if he needed help.

The old man shook his head, indicating no.

The old道ist said, “Elder brother, it’s alright. You live in this community, right? I’ll help you carry it back.”

But the old man still smiled and insisted on shaking his head, indicating he could manage on his own and didn’t need help, even though carrying things with only two fingers looked very difficult for him.

The old man walked on, presumably living in the same community as Wang Ke.

The old道ist let out a long sigh and said, “People are indeed different. A young person with all their limbs intact kneels on the ground, wanting to get something for nothing, begging for free food.

But this disabled old man, even older than me, still maintains his dignity and pride.

Cheers! This morning’s dose of wisdom is satisfying. I feel energized and full of positive energy for the day.”

The old道ist mumbled to himself and felt self-satisfied, which is common for anyone who has received such “chicken soup for the soul,” as if their spirit had been purified in an instant.

“He dropped something,” Zhou Ze prompted.

“What? Did he drop his wallet? Then I should quickly return it to him. He’s so old, it’s easy for him to forget things, and his memory won’t be good. It’s not easy for him.”

The old道ist said this while looking at Zhou Ze, then he froze, his face showing a horrified expression.

Zhou Ze was holding a middle finger joint in his hand, its tip still stained with blood, and even faintly steaming. It was truly fresh.

“You’re right, as people get older, their memory gets worse.

Even when a finger drops off,

They don’t notice.”

title: 第一百一十八章 舌尖上的家宴
content:
"Knock, knock, knock... Knock, knock, knock..."

Outside, a knocking sound came. Wang Ke, still seated on the living room sofa, raised his head, straightened his clothes, and walked to the entrance. He glanced at the monitor; the camera outside showed a hunched old man.

The old man had his head down, so his true face couldn't be seen.

Wang Ke wasn't planning to open the door.

But then, with a "click,"

The door opened.

Wang Ke stepped back, and the old man appeared at the doorway.

From the doorway, a chilling wind blew in, and the surrounding temperature gradually dropped.

With a "thud,"

The plastic bag the old man was carrying fell, spilling some pickled vegetables, ginger, garlic, and other ingredients.

"Going to cook later."

The old man's voice was somewhat thick, not like a young girl's soft voice, but more like a sound made by a throat full of fluid.

Wang Ke took a deep breath. At this moment, he was even calm enough to take off his glasses, wipe them, and put them back on, saying:

"Although I know the probability of convincing you is small, I still have to try. I really have nothing to do with that hospital."

"Oh."

The old man responded, then lifted his head. His skin began to wrinkle. Earlier, it only had some age spots, but now, it had completely turned into shriveled elm bark.

Rough and cracked, his eye sockets also sunken, and in his hollow eyes, a green flame flickered.

"Who cares?"

The old man took a step forward, closing the distance between himself and Wang Ke.

"Others don't care about the cheap lives of people like us, so why should I care about others' lives?"

Watching the old man steadily close the distance, Wang Ke sighed, "I consider myself a good person, and I sympathize with your experience.

Although I don't know what you've been through..."

"Bang!"

Before Wang Ke could finish his rambling, he was knocked to the ground. The old man's strength was immense, so much so that Wang Ke, an adult man, was like a small chick in front of him.

The fall was severe. Wang Ke's left arm was immediately fractured, and he didn't know how many ribs were broken in his chest.

"Sorry, I'm not a police officer, and I don't care about evidence when I act."

The old man squatted beside Wang Ke.

"In short, everyone in that photo, everyone related to that hospital, must die."

After speaking, the old man reached out and patted Wang Ke's face. Several of the old man's fingers were missing, and green pus oozed continuously from the broken parts, looking very disgusting.

Wang Ke let out a long breath, enduring the intense pain. He seemed to have resigned himself to his fate.

Just then, the old man looked up at the staircase. Wang Ke's wife stood there, staring blankly at everything below. The woman had changed from pajamas into sportswear, seemingly planning to go for a morning run.

"Go back to sleep, obediently. I don't kill women."

The old man grinned grimly, stood up, and dragged Wang Ke by the ankle. He walked in front, with Wang Ke being dragged behind him. Together, they entered the kitchen.

Wang Ke's wife came down from upstairs and stood at the kitchen doorway.

The old man looked at the woman at the door with some surprise. He seemed prepared to react, but he had expected the woman to call the police, but she didn't.

He had expected the woman to grab something and fight him to rescue her husband, but she didn't do that either.

In fact, the old man thought the woman screaming, crying, begging, or running away were all understandable reactions, but the woman's next response was somewhat astonishing.

The woman paused at the kitchen doorway for a moment, then turned and carried the pickled vegetables and other ingredients the old man had brought inside. She actively took out various seasonings from the kitchen cabinet and began washing pots and bowls for the old man.

Wang Ke, lying on the floor, wiped his face when he saw this scene, and said helplessly:

"Wife, you're having another episode."

The old man was also bewildered by the woman's actions. Since he couldn't figure it out, he stopped thinking about it. The old man picked up Wang Ke, pressed his neck into the sink, turned on the faucet, and began rinsing him with cold water.

The woman next to him picked up a knife, but instead of attacking the old man, she began to slice garlic and chop green onions for him at a rapid speed, demonstrating her culinary skill. At the same time, she opened the gas valve, poured oil into the wok, and lit the fire.

It was already clear what the old man intended to do with all those ingredients, and the woman seemed to be helping him.

The kitchen was harmonious, everyone performing their roles, all working towards preparing a delicious dish.

Wang Ke didn't resist; he also knew he couldn't resist anymore.

The old man reached out, grabbed Wang Ke's hair, and lifted his head. Then, the old man's fingernails repeatedly moved across Wang Ke's facial skin.

Like a customer at a market, choosing which cut of meat to buy.

"Stir-fry first, then boil the bones for soup. Delicious."

Wang Ke's wife stood by and said to the old man. She spoke very earnestly, indicating she had given it deep thought. At the same time, she swallowed, a little hungry.

The old man seemed to have gotten used to this eccentric victim's wife and actually pondered for a moment before agreeing with her suggestion.

The old man was about to use his fingernails to cut the meat, but Wang Ke's wife actively handed him the cleaver, signaling him to use it.

She pointed at the old man's fingernails and said, "Dirty, unsanitary."

An experienced housewife knows that the freshness of ingredients often determines the quality of a dish. One must be as meticulous and demanding as possible with ingredients, ensuring no external factors affect the taste. This is being responsible for oneself and for one's family.

And the old man, who had already become a cadaveric ghoul and had "eaten" more than a dozen hospital people to replenish himself, was quite the gourmand.

He well knew that differences in a person's gender, age, work environment, and physique often determined variations in flavor. The old man favored Wang Ke, who had plenty of lean meat, was middle-aged and not greasy, and had well-developed bones, making him very suitable for consumption.

This was a gift from nature, and the old man knew the secret to cooking this dish. This was the last person he intended to kill, so he planned to treat himself in a more ceremonious way.

He believed that this method could soothe the anger and sorrow he experienced before his death. This was the miraculous effect of food.

The green flame in the old man's eyes flickered. He took the knife, but with so few fingers, he held it somewhat unsteadily, yet still managed to grip the handle with his remaining fingers.

Wang Ke was shaking, so the old man flipped the knife and hit the back of Wang Ke's head with the blunt side. Wang Ke immediately passed out, much like stunning a fish before cleaning it.

And then,

The old man's knife fell!

"Clang!"

With a crisp sound,

The knife in the old man's hand flew off. A long tongue, appearing from nowhere, lashed out like a whip, striking the old man's wrist and sweeping the knife away.

Wang Ke's wife turned around and looked behind her.

The old man also looked at the kitchen doorway, where a small loli stood.

The small loli had her mouth open, half of her tongue still hanging out. The cleaver lay at her feet. Her eyes sparkled with intimidating light, but one of her hands was actually gripping the doorframe to support herself, clearly indicating that she was already at the end of her rope, on the verge of collapsing.

Wang Ke's wife looked at the small loli and gently beckoned, saying:

"Rui Rui is awake. Come, brush your teeth and wash your face. The soup will be ready soon.

It's soup made from Daddy's meat. It's very delicious. The bowl is full of thick fatherly love."

The small loli gave the woman in front of her a complicated look. She was still ecstatic beyond words.

The old man slightly tilted his head, staring at the small loli.

"The Underworld has its order; the Yellow Springs can be crossed!"

The small loli gathered her strength,

Her tongue extended again,

"The mortal world is not a place for rogue spirits like you to run wild. You are merely a cadaveric ghoul, not yet qualified to transcend!"

The tongue shot out again, striking the old man's chest.

With a crisp "crack,"

The old man's chest immediately caved in, and he flew backward, crashing into the tiled wall. A concave dent and a large area of cracks appeared on the wall behind him.

But the old man, with a hole in his chest, slowly got back up.

His fingernails were black and long, and pus began to drip from the corners of his mouth, but he stood up again and continued to look at the small loli:

"There really is... the Yellow Springs?"

The old man seemed bewildered,

He seemed to be thinking of his own relatives.

Everyone has a Yellow Springs complex because everyone, as they grow up, inevitably experiences the passing of loved ones.

In Chinese eyes, the Yellow Springs is a place to mourn the departed.

The small loli's tongue extended again, but this time, its force was clearly much weaker than before.

The old man stretched out both hands, grabbing the tongue. His body trembled, but he wasn't thrown back again. Then, his fingernails began to fiercely cut the long tongue.

"Pfft!"

The tongue snapped,

The small loli fell to her knees, her body convulsing, the light in the depths of her eyes flickering between clear and hazy.

She had barely escaped from Rongcheng,

Unexpectedly, an unformed cadaveric ghoul chose this moment to break into her home!

In any other time, if such a character dared to offend her, she would surely have annihilated him, body and soul!

"Are you... a Ghost Messenger? There really is an Underworld, and a Netherworld?"

The old man's appearance was terrifying, with a large hole in his chest and pus everywhere on his body. He first mumbled to himself, then began to roar madly:

"If there's an Underworld, if there's a Netherworld, then why haven't those who deserve to go to hell gone to hell?!

Those villains, those criminals, can still continue to harm people in the living world!

I... I... I'll eat all of you, all you useless, incompetent wretches,

I'll chop you all up and throw you into the pot to boil!"

As the old man spoke, he picked up the unconscious Wang Ke again. With a "clatter," he swept aside the previous pot, and the blue flame on the gas stove continued to rise.

The old man grinned grimly, poised to put Wang Ke's head into the flames.

The small loli struggled to lift her head,

And snapped:

"How much longer are you going to watch? I understand you don't want me to live, but are you going to leave even your childhood friend to die?"

"I really didn't expect you were already back."

From the entrance, Zhou Ze's figure emerged. He walked up to the small loli, looking at her kneeling on the ground with her butt sticking out.

A strange, low-level pleasure, typical of a low-level extra who doesn't survive half a scene, inexplicably arose in his heart.

In short, it was the triumph of a petty person!

You have your day too.

"Come on, Uncle will give you a pat."

With that, Zhou Ze reached out and ruffled the small loli's head.

Heh heh,

You actually have your day today.

The small loli bit her lip tightly, her eyes full of shame and indignation, and she squeezed out two words:

"Save him."

"You really think of him as your father?"

Zhou Ze was a bit surprised.

Zhou Ze knew she was injured, and she could have stayed upstairs, but she still appeared. It seemed his childhood friend wasn't entirely useless; he could make a Ghost Messenger willing to risk her life for him.

On the other hand, looking at himself,

He was now practically a villain.

He even felt a bit like he was being a jerk.

Testing whether the small loli had returned was just a spur-of-the-moment idea, but if Zhou Ze had intervened earlier, Wang Ke would at least have been spared the physical pain.

Zhou Ze was also a bit lost in thought; people really do change.

He used to be so kind and righteous, a doctor with a parent's heart.

Now, he seemed much more selfish than before.

Of course, Zhou Ze had to be cautious; the small loli's existence was a concern for him, and he had to treat it carefully.

The old man was startled when Zhou Ze walked in, but seeing that Zhou Ze ignored him and only spoke to the little girl without even looking at him, he didn't hesitate, continuing to push Wang Ke's head towards the flame.

"Woof woof woof!"

A barking sound came from outside the kitchen window,

Then,

A long, white figure directly shattered the window glass and flew in, knocking the old man to the ground. Wang Ke also rolled to the side, escaping the fate of being roasted, at least for now.

The old man quickly bounced up and grabbed at the white figure. Immediately, dull thuds constantly echoed in the kitchen, as if two people were swinging large hammers and fiercely smashing things.

Next,

It was a battle between the domesticated and the wild.

title: 第一百一十九章 最大的一單業績！
content:
For a long time, Zhou Ze hadn't seen Bai Yingying fight. Bai Yingying's daily routine was cleaning, being a sales clerk, playing PlayerUnknown's Battlegrounds, and sleeping with him.

But Zhou Ze never forgot the first time he and Xu Qinglang properly faced a reanimated Bai Yingying.

Why was Bai Yingying so docile?

Because she had been thoroughly *handled* by him before.

But that didn't mean she had truly become a little quail. For instance, the last time Zhou Ze saw Bai Yingying playing games, her essence wasn't that of a soft-spoken girl.

Zombies are, after all, zombies. Some fierce traits ingrained in their bones won't be erased, just as Zhou Ze himself isn't entirely conscious of what he does after "drinking himself into a blackout."

If zombies were truly gentle and obedient babies, Madam Bai wouldn't have specifically instructed Zhou Ze to cremate her body with bamboo at the next *Han Yi Festival* when she went to hell.

That old man, referred to as a "corpse demon" by the little loli, Zhou Ze didn't know what the term meant, but he could probably infer that it was inferior to a proper zombie.

At least Bai Yingying wouldn't suddenly have a finger break off while carrying a plastic bag, nor would she constantly ooze disgusting acid from her entire body. If Bai Yingying were like that, Zhou Ze would rather continue sleeping in the freezer than have her sleep beside him.

He might even burn Bai Yingying as a sacrifice to the heavens without hesitation when the *Han Yi Festival* arrived.

So, this is a society that values looks, after all. Many people, after being hurt in a beauty contest, might say grudgingly, "What's inside matters most."

But in reality, even after you die, having good looks is still a very important thing.

"Boom! Boom! Boom!"

A series of rumbling sounds came from the kitchen.

The floor was cracked.

The walls were dented.

The duel between two corpses, both immensely powerful, naturally caused quite a commotion. But it was clear that Bai Yingying had the upper hand and even had energy to spare.

Moreover, the old man had already been severely injured by the little loli earlier.

"Boom!"

With a loud crash, Bai Yingying directly slammed the old man onto the floor. For a moment, fluids splattered.

The old man's body was already battered beyond recognition, looking like the skeleton sailors often seen in *Pirates of the Caribbean*, with only a few scraps of flesh haphazardly adorning his frame.

"Clap, clap, clap, clap, clap!!!!"

The old Taoist, who had been observing from outside the entrance, finally walked in at this moment, applauding and cheering for Bai Yingying, shouting, "Yingying, you're the fattest!"

"Shasha sha..."

Dragging the old man's body, Bai Yingying emerged from the kitchen. Several green streaks were left on the tiles where the old man had slid.

But he wasn't dead. He really wasn't dead.

Regardless of anything else, just looking at his vitality was terrifying enough.

And Bai Yingying was like a cute little puppy.

At Zhou Ze's command,

She rushed out, pinned down the prey, and then dragged it before Zhou Ze, presenting it to him.

Zhou Ze crouched down in front of the old man. He looked at the old man, and the old man looked back at him.

"You... you're also a ghost messenger..."

Zhou Ze nodded.

"A blind ghost messenger..."

The old man spat at Zhou Ze. If his chin hadn't been devoid of flesh, a couple of thick phlegm blobs would surely have flown out.

"I've always been curious about something. That day at the hospital, were you also watching?"

"I wasn't there," the old man replied. "So... the people in the hospital... were they... knocked out by you?"

Zhou Ze didn't answer.

"Those people... are scum..." the old man repeated.

"Mm," Zhou Ze agreed.

"Scum should be killed, should be eaten!" the old man stubbornly insisted. "Heaven didn't let me die completely... it was so that I... I could clean up... clean them up."

"What about him?" Zhou Ze pointed at the unconscious Wang Ke.

The old man hesitated. After Bai Yingying's thorough beating, his anger had subsided significantly.

So, when you're in a bad mood, you can go to a street billiard hall or dance hall, flick boogers at the tattooed or sleazy-looking guys gathered there, and you'll immediately feel better.

"I don't know..." the old man answered.

Wang Ke, in that situation, could still calmly explain himself. Even when his life was threatened, he continued to articulate his thoughts. This, in itself, spoke volumes.

Either this guy had long since put life and death out of his mind and wasn't afraid to die, or he had a clear conscience, willing to die but not to have a bucket of feces dumped on his head.

"But you still intended to kill him and cook his flesh. You've gotten addicted to eating people, haven't you?" Zhou Ze chuckled.

The old man remained silent.

"You say Heaven didn't let you die, for some unknown reason, turning you into this neither-man-nor-ghost state, as if great responsibilities were to befall you.

I also admit, those scumbags in the hospital, even I wished they would all report to hell sooner.

But you've developed a habit, you've slowly stopped caring whether the people you kill are right or wrong, because you've become infatuated with this feeling.

I once heard a story about a prosecutor abroad. In his early years, he arrested some corrupt officials, gaining great fame. Later, to sustain that feeling, he used illegal means and even deliberately framed and incriminated some high-ranking officials to build his reputation. What he did, in fact, is just like you."

Zhou Ze reached out and gently patted the old man's face, then regretted the action and wiped his hand on the old Taoist's pant leg.

"..." The old Taoist.

"When you gaze into the abyss, the abyss also gazes into you;

You just haven't noticed it yourself."

Zhou Ze slowly stood up. "Alright, that's enough talk. You must be tired of listening. It's time for you to be on your way."

"I refuse... The suffering... and persecution... my family and I endured... why did no one... no one care... about me and my family..."

Zhou Ze made a cutting gesture and shook his head,

"I can guess your story must be very sad and tragic. You must have suffered greatly from that hospital's poisoning. If told, it would surely bring tears to those who hear it.

But pity and suffering cannot be a reason for your violence.

Because in this world, there are countless pitiable people, and countless people who have endured hardship.

The vast majority of people are overcoming hardships, facing new lives with a positive attitude.

Even if some abandon themselves because of it, that's their own business. They haven't harmed others, just suffered their sorrow alone.

So, what makes you so special?

That's not a reason. It never will be."

The old man remained silent upon hearing this.

"So, the program I despise the most is the one where reporters interview murderers. In it, they're always repenting, always complaining about how miserable their lives were before, how pitiful they are.

Even the prison authorities and reporters will contact the victims' families, asking them to forgive the criminals, so that the criminals can be better reformed and become new people.

How wonderful?

How touching?

They even have to strip the victims' families of their right to 'hate'.

But unfortunately, this show is still quite popular, after all, there are many people who like to defecate from a moral high ground."

After mumbling to himself for a bit, Zhou Ze looked at the old Taoist again: "I said so much, so I'll charge more for it. Nowadays, even high-end funeral homes offer psychological counseling services for families. Consider this an extra service from me. When you go down, give me more spirit money, understand?"

The old man slowly closed his eyes and sighed.

"You still have a soul, don't you? Or some kind of conscious entity, since you're not a proper zombie. Now, float out of your body, and I'll send you to hell."

The old man lowered his drooping hand, seemingly resigned to his fate. As for whether he found any peace, Zhou Ze didn't know and didn't care.

However,

In the next moment,

The old man's body suddenly spasmed. His nearly severed neck actually lifted, and he bared his fangs, biting towards Zhou Ze's body!

"Pfft!"

Zhou Ze didn't move, but his fingernail directly pierced the old man's body. The black aura swirling within his nail began to rage madly through the old man's body. This was a form of torture beyond ordinary understanding, even surpassing the physical blows Bai Yingying had inflicted earlier.

The old man hadn't even bitten Zhou Ze before he began to wail. He was in agony, utterly tormented, and he was begging, pleading for Zhou Ze to withdraw his nail.

But Zhou Ze remained motionless, calmly watching the old man writhe in extreme pain before him.

Clearly, all of Zhou Ze's previous rambling, all that psychological counseling, had been useless.

This also showed that the program exploring the pitiful and sunny side of murderers' hearts was also useless. Many people have impulses and feelings of hatred, but normally they wouldn't kill innocent people under the guise of impulse and anger. Once they do, they are no longer human; they are beasts.

"Actually, I don't hate you as much as you might imagine," Zhou Ze said faintly. "But you can no longer control yourself. You are ultimately not a knight who slays demons; in fact, you've become a demon awaiting a knight's slaying."

Under the pressure of Zhou Ze's fingernail, a black light cluster drifted out of the old man's body.

Zhou Ze opened the gates of hell,

Reached out, grabbed the light cluster, and threw it in.

Zhou Ze didn't scatter the old man's soul and even sent him to hell, giving him a glimmer of hope. This wasn't entirely because he was reluctant to part with the performance points, but rather because at the hospital entrance, he himself had harbored the idea of using others to do his dirty work and watching from the sidelines.

However, Zhou Ze instinctively reached out, took out his small notebook, and then his eyes immediately widened!

Damn it!

The performance record showed: fifty percent!

In other words, this one case with the old man was worth the sum of all the ghost performances he had sent down before!

Zhou Ze felt a bit of regret. He should have known not to send him down so quickly. He should have first asked if he had any fellow practitioners, or if they were also hidden in this city.

The little loli, still kneeling on the ground, watched Zhou Ze take out a small notebook, and a look of horror appeared on her face.

The shocking part wasn't just the document itself, but what that notebook represented!

She suddenly remembered what the Faceless Woman had said to her at the underworld shop: In her opinion, the prey in their eyes was far less important than that guy from Tongcheng!
