At that moment, Wang Ke's wife suddenly walked over with a knife, fork, and plate, knelt beside the old man's broken body, cut off a piece of flesh, placed it on the plate, then speared the meat with the fork, and prepared to put it in her mouth.

The old man reacted quickly and stopped her. She was still struggling, shouting:

"Let me eat, let me eat, let me eat..."

Zhou Ze walked over to the little loli, looked at her kneeling on the ground, then looked at Wang Ke's wife, and a hint of understanding appeared in his eyes.

He opened his mouth and asked:

"Is your mom sick?"

title: 第一百二十章 鬼差的身份
content:
小蘿莉微微側頭，她總覺得周澤是故意說出這種有歧義的話，她沒回答，這個問題，無論你回答「是」與「否」，都不好。



  而且，小蘿莉相信周澤也能看得出來。



  是的，周澤看出來了，一直以來，周澤都以為王軻是不是有那種特殊的癖好，現在想來，其實不是王軻的問題，而是王軻妻子的問題。



  王軻是一個心理醫生，他自己負責治療自己的妻子的問題，甚至，還得在家裡生活時，故意去配合妻子的那個點。



  他是在演戲，演出的目的是為了讓自己妻子開心。



  一個事業有成的大男人，每天在家裡，必須得裝作很開心的樣子去不停地吃肉喝肉湯，還得表現得甘之如飴。



  他妻子天天買肉回來，看著丈夫吃。



  對於其他人來說，可能是一種折磨吧。



  「把她綁了，你盯著他，讓她別出意外。」周澤對白鶯鶯說道。



  白鶯鶯點點頭，直接過去提起王軻的妻子進了書房。



  老道不需要知會，把昏迷的王軻抱起來放在了沙發上，幫其檢查著傷勢。



  周澤沒直接打120把王軻送醫院把王軻妻子送精神病院，對於自己妻子的事情，王軻應該有自己的選擇權，周澤沒必要給他的生活添亂和擅自做主，再加上，周澤也懶得接下這種麻煩事兒。 



  王軻雖然昏迷著，身上也有傷，但問題不是很大，應該很快就能清醒過來，到時候，他自己拿主意吧。



  而且，在這個當口，周澤還有一件需要解決的事情。



  他把小蘿莉抱起來。



  小蘿莉在掙扎。



  以前，小蘿莉也曾讓周澤把自己抱起來，但那是因為她想要和周澤在個頭上「平起平坐」，那時的她，帶著矜持，帶著克制，帶著絕對的壓迫和掌控。



  而現在，風水輪流轉了，這一次被周澤抱起來，周澤是純粹把她當鄰家小妹妹，



  我揉揉，



  我捏捏，



  看你還皮不皮。



  周澤抱著小蘿莉上了樓，



  老道站在樓梯口看著周澤把小蘿莉抱上去，



  臉上有些掙扎，也有些糾結，他在考慮要不要阻止老闆做這種禽獸的事情。



  太禽獸咧，



  她還只是個孩子。



  如果周澤知道老道現在心裡的想法，估計會毫不留情地給他身上開幾個天窗。



  把小蘿莉放在了床上，周澤退開一步，看見小蘿莉在自己抱起她上樓時就已經睡著了，現在躺在床上，發出著輕微可愛的「鼾聲」，像是一件精細的瓷器。 



  少頃，她揉揉眼，有些意外地看著周澤，糯聲道：



  「叔叔，你怎麼在我家啊，還在我房間裡。」



  好可愛，好萌啊。



  但周澤卻像是不解風情的糙漢子，直接把小蘿莉又舉起來，讓他在自己手裡晃來晃去，同時道：



  「我不管你是不是在裝，反正我無所謂，你是裝現在就別裝了，你不在裝現在就給我重新占據主意識醒來。



  我有些事有些帳要和你好好掰扯掰扯。



  別高估我的耐心，我不是那種喜歡喊小姑娘回家看金魚的怪叔叔。」



  周澤晃啊晃的，一開始小蘿莉還在哭鬧，甚至開始喊「爸爸媽媽」，但過了一會兒，她安靜了下來，目光沉靜，咬著自己嬌嫩的紅唇，沉聲道：



  「放我下來。」



  「喲，你還皮！」



  「啪！」



  一巴掌拍在了不可知的位置上，小蘿莉瞪大了眼睛，扭過頭看著周澤，恨不得把周澤給生吃了！



  你居然敢打本座的不可說位置！



  你還敢說你不是怪叔叔？



  「哦，抱歉。」



  周澤鬆開手，小蘿莉落到了床上。 



  但小蘿莉還在瞪著他，周澤有些訕訕，道：



  「剛疏忽了，沒留意你又回來了。」



  「周澤，你以為你現在就可以無法無天了麼？」



  小蘿莉呵斥道。



  「啪！」



  不可知的位置再度遭受重擊，



  小蘿莉一臉地不敢置信！



  你剛說是疏忽，不是故意的！



  周澤撫摸了一下剛拍了不可知位置的手掌，道：



  「這次不是故意的了。」



  說著，周澤也靠著床邊坐了下來，



  道：



  「別學電影裡的主角，死到臨頭還喜歡嘴硬，因為我又不是電影裡的反派，我才不願意和你廢話這麼久。」



  「你敢殺了我？」小蘿莉反問道。



  「啪！」



  「啪！」



  「怕！」



  三聲不可知位置的拍打，



  小蘿莉身體連顫了三下，



  貝齒都快要將紅唇咬出血來了。



  「前陣子有一個人和我說了一樣的話，但最後，她死了，所以，不要拿這個威脅我，因為沒用。 



  哪怕你躲藏在這個軀殼裡，我也有辦法把你給逼出來。」



  「她是被你殺的？」小蘿莉知道周澤殺的那個人，不，確切的說是那個鬼是誰。



  一個鬼差，周澤已經殺了，那麼他不在乎再殺一個。



  「你想問什麼，說吧。」



  小蘿莉翻身，坐在床上，隱藏住了自己不可知的位置。



  周澤取出了證件，放在手裡，問道：「鬼差到底是如何上崗的，我現在，算是上崗了麼？」



  「你有證，又有了我的地獄之門鑰匙，你就是鬼差。」



  「管理這麼寬鬆的麼？」周澤有些意外。



  「鬼差不過是陰司最低的一級，陽間這麼大，如果連最低級的鬼差都需要陰司的上層去一個一個地選擇和認命，那陰司的上層其他的事情就不需要去做了。



  哪怕是鬼差之上的鬼捕頭，也不需要認證，只需要取得相對應的資格，但之後的巡檢，才必須由陰司親自認證。」



  「哦，這樣啊，工作環境居然這麼寬鬆，那不就是誰殺了你們就能獲得鬼差身份麼？」



  「陰司有序，黃泉可…………」



  「啪！」



  周澤把小蘿莉翻了過來，不可知位置又是一記！ 



  「為什麼！」小蘿莉承受著可怕的屈辱感。



  「好好說話，別總喊口號。」周澤提醒道。



  「陰司有陰司的規則，殺鬼差，是大忌！」小蘿莉回答道。



  「感覺是廢話啊，我殺了，蓉城的那位肯定也殺了，他沒事兒就算了，為什麼我也沒什麼事兒、」



  說著，周澤抬起手，準備再來一記。



  嗯，



  觸感不錯。



  「那是因為你沒有違規，而且，你殺的那個鬼差，本就出了問題，與其說她是鬼差，倒不如說是一個厲鬼遊魂！」



  「好吧，我這樣總結一下不知道對不對，意思就是鬼差就是最低級的小蝦米，死了、工傷，都沒人負責，哪怕被搶奪了身份，只要後繼者沒胡作非為甚至還繼承了原本工作繼續做鬼差的事兒，陰司也不會管？」



  小蘿莉點了點頭。



  「講真，這公務員當得可真沒意思。」



  周澤撇撇嘴，這不是打擊自己的工作積極性麼，自己現在還是臨時工呢，但現在知道了哪怕轉正了，也沒什麼保證，頓覺這工作的前途，好暗淡啊。



  陽間裡，大家爭破頭想當公務員不就是為了一個鐵飯碗嘛。



  這到了陰間，就不是鐵飯碗了，甚至這飯碗還得輪流轉。 



  「鬼差，是鬼物入陰司謀求身份的最好方式，而且，鬼差證的身份，也不是那麼好拿的，基本來說，不可能被繼承到。」



  小蘿莉又著重看了一眼周澤手中的那個證件，抿了抿嘴唇，繼續道：



  「古往今來，多少山川河神因為走不了被正統王朝封舍赦的大道，又想謀求上進，自願成為鬼差走陰司地獄的路子，就是這個道理。」



  「行吧，還有一件事。」周澤攤開自己的手掌，「這個標記，你還能拿回去麼？」



  小蘿莉沒吭聲。



  「回答我。」



  周澤的臉慢慢地陰沉了下來。



  小蘿莉點點頭。



  周澤深吸一口氣，慢慢地握緊拳頭，柔聲細語的繼續問道：



  「怎麼拿回去？」



  「我給你的東西，我自然有自己的辦法收走。」



  「你這有點迴避這個問題啊。」周澤伸手在小蘿莉的腦袋上揉了揉，道：「來，乖，跟叔叔具體點說說，這個印記，這個你口中的地獄之門鑰匙，得用什麼辦法，才能拿回去？」



  小蘿莉看著周澤，她在猶豫。



  「說。」



  周澤提高了聲音，同時指甲長長，甲尖在小蘿莉臉上輕輕地滑行。 



  小蘿莉低聲道：



  「殺了你，就拿回來了。」



  預料之中的答案，



  但卻讓周澤的眼睛徹底深沉了下來，



  他沒生氣，



  他也沒憤怒，



  至少，沒有表現出來，只是淡淡地道：



  「意思就是，當初你對我畫的餅，對我許下的承諾，和給我的未來期望，全都是假的。



  你只是需要去蓉城辦事，所以讓我幫你代工賺業績。



  等你回來時，



  你是打算殺了我的，甚至，我也是你算計好的業績，



  對麼？」



  小蘿莉閉上了眼。



  時光往前追溯，那一天，周澤還淡然地看著唐詩和老道為蓉城那邊的事情發泄著怒火，甚至做出了很多普通人在激動之下才會有的舉動。



  那時候自己居然還能淡定地喝咖啡！



  如果自己當時知道萬一蓉城的那位輸了，等小蘿莉回來自己不光是利益受損，而且還會是徹底的GG，自己還可能那麼平靜地品著咖啡麼！



  說不定自己會更瘋狂，買上萬塊的煙花出來放放。 



  伸出舌頭，舔了舔自己的嘴唇，周澤依舊平靜地看著小蘿莉，沒有氣急敗壞，沒有歇斯底里，只是問道：



  「你為什麼不回地獄，是因為受傷太嚴重，連地獄都回不去麼，甚至，是現在的你，也不敢下地獄經過黃泉路？」



  小蘿莉沒回答，沉默，也是一種默認。



  周澤夾起自己的證件，掃了一眼，像是在自言自語，道：「把一個鬼差送回地獄，能賺多少業績？」



  「我是鬼差，送我進地獄，沒有業績。」小蘿莉回答。



  「哦，抱歉，是我沒清楚；



  我說的是，



  把一個鬼差的證件毀掉，再把她折磨成沒清醒神智的厲鬼，再把她送回地獄，



  是不是就有業績了？」

title: 第一百二十一章 捕頭
content:
The atmosphere in the bedroom instantly turned cold, a killing aura slowly beginning to fill the space.

Strike her while she’s down!

Besides, from the very beginning, he and the little loli had been in a life-or-death confrontation, and it was the little loli herself who had caused all of this.

To destroy her and extract the last bit of valuable essence from her, Zhou Ze felt no psychological burden whatsoever.

The little loli looked at Zhou Ze, then slowly opened her mouth:

“Do you want to be a constable?”

People on the verge of death always subconsciously grasp at any straw nearby to gain a sliver of hope for survival. The little loli before him was no exception.

She knew Zhou Ze wanted to kill her, and she knew Zhou Ze wanted to use her to gain a final bit of benefit and value, so she offered it willingly.

Moreover, her original pride and courage had long been completely shattered in that netherworld shop in Rongcheng, on that night. While her physical injuries hadn’t recovered, her mental wounds hadn't either.

That night, she knelt in a corner, watching her colleagues, who had come with her, perish one by one, like fireworks. This scene had almost overturned her original worldview.

Upon hearing the words "constable," Zhou Ze remained impassive, merely sitting there quietly.

His implied meaning was: Please begin your performance.

Anyway, listening wouldn't get him pregnant.

“Do you know the two basic conditions for becoming a constable?”

Zhou Ze still didn’t answer, but he slightly raised his hand to his nose and sniffed.

The implication was: Don’t shout slogans at me, and don’t play with preambles. Speak properly, or I don’t mind re-experiencing the wonderful sensation of that unknowable spot.

Anyway, you’re almost dead, and I can strike while the iron is hot.

The little loli took a deep breath. She wished she could tear Zhou Ze to pieces right now, but the tables had turned. She had returned severely injured from Rongcheng, and it was already a miracle that she hadn’t died. Now, she couldn’t even deal with a corpse demon.

She was the fish on the chopping block, and he was the knife. It was that simple.

“There are two conditions to become a constable: one is to meet the performance points, and the other is to have three other ghost messengers willing to serve under your command, obey your orders, and recognize you as constable.”

Zhou Ze still said nothing.

“To recognize you as constable, they must willingly offer their soul blood to be integrated into your identity badge, allowing you to control their life and death, making betrayal impossible.

Fulfilling these two conditions allows one to be promoted to constable. Afterwards, you can then strive for the position of patrol inspector.”

“Recognize me as constable?” Zhou Ze chuckled. “If it’s that simple, wouldn’t you ghost messengers be fighting among yourselves first?”

Just as the little loli often chanted the BGM slogan, “The Underworld has order, the Yellow Springs can be crossed,” if ghost messengers had to go through this process to become constables, and could casually force others to become their subordinates through life-or-death confrontations, wouldn't the entire ghost messenger circle become a chaotic arena for "raising gu*"?

However, in Zhou Ze’s view, the ghost messenger circle was actually quite peaceful. Otherwise, the little loli wouldn’t have been able to summon so many ghost messengers to Rongcheng that time.

“First, there’s only a difference in status between a constable and a ghost messenger, not a difference in strength. Only at the patrol inspector level does one receive a sealed certification from the Underworld, at which point one truly possesses a status superior to both ghost messengers and constables.

Second, as long as the constable one serves is promoted to patrol inspector, the previous contract automatically disappears, and one regains freedom.

Third, you are coercing me right now. Although you are also a ghost messenger, your act of coercing a colleague must have been noted by the Underworld. If you kill another ghost messenger who has caused trouble, it’s like solving a problem for the Underworld, and there will be no repercussions.

But if you kill me, it will definitely be recorded by the Underworld. You might not feel it now, but in the future, when you seek further promotion, you will surely encounter trouble. Furthermore, if you continue to act so unrestrained, the Underworld will issue a warrant for your arrest, just like that person in Rongcheng last time.

Therefore, while there is indeed coercion and an exchange of interests in the subordinate relationship among ghost messengers, there are rarely life-and-death forced subjugations because doing so isn’t worth it.

Wanting to be a constable is for the qualification to become a patrol inspector, to gain official status beyond being a mere yamen runner, and to have one's own spirit tablet in the Underworld, even if it's the lowest rank. So, not many lunatics would willingly use crude methods to coerce other ghost messengers just to become a constable.”

Zhou Ze extended his pinky finger and dug into his ear, saying, "So, if I kill you, I'll still have trouble later?"

“Absolutely.”

“Meaning, even if I become a constable, because of today’s incident, it will be difficult for me to become a so-called patrol inspector?”

“Indeed.”

“Then why shouldn’t I just kill you directly?”

“You can use your performance and your actions to erase the negative impact of your coercion today. It’s not entirely impossible to advance further. I can... help you.

Because as long as you are not promoted, I must remain under you, with my life and death in your hands.”

Zhou Ze slowly stood up, pulled open the curtains, opened the French window, and walked out onto the balcony, saying:

“The first time I came here, when I left the door, you were standing here watching me, right?”

The little loli didn’t understand what Zhou Ze meant.

Zhou Ze’s fingertips tapped lightly on the railing. He was hesitating and thinking.

In truth, Zhou Ze was a very conflicted person. He was a small figure, and he had never denied being one, neither in his previous life nor in this one.

The contradiction of a small figure lies in aspiring to freedom on one hand, and desiring to realize ambitions on the other, wanting to stand and admire the scenery, yet also thinking of kneeling to beg for progress.

If he were a powerful overlord, he would accept the little loli’s suggestion without hesitation. He wouldn’t care if she had wanted to kill him before; he would only care about the immediate benefits and progress.

If he were a free spirit, like the one in Rongcheng, he wouldn't care. He would only care about his own unrestrainedness, even if he was blacklisted, he would disdain it, thinking, "Either you kill me, or I kill you."

And Zhou Ze was exactly in between the two.

“How about this, let’s flip a coin?”

Zhou Ze thought of a method and pulled a one-yuan coin from his pocket.

“Heads, I kill you. Tails, I take you.”

The little loli’s eyes widened. She thought Zhou Ze was joking, deliberately humiliating her, to entrust her life to something like a coin toss!

Are you a goddamn idiot?!

The little loli roared in anger internally!

Her ten slender fingers gripped the bedsheet tightly. She hated that she was injured; otherwise, she would surely extract this person’s soul and burn it with hellfire a hundred times!

“Here goes!”

Zhou Ze tossed the coin.

The coin spun continuously in the air.

The little loli’s eyes were fixed on the coin until it fell.

Zhou Ze bent down and looked at the coin on the floor.

It was the "tails" side.

The little loli let out a long sigh of relief. Although the process was absurd, in the end, she would live. Even if she was under someone else's control, at least she could survive.

Moreover, the little loli had seen Zhou Ze’s ghost badge. She clearly knew which shadow stood behind that badge. Even if that shadow had vanished countless years ago, once, that Mount Tai had been a colossal entity that suppressed Hell!

She was willing to take a gamble. The future, in fact, was not entirely bleak. Because Zhou Ze did not seem like someone without good fortune. He was supposed to be her pre-planned performance target and substitute, but after she returned from Rongcheng, she found that everything had changed; he had gained status and controlled the situation.

Even the appearance of the corpse demon today became an opportunity for him to force her to reveal herself, preventing her from hiding any longer.

Zhou Ze picked up the coin, smacked his lips, as if somewhat dissatisfied:

“How about we flip it again?”

The little loli’s eyes instantly turned red, and her tongue extended, circling around her. She was going crazy; she was ready to fight!

“Don’t get excited, don’t get excited. I know you have a long tongue and are good at it.

Don’t get excited, I won’t flip it again.”

Zhou Ze walked up to the little loli, tilted his head slightly, and took out his ID booklet.

The little loli retracted her tongue, then slapped her forehead. Immediately, a black glowing bead floated out from there and merged into Zhou Ze’s ID booklet.

Zhou Ze licked his lips. In the unseen, it was as if another line had appeared in his heart, and this line concerned the little loli’s life and death.

A life and death that he could sever with a single thought.

The little loli got off the bed and slowly knelt before Zhou Ze, a single knee on the floor, one hand resting on her knee, looking up, performing the bowing ritual of a subordinate to a superior.

“Lin Ke, reporting to Constable!”

Lin Ke should be the name of the ghost messenger, and the name of this little loli's body seemed to be Wang Rui.

At this moment, the little loli, filled with anger and unwillingness, trembled slightly as she knelt, but she could only accept her fate!

Zhou Ze looked at the little loli beneath him,

and slowly lifted his head.

The once arrogant and cold little loli, who had been so overbearing in front of him, was now kneeling at his feet.

This dramatic reversal, this mix of ice and fire,

was indeed very pleasant.

Just then, the old Taoist priest came up the stairs. Wang Ke had woken up, and he was here to inform the boss.

He had just reached the stairs and gently pushed open the bedroom door,

Then his eyes immediately widened!

He saw the little loli kneeling before Zhou Ze.

Due to the obstruction of his view, Zhou Ze was blocking the old Taoist priest’s line of sight to the little loli. So, in the old Taoist priest’s field of vision,

The little loli was kneeling in front of the boss, her body trembling slightly,

And the boss was looking up, hands on his hips, looking very pleased.

“Hmm…”

The old Taoist priest gasped,

Daring not to make a sound,

He quickly tiptoed backward, hurrying down the stairs, softly muttering:

“Oh dear, truly a beast,

Three years minimum, three years minimum;

The boss is such a beast.”

---
Translator's Note:
* "raising gu": A practice in ancient China involving placing multiple poisonous insects into a sealed container and letting them fight until only one survives. The survivor, "gu," is believed to possess extreme toxicity and spiritual power. Here, it metaphorically describes a chaotic, ruthless competition.

title: 第一百二十二章 還有？
content:
Wang Ke woke up. He was badly injured. When Zhou Ze went downstairs, he was still lying on the sofa, his face a bit pale, partly from fright, partly from his injuries.

"Do you need my help?" Zhou Ze asked.

Wang Ke shook his head, then said, "As long as you help me..."

"Oh, then I'm leaving."

Zhou Ze saw Wang Ke shake his head and directly turned towards the entrance, as if he hadn't heard Wang Ke's "subtlety" just now.

Wang Ke: "..."

Stepping out the door, Bai Yingying and the old Taoist priest also followed.

Actually, for Zhou Ze, the matter here was already resolved. The remaining issues would be handled by the little loli. Judging by her actions of risking exposure to save Wang Ke, she still valued Wang Ke as her father very much.

This couldn't help but make Zhou Ze feel a certain emotion, though not for the sentiment of father-daughter love.

Rather, the ghost envoy who possessed his sister-in-law last time also seemed to have been influenced by the host, adopting the host's way of thinking, even going so far as to kill to fulfill the host's sister's unrequited love.

And the little loli seemed to be the same, risking danger to save her father. Zhou Ze didn't think Wang Ke's personal charm was so great.

So,

Does this mean that ghost envoys or high-level ghosts can inhabit a person's body but will inevitably be affected by them?

Then, was he also affected?

It seemed there was a period when that was true,

For example, that obsession that bothered him for a long time:

Anyway, she's not sleeping with me?

Right, that must be him being influenced by Xu Le;

The normal him couldn't possibly have such vulgar impulses in his mind.

But it seems the influence he experienced wasn't as severe as that on the two ghost envoys in the little loli and his sister-in-law. There must be some involvement and distinction here.

For example, they might keep the human host's soul intact for convenience when entering and exiting Hell, ensuring the body can continue to live for future use when their souls leave. However, with two souls in one body for a long time, some influence is inevitable.

As for Zhou Ze himself and Tang Shi, the body's original owner was dead, so there was no original soul getting in the way, and the influence was naturally smaller.

Each has its pros and cons,

For example, Zhou Ze couldn't learn the little loli's "biubiubiu" technique.

After hailing a taxi and returning to the bookstore, Zhou Ze yawned. He was a bit tired, but what surprised him was that there were still customers in the bookstore.

He checked the time; it was already past two in the morning.

If it were a customer who could send him Hell banknotes, Zhou Ze wouldn't be surprised, but this was a living person.

A girl in a white dress sitting there, reading a book and playing with her phone.

She looked to be about twenty-five or twenty-six, with a pleasant appearance. Her reading habits were a bit unusual; she would mouth the words while reading, like an elementary school student learning a text for the first time.

Bai Yingying went to take a shower. After a big fight with that disgusting old man, she wasn't injured, but she was dirty. Having spent a long time with Zhou Ze, she naturally picked up some of his habits.

One must know she was a zombie lying underground for two hundred years. Zhou Ze didn't believe Madam Bai would frequently take her corpse out for a bath and a spa treatment.

The old Taoist priest went out to buy a late-night snack. With Xu Qinglang not at the shop these days, everyone's meal situation was a bit concerning, as Xu Qinglang usually handled all three meals.

Thinking of this, Zhou Ze felt a bit sad.

If Xu Qinglang didn't come back soon,

He'd be running out of this 'juice'.

Not rushing upstairs, Zhou Ze poured two glasses of water and walked over to the girl. He placed one glass in front of her and sat on the sofa opposite.

Although it was a bit disappointing that she wasn't a ghost, a visitor was still a guest, so he had to entertain her.

"Thank you."

The girl looked up at Zhou Ze, then lowered her head again to read the article in her hand, muttering softly.

Zhou Ze initially thought this was just her reading habit, but slowly he realized it wasn't right. She wasn't just muttering; she was reciting with emotion and feeling.

As if noticing Zhou Ze's gaze, the girl looked up and glanced at him again, then smiled.

"Are you the owner of this store?" the girl asked.

Zhou Ze nodded, picked up his glass, and took a sip of water.

Composure, he needed to be composed.

"How's the bookstore's business?" the girl asked again.

Zhou Ze frowned. He hated it when people asked this question, because anyone who asked it had already figured out that the bookstore's business with living people wasn't good.

But he couldn't explain to them that he did business with the dead, so he could only silently endure their gaze that saw him as a fool with money to burn.

"It's alright."

"Oh, I think your store is great. Coming here at night to read books and drink a beverage, it has a wonderful atmosphere," the girl said.

"Mm."

Having just taken in the little loli, Zhou Ze was in a decent mood and willing to chat with the customer, so he asked,

"Are you a radio host?"

The girl shook her head.

"Then you're an audio storyteller?"

The girl smiled and nodded, "Boss, you're very smart."

There was nothing smart about it; these days, there were only a few professions related to voice.

"What do you record?"

"Novels." The girl took out her phone and asked, "Boss, do you usually listen to audio novels?"

Zhou Ze remembered that Xu Le's computer seemed to have many audio novels stored, such as the audio version of the *Bai Jie Stories* series.

"Occasionally," Zhou Ze said dismissively.

"This is my stage name, 'Master Hua'. I'm a signed host for 'Lazy Listener', Boss, you can try listening to the books I've recorded," the girl introduced herself to Zhou Ze.

"What kind of novels do you usually record?"

"I like to record horror novels. In the audio market, horror, romance, and another major genre used to be popular."

"Another genre?" Zhou Ze caught the key point.

"They're not allowed to be recorded now. Those were slightly explicit novels. They used to be allowed, and many people wanted to listen. Now, the regulations are strict, and they're forbidden.

In fact, when we had professional training, we used to specifically learn techniques for recording those kinds of books."

"There's even specialized training for that?"

"Yes, the teacher would hold classes, and dozens of us signed hosts would sit together, following the teacher's rhythm, making 'ah ah ah ah' sounds, with emotion and expressiveness.

Then the teacher on the podium would constantly shout at us: 'More passionate, more intense, more relaxed.'"

Zhou Ze's mouth slightly opened; this was truly eye-opening.

Imagine that atmosphere, it's really a bit alluring, a refined version of a bacchanalian feast.

Of course, this is art, after all, such matters and things related to them are not considered dirty, as no one was conceived by their mother bathing in sunlight and born.

"There was a sister in our class who was called out by the teacher for not being relaxed enough. She said aggrievedly: 'Teacher, I'm already loose, how much looser can I get?'"

After saying that, the girl herself laughed. Clearly, she was someone who enjoyed chatting and talking, and of course, talking was also her profession.

"What made you interested in coming here?" Zhou Ze asked.

Especially late at night.

"A fan invited me here," the girl replied, "He's been following my work for a long time, ever since I started out as a newcomer six years ago. He commented and messaged me every day, supporting and encouraging me for a long time. I didn't expect that he and I both live in Tongcheng, but he said he's going back to his hometown, which is very far from Tongcheng.

So he wanted to invite me out to meet him, and I agreed."

"He must have given you a lot of donations, right?" Zhou Ze asked.

The girl shook her head, "Not much, but the person willing to accompany you when you're most unknown is the one most worth cherishing and protecting."

"He invited you to this bookstore, and said he was going to a very distant place."

A bold guess formed in Zhou Ze's mind.

To living people, his bookstore was just a quiet shop, but to another kind of person, it held unusual significance.

"Do you think all the people who listen to your books are living people?"

"Of course! I never inflate clicks or recommendation votes. All these popularity and data metrics are real; no zombie followers or Taobao package operations here!"

Clearly, the girl misunderstood Zhou Ze's meaning.

Zhou Ze shook his head, dodging the question.

The girl, still thinking Zhou Ze didn't believe her, continued:

"Boss, the audio market isn't huge, but there are over a billion people in China. Even if the proportion of people who enjoy listening to audiobooks is very low, it's still a significant number given such a large population base.

You should know,

Visuals limit imagination,

Auditory input can infinitely spark imagination."

"That's quite a profound statement."

Zhou Ze stood up. Bai Yingying had finished her shower, and he was about to take one himself.

Coincidentally, Zhou Ze saw a man in a white shirt walk into the bookstore. He glanced around, first saw Zhou Ze, and smiled shyly and timidly,

Then he saw the girl next to Zhou Ze and walked over to her.

The girl seemed not to have noticed him, completely unaware of someone approaching.

"I really like your work, and I really like your voice. I'm leaving now, I'm going away, please keep up the good work.

You're not a small-time new broadcaster anymore, your popularity is already very high. Even without my company and support from now on, you'll become more and more popular!

Keep going!"

The boy made an encouraging gesture towards the girl,

However,

The girl heard nothing.

Instead, she checked the time, muttering that her enthusiastic fan who had invited her seemed to have stood her up.

Zhou Ze didn't rush to send the boy to Hell but lingered for a while longer, casually picking up a book from the shelf.

Indeed, the advent of the internet is truly a miraculous platform.

Across the screen,

Not only can you not distinguish whether the person flirting with you is a man or a woman.

In forums, in posts, in book review sections,

Those who reply to messages,

Those who give you likes,

Those who curse you,

Those who encourage and support you,

Might not only be living people,

But also...

title: 第一百二十三章 癩頭和尚
content:
"Companionship is the most enduring declaration of love," and this kind of companionship was one where they couldn't even meet. The streamer eventually left; she didn't wait for the person who had invited her here. She probably intended to go back and message that account, asking why they stood her up.

But she might not have known that the person had already permanently departed from this mortal realm.

The boy had voluntarily asked Zhou Ze to send him off. Zhou Ze didn't ask what obsession kept him lingering in the mortal realm, and the boy didn't answer. This time, sending a departed soul to hell was very easy and simple.

In fact, it could even be described as "peaceful."

There was no resistance, no struggle, no discontent; only a sense of composure.

After finishing this "business," Zhou Ze went to take a shower and then upstairs to rest. After relocating to the new store, "business" had actually improved significantly. Seeing the constantly stacking piles of Hell Bank Notes indeed gave a great sense of satisfaction to a "ghost."

He woke up already at noon. Coming downstairs, Zhou Ze saw the old Taoist priest sitting behind the bar, teasing the little monkey.

"Morning, Boss," the old Taoist priest greeted.

Zhou Ze nodded.

He sat down on the sofa by the window. Another day of leisure and basking in the sun was about to begin. This kind of life was truly pleasant, especially watching the bustling crowds outside Nanda Street.

All under heaven bustle and toil for profit. Watching others busy themselves for their livelihoods and dreams while he could steal half a day's leisure from a floating life—comparison breeds superiority, and superiority leads to better enjoyment.

"Boss, what would you like to drink?"

Bai Yingying could only wake up when Zhou Ze did. If she went too far away, Zhou Ze's sleep would be interrupted.

"Tea, please."

Bai Yingying quickly brewed tea and brought it over, placing an ashtray in front of Zhou Ze. Then she lit his cigarette before leaving.

Sometimes, Zhou Ze himself was a little confused. Did Bai Yingying know the instructions left by Madam Bai, which was why she was so meticulously attentive to him? But she seemed genuinely naive and sweet, and she held Madam Bai in great respect and admiration.

Some questions were not suitable for probing; it would just make things meaningless. Zhou Ze was content to continue playing the fool.

Drinking tea,
Smoking a cigarette,
Anyway, there weren weren't many ghosts during the day. He'd truly get busy only after nightfall.

Actually, Zhou Ze still preferred sitting in the bookstore, waiting for customers to come, like Jiang Ziya fishing — those who were willing would take the bait. It wasn't about being cool, but about it being less tiring.

He didn't like running around; it was too much hassle.

He picked up today's newspaper and skimmed through it. The "death gamble" case was already fermenting and undergoing trial. The police had acted swiftly; one by one, the behind-the-scenes investors and so on were apprehended and arrested. Justice awaited them.

Just then, the bookstore door behind Zhou Ze was pushed open. The person who walked in made the old Taoist priest's eyes light up, and he immediately showed a fierce glare!

It wasn't surprising for the old Taoist priest to react this way, because the person who entered was a monk with ring scars on his head, seemingly also suffering from scabies. A "scabby-headed monk," quite interesting.

The monk wasn't tall, about 1.6 meters, and a bit corpulent. He didn't have the demeanor of an enlightened monk; he was far from the ethereal grace of the old Taoist priest opposite him.

From ancient times, Buddhism and Taoism have always been at odds. During ancient dynasties, when Taoism flourished, Buddhism was suppressed, and when Buddhism flourished, Taoism was suppressed. After all, they were competing for followers and resources; if you had more, I naturally had less.

From the old Taoist priest's perspective, the bookstore was his territory, and this scabby-headed monk seemed to be here to challenge him.

But unexpectedly, the scabby-headed monk didn't even look at the old Taoist priest. He merely smiled at the "hostile implication" released by the old Taoist priest, then walked directly to Zhou Ze and sat down opposite him.

"A cup of tea."

The scabby-headed monk said.

The old Taoist priest, with a gloomy face, brought a cup of tea, while also reminding him, "The minimum charge here is one hundred, and we don't offer fortune-telling or geomancy here."

The scabby-headed monk slightly raised his head, looked at the old Taoist priest, and smiled:

"We are different."

"We are different."

A very profound statement, both belittling the old Taoist priest and elevating himself.

It implied: you are a quack who just muddles through, while I have real talent and learning; we are different.

Zhou Ze exhaled a smoke ring, blowing it directly into the monk's face.

It wasn't that Zhou Ze wanted to stick up for the old Taoist priest—after all, a visitor was a guest—but the moment the monk entered the bookstore, Zhou Ze felt an subtle sense of warning.

The scabby-headed monk was not angered. He simply clasped his hands together and recited, "Amitābha."

Suddenly, Zhou Ze felt uncomfortable all over, as if tiny ants were crawling on him.

At once, black nails began to slowly grow from the fingers of Zhou Ze's cigarette-holding hand.

"Patron, calm your anger. This humble monk came for tea and to read books; there is no ill intent."

The scabby-headed monk unclasped his hands, picked up the teacup, and took a sip of tea. Immediately, Zhou Ze's discomfort subsided.

"You can go attend to your duties," Zhou Ze said to the old Taoist priest.

The old Taoist priest could only withdraw.

"Patron, it's quite interesting that this shop is located in the bustling city. It provides tranquility amidst the hustle and bustle."

Zhou Ze didn't speak.

"This humble monk is currently traveling through the four directions. Today, I happened to arrive in Tongcheng, only to find that my two old friends were both gone. I was truly very curious. After some investigation, I learned that a figure like you, Patron, has appeared in Tongcheng."

"Who are your two friends?"

"One is a woman, in the prime of her youth. The other is an old man, serving in the Temple of Literature."

Zhou Ze pondered slightly. The former likely referred to the female ghost messenger who had problems, and the latter was probably the elderly dwarf from the Temple of Literature.

"Are you here to avenge them?"

"Not at all, not at all. Origins and ends, all have their destined course. Joys and sorrows, all by the will of Heaven. Nothing can be forced, nor should it be. This humble monk has come today simply to see you, Patron, to converse with you, and to forge a good karma."

"It seems that those who form good karma with you don't end up well."

The scabby-headed monk heard this and chuckled helplessly.

Then, Zhou Ze didn't speak, and the scabby-headed monk didn't speak either. The atmosphere suddenly became awkward.

It was only when the tea had likely grown cold that the scabby-headed monk finally spoke:

"This humble monk came to express some thoughts to the enforcers, to share some concepts. Wherever this humble monk goes, he always seeks out the local enforcers to discuss things with."

"You speak, I'll listen. Once you're done, you'll still have to pay."

"Buddha says that all living beings are equal. The 'living beings' here actually refer not only to the living but also to the deceased. They are born here, they grow here, and they are actually no different from the living.

In this humble monk's eyes, they are also people, also members of all living beings.

Those who seek good are the foundation of all beings, and should be cherished.
Those who fall into evil are a calamity for all beings, and should be punished.
For those ghosts who harm people, there is naturally the wrathful Vajra aspect. But for ordinary departed souls who linger in the human realm due to obsession or various reasons, this humble monk believes they have the right and the freedom to do so.

However, after the demise of the Lord of Mount Tai, the affairs of the Underworld operate on a system of merit points and performance. Any ghosts lingering in the human realm must be escorted to hell.

This humble monk has always disagreed with this practice.

Therefore, I have come to persuade the higher-ups: ghosts also have good and evil, and both advantages and disadvantages. Things cannot be dealt with by a single stroke, otherwise, it is lazy governance and dereliction of duty."

Zhou Ze felt a little like laughing.

Seeing Zhou Ze's reaction, the scabby-headed monk sighed. One who walks the path must go against the current, knowing something is impossible yet still striving for it.

He picked up the newspaper in front of Zhou Ze, turning to the last page. It featured news from another province, about a murder case.

"This newspaper, this humble monk has read it. When this incident occurred, this humble monk was not far from there.

A man went missing, and his relatives reported it. The police suspected he might have been murdered, but couldn't find the body and were at a loss.

At this time, a woman from the same village told the police that her deceased old mother had appeared in her dream last night, informing her that someone was buried next to her house, occupying her land.

The police initially dismissed it as a joke, but when they sent people to check by her old mother's grave, they found a newly disturbed patch of earth. After digging, they discovered the missing man's corpse.

Later, based on the evidence remaining on the corpse, the true murderer, a fellow villager named Li, was found.

The murderer was apprehended, and the victim found peace.

In this incident, the old mother's spirit did a good deed; good and evil reside in the heart.

Although she lingered locally and did not go to hell, she did not harm anyone, and even helped people. Do you think the Underworld should take such a ghost to hell?

Perhaps she just wanted to watch her children and grandchildren grow up and carry on the family line, nothing more."

Zhou Ze picked up the cold tea, took a sip, and shook his head.

Clearly, Zhou Ze did not agree with this argument.

"You still haven't convinced me. I'm sorry to have made you come all this way for nothing. You can go to other cities, other regions, and talk to other ghost messengers about your ideals and philosophies. Maybe you'll find a kindred spirit who will join you in fighting for ghost rights."

The scabby-headed monk smiled helplessly. Clearly, he had seen this kind of reaction many times. He picked up the newspaper again, looked at the news, and sighed once more.

Zhou Ze reached out and pressed the newspaper down.

The scabby-headed monk looked at Zhou Ze with some confusion.

"Monk, there's a saying: don't run before you can walk. You say you've been fighting for the rights of ghosts, but you can't even see humans clearly. What right do you have to speak for ghosts?"

"What do you mean?"

Zhou Ze pointed at the news in the paper, shook his head, and said:

"You said you were in that area at the time. So, did you find the old mother's departed soul in that village?"

The scabby-headed monk shook his head. "This humble monk was not fortunate enough to see her. If I had been, I would surely have treated her with respect. Though the elder's body perished, her good intentions remained."

Zhou Ze smiled. "I haven't been to that place, but I'd bet a drawer full of Hell Bank Notes that there was no such departed soul of an old mother. Her soul would have gone to hell long ago after she died."

"How is that possible? You're a ghost messenger; do you not believe in ghosts in this world?"

The scabby-headed monk found it absurd.

"The missing and murdered person was from the same village.
The murderer who hid the body was also from the same village.
Then, a woman who relayed clues to the police through a dream was also from the same village. Isn't that obvious enough?"

Zhou Ze lit another cigarette and said, "The newspaper says the police initially didn't believe it, and later, after excavating the grave and finding the body, they also found it very strange. This is the reporter's style, to make the news interesting and attention-grabbing.

But in reality, I believe the local police were well aware.

The woman was there to report it. It's highly likely she passed by and saw the murderer burying the body."

"Then why didn't she tell the police directly?" the scabby-headed monk asked.

"Because the murderer was also from the same village. The murderer might have parents, children, siblings. If she reported him directly, wouldn't she incur the resentment of his family?

So, she used the excuse of ghosts and spirits, saying her old mother dreamt it, subtly revealing the clue in that way to avoid being resented.

It's like some human trafficking cases in remote areas. Do you think the neighbors don't know that this family bought a person?

Or, do you think everyone in the entire village is evil, that no one has a conscience, that no one has good intentions?

It's just that people feel that reporting it would upset their fellow villagers whom they see every day. Even if they sympathize with the poor woman who was trafficked, they can only pretend not to see."

The scabby-headed monk was slightly startled, and asked blankly, "What is this?"

"Human nature."

title: 第一百二十四章 偷屍體的賊
content:
The Leprous Monk came suddenly and left suddenly. Of course, under the old Daoist's watchful eye, he paid his bill.

"Is this person sick, boss?" The old Daoist asked, annoyed. "This humble Daoist just stood by and listened for a bit. He actually advised you, boss, not to catch ghosts. If you don't catch ghosts, boss, where will your performance and netherworld money come from?"

After speaking, the old Daoist waved his hand and turned off the lights in the shop. Even though it was daytime, the brightness in the shop immediately dropped significantly. Then, he yelled like he was presenting a treasure:

"Monkey!"

The little monkey immediately hopped over, holding two plastic fans. The fans were stained with silver glitter, and when waved, they truly created a dazzling effect.

The old Daoist and the monkey stood in a row. The monkey and the old Daoist stomped their feet in unison and shouted:

"Our slogan is!"

"Work hard! Work hard! Work hard!" (Chirp chirp chirp chirp)

"Our spirit is!"

"Strive! Strive! Strive!" (Chirp chirp chirp chirp)

"Our goal is!"

"Netherworld money! Netherworld money! Netherworld money!" (Chirp chirp chirp chirp)

"Alright, dismiss!"

The monkey immediately retreated and jumped back onto the counter.

Zhou Ze watched, not knowing whether to laugh or cry.

"Netherworld money is justice, netherworld money is everything. Boss, don't let him trick you!"

The old Daoist had a scar on his chest. It was said that he once relied on netherworld money to escape a knife aimed at his heart, so he had a deep obsession with it.

Zhou Ze waved his hand, indicating he understood.

"Oh, it's you?"

The bookstore door was pushed open, and a young man walked in.

Zhou Ze knew this young man. He was an intern doctor at People's Hospital. When Zhou Ze pretended to be a doctor at the hospital to treat people, this intern was there several times, and Zhou Ze had helped him out of tricky situations a few times.

"Why are you here?"

The young intern doctor was very curious about Zhou Ze. Being naturally naive, he still hadn't figured out the relationship between Zhou Ze and Dr. Lin, and still thought Zhou Ze was truly a doctor.

Of course, it was also because Zhou Ze's medical skills were indeed superb, making it difficult for the young intern doctor to discern.

"Being a doctor has no future, so I started a business," Zhou Ze replied perfunctorily.

"Is this bookstore yours?"

"Sort of."

Just then, Tang Shi appeared at the top of the stairs, looking at Zhou Ze.

"You sit for now, I'll be right back."

The young doctor sat down, and the old Daoist enthusiastically brought tea. As long as you accepted the tea, the minimum charge was one hundred.

Zhou Ze walked up to Tang Shi, "What's wrong?"

"Are you free tomorrow?" Tang Shi asked.

"No."

"Then what were you planning to do tomorrow?"

"Haven't decided yet."

Tang Shi nodded, indicating she understood, "Then let's have dinner together tomorrow night."

As soon as she finished speaking, both Tang Shi and Zhou Ze frowned simultaneously.

Having dinner together tomorrow was normal social etiquette for ordinary people, but for these two, it was no less than torture.

To them, "having dinner together tomorrow night" could be translated as "electric shock together tomorrow night."

"Let's have tea," Tang Shi corrected.

"Are guests coming?"

"Sort of." Tang Shi looked around and said, "You can relax, I won't be fighting you for the maid anymore."

Zhou Ze smiled and nodded.

After talking with Tang Shi, Zhou Ze turned and walked back to his original spot. The old Daoist and the young intern doctor were chatting animatedly, seeming like fast friends despite their age difference.

Of course, with the old Daoist's experience, he could become a close friend with anyone from any walk of life.

"What's up?" Zhou Ze asked.

"Boss, he said that bodies in their hospital's morgue always get damaged or go missing, but they can't find out who's doing it. I just gave him a tip."

Saying that, the old Daoist took out a plastic bottle from his pocket. It was fluorescent powder.

"I'm telling you, it's definitely someone inside your hospital doing it. You secretly sprinkle this on the bodies. If you catch the thief, then you, as an intern doctor, can also become a full-time employee."

"Become a full-time employee at the Public Security Bureau?" Zhou Ze looked at the old Daoist. "Why are you giving others such bad ideas?"

At this moment, the young intern doctor received a call, probably urging him to return to the hospital. He hung up, smiled at the old Daoist, shook his hand, and turned to leave the bookstore.

"Boss, do people really steal bodies?" The old Daoist asked curiously. He knew Zhou Ze was a doctor in his past life and must know some inside stories.

"Yes," Zhou Ze replied.

"Then why? To transplant organs?" The old Daoist immediately asked.

"Do you think organ transplantation is that simple? The conditions for organ transplantation are very strict. Stealing bodies from the morgue for organ transplantation is basically impossible.

Generally speaking, in the past, they could be sent to some medical schools or research institutes for dissection experiments. After all, human bodies are not white mice; experimental subjects are scarce.

Then there are also some superstitious people who steal bodies for ghost marriages. Additionally, some people believe that drinking powder made from a corpse's skull can cure illnesses. In short, there are all sorts of theories, so body theft used to be quite serious, but it has gotten much better since cremation was promoted in the country."

"Grind a skull into powder and drink it? Like pearl powder?" The old Daoist made a motion as if he wanted to vomit.

Zhou Ze sat back down in his usual spot by the window. A Nissan stopped in front of the bookstore, and a person got out of the car—someone who had returned to their hometown earlier.

"You're back!"

The old Daoist looked at Xu Qinglang's figure with great excitement. He was tired of takeout and really missed the days when Xu Qinglang was in the shop.

Zhou Ze was calm, but he also let out a sigh of relief inwardly. He was almost out of his plum juice.

Xu Qinglang didn't come in. Instead, he waved at Zhou Ze, then squatted down by the shop entrance.

He looked troubled.

Zhou Ze walked out of the shop and stood beside him. After thinking for a moment, he also squatted down.

"What's wrong?" Zhou Ze asked.

Xu Qinglang didn't rush to answer. Instead, he handed Zhou Ze a cigarette, then sighed and said:

"Went home for a blind date."

"Good news," Zhou Ze said.

"Sigh."

"Didn't hit it off?" Zhou Ze asked.

Xu Qinglang shook his head, "Hit it off too quickly."

"How fast? Did you roll in the hay?"

Xu Qinglang glanced at Zhou Ze but didn't deny it.

"Really fast," Zhou Ze exclaimed.

"I'm not like you, I'm still normal," Xu Qinglang reminded him.

"Then why the long face?"

"The problem is, after it was over, she left a sum of money on the nightstand and then left."

"You got paid?" Zhou Ze was a little surprised.

Xu Qinglang was somewhat depressed and said:

"We originally agreed to meet at a coffee shop for the blind date, but the blind date suddenly had something come up and didn't show. I didn't get the notification and mistook someone else for her. So I sat in front of her and chatted, then I asked her to see a movie, then I accompanied her shopping, and then at night, she asked me to go to a hotel to show me a script she had just written. She's a screenwriter."

"I bet it was a fluorescent script, the kind you have to turn off the lights to see."

Xu Qinglang was a bit helpless, reaching out to scratch his hair.

"She left three thousand yuan on my nightstand after she left. I had thought of her as my blind date, and I was a bit surprised if she was too open and avant-garde, or if this was just irresistible love at first sight?"

"Most love at first sight is actually lust at first sight."

"Then I found out that wasn't the case," Xu Qinglang was conflicted.

"She took you for a gigolo?"

"Can you shut up?" Xu Qinglang looked at Zhou Ze with a resentful expression.

"You took the money, and you slept with the person, you didn't lose anything."

"That's true, but I feel my self-esteem has been hurt. I'm a man with over twenty properties, and I was actually paid by a woman who took me for a gigolo!"

"Actually, if you look at some things from a different perspective, you might feel more at ease."

"Like what?"

"Like, you're the gigolo with the most properties."

"............"

"Or, you're the one with the most properties who looks most like a gigolo."

"............"

"Sorry, I'm not very good at comforting people." Zhou Ze patted Xu Qinglang's shoulder and continued:

"Cheer up.

A bed is the most decadent place in the world. Why take a relationship that starts in bed seriously?

By the way, did you go back to your hometown just for a blind date?"

"Not entirely. Our ancestral grave is being relocated, so I went back to move it. Oh, and something strange happened, I'll tell you about it in a few days. For now, I want to go up and rest."

Xu Qinglang stood up, pushed open the bookstore door, grabbed a bottle of red wine from the counter, and went upstairs to his room.

The entire afternoon passed leisurely and easily. By eight in the evening, Zhou Ze finally perked up. Usually, around this time, the real customers would start to arrive.

Xu Qinglang was probably drowning his sorrows in wine and didn't come downstairs, so dinner was still takeout.

The old Daoist and the little monkey sat on a stool, the grandpa and grandson eating peanuts and sipping wine. The little monkey's alcohol tolerance had also been developed by the old Daoist.

The bookstore door was pushed open, and the door curtain let out a crisp sound.

The person who pushed the door open was the intern doctor.

The old Daoist was a bit drunk and reached out to invite the intern doctor to have a drink with him.

He couldn't help it; in the entire bookstore, he couldn't find anyone else to drink with him, so he could only drink with the monkey. Now that a living person had arrived, he was naturally happy.

"I just got off work. I completely forgot I didn't pay when I came here today. Oh, and I still owe you for the fluorescent powder." The intern doctor was still as dull and honest.

"Don't worry about it, it's just a hundred yuan for tea, and adding the fluorescent powder only makes it one hundred fifty."

The old Daoist said, pretending to be very generous.

The other person handed over the money, and the old Daoist angrily took it, then patted the intern doctor's shoulder and said:

"If you really want to thank me, treat me to a meal out. We brothers can have a good drink and chat."

After speaking, the old Daoist looked at Zhou Ze somewhat guiltily.

Zhou Ze nodded, granting him leave.

The intern doctor didn't refuse either. He wasn't a local, and due to his personality, he didn't have many close friends here. So, he and the old Daoist hooked arms and left the bookstore to find a pub.

It was already dark, and the streetlights were quite bright.

The old Daoist and the intern doctor walked for a while. As they neared the pub, the old Daoist turned into a dark alley nearby, unbuckled his belt, and said:

"Excuse me, gotta relieve myself first."

The intern doctor wasn't formal either. He stood side-by-side with the old Daoist and also unbuckled his belt.

"Hey, you kid, down-to-earth, I like it!"

"Haha, it's quite exciting, peeing anywhere," the intern doctor had clearly been led astray by the old Daoist.

"What's this? It's human nature, you know. By the way, did you wipe the fluorescent powder I gave you on the bodies at noon?" the old Daoist asked.

"I did, but the bodies went missing again today. The hospital already called the police, but the police still haven't found any clues."

"Didn't work, huh?" The old Daoist said somewhat apologetically.

"No, it didn't work," the intern doctor nodded.

"Then never mind. Let's split the bill for tonight's drinks."

"It's fine, I'll treat you," the intern doctor said.

"Alright, you're a generous kid, I like you!"

Saying that, the old Daoist, without washing his hands, directly patted the other's shoulder as encouragement!

"You're older, it's appropriate."

The intern doctor smiled.

The old Daoist suddenly froze.

He hadn't noticed before because there were lights in the bookstore and streetlights on the road.

But in this dark alley,

The old Daoist suddenly saw, when the intern doctor smiled,

On his teeth,

There was a faint,

Fluorescent glow.

title: 第一百二十五章 舍利子
content:
The hand that had just finished urinating trembled slightly.

The old Daoist regretted why he had skipped work to drink. Wouldn't it be a much better and nobler career to stay in the bookstore, dedicated to serving ghosts?

Why drink?!

The old Daoist was no ordinary man. Although he couldn't compare to Xu Qinglang—he had no real Taoist magic and was just a charlatan scraping by—he had, at least, served two generations of "ghosts." He had a good eye and had witnessed many bizarre things.

The faint glow on the intern doctor's teeth, like a devil's smile in the dark, sent shivers down his spine. The faucet, which had just been turned off after flushing, seemed to be turned on again, threatening to drip at any moment.

The old Daoist had told him to sprinkle the fluorescent powder on the corpse, and the intern doctor had replied that he had done so.

Then, the fluorescent powder appeared on his teeth. This connection immediately made him tremble with fear.

The old Daoist wasn't foolish enough to ask, "Oh, you're so stylish! Do you use toothpaste with fluorescent powder?"

"What's wrong?"

The intern doctor, seeing the old Daoist staring at him, asked curiously.

The old Daoist suddenly clutched his stomach, apologizing, "Sorry, my stomach suddenly hurts a lot. Must have eaten something bad recently."

"I'll take you to the hospital. It's not far from here anyway," the intern doctor said, helping the old Daoist. "Why are you shaking?"

"Damn it, my liver hurts! Cirrhosis, cirrhosis! I need to go back and take my medicine, or I'll have a cerebral hemorrhage and a stroke, and my heart disease will flare up too!"

The old Daoist babbled nonsense, but it all boiled down to one thing: I'm getting out of here!

Even if he had to invent other terminal illnesses, he had to leave. This world was too dangerous. The bookstore was safe. Now, the old Daoist suddenly found Zhou Ze's lazy sunbathing posture incredibly reassuring, and Miss Tang's cold remarks offered immense comfort!

"I'll take you back," the intern doctor said.

"No, you're tired too. You should rest. Go back and rest. You have to work tomorrow, right? You can't be careless; you have to treat and save people."

The old Daoist finished speaking and, without waiting for the intern doctor's reply, broke free from his support and ran towards the bookstore.

Under the streetlights, the old Daoist ran while looking back, afraid that the intern doctor would suddenly chase him. But the other party remained in the dark alley where the two had just relieved themselves, unmoving.

And that glowing orb of light kept appearing and disappearing, as if the other party stood there, smiling as he watched him run.

He ran all the way to the bookstore in one breath. The old Daoist pushed open the door and immediately knelt on the ground, panting heavily. He had run back with all his might, his body covered in sweat—half from the heat, half from fear.

Zhou Ze was sitting behind the counter, organizing shelves. Seeing the old Daoist return in this state, he smiled and said,

"What's wrong?"

"Boss, do you know what I just saw? That guy, that guy's teeth were glowing!"

The old Daoist gesticulated wildly as he recounted what had happened, as if he had barely escaped the clutches of a demon after a fierce battle that caused mountains to collapse, rivers to flow backward, and the sun and moon to lose their color!

It was truly terrifying!

But Zhou Ze remained calm, continuing his work as if nothing had happened.

After finishing his story, the old Daoist picked up the water on the table and drank it all, calming his internal panic. He asked, "Boss, why don't you react at all?"

"Perhaps he was just playing a prank on you."

"A prank?" The old Daoist's face crumpled. "What if it wasn't?"

"Then maybe he has a bit of necrophilia. It's no big deal. You can report it to the police. I think there's a crime called desecration of a corpse; he could get into trouble for that."

"And then?" the old Daoist continued to ask.

"Then what?"

"Boss, aren't you going to do something?" the old Daoist asked in surprise.

"Do I need to do something?" Zhou Ze countered.

"............" The old Daoist.

"You came back safely, didn't you? Nothing bad happened. Besides, if he really ate the corpse, would he deliberately sprinkle fluorescent powder on it and then eat it?

Is he stupid?"

"Boss, whether you believe it or not, I don't think that was a joke," the old Daoist said very seriously. "I think for the peace of society, we shouldn't sit by and do nothing. If he really is a necrophile, it's one thing if he's secretly eating corpses in the hospital now, but what if he can't steal corpses later and still wants to eat? Who can guarantee he won't do something even more outrageous in the future?"

Zhou Ze nodded upon hearing this, seeming to agree with the old Daoist. Then he reached out and patted the little monkey's head beside him, saying,

"Then you take Monkey Bro to vanquish evil and restore peace to the human world."

The little monkey didn't understand, but seemed quite encouraged, vigorously waving the plastic toy hammer in its hand.

"Squeak! Squeak! Squeak!"

The old Daoist's face immediately fell. He sat on a nearby chair, clearly still shaken.

After a while, the old Daoist looked up at Zhou Ze, who was preparing some snacks and wine. He asked curiously, "Boss, are you preparing a midnight snack?"

"Offerings."

"Offerings? Qingming Festival is over. Going to visit a grave?"

"Yes."

"For whom?"

"For me."

"This..."

"Today is my birthday," Zhou Ze explained.

The old Daoist was slightly stunned. He felt a deep sense of incongruity when a "living person" in front of him said he was going to make offerings to himself, and it was for his own memorial birthday.

Zhou Ze finished packing his things, put them in a single-shoulder bag, and walked out from behind the counter.

"Boss, how about I go with you?" the old Daoist offered eagerly. "You don't have a driver's license."

Zhou Ze hesitated for a moment, then nodded.

If he drove there and encountered a traffic stop, not having a driver's license would indeed be troublesome.

The old Daoist drove Xu Qinglang's Nissan out and took Zhou Ze to the cemetery.

The cemetery was already closed, but the fence wasn't very high; one could easily climb over it.

The old Daoist understood why Zhou Ze wanted to come at night. Only at night, when everything was quiet and deserted, could one experience that feeling.

In the cemetery, rows of tombstones stood neatly. Many people's lives eventually ended here.

In the dead of night, faint whispers emanated from the cemetery, as if someone was talking there.

The old Daoist initially thought he was hallucinating, but after listening carefully for a while, he realized there really were voices. He immediately reached down and touched his crotch.

"Boss, there's demonic energy!"

Zhou Ze ignored him, pointing to a small stand in front with a box and a speaker inside. The cover was a solar panel.

The sound was coming from within.

The old Daoist was a bit confused. He walked closer to look curiously. There was an instruction manual on it, detailing what programs played at what times, including morning news, emotional programs, international news, and local news.

"Damn, it's that user-friendly now?"

The old Daoist had only heard of leaving QR codes on tombstones before, which he already found very avant-garde. He never expected someone to put something like this next to their tombstone for entertainment.

Zhou Ze found his own tombstone. It had his photo on it and a brief summary of his life.

The Qingming Festival had just passed, and there were still wreaths, small toys, and letters in front of the tombstone—from his colleagues and the children from the orphanage.

Zhou Ze sat down in front of his tombstone and carefully opened each letter. They were all messages from the children to him, expressing their longing.

They all began with "Brother Zhou" or "Dear Brother Zhou." Some children's letters even used many Pinyin characters because they hadn't fully learned to read.

Zhou Ze leaned against his tombstone, quietly reading, without crying or red eyes.

After reading for a while, Zhou Ze laid out the wine and food he had brought. Then he began to eat and drink slowly.

He usually found eating painful, and this time was no exception, but eating while reading the children's letters seemed to have the effect of sour plum juice.

Although it was still hard to swallow and still nauseating, he managed to force himself not to vomit this time.

The old Daoist squatted beside him, watching his boss eat the offerings, and said nothing. He understood.

He was dead, yet still alive.

The offerings were for himself, for his own enjoyment.

The night breeze was cool, blowing all around.

At this moment, it seemed like true peace and quiet.

After finishing the letters, Zhou Ze stretched and looked at his tombstone.

He still remembered that day, being pushed into the crematorium, the great fire consuming him.

Erasing,

The traces of his previous life.

Beneath the tombstone lay his ashes.

"Boss, how about I secretly dig them out and take them back as a memento?" the old Daoist suggested.

Zhou Ze shook his head. Let the past be the past. He no longer had such deep attachments. Perhaps he once did, but now he had slowly come to terms with it.

However, inadvertently, Zhou Ze noticed a very subtle mark on the tombstone's construction. He immediately shone his phone's flashlight downwards.

Seeing this, the old Daoist also crouched down to look, then said, "This tombstone has been opened recently!"

Instinctively, Zhou Ze had a bad premonition. He had no intention of taking his ashes, but that didn't mean he was willing to see anything happen to them.

After all, it was his.

His fingernails immediately grew long. Zhou Ze directly used his nails to pry into the crack and lever it open, saving him the need for a shovel.

Soon, the masonry underneath was dug open, revealing a black urn inside.

He took out the urn. It felt heavy, meaning there was something inside.

Zhou Ze pried open the lock with his fingernails, then opened the urn.

Inside the box,

There was something,

But not ashes,

Instead, there were tiny, crystal-clear fragments.

"Damn it, Boss, you cremated out sarira*."

Zhou Ze reached in and grabbed a small fragment. With a gentle squeeze, it crumbled. At the same time, he said in a low voice, suppressing a terrifying rage,

"Have you ever seen sarira made of plastic?"

***
**Sarira:** Crystalline or pearl-like relics found among the cremated remains of Buddhist spiritual masters.

title: 第一百二十六章 神父
content:
**Anger?**

There must be anger!

"Boss, should we… should we call the police?"

Old Dao suggested from the side.

Then, he saw Zhou Ze looking at him with the gaze one reserves for mentally challenged children.

Uh...

Did I say something wrong?

But weren't you always saying to find the police when something happens and be a law-abiding citizen? I've been upholding your words and spirit.

"Old Dao," Zhou Ze slowly began.

"Hm?"

"If your money was stolen, would you be angry?"

"Of course, I'd be angry."

"Then if your ashes were stolen, would you be angry?"

"Uh..."

Who the hell is like you, this pervert, whose original body has turned into ashes, and can still discuss whether to be angry or not?

"I'm going to find that guy."

Black light began to swirl in Zhou Ze's eyes, and his ten fingernails glowed with an eerie light.

"Then, I'll tear him into a thousand pieces!"

He could have stolen anything, but he stole my ashes. Then I’ll make sure you’re buried with my ashes.

"That's the cemetery office over there. Go check the surveillance videos."

Zhou Ze instructed Old Dao. Old Dao quickly nodded. Alright, you're the boss. Whatever you want to do, I'll do it. I won't second-guess your intentions anymore.

Zhou Ze directly broke the lock on the cemetery gate, and the two walked in. Old Dao sat in front of the computer in the surveillance room and began to retrieve old footage, also locking onto the camera that could observe Zhou Ze's tombstone.

"Night, during the Qingming Festival."

Zhou Ze gave the specific time.

Because the trace of the moved tombstone hadn't completely faded, it must have happened recently, otherwise, if another ten days or half a month passed, Zhou Ze wouldn't have been able to discover this clue.

He might even come to worship himself every year and not know that what he's worshiping isn't his own ashes, nor his past, but a box of plastic pellets.

Then he would come over every holiday and mourn with a box of plastic pellets.

"Boss, if you ask me, since the other party stole something, they should have also deleted or dealt with the surveillance footage. That's how it always happens on TV.

For us to still be checking this surveillance footage now, it's the kind of pointless plotline that I, a poor Daoist priest, dislike most when watching TV.

It's completely useless, just filling time."

Zhou Ze's hand rested on Old Dao's shoulder, his fingernails lightly swaying. The chilling coldness felt as if it was directly piercing into Old Dao's body.

Old Dao's body stiffened, and he immediately sat up straight, not daring to blabber anymore, diligently starting to play back the surveillance footage.

"Stop!"

Zhou Ze called out.

Old Dao immediately pressed pause.

"Rewind a little more."

Old Dao began to rewind, and sure enough, a figure dressed in red appeared on the screen. The surveillance quality wasn't very good, and it was night, so the person's figure was very blurry, only their clothing color could be roughly made out.

He actually found it?

Old Dao was a little surprised.

The footage slowly played,

The person in red on the screen bent down, holding two surgical-knife-like tools, and pried open the tombstone. His movements were swift and clean, no slower than Zhou Ze's earlier use of his fingernails.

Then the person took out the urn, retrieved a glass container, poured the ashes into it, and then seemed to sprinkle something else into the urn. Without a doubt, it should be that string of plastic pellets.

The man placed the glass bottle into his embrace, then turned his head to look at the camera.

From the surveillance video's perspective, it was as if the other party was looking directly at the camera, making eye contact with Zhou Ze and whoever else was watching the video.

The other party deliberately pressed his face close to the camera,

This face,

Zhou Ze felt a strange sense of familiarity. It was an East Asian face, with very fair skin.

He began to search his chaotic memories for information about this person. Unfortunately, during his last confrontation with the Azure-robed Lady on the rooftop, he had entered a certain state, causing severe memory loss from that time, and he couldn't recall who the person was for a while.

"Amen!"

After uttering these words, the person turned and left, leaving behind a meaningful smile.

It wasn't until the person's final "Amen" was spoken that Zhou Ze's pupils suddenly constricted.

His memories began to rewind incessantly, finally appearing in the villa surrounded by rapeseed flowers, by the dining table, where the priest had stood quietly.

It's him!

He stole my ashes!

"Boss, do you know this person?" Old Dao looked at Zhou Ze's reaction, finding it a bit strange.

"Yes."

When the two walked out of the cemetery, it was already past midnight. Zhou Ze took out his phone and first called Xu Qinglang, but Xu Qinglang was probably drunk and didn't answer.

Zhou Ze could only call Tang Shi.

"What is it?"

"Help me wake up Xu Qinglang, no matter what."

"Alright."

About half a minute later, a scream came from the other end of the phone.

Then, Xu Qinglang answered the phone with some resentment, directly cursing:

"You're sick, calling her to wake me up!"

"Give me the phone number of that lady who rented our shop."

"Tsk, I'll find it."

Xu Qinglang heard the suppressed anger in Zhou Ze's voice and didn't complain to Zhou Ze anymore. He immediately began to look for the number and then recited it.

Zhou Ze called the number, but a prompt tone came from the other end: "The number you have dialed is switched off, please try again later."

Zhou Ze took a deep breath. Although Tongcheng was a small city with only a few million people, finding someone there without any connections would be very difficult.

And now, Zhou Ze's anger urgently needed an outlet, but he couldn't find any specific information about that priest.

When they returned to the bookstore at night, Tang Shi was sitting inside reading a magazine, while Xu Qinglang was at the bar counter, with some bruises on his face.

"Did you get in touch?" Xu Qinglang asked, applying an egg to his face.

Zhou Ze shook his head.

"Hiss..."

Xu Qinglang felt the pain on his face worsen. So he got beaten for nothing?

Zhou Ze walked up to Tang Shi and asked, "Is there any way to quickly find someone in this area?"

Tang Shi put down the magazine in her hand and countered, "Try scratching the ground with your fingernails and see if you can summon a local Earth God."

"I'm serious."

"I can't help either. Did you lose something?" Tang Shi asked.

Zhou Ze didn't answer. Losing his ashes wasn't something glorious to talk about, it was even comparable to having his underwear stolen.

It seemed there was no other way. The lady's phone was unreachable, and Zhou Ze believed that even if it were, finding the priest's address and information through her would be slim.

The other party seemed to have specifically investigated him. He might have deliberately left the surveillance video untouched because he was confident in his hiding place, believing that even if Zhou Ze discovered this, he wouldn't be able to find him.

Suddenly, Zhou Ze thought of something. He took out his phone and dialed an unsaved number:

"Hello, who are you?"

A cute, loli-like voice came from the other end.

"Get your sister to talk," Zhou Ze said.

"Who are you? I don't have a sister... Captain, I was just sleeping."

The loli voice suddenly turned into an older sister's tone.

"Help me find someone, a Japanese priest who has been active in Tongcheng recently."

"Alright."

Then, a sound like:

*Biu,*

came from the other end, and the phone hung up.

Zhou Ze felt a bit unreal,

He didn't expect his new subordinate,

Oh no,

It was a subordinate girl,

to be so efficient. After he told her something, she just said "Oh" and went to do it.

"Hey, let me ask you a question." Tang Shi suddenly spoke.

Zhou Ze looked at Tang Shi.

"Does your conscience still hurt these days?" Tang Shi pointed to her heart.

Zhou Ze didn't quite understand what she meant, then shook his head.

"Heh..." Tang Shi chuckled, "It seems you're slowly getting used to it."

"Used to what?"

"Used to living without a conscience, I suppose."

Tang Shi stood up, apparently preparing to go upstairs, and then reminded him, "Tomorrow night, we're having tea together, don't forget."

"I'm not in the mood."

Tang Shi made no comment and continued upstairs.

...

In the one-room rented apartment, a priest sat on the sofa. On the coffee table in front of him were some pictures and documents. He was deep in thought, muttering to himself.

Just then, the door opened.

The intern doctor walked in. He saw the priest sitting on his own sofa and was startled, scolding:

"Who are you? Why are you in my house!"

At the same time, the intern doctor reached for his phone, ready to call the police, thinking his house had been burglarized.

The priest, however, appeared before him in the blink of an eye, one hand grabbing his wrist and the other gripping his neck.

The phone dropped to the floor,

And his neck was lifted by the priest,

The intern doctor felt an intense sensation of suffocation.

The priest remained unmoving, maintaining that posture until the intern doctor's eyes slowly began to glaze over, and a hint of cruelty appeared on his face.

"I clearly fed you something extracted from his ashes, so why have you only turned into this ghoulish thing? What good is this kind of thing to me?"

The priest kicked the intern doctor's butt, sending him sprawling. The intern doctor immediately scrambled up, saliva dripping from his mouth.

"Slurp."

A raw pig's trot opened onto the floor by the priest.

The intern doctor directly rushed over, clutching the trot in his hands and gnawing on it, bloodstains from the trot still on his mouth, but his eyes showed dissatisfaction. Clearly, pig's trotters and pork weren't enough to satisfy him.

The priest shook his head, looking somewhat helpless as he sat back down on the sofa.

"It seems his transformation into a zombie isn't due to his body, but rather his soul. It's because his soul resided in that body, causing some changes that, when ingested by ordinary people, produced minor mutations. But these mutations are negligible.

Forget zombies, they can't even become ghouls. They just developed a lovely hobby—eating corpses."

The priest rubbed his hands,

"So, if it's not the body's reason, is it his soul's reason?

His body in his previous life wasn't the original one either?

His borrowing of a corpse to return a soul seemed to be the female Ghost Messenger's arrangement,

But in reality, there's something deeper hidden?"

The priest picked up his coffee and took a sip.

On the coffee table in front of him,

Were photos of Zhou Ze's previous life, as well as photos of Xu Le and his sister-in-law,

There was even a photo of the old man who had stabbed Zhou Ze with his fingernails at the hospital that day.

The priest pulled out a surgical knife and directly shredded the photos of the old man and his sister-in-law, then let out a long breath,

"I'll have to start investigating all over again."

title: 第一百二十七章 哈哈哈哈哈！
content:
Regardless of your mood, good or bad, one thing remains constant and unaffected by human will: time.

Another day had passed, and evening arrived. Zhou Ze sat on the sofa, twirling a pen in his hand. There was still no news from the little loli.

Zhou Ze didn't think she was being perfunctory. After all, her life and death were in his hands. If she dared to be perfunctory the first time he asked her to do something, pretending to "biu" and then secretly returning to sleep and recover, then he'd have to send her to win.

Actually, how important were his ashes from his previous life? Not that important. In fact, if he had the ashes in his hand, and someone suggested scattering them in the sea or a large river, Zhou Ze might actually do it.

Let bygones be bygones, let the past return to dust. Zhou Ze wasn't so melodramatic as to value some past item more than his own life.

But the problem was, his own things, and things deeply connected to him, he could discard them, but if someone dared to steal them, that was unacceptable.

This was no longer a matter of financial loss; it was a direct insult.

That priest, that Japanese priest, Zhou Ze hoped to find him in the next moment, and then personally pierce him with his fingernails;

He wanted the ashes, did he?

Then after Zhou Ze killed him, he'd turn him into ashes too, and mix in some dog shit for him.

The little loli was definitely still searching, and Zhou Ze knew that as a senior netherworld messenger, her roots in Tongcheng were definitely deeper than his.

So, even if he was unwilling, the only thing Zhou Ze could do now was eat and sleep as usual, maintaining his energy while waiting.

The old Taoist priest saw that Zhou Ze had been in a bad mood all day.

Most people couldn't experience the anger of having their ashes stolen,

But the boss did.

At this moment, the old Taoist priest brought over a cup of coffee, feeling that he should say something to relieve the boss's suppressed mood. He immediately said,

"Boss, that Japanese guy will definitely be found soon. Generally, in Chinese TV shows and novels, Japanese people are standard high-risk creatures with short lifespans."

Zhou Ze didn't look at the old Taoist, but picked up the coffee and took a sip.

He didn't want to chat with the old Taoist when he was in a bad mood, because he was afraid that at some point he might have the urge to stab the old Taoist to death. Perhaps his previous boss had also had such an urge?

Just then, Tang Shi walked down from upstairs, wearing a black dress today.

She was a cold and alluring woman, always pursuing high standards and refinement in her attire. This seemed to be a kind of obsession for her. Zhou Ze remembered that when she first woke up, she made the old Taoist buy her new clothes.

"Let's go for tea."

Tang Shi said coldly.

"I think I'll skip it." Zhou Ze really wasn't in the mood.

Tang Shi looked at Zhou Ze,

Standing there without moving.

She wouldn't act spoiled or beg. She always maintained that cold demeanor, and because of it, when she looked at you, you'd feel very uncomfortable and uneasy.

Zhou Ze was a soft-hearted person, and a kind one.

He couldn't bear to see others wronged or unhappy, always putting himself in others' shoes.

Of course, the pen he was twirling in his hand had just slipped from his control and was subtly trembling, looking ready to pierce his chest at any moment.

Mm.

He stood up.

"Let's go, let's have some tea," Zhou Ze said.

Tang Shi withdrew her gaze, pushed open the shop door, and walked out.

"Boss, it's a bit chilly tonight, bring more clothes," the old Taoist priest said solicitously from the side.

Zhou Ze waved his hand, indicating he didn't need any.

Then,

Zhou Ze also pushed open the door,

And then,

There was no "then."

Because Tang Shi was standing by the utility pole at the doorway, motionless. It didn't look like she had called a cab and was waiting. Zhou Ze could only stand beside her, not knowing what she meant.

Half an hour later,

Tang Shi was still standing there, motionless, without even a change in expression. Zhou Ze began to squat down and pulled out a cigarette.

An hour later,

Tang Shi was still motionless, while Zhou Ze simply sat on the curb, surrounded by a pile of cigarette butts.

Looking at the bookstore door, less than two meters away from him,

Zhou Ze really wanted to take a hammer and crack open this girl's head, to ask her what on earth she was thinking.

You've been waiting for so long less than two meters from the door, why couldn't you wait inside the bookstore?

Inside the shop, the old Taoist, Bai Yingying, and Xu Qinglang occasionally passed by, seeing the boss still sitting outside, and then looking again, still sitting outside.

Zhou Ze slightly raised his head, then lowered it,

Suddenly feeling a misconception that life was very difficult.

Finally, a white Roewe car drove over and stopped in front of the bookstore.

Are they here?
