The person to have tea with?

Because Zhou Ze saw Tang Shi move; she walked forward.

Zhou Ze also stood up, watching the car door open, thinking whether he should organize the employees who were laughing at him to wear bikinis, hold colored balls, and spread their legs while shouting a few times:

"Welcome, welcome, a warm welcome..."

But it seemed that except for Yingying, who looked good, the other two... no, actually, except for the old Taoist, the other two would look quite good and pleasing to the eye dressed like that.

But then, Zhou Ze froze. There was only one person in the car, the driver, but after the driver got out, he gave off a feeling of excessive indulgence.

Heavy dark circles under his eyes, combined with that excited state, made it easy to assume this guy was driving while high on drugs.

"Hahahahahaha..."

As soon as the driver got out of the car, he clutched his stomach and laughed.

Laughing like a pig.

Zhou Ze walked closer to him, lowered his head, and looked at him.

"Hahahahahaha... Where is this?" the driver asked while laughing.

"Tongcheng," Zhou Ze replied.

The other party spoke with a strong Sichuan accent,

Must be a friend from Sichuan.

"Hahahahahaha... Where's Tongcheng? Never heard of it."

"In Jiangsu," Zhou Ze reminded him.

"Hahahahahaha... I drove out to buy a condom, how did I end up driving non-stop all the way to Jiangsu?"

You ask me, who should I ask?

Zhou Ze felt like this driver had some mental issues.

Alright,

Before, Zhou Ze had guessed whether the person Tang Shi wanted to have tea with might be that one,

But if that person was like this in front of him,

Zhou Ze also wanted to join in the "hahahaha."

"Hahahahaha, I'm so tired, I'm so sleepy," the driver continued to hahahaha.

"Hahahaha, can you stop laughing?"

"Hahahahaha, I can't! I don't know why I'm so happy!" the driver said.

"Hahahaha, are you mentally ill?" Zhou Ze asked.

"Hahahahaha, yes, yes, I drove over two thousand kilometers non-stop from Rongcheng to this Tongcheng, I think I really am mentally ill."

"Hahahaha, what exactly are you here for?"

"Hahahahaha, there's someone in my trunk! I think he's my biological father or mother! I joyfully brought him here!"

"Hahahahaha... hmm?"

Zhou Ze stopped laughing and looked at the trunk.

Then he saw Tang Shi raise her hand,

The entire car shook,

Squeaking,

Without pressing the unlock button, the trunk popped open directly.

Although this white Roewe had become somewhat dusty after a long journey of over two thousand kilometers, Tang Shi's act of violently opening the trunk without even waiting to unlock it was still a bit excessive.

In the trunk, a person was lying,

Oh no,

More precisely,

It was one person and one cat.

The person's eyes were wrapped in bandages, from which a little blood had seeped out. Beside that person, there was a cat lying motionless.

Both the person and the cat looked as if they were dead, with only a slight rise and fall of their chests indicating they still had a breath left.

Tang Shi personally bent down, picked up the white cat, and then looked into the house.

"Old Taoist."

"Coming, what's up?"

The old Taoist priest scurried over, then glanced at the trunk, and was immediately startled. He quickly came over and picked up the person whose eyes were wrapped in bandages.

"Boss, how did you end up like this? You're so miserable, so miserable!"

Zhou Ze, standing nearby, knew the old Taoist wasn't crying for him,

But hearing such wails while standing there always felt a bit uncomfortable.

The person and the cat were carried into the bookstore by Tang Shi and the old Taoist, while the driver was still there, leaning against the car door, continuing to "hahahahahaha..."

Zhou Ze somewhat understood; this driver was really unlucky, he had been hypnotized.

He went out to buy a condom, probably had a girl waiting at the hotel, but he drove directly from Rongcheng to Tongcheng in one go.

But how did they break the hypnosis?

Fortunately, once the people from the car were carried inside, the driver seemed to return to normal, immediately collapsing to the ground and falling into a deep sleep.

Finally, the driver was sent to a nearby hotel by Xu Qinglang to check in. As for whether the hotel owner would misunderstand anything, Zhou Ze wasn't sure.

He went straight upstairs to Tang Shi's bedroom, where the man was lying motionless.

To be honest, Zhou Ze was quite grateful to him. If it weren't for his killing spree in Rongcheng, his relationship with the little loli wouldn't have become so harmonious.

Perhaps he would be facing the little loli's pursuit or already have been killed by now.

"Can he wake up?"

Zhou Ze asked.

Tang Shi didn't answer, personally wiping his face with a wet towel.

Carefully, obediently.

Why didn't I get this treatment when I was injured?

We're all possessing corpses; my Xu Le is much handsomer than this guy, alright?

"I don't mean anything else, I just want to ask, will his staying here attract the attention of other netherworld messengers, leading to another group of people coming to encircle him?

Don't misunderstand, I don't mean to drive him away, I'm just asking so we can make some preparations.

After all, you don't have netherworld messenger licenses, so your identities can't be cleared for now."

Tang Shi looked at Zhou Ze and said, "Netherworld messenger license?"

Are you truly unaware or feigning ignorance?

Zhou Ze pulled out his netherworld messenger license and shook it in front of Tang Shi,

"It's this thing. With it, you can clear your identity. As long as you don't do anything too extreme afterward, you can live peacefully for a long time. It's just that this thing is difficult to obtain; you need luck to get it."

Just then,

The unconscious man lying on the bed trembled slightly,

From his hoodie pocket,

Something seemed to spill out,

Falling from the bed to the floor,

Scattering all over the place,

It was a floor full of,

Netherworld messenger licenses.

title: 第一百二十八章 消失的三鄉村！
content:
Xu Qinglang sat on a sofa, smoking a cigarette, with a glass of iced beer in front of him.

Zhou Ze walked over, picked up the beer, and downed it in one go.

"What's wrong with you?" Xu Qinglang knew Zhou Ze usually didn't drink.

"Like you, showing off your twenty-some houses in front of that corgi girl last time."

"............" Xu Qinglang.

After a period of silence, Xu Qinglang poured Zhou Ze another glass of beer. The two men sat quietly.

"Let me tell you something. I meant to yesterday, but I wasn't in the mood."

"I'm not in the mood now either."

"It's just that your ashes were stolen. It's like a pervert collected your old toenail clippings. What's there to brood over?"

"Easy for you to say."

"I'm actually quite envious of you. I think if I could one day be drinking and feeling sad about my ashes being stolen, I'd be laughing out loud in my bed."

Xu Qinglang wore a serious expression.

Yes,

If it were an ancestral grave dug up, or parents' ashes stolen by an enemy, then of course, there'd be anger and anxiety!

But it really seems no one has ever been anxious about their own ashes being stolen.

"So, should I post something on Weibo, subtly and tastefully showing off?" Zhou Ze retorted.

"Heh, just kidding. Oh, right, have they found the thief?"

"The little loli is still looking."

Zhou Ze could only wait for news now.

Just then, Zhou Ze and Xu Qinglang both looked towards the stairwell. The old Daoist carried a man down.

"What's wrong?" Zhou Ze asked.

Tang Shi, who followed behind, ignored Zhou Ze. A taxi was waiting outside. Tang Shi and the man got into the taxi. It looked like they were planning to leave.

Leaving right after arriving, and the man was still unconscious.

The most crucial thing was that he even "trembled" while unconscious, scattering Ghost Messenger certificates all over the floor.

Zhou Ze hadn't even had a chance to wait for him to wake up and chat a bit before they were ready to leave.

Of course, Zhou Ze didn't try to stop them, because both knew they weren't the type to be polite, reserved, or fond of formalities.

Stay if you want to stay,

Leave if you want to leave,

No need for coy gestures or pretense.

The taxi drove away, but to Zhou Ze's surprise, the old Daoist came back. He didn't leave.

Zhou Ze had expected the old Daoist to go with them.

The old Daoist walked back into the shop as if nothing had happened.

"Hey." Zhou Ze called out.

The old Daoist turned his head to Zhou Ze, smiling with a simple, honest expression. He said,

"Boss, Miss Tang has left with Mr. Liang. Miss Tang had already arranged new lodging before, and they're going to Shanghai. She said they have their documents now and it's inconvenient to trouble you further."

"Why didn't you go with them?" Zhou Ze asked.

"I am your loyal old Daoist!"

The old Daoist spoke with an air of righteous conviction.

"Tell me the truth."

"I can't leave you, I can't let go of you."

"The truth."

Zhou Ze looked at his fingernails.

"Given Mr. Liang's current state, the Underworld Store won't be able to open anytime soon. There's nothing for me to do if I go with them, so I can only continue to help you here."

Zhou Ze nodded and walked over to his bar counter. Business had been good these days, sending many ghosts down, so a lot of冥鈔 (ghost money) had accumulated.

He took out half of it and handed it to the old Daoist.

"Give this to them. They're new here, so they're probably short on cash."

Zhou Ze was worried that if Tang Shi was short on money, she might just rob a bank. That woman was capable of anything.

冥鈔 could be used as a consumable or like a bank card; burning it would make money appear at your door.

Unexpectedly, the old Daoist shook his head directly. He said,

"Boss, Mr. Liang is very rich. He has many villas in Shanghai, properties all over the country, and he's hidden many boxes of 'little gold fish'."

"............" Zhou Ze.

His heart,

ached so much he couldn't breathe...

Zhou Ze felt like he'd taken two critical hits within an hour,

and both were invisible.

Putting the money back, Zhou Ze silently sat down.

Just then, a girl ran past the doorway. The girl was dressed rather shabbily, almost to the point of being scantily clad.

Actually, to be honest,

In this day and age, under the brilliant leadership of the Party Central Committee, the living standards of the people across the country are continuously improving, and people's material and spiritual lives are constantly enriched and enhanced.

New era, new policies,

With the help of targeted poverty alleviation measures, impoverished households can also receive significant assistance. It can be said that the era of a moderately prosperous society for all people is not far off.

Even if there are some beggars in some cities, it's very rare these years to see beggars in such a miserable state of being unclothed.

The old Daoist was still wiping the table, seemingly not noticing the little girl entering.

The little monkey, however, directly leaped onto the old Daoist's head, its two monkey paws clutching the Daoist's head, manipulating him to look towards the little girl.

"A ghost has come?"

The old Daoist mumbled to himself while taking out ox tears from his pocket to rub on his eyes.

There was no other way; in this bookstore, he was the only one who couldn't see ghosts directly.

After seeing the dirty little girl, the old Daoist instinctively looked at Zhou Ze.

"Boss, we have a customer! Time to greet!"

The old voice shouted,

like a dream back to an ancient brothel.

Girls,

Come out and greet the customers!

Coming,

Mama.

Xu Qinglang stood up to prepare cold dishes and drinks. Zhou Ze motioned for the girl to follow him.

The girl seemed a little confused and a little scared. She looked at Zhou Ze, then at the old Daoist, but still instinctively followed Zhou Ze into the private room.

Zhou Ze sat down and gestured for her to sit down too.

The girl sat down. Xu Qinglang also brought over several cold dishes, some small side dishes, and a steamed bun.

When he was about to pour wine, Zhou Ze gestured not to.

Even though she was a ghost, she was still a child.

And from the little girl's demeanor, it was clear she wasn't the type of being like a celestial child prodigy.

The girl began to wolf down the food,

She was clearly "starving."

And this kind of hunger was more akin to having been "hungry" during her life.

Zhou Ze sat silently, watching the girl eat.

After the girl finished eating, a satisfied smile appeared on her face. She said,

"So full. It feels so good to be full."

The girl's words carried a strong local accent from Tongcheng.

Children of this era, you might not even get them to speak a dialect; they mostly speak standard Mandarin.

"Now that you're full, let's get going."

Zhou Ze was about to open the Gates of Hell.

The little girl looked at Zhou Ze with some fear, but she didn't cry or fuss; she just waited silently.

"Wait." Xu Qinglang, who had been watching the little girl eat, suddenly spoke. "Want some meat?"

The little girl froze for a moment, then her eyes lit up, and she nodded repeatedly.

"Then wait."

He said this to the little girl and also to Zhou Ze.

Alright, Old Xu wants to be a good person, a great philanthropist. Zhou Ze had no reason to stop him, so he continued to sit there.

After a quarter of an hour, Xu Qinglang brought out a plate of braised pork, and the little girl continued to eat.

In reality, ghosts eat offerings, incense. The little girl seemed to be devouring the food, but to ordinary people, the dishes on the table hadn't been touched at all.

"Does the meat taste good?" Xu Qinglang asked.

"Delicious, delicious," the little girl said.

"Are you having a motherly outburst today?"

Zhou Ze asked, somewhat curious.

Xu Qinglang shook his head, a faint sorrow clouding his brows. Since returning yesterday, he had maintained this melancholic, Lin Daiyu-like demeanor.

A man,

having lost his virginity,

could be so resentful, as if life had lost its meaning.

Zhou Ze thought he should be grateful there wasn't a well in the bookstore, otherwise, Miss Xu might have chosen to gracefully perish.

The little girl finished eating,

then patted her belly,

and looked at Zhou Ze.

This time she was very well-behaved; she was good after eating her fill, a very sensible child.

She knew it was time for her to go.

Zhou Ze stood up, and while opening the Gates of Hell, he asked,

"Go on in."

Zhou Ze didn't ask for her story. Perhaps having heard too many stories before, Zhou Ze had become less fond of listening to them.

Most people who die have their own sad stories.

The little girl blinked, looked at Zhou Ze, and asked,

"Can I eat my fill before I go in?"

"Hmm."

Zhou Ze nodded.

"Then I'll go call everyone. The villagers are all hungry. I want everyone to be able to eat their fill."

Zhou Ze's hand, which was opening the Gates of Hell, trembled slightly.

There were "everyone" to call?

This meant there was a huge wave of performance to be gained!

Subconsciously, Zhou Ze closed the Gates of Hell he had just opened.

Boss Zhou was in the initial stages of his career, urgently needing performance to prove himself, so he naturally understood the principle of long-term investment.

"Where is your home?"

Zhou Ze asked.

"Sanxiang Village," the little girl replied.

"Where is Sanxiang Village? Which district? Rugao, Menhai, or Chongchuan Gangzha?"

Although Zhou Ze had undergone transmigration, he was from Tongcheng in his previous life, but he still didn't remember a place called Sanxiang Village in Tongcheng.

Zhou Ze looked at Xu Qinglang, who shook his head, indicating he didn't know either.

"I don't know." The girl didn't know where Sanxiang Village was, and she had never even heard of the district names Zhou Ze mentioned.

"Then............"

Zhou Ze was at a loss and could only continue to ask,

"Can you go back the way you came?"

The girl shook her head ignorantly. "I don't know how I walked out of the village, and then I kept walking and walking, and I ended up here."

Couldn't she go back the way she came?

Zhou Ze even began to wonder if the girl was from a neighboring city, a ghost who had crossed boundaries, but then he thought again that it wasn't right; the girl spoke in a Tongcheng dialect, so it was unlikely she was from somewhere else.

Just as Zhou Ze was wrestling with this, Xu Qinglang, who was standing by, took out his phone and searched.

"Did you find it?" Zhou Ze asked.

Xu Qinglang shook his head. "I didn't find any information on this administrative village."

"Not even searchable online?" Zhou Ze was a little surprised.

"Hey, wait a minute, there's a post here that mentions 'Sanxiang Village'."

Xu Qinglang motioned for Zhou Ze to wait, then clicked into the post and said,

"The title of this post is:

'Asking the well-informed,

Is there a place called Sanxiang Village in Tongcheng?'"

"What are the replies below?" Zhou Ze pressed.

"None.

Don't know.

Never heard of it.

No.

Never heard of it.

Upstairs +1............"

Xu Qinglang kept flipping through the pages, then froze, looked down for a while, and then looked up at Zhou Ze.

"Did you find anything?"

"There's a reply here: 'When I was little, my grandma told me she was from Sanxiang Village, but when she was ten, she followed her maternal grandmother back to her hometown in Xingdong Town.

A few days later, when she went back, she found that the village was gone.'"

"Gone?" Zhou Ze was stunned.

Gone,

What did that mean?

"Someone asked about it below," Xu Qinglang said. "I'll look for that person's reply again... Found it. He replied to the person above, saying:

'That year was 1938. You can imagine why the village was gone.'"

title: 第一百二十九章 鬼話連篇
content:
1938?

Zhou Ze looked at the little girl, then at Xu Qinglang, and said,

"The devils entered Tongcheng in '38, right?"

Xu Qinglang thought for a moment, then said, "It seems they entered Tongcheng in March of '38."

If that were the case, then the so-called Sanxiang Village was likely a tragedy of that era. The village should have been razed when the devils entered Tongcheng, and everyone in the village, including this little girl, likely perished. The grandmother of the person who posted the thread was simply lucky to have escaped.

Even today, there's no way to find any other information about Sanxiang Village, nor are there any official records.

This wasn't due to official negligence; it was because, in that era, countless similar tragedies occurred. Amidst years of constant turmoil, many who died tragically were simply forgotten.

"So, an entire village that died during the Anti-Japanese War didn't enter the cycle of reincarnation?"

Zhou Ze frowned.

It's been eighty years, more than a sixty-year cycle. Are the souls of this entire village still lingering there?

"I don't know, but looking at this little girl, it seems that way. How about this, I'll go to the municipal library and check the local gazetteers to see where Sanxiang Village was specifically located, or I'll consult relevant people."

Xu Qinglang got up, grabbed his car keys, and went straight out.

He was very proactive in this matter, but his proactiveness differed from Zhou Ze's. Zhou Ze still had performance targets as a reason, while Xu Qinglang simply wanted to do something from the bottom of his heart.

After all, they were all fellow townspeople.

Zhou Ze sat down in a nearby chair and pointed at the old Taoist priest: "Watch her."

The old Taoist nodded and watched the little girl with the little monkey.

The little girl looked somewhat bewildered, not knowing what was happening, but instinctively stood there, not daring to move much.

The little monkey reached out as if to touch the girl's soul but was directly slapped away by the old Taoist, who reprimanded,

"What are you touching? She's even older than me!"

If the little girl hadn't died, she would be ninety years old now.

But she was still so innocent and childlike, completely retaining her pre-death mental state. This was what Zhou Ze found most curious. Zhou Ze guessed that there might have been some problem in that village, preventing the souls of the entire village from leaving, trapping them there together, unaware of seasons or time.

However, the specific situation would only be verifiable after Xu Qinglang found concrete information.

Zhou Ze took out his phone and scrolled through it casually. He rarely used WeChat or QQ because they were filled with Xu Le's old social network, which couldn't be helped, as his old account couldn't be recovered and was difficult to appeal.

Scrolling through his Moments, Zhou Ze surprisingly saw Bai Yingying had shared an article titled "On the Bed Skills of Men in the Military!"

Zhou Ze was momentarily stunned.

This female corpse seemed to be running further and further down the path of a chuunibyo girl.

It seemed he needed to find time to have a serious talk with her. Such things should not be reposted; they were taboo.

At this moment, Bai Yingying was busy upstairs in her room playing PUBG and wasn't downstairs.

Zhou Ze got up and walked up the stairs, and as he walked, he casually clicked on the shared link.

Hmm,

To educate a chuunibyo girl, one must prescribe the right medicine and know both oneself and the enemy to win every battle.

After clicking in,

It was a bunch of white and green pictures,

And then,

It turned out to be a bedding-folding competition for a certain factory, and the top three winners were all masters who had previously served in the military.

What a despicable clickbait title!

Zhou Ze put down his phone and pushed open the bedroom door.

"Seaweed, seaweed, swaying with the waves;

Seaweed, seaweed, seaweed, seaweed, dancing in the spray!"

Bai Yingying lay on the bed with her bare white feet dangling back and forth, holding her phone and scrolling through videos, giggling like a pig.

She didn't even notice Zhou Ze walking over.

Then, Zhou Ze sat down by her bed.

"Hahahahaha..."

Bai Yingying laughed and then rolled over, directly sprawling onto Zhou Ze's lap.

Immediately,

Her long eyelashes fluttered, her alluring red lips slightly closed and then opened, and her delicate skin flushed slightly.

The atmosphere,

At this moment, became enchanting.

However, Zhou Ze, living up to his title as a spoiler of fresh atmospheres, directly said,

"I've told you many times, don't get on the bed without washing your feet and showering after getting up."

Saying that, Zhou Ze looked at the exposed, long, and infinitely tempting jade feet, and frowned:

"Dirty."

Bai Yingying immediately got off the bed, put on her slippers, crossed her hands beneath her, and lowered her head to Zhou Ze, striking a pose ready for a lecture.

She was quite familiar with this posture.

"Wash the bedsheets."

Zhou Ze said.

"Okay, boss."

Bai Yingying tidied up the bedsheets and went downstairs. Zhou Ze, meanwhile, sat in front of the computer, opened a web page, and began searching for information about Sanxiang Village again.

Previously, Xu Qinglang had searched on his phone, which might have missed some details.

Unfortunately,

Regarding that village, at least online, there was no information other than that discussion thread.

Zhou Ze also clicked on the thread Xu Qinglang had read earlier. The thread was posted on a local Tongcheng forum in 2009.

He first read the two replies stating that the grandmother was from Sanxiang Village but found nothing. Then, Zhou Ze chose to view the main topic. In this thread, there were actually two informed people.

One was, of course, the replier, but the replier had already said everything they knew. The other was the original poster.

Since Sanxiang Village had been forgotten by people, not even existing in records, only in stories told by the grandmother, why did this original poster suddenly bring up the place name and ask about it?

Zhou Ze clicked on the original poster's avatar and found that this user hadn't posted anything after 2009. Zhou Ze copied the original poster's ID.

The ID was "WoxinchangdanSanqianYuejiaKeTunWu19800201".

The beginning was familiar, and Zhou Ze speculated the string of numbers at the end might be the person's birthday.

Then, Zhou Ze searched for this ID again and indeed found a thread. This thread was posted on the "Penglai Ghost Stories" section of the Tianya Forum.

The original poster was still "WoxinchangdanSanqianYuejiaKeTunWu19800201", and the post date was still 2009.

This thread didn't gain much traction, and there weren't many replies.

Of course, the ID numbers at the end were also the same, which meant that the person who posted the inquiry about Sanxiang Village on the Tongcheng local forum was also the person who posted the story on the Tianya Forum.

Zhou Ze continued reading; it was a story.

The original poster began by saying:

"This is something I experienced personally. Although it's strange and absurd, I believe it wasn't a dream or a hallucination. This is my true story."

A very clichéd ghost story opening,

Very popular in ghost story tropes ten years ago, where the beginning would subtly emphasize its truthfulness.

Zhou Ze continued to read:

"In March this year, I was driving home from the Guanyin Mountain Town Power Supply Station. Yes, I work at the power supply station, but my home is near Xingdong Airport.

On my way home, I passed through Xingren Town. I got off the elevated road there because I needed to pick up my dry-cleaned clothes that I had left there that morning before work.

The dry cleaner was on Xingren Town Street, right across from Xingren Elementary School.

It was 9 PM when I drove over, and the streets were much emptier. But when I parked my car in front of the dry cleaner and stepped out, I twisted my ankle and fell directly.

At first, I just thought I was unlucky today, but this was only the beginning. Because when I fell to the ground, I suddenly found that the surrounding streets and tall buildings were gone. I wasn't on the road but on a muddy field path, and opposite me wasn't the dry cleaner but rows of mud houses.

I was stunned. I looked back at my car and found that it had turned into a haystack.

I was really scared then. I didn't know what had happened. I sat on the ground for fifteen minutes, constantly thinking it was a dream and hoping I would wake up soon.

But I didn't wake up. Then I saw an old man leading a little girl walking towards me. The old man had a hoe on his shoulder, and the little girl was playing with a sugar figurine.

They got closer and closer. They were also talking, and they were speaking Tongcheng dialect.

I immediately asked them, where is this?

They looked at me curiously too. The old man replied that this was 'Sanxiang Village'.

Where is Sanxiang Village?

I'd never heard of it.

Then I immediately stood up and asked them how I could get out.

The old man probably thought I was crazy or had a problem with my mind, and quickly pulled his granddaughter away.

Having no choice, I walked into the village alone. At that time, I even wondered if I had been drugged and abducted to some remote mountain forest, but then I found it absurd. I'm a grown man; why would anyone abduct me?

I can't have children.

Every household had its doors closed. A few houses occasionally had lights on with silhouettes inside. I didn't dare to knock on doors or go inside. I just walked cautiously past each house.

I heard people inside many houses chatting and talking, and they were all shouting that they were hungry.

Wives shouted they were hungry to their husbands,

Children shouted they were hungry to their parents,

Elderly parents shouted they were hungry to their sons and daughters-in-law,

The people in this village were all very hungry.

At night, inside their houses, they just kept talking about "so hungry, so hungry."

My heart grew more and more anxious as I walked.

I had a feeling that since they were so hungry, they might all rush out and boil and eat me.

I started to run,

Running quickly,

I instinctively sensed danger.

I had to run out of here before they came out to catch me, no matter where I ran, I just had to get as far away from this cursed village as possible.

I don't know how long I ran,

Until finally,

I forgot...

Then, when I woke up the next day,

I found myself in the driver's seat of my car, having slept through the night.

But this was absolutely not a dream; a dream couldn't be that real!

And my clothes and pant legs were all muddy,

And there were a few bits of straw in my neck and hair.

Sanxiang Village,

This place definitely exists,

Definitely!"

The original poster also posted photos of himself at the time, showing the muddy clothes and straw bits.

But the replies below clearly didn't believe him, saying:

"This ghost story is too far-fetched."

"The production cost is also very low. Just make some clothes dirty, take a picture, and play 'picture talk'?"

"Starting with one picture, everything else is made up, OP. Not serious, not serious."

"OP, didn't you have your phone with you then? Why didn't you record or take pictures?"

Zhou Ze continued to scroll down.

Fortunately, there weren't many replies because this ghost story was truly neither novel nor exciting.

But below, Zhou Ze saw a reply from the original poster:

"Just wait, I will definitely find a way to go again. This time I'll bring evidence back to prove I'm not making things up."

The next reply was from 2010, a year later.

"It's been a year, OP, where the hell is your story? Haven't you finished writing it yet? I've kept it in my favorites."

Then in 2011, there was a reply:

"Two years have passed, has the OP gone again or not?"

The last reply was from 2012:

"Everyone, disperse. The OP is gone."

As Zhou Ze read, he was suddenly stunned.

A passage suddenly came to his mind:

"Liu Ziji of Nanyang, a noble scholar, heard of it, and joyfully planned to go. Before he could, he fell ill and died, and thereafter no one sought the way again."

title: 第一百三十章 劇本，好像錯了
content:
白鶯鶯抱著剛洗好的床單回來了，曬衣服都是在二樓，當然，白鶯鶯洗衣服的速度確實很快，但絕對沒有敷衍了事。



  她清楚，在家庭衛生這一方面，自己的老闆有著幾乎苛刻地強迫症。



  簡而言之，



  就是好難伺候。



  有時候，白鶯鶯也會在心理腹誹：



  自家老闆上輩子是孤兒被父母遺棄也不是沒有原因的，很可能是奶嘴沒消毒他不吃，被褥沒洗乾淨他不睡，爹媽沒洗手不給碰，然後父母實在受不了把他丟掉了。



  當然，這種腹誹白鶯鶯只敢在心理嘀咕一下，萬萬不敢說出口的。



  她還必須每次都擺出受教的神情，然後陪著自己老闆一起手拉手奔向潔癖的快樂天堂，做出一副領會到精神且甘之如飴的樣子。



  從心，



  就是如此。



  天不生我白鶯鶯，萬古慫道如長夜。



  周澤站在窗邊抽著煙，那個帖子他看了，其實已經給出了很多的信息。



  興仁鎮，



  乾洗店，



  位置應該就在那裡。



  甚至，周澤還能看出很多帖子裡沒有的信息，因為他是鬼差，且不再是之前那種愣頭青，已經開始慢慢地入行且熟悉業務了。 



  鬼出自於人，人必將變鬼，但人鬼殊途，有一條線，將彼此隔絕開。



  陽間和陰間，



  彼此共存也彼此對立。



  什麼樣的人才會容易見鬼？



  有遭遇了特殊事情的，這是一類。



  還有一大類，則是快死的人，陽壽將盡，就像是你手機餘額不多了，10086會不停地給你發提示簡訊一樣。



  到點了，



  你該走了。



  在那個時候，你雖然是活人，但即將變成死人，身上的死氣已經開始加重了。



  這種加重，並非單純地是指你生病了，重病纏身，可能也是指你即將遭遇不測，可能是一場車禍，可能是吃飯被噎死喝水被嗆死，



  總之，



  你快掛了。



  然後你就很可能見鬼了，彼此之間的氣場開始從對立變得融合起來。



  結合這個樓主09年之後再沒有活躍的消息，應該可以大概猜出，樓主確實已經涼了。



  但他對三鄉村的描述以及他自己記錄下來的經歷，再加上樓下小女孩的話語，其實已經將整件事情的淪落給勾勒了出來。



  一個在日軍攻入通城的那一年被屠殺的村子， 



  在八十年之後，



  那個村子裡的人，不，是整個村子的鬼，卻依舊被困鎖在一個區域裡，無法投胎，無法轉世。



  他們也沒有變成厲鬼，如果變成了厲鬼，再加上八十年的發酵，那個樓主第一次進去時，就該GG了，也不可能出得來。



  而且小女孩依舊天真爛漫，仿佛剛死的樣子。



  到底是什麼原因，導致那樣子的一個和諧的村子出現？



  白鶯鶯曬了被子，偷偷摸摸地坐到電腦前，網癮少女一邊打量著周澤一邊想偷偷地玩會兒遊戲，目光盯著屏幕，自然而然地把那個小故事看了一遍，隨即道：



  「老闆，這不就是《桃花源記》麼？」



  周澤點點頭，



  是的，



  這就是翻版的《桃花源記》。



  一直以來，人們一直想當然地把陶淵明筆下的《桃花源記》當作一個世外桃源來理解，然而實際上，這篇看似美好的故事文章，四處都透露著詭異和陰森。



  你如果換一個視角來看，《桃花源記》完全就是一個鬼故事，一個漁夫誤入鬼村的故事，正如帖子裡的樓主一樣。



  十指，在窗台邊輕輕抖動，這個地方，自己是要去的。 



  不提如果能夠把那個村子所有的亡魂送入地獄自己基本可以轉正的誘、、、惑，光是父老鄉親這一點，就足以讓周澤去嘗試出手幫助了。



  八十年前，民族沉淪時，他們淪為了侵略者屠刀下的可憐亡魂，他們已經受了八十年的苦，是時候得以解脫了。



  周澤拿出手機，撥通了許清朗的電話。



  那邊卻顯示不在服務區，這讓周澤有些意外，許清朗現在不該是在地方圖書館麼，那裡手機信號這麼差？



  過了一會兒，周澤又打了一次電話，對方還是無法接通，周澤不打算等了，直接示意白鶯鶯看店，自己則是帶著老道一起打車去了興仁鎮。



  帶老道的原因很簡單，一是老道看管亡魂的能力不強，除了摸褲襠，對亡魂基本沒約束力，而那個小女孩的亡魂需要白鶯鶯看住。



  二則是小猴子和老道玩得來，這一次要找尋那個樓主進入三鄉村的切入點，需要這頭畜生的幫助。



  一念至此，



  周澤的目光也就落在了小猴子身上，原本在老道膝蓋上趴著的小猴子忽然抬起頭對周澤齜牙咧嘴。



  喲，



  能看懂我內心想法？



  或者是，



  單純地感應到我在罵你？ 



  周澤伸手，攥住了小猴子的尾巴，避讓著前面司機的視線，盯著小猴子看了看。



  好像長大了一些，



  也重了一些，



  呵呵，



  膽兒也肥了啊。



  小猴子很不滿地扭動著身子，它對周澤一向有些不感冒，所以在書店裡，它基本就跟著老道玩，對於周澤，它骨子裡有一種畏懼和忌憚。



  畢竟，小猴子的前身，是被周澤活生生地用指甲刺死的。



  它跟周澤，一人一猴，像是兩條交織的線，因果關係，亂得一塌糊塗。



  到了地方，下了車，周澤輕輕地伸了個懶腰。



  興仁鎮是一個小鎮，靠近市區，隔壁就是機場，而周澤所處的位置，就是十字街往東這邊，也是一個小交叉路口。



  正北方向是興仁小學，正南是公寓樓，中間一條街都是小商鋪。



  那家乾洗店還開在那裡。



  算了算位置，周澤腦海中開始模擬那個樓主開車停在這裡摔跤的畫面。



  「老闆，應該是小學方向吧？」老道這個時候開口道。



  「哦？」周澤有些疑惑，老道是什麼水平，他是知道的。 



  「嘿嘿，我沒看出來什麼，但我有經驗，通常來說，學校或者醫院這種地方，很多都是在亂葬崗那邊建起來的。



  因為地便宜，尤其是學校這種地方，它不用開在鬧市區，哪怕偏僻一點，也無所謂。



  而且，不是說現在學區房很熱，哪怕是很多年前，學校建在哪裡，哪裡的人氣也會馬上起來，所以在城市規劃的時候，往往都會把學校這個地方當作一個重要的落子點，選一個偏僻一點的地方，帶動那裡的發展。」



  老道說得頭頭是道，也確實有幾分道理。



  周澤看了看小猴子，道：「能看出什麼東西麼？」



  小猴子撓撓頭，從老道身上跳下來，開始四處尋找。



  然後，它懵懂地搖搖頭。



  周澤眼睛微微眯了起來，他不認為小猴子在偷奸耍滑。



  或許，是天還沒完全黑的原因吧，一些地方，在白天的時候受到壓制，等到晚上的時候，可能就容易顯露出蛛絲馬跡。



  就這樣，周澤和老道進入了旁邊的一家快餐店，點了一些飲料零食坐在那裡等著。



  小學開始放學了，這裡聚集了很多車輛，等到小學放學結束，天色也慢慢地黑了起來，附近的人氣也就慢慢低落了下去。



  算算時間，也差不多了，這種事情，也沒必要等到深夜子時什麼的。 



  再次牽著小猴子出來，小猴子這一次似乎一下子就捕捉到了什麼，開始在原地不停地打著圈兒，老道跟在小猴子身後也在打著圈兒。



  周澤則是站在旁邊看著。



  終於，小猴子嘴裡發出了「吱吱吱」的聲音，而後直接沖向了馬路。



  就在此時，一輛小轎車正好開過來，車速其實並不快，但小猴子等於是往人家車輪里壓！



  「吱呀！」



  小轎車一個急剎車，車主罵道：「哪裡的死狗！」



  車主下車檢查了一下，他剛剛看見一團黃毛衝到自己車前，結果下車後卻沒看見血污痕跡，當下又罵了幾句又上車開車走了。



  老道有些後知後覺，在小猴子衝出去時，他連喊都來不及喊。



  但這一會兒，他也明悟了過來，



  猴子沒被車撞到，



  確切的說，



  猴子進去了。



  「老闆，怎麼辦？」



  老道問道。



  周澤在原地，沿著猴子之前轉圈的位置，轉了幾圈，然後順著那個方向，衝刺了過去，剎那間，周澤感知到自己的指甲微微一顫，像是捕捉到了什麼東西，順勢一抓。 



  「嗡！」



  緊接著，四周的環境開始扭曲起來，



  高樓、



  馬路、



  車輛、



  全都消失不見，



  這裡是一塊泥濘的田埂，不遠處則是一排排以泥土和稻草修葺起來的房子。



  金絲猴蹲在周澤前面，看著周澤。



  周澤環視四周，



  他知道，



  自己也進來了。



  至於老道，



  他估計進不來，除非等到他快蹬腿咽氣的時候，說不定才能碰巧起來。



  遠處，走來一對爺孫，是一個爺爺牽著一個小女孩。



  小女孩和自己書店裡的有點相像，比仔細看的話，還以為是一個人。



  對上了，



  和樓主在帖子裡的描述對上了。



  「這裡是哪裡？」周澤問道。



  按照劇本，他們應該回答自己這裡是「三鄉村」。



  但接下來的一幕，



  卻讓周澤愣了一下，



  爺爺沒有回答， 



  女孩也沒回答，



  一老一少，



  就這樣死死地盯著周澤和小猴子，



  嘴角開始很誇張地滴落出口水，



  同時眼睛，



  也開始慢慢地泛起了紅光！



  喂，



  導演，



  劇本，



  好像拿錯了？

title: 第一百三十一章 餓鬼出籠
content:
The progression of events seemed to be slowly veering in an uncontrollable direction, at least, Zhou Ze hadn't been mentally prepared for it.

The state the little girl displayed upon entering his bookstore made Zhou Ze completely unprepared for the fact that the people in this village—

Oh no,

—that the ghosts in this village, would turn out like this.

He was clearly here to deliver them, to save them,

But they were obviously treating him as food now.

The old man, hale and hearty, walked with the speed of wind. His hoe, when swung, even resembled Qin Shubao's three-strike maneuver.

And the little girl, with her braids flying backward, a ferocious expression, and rapid speed, let out continuous shrill cries.

This was the manifestation of a vengeful spirit; ordinary deceased souls couldn't reach this level.

Right now,

The old one lunged at Zhou Ze,

While the young one lunged at the monkey.

The monkey initially swung its plastic toy hammer, but seeing the formidable vengeful spirit, it immediately stood behind Zhou Ze.

Cowardice,

Was a belief,

And had almost become a prevailing atmosphere in the bookstore,

Even affecting the animals.

One must know that the monkey had previously shown a disdainful, aloof attitude towards Zhou Ze, but at this moment, it swiftly decided to let bygones be bygones.

Although things had changed and the script seemed to be wrong,

Zhou Ze wasn't so easily startled into helplessness by two vengeful spirits.

Immediately, he took a step forward, his fingernails growing longer, accompanied by wisps of black mist appearing around him.

By now, following the two instances of entering that severely injured zombie state, Zhou Ze was becoming more and more adept at using his fingernails and the power associated with them.

Compared to when he first fought like a shrew tearing at people with her nails, it looked much better.

"Clap!"

"Clap!"

When the black mist struck the old man and the little girl, their movements seemed to suddenly go into slow motion, while Zhou Ze floated lightly between them.

His clothes billowed,

He strolled at leisure,

His two hands,

Slowly descended towards the tops of their heads,

Like an immortal stroking one's crown,

Everything under control.

At this moment, the only regret was perhaps that the old Daoist priest hadn't come in; otherwise, the thoughtful old Daoist would surely have helped him film this scene for future enjoyment.

Then he would quietly smoke a cigarette, showing disdain,

Implying it was basic operation, sit down.

However, just as Zhou Ze's fingernails had pierced the heads of the grandfather and granddaughter, about to signal the end of everything,

The old man and the little girl's bodies suddenly twisted, and then completely dissipated.

Their speed,

Was even faster than the little loli's "pew!"

Zhou Ze's hands were still suspended in the air,

He had already struck his pose,

But the people meant to collaborate in the performance had spaced out,

Which was a bit awkward.

Putting his hands down, turning around, Zhou Ze was astonished to find the figures of the grandfather and granddaughter reappearing on the distant path.

The grandfather was carrying a hoe and holding his granddaughter's hand,

The old and the young seemed to have just returned from the fields,

With a sense of happiness and contentment,

Just like the description in "The Peach Blossom Spring": "old men with white hair and children with hair tied in knots were all content and happy."

The little monkey was also a bit baffled; clearly, its monkey brain, no matter how clever, couldn't comprehend what was happening.

The old and the young walked over again. The old man looked at Zhou Ze and asked curiously,

"Young man, where are you from?"

"I don't know either." Zhou Ze shrugged.

Damn it,

This time, he really didn't know.

"Are you lost?" The old man was kind-hearted.

"Sort of." Zhou Ze sighed.

"This is Sanxiang Village, not far from the city. If you follow this road south, you'll reach the city." The old man kindly pointed the way.

The little girl played with the candy figurine in her hand, her figure somewhat thin, but still innocent and adorable.

The image of the grandfather and granddaughter was simply two extremes compared to their recent man-eating appearance.

"Okay, got it." Zhou Ze nodded.

The grandfather and granddaughter walked into the village, chatting and laughing.

Zhou Ze looked up at the sky; he hadn't noticed it before, but now he did—the moon in the sky seemed to have a faint reddish glow at its edges.

Nine years ago, when that original poster first came here, the first scene he experienced should have been the same as Zhou Ze's second experience; otherwise, he wouldn't have been able to leave or post anything after his first entry.

But he mentioned in his post that when he walked through the village at night, every household was talking about how hungry they were and how much they wanted to eat, which meant that nine years ago, the "hunger" in this village had already started to become problematic.

Now, nine years later with his arrival, the problem had further fermented and worsened.

From then on, if any "fisherman" accidentally entered, he would likely not see a simple Peach Blossom Spring, but only become food for the many departed souls in this village.

Here,

It had gradually become a fierce place.

Zhou Ze took a step and walked into the village. He needed to look around and explore the village, at least to find out what had happened in this village during the massacres by the Japanese devils.

In those years of national crisis, countless innocent souls perished. Why did this village alone survive in such a bizarre manner?

Something abnormal must indicate something monstrous.

The houses in the village were built with mud and straw, a few better-off families would lay some tiles on their roofs. This was the general housing standard in rural areas eighty years ago.

Zhou Ze remembered seeing similar houses in the countryside of Tongcheng when he was a child, but those were ancestral homes, no longer inhabited.

Every household had its own fenced yard, all very tidy, even excessively tidy. Generally, one could plant some green onions, ginger, garlic, or other small vegetables in the yard, but here the yards were barren and flat, not even a blade of grass.

An old woman sat on a small stool by the door, doing needlework on cloth shoes. She was very serious and engrossed, but Zhou Ze saw from afar that the old woman was drooling while doing her needlework.

On the ground,

A large puddle had already accumulated.

This scene was quite eerie.

The old woman remained oblivious, even as her saliva soaked the shoes in her hands, she continued as she pleased, immersed in her own world.

Fortunately, when Zhou Ze and the little monkey walked past, she didn't look up. However, Zhou Ze didn't dare to completely disregard her as a passerby. With the previous example of the old man and the little girl, Zhou Ze knew that the people in this village could be overwhelmed by hunger and turn into vengeful spirits at any moment.

Ahead was a well, where a woman in her thirties or forties was drawing water. The woman had a good figure; though a bit rustic, in that era, she would have been considered a standard rural beauty.

Tall, with ample breasts and two round buttocks, exuding the most primitive and impulsive allure.

But when the woman turned around with her bucket, Zhou Ze saw that her mouth was full of a black mass, which she was vigorously chewing.

It was her hair,

She was tearing and eating her own hair while drawing water; she was very hungry, terribly hungry.

The old woman making cloth shoes looked up at the woman drawing water and called out,

"Dead widow, you lost your man and still dress so alluringly. Is that mouth of yours down there very thirsty?"

The woman called a widow didn't back down, immediately shouting, "Old Woman Cui, I'm not like you. Your mouth down there can't even spit out saliva anymore."

"Pah, you indecent thing, always thinking about men!"

"I do, I think about it every day, I wish all the men in the village would come to my bed tonight, so I can eat them one by one.

Fried,

Steamed,

Mixed with sauce,

Tsk, tsk,

That taste... I can't take it anymore, I really want a man."

As the widow spoke, she chewed her hair even more vigorously.

And the old woman seemed to be stirred, drooling even more profusely, with an expression of longing.

Zhou Ze walked between them. For some reason, these two women seemed not to have seen him at all. But after Zhou Ze and the little monkey had walked away,

The old woman and the widow slowly raised their heads together, looking in the direction Zhou Ze had walked,

Both their eyes glowed with streaks of crimson.

The houses ahead looked a bit grander, with tiles on the roof and stone piers at the entrance, indicating a prosperous family.

Zhou Ze entered the courtyard; there was no one in the yard, but the smell of meat came from the kitchen. Zhou Ze walked over and opened the window.

Inside was a rural earthen stove,

A young man was putting firewood behind the stove; the fire was burning fiercely.

But there was nothing in the pot, just a large pot of boiling water.

"Wife, the water's boiling, come quickly!"

The man called to the other side, sounding a bit impatient.

Like a newlywed husband, urging his wife to take a bath every night.

"Coming, coming, look at you!

You're never so diligent with other things, only so keen on this."

The man ran out from behind the stove and embraced the woman, shouting,

"Quick, quick, quick, I can't hold back, I can't hold back."

"You wait."

The woman took off her clothes,

Seemingly completely oblivious to the person standing by the window watching.

After the woman took off her clothes, she revealed a clean, smooth back, but her right arm was already red, like the cooked pork head sold at a street food stall.

The woman directly climbed onto the stove and then sat into the scalding hot water, pouring hot water over herself with a basin while scolding her husband:

"Keep adding firewood, or it won't cook thoroughly, and it won't be tasty! Look at you, useless thing, put more effort into it, your old lady's not feeling good!"

"Alright!"

The husband immediately went to the back to add firewood.

And the woman sitting in the pot, while cooking herself,

Bit into her right arm, which she had already cooked and braised earlier.

Her eyes narrowed,

And she enjoyed saying,

"So, so delicious."

title: 第一百三十二章 吃，吃，吃！
content:
A calm pace of life,

A tranquil Republic of China rural atmosphere,

Down-to-earth shouts of curses,

Notes carrying the fragrance of soil.

This is its silhouette, the silhouette of Sanxiang Village, but once you take a few steps to the front, you'll be scared to death by its full face.

Every detail here is like a crack, and drops of fresh blood gush out from within, then engulfing and suffocating people.

A terrifying dark cloud constantly hovers above this village, like a stage play, where every character seems to wear a mask with profound meaning.

Hanging in the sky was clearly the moon;

But the light on the ground was an uneven, ghastly white, as if an incompetent lighting technician had adjusted the angle incorrectly, making everything quite chaotic.

Some people were sleeping,

Some were cooking,

Some were fetching water,

Some were shouting curses,

Some were laughing,

And some were crying.

Zhou Ze walked for a long time, almost touring the entire village.

It could be confirmed that this place was indeed entirely different from when the original poster last visited.

If nine years ago, when the original poster first arrived, this place was merely playing hard to get, then now, it truly resembles a giant tiger that has opened its mouth, while its tiger eyes are fixed on you.

It can devour you whenever it wishes,

And that feeling of constantly anticipating being eaten is the most agonizing and torturous.

If the original poster from nine years ago had seen this scene today, he probably wouldn't have had the courage to say he wanted to come back for evidence and photos.

After walking around, Zhou Ze arrived outside an ancestral hall.

This ancestral hall was considered the most prestigious building in all of Sanxiang Village.

It wasn’t large,

But outside hung a plaque, and inside were carved beams and painted rafters; though small and somewhat cramped, it exuded a sense of refinement and solemnity.

A blind old man in a long gown sat at the entrance of the ancestral hall, tapping the ground repeatedly with his cane, his lips trembling slightly.

Zhou Ze stopped in front of him, because this old man, in Zhou Ze's opinion, was the most normal one in the entire village.

At least, the old man wasn't drooling or letting saliva drip.

But after approaching,

Zhou Ze still heard the old man muttering to himself:

"Hungry, so hungry, truly hungry, I really want to eat white steamed buns, I really want to eat steamed buns."

The little monkey directly scampered up and grabbed the blind old man's goatee.

The blind old man raised his head; he was blind, without sunglasses, but where his eyes should have been was a murky expanse. At this moment, however, he must have sensed that someone, a stranger, was in front of him.

He licked his tongue, then swallowed,

And said:

"Go, you should go. Everyone is about to lose control."

The blind old man's words were filled with weariness and helplessness.

He was warning Zhou Ze,

That this place,

Was a place of trouble, and the people here were all very hungry.

One by one, hungry ghosts were about to be unleashed!

If he didn't leave now, he wouldn't be able to.

Zhou Ze still didn't move. To be honest, he wasn't particularly afraid of the vengeful spirits here. Even if their large number was a bit much for him to handle, there was a big difference between being unable to defeat them and being unable to escape.

Zhou Ze believed that no matter what, he still had a chance of escaping.

"What exactly happened here?"

Zhou Ze asked.

He hoped for an answer, as to why the people in this village had turned out like this.

Actually,

The darkness and blood moon above the village had already explained many things. The village was an ominous place, a characteristic often seen in ancient battlefield sites.

"Don't ask, don't ask. Go, everyone is very hungry, very hungry. If you don't go, you'll be eaten."

The blind old man kept repeating these few sentences.

"Hungry? Were you starved to death?"

That's impossible.

How could an entire village starve to death? If there was no food, wouldn't they go out to flee famine?

Moreover, that grandma online who used to be from Sanxiang Village had replied that this village was massacred on the day the Japanese invaders marched into Tongcheng. What does that have to do with starvation?

"Go, you go!"

The blind old man grew angry,

Tapping his cane on the ground incessantly.

"Go! Go!"

Zhou Ze still didn't move, which made the blind old man anxious. Of course, while anxious, he also began sniffing continuously, clearly, he was drooling!

"If you don't go, you'll be eaten."

The blind old man's voice began to get lower and lower.

He himself was about to lose control.

Zhou Ze still didn't move. He wouldn't leave until he figured out what was happening here.

The affairs of the living belonged to the police, but the affairs of the dead were his responsibility.

This village, once called a "modern-day" Peach Blossom Spring, had, after nine years, gradually shown a tendency to become a den of vengeful spirits.

That little girl was likely fortunate; she wasn't corrupted or greatly affected and ended up at his bookstore.

But at the same time, the fact that the little girl appeared at the bookstore also indicated that the ghosts in Sanxiang Village, and the situation here, had begun to change.

Not only could people enter,

But ghosts,

Could also leave!

Once so many vengeful spirits were unleashed at once, how much impact and destruction would they cause?

If Zhou Ze hadn't known, it would have been fine, he could just deal with it in time, but he was already here.

The little loli once said that the Underworld had a scale.

Zhou Ze believed that if he left without intervening, his actions would be judged far more severely by the Underworld than his coercing the little loli into becoming his subordinate.

In the eyes of the Underworld,

Ghost messengers and constables are the lowest-ranking civil servants. You can engage in internal strife, vie for favor, or quarrel, but you must get things done, and maintaining stability is paramount.

Controlling the situation and preventing ghosts from affecting the human world is the most basic red line; everything else is not a problem.

Therefore, Zhou Ze couldn't leave, even though he could sense that the oppressive feeling in the air was becoming increasingly intense.

But the most critical issue now was that without knowing the secret and origin of this village, Zhou Ze had no way to resolve the problem.

Just like the old man and the little girl he encountered when he first entered, after Zhou Ze killed them, they instantly reverted to their previous state.

In this place, Zhou Ze simply couldn't kill them, let alone capture them for performance points.

"Go!"

The blind old man suddenly stood up, extending his cane toward Zhou Ze.

Zhou Ze reached out and grabbed the cane, his two fingernails directly embedding into it.

"Ahhhhhhh!!!!!!"

The blind old man let out a low roar, then opened his mouth and bit directly at Zhou Ze.

Zhou Ze took a step back, turned sideways, and entered the ancestral hall, while the blind old man was thrown back, tumbling down the ancestral hall steps.

But then, the blind old man directly lay on the ground, propping himself up with both hands and feet, his stomach heaving.

"Bang!"

The blind old man leaped over again,

Zhou Ze spread his hands, black mist swirling, directly trapping the blind old man. But Zhou Ze didn't use his fingernails to stab him to death; instead, he patted his face,

And asked:

"Tell me, what exactly happened to this village!"

"Ahhhhhhh!!!!!!"

However, the blind old man seemed to have completely lost his mind, struggling incessantly, trying to break free from Zhou Ze's restraint to bite him.

There was no way around it; Zhou Ze could only kick him again, sending him flying once more.

Just like last time, the blind old man bounced back up after landing. Black liquid, mixed with fragments of tree bark and grass roots, constantly seeped from the corners of his mouth.

Clearly, for a long time, he had been so hungry that he had to subsist on such things.

And at this moment,

Unbeknownst to Zhou Ze, one villager after another had slowly gathered outside the ancestral hall. They all looked numb and staggered closer.

There was the old man carrying a hoe,

The little girl holding a candy figure,

The widow eating her own hair,

The old woman holding cloth shoes,

The young couple eating their own flesh,

And many, many others,

They all gathered at the entrance of the ancestral hall,

Their eyes fixed on Zhou Ze. They were hungry, extremely, extremely hungry.

The little monkey shivered in fear and jumped directly onto the ancestral hall's offering table, trembling.

So many vengeful spirits,

It was terrifying,

The malevolent aura emanating from them alone was enough to suffocate a person. When they stood there, it seemed as if a dark cloud had engulfed the sky.

Zhou Ze gritted his teeth and asked:

"I know you're very hungry, but I truly wish for someone who is still sane enough to speak to tell me what's wrong with you.

I'm here to help you, to relieve your suffering. Even if you've become like this, there's not entirely no possibility of reincarnation!"

Zhou Ze spoke earnestly and sincerely,

And,

The place where he hadn't felt pain for a long time now began to ache.

Zhou Ze instinctively reached for his chest.

He had almost forgotten its existence; it hadn't hurt for a long time.

Tang Shi told him before she left that he had become accustomed to living heartlessly, so now, was he starting to have a conscience again?

Yes,

He was having a conscience,

Because Zhou Ze couldn't bear to completely extinguish the last hope for everyone in this village. Eighty years ago, they were already tragic, like the 300,000 souls lost in Nanjing.

So, as long as there was a sliver of possibility, Zhou Ze still hoped they could have a chance to re-enter reincarnation.

It was precisely for this reason that Zhou Ze held onto a sliver of hope, attempting to find another conscious person in this village to gain some clues.

Now, he was surrounded by the entire village, losing the flexibility he had previously held.

He could charge out, but he would probably have to enter that state again amidst the tearing of vengeful spirits,

And then be paralyzed and severely injured for a long time again.

This was very costly,

And very foolish,

It was a stupid act and choice,

So his conscience ached again.

"Roar!"

"Hungry!"

"Eat him!"

"Eat!"

No one seriously responded to Zhou Ze's words,

They swarmed forward, rushing over.

Zhou Ze's fingernails flew incessantly, and one vengeful spirit after another was flung away by him. But they seemed endless; even when dispersed, they would quickly reappear in some corner of the village and continue to join the fray.

Zhou Ze was essentially facing an army of undead that could continuously revive!

"Bang!"

"Bang!"

The ancestral hall continuously endured blows,

The floor tiles also began to crack,

Finally, after Zhou Ze heavily slammed a vengeful spirit onto the ground,

A string of floor tiles beneath his feet completely shattered,

But beneath the tiles,

A large expanse of glistening white rice appeared.

Zhou Ze was stunned,

All the vengeful spirits present were also stunned,

The rice was definitely fake,

The village had long been flattened, even a school built on top of it,

But the scene here was real.

This meant that,

When everyone in the village was starving,

Beneath the ancestral hall of this village,

There truly was so much grain hidden!

Zhou Ze squatted down, scooped up a handful of rice, and held it up to the vengeful spirits in front of him,

Saying:

"Eat, you won't be hungry after eating, and then... you can depart in peace."

However,

The vengeful spirits of the entire village in the ancestral hall didn't move. They seemed to feel nothing for the rice.

Their gaze lingered on the rice for only a moment,

Then, in unison, their eyes fell back on Zhou Ze.

They didn't eat rice,

But they were still hungry,

So,

They could only eat Zhou Ze!

Zhou Ze truly had the feeling of laughing out of extreme anger,

What the hell,

Am I really that delicious?

title: 第一百三十三章 揭秘（修）
content:
It was a chaotic scene that left Zhou Ze somewhat helpless. The villagers completely ignored the food, instead swarming towards Zhou Ze once more.

Zhou Ze's fingernails tore through the villagers in front of him again and again, but they would quickly reassemble. It was an endless slaughter, a typical case of ants biting an elephant to death.

Something must be supporting this place, making it like a looped barrier that continuously repeats. These vengeful spirits didn't seem as strong as true vengeful spirits, but their most abnormal trait was their ability to reform after being destroyed.

The little monkey grabbed Zhou Ze's shoulder, watching him fight his way out. It wanted to help but couldn't. If it were its old self, working with Zhou Ze—one demon, one ghost-catcher—they could have easily charged out. But now, all it could do was tremble, praying that Zhou Ze wouldn't run out of strength too quickly.

It knew that if Zhou Ze was finished, it would surely be finished too.

Last life, it was eaten by humans. This life, was it going to be eaten by ghosts again?

It definitely didn't want that kind of grand slam.

These villagers seemed intent on blocking Zhou Ze's path out of the ancestral hall, rushing forward fearlessly, one after another, just to delay Zhou Ze for a few seconds. And they succeeded. Zhou Ze wasn't far from the ancestral hall's entrance; if he could just get out, finding a way to escape would be much simpler. But now, he was trapped in this narrow space, which was very uncomfortable.

"Squeak! Squeak! Squeak!!!!"

The little monkey's tail was grabbed by a villager, and it let out a cry of agony. It felt like it was about to be eaten.

Zhou Ze directly turned around, his fingernails bringing a black mist that instantly tore apart the villager and pulled the little monkey back. However, this action made Zhou Ze's distance from the door even greater.

The villagers pressed on, their momentum building, making Zhou Ze's repeated attempts to break through futile. Now, Zhou Ze was pinned against the offering table at the deepest part of the ancestral hall, where the ancestral tablets were placed.

"Huff... huff... huff..."

Gasping repeatedly, Zhou Ze was indeed a bit tired, but these villagers gave him no chance to relax.

"Clatter!"

With a crisp sound,

Zhou Ze directly swept all the ancestral tablets off the offering table. He hoped the villagers would go protect their ancestral tablets, giving him an opening.

But unfortunately, the villagers felt nothing for the ancestral tablets. They remained indifferent as the tablets fell to the ground, continuing to charge at Zhou Ze.

For the first time, Zhou Ze felt a bit wronged.

First, he genuinely wanted to help people; his conscience was aching!

You say you're very hungry, I can see that, but rice and grain are right in front of you, and you won't eat them. You still want to eat me?

That's unreasonable!

If you're going to be unreasonable, don't blame me for being unreasonable too!

Zhou Ze's anger was ignited. Human kindness and compassion have limits. Zhou Ze charged forward. This time, he didn't actively try to run away; instead, he targeted the spirits and killed them. At the same time, as the irritation and anger piled up in his heart, Zhou Ze's skin slowly began to take on a bronze color.

Clearly, the invasion of fatigue and anger was slowly awakening Zhou Ze's other side.

"Boom!"

Two spirits were grabbed by Zhou Ze's hands and slammed violently onto the ground.

"Boom!"

The spirits exploded, scattering to reform elsewhere before rushing back. At the same time, another pit was smashed into the ground, and white rice grains splattered everywhere.

Suddenly, Zhou Ze stood up, somewhat bewildered, because all the villagers who had been screaming in hunger and frantically charging at him had suddenly crouched down again, beginning to pick up the rice grains from the ground, not even missing those in the crevices.

Then,

The darling of the stage, the one with the spotlight, Zhou Ze,

was suddenly ignored by everyone.

This was a huge drop-off.

It left Zhou Ze feeling at a loss. He could only say that these villagers seemed to have some kind of illness, starving like this yet not touching the abundant grain in the ancestral hall.

Were they all misers?

Fortunately, Zhou Ze knew this wasn't the time to quibble. He immediately took the little monkey and rushed out of the ancestral hall. This time, no one blocked him. After running back to the field path, the bronze glow that had just appeared on Zhou Ze's body began to slowly fade.

Zhou Ze also let out a long sigh of relief. It was better not to enter that state if possible. The main reason was that afterwards, not only did his soul suffer greatly, but the resulting paralysis and long-term inconvenience in life made Zhou Ze very resistant.

He grabbed the monkey, still clutching his shoulder and looking somewhat shaken, and directly dropped it to the ground.

"Find the way out."

Zhou Ze didn't want to linger here until the villagers finished picking up the rice and came back to attack him again.

The little monkey didn't disappoint Zhou Ze. After running a short distance and circling a few times, it plunged directly into a pile of thatch and disappeared.

This made Zhou Ze wonder if he had adopted a monkey or a dog,

because when the monkey was circling on the ground, its nose was constantly sniffing the ground.

Zhou Ze also circled a few times, but he didn't imitate it by putting his nose to the ground, and then plunged into the pile of thatch.

He felt his whole body lighten,

and Zhou Ze found himself on the street. At this time, the shops on this street were mostly closed; it was clearly very late.

The old Taoist priest was squatting on the side, petting the monkey that had come out earlier. Seeing Zhou Ze emerge, he immediately stood up and asked,

"Boss, are you alright?"

Zhou Ze shook his head.

A Nissan was parked across the street, and Xu Qinglang was sitting inside. When Zhou Ze came out, he also got out of the car and asked,

"Is the matter resolved?"

"Where were you before? I couldn't reach you when I called."

"The basement of the library probably has bad signal. Get in the car first, I've found some other clues here."

Once in the car, Zhou Ze briefly recounted what had happened inside.

Xu Qinglang nodded and said, "I went to the Municipal Library first and looked up some information. I found a local diary from the Republican era. Actually, it wasn't really the Republican era; this area was under Japanese occupation at the time.

It was a record book, kept by the local puppet government, and it was preserved. It documented the massacre of Sanxiang Village. According to the book, it was because the villagers had hidden wounded anti-Japanese resistance fighters, which led to retaliatory mopping-up operations by the devils."

"Get to the point," Zhou Ze reminded him.

"Then, I checked the borrowing record for this book. It's a very obscure book that ordinary people wouldn't even notice. But in 2009, someone borrowed it, named Li Shi. I suspect this person and the one who posted are the same."

Zhou Ze nodded.

During that period, not many people would have paid attention to the events of Sanxiang Village.

"I also investigated Li Shi and found that he died of a sudden heart attack at the end of 2009. However, his trail didn't go cold because he was driving when he had the heart attack, and his car hit a tree.

The death location was on a road in the suburban woods.

It was very desolate there in 2009, and it still is now. But there's a sanatorium there, similar to a nursing home, but more upscale, a public-private partnership."

"So, you think Li Shi was driving there, going to the sanatorium before he died?"

"That's right, so I think there should be a clue hidden at the sanatorium, and he found it. In fact, I think he might have entered Sanxiang Village a second time back then. According to what you said, the villagers inside were all starving and trying to eat people, but in 2009, the problem shouldn't have been that serious.

Then, he got some information in the village. But, anyone who can enter Sanxiang Village, apart from you as a special case, are people who are about to die."

At this point, Xu Qinglang subconsciously looked at the old Taoist priest sitting in the back seat.

The old Taoist priest had initially felt very dejected,

the monkey went in,

the boss went in,

but he himself couldn't get in no matter what, making him feel like a failure.

Then, when Xu Qinglang arrived and told him that only those close to death could enter, the old Taoist priest laughed joyfully, with two snot bubbles appearing at his nose.

"Li Shi didn't have time to solve that problem; he died halfway."

Zhou Ze watched Xu Qinglang driving and chatting, then asked, "So, we're going to the sanatorium now?"

Xu Qinglang nodded.

Half an hour later,

the car drove into the sanatorium. Because it was late at night, the sanatorium was already closed, but Zhou Ze and Xu Qinglang still climbed over the wall and entered the office to access the sanatorium's client data.

Extraordinary times naturally call for extraordinary measures. If the problem in Sanxiang Village wasn't resolved soon, the issues caused if vengeful spirits truly broke loose would be terrifying.

Zhou Ze, the old Taoist, and Xu Qinglang searched together, but this kind of search was like looking for a needle in a haystack.

Because no one knew,

if the person the楼主 (original poster) was looking for nine years ago,

was still alive?

After all, many people who enter sanatoriums are elderly or in very poor health. Nine years might genuinely be too long for them to survive.

Moreover, there was no specific search information; they could only rely on intuition.

This was no longer looking for a needle in a haystack, but fishing for a needle in the ocean.

However, a patient's record made Zhou Ze's gaze slightly condense. He gestured to Xu Qinglang and the old Taoist beside him to come over, then pointed to the person in the photo and said,

"Chen Guangnong, born in 1919."

"Holy cow, Boss, this guy must be 99 already?" the old Taoist exclaimed, then puzzled, "This... surely the person we're looking for isn't necessarily the oldest one? I have a few centenarians here too."

Tongcheng was a longevity village, with the number of centenarians ranking among the top cities nationwide.

Zhou Ze shook his head and said, "This one's different. I think I've heard of this person. He served as an official in Tongcheng for a period in earlier years."

Zhou Ze opened a webpage and started searching. Baidu Baike directly brought up Chen Guangnong's detailed biography.

"He revolted?" Xu Qinglang noticed something.

The record states that this person was a battalion commander in the Huaihai Campaign during the Liberation War. He led his troops in an uprising and also participated in the Korean War. Later, he returned to his hometown, Tongcheng, and served as a local official for a period before retiring.

"I think it should be this person. Li Shi was likely looking for him," Zhou Ze said.

A legendary person must have a legendary life to match. This person's life story was already exciting enough.

Zhou Ze first found his hospital room, but to the dumbfoundment of Zhou Ze, Xu Qinglang, and the old Taoist, Chen Guangnong had already fallen into a long-term coma several years ago, similar to a vegetative state. Now, he was merely still physically alive.

"Damn, how do we handle this?" The old Taoist looked bewildered.

Zhou Ze opened the ward door and walked in. Xu Qinglang signaled the old Taoist and the monkey to keep watch outside, then followed him in.

The ward felt somewhat oppressive. This elder, just one year shy of achieving the centenarian milestone, his life truly had reached the stage of a dying lamp.

He lay there now, unconscious.

You could say he was alive, but it was indistinguishable from death.

Zhou Ze sat down on the chair beside the bed and glanced at the data from the various instruments beside the elder. The elder's condition was not optimistic.

"Is there any way to wake him up?" Xu Qinglang asked.

He knew that Zhou Ze used to be a doctor.

Zhou Ze shook his head. If the one from Rongcheng hadn't been taken away by Tang Shi, inviting him might have been easier. That guy was said to be a psychologist, and his hypnotism was terrifying; he could even hypnotize and control ghost-catchers.

"Now, it seems there's only one way left," Zhou Ze said.

"What way?"

"Kill him now, then grab his spirit and question it."

"..." Xu Qinglang.

Zhou Ze shook his head, indicating he was just joking. It was not easy for someone to live to be ninety-nine. He couldn't just kill someone for an uncertain reason, just to ask a few questions.

Moreover, looking at his state, his life had been full of ups and downs, rich and colorful, and he had been lying here for so many years. He might have already come to terms with everything. If he killed him, his soul might go directly to hell, and he wouldn't even be able to ask.

"There's a book in the drawer."

Xu Qinglang opened the drawer and said.

"What book?"

"An autobiography. It must have been self-published by later generations or others."

Xu Qinglang took out the book and flipped through it.

"Look at his early life," Zhou Ze reminded him.

"I know."

Soon, Xu Qinglang found an entry and said, "Before the War of Resistance, he served as a company commander in the Tongcheng Security Regiment."

The Security Regiment, which was a local armed force, was pretty much as depicted in anti-Japanese war dramas, essentially having little fighting capability.

"When the Japanese invaded Tongcheng, was there any resistance?" Zhou Ze asked.

"I checked. The Japanese Iizuka Unit, I think it was the 101st Division, I'm not entirely sure of the specifics. But it's said that Japanese divisions numbered 100 and above generally weren't very strong in combat. This division was apparently badly beaten in Jiangxi.

However, at that time, Tongcheng had no regular Chinese army. It was entirely local armed organizations in Tongcheng that organized the resistance and fought against the Japanese. But no matter how greenhorn a greenhorn division was, it was still far stronger than local armed security regiments and the like, so Tongcheng fell quite quickly at the time."

"So, he participated in Tongcheng's resistance against the Japanese army then?"

"He should have. He probably didn't betray and surrender, otherwise he wouldn't have become a battalion commander in the National Revolutionary Army."

Zhou Ze frowned,

The sleeping old man, covered in age spots, and all the villagers of Sanxiang Village, gave him a sense of powerlessness. He had all the strength in the world, but it was like punching cotton.

He and Xu Qinglang had been standing there talking for so long, and the old man just kept his eyes closed without any reaction. Clearly, he had truly lost his perception of the outside world.

But Zhou Ze was a bit unwilling to just leave like that. So, Zhou Ze bent down, leaned close to the old man's ear, and slowly asked,

"Old sir, do you still remember... Sanxiang Village?"

Suddenly,

a miracle happened,

The old man's fingers suddenly trembled,

followed by his eyelids twitching incessantly.

It was as if he had heard, or been stimulated. His lips parted slightly, and he seemed to utter a very faint sound:

"Villagers..."

"What did he say?" Xu Qinglang asked.

Zhou Ze shook his head; the voice was too faint.

Xu Qinglang pushed Zhou Ze aside, put his ear next to the old man's mouth, and listened carefully.

After a moment, Xu Qinglang straightened up, his expression solemn.

"What did he say?" Zhou Ze asked.

"He said... he wants to kiss you?"

title: 第一百三十四章 血月，墜落！
content:
“Boss, is everything alright?”

The old Taoist sat in the back, trembling slightly as he pointed to the old man lying on his lap.

The old man was still semi-conscious, but he could open his eyes, though only for a moment before closing them again. His speech was intermittent.

He was awake.

He was indeed awake.

But this awakening,

Strictly speaking, should be considered a final burst of energy before death.

He was awake,

Which meant he was nearing his end.

He had held on, sustained by a single breath. Previously, Zhou Ze thought it might be his strong life force, or good medical conditions coupled with some heavenly favor, but now he realized it was likely that there was something he couldn't let go of, something that prevented him from closing his eyes in peace.

Xu Qinglang was driving, fast yet steady. He had to be steady, because a sudden brake or sharp turn could make the old man simply pass away.

Taking a patient, a dying, long-comatose one, out of a sanatorium was a crazy thing to do, but Zhou Ze didn't regret it and felt no burden of conscience.

Although the old man hadn’t spoken clearly, his attitude had made it evident:

Sanxiang Village,

It had always been in his heart, never erased.

In truth, humans are forgetful creatures. People always subconsciously blur out what they don’t want to see, erasing painful memories.

Many people remain undisturbed and indifferent as the elderly women who were comfort women pass away one by one, unaware that their departures slowly seal off that part of history from us.

Some things, in fact, must not be forgotten.

Upon reaching the streets of Xingren Town, Xu Qinglang got out of the car, then, with the old Taoist, helped the old man out.

“Old brother, hold on a little longer, we’re almost there, almost there,” the old Taoist encouraged the 99-year-old elder.

Xu Qinglang felt the old man’s hand press lightly on his shoulder.

The old man’s half-open eyes turned to Zhou Ze. His eyes were very cloudy, as if veiled. His body was long exhausted; he needed to rest, he needed to go.

“The villagers are all there,” Zhou Ze said earnestly. “I don’t know what they’re waiting for, but since you woke up when I spoke the words ‘Sanxiang Village,’ it means I found the right person, and you too care for them.”

Saying this,

Zhou Ze reached out and smoothed the old man’s sparse hair, then fastened a button on his patient gown.

The old man was already experiencing a final burst of energy.

Right and wrong, good and bad deeds, would be judged by future generations.

It was hard for modern people to empathize with or judge the disputes of that era.

At least, one thing could be proven: when the old man served in the Tongcheng Security Regiment back then, he didn’t desert or become a collaborator. When a Japanese division landed in a harbor near Tongcheng, there were no regular Chinese forces in Tongcheng.

However, relying solely on the local armed Security Regiment and spontaneous resistance from residents, they inflicted significant losses on the Japanese. In fact, the local armed forces had planned counterattacks on the Tongcheng city gates more than once. While the main forces and their focus shifted southwest,

In this isolated Japanese-occupied zone, resistance continued, and gunshots still echoed.

The old man was still looking at Zhou Ze. As he watched, he began to cough. Most of his teeth were gone, and his cough was weak, but he was smiling.

Then,

He painstakingly reached out, as if trying to grasp Zhou Ze.

The old Taoist watched beside him, his heart aching, thinking, *Old brother, just rest easy, don’t wear yourself out before you even get in.*

Zhou Ze stood still,

Allowing the old man’s emaciated hand to gently grasp the fabric over his chest.

The old man’s grip was faint.

Then, Zhou Ze felt two light presses on his chest,

Right where,

His heart was.

After performing this action, the old man slumped, as if all his strength had been drained, and his breathing became erratic.

“Go in, quickly.”

With that, Zhou Ze began circling at that spot, then rushed onto the road, and then his entire being vanished.

Xu Qinglang took out a talisman and placed it on his forehead. Instantly, his glabella darkened, and then, following suit, he also circled a few times at that spot and rushed forward.

The old Taoist also circled a few times at the end, then rushed forward,

Hey,

He didn’t get in.

Hehehe.

The old Taoist laughed, his entire face wrinkled like a chrysanthemum, truly overjoyed.

The little monkey beside him watched the old Taoist’s foolishness, tilting its head slightly to indicate it didn’t know this old salted pervert.

Entering Sanxiang Village again, Zhou Ze looked up and saw that the moon in the sky had almost turned blood-red. It hadn’t been like this when he came in half a day ago.

It seemed that his massacre in the ancestral hall had intensified something, invisibly making the situation here more urgent.

Therefore, if the old man on Xu Qinglang’s back couldn’t resolve the situation here and break the deadlock, then Zhou Ze, as a ghost messenger, would probably have to call the little loli to guard the exit.

Whether they would succeed in guarding the passage and preventing these fierce ghosts from wandering into the human world,

It was hard to say.

Xu Qinglang also entered, carrying the old man. As soon as he entered, Xu Qinglang felt the person on his back grow heavier. Xu Qinglang immediately widened his eyes, somewhat disbelieving:

No way,

Dead?

Grandpa, don't scare me, you haven't lived to be a hundred yet!

Xu Qinglang anxiously tried to turn his head to check on the old man on his back, but he suddenly saw Zhou Ze looking calmly behind him.

“Put him down,” Zhou Ze said.

Xu Qinglang slowly lowered the old man's remains from his back. Turning around, he saw a young man standing behind him.

The young man wore a black military uniform, with a rifle slung over his back and a cap on his head.

It was a typical Security Regiment uniform, with some patches showing signs of wear. This attire was common in popular anti-Japanese war films.

He was dead.

Was this his soul?

The old man,

Oh no,

The young man looked at Zhou Ze and Xu Qinglang, nodded slightly, closed his eyes, and took a deep breath, as if in remembrance, or perhaps in mourning.

Two lines of tears trickled down from the corners of his eyes.

He was dead,

But the tears were not because he had died.

In fact, death was more of a release for him. He had been bedridden for too long, and before he fell into a coma and lost consciousness, he had actually endured for far too long.

He didn't know what he was holding on for. His comrades, who had walked out of the flames of war with him, had left one by one, until he was left all alone.

He was almost a hundred years old, but he didn't live for the sake of living to a hundred. He had people he cared for, promises he cherished, and...

A debt of gratitude.
