The old Taoist slowly retreated, then prepared to shout. At this point, he didn't care if he'd disturb the slumber of the nation's future, nor did he care about his own face. Without Zhou Ze by his side, the old Taoist felt very insecure.

But just as the old Taoist opened his mouth, before he could make a sound, he felt as if something was stuck in his throat, making it impossible to shout. He almost choked.

Now, beads of sweat began to appear densely on the old Taoist's forehead. He knew that ghost had targeted him.

Damn,

What kind of skill is it to bully a Bronze-level player? If you're so capable, go find a spirit of the deceased!

The old Taoist intimately greeted all eighteen generations of the female ancestors of this ghost, which bullied the weak and feared the strong, then unhesitatingly turned and prepared to go down the stairs.

Can't afford to provoke, can't afford to provoke.

I can afford to hide!

Who knew, as the old Taoist descended the stairs, he saw the steps below him suddenly become distorted, uneven in height. The old Taoist slipped and fell directly. Fortunately, he was agile, otherwise, any other elderly person falling like that could have started preparing their funeral.

But even so, the old Taoist still ended up bruised and battered.

When he struggled to stand up, he saw the young boy in the yellow sweater, holding a drawing board, still standing in front of him.

He was looking at him,

At the same time,

The fountain pen in his hand seemed to be drawing something on the drawing board.

Even a cornered rabbit will bite. The old Taoist directly charged forward, holding the talisman in his hand. At worst, it would be a fight to the death!

However, while he couldn't go down the stairs before, now he couldn't go up. The old Taoist kept running up the stairs but maintained a distance of about two meters from the boy, unable to get close.

The old Taoist simply took flight, jumped up, and flung out the talisman in his hand.

The boy looked up,

His eyes were hollow. He raised his hand, and the fountain pen in his hand suddenly pointed out, becoming a rich, dark stroke that instantly blackened the bright yellow talisman.

Seeing this, the old Taoist felt despair. His ancestral talisman had been so effortlessly neutralized by this ghost.

It's over,

It's over!

The old Taoist, who had jumped up, fell heavily onto the stairs, sliding down with a series of "thumps."

The boy slowly walked down,

The old Taoist struggled to raise his head, watching the other party continuously approach him.

Just then, the most beautiful, most wonderful sound in the world, the one that now brought tears to the old Taoist's eyes, rang out:

"Oh, you're here."

Boss Zhou's voice came through,

The old Taoist's heart, which had been ashen, was instantly filled with hope!

The boy turned sideways, saw Zhou Ze behind him, and frowned slightly, as if feeling somewhat helpless, or perhaps a headache.

Immediately after, the boy began to walk towards the wall, intending to hide himself again. He seemed to have no interest in confronting Zhou Ze, and he knew how difficult this man, who had entered the dorm building for the first time today, would be to handle.

But how could Zhou Ze let him leave so easily? His fingernails directly dug into the wall. Zhou Ze stepped back, using his arms to pull backward with force!

"Bang!"

The boy was yanked out and fell onto the stairs, his drawing board and fountain pen falling to the ground.

"Buzz!"

The boy's previously hollow eyes revealed a dark red. He was angry, he was furious. Before this, he felt he had given Zhou Ze a lot of face, but Zhou Ze was being a bit ungrateful.

"Hiss..."

An astonishing scene appeared before Zhou Ze. He heard the sound of tearing paper in front of him. Immediately after, Zhou Ze saw the sleeve on his arm rip open, followed by his skin and flesh tearing, and blood continuously flowing out.

Zhou Ze began to retreat. After retreating a certain distance, the previous injuries disappeared, and even Zhou Ze's previously injured arm returned to normal.

What was going on?

The old Taoist took advantage of Zhou Ze's entanglement with the ghost to get up and try to escape, but the boy seemed to be fixated on him, appearing instantly in front of him.

"%...￥￥##@@...!"

Bullying an honest man!

The old Taoist cursed in his heart.

"Pfft..."

A fountain pen,

Directly pierced the old Taoist's chest. The old Taoist looked down in shock. He saw the wound on his chest continuously expanding. Crimson blood began to permeate relentlessly, staining his entire Taoist robe red at an astonishing speed!

"Thump..."

The old Taoist knelt on the ground, covering his wound with both hands, watching the blood continuously gushing out onto the floor.

He felt it was unreal, extremely unreal. Although he knew there were risks in accompanying the boss to catch ghosts, he really hadn't expected to die here!

He,

Just died like this?

Died in this dorm building?

Zhou Ze had already rushed over. The boy glanced at Zhou Ze, seemingly not intending to make another move, or perhaps having some reservations, and once again slipped into a nearby wall.

As Zhou Ze was about to continue the pursuit and use the same method to drag the boy out again,

He found his pant leg grasped by a pair of hands,

Looking down,

He saw,

It was the old Taoist.

The old Taoist's blood-stained hands clutched Zhou Ze's pant leg,

Wiping snot and tears onto it incessantly,

Zhou Ze took a deep breath,

Forcing himself to resist the urge to slap this old man to death first!

For someone with mysophobia, the old Taoist's current behavior,

Was like carrying a dung bucket and scurrying around the streets,

Looking for excrement (death).

"Boss, I can't go on, I can't go on! Don't chase him yet, let me say my last wishes first before you chase him, I'm afraid I won't have a chance!"

At this moment, the old Taoist didn't care if Zhou Ze was going to catch a ghost. He knew he wouldn't last much longer. He was afraid that by the time Zhou Ze came back after catching the ghost, he would already be cold, and then he wouldn't even have had time to say his last words or make arrangements for his funeral, which would be too great a loss.

"Boss, I have a small box under the bed in my bookstore room. Inside is another box of ancestral talismans, and in a hidden compartment, there are three bank cards. The password is the last six digits of my phone number. It's not much money, only about a million yuan..."

"..." Zhou Ze.

The old Taoist suddenly shivered. He sensed a killing intent, seemingly from his boss.

The old Taoist's heart immediately warmed,

Ah,

Don't look at how ruthless and uncaring the boss usually seems. When he saw his good buddy, good brother, good friend, good partner, and soulmate about to depart,

He too was enraged,

He probably wanted to kill that ghost immediately to avenge himself.

Alas,

A long road tests a horse's strength, and time reveals a person's heart.

The old Taoist sighed in his heart,

He didn't know that when Zhou Ze heard the old Taoist say, "It's not much money, only about a million,"

A thought had occurred to him: should he just go with the flow and kill this old Taoist to seize his wealth?

If the old Taoist knew the truth, he would probably spit out a mouthful of old blood and die on the spot.

"The talismans, just burn them in front of my grave. You can keep two for yourself.

Boss, after I die, please donate my money to the children in the mountain areas. You can also keep two for yourself, but don't keep too much.

Also, after I die, please inform Mr. Liang in Shanghai to attend my memorial service. After all, it's a kind of fate.

Of course,

Boss, if you and Mr. Liang truly can't bear to lose me, you can both kill your way into hell and rescue this poor Taoist's wandering soul. This poor Taoist won't mind!

Even if I can't enter reincarnation, this poor Taoist is willing to make the sacrifice to return to the human world and continue to accompany you!

Come rain or shine, this poor Taoist will wait for you!"

Zhou Ze really couldn't listen anymore,

Kill his way into hell?

And for you?

"Boss, this poor Taoist can't bear to leave you! Although your temper is really bad, and you're very selfish, and you're broke, not earning much money, I never had the nerve to ask you for a salary."

"..." Zhou Ze.

"Although you're very lustful, always making Yingying serve you in the bath with a straight face. I heard from Miss Xu that you have problems in that area, unable to get it up..."

"..." Zhou Ze.

Why aren't you dead yet?

Or, should I help you along?

Just die soon,

Otherwise, I really can't stop myself from killing you.

The old Taoist, with snot and tears, continued, "But actually, you're not a bad person. Although you have many flaws, you do have advantages, for example... uh... for example..."

The old Taoist scratched his head,

It's so hard,

For example, what?

Just then, the old Taoist lost his balance and fell, rolling out of where he had been kneeling. In an instant, the old Taoist found that all his injuries had disappeared, and he was completely clean!

Not dying after all?

"Boss, I'm fine now, I don't have to die!"

The old Taoist was so excited he forgot himself,

Then he saw Zhou Ze extend his fingernails towards him,

"What did you just say? I didn't hear you clearly. Say it again."

title: 第一百四十二章 隨處可見的不對勁
content:
"Boss, what exactly is going on?"

The old Taoist priest was a bit confused. He had clearly seen himself get hit by an arrow just now—

Oh no, he was hit by a pen.

But now he felt completely fine, except for the lingering bruises on his face, which were from his own fall.

Zhou Ze reached out and picked up the pen that had fallen to the ground. As soon as it was touched, it crumbled into ash.

"It was drawn," Zhou Ze said. "If he were truly that powerful, he wouldn't be unwilling to confront me directly. In fact, he could have easily crushed me."

"Drawn?"

"Yes, drawn. It's like a more advanced form of hypnosis, deceiving your sight, hearing, smell, and other senses, and changing them according to his design."

Zhou Ze looked at his arm. Before, there were clear injuries on his arm, but now not a trace could be seen. Yet, the realistic texture of those images was enough to make one instinctively believe it was all real in a short amount of time.

"Damn, so he's a colleague of ours, a trickster from the jianghu."

The old Taoist priest instantly regained his masculine confidence.

The great leader said that all reactionaries are paper tigers!

"Boss, should we go and catch him now?"

Zhou Ze shook his head, pointing out the hallway window. "It's almost dawn, and he's already hidden."

In truth, the appearance of ghosts has little to do with day or night. At least for ghosts, there's no fundamental impact. Instead, it affects humans.

During the daytime, everything is out in the open, and even if something strange happens, ordinary people can feel a bit bolder, at least finding some psychological comfort.

But at night, people are easily startled by anything that happens, giving ghosts an opportune moment.

Of course, that particular ghost was special. He was good at painting, but even the best painting and picture quality needed an environment to support and complement them. Daytime wasn't his preferred background for painting because it would magnify the flaws in his art, whereas at night, his paintings could be more realistic.

"So what do we do next... go for breakfast?"

Zhou Ze walked towards the other end of the corridor, and the old Taoist priest naturally followed. Then, the old Taoist priest watched Zhou Ze walk into a dormitory room labeled "Storage Room."

Inside the dormitory, besides a pile of miscellaneous items, there was a pair of black leather shoes.

Zhou Ze sat on a wooden board, seemingly lost in thought.

"Boss?"

Zhou Ze raised his hand, gesturing for the old Taoist priest to be quiet for now.

The old Taoist priest nodded and sat down on the opposite bunk. He wasn't worried about the bruises on his body. After so many years of traveling north and south, he had endured countless hardships and minor injuries. This was child's play.

About fifteen minutes later, Zhou Ze bent down and started searching under the bunk.

The old Taoist priest also bent down and rummaged around. He didn't know what his boss was looking for, but that was okay; searching was the right thing to do!

After all, most bosses don't look at your progress, but your attitude.

Under the bed were only miscellaneous items. After pulling them out, the space underneath was empty, as no one had been living in this dormitory.

Zhou Ze opened the wardrobe. All eight compartments were open. Inside, there was nothing but a thin layer of dust.

The old Taoist priest scratched his head and simply climbed onto the upper bunk. On the wall by the upper bunk, there were many posters of football stars, like Cristiano Ronaldo and Sergio Ramos.

Zhou Ze also went to the upper bunk. He felt that there should be something here; otherwise, Wang Baogang's ghost wouldn't have lingered here, and he had also seen other bizarre scenes in this dorm.

If nothing else, this dormitory should be the key point in this series of events.

"Boss, what kind of painting is that poster you have? It looks weird," the old Taoist priest said, pointing to Zhou Ze's side.

"A Picasso painting," Zhou Ze replied.

Immediately, Zhou Ze seemed to discover something and reached out to touch the poster.

From the old Taoist priest's perspective, his boss was actually touching the chest of the woman in the painting. The old Taoist priest immediately said:

"Boss, go home and touch Yingying's; the woman in this painting is too ugly—"

The old Taoist priest hadn't finished his sentence when—

He heard a "rip."

Zhou Ze directly tore the painting down. Several pieces of paper fell between the painting and the wall.

Zhou Ze didn't have time to bother with the old Taoist priest's nonsense. He immediately picked up a piece of paper. It was a pen drawing, meticulously done. The drawing depicted a dormitory room, but this room was filled and covered by a special liquid.

It could be water, or it could be... blood.

The next drawing showed a boy with only half a body trying to crawl inside on a balcony, and two legs extended from the dormitory wardrobe.

Next was the third drawing, which showed a man standing on his head, wearing leather shoes and doing a handstand on the tile floor.

Three drawings, representing three scenes, and Zhou Ze had just witnessed these three scenes earlier.

One was the dormitory filled with bloody water, another was the half-bodied boy, and the third was Wang Baogang walking upside down.

Below, there were three more drawings, making a total of six.

Picking up another drawing, it depicted a skeleton holding a book, walking among students and teachers. If there was no mistake, it should be Sun Qiu.

Next was the fifth drawing. When Zhou Ze saw the scene in this drawing, he immediately turned his head to look at the old Taoist priest. The old Taoist priest had just climbed down from the opposite upper bunk and was now climbing onto Zhou Ze's upper bunk, apparently also interested in what Zhou Ze had found.

"What's it drawing? Can't see clearly," the old Taoist priest asked.

Zhou Ze handed the drawing to the old Taoist priest. The old Taoist priest grabbed the ladder with one hand and took the drawing with the other. Then he froze for a moment and fell straight down. Fortunately, it wasn't a high fall, so he wasn't injured, but the old Taoist priest looked as if he had lost his soul.

The drawing landed on the ground. In the drawing, an old man in a Taoist robe lay there, decapitated, with a black cat nearby appearing to gnaw on his corpse.

Zhou Ze turned to the last drawing.

Somewhat unexpectedly, the last drawing was not of himself, but of the flat-headed man. The flat-headed man had a sharp object sticking straight out of his forehead. He was standing perfectly straight. Because the flat-headed man had two moles on his face, it was easy to identify the person in the drawing.

After looking at all the drawings, Zhou Ze looked at the dejected old Taoist priest below and suddenly felt a sense of disappointment.

Why was there a drawing of the old Taoist priest but not of himself?

Hmm,

This feeling was like a pre-determined protagonist in a movie being completely upstaged by a minor extra.

The old Taoist priest immediately climbed back up, took the other drawings from Zhou Ze's hand, and looked at them all. Then, he asked Zhou Ze tremblingly:

"Boss, the drawings are all fake, right?"

Zhou Ze got off the bed and washed his hands at the sink, saying, "Only the two drawings of you and the flat-headed man I haven't seen. I've seen the other four drawings."

"How is that possible? This isn't some Mayan prophecy. This poor Taoist is still alive, and that flat-headed dorm supervisor is still alive too."

"Are you trying to say that a few years ago, there was a talented middle school student in this dorm who started admiring you in advance?" Zhou Ze countered.

"This is the ghost's trick, a deliberate deception, trying to sow discord in our ranks!"

Zhou Ze said no more, but motioned for the old Taoist priest to put all six drawings away. Then, Zhou Ze walked out onto the balcony.

It was almost dawn; the morning light was faintly visible. People always liked to see dawn as a symbol of hope, but sometimes, it was more like the oppressive calm before the darkness.

The old Taoist priest, with a bitter face, also walked to the edge of the balcony, took out a cigarette, offered one to Zhou Ze, lit one for himself, and then sighed, saying:

"Boss, these are all fake, right?"

The old Taoist priest had already asked this question.

"I don't know." Zhou Ze shook his head. Then, Zhou Ze leaned against the edge of the balcony and continued, "Do you feel how damp everything is here since we entered this dormitory building?

And it also has a musty, earthy smell?"

"Dormitory buildings are all like this," the old Taoist priest exhaled a puff of smoke.

Zhou Ze reached out and rubbed his forehead. Just then, the dormitory bell rang, meaning students should get up for morning self-study.

Some more diligent students had already exited from the ground floor as soon as the bell rang. They were wearing red school uniforms.

Meanwhile, students in the other surrounding buildings were wearing blue school uniforms.

"Different school uniform colors."

Zhou Ze pointed downwards. He didn't want to miss any detail now, for a simple reason: from the moment he entered this dormitory building, the string of events that had occurred left Zhou Ze feeling completely without a clue.

"Maybe it's because junior high and senior high school uniforms are different. This is a junior high dormitory building, and the two outside buildings seem to be high school dorms. This school combines both junior and senior high sections."

As the old Taoist priest spoke, he took out the drawing and looked at it again, feeling increasingly uncomfortable. He even wondered why the person who died so tragically in the drawing wasn't Zhou Ze, but himself?

When did I become so important?

"Look, your flat-headed friend is out."

Zhou Ze pointed downwards. The flat-headed dorm supervisor teacher walked out to the exit, holding a phone as if making a call.

"Didn't they call the police?" Zhou Ze asked.

"No, right?" the old Taoist priest wondered.

Actually, for Zhou Ze and the old Taoist priest, causing a minor disturbance wasn't a big deal; burning some paper money would usually resolve it. The key was that even if the flat-headed supervisor and his group didn't call the police, they wouldn't just act as if nothing had happened.

Before, they were only focused on catching the ghost and overlooked this detail, but now that they had leisure, they realized something was off.

No, to be precise, ever since they entered this dormitory building, few things had felt right.

"Look, he's still alive too."

The old Taoist priest pointed to the flat-headed man standing below.

This feeling,

Really,

He's good,

I'm good too.

"Crack!"

Suddenly, the sound of glass shattering came from the roof. The old Taoist priest felt a gust of wind brush past his face, and then he heard a commotion and screams from below.

The flat-headed man standing below was just hit by the glass.

That piece of glass,

Punctured directly into his forehead,

Perfectly straight.

title: 第一百四十三章 小蘿莉和白鶯鶯
content:
The bookstore at dawn was quite deserted. Of course, with its exaggerated sign boasting a minimum spend of one hundred yuan, it was destined to rarely be lively.

Xu Qinglang was upstairs in his bedroom, sleeping a beauty sleep with a face mask on. After bidding farewell to his restaurant life and escaping the erosion of kitchen fumes on his skin, he had come to increasingly appreciate and cherish it.

Hah, a man,
must learn to treat himself well, to love himself more.

Bai Yingying sat alone at the counter on the first floor, playing a mobile game, "Chicken Dinner," and having a blast.

The bookstore door was pushed open at this moment. Bai Yingying looked up and saw a little loli in a red dress standing at the doorway. The loli's outfit was truly festive, making her appear even more guileless and adorable.

Yawning, Bai Yingying continued to look down at her phone.

The little loli walked up to the counter. She was a bit short and couldn't reach, so she simply pushed open the small counter door and walked in, standing behind Bai Yingying and watching her play.

After a round ended, Bai Yingying stretched, glanced at the little loli, put down her phone, and asked, "What do you want?"

The little loli lifted her delicate chin, sized up Bai Yingying, shook her head, and smiled faintly. "Your mistress, back then, didn't dare to speak to me in such a tone."

"You said 'back then'," Bai Yingying shrugged. "What's the difference between you and me now?"
We’re all dogs, all tied by a man's leash.
Why criticize the pot for being blacker than the kettle?footnote:[Literally "why should the fifty-pace man laugh at the hundred-pace man?", meaning why criticize someone for a fault when you share a similar one.]

The little loli sat down on a chair nearby, which gave her a special sense of satisfaction. She was always sensitive about her height and disliked standing below, looking up at people taller than her.

"Can you compare to me?" the little loli retorted.

"Hey, I can even 'ying ying ying'*. What can you do?
Ying ying ying..."footnote:["Ying ying ying" (嘤嘤嘤) is an onomatopoeia for crying or whimpering, often used sarcastically to describe someone acting overly cute or helpless to gain sympathy, especially from a man.]

The little loli frowned slightly, unsure how to respond to that.
After all, she was a two-hundred-year-old zombie,
and she could actually "ying ying ying" that man without any sense of incongruity.

"What are you here for?" Bai Yingying asked. "Did your mom go to get her hair done in the middle of the night again and dump you at the bookstore?"

The little loli took a sealed envelope from her pocket and tossed it onto the counter. "Everything he asked me to investigate is in there. The location of that Japanese priest has also been confirmed."

"Why didn't you just call him?" Bai Yingying tilted her head and asked. "Oh, I get it. Do you think delivering it in person shows more sincerity and earns you some goodwill with him?"

Then, a sense of crisis appeared on Bai Yingying's face:
"Are you... trying to compete with me for his favor?"

"Bang!"

The little loli slapped the counter,
scolding Bai Yingying:
"Don't think of me as being like you!"

Bai Yingying pouted, muttering, "Little brats always care about face."

The little loli suppressed her urge to physically confront Bai Yingying and said, "I couldn't get through to his phone. I couldn't contact him and thought he was in the bookstore, but he wasn't."

"He went out for something," Bai Yingying said.

"He's really busy."

"He's almost getting promoted," Bai Yingying said, smiling. It was clear she was genuinely happy for Zhou Ze.

"Why are you happy if he gets promoted?" The little loli found Bai Yingying's "ugly face" of being enslaved and controlled yet content utterly intolerable.
Because she didn't want to become like this stupid zombie in front of her.

"What? He's my boss. Don't I share in his glory if he does well? Besides, the sooner he gets promoted and moves up, the sooner you can be free, right?"

"Whether he does well really has nothing to do with you. You should be thinking about how you're going to spend the next Cold Clothes Festival!"
The little loli couldn't stand Bai Yingying's naive "sweet and simple" mode anymore.
All those false, beautiful, fresh little things,
had to be pricked,
pricked, pricked with a silver needle!

The little loli and Mrs. Bai knew each other. Due to Mrs. Bai's unique nature, the little loli hadn't laid a hand on her. Both parties kept to themselves.
You cultivate your merits, I do my work; peace between us.

But the little loli was clear about what kind of person Mrs. Bai was. She could even guess Mrs. Bai's purpose in handing her corpse over to Zhou Ze before achieving full merit and descending into Hell.

"How to spend it? Of course, I have a design."
Saying that,
Bai Yingying opened the computer, clicked on a folder, and said,
"I've been designing for a long time, and I've designed many styles."

The little loli saw one bamboo bed after another appear on the computer screen: mandarin duck and butterfly-style bamboo beds, small boat bamboo beds, princess beds, all with various decorations.
The little loli was shocked.
She,
already knew?

"These bamboo beds aren't cheap to make, but luckily I have enough burial goods. I can sell two items to build them then. Don't you think it would be beautiful to lie on one of these and be burned?"

The little loli covered her face with her hand. She didn't know how to talk to this zombie anymore.
This wasn't foolishness;
this was having a screw loose!

"You know that day is coming, and you're still here acting as his maid?" the little loli finally asked.

"I quite like my current life," Bai Yingying said, as if it were the most natural thing. "It's pretty good."

"Do you think this will move him?" the little loli retorted.

Bai Yingying didn't answer.

"Last time, a corpse demon could bring him so much merit. Do you know how much merit a genuine two-hundred-year-old zombie is worth?"

Bai Yingying still didn't speak.

"Forget it," the little loli said, giving up. She looked at the envelope she had just thrown onto the counter and asked, "Where did he go?"

"He seemed to go to some school," Bai Yingying said. "He's just one ghost short, and the boss is anxious."

"School?" The little loli tilted her body, not taking it seriously. "I'm leaving first. When he gets back, give him the envelope."

"Okay."
Bai Yingying nodded, indicating she remembered.

The little loli got off the chair and was about to leave. As she reached the door, she inadvertently glanced at the young man sitting in a corner of the bookstore, reading.
The young man held a book, engrossed in it, occasionally letting out snorts of laughter.

The little loli stopped.
When she came in,
why hadn't she sensed another ghost in the bookstore?
This ghost,
she had seen with her eyes,
not sensed.

The little loli pointed at the young man and asked Bai Yingying, "Who is he?"

"A ghost. According to the boss, he's a 'high-level simpleton' who just walked into the bookstore. Because his soul isn't complete, he can't be taken to Hell, so he's staying for now. The boss will send him off once he's dealt with his own matters."

"Incomplete soul?"

The little loli walked towards the young man who was reading. The young man didn't even notice the little loli approaching, completely absorbed in the world of his novel.

"What's his name?" the little loli asked.

"Sun Qiu, a middle school student."

The little loli reached out and took the book from his hand.

Sun Qiu was stunned, somewhat displeased. "Little sister, what are you doing? Don't be mischievous."
Saying that, Sun Qiu reached out for the book again.
However,
in the next moment,
the little loli suddenly extended her tongue. Instantly, her tongue lashed out like a whip, striking Sun Qiu's soul hard.

"Thwack!"

Sun Qiu was whipped to the ground, screaming in pain.
For a soul body, the little loli's tongue skill was absolutely terrifying.

Bai Yingying immediately stepped out from behind the counter. "Hey, what are you doing? That's the boss's reserved merit."

"Merit?" The little loli was somewhat bewildered, even a little amused. She pointed at Sun Qiu, who was on the ground. "Are all of you at this bookstore idiots?
This is not a soul, this is not a ghost!"

Zhou Ze hadn't been in the Ghost Catcher circle for a short time, but of course, he couldn't compare to the little loli. She was a senior Ghost Catcher, naturally having experienced much more.

"He's not a ghost?" Bai Yingying was stunned. If he wasn't a ghost, what was he?

"So, he couldn't be sent to Hell not because his soul was incomplete, but because he's not a ghost at all. Of course, he couldn't pass through the Gates of Hell to be sent below."

The little loli walked up to Sun Qiu, her tongue lashing him repeatedly, making him scream continuously.

"Look, his soul is just weak, but there's no sign of it dissipating. He's fundamentally an illusory energy body, not a soul body."
The little loli said with absolute certainty.

"He's not a ghost, but he deliberately came to the bookstore..." Bai Yingying immediately realized something, her expression instantly changing.
A guy who wasn't a ghost came to the bookstore and told a ghost story?
And the boss took the old Taoist to the school?

"Has anyone new come to Tongcheng recently?" the little loli asked.

"The one from Rongcheng has been here."

Upon hearing this, the little loli's face showed unconcealed horror, but she quickly suppressed it and asked, "Anyone else?"

Bai Yingying pondered, and then she suddenly remembered the little girl who said she came from Sanxiang Village that day, and how that little girl had actually knocked her down and tied her up.

"It seems there really was one, very powerful, the kind that could knock me down in an instant. Oh, by the way, you haven't said, how did this thing come about?"
Bai Yingying pointed at Sun Qiu and asked.

"Every Inspector, when advancing to a Judge, is granted a Yin-Yang Brush by the Underworld—it can determine destiny, it can discern right from wrong. And there's also a Yin-Yang Tome, which contains Yin and Yang.
This thing should have been born from within the Yin-Yang Tome... a puppet."

After saying that,
the little loli suddenly looked up and burst into laughter,
"Hahahahahahaha..."
A little loli,
with her hands on her hips,
burst into loud laughter.
She seemed to want to create a heroic feeling, but in reality, her pose was utterly comical and adorably chuunibyou.

"So, the boss is in danger?" Bai Yingying asked.

The little loli shrugged, then looked at Bai Yingying and said, "Shouldn't we be happy? If someone kills him, then you and I will both be free."
Yes,
if Zhou Ze were killed,
then the little loli could break that night's truce and regain her freedom!

"Have you forgotten what kind of person the boss is?" Bai Yingying suddenly asked.

"What?" The little loli was confused.

"If the boss knows he can't escape, and he's really going to die... given his personality, he might feel too lonely dying alone. Then, at the moment before his death, he might crush your soul-blood and make you accompany him in martyrdom."

"..." The little loli.

title: 第一百四十四章 畫壁
content:
Xiao Pingtou's head was impaled with a shard of glass, like a headdress, and blood slowly began to seep down.

He stood for several seconds, then staggered a few steps before collapsing amidst the screams of those around him.

Zhou Ze had once read some memoirs from Japanese war criminals and soldiers, in which someone had written that headless bodies would still twitch after decapitation, and even eyes in severed heads could move a few times.

Perhaps death came too suddenly, and too swiftly; not only did the person involved not have time to react, but even their body seemed unable to make a timely response.

Downstairs in the dormitory building, chaos had erupted.

Zhou Ze leaned his hands on the railing, sighed, and then looked at the old Daoist.

The old Daoist was currently dazed, his face deathly pale from fright.

"Boss..."

"Ah, see? A perfectly fine person, you practically jinxed him to death."

"..." The old Daoist.

The old Daoist felt very wronged; he didn't want this either. He genuinely hoped Xiao Pingtou would live a long life, be hale and hearty, and "come eighteen times a night."

But he died.

He died so abruptly.

So,

Only one painting remained out of six.

There was a famous film series called "Final Destination." The old Daoist now felt like a character in it, being explicitly told that he would die, and how he would die.

Truly, it would be better to just die quickly and painlessly in a sudden accident.

At this moment, the old Daoist actually felt a bit envious of Xiao Pingtou, who had simply died in an unexpected incident without knowing. Now he had to endure the torment of not knowing when he would die.

It was simply... a fate worse than death.

He looked at his boss beside him, who was still smoking.

"Let's go down and see."

Zhou Ze said, walking out of the dormitory first. The old Daoist naturally didn't dare leave Zhou Ze at this point. He had already made up his mind that he would stick close to Zhou Ze, even if he went to the restroom.

At the main entrance of the dormitory building, a group of students surrounded Xiao Pingtou's body, and several dorm supervisors were maintaining order.

The feeling was very strange because at this time, they should be calling 120 and 110. In fact, they had called and done what needed to be done, but it seemed such a major incident—a death in broad daylight—only affected a corner of the school.

The students in front went to class if they were supposed to, or to the cafeteria for breakfast, as if they didn't care about the incident at all.

Zhou Ze flicked his cigarette ash and looked up at the dormitory building.

The old Daoist was trembling beside him, stealing glances at Xiao Pingtou's body before quickly averting his gaze. The thought of soon following in his footsteps filled the old Daoist with immense dread.

Zhou Ze sat down on the steps like an observer, continuing to watch everything around him.

"Boss, should we go back first?" the old Daoist suggested.

He didn't want to stay here anymore; he wanted to return to the bookstore. At least the bookstore could give him some sense of security.

Zhou Ze shook his head. "Can't leave."

It wasn't a reply of "no, we won't go," but "we can't go."

The old Daoist froze, vaguely sensing something was amiss.

Zhou Ze turned around and re-entered the dormitory. He went directly into the dorm supervisor's office, found a place to sit, and brewed a cup of tea using their tea leaves.

The old Daoist stood beside him like a small quail.

He didn't know what Zhou Ze was planning, but it seemed his boss had grasped some information. Although he didn't know if he was feigning calm or truly calm, at least it gave him a bit more hope.

The students had all gone to class, and the dormitory building had become much quieter.

The dorm supervisors hadn't returned either; none of them were back in the office. Perhaps they were busy with Xiao Pingtou's body.

The police hadn't come.

The ambulance hadn't come either.

After sitting for about half an hour and drinking two cups of tea, Zhou Ze left the office.

At the entrance of each dormitory room in the hallway, a row of thermoses was placed. Students would take their thermoses out and leave them there before going to class in the morning, and a special auntie would come with a plastic hose to fill these thermoses with boiling water.

Because this boiling water passed through plastic hoses, it inevitably had a bit of a plastic taste. Students generally didn't drink it, only using it for washing clothes or soaking their feet.

At that moment, an auntie came with a plastic water gun, preparing to dispense water. She slowly walked from one end of the corridor to the other.

Zhou Ze stood there motionless. The old Daoist stood beside Zhou Ze, and the auntie seemed to not see Zhou Ze at all, continuing to walk towards them.

"Old Daoist, don't you think something's strange? There are too many odd things in this place," Zhou Ze said.

"Huh?"

"First, Sun Qiu died but continued to live out of inertia, and no one noticed even when corpse spots appeared on his body. Then there's one accident after another, one bizarre scene after another.

Is this dormitory building a once-in-a-century land of extreme malevolence, which is why so many ghosts and strange entities can emerge?

Then why was there no activity before, but it has suddenly erupted recently?"

"Uh... Boss, what exactly do you mean?"

Zhou Ze was silent for a moment, thought about it, and then said, "I think we should go back."

"Alright."

The old Daoist was more than willing. Regardless of whether he would encounter an accident, if he had to choose between dying here or dying in the bookstore, he would rather choose the latter.

The two walked together towards the dormitory building entrance. Outside, Xiao Pingtou's body had already been taken care of.

Zhou Ze stood on the steps at the entrance, not rushing to go down, but watching the old Daoist walk out step by step.

As the old Daoist was about to exit the dormitory building's perimeter,

Zhou Ze looked up,

He saw,

The building was bending,

As if it were about to collapse.

The old Daoist, however, was completely unaware and continued walking.

"Old Daoist, stop," Zhou Ze warned.

"Huh?"

The old Daoist took another step out, then turned his head.

In an instant, from a certain dormitory window above, blood gushed out, sweeping towards the old Daoist. This should be the dormitory where Zhou Ze had been before and found the pen sketch; it should be on the third floor, but now, because of the bizarre bending of the entire building, the window of that dormitory was directly facing the old Daoist.

When the blood rushed over, the old Daoist was completely engulfed.

"F***..."

This was the last word the old Daoist managed to utter.

He was practically on the verge of collapse.

It didn't matter how many ghosts came; ghosts, he'd seen them before.

But this building could bend like it was pole dancing.

Who had ever seen that?

Damn it,

You can't play like this!

Zhou Ze turned around and looked at the woman behind him who was still pouring boiling water into the thermos.

However, this bottle of boiling water from the woman seemed to never fill up, remaining perpetually above the thermos, with the sound of water continuously emanating from within.

For those with life experience, the sound changes as the water level rises when pouring boiling water into a thermos, but here, it remained unchanged.

"Hey, the thermos is leaking."

Zhou Ze pointed at the thermos, reminding the woman.

The woman froze slightly, turned her head, and looked at Zhou Ze. Her face was densely covered with "hornet's nests," like countless corns, and some areas were involuntarily closing and expanding.

A very disgusting sight,

Truly disgusting.

The woman continued to grip the plastic water hose, while the old Daoist outside the dormitory building struggled ceaselessly in the blood. In the blood, several dark figures were vaguely visible slowly approaching him, and in their hands, they held gleaming broadswords.

Zhou Ze walked over, preparing to take the hose from the woman's hand.

A ghastly smile appeared on the woman's face.

The hose immediately twisted, wrapping around Zhou Ze. The inanimate object from before now seemed to have transformed into a living python!

Zhou Ze's fingernails grew long.

He didn't resist the python, allowing it to bind him. He could even hear the crisp snapping of his bones.

Honestly,

It was somewhat pleasant to hear.

In the distance, at the hallway entrance, the boy with half a body began to crawl towards them again, wriggling like a mad dog, roaring something.

On the other side, Sun Qiu, covered in corpse spots, also stumbled towards them, dazed.

Xiao Pingtou also appeared, the glass still impaled in his head, blood flowing.

Even the leather shoe that Zhou Ze had destroyed somehow reappeared, making incessant "drip-drop" sounds.

"Is the dagger finally revealed, because you know I've seen through you?"

Zhou Ze muttered to himself.

In the distance,

The old Daoist had already submerged in the blood, with only occasional bubbles rising from his nose, clearly indicating he couldn't hold on much longer.

Those dark figures seemed to be closing in on him, and within the blood, a small figure, not human, like a cat, waited for its dinner.

Zhou Ze's fingernails didn't sweep around.

Instead, with a decisive and resolute motion, he plunged them directly into his own chest, then twisted them around.

"Hiss..."

The pain was so clear, Zhou Ze's body even began to convulse because of it.

But at this moment, the surrounding scene began to retreat rapidly. The woman retreated, Xiao Pingtou and the dorm supervisors retreated, the half-bodied boy retreated, the leather shoe began to retreat, and even the bending dormitory building began to return to normal.

Everything, everything seemed to be returning to normal.

During this rapid retreat of everything,

Zhou Ze seemed to see a girl standing deep in the hallway, looking at him. The girl's appearance was somewhat familiar.

"Snap!"

A crisp sound echoed.

The sound of a book being closed.

"Thump... pant, pant, pant... cough, cough..."

The old Daoist lay prostrate on the lawn, gasping for air and coughing violently, his hands clutching his neck tightly. It took him a while to calm down, then he looked around with a bewildered expression.

He saw Zhou Ze standing beside him, holding a closed notebook.

The crisp sound earlier was Zhou Ze closing the notebook.

Zhou Ze looked up, still feeling a lingering pain in his chest.

"Boss... what happened?" The old Daoist thought he had just died, but how did things suddenly take such a turn?

"You can think carefully about how we got in," Zhou Ze said slowly.

"We drove here. I tricked the security guard at the school gate to let us in, then we got out of the car, walked to the living area, found Building B, and then we snuck in and saw Sun Qiu, and then we even fought with the dorm supervisor..."

"Think carefully again," Zhou Ze reminded.

"Think carefully?" The old Daoist scratched his head, then a look of shock appeared on his face. "I... I... we did drive in, but as soon as we got out of the car, we seemed to see a black cat. That black cat was staring at us in the lawn, and I even said we should catch it and keep it as a pet.

Then we walked to the lawn and found the black cat was gone, but there was a notebook on the ground. Boss, you picked up the notebook, and I even asked you what was written or drawn in it... and then... and then we..."

Zhou Ze looked at the slightly worn notebook in his hand,

He didn't dare to turn any page again.

"Boss, where's that dormitory building?" The old Daoist scanned his surroundings, realizing something seemed to be missing.

"Look at the other dorm buildings nearby. How are they labeled?"

"Building 1, Building 2, Building 3..." The old Daoist counted, then he slowly stopped counting. The buildings here were numbered with Arabic numerals; there was no naming system using English letters!

"Boss... then Building B, where is Building B?"

Zhou Ze pointed to the notebook in his hand,

"Building B,

It's in here,

It's drawn."

title: 第一百四十五章 狗血和俗套
content:
It was almost dawn, which meant Zhou Ze and the old Taoist had been standing still on the lawn for a very long time.

Fortunately, there were hardly any people walking around the dormitories at this hour, so no one noticed the two men standing there like idiots.

Otherwise, if something unexpected were to happen, there would be no way to attend to it. Just like Tie Guai Li* possessed the dead beggar's body because his own body encountered an accident when his spirit was wandering.

The old Taoist got into the car, took out the bruise liniment, and rubbed his knees. At this moment, he was a bit disoriented. The previous illusion and the current reality, two feelings that were hard to distinguish, kept assailing him. He couldn't tell which of his aches were real and which were imagined.

It was like a person feeling disoriented by gravity after just getting out of the water after swimming.

Zhou Ze also sat in the passenger seat. In front of him was the notebook.

The notebook cover was blue, very understated and ordinary.

"Boss, what exactly happened? How did looking at a notebook turn into that?"

The old Taoist had always been curious about this. For some unknown reason, a part of his and the boss's memory after entering the school had been erased, and they had directly entered Block B.

But in fact,

Block B didn't exist,

the dorm supervisor inside didn't exist, the boy with half a body, Zhao Baogang walking upside down, the aunt refilling thermoses with hot water, and so on, none of them actually existed.

But that feeling of non-existence that was extremely real, that subconscious "seamless transition," it was truly terrifying.

"Heard of *Painted Skin*?" Zhou Ze asked.

"The movie, I've seen it," the old Taoist replied.

"It's a story from *Strange Tales from a Chinese Studio*." Zhou Ze leaned his head against the headrest. "It's pretty much the same thing. But in that story, people entered the world of a wall painting, while this time, we entered the world inside this notebook. If I'm not mistaken, the notebook should contain some ink drawings. Everything we saw in that dormitory building was drawn in there."

"Is it that exaggerated?"

"Now there's only one question: what the hell is that Sun Qiu?"

If Zhou Ze still hadn't realized the problem with Sun Qiu by this point, he would have truly wasted his time.

From that guy entering the bookstore and telling the story to himself and the old Taoist entering Pingchao Middle School and being led by a black cat to find this notebook, the whole thing was interconnected.

Someone was guiding and manipulating behind the scenes, seemingly waiting for all of this to happen.

This feeling was very uncomfortable. Normal people didn't want to be someone else's puppet.

And the scene of the girl deep in the hallway that he saw when he "closed" the notebook reminded him of the little girl from Sanxiang Village. She was naive, she was very hungry, and she was very well-behaved.

Bai Yingying was even directly knocked down and tied up by the other party.

Before, Zhou Ze had thought the other party was some elusive expert who did good deeds anonymously, but who knew, she wasn't that simple after all.

Zhou Ze could guess the purpose of the six ink drawings found in the dormitory building, especially the one about the old Taoist.

Paintings, like movies, were all fake and not strictly existent. The scenes and characters in the paintings could naturally be unrestrained.

For example, the dormitory building could bend, and the ghosts appearing one after another inside could do so without any logic or reason. But fakes were fakes; how could they become real?

By having a living person die inside, by having a real living person die in a fake world, starting from a point and spreading out, it could give originally fake things the ability to influence reality.

Like some financing scams, their hype and all their promotions were basically fake, but they could attract funding in reality, defrauding vast amounts of money. In the end, whether it was real or fake no longer mattered; it had successfully caused chaos in reality.

And because he himself was a "dead person," not a living one, the protagonist of that painting became the old Taoist.

Zhou Ze reached out and rubbed his forehead. Honestly, this matter was a bit disjointed, and the feeling of being watched and schemed against was unpleasant.

"Meow!"

A cat's meow sounded. The old Taoist, who was in the driver's seat applying medicinal wine, froze suddenly and quickly looked out the window. On a nearby overpass, a black cat squatted there, its eyes like sapphires, looking this way.

"Damn it, this cat's out again."

The old Taoist was quite sensitive to cats. He now recalled that the reason he had suggested catching that black cat back then was because his previous boss had a white cat, and he felt that if Zhou Ze had a black cat, it could effectively boost his image.

Zhou Ze got out of the car and looked over, still holding the notebook. On the back of the book was a sticker of a black cat's head.

The black cat was nearly a hundred meters away from Zhou Ze. It licked its paws, seemingly still not satisfied. Just now, it had been so close to getting a taste of the old Taoist.

Zhou Ze didn't run over to catch the cat, nor did he bother to play hide-and-seek with it. He took out his lighter, flicked a flame, and held the bottom of the notebook to it.

Screw your schemes,

I'll just burn it down!

The black cat froze. It seemed it hadn't expected Zhou Ze to react this way. Its body tensed, then it leaped over directly. The black figure almost flew across the cement road, pouncing on Zhou Ze.

As expected,

was this black cat like the spirit of this notebook?

"Buzz!"

Zhou Ze's left fingernails grew long, and he directly clawed at the black cat pouncing on him.

"Pfft!"

The black cat was sent flying by Zhou Ze, landing on the ground. Its body began to become ethereal, appearing very uncomfortable. It was far weaker than Zhou Ze had anticipated.

"Hey, are you really going to burn it?"

A girl's voice came from behind Zhou Ze. Zhou Ze turned around and saw a little girl sitting on top of his car, swinging her legs, as if watching a play.

She was indeed watching a play, watching from beginning to end.

The old Taoist poked his head out of the car. Before he could look up, a foot stepped directly on him.

"Ah, that hurts!"

The old Taoist cried out in pain and pulled his head back in.

It was truly the old Taoist's own fault. The girl was sitting on the car, swinging her legs. If he poked his head out and looked up, wouldn't he expose everything?

"Who exactly are you?" Zhou Ze asked.

"I just passed by, and I'm leaving Tongcheng soon. I just want to remind you that this notebook is much more valuable than you think. It's just been contaminated and was accidentally picked up by a student who can draw, and then they drew all those ghost stories about the dormitory on it.

Coupled with being permeated by the students' resentment and negative emotions in this school, it became that way.

But its function is actually much higher than this; its use is definitely not limited to VR glasses."

"Why should I believe you?" Zhou Ze asked.

The little girl jumped off the car and walked in front of Zhou Ze.

A half-smile,

Her eyes were like stars, completely different from the naive little girl from Sanxiang Village who had come into his bookstore before.

"Hehe, so much fun. You look so funny."

The little girl reached out, wanting to touch Zhou Ze's face.

Zhou Ze's eyes narrowed slightly, but he didn't resist or refuse.

Her palm was very cold, and honestly, not very comfortable.

As the little girl stroked, she looked up and let out a long breath. "Do you know, this is a judge's artifact, a fallen-grade Yin-Yang Scroll."

Zhou Ze shook his head, indicating he didn't know.

He was still a temporary worker.

Only after becoming a full-time ghost messenger could he be considered official, and then he would have to slowly work his way up to captain, then inspector, and only after that, judge.

It could be said that the "judge" level was too distant for Zhou Ze right now.

"If I hadn't isolated the scroll's influence, only confining it to one dormitory building, how long do you think it would have taken you to realize that what you were seeing was actually a painting? That the place you were in was actually fake?"

The little girl seemed to be talking to herself,

"I'm leaving. That ring last time and this notebook, consider them my gifts to you. Keep them safe; you'll probably need them later."

The little girl reached out and grabbed forward. The black cat that Zhou Ze had just sent flying transformed into a black light and flew into the girl's palm. Then, the little girl sent it into the notebook.

At the same time, Sun Qiu, who had been reading in the bookstore, instantly disappeared. The book he had been holding fell to the ground.

"Keep it safe. Although this thing is badly damaged now, it's still somewhat useful. Later, you can even put some ghosts in it.

Like a beautiful ghost or something, then you can go in and look whenever you want. The experience will definitely blow away current VR adult technology."

The little girl retracted her hand and looked at Zhou Ze carefully again.

"I'm going down. It'll be hard to come up next time. You can also try to keep a low profile, but there's no need to shortchange yourself. Forget it, you seem to have gotten used to it after your last life anyway."

"You know me?" Zhou Ze asked.

"Uh-huh, do you still think the you of your past life is the real you?" the little girl retorted.

"If you want to talk to me about past lives or something, that's too cliché and melodramatic," Zhou Ze said.

"Then let me tell you an even more melodramatic story. I do know the you from your past life." The little girl blinked, looking at Zhou Ze,

"And then, you raped me."

"..." Zhou Ze.

"How's that, melodramatic?"

Zhou Ze nodded.

"Were you that small then?" Zhou Ze asked.

He wanted to know if he had been that beastly in his past life.

The little girl bent over with laughter,

And then slowly began to grow up.

A thin black mist enveloped her,

Making her face unclear, but she indeed transformed into the appearance of an adult woman.

Zhou Ze felt a little relieved mentally.

Good,

Not that beastly.

However,

What Zhou Ze couldn't see was that the woman's face within the black mist was a wrinkled, chilling old hag's face.

The old hag wore a dark golden robe and a phoenix crown, exuding endless elegance. Only that face was extremely mismatched with her figure and aura, like a perfect work of art that had been brutally ruined and distorted.

"I'll wait for you. I'll slowly wait for you to climb step by step, until the day you return to the Underworld to be conferred, until you can remember some things from your past life."

"Don't do that. You'll make me feel like I'm on the wrong set. We're not filming *Chinese Paladin*."

"At that time, I'll torture and kill you again, personally throwing you into the Animal Path. Only then will I get the pleasure of revenge.

You're growing too slowly, so slowly that I can't stand it. I can only appear to give you a few good things to make you fatten up faster."

"..." Zhou Ze.

Suddenly, he felt that it would be better to have actually been on the wrong set than this.

"Hehehe..."

The woman's figure and the surrounding black mist vanished in an instant, merging into the ground.

She left,

Very decisively.

The car door opened, and the old Taoist, with a clear footprint on his face, rubbed his face and got out.

He snorted discontentedly at the spot where the woman had disappeared:

"Heh, women."

---
*Tie Guai Li (鐵拐李): One of the Eight Immortals in Chinese mythology. He is often depicted with an iron crutch and a gourd. His origin story includes his spirit leaving his body and returning to find it gone, thus having to possess a dead beggar's body.

title: 第一百四十六章 體貼的老闆
content:
On the way back, Zhou Ze drove. Old Dao, in his current state, was not suitable for driving.

"Boss, is that woman really a karmic debt from your past life?"

"What did you hear?" Zhou Ze asked.

"Uh, don't worry, Boss, I'll keep your secret!" Old Dao immediately patted his scrawny chest.

"Dead men tell no tales."

"............" Old Dao.

"Screech............"

The car braked sharply and stopped.

Old Dao jumped in fright,
Holy cow,
Is he really going to kill me to silence me?

Zhou Ze habitually reached for a cigarette but found he was out. He looked at Old Dao, wanting to ask him for one, only to find Old Dao clutching his knees, trembling.

Was he really that scared?

Zhou Ze reached out and patted Old Dao's shoulder,
"Hey."

"Ah!"

Old Dao yelped, looking at Zhou Ze.

Zhou Ze found it a bit funny. Was his usual image really that bad, making Old Dao think he would kill him to silence him?

"Give me a cigarette."

"Oh, okay."

Old Dao immediately pulled out a cigarette and handed it to Zhou Ze, then personally lit it for him, cautiously and carefully like an ancient maid, though this maid was a bit too old.

"Boss, why did you stop the car?"

"Stop pretending. Is acting that much fun?"

"Uh............"

Old Dao rolled his eyes internally. Is it easy to serve a heartless B like you!

Old Dao sometimes couldn't understand himself. Why did he always have to deal with a ghost boss instead of living a carefree life? But then he felt relieved, perhaps this was life.
Perhaps,
This was what it meant to be a man.
If you didn't seek out some excitement and challenges when you were full of energy, how boring would life be?
Besides, this current life was something he had never experienced before, and most ordinary people wouldn't either.

"Boss, why did you stop?" Old Dao finally asked.

"To eat breakfast."

Zhou Ze said, pushed open the car door, and got out.

Eat breakfast?
Boss, did you bring any money? I didn't.

Ahead was a row of breakfast stalls, selling Jianbing (Chinese crepes), noodles, steamed buns, and Youtiao (fried dough sticks). This was a small intersection with a lot of traffic, and many people stopped their cars here to eat something.

Zhou Ze walked up to a meat soup vendor. The vendor was a middle-aged man.

"Two bowls of beef soup," Zhou Ze said.

"Alright, want it spicy?"

"Yes."

"Okay."

The vendor first took out two bowls, put green onions and cilantro in them, then some beef;
Afterward, he scooped a ladle of soup from a pot kept hot by a coal stove, poured it into the bowls, then poured the soup back into the pot, and then added various seasonings to the bowls before filling them with soup again. He then placed the two bowls on a small table to the side for Zhou Ze.

Zhou Ze added more chili to his bowl, ordered two flatbreads, and sat down.

Old Dao arrived then, too. He sat next to Zhou Ze, rubbing his hands, a bit constrained and a bit flattered. Damn, this was the boss's first time treating him!
This cheapskate actually treated him!
Should I cry a little to set the mood?

Old Dao kept having self-destructive thoughts, then saw Zhou Ze methodically tearing the flatbread into pieces and soaking them in the soup bowl.

Old Dao followed suit. Old Dao had traveled extensively in his life and was no stranger to this kind of breakfast. The boss's accent immediately told him he was from Henan.
And for many Henan people, the morning often began with a bowl of soup.

However, Old Dao didn't drink or touch it. He just silently watched Zhou Ze.

Zhou Ze felt a bit uncomfortable under his gaze and said, "What's wrong, don't like it?"

"No, no, no, I like it, I like it."

Old Dao responded evasively, perfunctorily.
This soup,
Definitely problematic!
Stopping suddenly to eat breakfast was already suspicious, and he was even seriously tearing up the flatbread, looking so formal about it.

Old Dao turned his head and glanced at the vendor again,
Is this vendor a ghost?
Then this soup is definitely not clean!

Old Dao felt he had seen through everything. MMP, the boss was up to his tricks again, just like when he told me to leave the dorm building first, and then watched the building bend.
This time, he's definitely messing with me again!
Waiting for me to drink this soup and make a fool of myself!

"It's a bit hot, I'll drink it later," Old Dao explained.

Zhou Ze nodded and continued tearing the flatbread in his hand.

Old Dao was actually a bit hungry. He glanced at the vendor again, then stood up and said, "Boss, this isn't enough. I'm going to buy two steamed buns from across the street."

With that, Old Dao ran across the small road, bought a few plain steamed buns, sat back down, picked up a bun, and bit into it directly, eating with relish.
Damn,
Eating something you bought yourself is just reassuring, and delicious!
And the *mantou* (steamed buns) on that saleslady's chest were also very big.

As Old Dao ate, he offered a bun to Zhou Ze.

Zhou Ze took the bun, placed it next to his soup bowl, and then looked at Old Dao with a half-smile.

Huh,
Why is he looking at me like that?

Old Dao began to murmur to himself again,
No way,
You're not happy that I didn't fall into your trap and didn't drink this soup?
How can you be like this!
So, should I drink a little?

Old Dao thought while chewing his bun. It was truly like accompanying a tiger king; none of these ghost bigshots were easy to deal with.
However, this seemingly fragrant soup in front of him—who knew what it actually was? If it were something like grilled centipede or roasted mouse, he might be able to eat it, but the unknown fear of not knowing what it was at all was truly terrifying.

"Boss, eat. This steamed bun is really delicious," Old Dao said with a laugh.

Zhou Ze picked up the bun he had just placed on the table and said, "The table isn't clean; the bun is dirty."

"Then I'll eat this one. I'm not particular; don't waste it."

Old Dao took the bun from Zhou Ze's hand and continued to chew on it. Anyway, he wasn't going to drink that meat soup!
At worst, he'd find another excuse, saying he was full from the buns and couldn't drink anymore.

Zhou Ze looked at Old Dao and shook his head.

Heh,
Disappointed, aren't you?
Didn't get your way, did you?
Am I smart?
Are you helpless?

Old Dao felt smug.

Then, Old Dao watched Zhou Ze lower his head, pick up the soup bowl, take a sip of soup, then use his chopsticks to pick out a piece of meat and chew it.
It was clear that even with a lot of chili and a strong flavor, Zhou Ze still ate with great difficulty and swallowed painfully, which was consistent with Zhou Ze's usual eating patterns.
However, what surprised Old Dao was that the boss actually drank the soup?
Could it be that he was overthinking things?
Was there nothing wrong with this soup?
Old Dao didn't believe Zhou Ze would sacrifice himself just to trick him.
Was I overly suspicious?

Old Dao watched Zhou Ze continue to painfully drink the soup and eat the flatbread, and finally confirmed that there was nothing wrong with the soup; he had overreacted!
Immediately, Old Dao also lowered his head and took a sip of soup.
Mmm, very authentic, the flavor is great, absolutely delicious.
Damn, I almost choked on the bun just now.

Old Dao ate freely and joyfully. Even in the cities of Henan, it was hard to find an authentic soup shop, and to find one with such authentic flavor in Tongcheng, especially on the roadside, was even more precious.
With the soup, Old Dao finished both the buns and the flatbread. He even refilled his soup once. Hmm, no charge for refills, very authentic.

Zhou Ze ate a third of his bowl, couldn't eat anymore, put down his chopsticks, and sat there.

After eating, Old Dao patted his stomach, feeling a bit unsatisfied. Had he not eaten enough?
As he wondered whether to order another bowl, Zhou Ze made a gesture for his wallet.
Old Dao understood immediately, got up, and paid the bill. He had that much discernment.

Standing up, Old Dao took the car keys from the table first and said, "Boss, I'll drive back. You must be tired."

Zhou Ze shook his head. "You've also had a tough time. I'll drive."

The boss had changed,
He had really changed!
Not only did he treat his subordinates to breakfast and soup, but he also knew how to be considerate of them!

Old Dao hesitated, wondering whether to shed a few tears and take the opportunity to express his loyalty to heighten the atmosphere, when Zhou Ze walked towards the road. Old Dao naturally followed, and then, Old Dao saw Zhou Ze stop in front of the stall where he had just bought the steamed buns.

Heh heh,
I told you the vendor lady's *mantou* (steamed buns) were big, didn't I? Boss, you hypocrite, Yingying's aren't small either, you can look whenever you want.
Heh, men,
Homegrown flowers never smell as sweet as wildflowers.

Old Dao's mind raced with thoughts. He felt that after contact with that person from his past life, the boss seemed to have changed, becoming more down-to-earth.

"Boss, what filling do you want for your steamed buns? Or just plain white ones?" The vendor lady asked enthusiastically.

Zhou Ze shook his head and pointed at the vendor lady.

Damn it, you beast! We're just looking, and you're already flirting! Do you want to buy the vendor lady's steamed buns?
Old Dao watched excitedly as the boss flirted.
Huh, didn't I hear the boss couldn't get it up?

"Boss, what do you want?" the vendor lady asked.

"You, come with me, to where you belong," Zhou Ze said.

Old Dao froze,
Crap,
Old Dao had a bad feeling!
No way?
Seriously?
It can't be, can it?
Impossible, right?

The vendor lady pursed her lips, and her voice suddenly deepened a bit, saying, "I died young from illness. My wife is raising three children alone, working two jobs a day, and still coming out to sell breakfast. It's too hard.
That's why I thought I'd possess her in the morning, to let her rest a bit."

The voice was still a woman's, but it had clearly changed to another person's tone, likely her husband's.

"Everyone is pitiful, but don't act pitiful yourself. Possessing your wife severely harms her lifespan."

Saying that, Zhou Ze opened the steamer and took out a steamed bun. He gently pressed his thumbnail into it.
"Besides, selling these steamed buns to deceive the money of the living, even if it's for your children's tuition, aren't you afraid of harming their yin virtue?"

The steamed bun in Zhou Ze's hand slowly began to change,
Turning into a paper-mâché bun-shaped object, the filling inside was actually a messy, black paste.

Old Dao, to the side, immediately started to vomit:
"Ugh!"

title: 第一百四十七章 恐怖的輪迴
content:
The old Taoist priest was throwing up beside them, everything he had just eaten came back up, a truly miserable sight. On the ground was a puddle of red, white, and yellow, a colorful mess, like a sauce shop had opened.

Tears welled in his eyes. The old Taoist priest was filled with regret and hatred. How could he be so unlucky?

With a thousand precautions and ten thousand careful steps, he thought he had avoided one pit, but he hadn't expected that he would foolishly and freely jump into an even bigger abyss.

While jumping, he had even shouted:

"So weightless!"

"Leave her body and come with me," Zhou Ze urged. He was the last one; once he sent him back to hell, he could become a regular employee.

Perhaps this was a case of "what one seeks with diligence is found without effort." He had been busy for a long time at the school, even the so-called "karma from a past life" had appeared, but he hadn't caught a single genuine ghost. Then, on his way back, he found him (her).

The woman looked dejected, as if resigned to her fate, but she still spoke:

"I want to stay with her a little longer. She is willing too. We can still meet in our dreams every night. I can still see my three children."

Zhou Ze was unmoved. Every dead person has their own lingering attachment to the human world. This is a characteristic of all intelligent life forms; there's always a survival instinct that compels them to seize any opportunity to stay.

Even Zhou Ze himself was the same, but understanding was one thing, rules were another.

Moreover, if this husband's ghost remained in the woman, her body would soon become overwhelmed and develop problems. In the end, it would only cause harm to both.

"Bang!"

The woman suddenly pushed aside the stall in front of her, sending the steaming baskets tumbling towards Zhou Ze. Then, she directly turned and began to flee. She wanted to escape; she didn't want to be caught.

Zhou Ze pushed aside the steaming baskets. With a light flick of his fingernail, an invisible black mist was released, directly entangling the woman.

The woman let out a muffled groan and fell to the ground.

Zhou Ze took a few steps forward, approached the woman, knelt down, and placed his hand on her forehead. Immediately, a wisp of black ghost was pulled out by Zhou Ze.

It was a man's face. The man struggled continuously and roared furiously, filled with intense unwillingness and hysteria.

"She's willing! She's willing to stay with me! She told me in her dreams at night that we would raise the children together! She's willing!"

The man argued for himself, then glared at Zhou Ze:

"She's willing, so why are you meddling?"

"I need performance," Zhou Ze stated frankly. Ultimately, he needed performance, and he was only one point away now. He had waited several days, so he had no choice but to take him back to complete his task and become a regular employee.

The man was stunned. Zhou Ze's frank admission that it was for profit left him speechless, because he knew that no matter how much he argued or debated, it wouldn't soften the other party's heart.

"Let me go home and see my three children again," the man pleaded.

"This time, I promise I won't leave or run away."

"You are not qualified to bargain with me, and I am not making a show."

"My family... there's also... a ghost!"

"Alright then, it's only right to let you go home and see them before you leave. There's human kindness beyond the law, right?"

The old Taoist priest, who had just finished throwing up, suddenly felt like throwing up again when he heard this.

But he held back.

He didn't dare.

The woman woke up, but she was a little groggy. The old Taoist priest helped her back. Being possessed by a ghost, even if it was her own husband, caused considerable damage to both body and spirit.

Following the male ghost's guidance, Zhou Ze started walking towards his home.

The old Taoist priest was an active person. Although he had joked about the size of her buns earlier, he wasn't so low as to take advantage of the situation now. The woman was already pitiful enough, and he couldn't do such beastly things. So, he simply started chatting with the male ghost:

"Brother, where are you from? Your wife's accent doesn't sound local."

Tongcheng dialect is very distinctive; its recognition rate is too high because it's fundamentally on a different channel from Mandarin. However, some local dialects are sometimes so similar to Mandarin that locals unconsciously infuse their Mandarin with a dialectal flavor.

"Sichuan," the man replied.

At this point, he had somewhat come to terms with it and felt a little relieved. The key was Zhou Ze's attitude, which was truly too different from the compassionate Taoist priests and monks he used to see on television.

"Then how did you die?" the old Taoist priest asked again.

"Died comfortably."

"How did you die comfortably?" the old Taoist priest pressed.

"Drug overdose."

"Uh..." The old Taoist priest immediately became interested, asking like a curious child, "What does it feel like to take that stuff? Is it really amazing?"

Zhou Ze glanced at the old Taoist priest, who stuck out his tongue and dared not say another word.

"Heh, of course, it's very comfortable, so comfortable it makes you feel like you're in heaven and hell," the male ghost replied.

"So comfortable that you turned into a ghost, and your family fortune was squandered?" Zhou Ze began to add insult to injury.

As a doctor in his previous life, Zhou Ze was well aware of how terrifyingly harmful that stuff was to the human body. Ordinary people only knew that taking it was addictive and would squander money, but in reality, many of its damages to the body were irreversible.

"Exactly, exactly! Look at you, living such a dog's life! Your wife is working so hard to raise the children, while you died comfortably."

The old Taoist priest immediately grasped Zhou Ze's conversational intent and began to echo him.

"Heh," the man snorted. "The stuff rich people here take is nothing. God knows how much miscellaneous junk is mixed in. Almost our entire village does this. Buying it from us is purer and cheaper.

Also, I made money from this. I wanted to earn money for my family. Carrying one trip back could earn 100,000 yuan, equivalent to ten years of hard labor in the fields. With the money I earned, I even opened factories, workshops, and bought large trucks for transportation."

"Brag all you want. If you earned so much money, why are your wife and children so miserable now?" The old Taoist priest didn't believe him.

The male ghost seemed to be stubborn with the old Taoist priest and directly said, "Heh, if I'm lying, I'm a bastard. I was once wealthy, much wealthier than you can imagine."

"After earning your first pot of gold, did you continue to transport it?" Zhou Ze asked.

"Of course, why wouldn't I? Can opening a factory, workshop, or running a transport business make money as fast as transporting this stuff? It's a hugely profitable business! Who would still open a broken factory that can't even break even in three years? It's really meaningless."

"Tsk, tsk, tsk," the old Taoist priest clicked his tongue.

In fact, the old Taoist priest had seen many people like this.

This male ghost was probably once a poor farmer who took risks transporting that stuff to earn his first sum of money, then turned his life around, and things got better. But this taste of "eating the marrow and knowing the flavor" is truly hard to give up. If you tell him to run a factory and live a stable life, he can't, because his values and financial outlook have completely collapsed.

This is similar to many prostitutes or gamblers. For a prostitute, she can easily earn tens of thousands a month. For a gambler, a single bet can be several thousands or tens of thousands. After their financial outlook is impacted by this, asking them to reform and work diligently in a factory for three or four thousand a month feels meaningless to them.

Then,

People are ruined.

It's hard to start over and live a good life.

Why do so many people who are determined to quit and reform relapse soon after?

Because they simply can't live the pace of a normal, ordinary person's life.

"Then, since you say the whole village there does this, you should know that smoking that stuff is harmful to your health, right? Why did you still smoke it?" The old Taoist priest asked with some confusion.

"If everyone in the village smokes, you'll feel like it's nothing. The environment is different," the man said wistfully. "It's like if your father, your uncle, your brother, and your colleagues all smoke, even if 'smoking is harmful to health' is printed on cigarette packs, you'd still think it's no big deal.

After all, everyone is smoking."

The old Taoist priest nodded thoughtfully.

Immediately, the old Taoist priest asked again, "Then where's your money? Did you use it all up before you died?"

"I left a lot of money," the man said. "I didn't let my family down, I didn't let my wife and children down."

"Heh," the old Taoist priest chuckled.

This family lived in a garage apartment in a residential complex. The ground floor was originally someone's garage, but it had been converted into a one-bedroom rental.

The woman was helped into the house. Inside were three children, all staring with wide eyes at Zhou Ze, the old Taoist priest, and their mother.

Two boys and one girl, all probably elementary school age, with one still wearing a red scarf around his neck.

The children's clothes were a bit worn, but their faces were clean, and they seemed to be in good spirits. Although their living conditions weren't great, their mother must have taken good care of them.

But no matter how you looked at it, this family didn't seem to have a large sum of money left by the man after his death, as he claimed.

"Hey, didn't you earn a lot of money? Why did your wife and children come to Tongcheng and live here?" the old Taoist priest asked.

"She wanted to bring the children here; she didn't want to stay in the original village," the man replied.

At this moment, Zhou Ze spoke, "And the other ghost? Where is it?"

Boss Zhou always preferred more performance, and he really wasn't interested in relationship columns or charity.

The male ghost's gaze went to a curtain in the corner.

Zhou Ze walked over,

Pulled back the curtain,

Behind the curtain was a small plastic bathtub. Crouching inside was a very young-looking man, trembling. On his chest was a strikingly bright, crimson mark.

"He's my son. After I died, he also got hooked using the money I left at home. Then the money ran out, and he followed my old path, dealing to support his addiction.

He was unlucky and got caught.

The quantity was too large,

Sent to Rongcheng,

Executed."

title: 第一百四十八章 生死簿！
content:
"So, do you think this is a kind of retribution?"

Zhou Ze looked at the man. Honestly, he felt no sympathy for this man, nor for his son who had become a ghost but, like his father, still remained in the living world.

Man proposes, God disposes. Cause and effect, retribution never fails.

"Retribution for what? I don't believe this is retribution. I trafficked the drugs myself, took the risks myself, earned the money myself. What retribution is there?"

"How many people, because of the drugs you brought in, ended up with broken homes, wives separated from husbands, children from parents? They certainly were culpable and went astray, but you, too, are inextricably linked to a primal sin."

Zhou Ze raised his hand, and the Gates of Hell opened.

Honestly, there was nothing more to say to this kind of person—oh, no, to this kind of ghost. He was too lazy to say anything further.

The son's ghost was forcibly seized by Zhou Ze. He tried to struggle, but couldn't escape Zhou Ze's control and was directly sent into the Gates of Hell.

Zhou Ze didn't rush to check his credentials book. Instead, he casually grabbed the husband's ghost as well. The husband's ghost seemed to accept his fate; he didn't struggle, just looked at Zhou Ze coldly, with a hint of mockery.

"There are plenty of bad people in this world. Good deeds go unrewarded, while villains thrive for millennia.
How many truly face retribution?"

Zhou Ze didn't retort. He grabbed him and also sent him into the Gates of Hell.

Everything settled.

Zhou Ze opened his credentials book. The word "(Temporary)" next to his position had disappeared, replaced by "Ghost Catcher."

He had been promoted.
He was finally no longer a precarious temporary worker.

At this moment, Zhou Ze felt a simple joy and pride, similar to what people experienced decades ago when they joined the system and secured a so-called "iron rice bowl." He felt as if he had reached the pinnacle of life, becoming a cut above the rest.

Turning to the next page, a verdict appeared:

*Originally a traveler in the human world, coming vaguely and leaving vaguely;*
