title: 第一百六十八章 死侍！
content:
There's a story like this: a highly skilled blacksmith first forged an extremely sturdy cage, then crafted an equally strong iron lock.

He then walked into the cage he had made, carefully feeling its strength, when suddenly, the lock hanging on it fell shut.

He was trapped inside. Because his shop was quite secluded and business wasn't good, by the time he was discovered, he had long since died of thirst or starvation in the cage.

And the Japanese priest before them now was like the blacksmith in the story, meticulously crafting an iron cage and an iron lock, only to end up locking himself in.

The priest, after all, was different from the young man whose head Bai Yingying had twisted off upstairs moments ago to end his suffering. He was more advanced, with a stronger capacity for endurance.

Therefore,

he still retained a part of his sanity.

When that young man called Zhou Ze "Papa," the elation, the overflowing joy, the immense excitement were truly genuine expressions, moving one to tears.

But when this Japanese priest called out "Otou-san," it was with extreme awkwardness, shyness, shame, suppression, and a coy resistance, much like a female protagonist in some melodramatic TV show who has been drugged by a villain.

"Otou-san!"

After calling out, a look of horror flashed in the Japanese priest's eyes. How could things have turned out this way? He had a very ominous premonition, and this premonition told him that events had taken a turn towards an extreme more terrifying than death.

Things had come to this point, a glimmer of hope appeared, at least from Zhou Ze's perspective, it certainly was.

He continued to spread his arms, and facing that "Otou-san," he nodded gently, responding with a soft,

"Yes?"

With a response came interaction, and with interaction, that impulse grew even stronger!

The Japanese priest's eyes were wide, he could no longer control himself.

"Otou-san!"

"Yes?"

"Otou-san!"

"Yes?"

"Otou-san! Otou-san! Otou-san!!………………"

The first time was awkward, purely accompanied by a slight dryness and pang of pain.

The second time was much easier, after all, the first time had laid the groundwork.

After that, everything became second nature. The struggling person gave up struggling, because they were already numb.

Zhou Ze slowly squatted down, patting his hands towards the priest, as if teasing a corgi at home, calling it over for a rub.

The priest staggered towards Zhou Ze, then, in front of Zhou Ze, actually lay down. His face twitched and trembled, his subconscious telling him he absolutely couldn't do this, but that impulsive and intimate urge from the depths of his heart directly shattered his rationality.

"Good boy, no more struggling."

Zhou Ze said softly to him.

The priest slowly closed his eyes.

He had, in a way, resigned himself.

"Pfft..."

However, Zhou Ze showed no subsequent warmth. His sharp fingernails directly pierced the top of the priest's head.

The priest's body began to tremble incessantly, but his face revealed a sense of enjoyment.

"Thunder, rain, and dew are all blessings from the sovereign,"*

This saying was vividly interpreted on his person.

Why Bai Yingying was so respectful to Zhou Ze now was for the same reason. In ordinary human society, one could still shout the slogan "Are kings, marquises, generals, and chancellors born to be so?" But in the genes of other species, the subordinate obeying the superior is an ingrained habit, difficult to change, and difficult to resist.

The little loli walked to Zhou Ze's side, looking at the priest below, who was both enjoying and being tormented. She pursed her lips and then spoke,

"Aren't you considering taking a godson for real? After all, the difference between you and the Grand Eunuch is not that big."

"This son, I cannot afford to take," Zhou Ze replied.

Yes, taking this Japanese priest home, even if not as a son but as a pet, seemed like a good decision. After all, there were already quite a few strange people in his bookstore; one more priest wouldn't hurt.

But Zhou Ze didn't have a hoarding habit, and this priest was too dangerous. Zhou Ze wasn't sure how long this "father-son" relationship could last, and he didn't know when this priest might "wake up" on his own.

Keeping a dog was fine; a dog at least knew loyalty. But keeping a venomous snake was playing too dangerously; he might actually get bitten by it one day.

The priest's body slowly began to turn black. The black aura from Zhou Ze's fingertips was continuously pouring into his body, furiously destroying his flesh.

This torment lasted about twenty seconds. The priest stopped moving; his entire body had turned a dark purplish-blue.

Zhou Ze withdrew his fingernails, but at the same time, he extended his other hand forward, clenching his palm tightly.

"Ah!"

A black soul was clutched by Zhou Ze. It was the priest's face, twisted with struggle and boundless rage.

Because he couldn't imagine that his final outcome would be like this, voluntarily offering himself up in such a shameful manner, extending his neck to the other party, awaiting the execution.

This ending was too stifling, too unbearable. He was truly unwilling, extremely, extremely unwilling.

He still had other methods, other secret techniques. Even if the situation was truly critical, he was not without a chance to escape with his life.

"Yingying," Zhou Ze called out.

"Here, Boss."

"Find some gasoline and burn his body for me."

"Okay, Boss."

Zhou Ze casually took out a small stack of Hell Bank Notes from his pocket and burned them with a lighter.

This would ensure that when he destroyed the body in the residential area, no outsiders would come to see it, and no one would accidentally intrude.

Hell Bank Notes could be exchanged for money, but they could also ward off trouble. This kind of use, where one hadn't done anything wrong but simply wanted to avoid trouble, had always been smooth.

The priest's soul in Zhou Ze's palm continued to struggle, and after a while, he began to beg again.

Even in death, the soul of such a person was somewhat different from that of an ordinary person.

Zhou Ze ignored him, keeping him there.

Bai Yingying found gasoline, placed it on the ground, and then silently walked out again.

A moment later, Bai Yingying returned, carrying a barbecue grill. She set the grill down next to them.

Zhou Ze was stunned.

The little loli was also stunned.

Zhou Ze pointed to the barbecue grill and asked,

"What is the meaning of this?"

Bai Yingying looked a bit bewildered, then looked up and asked Zhou Ze, "Boss, aren't we barbecuing him?"

"You like to eat this?" Zhou Ze pointed at the Japanese priest's body.

Bai Yingying shook her head, "Boss, didn't you say you wanted to mix his ashes with rice?"

Saying this, Bai Yingying even pulled out a bag from beside her.

"I even specially bought rice."

"…………" Zhou Ze.

The little loli beside them laughed like a pig.

Zhou Ze really wanted to caress Bai Yingying's head and gently ask her if she was doing it on purpose.

But he decided against it, because Bai Yingying was truly the type of person who might take his "exaggerated metaphors" made in anger seriously.

At least, you couldn't blame her for this.

"I didn't finish the second half of my sentence," Zhou Ze said.

"Huh?" Bai Yingying.

"I want to mix his ashes with rice and feed it to my Yingying for supper."

Bai Yingying's expression instantly became a sight to behold.

"Just burn him first, then find a public restroom and toss the ashes," Zhou Ze said, no longer teasing the female zombie.

One couldn't blame Zhou Ze for being so particular about ashes, because most people couldn't experience the situation of having their ashes stolen and then seeking revenge on the thief.

So, special circumstances call for special measures. Since you stole my ashes, I'll retaliate with yours, an eye for an eye.

Bai Yingying began pouring gasoline on the priest's body. The priest's soul was frantically jumping up and down, but Zhou Ze just made him watch.

"Boss, I'm lighting the fire."

Zhou Ze nodded.

Bai Yingying lit the fire, and the priest's body began to burn. For a moment, the smell of roasting meat filled the air.

A sense of despair emanated from the priest's soul.

However, as it burned, Zhou Ze suddenly noticed something amiss and took a step forward.

Bai Yingying also let out a startled sound, because she saw the body in the fire slowly sitting up.

"Boss, do bodies do that when they're burned?" Bai Yingying asked Zhou Ze.

Why ask Zhou Ze?

Because Zhou Ze had experience.

In fact, theoretically, a corpse suddenly twitching or sitting up during cremation could also be explained scientifically.

Zhou Ze didn't have time to explain,

because soon, no scientific explanation would be needed.

The body didn't just sit up,

it actually stood up.

Here, take the pen,

how do you explain this?

From the flames, the corpse walked out. It still had embers on it and was still burning. Its clothes had long since disintegrated, and its skin was already a gruesome sight.

But it still walked out. Its eyes had been closed, and even though its entire face was a bloody, pitted mess, when it stepped out of the firelight, it slowly opened its eyes.

In its eye sockets,

there was an empty void,

but soon, two green halos of light appeared, radiating a peculiar glow.

For some reason, when this fellow walked out, Zhou Ze felt a telepathic connection with him, as if this fellow was another self, completely pure, without any impurities.

"Ugh..."

It opened its mouth,

but no words came out.

The priest's soul, clenched in Zhou Ze's palm, was incredibly excited at this moment. He had succeeded, his research had actually succeeded in this unforeseen way!

However,

Zhou Ze lifted him up,

and then,

let go.

The priest was stunned,

he was just set free like that?

"Ugh..."

But in the next instant,

the corpse suddenly moved. It opened its mouth, revealing black fangs, and bit directly into the priest's soul, then tore at it frantically.

The priest didn't even have time to scream before his soul was torn to shreds by his own corpse in an extremely brutal manner!

After doing all this,

the corpse raised its head again, looking at Zhou Ze.

The two of them stared at each other;

then,

the corpse silently bent down,

on one knee,

and knelt.

---
*雷霆雨露皆是君恩 (léi tíng yǔ lù jiē shì jūn ēn): An idiom meaning "All things, be they thunder or rain, are blessings from the sovereign." It implies that a subordinate should accept whatever the superior bestows, whether it be punishment or favor, as a form of grace or benevolence.

title: 第一百六十九章 色字頭上一把刀
content:
“What the hell is that?”

The old Taoist priest watched an adult draped in black gauze emerge from the car, wondering if the boss and the others had gone out for revenge. Not only did they not lose any members, but they came back with an extra person?

And this person was so strange, completely covered from head to toe, not even their eyes showing.

Couldn't even tell if it was a man or a woman.

So mysterious,
A person in black?
Hmm?
No,
And they smelled good,
Like Brazilian BBQ.

The old Taoist priest put his nose close to the person and sniffed. So fragrant, very aromatic. He then turned to Zhou Ze and asked:

“Boss, did you go for BBQ?”

“Ugh…”

The little loli beside them couldn't bear it, especially when the old Taoist priest blissfully sniffed that thing. It was truly disgusting.

She was very glad she hadn't brought her physical body today, otherwise she would have puked.

“Brought them back to help with housework. If you need anything done, you can ask them,” Zhou Ze said.

“Huh?”

The old Taoist priest was startled.
Darn it!
He had previously mocked Bai Yingying for constantly trying to compete with the little loli for affection, and now his own status was being infringed upon?

Even this job of cleaning, living by the whims of ghosts, earning no salary, and having to offer sacrifices to ghosts from time to time—someone was trying to take it from him?

Is there no justice left in this world!
Job competition is too brutal nowadays!

“Go give them a bath. Be gentle,” Zhou Ze said.

“A bath?”

The old Taoist priest paused, then asked:

“Is it a woman?”

“Yes, it's a woman, so you need to be gentle. They have severe autism.”

Hearing this, the old Taoist priest
Hehe,
Subconsciously rubbed his calloused hands.

“Is this, appropriate?”

“I trust your character.”

Zhou Ze patted the old Taoist priest on the shoulder,
Indicating, *I have high hopes for you*.

Then, Zhou Ze said to the masked person: “Follow him. Do whatever he tells you to do.”

The masked person walked over to the old Taoist priest, very obedient.

The old Taoist priest was a bit shy, but still led them to the bathroom.

Zhou Ze and the others also entered the bookstore. Bai Yingying poured Zhou Ze a cup of coffee. Zhou Ze took a sip, then said:

“Go lock the bathroom door.”

“Alrighty.”

Bai Yingying quickly went and locked the door.

A moment later,
Horrified screams came from the bathroom, followed by the old Taoist priest continuously banging on the bathroom door, looking utterly miserable.

“Boss, let me out! Let me out!”

“Clean them up first,” Zhou Ze said.

“…” Old Taoist priest.

About half an hour later, the old Taoist priest emerged, his face a mix of green and white. He didn't eat dinner and sat alone at the bar, contemplating life.

The visual impact had indeed been too strong, almost causing the old Taoist priest to collapse internally.

The little loli went back; she had been out of her spiritual body for too long and needed to return to slumber.

At dinner, Xu Qinglang still hadn't returned, likely still feeling melancholic. Zhou Ze had to order takeout again.

Following Zhou Ze's instructions, Bai Yingying went out and bought a few sets of clothes, the kind that cover the entire body. These were hard to find, so Bai Yingying could only buy a few Spider-Man and Iron Man outfits. After dressing the person in them, they looked much more normal.

This way, they could move around the bookstore and do things normally in the future, without worrying about scaring anyone.

After dinner, Zhou Ze looked at the old Taoist priest, who was still sitting there absentmindedly, feeling a bit sorry for him.

In his heart, there was also some guilt.
Right then,
Zhou Ze walked over and stood in front of the old Taoist priest.

The old Taoist priest looked at Zhou Ze blankly,
*I'm so wronged,*
*I want to cry.*

“Boss…”

“It's okay. Try to look on the bright side.”
Zhou Ze comforted him.

“Boss, next time, can you give me some psychological preparation beforehand?”

It wasn't that the old Taoist priest was too naive. It was because those around ghosts were all strange people, and it wasn't impossible for a shy girl to ask him to help her bathe and chat about life.

But when he, with anticipation and excitement, helped that person undress,
What was revealed was a large area of burnt skin, with pus oozing from all over…

Imagination was full,
Reality was skeletal.
This huge discrepancy was enough to make the old Taoist priest break down. He even felt that he might contract the same problem as the boss because of this incident.

This was the boss's revenge, definitely revenge. It was his fault for constantly talking about his "prostitute-protecting" deeds in front of the boss.

It was like talking about how spoiled and disobedient one's son was in front of a eunuch—asking for death.

“Don't worry, it won't happen again next time.”

“Mm, thank you, boss.” The old Taoist priest took a deep breath and asked: “Boss, what is this thing?”

That fellow, he wasn't even considered human anymore.

“It's that Japanese priest,” Zhou Ze replied.

“What?” The old Taoist priest was startled.

“You can ask Bai Yingying about the specific process. Anyway, he's quite safe now, completely under my control. You can really have him help with cleaning and stuff in the future.”

“Alrighty.” Hearing this, the old Taoist priest finally felt a little better.

“You're getting old. It's not suitable for you to do too much of this kind of work in the future. You should also pay more attention to your health.”

“Don't worry, boss, this humble Taoist priest is in great health. I can go for half an hour at a time, making them feel like earning my money is truly difficult and a torment.”

“Oh.”

Just then, Xu Qinglang walked in from outside. He went to the bar, poured a glass of red wine, and drank it in one go.

Clearly, he was quite dejected.

Zhou Ze patted the old Taoist priest on the shoulder again, saying: “Don't worry, next time I ask you to do something, I'll definitely let you know beforehand.”

“Thank you, boss.”

“He'll be sharing a room with you and sleeping with you from now on. This is advance notice.”

“…” Old Taoist priest.

Zhou Ze walked up to Xu Qinglang and said, “What's wrong? Still dispirited?”

“I'm fine. It's not like I can't get over it.” Xu Qinglang licked his lips with his tongue, then poured another glass of red wine and continued drinking.

Zhou Ze didn't know how to comfort him; he'd probably get over it himself in a while.

“Old Zhou, do you think there are really gods in this world?” Xu Qinglang asked.

“Probably, given that I'm a ghost messenger.”
If there's one, there can be two; if there are two, there can be three; if there are three, there can be all things.

Xu Qinglang nodded. “So, there's also a sea god?”

“If you think so, then there should be.”

“That sea god is a real piece of work.”

“Maybe he's not even a human. Could be a giant sea turtle that became a spirit, who knows.”

At the bookstore entrance, a group of students walked in. The leader was a girl, about seventeen or eighteen, likely a high school student.

“Boss, there are so many of us, can we get a discount?”

“What discount? I'll pay for everyone,” a chubby male student said.

Subsequently, these students sat together and began copying each other's homework.

Everyone copied very seriously and solemnly, as if they were truly doing it themselves.

“It feels like going back to the old days,” Xu Qinglang said, pointing at the students with one hand holding his wine glass.

“I never copied; others copied me,” Zhou Ze chuckled.

“I know, you're a top student, a scholar,” Xu Qinglang poured Zhou Ze a glass of wine too.

“A milk tea for everyone,” the chubby boy called out, gesturing.

“Alright.”

Xu Qinglang nodded and went to the back kitchen to start making milk tea.

A while later, the chubby boy himself came over and asked, “Is the milk tea ready?”

“I'll bring them out when they're done,” Bai Yingying said.

“Forget it, I'll wait. I'm already done copying anyway.”

The chubby boy played on his phone beside them, then pulled out a cigarette and lit it with his back to his distant classmates.

Soon, Xu Qinglang had all the milk teas ready and sealed.

The chubby boy took one cup of milk tea and inserted a straw, then took a few more cups and walked over to his classmates.

Bai Yingying then took the remaining milk teas on a tray and delivered them.

A moment later, Zhou Ze actively got up and walked over to the students, looking left and right, which made the students who were copying their homework feel very unnatural, as copying homework was not something glorious.

However, Zhou Ze also noticed an exception: a girl who was dressed slightly more simply but looked very delicate was not copying; she was doing her own work.

Then she would share the completed parts with the surrounding classmates for them to copy.

This was a very natural thing; among a group of academic underachievers, there had to be one academic overachiever to be the pillar.

“The ice is melting, drink it quickly,” the chubby boy said to the top student girl, while pushing the milk tea closer to her.

The girl shook her head, indicating she wasn't thirsty, and at the same time said, “Next time, don't come here. It's too expensive.”

“It's not expensive, not expensive. I have plenty of pocket money,” the chubby boy boasted. “Drink some, this shop's milk tea tastes really good, very carefully made. I came here last time, and it's also sold very expensively.”

Hearing this, Zhou Ze suddenly wanted to tell this chubby classmate that the milk tea and drinks sold in their bookstore were all instant powdered “Xiang Piao Piao” mixed by Xu Qinglang in the back kitchen. Old Xu had become lazier and lazier ever since he realized he needed to start taking care of himself.

The girl hesitated, put down her pen, and reached for the milk tea.

But just as Zhou Ze walked past, his arm bumped it, and the milk tea fell to the ground, spilling some.

“Oh, I'm sorry. I'll get you another one.”

Zhou Ze bent down and picked up the milk tea from the floor.

The chubby boy looked up, glaring at Zhou Ze, “What are you doing, just wandering around here for what!”

“Alright, don't be angry, it's just a cup of milk tea,” a classmate beside him advised.

Zhou Ze ignored the chubby classmate and walked back to the counter with the milk tea, saying to Xu Qinglang:

“Brew another packet.”

Xu Qinglang nodded.

Zhou Ze walked out and stood at the bookstore entrance, smoking.

At this moment, Bai Yingying happened to be sitting behind the bar playing "PUBG Mobile" on her phone. Seeing the milk tea Zhou Ze brought back on the counter, she simply took it and drank it herself. After all, it had only fallen on the ground, no one had drunk it yet, and it wasn't dirty.

She didn't need to eat, but sometimes needed to replenish some water.

Another half hour passed,
Among the group of students, those who finished their homework began to leave one by one.

Finally, only the chubby classmate and the female academic overachiever remained. The chubby classmate said eagerly:

“Shall I call a taxi to take you home?”

“No need, I'll take the bus home.”

The female academic overachiever tidied her backpack and walked out of the bookstore.

The chubby classmate sighed, stood up, and went to the counter to pay the bill first.

“Nine hundred in total,” Xu Qinglang calculated by headcount, with a minimum consumption of one hundred.

“Alipay.”

“Okay.”

The chubby classmate paid the bill and turned to leave when he saw Zhou Ze walking in from outside.

He snorted through his nose; the chubby classmate was clearly very displeased with Zhou Ze.

Zhou Ze smiled at him,
Then, as the chubby classmate walked past Zhou Ze,

“Slap!”

A crisp sound,
Zhou Ze slapped the chubby classmate directly across the face.

A human figure was slapped out of him. The chubby classmate spun in a circle, feeling dizzy, seemingly unaware that he had just been slapped.

He looked at Zhou Ze in a daze and said, “What happened to me?”

“You walked into the door. Go home quickly.”

“Okay, thank you, boss.”

The chubby classmate nodded and smiled at Zhou Ze, then walked out of the bookstore.

Inside the bookstore,
A short man was left behind,
The man knelt there, trembling.

“Nice haircut,” Xu Qinglang said, leaning on the bar.

Yes, this short man's haircut was indeed unique,
Others' Mohawks were already unconventional enough,
His was even more exaggerated,
On his head,
A knife was stuck.

Hold tight to the Dragon!

title: 第一百七十章 嚶嚶嚶！
content:
As the saying goes, "Lust is a knife to the head." The true nature of this guy, this ghost, was actually already obvious.

In fact, both in ancient and modern times, people have often held a great deal of tolerance for the term "licentiousness."

In ancient times, a scholar's licentiousness, his lingering in the pleasure quarters, was considered a very elegant thing. Even in modern times, when a "player" brags about his conquests, you might not agree with his lifestyle, but you wouldn't necessarily feel he's committed a heinous crime.

All of this, after all, is built on the foundation of mutual consent.

It could be "sweet talk," "lonely companionship," or "a clean transaction of money and goods." People are quite open-minded in this regard.

But the kind of pervert who likes to use force and despicable means often suffers society's contempt and scorn. It's said that in prison, the lowest status is typically held by sex offenders.

The man knelt there, kowtowing repeatedly to Zhou Ze, hoping Zhou Ze would spare his life.

The bookstore was actually Zhou Ze's execution ground, especially after Zhou Ze became a full-fledged official. This place was considered a special location. Various ghosts from outside would instinctively want to approach the bookstore, either stumbling in directly through the door, or attaching themselves elsewhere or connecting with the bookstore in other ways.

Boss Zhou was fishing; whoever wished to take the bait was welcome.

Actually, at first, Zhou Ze hadn't noticed that there was a ghost lurking on the chubby student. Yes, Xu Qinglang hadn't noticed either.

Zhou Ze only noticed that the chubby student was secretly putting something into a cup of milk tea. As for what kind of medicine it was, everyone knew well enough; it certainly wasn't cold medicine.

Based on the principle that this was his own store, and according to legal regulations, he had to protect the personal safety of customers who consumed goods in his store, so Boss Zhou had no choice but to intervene.

"Hey, you saw it early, didn't you?" Xu Qinglang said to Zhou Ze.

"Ah, mm."

Zhou Ze nodded silently.

There was no need to explain this matter. If the people around you think you're awesome and amazing, let this beautiful misunderstanding continue.

"Heh heh, the way you walked up and slapped that guy, directly slapping a ghost out of him, honestly, it looked quite unexpected, a bit like the style of a Celestial Master from Longhu Mountain."

Old Xu was still hyping him up, and Zhou Ze continued to be silent, accepting these praises.

He actually wanted to say that he had only intended to give that fellow a slap to teach him a lesson, purely because he found him annoying and wanted to hit him. At most, he'd beat him up later and burn some joss paper. But he unexpectedly discovered that the lecherous ghost attached to the chubby student had actually been slapped out by him.

In fact, Zhou Ze had also wondered why he and Xu Qinglang hadn't seen this lecherous ghost before. The reason, he thought, could only be one: everyone has lust in their hearts.

Everyone has that impulse, that restlessness, that desire. This desire is similar to the pursuit of money and power; it's an expression of human nature. And because of this, the lecherous ghost could rely on that cover to hide itself.

Whether the ghost existed or not, that chubby student actually had lust, so that was its best camouflage.

Zhou Ze opened the Gate of Hell, grabbed the short, lecherous ghost on the floor with one hand, and prepared to send it to hell.

"Spare me, spare me, spare me..."

The lecherous ghost was still begging,

But all it did was beg for mercy; it offered no other useful words, such as "spare me and I can give you something," or "spare me and I can tell you some important news."

Hmm,

In this situation, Boss Zhou was still fiercely righteous and utterly impartial.

Finally, the lecherous ghost was thrown into the Gate of Hell.

Tonight's revenue could be considered an addition.

"Do you think every lecherous ghost has a knife above its head?" Xu Qinglang asked.

"Do you remember that high-hatted teacher we met before?" Zhou Ze retorted.

"Mm, but that one was wronged; this one probably doesn't count."

That high-hatted teacher was clearly wronged, but under the power of public opinion, even Zhou Ze's fingernails couldn't remove the high hat on his head.

Perhaps, Hell seems to have this tradition, or perhaps it's because Hell is simply too large, and the officials in the Underworld are rather lazy and inefficient in governing, so they prefer a "one-size-fits-all" approach. Most of them carry on the "verdicts" of the mortal world.

Those who wear hats wear hats, those who are tattooed are tattooed. Whatever conclusion is reached in the mortal world, the Underworld inherits that conclusion, greatly reducing the workload of the Underworld. As for whether anyone is wronged within it, sorry, no one cares.

With a deal done for the day, Boss Zhou wasn't inclined to stay up until dawn. He went to the bathroom, took a shower first, and then went upstairs in his bathrobe.

Watching Zhou Ze climb the stairs, Xu Qinglang took another sip of red wine and looked at the problematic milk tea cup that Zhou Ze had brought over earlier. The milk tea was already gone.

Xu Qinglang stretched. Of course, Xu Qinglang knew who had drunk it, and the person who drank it seemed to have sensed something was amiss and had secretly gone upstairs earlier.

Heh heh.

Old Xu's gaze wandered, awaiting a good show.

Pushing open the bedroom door, Zhou Ze sensed a slight chill.

He wasn't afraid of the cold, but the strikingly different temperature in the bedroom compared to outside still caught Zhou Ze's attention.

He looked up at the air conditioner; it wasn't on. So why was it so cold?

On the bed, Bai Yingying lay there, covered by a quilt, still wriggling continuously.

Zhou Ze was slightly displeased. He had told her countless times not to get on the bed before showering. It was a disrespect to the bed. Of course, most importantly, Boss Zhou had a phobia of germs.

No matter how beautiful or pretty you were, if you dared to get on his bed without showering, sorry, he would kick you off.

"Cough cough..."

He coughed by the bed.

In the past, Bai Yingying would probably have been scared and immediately gotten up to admit her mistake, promising never to do it again.

But this time, Bai Yingying still lay on the bed, not moving.

No, she moved a little.

But it was only to use her legs to flip over, clasping the quilt between her thighs. Soft "Ying Ying Ying" sounds emanated from within the quilt.

Ying Ying Ying... Ying Ying Ying...

Sometimes soaring, sometimes melodious, sometimes passionate, sometimes deep.

He lifted the quilt.

Bai Yingying turned on her side and looked at Zhou Ze. Her eyes were seductive, her hair disheveled, her face flushed, her lips red and teeth like pearls. She truly evoked pity.

Making one want to gallop directly, until one's horse-hide wrapped corpse returned to battle.

"Did you wet the bed?"

Zhou Ze asked.

The atmosphere killer,

The innocent destroyer,

The man who should be sent to the stake — Ze,

Was once again illustrating the reason why he was still a bachelor at thirty in his previous life.

Bai Yingying bit her finger, slowly curled up her body, and then she sat up, placing her hands on Zhou Ze's shoulders, cooing seductively:

"Boss... I want... Ying Ying Ying..."

Zhou Ze smiled,

His smile was a bit helpless.

He first looked down at the quilt he had just lifted and thrown onto the floor, which was now stiff enough to be used as a chopping board.

Then he looked at Bai Yingying's thighs.

You want,

But I wouldn't dare give.

This is a normal human body. If I really gave it to you, tomorrow I'd have to go to the hospital to find Doctor Lin for an amputation due to frostbite.

"That milk tea, you drank it?"

Zhou Ze suddenly remembered something and asked.

"Milk tea... What milk tea... Ying Ying Ying... I want it, Boss... Ying Ying Ying..."

Saying that,

Bai Yingying leaped up,

Her physical prowess was not something an unpowered Zhou Ze could resist. Zhou Ze was directly tackled to the floor by her.

A dull thud sounded from the floor.

Downstairs, Xu Qinglang looked up, a little dejected and melancholic. He poured another glass of red wine.

The old Daoist, who was playing cards with the monkey, also looked up, somewhat puzzled, at the ceiling above.

"Boss, I really like the smell on you, I really do, Ying Ying Ying..."

Bai Yingying transformed into an overbearing female CEO, pinning Zhou Ze down, undressing him while flirting.

Zhou Ze's face showed a hint of helplessness.

"Yingying, back off."

"Boss, just give it to me..."

"... ..." Zhou Ze.

This wasn't a matter of giving or not giving,

Nor was it a matter of *getting hard* or not *getting hard*,

Do you not have any idea whether what you have down there is a water curtain cave or an ice cave?

At that moment, Zhou Ze hardened his heart, and he had no choice but to harden his heart. His right fingernails grew out. He didn't dare to pierce Bai Yingying, but merely stroked her back with his fingernails.

"Ahhhhhhh!!!!"

Black mist began to enter Bai Yingying's body. Bai Yingying was so stimulated that she fell to the ground and began to roll around. Zhou Ze did not stop, continuing with his fingernails.

Bai Yingying twisted and turned, screaming incessantly.

She feared the boss's fingernails the most.

...

Downstairs,

Xu Qinglang, who was drinking red wine, spewed it out with a "pfft," looked up, somewhat surprised. That fierce?

The old Daoist was so scared that the playing cards in his hand dropped to the floor. He looked up again at the ceiling.

Holy crap,

Is the boss unleashing his power?

Old Xu and the old Daoist were both deeply wounded at that moment.

It was the profound and bitter hurt of being outdone in an aspect where a man must never concede.

...

After a long while, Zhou Ze retracted his fingernails.

Bai Yingying, lying on the ground almost collapsed, her eyes finally regained clarity. As if she had vented completely, she looked at Zhou Ze blankly:

"Boss, what just happened?"

"You said your back was a little itchy, so I helped you scratch it."

"Oh, thank you, Boss."

"Go take a shower," Zhou Ze said.

"Okay, Boss."

Bai Yingying leaned on the wall and slowly walked downstairs, wobbling and struggling with each step.

She saw Xu Qinglang and the old Daoist looking at her with sympathetic gazes.

From then on, for a long time, neither Xu Qinglang nor the old Daoist ever brought up the subject of *getting hard* in front of Zhou Ze again.

According to the old Daoist,

He couldn't boast anymore, he really couldn't. He sought out unfortunate, pitiful women, but the boss had KO'd a zombie.

How could they even compare?

title: 第一百七十一章 一屋子鹹魚的書店
content:
The next morning, Zhou Ze was, as usual, sitting on the sofa by the bookstore's glass window, reading the *Yangtze Evening Post*.

In front of him sat a cup of coffee and a small slice of cake.

Boss Zhou's life was just that leisurely, that unproductive, that lacking in ambition. He was just drifting along, taking things as they came.

Initially, Xu Qinglang had criticized Zhou Ze for living such a purposeless life, saying he was too much of a slacker, that he was practically wasting his second chance at life.

Most importantly, he was wasting his "golden finger."

And then...

And then Xu Qinglang couldn't change Boss Zhou's continued idleness. Instead, he himself was assimilated by Boss Zhou.

Originally, a second-generation rich kid who, despite owning over twenty apartments, still ran his own noodle shop and hadn't lost his life's ambition,

was slowly bent by Boss Zhou,

and also became a slacker who started taking care of his skin and grooming himself.

Actually, Zhou Ze felt his current life was quite good. The bookstore had many novels, including quite a few transmigration stories where the protagonists, after being reborn, were all full of bitter resentment, or aiming for imperial power, or conquering the world.

Old Dao, with nothing to do, would flip through these books and always say that the boss was different from the people in the books.

But Old Dao himself could also understand. Books, after all, were fake, and if the protagonists in the books were really like their boss, just sunbathing and loafing around every day,

who would read them?

Would readers come just to watch you sunbathe, sunbathe, sunbathe again, and keep sunbathing?

The priest in the Spider-Man costume was diligently cleaning, missing no detail. He always executed Zhou Ze's instructions without any discount.

Bai Yingying was somewhat relieved, thankful that this "colleague" was a man, otherwise she'd have to face competition again.

After his initial bewilderment, Old Dao had gotten used to the priest's presence. Though at first, when they slept in the same room at night, he'd always smell roasted meat, he had slowly grown accustomed to it.

Now, Old Dao could finally take a break, finding a sofa to lie on like his boss, sipping tea, reading some 'yellow books,' and leisurely enjoying life.

Daytime business had always been very slow.

There were hardly any customers.

So,

the bookstore owner was sunbathing and reading the newspaper,

Old Dao was drinking tea and reading 'yellow books,'

Xu Qinglang was mixing his new cocktail,

Bai Yingying was playing *Honor of Kings* on her phone,

the little monkey, having stolen and eaten Old Dao's peanuts, was now lying there asleep.

The whole house,

exuded an air of idleness,

completely out of sync with the bustling atmosphere of the Nanda Street commercial district outside.

It wasn't until noon that a customer finally walked in.

Xu Qinglang looked up and saw a young man enter. The man was quite tall and seemed delicate, but his face was covered in stubble, indicating he'd been neglecting himself lately due to some recent troubles.

Being disturbed annoyed Xu Qinglang greatly. He glanced back at the "Minimum consumption 100" sign and wondered if his place wasn't 'black' enough.

Should he change it to "one thousand" next time?

Otherwise, there'd always be people who, thinking they had a bit of money, would come in and disrupt him, wanting to experience a "petite bourgeoisie" atmosphere.

This place was clearly for ghost business, so why were living people always crowding in for fun?

One hundred yuan just to sit here, read a book, and drink some instant coffee or milk tea,

wasn't that stupid?

The man pointed at the cocktail glass in front of Xu Qinglang and said,

"A cocktail."

Then, the man sat down in front of Xu Qinglang.

Xu Qinglang nodded. Although he felt very uncomfortable being disturbed, he was, after all, from the catering industry, and wouldn't really take it out on a customer.

Immediately, a cocktail was quickly mixed and placed before the man.

The man took a sip, seemingly satisfied. Then he leaned on the bar, resting his head, and just watched Xu Qinglang.

At first, Xu Qinglang didn't think much of it, but the other party just stayed there, taking a sip of his drink, then continuing to watch him, taking another sip, continuing to watch him.

Xu Qinglang felt like he was being treated as a snack to go with the drink.

"Feast for the eyes" was mostly a compliment when applied to women, but Old Xu always thought of himself as a man.

Oh no,

he *was* a man, not "thought of himself as."

This made Old Xu uncomfortable, and he said with some displeasure, "Do you want more drinks?"

"You're really handsome."

The man suddenly chuckled.

He had a lecherous look on his face.

Xu Qinglang let out a long breath and licked his lips. He was about to hit someone.

"Hey, you're so pretty, a lot of men must like you, huh?"

The other party asked again.

Xu Qinglang rolled up his sleeves, ready to fight.

"There must be, hehe. Do you want to hit me? Do you think I insulted you?"

The man looked up at Xu Qinglang, then pointed at his own face,

"Go ahead and hit me. Hit me right here."

With him being so obnoxious,

Xu Qinglang was actually a little hesitant to hit him, but still said in a low voice,

"My orientation is very normal."

"Oh."

The man responded, sounding a bit disappointed, then picked up his glass and took another sip.

"So, someone's taken a fancy to you?"

Boss Zhou, having finished his sunbathing, walked over at that moment.

The man at this point seemed drunk, or perhaps he was originally just angry, as he immediately smashed the glass in his hand on the floor.

With a crisp "bang,"

the glass shattered into pieces.

The "Spider-Man" who had been cleaning stopped. He walked over, looked at the customer, then at Zhou Ze.

Meaning,

should he kill this person?

Spider-Man was already exuding killing intent.

Zhou Ze waved his hand.

Spider-Man immediately retreated and went back to cleaning elsewhere.

"Sorry, I'll pay for it."

The man took out his wallet.

"Broken up?" Zhou Ze asked.

The man shook his head. "Lost my job."

"Understood." Zhou Ze shrugged.

The man looked at Xu Qinglang, paid first, then said, "Can I get another drink?"

Xu Qinglang nodded, made him another drink, then specifically pointed to the glass and said, "This glass is a work of art, bought for two thousand yuan."

The implication was, if he smashed it again, it would cost two thousand in compensation.

The man froze for a moment, laughed awkwardly, then took a sip.

Zhou Ze sat down next to him and said to the man,

"If you don't mind, you can tell us what's making you unhappy so we can be happy."

"…………" the man.

The man forced a bitter smile and said,

"I used to be the deputy director of logistics at Tongcheng University."

"You're a director so young." Old Dao chimed in at this point, "Your family must have some serious connections, right?"

"…………" the man.

"Don't mind them, keep going." Xu Qinglang urged, "You haven't gotten to the tragic part yet."

"…………" the man.

The man nodded and said, "Because there were stray dogs biting people on campus, I was held accountable and dismissed. My previous job was in charge of campus safety."

"Then you deserve it. You neglected your work." Old Dao analyzed from the side.

"But the thing is, last year I planned to take the security guards and round up all the stray dogs on campus. We did, but then we were stopped."

The man took a deep breath, then exhaled heavily.

"Stopped by the leaders?"

"Stopped by the students." The man replied.

"Uh... why did they stop you?"

"They said what we were doing was too cruel, heartless. Because we had contacted the local stray animal shelter, and they were also under a lot of pressure and couldn't take in so many stray animals. Our plan was to send away those we could, and for those we couldn't place, we would put them down directly."

"Put them down directly? Tsk tsk, how cruel." Old Dao clicked his tongue, "But it's also true, you can't have them posing a danger to students on campus, otherwise things would get serious."

"Later, I remember a student wrote an article online exposing what we were doing, and it was even picked up by the media, with the headline:

*'Can a university that can't even tolerate a stray dog tolerate a person?'*"

"Tsk tsk, that's a good cap to put on it." Old Dao commented.

"At the time, it was because students hung banners and protested, obstructing our actions. In the end, that matter was left unsettled and couldn't proceed."

The man wiped his mouth, then moved his glass aside before he dared to forcefully bang on the table, venting his frustration:

"The worst part is, last week, two female students were attacked by a pack of stray dogs on campus at night. Both were bitten and sent to the hospital!

Then the school investigated, and the responsibility fell on me, and they fired me directly!"

The man banged on the table again forcefully,

"I'm not convinced, really not convinced. Back when I was preparing to have the security guards solve this problem, not only did the students at school curse me, but a large group of people online cursed me too. Because of this, I even received criticism and disciplinary action.

Now the stray dogs have bitten people, and I'm still the one taking responsibility, it's become my dereliction of duty again."

Old Dao heard this, reached out and patted the man's shoulder,

This guy was really unlucky.

"There's nothing we can do about it. After all, protecting small animals is 'politically correct' now."

Xu Qinglang prepared a fruit platter and pushed it in front of the man, as if to comfort him.

The man grumbled and complained for a while longer, then despondently walked out of the bookstore. Whether he continued to drink away his sorrows at a small restaurant or went home to sleep was unknown.

Old Dao turned his head to Xu Qinglang and asked, "Old Xu, what was that 'correct' thing you just said?"

"Politically correct."

"Oh, right, that thing. I really dislike that term now. My live stream was shut down several times because of it, saying I was mocking some group or something, it's ridiculous. I can't even speak properly anymore, if I'm not careful, I've offended someone. Why are those people so sensitive?"

Old Dao streamed live, and though he was old, he was also very trendy.

"Political correctness is necessary," Zhou Ze said, "but now it's becoming more and more distorted, being abused.

When society's emotional protection of certain groups surpasses the pursuit of truth, it means there's a problem."

"Exactly, that's the feeling. Boss, what you said is so insightful and brilliant. No, Old Dao needs to find a pen and paper to write this down, to ponder and understand it thoroughly."

Old Dao knew his job: cleaning was secondary; his primary duty was to shower the boss with "66666" when needed.

"Alright, let's not talk about this anymore. What's for lunch?" Zhou Ze asked Xu Qinglang.

"Stir-fried chives with eggs, stir-fried chives with wood ear mushrooms, stir-fried chives with sliced pork, stir-fried chives with beef penis, chive egg drop soup..."

"Hmm?" Zhou Ze.

"To replenish you. You must have been tired last night," Xu Qinglang said with a look of concern.

"…………" Zhou Ze.

Ah,

After much hesitation,

Zhou Ze glanced over and saw that Bai Yingying was still intently playing *Honor of Kings*,

So he subtly,

nodded.

————————

Requesting monthly votes, to help the bookstore return to the top ten on the overall list.

Dragon rolls for monthly votes,

Rolling over...

...Rolling back...

In short,

Fire your monthly votes at the dragon!

title: 第一百七十二章 鬼來電
content:
For lunch, Zhou Ze didn’t eat much, maintaining an aloof and reserved posture as if he didn't need much nourishment. He ate only a little, washing it down with plum juice.

The old Taoist, however, ate a lot, frantically, with the vigor of a “Lian Po, old yet still able to eat.” More than half of the dishes on the table ended up in the old Taoist’s stomach.

By the afternoon, the old Taoist kept glancing outside the bookstore, seemingly eager to go out and spread some “love.” Anyway, the Spider-Man could handle the cleaning now, making his job much easier.

However, at three o'clock in the afternoon, Zhou Ze's phone rang.

The caller ID showed an unknown number. Zhou Ze answered, and a very hoarse voice came from the other end:

“Help me… help me…”

Zhou Ze tilted his head slightly, holding the phone a little further away from himself. The static on the other end was very heavy, like a string of small firecrackers going off.

“Hello?” Zhou Ze asked again.

“I’m in General’s Mountain, save me… save me…”

*Snap!*

Zhou Ze hung up the phone immediately, tossed it onto the coffee table, and picked up his coffee to take a sip.

Xu Qinglang, next to him, looked up at Zhou Ze and casually asked, “Whose call was that?”

“A prank call, a cry for help.”

“What if it was real?” Xu Qinglang asked with a smile.

“It said General’s Mountain, but that’s too far. Too lazy to go.”

Boss Zhou was a trouble-averse individual. Why run around when he could sit in his bookstore and wait for business to come to him? Zhou Ze didn’t even bother to think about the true reason behind the call, nor did he have time to discern whether it was real or fake. He wasn't God, nor was he a Powerpuff Girl, going wherever he was needed.

“Boss, this humble Taoist wants to go out and buy some daily necessities.” The old Taoist came over to ask for leave.

Zhou Ze was about to nod in assent when his phone rang again. It was still the unknown number. Zhou Ze simply put it on speaker.

“Hello?”

“Save me… save me… I’m in General’s Mountain… they’re going to kill… going to kill… General’s Mountain… General’s Mountain…”

The voice was clearer than before, but there was still a lot of static.

“Save me… save me… I’m in General’s Mountain… they’re going to kill… they’re about to kill… children… women… they are executioners… executioners…”

Xu Qinglang and the old Taoist exchanged glances. If it was a prank, it was possible, but no one usually paid attention to Zhou Ze's private number; only they would contact him. Who would be so bored as to prank him?

So… what if it was real?

But how would you explain why a randomly dialed number would land on Zhou Ze’s phone? Wouldn't they call 110 for help themselves?

Now, neither possibility seemed to make much sense.

Zhou Ze hung up the phone again, rubbing his temples.

“What’s for dinner tonight?” Boss Zhou asked.

Clearly, Boss Zhou’s trouble-averse nature was still working hard, trying to avoid this strange cry for help. Real or fake, he just didn't want to go out, okay?

“Spaghetti, perhaps,” Xu Qinglang said.

“Oh, right, old Taoist, you said you wanted to go out. Go ahead, just remember to come back early.”

“Alrighty.”

The old Taoist left excitedly, strutting out, feeling as vigorous as a young man.

“Yingying, help me buy an unregistered phone card,” Zhou Ze told Bai Yingying.

“Okay, Boss.”

Bai Yingying left the shop and returned shortly. Although China strictly enforces real-name registration for phone cards, unregistered cards could still be bought everywhere; they likely had someone else’s ID registered to them.

After swapping the card, Zhou Ze dialed 110. The operator quickly answered the emergency hotline.

“Hello, this is the Tongcheng Police Service Desk…”

“I want to report something. Someone said there’s a murder case in General’s Mountain. You’d better check it out. I don’t know if it’s true or false. That’s all.”

“Please wait a moment, did you say General’s Mountain?”

“Yes.”

“Could you please provide your contact information and address? We will send someone to get in touch with you.”

Zhou Ze hung up the phone again, then removed that phone card and put his original card back in.

With his own card back, Zhou Ze hesitated. “Something feels off.”

“What feels off?” Xu Qinglang asked.

“I can’t put my finger on it, but it just feels wrong somewhere.”

………………

There were some clubs on South Street, but their prices and class were too high. Although the old Taoist had a decent amount of money in his pocket, he preferred comforting those older, faded women. Of course, no matter how old or faded they were, they were still around his daughter’s age, which was quite beastly. But if they were his granddaughter’s age, that would be worse than a beast!

Taking a taxi to Gangzha, the old Taoist, familiar with the area, found a foot massage parlor. The rolling shutter door was closed, but the old Taoist knew that didn’t mean it was closed for business.

He smoked a cigarette outside for a while, and then the rolling shutter door was pulled open. An old man, younger than the Taoist, emerged from inside and exchanged a smile with him.

The bond of “brothers-in-law.”<sup>1</sup> Ten years of cultivation to share a boat, a hundred years to share a pillow, a thousand years to be a brother-in-law.

The old Taoist bent down and went inside.

Inside, there was a heavily made-up woman, around forty, who told the old Taoist:

“Bro, I’m going to take a shower first. Wait for me, okay?”

“Alright, alright.”

The old Taoist sat down on the sofa, facing the television. The woman was washing herself inside, and the old Taoist outside was already in a state of heightened anticipation.

But then, the news broadcast on the television made the old Taoist’s mouth drop open.

“Our station’s latest news: new progress has been made in the murder case that occurred in General’s Mountain a week ago. The police have identified the suspect, a young man named ‘Ye Qing.’

The police’s wanted poster is now released: Ye Qing, male, 25 years old, formerly employed at Tongcheng Waterworks, a friend of the deceased family. On the day of the incident, he went on vacation to General’s Mountain with the deceased family.

After the incident, Ye Qing’s whereabouts have been unknown. Anyone with information is asked to contact the police. The police are offering a reward…”

The old Taoist stared at the television screen, stunned.

Just then, the woman finished her shower and came out. Seeing the old Taoist staring at the news, she smacked her lips and said:

“It happened last week. A family of three, all murdered. Their heads were even cut off and haven’t been found yet. It’s truly tragic. The couple was quite young, and the child was only about five years old, a girl.”

The old Taoist suddenly stood up.

Based on his experience solving cases with his previous boss, he keenly sensed that the phone call his boss received before he left was definitely unusual!

“Sis, brother didn’t bring his medicine today. I’m leaving first, okay?”

With that, the old Taoist ran straight out of the foot massage parlor.

………………

By the time the old Taoist took a taxi back to the bookstore, he found Zhou Ze wasn’t on the first floor. Spider-Man sat there, motionless. Xu Qinglang sat behind the counter, with cucumber slices on his face.

“Where’s the boss?” the old Taoist asked.

Xu Qinglang pointed upwards without speaking.

The old Taoist immediately ran upstairs and pushed open the door to the boss’s bedroom.

In the bedroom, the boss was lying on the tatami, his head resting on Bai Yingying’s lap, while Bai Yingying massaged his head.

The boss looked exhausted, as if he was burdened by a million responsibilities and incredibly hard-working. Bai Yingying, on the other hand, looked like she was deeply concerned about how tired, hardworking, and over-stressed her boss was.

*Pah!*

Dog and bitch!

The old Taoist inwardly snickered.

Then, he righteously declared:

“Boss, something’s happened.”

Zhou Ze turned his head slightly to look at the old Taoist standing at the door. “What is it?”

“Boss, in General’s Mountain, there was a murder case last week. A family of three was killed. Not only has the murderer not been found yet, but even the heads of the three victims haven’t been found.”

“Oh,” Zhou Ze responded. No wonder the police took his alarm call so seriously; it made sense now.

“Boss, that phone call you received might be a message from an insider,” the old Taoist reminded him.

“Mm-hmm,” Zhou Ze responded again. Then, he continued to immerse himself in Bai Yingying’s perfectly timed massage.

“…” the old Taoist.

He understood now. The boss probably already knew, but he was probably just afraid of trouble. This "trouble" might not only refer to the hassle of investigating the matter but also the trouble of a *Yama<sup>2</sup>* privately meddling in mortal affairs. The latter might be even greater and more sensitive.

This made the old Taoist a bit exasperated; the emperor wasn't worried, but the eunuch was, which was the most frustrating situation.

Just then, Zhou Ze’s phone rang again. It was on the bedside table, charging. Zhou Ze frowned, clearly not wanting to answer, so he didn’t ask Bai Yingying to get it for him.

The old Taoist rushed over, saw it was still the unknown number, and immediately pressed the answer button.

“Save me… save us… I’m in General’s Mountain… they’re here… they’re here… they’re going to kill… kill…”

Zhou Ze dug into his ears.

Didn’t hear, didn’t hear,

I’m deaf,

I’m deaf,

My ears are out of whack.

But then, a little girl’s painful,慘聲尖叫: “Ah ah ah ah ah ah ah ah ah ah ah!!!!!!!!” suddenly came from the phone.

Zhou Ze opened his eyes, looking helpless and conflicted.

The call on the other end was hung up.

The old Taoist swallowed, took out his own phone, walked over to Zhou Ze, and held it up to his boss. “Boss, this is a photo of the victim family’s daughter.”

A photo of an innocent five-year-old girl was placed in front of Zhou Ze.

Zhou Ze glanced at it and then looked away, but the old Taoist continued to hold the phone screen towards Zhou Ze’s eyes.

Look,

Take a look,

Can you bear it?

Can you?

Are you even human?!

Oh, no, even ghosts wouldn’t bear it, right?

“Boss, investigate it. This girl’s head hasn’t even been found yet,” the old Taoist urged.

Zhou Ze remained silent.

“Boss, I think the person who called is very suspicious; it’s like they were at the scene.”

Zhou Ze sighed, gave up the struggle, and then silently stood up.

He told Bai Yingying, “Help me find a set of casual clothes and sneakers.”

“Okay, Boss.” Bai Yingying immediately got up to find clothes.

Zhou Ze then looked at the old Taoist, smiling, “With your level, you’re trying to analyze and solve cases?”

“Huh?” The old Taoist looked a bit bewildered.

“Who am I?” Zhou Ze asked.

“A Yama, Boss.”

“Then what was that unknown call to me?”

“It was…”

“A ghost call.”

---
<sup>1</sup> 連襟 (lián jīn): refers to the husbands of two sisters or the husbands of two female cousins, a colloquial and somewhat humorous term for brothers-in-law in certain regional dialects, often implying a close, familiar relationship.
<sup>2</sup> 鬼差 (guǐ chāi): literally means "ghost envoy" or "ghost official." In Chinese mythology, these are the underworld officials or escorts who guide or apprehend spirits. In this context, it implies Zhou Ze has a supernatural role related to the deceased or the afterlife.

title: 第一百七十三章 溫泉驚魂！
content:
開車的是許清朗，不是周澤一定要和許清朗在一起，而是因為自己和老道都沒有駕駛證。



  試想一下，如果自己和老道兩個人開車出去後，半路再遇到交警，再因為無證駕駛被扣下，那樂子就大了。



  上次老道已經以身試法過一次了，這一次，總得小心一點。



  白鶯鶯和蜘蛛俠留在了書店裡看店，周澤沒讓他們跟過來。



  將軍山位於通城郊區，和臨近的揚州接壤，開車過去還是挺遠的，從書店出發，一路上沒什麼耽擱，大概一個半小時後，才抵達了目的地。



  長三角平原是沒什麼山的，就算是有，也只是小山，放在四川和放在東北那幾個多山的區域，根本就不值一提。



  這就像是南方人沒見過雪見到雪很激動一樣，你讓平原地區的人第一次開車進山路，也會激動得很。



  將軍山也是近些年才得到了開發，上頭開了幾家比較大型和上檔次的溫泉山莊，算是吸引了一些客流，附近一些村民也辦起了小民宿，但還沒到形成規模的時候。



  許清朗直接把車開入了一家叫「溫雅溫泉度假山莊」的店裡，他在這裡訂了房間，其實，被害的一家三口當時也是住在這裡，不過他們並不是死在裡頭，而是死在下山的山路上。



  但哪怕是這樣，這件事對這家酒店生意的影響也是極為恐怖的。 



  最明顯的就是許清朗原本訂的是一千五一天的帶院子室內溫泉池子的小別墅，前台居然直接熱情地免費給他升級成了帶小四合院日租金五千的房間。



  而且無論是前台還是迎賓，服務態度簡直好得跟見到親爹媽一樣，熱情得不能再熱情。



  後來，周澤才知道，現在整個酒店，似乎只有自己這一波的客人。



  先進了房間，許清朗讓服務生給溫泉池子放水，他打算先去泡一泡，之前周澤喊他出來時已經說好了的，他只負責開車，其餘的事情不管，畢竟周澤喊他的時候他還在做美容。



  老道倒是殷勤，不停地在網上查著案件資料，周澤則是坐在藤椅上，面前的茶几上放著手機。



  讓周老闆去跟警察一樣四處找線索，找蛛絲馬跡，這不現實，而且這些事情警察比自己更精通，畢竟術業有專攻嘛，周老闆只需要負責接電話就可以了。



  其實，周澤真的不是很願意多事兒，也不願意沾惹這些麻煩，但電話里傳來的那個女孩兒的慘叫聲，實在是太讓人難受了。



  再加上，既然這次很大可能是「鬼來電」，既然是有鬼參合的事兒，自己出手去管的話，也就可以名正言順了。



  只是，之前連打好幾次的電話，等周澤到了將軍山之後，卻反而沒了動靜，安靜得不得了。 



  許清朗已經進池子開始泡澡了，他還給自己加了玫瑰精油這些東西，躺在裡面不時地撩撥著水花，還把自己的大腿伸展出來輕輕地撫摸，這姿態，真的很像早些年的香港三J片裡的唯美畫面。



  辣眼睛，



  真的太辣眼睛了，



  如果不知道他是男的還好，你還能欣賞欣賞，



  但你知道他是男的，就覺得很噁心。



  「老闆，要不我們還是先去案發現場看看？」老道主動道。



  周澤很想拒絕，但是繼續留在賓館裡看著院子裡的許娘娘作妖似乎是更痛苦的一件事，當下也就點點頭，跟著許清朗說了一聲後，和老道一起出了酒店。



  屋子裡就剩下自己一個人，許清朗覺得更加的愜意，一般來說，溫泉池子的水有沒有料，就看你在水裡泡一會兒看看手上腳上有沒有起白皮，如果起白皮了就意味著這水跟大澡堂里沒啥區別。



  老許一個人泡得美滋滋，雙臂撐開，姿態舒展，旁邊放著酒店送的便宜紅酒，至少，那股子的意境兒許清朗是泡出來了。



  「叮咚…………叮咚…………」



  門鈴聲響起。



  許清朗有些不甘願地從池子裡走出來，披上了浴袍，打開門後，許清朗看見一個服務生端著三杯牛奶和一些零食過來。 



  「先生，這是酒店送您的。」



  「好，謝謝。」



  接過了東西，許清朗關上門，把東西隨手放在了茶几上，然後又脫去了浴袍，重新走入了池子裡。



  泡著泡著，當自己快要睡著時，許清朗忽然聽到了「喀嚓喀嚓」的聲音，像是有老鼠在咬東西一樣。



  許清朗一開始以為自己幻聽了，可能溫泉泡久了，整個人也有些飄飄然了，但這個聲音卻還在一直繼續著。



  回過頭，看向屋子客廳那邊，許清朗並沒有看見人或者老鼠。



  「咕嘟…………咕嘟…………」



  聲音還在繼續，



  就在客廳里。



  抿了抿嘴唇，許清朗再度從池子裡走出來，重新披上了浴袍。



  雖說他也不是什麼普通人，住在這裡也確實沒什麼害怕的，但眼下畢竟周澤不在，如果自己真遇到什麼事兒，還是有一點點麻煩的。



  當家的不在，就沒了主心骨啊。



  客廳里檢查了一遍，讓許清朗有些疑惑的是，當自己走入客廳時，之前響起的聲音又消失不見了。



  許清朗在客廳沙發上坐了下來，然後目光看向了面前的茶几，茶几上有服務生剛送來的零食和牛奶。 



  但是零食那邊卻缺了一大塊。



  被老鼠偷了？



  許清朗默默地拿起手機，他覺得事情有點詭異，雖然那一家子不是死在這家酒店裡的，這家酒店還在正常營業，但又怎麼能證明這家酒店就一定乾淨？



  只是，萬一真的是老鼠或者其他小動物偷吃的東西，自己這樣給周澤打電話讓他回來，到時候會不會被笑話？



  許清朗有些猶豫，他在沙發後面尋找，在茶几下面尋找，他希望看見一隻老鼠或者松鼠之類的東西在這裡躲著，這樣子他就放心了。



  只是，找來找去，還是沒找到小動物的蹤跡。



  許清朗又走到了外面院子裡，沒下池子，就站在池子旁邊，等著。



  「咔嚓咔嚓…………」



  咀嚼的聲音又響起來了，許清朗目光在客廳里逡巡著，終於，他確定了聲音來源位置！



  當下，



  許清朗直接沖了過去，掀開了那裡的茶座，還是一無所獲，聲音也直接消失，但在這裡，還有一個小冰箱。



  在冰箱裡？



  許清朗伸手，慢慢地攥住了冰箱把手，然後直接把冰箱打開。



  冰箱裡放著可樂和啤酒，並沒有其他什麼東西。 



  長舒一口氣，許清朗覺得自己還真怕看見什麼東西在裡頭，那個畫面，想想都讓人覺得頭皮發麻。



  「天地無極，玄心正法！」



  許清朗掐著手印，然後取出了一枚護心鏡，直接放在了客廳正中央的茶几上，然後默默地坐在沙發上。



  溫泉也不去了，



  其他地方也不去了，



  就一個人坐在這裡發著呆。



  「滴答…………滴答…………」



  客廳掛鐘不停地作響，但先前不斷襲擾人的咀嚼聲音就似乎真的因為許清朗坐在這裡，而沒有再出現過。



  坐了大概半個多小時後，許清朗再次拿起手機，這次他準備給周澤打電話了，問問他們什麼時候回來，畢竟到了晚飯的點了。



  許清朗是不會說自己被不知道什麼玩意兒給嚇得連溫泉都沒泡舒坦的。



  但不知道怎麼的，手機顯示沒有信號，電話怎麼打就是打不出去。



  許清朗從沙發上站了起來，



  事情到了這一步，如果他還沒能察覺到詭異的氛圍就真的是白混了。



  「叮咚…………叮咚…………叮咚…………」



  門鈴聲再度響起。 



  許清朗一邊環視四周一邊走向了大門那邊，打開門。



  換了一個女性侍者，對方手裡拿著一件未開封的浴袍，遞了過來。



  「這是你要的新浴袍。」



  「什麼？」



  許清朗愣了一下，他什麼時候要過新浴袍？



  「是這個房間啊，說你們需要額外一件浴袍。」女服務員又看了一眼門牌號，確認了一下，道：「沒錯，那我先走了，祝您度假愉快。」



  女服務員走前關了門，



  許清朗抱著這件沒開封的新浴袍走了回來。



  「嘩啦啦…………」



  池子裡的熱水，又在放了起來，無緣無故地自己放了起來。



  而後，之前被自己關上的冰箱門居然又被打開了。



  茶几上送來的零食，又少了一些。



  拿起手機，該死，手機信號還是一格都沒有。



  慢慢地，許清朗覺得自己快被折磨瘋了，這不是他疑神疑鬼，他沒脆弱到那種地步，這的確是一些詭異且匪夷所思的事情正在他身邊實實在在地發生著。



  許清朗想要洗把臉，他走到了衛生間，把浴袍放在一邊，然後彎下腰洗臉，等到他準備拿洗面奶時，卻忽然發現自己剛剛放在洗臉池旁邊的那件新浴袍不見了。 



  許清朗抬起頭，對著鏡子，



  卻發現在鏡子裡，



  自己的身邊，



  站著三個人，



  一個男人一個女人，還有一個小朋友。



  他們三個人，都穿著浴袍，



  渾身上下濕漉漉的，面色蒼白，



  就這樣比比直直地站在他許清朗的身邊。



  許清朗下意識地歪了歪頭，想看得更仔細一些，



  鏡子裡那一家三口也一起跟著許清朗的動作歪頭，



  「噗通」



  「噗通」



  「噗通」



  三聲悶響，



  一家三口，



  三顆頭顱，



  一起滾落。

title: 第一百七十四章 溫泉山莊殺人事件！
content:
In this situation, an ordinary person would either be scared senseless or start screaming hysterically.

Fortunately, Xu Qinglang himself was considered a practitioner of metaphysics, albeit with only a smattering of knowledge. Still, he wouldn’t be utterly terrified by these so-called “unclean things.”

He was just a little helpless. He was minding his own business, soaking in the hot spring, and when he went out to look for their Boss Zhou, he didn’t find them. But here he was, minding his own business, and they came looking for him.

Xu Qinglang silently calmed his mind. He knew that ordinary ghosts could only attack you by finding your inner weaknesses. As long as you didn't panic, you could greatly restrain their influence.

However, what surprised Xu Qinglang was that this family didn’t seem to intend to trouble him. They began to squat on the floor, their hands constantly fumbling on the bathroom floor, as if searching for something.

At first, he didn’t understand, but soon Xu Qinglang figured it out: they were looking for their heads!

Yes, initially they had heads, but now their heads were gone, and they were searching for them.

The news reports of the case also stated that the police found their bodies, but the heads of the family of three had yet to be found.

The ancients valued being whole when buried, even eunuchs in ancient times would have tailors sew their "treasures" back on to be buried with them, let alone their heads.

While they were fumbling on the floor, Xu Qinglang tiptoed out of the bathroom and returned to the living room.

He lit a cigarette, and the previous tension had vanished. Perhaps the unknown was the most terrifying. The tension from the previous anomalies mostly came from the unknown. Now that he knew who was behind the mischief, he felt much more at ease.

He glanced at his phone again, finding there was still no signal, so he couldn’t directly contact Zhou Ze. Xu Qinglang sighed and simply curled his legs, turning on the TV.

The TV was showing the children's channel, playing the animation *Boonie Bears*.

Xu Qinglang watched from the side. He didn't flee the room in a panic. He knew that Zhou Ze was looking for them, and furthermore, it seemed that this family were victims. Their greater obsession was finding their heads, so they wouldn’t have too much aggression or resentment.

*Boonie Bears* finished, and *Detective Conan* started playing next.

Xu Qinglang frowned and changed the channel. Watching Conan at this moment felt strange.

But coincidentally, after switching to a local channel, it was reporting on the General Mountain massacre case and the police's pursuit of suspects and search for the victims' heads.

This made it even more unnerving.

The ghosts of the deceased family of three were right there in the room. Was there any more live broadcast than this?

Xu Qinglang instinctively wanted to change the channel again,

But he suddenly noticed that the family of three had crawled in front of the TV and stopped, as if they were also watching the news.

After a moment of hesitation, he decided not to change the channel.

...

By the time Zhou Ze and the old Taoist priest returned, Xu Qinglang had already fallen asleep on the living room sofa.

“Oh, what a graceful posture.”

The old Taoist priest walked over, wanting to pat Xu Qinglang’s thigh to wake him up, but thought better of it. He was afraid he might turn himself gay. The old Taoist priest was very particular about his reputation, having maintained his “knowing the difficulties and pressing forward” for seventy years, and he didn’t want to stray into the wrong path now.

“Hey, wake up,” Zhou Ze called out.

But there was no response, which surprised Zhou Ze. Was he sleeping that deeply?

Zhou Ze then took two steps closer to Xu Qinglang and noticed a faint dark mist hovering over Xu Qinglang’s brow. Had he been possessed by an evil spirit?

Extending a fingernail, Zhou Ze poked Xu Qinglang’s brow with his index finger. Xu Qinglang’s brow was pierced, and a few drops of black blood emerged. Then he slowly opened his eyes and stretched.

“Is there something wrong with this room?” Zhou Ze asked, looking around.

Xu Qinglang had clearly been invaded by malevolent aura just now, but Xu Qinglang wasn't an ordinary person, which indicated that something very ominous had been in this room recently.

“I saw that family, right here in this room,” Xu Qinglang said.

“What?” The old Taoist priest was startled and quickly ran to his boss’s side, ready to protect him.

It was the old Taoist priest who had previously declared they would investigate the case to avenge the family of three, and it was also he who was now frightened. He was the type to love dragons but fear them in reality.

“That family of three, here?” Zhou Ze was somewhat bewildered. “That shouldn’t be. I asked the front desk earlier, and that family of three stayed in a different room, not ours. And that room is currently suspended from renting out. They said they plan to invite monks and Taoist priests for a ceremony after things calm down.”

“It’s genuine, a family of three, crawling around in this room, looking for their heads,” Xu Qinglang affirmed. “Was I asleep just now?”

“Yes,” the old Taoist priest responded.

“Then I must have been with them for too long, and my body was invaded by the malevolent energy,” Xu Qinglang shook his head. Clearly, he was still somewhat groggy.

In traditional Chinese medicine, there's a saying that evil qi entering the body can cause colds and fever. Xu Qinglang's current state was similar, like a severe cold.

“But that family of three didn’t do anything to me. They were looking for their heads. Whether the murderer is found or not, they can’t descend to hell without their heads,” Xu Qinglang speculated.

“But the problem is, the first time I entered this room, and now the second time, I haven’t felt anything unusual,” Zhou Ze said, somewhat puzzled. “If the souls of that family of three were truly lingering here, it would be impossible for me not to see them. At the very least, I wouldn’t be able to detect even a trace.”

As a Ghost Catcher, if he couldn't even tell if there were ghosts in a room, he might as well retire.

“But I’m sure I saw them,” Xu Qinglang affirmed. Then he thought for a moment and said self-deprecatingly, “Perhaps I have some talent that even I haven’t discovered.”

“That’s impossible.”

The old Taoist priest pouted, too lazy to see Xu Qinglang being conceited, and directly said, “Boss, I think the reason Old Xu can see what we can’t is very simple.

There must be something Old Xu did that we didn’t, so the trigger conditions are different, and naturally, the things seen are also different.”

“So, what is it that he did that we didn’t?” Zhou Ze asked.

“Skincare, BB cream, face masks…” The old Taoist priest counted on his fingers.

Xu Qinglang simply had more cosmetics than Bai Yingying, although the female zombie was an exception—she was eternally youthful, forever sixteen, so she didn't need makeup or whitening.

As he was speaking,

The old Taoist priest seemed to remember something,

Then pointed to the hot spring pool in the courtyard outside:

“Hot spring bath! He was the only one who bathed, none of us did!”

...

The old Taoist priest was the first to undress and enter the pool. The water in the pool was still warm. The old Taoist priest added some hot water and lay in it, feeling utterly wonderful.

However, when Xu Qinglang came to bathe, the old Taoist priest felt a pang of jealousy.

Yes, if it had been a woman, he wouldn't have been jealous, but it was a man.

That smooth, delicate skin, those slender and graceful legs, that somewhat hazy countenance in the steam—the old Taoist priest instinctively covered a certain area with his bath towel.

Then he lowered his head and silently recited the few Taoist scriptures he knew.

It’s over,

It’s over,

My lifelong reputation is ruined now.

Looking at Concubine Xu’s skin and figure, then at his own scrawny body, protruding ribs, and skin like old elm bark, the old Taoist priest silently sighed again, lamenting how time ages a person.

He remembered back when he first became a monk, how all the female pilgrims used to praise him as a handsome Taoist priest.

Time is a butcher’s knife, a butcher’s knife indeed.

Old Xu also felt a bit awkward; he wasn’t very used to bathing with others. In fact, many people are like this, similar to college men's bathhouses, where there are always some shy boys who have to wear underwear to bathe.

When Zhou Ze walked over from inside, the old Taoist priest and Xu Qinglang both looked his way.

The old Taoist priest thought, with the boss’s useless appearance, he probably has a lot of flab. Even if the boss isn’t fat, he eats little and exercises little, so after taking off his clothes, his physique probably isn’t even as good as mine.

But when Zhou Ze walked over, both the old Taoist priest and Xu Qinglang were surprised.

Zhou Ze’s body showed several unhealed scars, giving him the look of a war movie protagonist. His muscles were well-defined; he wasn’t a bodybuilder, but the lean and refined physique he revealed after undressing truly dazzled the two men in the hot spring pool, as if their eyes were made of titanium alloy.

“That’s not fair,” the old Taoist priest muttered, somewhat speechless. How could a man who spends all his time basking in the sun, reading newspapers, and then lying on a maid’s lap groaning have such a good physique?

Actually, Zhou Ze knew the reason: every time he unleashed his full power, his physical condition would improve, and he indeed didn't need to exercise much.

The three of them sat in the pool.

The old Taoist priest began pouring rose essential oil and scattering petals, then used a bath towel to scrub himself.

The steam from the hot spring slowly rose,
and even their vision gradually became blurry.

“You’ve poured too much essential oil,” Xu Qinglang complained.

“It’s free anyway, so why not use it all?” the old Taoist priest scoffed.

Immediately after, the old Taoist priest, who was scrubbing himself, suddenly felt a leg gently rubbing against his calf. The leg was very smooth and tender.

Concubine Xu’s leg?

It must be. The boss’s legs have a lot of muscle, so the touch isn’t the same.

Hehe,

Alas,

Hehe,

Alas,

The old Taoist priest was extremely conflicted. He really didn’t want to turn gay, but at this moment, he couldn’t help but feel his mind wander.

That leg began to move deeper,

Oh,

Oh,

Oh oh oh,

The old Taoist priest instinctively gasped,

His voice changed pitch.

Just then, the old Taoist priest’s heart jolted, and he told himself: “No, no, I can’t turn gay, I can’t!”

“Old Xu, what do you mean? Can’t you bathe properly?” the old Taoist priest yelled at Xu Qinglang.

“Are you sick?” Xu Qinglang replied languidly.

“Then why are you teasing me? If you have the guts, tease the boss! I’m not into that!”

“...” Zhou Ze.

“Who’s teasing you?”

“Hey, still not admitting it!”

The old Taoist priest reached into the water, grabbed that leg, and pulled it up with all his might, then stood up himself.

I’ll make you admit it,

I’ll make you admit it!

“Haha, I got you!”

The old Taoist priest stood up, only to find the boss and Xu Qinglang staring at him in a daze. This time, he saw clearly that Xu Qinglang was sitting at the other end of the pool, with the boss between them. His leg couldn't possibly be that long.

The old Taoist priest swallowed hard,

Turned his head,

And saw the thigh,
which he was holding in his hand...

title: 第一百七十五章 餐廳驚魂
content:
A segment of a thigh, clutched in the old Daoist priest's hand. When the old Daoist priest looked at it, he was so startled he even forgot to drop it.

Just then, Zhou Ze and Xu Qinglang emerged from the pool. The two quickly changed their clothes in the living room.

After they left, the old Daoist priest finally came to his senses, hastily threw away the thigh, and fled the hot spring pool as if his life depended on it. He had intended to get dressed, but seeing the boss and Xu Qinglang directly open the room door and prepare to leave, he simply grabbed a bathrobe, wrapped it around himself, and followed them out of the hotel.

The old Daoist priest was, after all, not Xu Qinglang; he didn't have the guts to stay alone in a haunted house.

This resort mountain village had a large layout, resembling a villa district, with very well-maintained green spaces. Typically, after checking in at the front desk, a greeter would specifically drive an electric sightseeing cart to take guests to their chosen villa. If one wanted to dine or go out, they could also call the front desk to arrange pickup and drop-off.

"Is it going to rain today?" The old Daoist priest looked up at the sky. Dark clouds covered the sky, as if a thunderstorm was imminent.

Zhou Ze didn't answer, continuing to walk forward. Xu Qinglang followed behind Zhou Ze, his expression solemn.

They had experienced the events at Sanxiang Village, so they weren't unfamiliar with this kind of setting. As for the old Daoist priest, due to his exceptionally strong vitality, he hadn't fully grasped the situation since he hadn't entered Sanxiang Village last time.

After walking for about five minutes, they reached the reception building. The left side of the first floor of the building was the restaurant, serving breakfast, lunch, and dinner.

When Zhou Ze and the other two walked into the building, they noticed many people, like the old Daoist priest, dressed in bathrobes, entering from outside and heading directly into the restaurant to eat.

"Oh, it seems rich people enjoy themselves this way, huh? Eating in a bathrobe really adds flavor!"

The old Daoist priest was a bit shy at first, but seeing everyone else like this, he relaxed.

Zhou Ze first walked towards the reception desk and found that the staff there were gone. Aside from the restaurant, the rest of the place was empty, with no one in sight.

Finally, Zhou Ze had no choice but to enter the restaurant.

"Hello, sir, please show your room card." There were uniformed waiters here.

Xu Qinglang handed over the room card. The person swiped it, verified the room type and number of diners, and nodded.

"Enjoy your meal."

Subsequently, the three walked inside.

There were quite a few people inside; it was a buffet. Zhou Ze and Xu Qinglang found a place to sit down.

"Boss, why don't I get some food for us to stave off our hunger first?" the old Daoist priest suggested.

Zhou Ze looked at the old Daoist priest, then pointed at someone nearby.

The old Daoist priest followed the direction and saw a pretty young woman sitting there eating. She looked quite good.

The young woman picked up the milk in front of her, took a sip, and then with a "plop," her eyeball actually fell out and directly into the milk cup.

The old Daoist priest subconsciously swallowed.

Then, the young woman reached into the milk cup and stirred, finally retrieving her eyeball and putting it back into her eye socket.

The old Daoist priest swallowed twice more in succession.

"Still want to eat?" Zhou Ze asked.

The old Daoist priest immediately shook his head and sat obediently beside Zhou Ze.

Such gratitude,

Truly, an overwhelming sense of gratitude.

This was the first time the boss hadn't deliberately tricked him; he even specifically told him the food here wasn't edible!

Perhaps because he was used to being "teased," the old Daoist priest felt even more grateful to Zhou Ze at this moment. He had genuinely fallen for such tricks far too many times before.

Including the incident with the steamed buns last time, which almost made him lose half his old life, though he couldn't really blame the boss for that one.

"Are there any big ghosts here?" Xu Qinglang whispered.

Zhou Ze shook his head. He wasn't sure. The last time in Sanxiang Village was due to the influence of that bronze ring. The bronze ring was still on him now; normally, when in the bookstore, he would have Bai Yingying keep it in the bedroom, but when going out, he definitely carried it with him, just in case he might need it sometime, purely for luck.

As for the Yin-Yang Scroll, Zhou Ze couldn't carry it with him. What if he encountered a child again and it vibrated a few times? Should he save them or not?

"Let's just watch for now."

Zhou Ze lightly touched his face, which was covered in a layer of sweat.

"The humidity here is extreme," Zhou Ze said.

Xu Qinglang nodded. "I feel it too, like we're still soaking in the hot spring."

The old Daoist priest could only listen from the side, his gaze scanning around. He saw a young man at the opposite table eating noodles while gnawing on his own fingers, treating them like garlic, eating with great relish.

He saw the chef preparing rice noodles by stirring with his arm directly in the pot, and scooping them out with his bare hands when done, even as his arm turned bright red from the heat.

Good heavens,

The old Daoist priest watched until he couldn't bear to look anymore, lowering his head.

He silently put on a thoughtful expression.

He wasn't particularly panicked or scared; after all, the boss was right there. If the sky fell, the tallest one would bear the brunt.

In truth, since ancient times, places with many ghosts often signify two possible situations.

One is the presence of a great ghost, similar to a ghost king, under whose command various mountain spirits, wild monsters, and lonely ghosts would naturally gather, such as the former Lady Bai or the Black Mountain Demon from "A Chinese Ghost Story."

Another possibility is the influence of a special magical artifact, just like Sanxiang Village last time, which existed due to the influence of that bronze ring.

If it were merely the influence of a magical artifact, the problem would be smaller, as magical artifacts have no good or evil, nor any intelligence. But if this General Mountain was the domain of some ghost king, then the problem would be much larger.

Zhou Ze wasn't afraid of angering that ghost king; he simply didn't want to add too much trouble.

He came here merely because of that "ghost call." He only wanted to complete his original plan. Of course, if he could take all the ghosts here, that would be for the best; the newly promoted Boss Zhou's performance was quite pitiful right now.

"That family of three is here," Zhou Ze said.

At the entrance, the family of three walked in and sat down at the table next to Zhou Ze and the others. The daughter sat in her seat, while the father and mother went to get food.

Then,
