The father and mother brought back a lot of food.

The family of three sat stiffly in their chairs, facing the food on the table, motionless.

They had no heads, so they naturally couldn't eat.

"Is that them?" Zhou Ze asked Xu Qinglang.

"Yes, it's them," Xu Qinglang confirmed with a nod.

Zhou Ze understood, rose, and walked over, sitting in the empty seat next to the father.

"Can you speak?" Zhou Ze asked.

The family of three remained silent.

"I'm here to help you. You can tell me who killed you. You're looking for your heads, right? I can help you."

Zhou Ze explained.

The family of three continued to be silent.

Zhou Ze pointed at the little girl.

"She's so young, her life had just begun, and she was murdered. Aren't you, as parents, angry?"

At this moment,

The wife's arm rose. She dipped her finger into the soup in front of her, then, using the liquid, began to write on the table.

Zhou Ze watched carefully,

Then his expression changed.

Not because the woman wrote anything shocking,

But because the woman seemed unaware that she still had a piece of green vegetable clutched between her fingers. As she wrote a character, the vegetable leaf also swept back and forth across it.

Zhou Ze couldn't understand what was being written at all!

But the woman was still writing diligently; she wanted revenge for her daughter. Yet, the more seriously she wrote, the more frustrated Zhou Ze became; he just couldn't understand it.

"The writing's smudged. Take the vegetable leaf off," Zhou Ze reminded her.

Just then,

A few waiters at the front service desk shouted, "Mealtime over!"

"Clatter, clatter..."

Everyone who was dining stood up simultaneously, even Zhou Ze and the old Daoist priest followed suit. Then, everyone in the restaurant, including the chefs and waiters, began to line up and walk out. Everything was orderly, as if rehearsed countless times.

The family of three did the same, rising and heading towards the exit.

Zhou Ze reached out to grab the husband's wrist, but the husband passed directly through him. Zhou Ze extended his claws, but still couldn't grasp them.

At this point, Zhou Ze grew angry. All his fingernails extended, and black mist immediately spread out.

He was ready to cause trouble.

He wasn't going to play charades with them anymore.

However, the claws, which had previously been effective against spiritual bodies, seemed to have lost all their utility at this moment. The people around them continued to go about their business, completely unaffected.

Zhou Ze frowned slightly.

They...

They weren't ghosts?

If not ghosts, not souls, then what were they?

Soon, everyone in the restaurant was gone, leaving only Zhou Ze, the old Daoist priest, and Xu Qinglang.

"Boss, what happened just now?" the old Daoist priest stepped forward and asked. He had just seen the boss strike a pose and thought he was about to flip the table, but who would have thought, it was all thunder and no rain?

"These guys aren't departed souls," Zhou Ze stated with certainty.

"If not departed souls, then what are they?" the old Daoist priest was baffled.

"It might be a kind of magnetic field," Xu Qinglang speculated. "There might be some mineral deposits in General Mountain that have caused the magnetic field here to change, just like lightning can record images from a long time ago." He added, "Ghosts exist everywhere, but this many is clearly impossible. Perhaps this supernatural phenomenon has recorded all the traces of ghost activity over the years, giving us the illusion that there are many ghosts here?"

Just then, Zhou Ze's phone rang. Zhou Ze answered; it was still the unknown number.

This time, the voice on the other end of the phone was incredibly clear:

"Save me... save me... I'm at General Mountain... save me... save me..."

"We're also at General Mountain, where the hell are you!" the old Daoist priest roared directly into the phone.

"They're coming... they're coming... coming... ah..."

A scream came from the phone.

Then there was a burst of static,

Another confusing ghost call, with no valuable information.

However, just as Zhou Ze was about to hang up,

Another voice suddenly came from the other end of the phone:

"Amitābha!"

"It's the bald monk!" the old Daoist priest exclaimed excitedly. "The bald monk, there's a bald monk causing trouble here! This poor Daoist has finally discovered the truth!"

Zhou Ze frowned and exchanged a glance with Xu Qinglang. Zhou Ze asked, "Did that voice just now sound familiar?"

Xu Qinglang also nodded. "It does sound a bit familiar."

Next,

A second sentence came from the phone:

"Amitābha, this poor Daoist has finally found you, hehehe!"

title: 第一百七十六章 幕後黑手
content:
"Amitabha, this poor Daoist has finally found you, hehehe!"

When this sentence came out from the phone,

Zhou Ze and Xu Qinglang both turned their gazes to the old Daoist beside them.

The expression on the old Daoist's face was very rich and colorful: there was shock, panic, bewilderment, and helplessness.

Yes,

Zhou Ze and Xu Qinglang had said before that the voice sounded a bit familiar.

Now it was proven that this was indeed the old Daoist's voice.

However, because the human voice transmitted from a phone inevitably gets distorted and altered, and Zhou Ze and Xu Qinglang hadn't expected the old Daoist's voice to appear in it, they were caught off guard.

But the phrase "Amitabha" followed by "this poor Daoist" was the old Daoist's usual habit, especially the subsequent "hehehe," which perfectly encapsulated the old Daoist's "base demeanor."

The old Daoist was a Daoist priest; his real name might sometimes be forgotten even by himself. His name was Lu Fangweng. Lu You in ancient times was also known as "Fangweng" and was called Lu Fangweng, but despite sharing a name with an ancient great poet, the old Daoist's conduct was much less principled.

Engaging in illicit trades, wandering the jianghu,* for decades through trials and tribulations, he had done almost everything. He always considered himself a Daoist priest, yet he had not an ounce of the discipline expected of one. Aside from the inexhaustible ancestral talismans he kept hidden in his trousers, which still had some effect, there was almost no other feature of a Daoist to be found on him.

Even his usual catchphrase, "Wuliang Tianzun," he often mispronounced as "Amitabha."

Seeing the Boss and Xu Qinglang looking at him,

The old Daoist gave an awkward smile,

And pointed to his face, saying:

"You can't possibly think that I, this poor Daoist, am the mastermind, can you?"

Alright,

Generally speaking,

In a suspense drama, the most unremarkable and unlikely character at the beginning often steps forward at the end, tearing off their mask to surprise everyone that they are the killer, while those who are boisterous and immediately suspected at the beginning are often innocent.

But when it came to the old Daoist,

He's the mastermind?

He's standing behind, orchestrating all of this?

Xu Qinglang and Zhou Ze both shook their heads slightly, "Let's go out first."

"Hmm, right."

The two turned around and walked out of the restaurant.

The old Daoist was initially a bit nervous, afraid the Boss and the others had misunderstood something, but seeing the Boss and Old Xu directly giving up on their suspicion, the old Daoist suddenly felt a bit let down.

This feeling of being "trusted" didn't seem to be all that pleasant.

"Boss, why don't you two reconsider for a bit..."

Zhou Ze and Xu Qinglang continued walking forward without looking back.

"Just pretend, even..."

The old Daoist felt somewhat helpless and could only follow them out.

From exiting the restaurant until they returned to the rented villa, they didn't see any other pedestrians along the way. The three returned to the side of the hot spring pool.

Zhou Ze first stepped into the hot spring, submerged his face, and when he lifted his head, he wiped away the water droplets from his face. The dark clouds and oppressive atmosphere in the sky had vanished.

It seemed he was right; the entrance was indeed this hot spring.

The old Daoist and Xu Qinglang had also returned; everyone's clothes were soaked. Clearly, the space they had been in before was not an entirely separate place, but rather a supernatural "environment" that relied on the real world.

For example, when they were lying in the hot spring earlier, Zhou Ze and the others were unclothed. It was only when the old Daoist fished out a leg from the pool that they ran out of the pool, put on clothes, and left the room.

But now, their clothes were still on them, and the old Daoist was still wrapped in a bathrobe.

The hot spring pool was a bit like a hypnotist's pendulum, allowing you to see more things, but in reality, you might just be seeing "illusions," and you yourself were still walking and moving in reality.

Sometimes, Zhou Ze couldn't help but wonder if many of the lunatics in this world, who spout nonsense and are labeled by those around them as "mentally ill, abnormal," actually mean that they can truly see a "world" that exists within reality but is completely invisible to ordinary people.

Of course, this is like how among the numerous natural and accidental deaths reported each year in various countries, many homicides are actually hidden and never discovered or prosecuted. The specific circumstances within these cases are truly unknowable.

Xu Qinglang took off his clothes, changed into a bathrobe, then walked up to Zhou Ze, motioning for Zhou Ze to take off his wet clothes as well. Afterwards, he hung both their clothes on a hanger outside to dry.

Zhou Ze sat on the living room sofa, toying with his phone.

The old Daoist sat nearby, making tea with freshly boiled water from an electric kettle, and proactively handed a cup to Zhou Ze.

Zhou Ze took the teacup, swirled it, and said, "Old Xu, have you seen a movie called 'The Shining'?"

"That horror movie?" Xu Qinglang asked.

"Hmm, I think the situation we're in now is somewhat similar to 'The Shining'—a reality and illusion that are hard to distinguish, plus the scene where the former residents who died here and nearby were all dining together. It's very much like the photograph in 'The Shining'."

"So, what's your point?" Xu Qinglang took a sip of tea. "Are you getting greedy?"

Zhou Ze shook his head, "I don't want to deal with the secrets of this place for now. It's here, and there'll be plenty of opportunities later. To be honest, I've almost forgotten why we came here.

Forget it, let's find the killer of that family of three first before anything else. The key is that ghost call; I need to figure it out, otherwise, I just feel uncomfortable."

Speaking of the ghost call, Zhou Ze looked at the old Daoist again. How did the old Daoist's voice appear on the phone?

Could it be that the person on the phone was a ventriloquist, skilled in imitating the old Daoist's voice and mannerisms?

"Ding-dong... Ding-dong..."

Someone was pressing the doorbell outside.

The old Daoist got up and opened the door. A waiter stood outside, asking with some concern, "Hello, I just wanted to ask if you need any assistance?"

"Assistance?" The old Daoist was a bit puzzled.

"It's like this, I saw the three of you wandering and talking in the restaurant earlier. I called out to you, but you didn't respond, so I specifically came over to ask if you're hungry and would like to dine, we can start a bit earlier, as there aren't many guests checked in right now."

"No, thank you," the old Daoist refused.

"Alright then, I won't disturb your rest," the waiter smiled and nodded.

The old Daoist closed the door, then called out to Zhou Ze and the others inside, "Boss, the hotel waiter came to see if we were all sleepwalking, haha."

"Next time, let's not all go in together. At least one or two people should stay outside and watch," Zhou Ze said.

Xu Qinglang nodded, "I look terrible now. I'll go wash my face and do my skincare first. We can make further plans tonight."

"Okay, let's rest first," Zhou Ze agreed.

Immediately, Zhou Ze rose from the living room and walked to the hot spring pool, pointing to it, "Old Daoist, you initially found a human leg here, right?"

"Yes, a woman's leg, I guess. If it were a man's, it would probably be..." The old Daoist said, subtly glancing around the room.

He had genuinely mistaken it at first, thinking Old Xu was teasing him.

"Drain the water from the pool," Zhou Ze said.

The old Daoist nodded. By this time, the hot spring pool had cooled down; the water was still warm, but there was no steam. The old Daoist, barefoot, went down and pulled out the stopper, and the water slowly began to drain.

"The human leg, it should be real."

Zhou Ze lit a cigarette and said quietly:

"This whole thing seems a bit big. That family of three just seems to be a trigger. That family of three had their heads cut off, and now there was a leg in this hot spring pool."

He exhaled a puff of smoke,

"After the case of the family of three, this hot spring hotel was still able to operate because that family of three died on their way down the mountain after checking out, not in the hotel itself.

But the facts don't seem to be this way. Old Xu said earlier that the family of three was fumbling around in their hotel room for their missing heads. Now, it seems that at some unknown time in the past, someone dismembered a body here and left a leg. Although the leg is not visible now, since we could see it in that state, it means it once appeared."

"Boss, are you suspecting the murderer is internal staff of this hotel?"

"Not just that," Zhou Ze flicked the ash from his cigarette. "I'm even starting to wonder if this is a hot spring resort or a slaughterhouse."

Saying that, Zhou Ze tried to make his left fingernails grow long. A black mist immediately condensed in his palm, and then Zhou Ze inserted his fingernails into the edge of the hot spring pool.

This was a method Zhou Ze used to find nearby spirits in the past; now he was just trying it casually, as he had no other leads anyway.

Who knew it was better not to try,

But once he tried, he found that there were indeed black footprints here,

This trail of footprints extended from the hot spring pool all the way into the living room.

Really there?

Zhou Ze looked up and followed the trail of footprints.

The footprints turned a corner in the living room and went straight into the bathroom.

At this moment, Xu Qinglang was washing his face with facial cleanser in the bathroom, applying skincare products to his face in front of the mirror, meticulously smoothing them on.

And the footprints,

After extending to the bathroom vanity, they started to go upwards, implying that the thing had climbed onto the vanity.

After climbing onto the vanity,

Where did it go then?

Zhou Ze reached out and patted Xu Qinglang on the shoulder.

"What?" Xu Qinglang asked, continuing to pat his face in the mirror.

Zhou Ze gently rubbed the mirror surface with his fingernail,

Xu Qinglang stopped patting,

But his reflection in the mirror,

Was still diligently and meticulously patting its face,

Showing no sign of stopping.

"Slap, slap, slap..."

---
*Jiānghú (江湖): Literally "rivers and lakes," refers to a wandering, vagabond lifestyle, often associated with martial arts, vagrants, and outlaws.

title: 第一百七十七章 躲貓貓的遊戲
content:
So, when you have nothing to do, don't always look in the mirror;

This habit is really bad.

Because you don't know,

Is the person in the mirror truly your reflection, merely mechanically following your every move;

Or,

Is he just treating you like a fool, playing with you, silently chuckling and snickering behind your back when he sees you haven't discovered his existence yet?

The one in the mirror stopped patting his face after about seven or eight seconds. He stood in the mirror, initially still trying to imitate Xu Qinglang's current posture.

But then he thought,

Looking at Zhou Ze and Xu Qinglang's expressions, he knew it would be meaningless to continue feigning.

Before, he had treated others as fools, applying skincare products with a man, smacking his face, and found it very amusing. Now, continuing the act would be treating himself as a fool.

He quietly retreated, his figure shrinking further and further away, smaller and smaller. He wanted to leave this place.

Zhou Ze believed that even police academies, when teaching methods for apprehending criminals, wouldn't teach how to catch a criminal who hides in a mirror.

But now, he faced this very problem.

First, breaking the mirror was impossible; the person inside probably wished for him to do so. But to enter the mirror?

Zhou Ze reached out to try; his hand couldn't penetrate it. Evidently, this attempt failed. Of course, Zhou Ze hadn't held much hope to begin with.

If mirrors could really be penetrated by just anyone, then the number of children who accidentally fell into mirrors and went missing each year would definitely be far greater than those who drowned swimming in rivers.

That jerk in the mirror became smaller and smaller as he ran. He even turned his head with interest and made a "throat-slitting" gesture towards Zhou Ze and the others, truly arrogant.

"Heaven's ultimate infinity, profound heart's righteous law!"

Xu Qinglang formed a hand seal, and a heart-protecting mirror was slapped directly onto the mirror surface.

It must be said that Old Xu, whether in his hand seal motion or the way he took out the heart-protecting mirror, was impeccable, exuding the air of a profound mystic. But after the heart-protecting mirror was applied, the person in the mirror merely tilted his head, seemingly still smiling. Clearly, Old Xu's method was ineffective.

"Old Daoist, your crotch!"

Zhou Ze shouted.

Old Daoist instinctively reached for his crotch,

And then,

He actually pulled out another talisman!

Bear in mind, Old Daoist wasn't wearing his robes now, but a bathrobe! This meant that after changing clothes, Old Daoist had transferred the talisman with him!

"By the swift decree of the Grand Pure Old Lord, listen to my command, Buddha of the West!"

Muttering a rather nonsensical incantation, Old Daoist directly pressed his talisman onto the mirror.

The talisman glowed red for a moment, and the image in the mirror twisted. The person inside seemed to emit a faint cry of pain, but he still didn't come out. And perhaps because he was stimulated by the talisman, he, who had originally intended to stay and show off, now genuinely began to prepare his escape.

"Any more?" Zhou Ze urged Old Daoist.

He refused to believe that if ten or eight talismans were stuck on this mirror, the fellow inside wouldn't be forced out.

Old Daoist rummaged again, then spread his hand, revealing only a few black, curly hairs in his palm.

Nothing else.

"None left, Boss. Only brought one today."

By now, the person in the mirror was just a small black dot, almost vanishing.

Zhou Ze closed his eyes, spread his hands, and all his fingernails elongated. Layers of black mist began to rise from his palms. For Zhou Ze, only one method was left to try.

Faced with an irrational situation, it seemed he had to try an irrational approach.

Under the bewildered gazes of Old Daoist and Xu Qinglang, Zhou Ze clasped his hands in front of him and adopted a tug-of-war stance.

In reality, Zhou Ze hadn't grabbed anything, but he was pulling backward as if he really held something, and he was pulling quite strenuously.

Is it really that exaggerated?

Is your imagination that vivid?

Old Daoist's mouth twitched. He wanted to tell his boss that this method was even less reliable, but then Old Daoist's jaw stiffened, because he saw the guy in the mirror, who had been reduced to just a dot, slowly running back.

Oh my goodness!

Boss actually pulled him back!

Old Daoist suddenly felt he couldn't understand this world anymore. This works too?

"Help me!" Zhou Ze shouted.

Help you?

Xu Qinglang and Old Daoist paused, then joined in, pretending to help Zhou Ze pull. Xu Qinglang felt like he was one of the ministers in "The Emperor's New Clothes," doing something very foolish, but the crucial point was that as he and Old Daoist joined in, the speed at which the guy in the mirror retreated actually increased!

"If you believe in your heart you can pull him back, you can. He's in the mirror, but in reality, he's more in our eyes," Zhou Ze said something very philosophical.

The mirror's function is to reflect light; it merely acts as a medium. Rather than saying there's something in the mirror, it's more accurate to say there's something in one's eyes.

Of course, this involves many philosophical arguments, and going into detail would be too troublesome.

As they pulled, the person in the mirror slowly returned to the same size as Xu Qinglang had been when he was applying skincare products.

He's about to be pulled out,

He's coming out,

Pull harder!

A little more force!

Almost out!

Old Daoist shouted by the side, chanting a work song. Vaguely, he seemed to return to his days as a porter on the dock. But as he chanted, it sounded more like three grown men acting as midwives.

Finally, a corner of the object in the mirror's clothing appeared.

But then,

With a crisp "crack," the mirror suddenly exploded.

Then, a black shadow darted out from within. Perhaps Zhou Ze and the others were too engrossed, as all three fell backward simultaneously, as if the rope in a tug-of-war had suddenly snapped.

This made Zhou Ze smile wryly. When he quickly stood up, realizing he needed to catch the black shadow, he found he had already lost the initiative.

Zhou Ze's fingernails had only snagged the opponent, and after a pained shriek came from within the black shadow, it actually shrunk again, escaping Zhou Ze's grasp.

Then it burrowed into another glass door in the bathroom.

Only this time, it seemed unable to fully penetrate, with a part of it still outside, like a blood leech. This might have been due to its injury, affecting its performance.

Zhou Ze's fingernails swept past, and the glass door shattered. The black shadow let out another shriek and fled again, like a wild rabbit, moving very fast.

"Don't let him escape! He can only hide in reflective surfaces. You two go look, I'll trap him first!"

Zhou Ze plunged his fingernails into the ground, and black qi immediately spread out, completely enveloping the small villa. Zhou Ze had done this before when facing the water python's attack, but that time was for self-preservation; this time was an active containment.

Meanwhile, Old Daoist and Xu Qinglang rushed out of the bathroom and began searching for reflective surfaces to see if that thing was hiding inside.

The beginning of the matter was unbelievable, but the process was even more astonishing. As for it now directly turning into a game of hide-and-seek, that was something no one had expected.

In truth, it was fundamentally because Old Daoist and Xu Qinglang were living people. Living people in this world abide by birth, old age, sickness, and death; there's science, reason, and laws to be followed. Thus, their perspective was sometimes not as broad as Zhou Ze's.

For someone who had been to hell, nothing was unacceptable, and nothing was impossible.

The search process was difficult and complicated, because there were too many reflective objects here. Checking them one by one, while also guarding against the opponent moving, even though Zhou Ze had confined the range to this small villa, it was still not a simple task to truly ferret out that thing.

Old Daoist searched around, found nothing, and had no leads. He felt like he was going crazy, his mind filled with glass, wishing he could turn into glass himself.

Xu Qinglang searched around too and found nothing. They also didn't dare to ask Zhou Ze if he had truly stopped that thing, what if it wasn't in the villa and had already escaped?

"Oh, right, the hot springs!"

Old Daoist ran to the edge of the hot springs. The water in the hot spring pool had been drained, but there were still several puddles of standing water. These could also reflect light, and act as mirrors!

Old Daoist jumped into the hot spring area, searching puddle by puddle, but still found nothing.

Feeling somewhat exhausted, Old Daoist simply sat down at the bottom of the hot spring.

Can't find it,

That thing can burrow into mirrors. Who knows where it went now. Amitabha, Immeasurable Heavenly Venerable, merciful Lord, please show your divine power and let this humble Daoist find him.

Zhou Ze in the bathroom was close to collapsing, constantly yelling from inside the bathroom, asking if they had found it.

This increased Old Daoist's pressure.

Damn it, if only I could call the police and ask them to help find someone, Old Daoist thought wildly, then he suddenly froze. He pulled his phone from his pocket.

A phone screen is also a mirror, it can also reflect light!

And it's been on him all along, the easiest place for a "lamp under black" situation!

Old Daoist immediately pressed the phone screen; it lit up. Originally, Old Daoist's wallpaper was the classic photo of Marilyn Monroe's skirt blowing up, but now, beneath Marilyn Monroe's skirt on the screen, a black shadow had appeared, like a layer of pixelation, and it was wriggling.

Old Daoist was so happy that a bubble formed at his nose.

He was very excited,

And immediately reached out to grab that "pixelation," muttering excitedly:

"Amitabha, this humble Daoist has finally found you, hehehe!"

title: 第一百七十八章 血崩！
content:
"Amitabha, this humble Daoist has finally found you, hehehe!"

After saying this, the old Daoist began to rub vigorously on the screen with his hand. This thing had been injured by Boss Zhou before, and now even when it burrowed into a mirror, it wasn't as nimble as it used to be. The boss had been able to smash mirrors to force it out, and the old Daoist felt he could do the same.

But as he rubbed, the old Daoist suddenly froze. He recalled what he had just said and suddenly felt a chill down his spine, then instinctively swallowed.

No way...

This must be a coincidence.

Yes, it was precisely because he had heard the previous words on the phone that they were imprinted in his mind, and he had blurted them out just now.

Yes,

It must be like that.

There was another possibility, one the old Daoist dared not think about, truly dared not.

As he rubbed, a layer of black grime, like the filth from someone who hadn't bathed in a long time, began to accumulate. The old Daoist pinched it with two fingers and pulled hard.

"I found it!"

At the same time, the old Daoist, recovering from his shock, remembered to call for help.

Xu Qinglang immediately rushed over. Seeing the old Daoist pulling something out of the phone, he instantly understood and watched closely from the side, fearing the thing might escape again.

Zhou Ze finally pulled his fingernail out of the ground and let out a long sigh. He used to read wuxia novels or watch TV shows where characters could raise a hand and turn things to ashes, causing mountains to crumble and rivers to reverse. Douzong masters were truly terrifying...

When it was his turn, he realized the gap between fantasy and reality was immense. In just this short time, he was already a bit sore in the back from exhaustion.

The old Daoist pulled the thing out and pressed it firmly with both hands. In fact, you couldn't feel its presence; his hands were perfectly pressed together, as if there was nothing inside.

But there was indeed a sensation stimulating him—that wet, slippery, somewhat chilly feeling that kept telling him there was something in his palm.

"Boss, here you go!"

Seeing Zhou Ze approach, the old Daoist immediately stood up and handed this "hot potato" to Zhou Ze.

Zhou Ze reached out and took it. It was a black ball, no, now it looked like a black rag. But to be safe, Zhou Ze directly pierced it through the middle with his fingernail, like skewering a piece of barbecued meat, because this thing was too good at running and hiding.

Any soul-like creature seemed to be suppressed by Zhou Ze's fingernail. After being pierced by Zhou Ze's fingernail, the thing kept "spinning" and "jumping,"

looking very pained.

"What are you...?"

Zhou Ze hadn't even finished his first question,

when a sound like a balloon popping was heard.

The black thing impaled on his fingertip actually exploded directly, turning into wisps of green smoke.

"..." The old Daoist.

"..." Xu Qinglang.

The old Daoist had ten thousand "motherf*****s" in his heart that he didn't know whether to utter, but a strong survival instinct made him swallow his words. Having deeply mastered the Dao of Prudence, the old Daoist immediately said:

"Boss, this fellow's bones are too hard; he'd rather die than yield."

He wouldn't accuse Zhou Ze of having broken the thing directly, after all their hard work, they hadn't even gotten a single word out of it.

Xu Qinglang took a deep breath. He wanted to curse, but he was too lazy to bother.

"My apologies." Zhou Ze looked a bit sheepish. Everyone had spent so much effort catching this thing, and it had gone wrong in his hands. "I didn't realize it was so fragile."

The three returned to the living room, where the atmosphere was heavy. They had thought a turning point had appeared, and a breakthrough seemed imminent, but with that "pop,"

the whole situation returned to square one.

"Boss, at least we've confirmed one thing: this hotel definitely has something fishy going on!"

The old Daoist said very seriously and earnestly, not at all feeling that he had stated the obvious.

"Should we rest first, or go for another bath?" Xu Qinglang asked.

"Let's rest first. It's almost eight o'clock now. We'll go for another bath around one or two in the morning," Zhou Ze said, checking the time.

The three didn't go back to their rooms to rest but made do by lying on the living room sofa and tatami. Zhou Ze actually wanted to go back to his room to sleep, but Xu Qinglang and the old Daoist clearly didn't want to. The old Daoist, being shameless as ever, insisted on staying with the boss. Although Xu Qinglang said no, his body was very honest.

Being next to Zhou Ze meant there was at least someone who could confront things head-on when something happened, whereas if he were alone, he often became flustered.

The old Daoist didn't mention the words earlier because he thought it might be a coincidence, and he felt a bit uneasy.

Around eleven o'clock, the old Daoist was woken by the need to urinate. He didn't dare go to the bathroom. Firstly, the bathroom was indeed haunted today, and the old Daoist was afraid that while he was relieving himself, the family of three might suddenly appear on the floor looking for their heads, which would scare him impotent.

Secondly, too many horror stories and movies involved accidents happening during urination and defecation. Knowing there was danger nearby, yet insisting on being alone, and bothering with certain things at a critical moment, often led to one's own demise.

So, the old Daoist directly reached for an empty mineral water bottle from the coffee table, preparing to relieve himself right in the living room.

Just as the old Daoist unzipped his pants and was about to "turn on the faucet," he saw Zhou Ze on the opposite sofa watching him with open eyes.

The old Daoist immediately stopped, startled, and said somewhat awkwardly, "Boss, you're awake?"

"I can't sleep," Zhou Ze said.

Only then did the old Daoist realize. Yes, the old Daoist knew that without Bai Yingying, Zhou Ze couldn't sleep at night; he had actually forgotten.

Zhou Ze got up, lit a cigarette, walked to the front of the living room, directly facing the bathroom, and pointed inside. "I'll watch. Go ahead and relieve yourself in there."

Moved,

Incredibly moved,

One hundred, one thousand, ten thousand times moved!

The old Daoist wished he could cry tears. The boss had changed, truly changed, becoming more caring towards his subordinates, more attentive to lonely old people.

Although it seemed a bit late to understand these principles after two lifetimes, it was... worth it!

The boss was actually willing to help him urinate at night!

The old Daoist's inner thoughts were abundant. Of course, it was truly Zhou Ze's unintentional gesture, but for him, the impact was profound.

"Alright, boss."

The old Daoist immediately entered the bathroom.

The door was left open.

Standing by the toilet, the old Daoist could see Zhou Ze in the living room, and Zhou Ze could see him. It felt very secure!

This feeling was absolutely great!

"Boss lights the lamp, illuminating the ghost's home, letting the lost ghost find the way back;

Boss lights the lamp, illuminating the ghost's future, with a bit of light, comforting the ghost's heart..."

The old Daoist was in a good mood, even humming a tune, leisurely pulling out his "faucet," finding the most comfortable angle, and then preparing himself.

Getting old,

The "faucet" inevitably rusted,

So singing now was also to ease the awkwardness. Otherwise, if he stood by the toilet for a long time and the boss didn't hear the sound of water, wouldn't he be very curious?

Just then, Zhou Ze's phone rang. He looked down and saw it was still that unknown number.

The whole incident, in fact, originated from this unknown call. It was like a string, constantly pulling them to this hotel to investigate its affairs.

And indeed, the hotel did have problems, but that feeling of being led by the nose constantly made Zhou Ze very uncomfortable and dislike it greatly.

But no matter what, Zhou Ze still answered the call.

Immediately after,

The phone delivered the somewhat tired phrase:

"Save me... save me... I'm on General Mountain... save me... save me... please... save me..."

It seemed his opening line was always this one.

Zhou Ze felt like swearing. If this guy were in front of him, Zhou Ze would probably walk over and slap him.

Seriously, could he provide some, even slightly, useful information?

"I'm on General Mountain," Zhou Ze replied weakly.

But this time, it seemed different.

Because the voice on the other end of the phone,

seemed to have suddenly learned how to communicate.

He actually changed his usual Xianglin's Wife-like monologue:

"Really...? You've come...? Have you really come...? Really...?"

"Yes, I'm here. Where are you? How can I save you?"

Zhou Ze perked up slightly, a glimmer of hope in his heart.

"Hehe... it's good that you've come... so good... so good... thank you for coming to save me... truly... thank you... I'm very grateful to you... extremely, extremely grateful to you..."

A barrage of thank-yous,

but still not a speck of useful information.

Zhou Ze interrupted the incessant thanking and said directly:

"Tell me something useful, or I'm leaving first thing tomorrow morning."

"Useful things... ah... right... I'm sorry... my mind... it's a bit messed up..."

This was already known.

"Oh... I remember... I remember... how you can save me... oh no... how you can save us..."

"Hurry up."

"That is... you take our place... you take our place here and accept the punishment and suffering... then we... then we can... escape from this sea of bitterness..."

Zhou Ze's eyes narrowed.

Just then,

The voice on the phone suddenly sped up:

"Surprised?

Delighted?

How about,

I pour you some red wine first,

to celebrate?"

Red wine?

Zhou Ze frowned slightly.

At this moment,

The old Daoist, after a long period of preparation, finally released the water,

making a "gurgling" sound.

Just like most people's first action after pooping on the toilet is to look back at the poop they've just produced,

the old Daoist instinctively looked down at himself,

then his face suddenly changed color.

He realized what he had just urinated was,

blood,

bright red blood!

title: 第一百七十九章 鏡中人
content:
Suddenly, a feeling of ground-shaking swept through the surroundings. Zhou Ze instinctively lowered his center of gravity to prevent himself from falling.

But he saw the old Taoist priest in the bathroom still clinging to his faucet, screaming;

Xu Qinglang, on the living room sofa, was still in a deep sleep, seemingly oblivious to anything amiss.

Zhou Ze realized, with a start, that it wasn't actual ground-shaking or an earthquake, but rather a severe distortion of all light and shadows around him, creating the illusion of violent shaking.

Everything reflective seemed to come alive, becoming very active, actively trying to mislead and influence him.

It was an unfathomable feeling, as if at this moment, he was being rejected by the entire environment. They were no longer inanimate objects around him, no longer tools he could pick, choose, or trample upon. Having gained their own consciousness, they instinctively began to repel him, to dislike him.

Zhou Ze opened his mouth, wanting to wake Xu Qinglang, but when he called out, Xu Qinglang continued to sleep on the sofa, as if he hadn't heard anything at all.

No matter how soundly he slept, he couldn't be *that* dead asleep.

"Old Taoist!"

Zhou Ze called out to the old Taoist priest again.

The old Taoist stood in the bathroom, still staring at his faucet and yelling. No matter how Zhou Ze called him, he wouldn't turn around.

Gradually, Zhou Ze noticed the old Taoist's figure twisting, and Xu Qinglang's body, lying on the sofa, also twisting. He felt like he was in a hall of mirrors, where all the light around him was bent, causing an extremely painful visual impact.

Taking a deep breath, Zhou Ze began to close his eyes. He wasn't a novice ghost catcher anymore. In the past six months, he had been through many storms. He knew that in such a situation, the first thing to do was to calm his inner self.

Heart like ice, unfazed by the sky falling!

However, as soon as Zhou Ze closed his eyes, he felt a sudden sensation of weightlessness beneath his feet, as if he was about to fall into a deep abyss.

This feeling often occurred during sleep, a sudden sensation of falling, then the whole person would instinctively twitch and quickly wake up, realizing it was a false alarm.

But for Zhou Ze at this moment, this feeling lasted for a long time, and it grew more intense.

Zhou Ze could only choose to open his eyes, and the moment he reopened them,一道道 white light suddenly burst forth, their brightness like a car suddenly turning on its high beams at night.

After a moment of dizziness and blindness, when Zhou Ze's vision returned to clarity, he found himself still standing in the living room.

Everything around him was unchanged, as if everything that had just happened was merely an illusion that didn't count, a fleeting mirage. But soon, Zhou Ze realized something was wrong.

The sofa was still the same sofa, but Xu Qinglang on it was gone.

The bathroom was still the same bathroom, but the old Taoist priest who was urinating blood in it was also gone.

The furnishings were all there, everything was unchanged, but he was the only one left here, and only he.

Zhou Ze took a deep breath. The light was on, but its brightness was clearly insufficient, even very low, making everything feel dim.

He walked into the bathroom and, through the cracked mirror still on the wall, Zhou Ze suddenly saw the figures of the old Taoist priest and Xu Qinglang.

The old Taoist priest was leaning against the wall, looking terrified, with blood all over him. Xu Qinglang was next to him, watching over him, also seeming to comfort the old Taoist.

Were they in the mirror?

Zhou Ze was a bit stunned. Then, Zhou Ze saw Xu Qinglang helping the old Taoist priest leave the bathroom, and he couldn't see them anymore.

"Hey! Can you hear my voice?"

Zhou Ze called out, but there was no response. Afterward, Zhou Ze exited the bathroom and walked into the living room. There was a large picture frame in the living room with an oil painting of Eight Steeds. From the mirror, Zhou Ze saw the old Taoist priest sitting on the sofa in the living room, and Xu Qinglang bringing him a glass of water.

Immediately after, Xu Qinglang lit a paper talisman, dissolved it in the water, and handed it to the old Taoist to drink.

The old Taoist, frowning in pain, gulped down the talisman water, then kept exhaling.

Zhou Ze couldn't hear their voices at all, only see their images and movements.

It wasn't until Zhou Ze saw himself in the mirrored scene that his heart sank.

Something,

Had truly turned into an unimaginable situation.

His own reflection on the sofa was just lying there, motionless.

Xu Qinglang and the old Taoist priest occasionally looked at him on the sofa with concerned expressions. Xu Qinglang even used a wet towel to wipe his face, but he felt nothing.

Hoo...

He understood now.

It wasn't that they had unknowingly entered the mirror.

In fact,

The one who had truly entered the mirror,

Was himself!

Zhou Ze tried to scratch the mirror with his fingernails. He instinctively wanted to break this thing and get out, but his usually infallible fingernails were completely useless against this small mirror at this moment. This mirror was as hard as *King Kong*, so solid it was despair-inducing.

After trying for a while, Zhou Ze gave up and sat down on the sofa.

Once seated, Zhou Ze realized that while the furnishings in the room were indeed the same, the arrangements were actually reversed, as things in a mirror are indeed opposite to reality.

He reached out and felt, discovering that his cigarettes were still there. He took a cigarette and put it in his mouth, and was actually able to light it with a lighter. The smoke even had the scent of tobacco.

Zhou Ze didn't know what state he was in. His body was still in reality outside the mirror, but everything here felt so real, unlike a soul leaving the body.

Zhou Ze had experienced the state of a soul leaving the body. It was a very weak and bewildered feeling. But he clearly didn't have that feeling now, which meant he wasn't in a state where his soul had been sucked in.

Zhou Ze remembered that in the afternoon at the restaurant, his fingernails were also useless against those "departed souls." This seemed to imply that he was currently in the same state as those "departed souls" dining in the restaurant?

Not a soul,

Not a physical body,

A... very strange and indescribable state?

This was,

The state within the mirror?

Throughout this night, Zhou Ze mostly sat on the sofa, pondering how to get out, how to leave this place. Zhou Ze also tried to open the door and look outside, but he found that the main door and the walls of the courtyard were all separated by a layer of "glass." He couldn't get out at all, only able to move within this confined area.

So, this night was spent either sitting on the sofa contemplating life, or standing in front of the picture frame, watching the old Taoist priest and Xu Qinglang desperately trying various methods to wake him up.

Actually, what Zhou Ze was most worried about at the moment was whether Xu Qinglang and the old Taoist priest would take his body back to the bookstore in the city center the next day.

Although Zhou Ze's character was quite resilient, he really didn't want to be abandoned by his companions like this, even if his companions probably didn't know that he was actually in the mirror at the moment.

Zhou Ze even tried to fill the hot spring pool with water and soaked in it several times, only to find that even if he submerged his head in the pool, he still couldn't leave this area. Zhou Ze had executed and tried every possible method, and all had failed.

In short, this night was very long, so long that Zhou Ze felt a bit suffocated.

When faint sunlight seeped in from outside, Zhou Ze slowly raised his head,

It's morning, isn't it?

"Crunch... Crunch..."

There seemed to be the sound of something breaking. Zhou Ze stood up, walked to the door, and reached out to open it, finding that a piece of the glass outside had shattered, enough for a person to walk out normally.

This was like a tunnel for children to pass through in an amusement park. Zhou Ze walked in, able to follow only this single path forward, because all around were thin layers of glass. You could see people outside, see the scenery outside, but you just couldn't get out.

No matter how much force you used, you couldn't break even a shred of this glass.

As he walked, Zhou Ze saw a door. The door was open, and Zhou Ze walked in.

Then,

It suddenly opened up.

After walking through the narrow glass tunnel for more than ten minutes, suddenly entering an open area truly felt like a fisherman accidentally discovering a Peach Blossom Spring.

However, what Zhou Ze entered was the restaurant.

A buffet-style layout,

A familiar environment,

It was the hotel restaurant.

"Sir, your room card please."

A voice sounded beside Zhou Ze.

Zhou Ze turned his head to look at her.

It was a server, but her mouth was above her eyes, and her entire facial features were inverted, giving a very eerie feeling.

Zhou Ze didn't move.

The other party reached out, and a room card appeared from his own person.

"Hello, enjoy your meal," the server smiled.

This smile was the most unsettling smile Zhou Ze had ever seen in his life. Picasso probably couldn't paint such an effect either.

The restaurant wasn't very crowded, but as Zhou Ze sat down, more and more guests came in to dine, exactly like the scene from yesterday.

The only difference was that yesterday Zhou Ze was an observer, this time, he was in the game.

He didn't go to get food, just sat down in the same spot as yesterday. If this was the case, Zhou Ze really wanted to look forward to seeing if Xu Qinglang and the old Taoist priest would also come through the hot spring pool.

He didn't wait for Xu Qinglang and the old Taoist priest, but Zhou Ze first saw the family of three. They also sat down in the same spot as yesterday, with the little girl sitting first, and her parents going to get food.

Then,

The headless family of three collectively stared blankly at the dazzling array of food in front of them.

"Hi, hello again," Zhou Ze said, with a hint of gallows humor.

However,

The family of three, who had been unable to communicate before, suddenly all turned their bodies toward Zhou Ze.

They had no heads,

So logically, they couldn't speak, especially since they couldn't eat,

But they made a sound, collectively,

Though it was just one simple word:

"Hi."

------

PS: Starting today, Long will be participating in a "Network Writer" grassroots charity event, going to poverty-stricken mountain areas. It's estimated to take over a week. Long will try his best to ensure updates;

Of course, if there are unexpected circumstances preventing timely updates, Long will post a single chapter to inform everyone in advance.

Don't panic,

Hold onto Long!

title: 第一百八十章 洗白白！
content:
That "Hi" carried a great deal of dark humor.

People often assume that ghosts are filled with immense resentment and a hysterical, profound sense of bitterness; this is a common preconceived notion.

Zhou Ze used to think so too, until he himself became a ghost.

How much difference is there, really, between ghosts and humans?

In terms of malevolence,
Humans fear the terror of ghosts, ghosts know the venom of human hearts;
In other aspects,
Ghosts originate from humans, and in many ways, whether in personality or senses, they actually have a deep sense of identification with humans.

The only difference might be that ghosts, most of the time, resemble the extreme character of "desperadoes" or "fugitives." It's hard for them to linger in the human world for too long. Even if there are some accidental circumstances where they don't descend to hell, and the *guichai* haven't discovered them yet, residing in the human world is more like a rat hiding in a sewer.

Humans fear ghosts, but in this world, there are too many things that can harm and subdue ghosts.

For example, an old Daoist priest's crotch.

Zhou Ze reached up, touched his head, and yawned. The suppression of the whole night before seemed to have dissipated quite a bit now. For someone who had already walked the Yellow Springs Road, there was nothing left to be hung up about.

To go back, to return to his own body, to his original life—of course, that was his desire.

But for now, without a way to achieve that, there was no need to be overly anxious or troubled.

"Can you tell me now, who killed you?" Zhou Ze asked.

The family of three was still looking at him,
Then,
Silence.

The feeling of being "stared at" by three headless people was truly unsettling.

Even Boss Zhou was a bit uncomfortable now.

*Ding-dong*...

Next to Zhou Ze, there was the crisp sound of a spoon hitting a plate. Zhou Ze turned around and saw a beautiful young girl sitting beside him, seemingly about to start her meal.

The girl turned her head and glanced at Zhou Ze—oh no, she was actually looking at the family of three over there, giving them a gentle nod.

Well,
Zhou Ze felt a bit sad and weary.
It turned out she was greeting someone else through him, and he had misunderstood. That was indeed quite awkward.

Then,
The family of three sat up straight again, staring blankly at the food in front of them.

The girl, meanwhile, ate unhurriedly. She ate very elegantly; it wasn't a constrained or overly prim way of eating. In fact, she ate quickly, but it conveyed a unique kind of grace.

Zhou Ze just watched the young lady eat.

Fortunately, the old Daoist priest and Old Xu were still anxious about Zhou Ze not waking up, and hadn't thought to come back through the hot spring pool to check. Otherwise, if they had seen Zhou Ze staring intently at the eating girl as if nothing were wrong, they might really have fallen ill from anger.

The girl finished her meal, drank the last bit of milk from her cup, wiped her mouth with a tissue, and then stood up, seemingly preparing to leave.

Zhou Ze also stood up and followed her, like a loitering pervert.

It wasn't that Zhou Ze was interested in her in any particular way. In this environment and state, Boss Zhou wasn't so despairing as to stoop to that level. It was because, in Zhou Ze's eyes, this girl was very different from the other people in the restaurant.

While the other diners in the restaurant could eat, their movements felt no different from the headless family of three.
Numb,
Lifeless,
With a musty scent like an old woman's bound feet.

But this girl radiated a sense of life. She seemed to possess a higher degree of... freedom in this environment, just like him.

Zhou Ze followed her out of the restaurant. To his surprise, he and she were walking along a glass passageway.

It was like a beehive, intricate and complex, with each bee having its own place.

Zhou Ze continued to follow behind the girl. The two walked slowly, one after the other.

As they walked, the girl stopped. She seemed to have only just noticed Zhou Ze.

The girl turned her head and smiled at Zhou Ze, a very pure smile.

"Kon'nichiwa." (Hello)

The girl bowed slightly to Zhou Ze.

Japanese?

Zhou Ze's first thought was of his own Spider-Man.

"Hello."

Zhou Ze responded.

Zhou Ze understood such simple Japanese, but he still replied in Chinese.

"Hello," the girl replied again in Chinese.

Afterward, the girl continued to walk forward, and Zhou Ze continued to follow.

The brief exchange and greeting seemed more like an insignificant interlude, like a pebble thrown into a calm lake, quickly restoring its tranquility after causing a ripple.

They walked all the way to the lawn outside the room door, where Zhou Ze saw the girl turn in another direction.

So,
She was his neighbor.

The layout of this hot spring villa hotel was such that a single detached villa was divided into two for use, sharing a single wall.

This explained why the girl and Zhou Ze's "walking" routes were the same. However, at this point, they had to part ways. Zhou Ze also tried walking in the girl's direction but was blocked by a thin layer of glass.

Giving up the struggle, Zhou Ze returned to his room.

He sat down in the living room, lit a cigarette, then stood up and walked to the picture frame to look. In the mirror, he was still lying on the sofa, Old Daoist priest was dozing beside him, and Xu Qinglang was on the phone, seemingly contacting someone.

Zhou Ze guessed he was contacting Bai Yingying at the bookstore, or perhaps the little loli. After all, his unresponsive state in reality, where he couldn't be woken no matter how much they called, was truly incomprehensible and difficult for Old Xu and the others to handle.

This feeling of being cared for was quite nice. Of course, the feeling of peeping was also quite nice.

Zhou Ze stretched, flicked off the cigarette ash. Just then, he heard the sound of the hot spring pool filling up from next door.

The courtyard was actually divided into two as well, with each side having a hot spring pool. The sound of the water filling was loud enough for the other side to hear.

Zhou Ze walked into the courtyard and sat down in a wicker chair.

This was unavoidable. In the world within the mirror, you were lonely, essentially a prisoner, only allowed to go to the dining hall at specific times along specific routes and then return to your cell.

Of course, he could also peep through the mirror to see what Xu Qinglang and the others were doing in reality. But it wasn't *that kind* of movie where he could just watch the visuals without sound. In this situation, he could only peep but not communicate, only stand by and fret. It was truly boring and only made him increasingly agitated.

Now that he had a neighbor next door, listening to her movements was quite nice. Of course, if this neighbor were a large, burly fat man, Zhou Ze probably wouldn't have been interested.

The water was soon ready. Zhou Ze heard footsteps, and even the rustling sound of clothes being taken off.

To only hear and not see was always a defect. And for the sake of not missing any clues, Boss Zhou simply moved his wicker chair against the wall and stood there.

There was also a thin layer of glass on top of the wall, preventing entry and stopping you from crossing the line. But it couldn't stop you from looking. This thin layer of glass was more like a subtle censor bar, adding a hazy beauty to the image, which was more appreciative... oh no, more *research-worthy* than a simple, crude one.

Zhou Ze held a cigarette in one hand and gripped the wall with the other, peering inside.

The girl had already entered the hot spring pool, and she began to sing, a melancholic Japanese song. Zhou Ze didn't understand the lyrics, but it felt quite good, very pleasant to listen to.

Slowly, Zhou Ze turned around, no longer looking inside, but leaning his back against the wall.

For some reason, Zhou Ze heard a sense of loneliness in the girl's singing, not the loneliness of an unfaithful wife, but the loneliness of being confined here for a long time.

Zhou Ze even thought that perhaps the other people in the restaurant, at first, were just like him: wanting to get out, wanting to question, wanting to do something. But slowly, they were tormented into numbness by this day-after-day prison life, becoming like the family of three.

Would he,
Too, have this day?

*Whoosh*...

The girl finished singing and began to wash herself, wiping her body with a bath towel. Zhou Ze could hear the sound of the water, and even the girl's breathing.

Because the distance was truly too close, both hot spring pools were actually built against the wall, so the girl and Zhou Ze were truly just separated by a wall.

"What's your name?" Zhou Ze asked.

A pervert who had been peeping at someone bathing, brazenly speaking, asking for her name.

"Tsukino Saori."

The girl replied.

She had actually noticed Zhou Ze's peeping long ago.

"And you?" the girl asked.

"Xu Qinglang."

"A very pleasant name," the girl said.

"Mm," Zhou Ze agreed.

"Did you also die near here?" the girl asked again.

"Die?"

"Yes, die."

"Are you already dead?" Zhou Ze asked.

"Haven't you died yet?" the girl seemed a little confused, then added, "Or perhaps, Mr. Xu, you just haven't realized that you've actually been dead for a long time?"

"I've been dead for a long time, a very, very long time ago," Zhou Ze replied. "Can you tell me how you died?"

"I'd rather not answer that question." The girl refused.

"But I really want to know. Anyway, we don't have anything else to do right now, do we?" Zhou Ze tempted.

"We can take a bath," the girl said very seriously.

"Take a bath?"

"Yes, we can soak in hot springs every day, take baths, and wash every part of our bodies, thoroughly, cleanly.

People should be clean, no matter when, no matter what the situation, they must be clean, and it's essential to be clean."

As a man with a cleanliness obsession, Zhou Ze actually felt some resonance upon hearing the girl's words.

The girl truly stopped chatting with Zhou Ze. She began to seriously scrub her body, that is, to clean herself.

Zhou Ze felt she was washing excessively clean. He could clearly hear the sound of the bath towel vigorously rubbing against her skin. It must have, hurt, right?

A moment later,
The girl spoke proactively, "Mr. Xu, can you do me a favor?"

"Speak."

"One of my legs,
Is in the pool on your side.
Could you help me,
Wash it clean?"

————————

There was a small earthquake in Sichuan, which made the original route impassable, so we had to take a detour. Therefore, for most of this time, Long could only be on the bus. Today, we visited and comforted two primary schools in Liangshan, then rode the bus from afternoon until evening to reach the hotel. As a result, this week's updates can only be squeezed out of time, as it's really impossible to type on a laptop on the bumpy mountain roads.

This is the first update, there will be a second one shortly.

title: 第一百八十一章 不玩？
content:
The Bookstore was as deserted as ever. Of course, if it ever became lively, that would truly be a ghost sighting.

After receiving a call from Xu Qinglang, Bai Yingying immediately changed her clothes. As she locked the store door, preparing to leave, she saw Spider-Man sitting alone inside. She frowned slightly, then reopened the door and walked back in, speaking to the silent Spider-Man:

"Hey, the boss is in trouble. Come with me to help him."

Spider-Man looked up at Bai Yingying, then silently stood up. He only listened to Zhou Ze, but that didn't mean he had no intelligence whatsoever.

Taking him out of the store, Bai Yingying locked the door. Just then, a taxi drove up, and the little loli was sitting in the front passenger seat.

After Bai Yingying and Spider-Man got into the car, the driver looked at the passengers and smiled, saying:

"You're like... what are they called? Oh, cosplay enthusiasts, right?"

Bai Yingying didn't answer.
The little loli didn't answer.
The Priest couldn't possibly answer.

The driver was awkward, and then suddenly felt very cold in his car. He looked down and saw the air conditioning wasn't on.

"Let's go, driver, to General's Mountain," the little loli urged.

She was in a very bad mood because Zhou Ze was constantly getting into and causing trouble. She just hoped Zhou Ze could steadily rack up achievements and become a patrol inspector, and then she would be free.

In fact, she had always thought Zhou Ze was someone who knew his place, whether before or after she was subdued by him. The little loli maintained this view.

Because he was so lazy, practically indistinguishable from a salted fish, but how could this salted fish get into so much trouble?

First, the Prefect's ID, then Lady Qingyi, followed by the Book of Yin and Yang, then the Priest, and now, he'd gone to General's Mountain and gotten himself "unconscious."

The little loli took a deep breath. Dealing with a bailiff like this was really troublesome.

"Is there a way to solve the boss's problem?" Bai Yingying asked the little loli.

The little loli smiled. "I just received a call. That noodle shop guy is only a half-baked mystic. His description can't provide much valuable information. I need to go to the scene to make a conclusion, but one thing is certain: a person like your boss, without you and without a freezer, he can't even sleep, so how could he be in an unconscious state? Especially without any external injuries."

Bai Yingying frowned slightly upon hearing this, saying, "No matter what, we have to wake the boss up."

"I'll do my best," the little loli pouted.

"If the boss doesn't wake up, you'll be buried with him."

Upon hearing this, the little loli's expression hardened. She whispered, "At this point, threatening me is pointless."

The driver listened to a little girl and a young woman bickering. Although he couldn't understand what they were saying, he found it quite interesting. He wanted to interject, but it seemed he wasn't part of the cosplay crowd, so it was hard to find common ground.

However, the driver found an opening. "Are you going to General's Mountain for tourism? I heard there was a murder case there recently."

The little loli was silent.
Bai Yingying was silent.
The Priest continued to be silent.

The driver felt even colder, so cold he didn't even want to drive. His feet started trembling.

This was normal, considering the driver hit the jackpot today, picking up three passengers: one a ghost messenger, one a zombie, and one also a corpse. How could it not be cold?

An average taxi driver would be spooked if they drove to a funeral home or cemetery at night and saw a blurry white shadow in the distance. But he'd hit the grand slam, achieving the peak accomplishment of "taxi driver sees ghosts!"

"General's Mountain, what a great place. Do you know the origin of General's Mountain?" The driver still wanted to talk. He had to talk; he was freezing and puffing out breaths.

"What's its origin?" Bai Yingying asked.

Perhaps because Bai Yingying initiated the conversation, and she deliberately reined in her malevolent aura, the driver suddenly felt the temperature rise. It wasn't Bai Yingying's fault; she only "ooh-ooh-oohed" for Zhou Ze. When facing others, she was truly icy cold. Especially after the boss got into trouble, Yingying wasn't in a good mood either.

"Cao Ding, do you know him?" the driver asked.

"Who is he?" Bai Yingying asked.

"A famous general who fought against Japanese pirates. Of course, he couldn't compare to Qi Jiguang, but he was still very formidable. He was a local from Tongcheng. During the Jiajing era of the Ming Dynasty, the Japanese pirates were causing a lot of trouble, and our Tongcheng is near the mouth of the Yangtze River, so many pirates came here. He led his troops to repel the pirates several times, but he died heroically in battle at the age of forty-four."

"Oh," Bai Yingying nodded.

The little loli, however, suddenly became interested. "What's the connection between General's Mountain and Cao Ding?"

"It's named after him. There's also a scenic spot on General's Mountain called Wako Tomb, which is dedicated to him. At that time, the Japanese pirates were burning, killing, and looting their way here. Cao Ding defeated them and pursued them to General's Mountain, where an accident happened, and he sacrificed himself. Originally, General's Mountain wasn't called that, and Cao Ding's official rank wasn't high, but the people of Tongcheng were very grateful to him, so they called that mountain General's Mountain, and it has remained so ever since."

The little loli licked her lips, deep in thought.

About an hour later, the car finally reached the foot of General's Mountain. The little loli paid and got out first.

When Bai Yingying got out of the car, she saw the little loli with her hands behind her back, looking up towards the mountaintop, acting like a little adult.

"See anything?" Bai Yingying asked.

"The problem is I didn't see anything," the little loli frowned. "That's the strangest part, because that guy surnamed Xu said they saw ghosts, and many of them, at the hot spring hotel on the mountaintop, but it's very calm here, not a trace of malevolent aura.

I think your boss must be as confused as I am. There are clearly ghosts, yet it's calm."

"Why?"

"Didn't you hear what the driver said earlier? This is where heroic souls sacrificed themselves. They've received generations of incense offerings from the local people. In this place, even if evil spirits appear, they will be suppressed heavily. Even you and I will feel some suppression."

"Then the boss, he...?"

"Probably not. Although your boss is a ghost, he shouldn't be directly targeted. Moreover, five hundred years have passed since the Jiajing era. Even the most powerful heroic souls can't sustain themselves for that long. People are always forgetful."

"Let's go to the hotel first and see what's wrong with the boss."

Bai Yingying said, then walked directly up the mountain.

The little loli followed behind, and the Priest walked last.

However, as they walked, the Priest suddenly stopped. His slightly hunched body slowly straightened, and a faint green light emerged from the head covering over his eyes.

The little loli turned her head to look at the Priest, somewhat worriedly asking, "He won't lose control, will he?"

Bai Yingying shook her head firmly, saying, "Impossible. He's not his old self. You're not a zombie, so you don't understand that feeling we zombies have.

I can tell you with absolute certainty that in this life, he will never betray the boss."

The Priest's gaze darted around, as if searching for something, or as if something was calling to him.

Meanwhile, Bai Yingying and the little loli felt nothing at all.

"Is something there?" Bai Yingying asked the Priest.

The Priest looked bewildered, spreading his hands as if not knowing how to describe it. Since Zhou Ze brought him back to the Bookstore, he hadn't said a single word.

Communicating with Zhou Ze was simple for him, but communicating with others was very difficult.

"What exactly is wrong?" Bai Yingying pressed.

The Priest remained bewildered, but he mechanically bent down and picked up two stones, one large and one small.

The small stone was placed on top of the large stone.

Then, the Priest reached out and squeezed the small stone on top.

With a "snap," the small stone instantly pulverized.

The debris slowly slipped through the Priest's fingertips.

Then, he looked at Bai Yingying and the little loli, as if to see if they had understood.

"Oh..." The little loli opened her mouth, making a sound.

"What does that mean?" Bai Yingying looked at the little loli.

"Oh... I didn't get it either," said the little loli.

"..." Bai Yingying.

The Priest scratched his head, seemingly thinking about how to express himself.

"Forget it, let's go find your boss first," the little loli said, not wanting to waste any more time. She turned and walked up the mountain. Bai Yingying glanced at the Priest and followed.

The Priest, still bewildered, continued to follow behind them.

The Priest walked steadily, but with every step, he left a footprint below. At the same time, he unconsciously shook his head, like an ox trying to shoo away annoying flies.

...

"Hey, I've wiped this leg clean for you. Not bad, a leg for years of enjoyment."

Zhou Ze held the girl's leg, waving it towards the wall.

Earlier, the old Taoist priest had retrieved a leg from the pool water in the hot spring illusion. It was the very same leg Zhou Ze now held.

"Do you want to play with it?" the girl next door asked.

"Sorry, I was just joking. After all, we're both dead, there's no joke we can't take."

"I'm asking you... do you want to play with it?" the woman pressed again.

"No."

Zhou Ze looked at the leg in his hand and refused.

The moment Zhou Ze refused, hot water, not hot spring water but boiling, bubbling blood, began to surge into Zhou Ze's hot spring pool.

The blood quickly filled the hot spring pool, like a pot of boiling Chengdu hotpot, fiery and scalding.

Indeed, there were things churning inside as if being cooked.

It was another leg.
It was an arm.
It was a torso.
It was a neck.

Sections of dismembered corpses continuously churned within.

She had arrived.
She had leaped past the glass barrier.
From next door, she had come to Zhou Ze!

From within the blood, the head slowly floated up. Her limbs and bones continued to churn around her.

At the same time, she spoke:

"Not playing?"

title: 第一百八十二章 被魔鬼選中的人
content:
"Not playing?"

Facing the girl's question, Zhou Ze was somewhat speechless. Such matters were usually based on mutual consent or a clear transaction of goods for money. He had never heard of forced buying and selling.

You're awesome,
You can cross the line,
You can come from next door into my yard,
But no matter how awesome you are,
Even if I concede ten thousand steps,
With you in this state of being torn into pieces, even if I were just feigning refusal earlier, I wouldn't be able to get aroused now even if I wanted to.

Boss Zhou stroked his forehead, feeling a bit melancholic.

But the girl was clearly filled with immense anger. At this moment, the blood in the hot spring pool actually overflowed, and simultaneously, the girl's originally severed body parts slowly reassembled.

Alright,
The body's reassembled,
It can be used now.
Is that what you mean?
Aren't they all the same with the lights off?
Isn't the most common thing said "you're lying on my hair?"

Chinese parents always teach their children from a young age that being a picky eater is wrong, and they should think about how many peasant uncles in ancient times toiled hard in the fields only to have no money to marry a wife and end up bachelors.

Boss Zhou wanted to concede. If conceding could solve the trouble in front of him, it was best not to resort to violence. After all, from the woman's perspective, she had been so proactive. As a man, no matter the reason for your prevarication, you would always be looked down upon.

But looking at the reassembled girl, the previously severed parts of her body were clearly marked with raised bloody seams, surrounded by dense, crimson patterns, like a painting embroidered by Li Kui. It was truly a sight too gruesome to behold, giving the pure impression of a pieced-together doll.

Sorry,
I refuse.

Zhou Ze stood in place, watching the girl approach him step by step. His fingernails slowly extended.

Then,
The woman drew closer to him.
The surrounding blood rushed towards Zhou Ze like boiling water, truly a grand display.

Zhou Ze spread his arms, his fingernails sweeping to both sides, directly parting the blood. The girl's body was instantly divided into two halves. The poor girl, like a piece of clay, had just managed to reassemble herself only to be cruelly destroyed by Zhou Ze.

If I can't do anything about this glass, can't I do anything about you?

The girl, split into two halves, began to writhe, as if about to rejoin.

Zhou Ze said nothing more, continuing to slice with his fingernails, like cutting vegetables, directly re-dividing the girl. Adhering to his principle of not being too much of a beast, Zhou Ze picked up the two halves of the girl's head and turned to walk into the living room.

Perhaps,
The girl was also shocked.
Such a stunning entrance, such a sharp declaration,
In the end,
She herself was like a dish served up,
And truly cut by Zhou Ze.

The girl's head was placed on the coffee table by Zhou Ze. Zhou Ze lit a cigarette. To be honest, with Zhou Ze's current strength and status, dealing with a small female ghost no longer gave him any thrill.

But there were some questions Zhou Ze needed to ask her, most importantly,
How to get out of this damn mirror world.

After the two halves of the girl's head were put together, they slowly began to merge. Her body outside the living room also started to re-coalesce. The headless body wandered restlessly outside the living room, as if wanting to come in, but also somewhat hesitant.

After the girl's head recovered, it sat squarely on the coffee table, continuing to glare at Zhou Ze, but the anger in her gaze had significantly diminished, replaced by a sense of apprehension.

As the saying goes, a pitiable person must have something detestable about them. The same applies to ghosts.

Boss Zhou had seen countless ghosts and heard many ghost stories of all kinds. He could somewhat guess the girl's experience before her death.

Raped,
And dismembered,
Finally trapped here as a soul in the mirror, that should be more or less correct.

She desperately scrubbed her body, wanting to gain some psychological suggestion and comfort from this action, to make herself feel that her body was still clean.

A pitiable Japanese girl,
This kind of pity knows no borders.

But ghosts are products of extremes. In fact, those who are too detached are not qualified to linger in the human world as ghosts. Those who were "salted fish"<sup>1</sup> their whole lives, always laid-back and stoic, and then died, are all obediently queuing up on the Yellow Springs Road.

From the perspective of a ghost messenger, the ghosts who can linger in the human world are basically troublemakers, like children in class who don't listen and talk back to the teacher.

Therefore, when the girl directs her anger at you, reasoning with her won't work; she won't listen at all.

Last time, when he encountered the vengeful sea serpent, and in many other incidents, Zhou Ze had indeed come across many resentful and wronged souls. However, if Zhou Ze didn't have his fingernails and wasn't a ghost messenger, he might not have even had the right to pity them, only becoming a sacrifice to their anger.

"They... I didn't release them. In fact, I don't even know why I was pulled into this place."

Zhou Ze exhaled a smoke ring towards the girl and continued,

"I told you, I can help you get revenge, provided you tell me the secret of this place and how to leave this cursed place."

The girl continued to stare at Zhou Ze with hateful eyes. Zhou Ze didn't pay much attention, continuing to smoke.

Just wait.

About fifteen minutes later, the headless body of the woman outside slowly sat down. She wrapped her arms around her knees, leaning her back against the floor-to-ceiling window outside the living room, looking very lonely and desolate.

And in the girl's eyes, there was no longer the light of anger; instead, a string of tears flowed down.

Zhou Ze pulled out a tissue from the coffee table, wiped her tears, and comforted her,

"Don't cry. You'll ruin your beautiful face if you cry.
I, Xu Qinglang,
Will be heartbroken."

So, when doing something shady outside, it's very necessary to use your good friend's name.

Like when peeking at a girl bathing,
Or when you've just sliced a girl like vegetables but then pretend to wipe her tears,
Or when a technician gives you a form to rate the "Ice Water Tenderness" project at a club and asks for your signature,
In these moments,
Leaving your own name is very unwise.

"They... they're already gone."

The girl choked out.

"How many people?" Zhou Ze asked.

"Three, three people."

"Oh." Zhou Ze nodded. "Then how did they die?"

If the girl was killed by those three people, then how did those three people die?

It couldn't be that the killed girl immediately turned into a vengeful ghost and successfully got her revenge, right?

If she had succeeded in her revenge, she wouldn't still harbor such immense resentment.

"They were chosen by the devil." A hint of confusion flashed in the girl's eyes. "They were chosen by the devil..."

"You can be more specific. We're not writing poetry," Zhou Ze reminded her.

"It's the devil, it's the devil, it's the devil!!!"

"Alright, it's the devil, it's the devil," Zhou Ze said, somewhat resigned. "Anything else? It's best if you tell me everything you encountered from the time of your incident and afterward in detail."

Zhou Ze reached out and rummaged, pulling out his ghost messenger badge, and waved it in front of the girl,

"You can think of me as a police officer."

The girl's gaze began to scan her surroundings.

Zhou Ze also looked around and asked, "What's wrong?"

"This place is enveloped by mirrors, and mirrors can not only reflect the present but also remember the past."

"How can I see it?"

Tears continued to drip from the corner of the girl's eyes, but this time, the tears evaporated in mid-air before falling, creating a hazy, colorful halo, and even the surrounding glass reflected an unusual light.

This felt like being in a movie theater; everything around them seemed to be covered in a fresh layer of white dust, tinted with an unreal haziness.

What surprised Zhou Ze most was that he could actually hear sounds. The mirrors here didn't just record images.

On the sofa in front of Zhou Ze sat a man with a buzz cut, under thirty, smoking a cigarette with his feet propped up on the coffee table.

This was an image, recording past events.

"Clang!"

The door was heavily shut.

Two more men walked in. These two looked younger, perhaps in their mid-twenties. They were carrying two large plastic bags. One wore a baseball cap, and the other had long hair, giving off an artistic vibe.

The baseball cap man and the long-haired man sat opposite the buzz-cut man. Both put their bags beside them.

The baseball cap man pointed at the buzz-cut man, who was smoking in silence, and said to the long-haired man beside him with a laugh,

"What did I tell you? His home team lost today. He's definitely in a bad mood and getting angry by himself, hahaha..."

"Laugh your ass off, just keep laughing!
We could've won against Jiangsu today, damn it!
Their Jinling home field was just cursed today. We hit the goalpost several times, and they just took a casual swing and it went in. It's infuriating."

The buzz-cut man directly cursed at the baseball cap man. Clearly, he was indeed in a very bad mood.

"It's just that the team lost. What's the big deal? Real Madrid and Barcelona lose too, don't they?"

The baseball cap man said indifferently. Then, he opened his bag. "Come on, let's have our party. I brought the drinks too."

Inside the bag were clothes, which the baseball cap man took out and handed a set to the buzz-cut man opposite him.

The buzz-cut man took the clothes, and all three began to change.

These three sets of clothes were Japanese military uniforms. Having been subjected to various anti-Japanese war films, Chinese people were simply too familiar with these uniforms.

The buzz-cut man adjusted his collar, looked in the mirror, and seemed very satisfied. Then, as if something occurred to him, he said directly,

"Damn it, you guys,
If the Japanese had killed more people in Jinling back then, killed all those idiots, wouldn't my team have won today?
It's best if everyone in Jinling was killed and there were no more teams there. I wouldn't be in such a bad mood today. I was supposed to have a good time at the party with you guys."

The long-haired man nodded and said,

"Exactly! If it weren't for those sneaky Americans back then, we would already be Japanese citizens. Now we still have to be with these Zi-<sup>2</sup>-na bastards,
Just thinking about studying with them before and having to work with them now makes me sick."

***
<sup>1</sup> "Salted fish" (咸鱼 - xiányú) is a Chinese slang term describing someone who is listless, unmotivated, and content with mediocrity.
<sup>2</sup> "Zi-" is a partial phonetic translation of "支那" (Zhīnà), a derogatory term for China. The speaker uses a more offensive variant ("支那逼" - Zhīnàbī).
